name: Dennis de JONG
text: Rapporteur. – When I started working as rapporteur for this legal aid directive more than a year and a half ago, I took seriously into account that it would take many years before we had an agreement on it. This was linked to the fact that this is legislation which is at the cutting edge of criminal procedure law and social security, and that is a sensitive area. I think the Commission was well aware of this, because the Commission's original proposals really only extended to legal aid in the case of a European arrest warrant and provisional legal aid in other cases. In a separate recommendation, the Commission had also included rules on, among other things, the quality of legal aid. That was very modest. If we really want to have confidence in each other's legal systems, then that includes trust in each other's legal aid systems. There should be no place for class justice in the European Union. Equal access to justice for everyone, regardless of your income. The right to a lawyer had already been regulated by the EU in a separate directive. Then it made sense to me that in those cases where you are entitled to a lawyer, you also get the right to legal aid, if at least you cannot afford a lawyer yourself.  In addition, I think it is important that certain elements of the recommendation, in particular on the quality of legal aid, should also be included in the directive. The majority in the European Parliament supported this approach and so we entered the negotiations with the Council with an ambitious position. The vote in the Council was quite reticent. Despite good efforts by the Luxembourg Presidency, the differences between the Council and Parliament remained wide. It was thanks to the great commitment of the subsequent Dutch Presidency that we were finally able to agree on a text that was stronger than the original Commission proposals, even though Parliament did not get its way on all points.  The great gain is that legal aid has been arranged in ordinary criminal cases, not in all cases, but in the case of deprivation of liberty and in certain far-reaching investigative methods involving the accused himself. In the case of questioning of the accused, the right to legal aid is guaranteed and, in the case of European arrest warrants, there is a right to legal aid in the executing, but also in the requesting Member State, if necessary. In all cases, the main rule is that an independent body becomes responsible for the addition of a lawyer. Only in an emergency, the police still play a role in this. Member States must also ensure that there is sufficient money for a high-quality form of legal aid.  Is a whole lot going to change in the European Union? This will vary from one Member State to another, but at least all Member States will now have to set up a high-quality legal aid system for people who cannot afford a lawyer themselves. For some Member States, as the securities report we have carried out as Parliament itself, this will be a considerable financial investment. In any case, it means that there can be absolutely no question of the tendency of governments in other Member States where there is legal aid, as in the Netherlands, to then cut back on legal aid.  A large part of the rights that have been in the directive have been derived from the case law of the European Court of Human Rights. The Directive also explicitly refers to key UN instruments, such as the principles and guidelines for access to legal aid, as a guide for the implementation practices of the Member States. This strengthens the power of all these international instruments and makes it easier to monitor their implementation. All in all, I am satisfied with the end result. I am convinced that in practice many people will benefit from it, which is still devoid of a good lawyer. Thanks to the shadow rapporteurs and to the Commission and the Council.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, following the path set out by the Council in its roadmap from 2009, the Commission presented two packages of legislative proposals strengthening procedural safeguards for EU citizens in criminal proceedings. The first was in 2010, on the right to translation and interpretation, the right to information, and the right to access a lawyer. Later, in 2013, we proposed the Directive to strengthen the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial, the Directive on special safeguards for children suspected or accused of a crime, and the Directive on the right to provisional legal aid. And this is the proposal you are going to vote on tomorrow, as the last piece missing from the system of procedural rights. I think we can all agree that there is no point in rights if you cannot really take advantage of them. What is the right of access to a lawyer worth, if you cannot afford a lawyer? In other words, access to justice and a fair trial must not be something which is only for rich people. I would like to thank your rapporteur, Mr de Jong, and the shadow rapporteurs for their dedicated work on this issue, which made an agreement on this directive possible after long and very difficult negotiations. The directive is an important step forward in the construction of an area of justice in the European Union. Today there are large disparities in the way legal aid is provided in the European Union. The directive, once adopted, will significantly strengthen the procedural safeguards for all citizens in criminal proceedings. The scope of the directive covers those situations where legal aid is needed most: when persons are deprived of liberty, during a number of crucial evidence-gathering acts, and in cases of mandatory defence by a lawyer. As proposed by the Commission, legal aid will also be granted at the very early stages of proceedings when persons are most vulnerable, especially during police questioning.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, the rapporteur, Mr de Jong, and the co-rapporteurs deserve congratulations. As the Commissioner, Mrs Jurova, has said, we are moving in the sphere of criminal law and we are talking about the rights of suspects and accused persons, because of the need, thanks to this agreement already enshrined, to adopt a directive that effectively harmonises the laws of the individual Member States.  We all know that the right to legal protection for the suspect and the accused who is in a difficult position and faces the possibility of a custodial sentence must be guaranteed in practice and not only in theory. The Commissioner quite rightly pointed out that the quality of legal protection and legal aid that a suspect or accused person can look forward to in practice often depends on his financial capacity.  The Member State's response to this problem must be to guarantee the right of these persons to financial cover from specific funds. The provisions of the law ensuring the protection of such persons should also be harmonised by the Member States. We know, of course, that these rights, such as the presumption of innocence, are guaranteed not only by the Constitutions of the Member States but also by national law based on international instruments of law, such as the ECHR. We also see in the Member States too many cases of suspects or accused persons who, both in the pre-trial proceedings and in the main proceedings, go to the Court of European Rights on the basis of Article 6 of the ECHR and accuse the Member State in which they are located, whether they are citizens of the Member State or foreigners, of inaction in terms of the protection and protection of their individual rights and, in particular, the rights guaranteed by the Constitutions and by supranational legislation.  Ladies and gentlemen, I know, from my thirty years of experience as a lawyer and indeed in criminal law, that the Member States have rules of law that protect and protect the rights of suspects and accused persons. But what we are seeking today and will be voting on tomorrow is the harmonisation of the laws, so as to preserve the European edifice from the divergences between the Member States in relation to the different levels of protection they provide. It is ultimately in the interests of the rule of law and justice that all citizens of the European Union should be able to look forward to the same protection of their rights.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The European Union is enabling more and more European citizens to live, study and work in another Member State. This, of course, also increases the likelihood that one may be involved in criminal proceedings in a Member State other than one's own. For years, the Council and the Commission – and this is a good thing in principle – have been very ambitious in harmonising and Europeanising law enforcement: the European Arrest Warrant, the Evidence and Investigation Order, instruments for long-term storage or exchange of data, joint investigation teams – to name but a few examples. Harmonisation of procedural rights, however, has long been neglected – to the detriment of citizens involved in criminal proceedings. They face very different standards of protection in the different Member States. Fair procedures for everyone across Europe? Misreporting. Information about my rights in criminal proceedings, translation, the principle of the presumption of innocence, the right to a lawyer. The legal aid directive is now the last of a total of six to strengthen procedural rights in criminal proceedings and, in my view, one of the most important. Why? What good is all the well-worded rights, including the right to a lawyer, if I cannot pay for it at the end of the day and i run the risk of not really being able to exercise my other rights in the proceedings and thus not to receive a fair trial? As Mrs Jourova has already pointed out, fair procedures must not be a question of money. That is another reason why we, as a Parliament, have clearly supported the Commission's proposal and have also developed it further in the negotiations with the Council, with the Member States. For example, the provisional right to legal aid has now become a general right, and in the cases of the European arrest warrant we have been able to enforce that the right to legal aid applies in both the exporting and the issuing Member State. There are also quality standards for legal assistance, and we have also provided for an effective remedy. I now expect the Member States to implement this jointly negotiated directive swiftly and comprehensively. The Commission and Parliament will follow this closely. This is the only way we can finally ensure fair procedures for all citizens throughout the European Union. (The speaker refused to answer a question from Mr Pospil on the blue card procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – This report is intended to ensure a minimum level of legal aid in legal proceedings within the EU. We already have directives on the right to an interpreter or lawyer, whereas this draft law specifically deals with the right to legal aid. We are therefore talking about access to legal information, getting an initial opinion or a referral to a lawyer, free of charge or not.  The text proposed by the Commission was a meageny critter. During the trialogue negotiations, the text was substantially aedentied. I am already satisfied with the increased level of protection. It seems to me, more than normal, that the same minimum level should be maintained throughout the European Union. For example, certain EU Member States do not provide legal aid for people detained under a European arrest warrant. Such gaps are eliminated in the current text.  Finally, it seems to me to be a good thing that such legal aid is only offered if there can be some added value, regardless of the incapacity of the person. In Belgium, this is already the case with regard to the assistance of a lawyer. If he thinks that his intervention has no added value, he can ask the overarching agency to remove him from the case. That seems to me to be a sensible use of taxpayers' money. Therefore, the N-VA will support this proposal.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: ALDE-Fractie namesns. Ik wil eerst en vooral eleven collega De Jong danken voor de bijzondere inspanningen die hij geleverd heeft om in deze kwestie vooruitgang te boeken. The right of access to a lawyer is a fundamental right guaranteed by European legislation. However, as we know, in practice, this right is not matched or rarely accompanied by measures to make it effective. For lack of resources, some people may find themselves alone in the face of the charges against them. Personally, I refuse to endorse a two-tiered justice system. We had to ensure the effectiveness of legal aid systems in the Member States. The European Union had to define a minimum floor to be respected, and the façade systems - I call them "decoy systems" - which exist only on paper, must disappear. This is an absolutely scandalous cynicism. The European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, played a decisive role in the negotiations. Our ambitions have paid off since we have achieved, among other things: first, that common minimum criteria be established; secondly, that legal aid be guaranteed during all criminal judicial proceedings; third, that special attention be given to vulnerable people by taking their specific needs into account; and, finally, fourthly, and this seems important to me, that the police and the prosecutor's office play a very limited role in the appointment of the pro deo lawyer. This is a real victory. It is unacceptable that the police can both investigate a person and, at the same time, make decisions about their defence. I would like to thank the European Commission, which was crucially supported during the negotiations. I would also like to commend the work of the Dutch Presidency and its determination to reach an agreement. Of course, we would probably all have preferred to go one step further, fully aligning the right of access to a lawyer with the right to legal aid. That was not possible. Unfortunately, the legislation is limited to guaranteeing legal aid to situations of deprivation of liberty, but it must be clear that this must include the period of interrogation. Under no circumstances can we accept that people are subject to questions from the police without the right to a pro deo lawyer. We are talking about a fundamental human right. The fact that some Member States still have such a wretched conception of the law is shocking, and it must be reminded of them in all circumstances.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, today's debate is about strengthening citizens' rights and the proper functioning of justice at European level. The possibility of representing the accused is one of the most important aspects of the right to a fair trial, as enshrined both in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and in the European Convention on Human Rights. Particularly in the light of the ongoing economic and social crisis afflicting millions of European citizens, we must ensure that the accused or suspects can be effectively represented before the authorities.  The timely provision of legal aid and the extension of its scope to any Member State where evidence is collected or other investigative acts are carried out are necessary steps. At the same time, the obligation on Member States to ensure the quality and independence of the legal aid provided, together with the existence of legal remedies in cases of violation of this right, will help to safeguard citizens' rights. I therefore believe that the current process can help to improve the position of European citizens while creating a positive climate for intensifying cooperation between Member States.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Finally some good news! We set a European minimum for legal aid, and Parliament - and let me congratulate Dennis de Jong - finally got the Commission and the Council along. We had previously enshrined the right to a lawyer in the law at a first hearing, but what do you have if you are told in a number of Member States: yes, you have the right, but how you are going to pay that right is a second one. Legal aid allows people with little money to represent themselves, and with that our rule of law has improved a little bit.  We are also seeing some improvements in the implementation of the European Arrest Warrant. You are now entitled to a lawyer in the country where you were arrested, but unfortunately not yet in all cases in the country where you are sent. However, this is a significant improvement. Too often we see cases of civilians being handed over for a minor offence or on the basis of a weak suspicion. And where you are at home in your own country, you can wait for a trial by just working through and eventually get a call to report you, you will be placed on remand in another country. We know that pre-trial detention is not done equally neatly in all countries in Europe. You will be placed on remand and say goodbye to your work, to your life and perhaps to your relationship and sometimes say goodbye to your health. So yes, the Greens are happy with this step, and now the next steps.  I would like to warn of two things: further criminal justice harmonisation should not take place at a minimum level of protection, because it erodes national achievements. And a second point is: don't let money be the guiding principle. The costs of proper protection of suspects and victims are often used as an excuse to refrain from improving procedural rights. At a time when European Member States are being rocked by terrorist attacks, we need a well-functioning criminal justice system. So we need to harmonise procedural rights at a good level. Because if we don't, we risk releasing the guilty on administrative grounds and the innocent languishing in pre-trial detention.   (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Honourable Member, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. She said that our decisions must not be limited to the minimum level. However, the Treaty on this matter (Article 82 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union) says that it is on this matter that we are to limit ourself to establishing minimum conditions. It is the treaties that encourage us to make savings. I would like you to explain your view on this matter.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: blue-card answer. – I am always happy to give a colleague the space to make a point, but let me try to understand what you are saying. I think what we have here are minimum standards. What I am pleading for is not to lower our standards to a bare minimum. That is one thing. Secondly, yes, legal aid is costly in countries that do not yet have legal aid, but it is much more costly for society to put the wrong people behind bars. So I would say that, in a European Union that looks across the border to find criminals, we need to look across the border to provide people with legal aid.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – If I am allowed a small comment on this, I would say that the full equality of all people before the law does exclude, from the beginning, minimum standards. All of them should enjoy the same standards. But forgive me – I now give the floor to Ms Ferrara.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the adoption of the directive on admission to legal aid at the expense of the State, the European Union is taking a further significant step towards recognising citizens' right to a fair trial. The extension of the procedural guarantees granted to suspects and defendants is in fact a conquest of civilisation, which unfortunately not all the Member States had transposed uniformly. This was clearly a vulnus to be filled in order to ensure the correct application of the Treaty provisions on judicial cooperation in criminal matters. We very much appreciated the tenacity with which the rapporteur defended Parliament's position in the interinstitutional negotiations, for which I thank him. We are satisfied with the result achieved, in particular the fact that minimum legal aid is guaranteed, at least from a regulatory point of view, in all Member States.  It is also a real success for Parliament, and in particular for its negotiating team, to have obtained in the trialogue the extension of the scope of the directive, with the provision of the right to ordinary legal assistance as well as temporary legal aid. Finally, we hope that, in addition to the timely transposition of the directive in all Member States, there will be a real commitment to finding the financial resources necessary to ensure the effective recognition of the right to legal aid.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Mrs Jourova and the parliamentarians who have just spoken are clearly all in favour of this draft directive, and I regret to have to break this fine consensus. What is it about? This directive aims to ensure access to a lawyer for anyone who is criminally prosecuted. In particular, it is a matter of forcing states to grant legal aid to people who are too poor to pay their lawyer in full.  So, in itself, legal aid is obviously a good system, but states do not need the European Union to impose it. If I take the example of France, know that this system is introduced here by a law of January 22, 1851. That is to say if France is two centuries ahead of you. The European Union's interference in this text is based in particular on Article 47 of the Eu Charter of Fundamental Rights, which provides for precisely this right to legal aid.  But precisely, it is problematic to invoke this charter which, in my opinion, is an extremely questionable instrument. If we are serious about protecting human rights at European level, I believe that the European Convention on the Protection of Human Rights is more than enough. In reality, the charter is a wolf for human rights. It is the ultraliberal wolf in the human rights fold. The justification for interference is given by the directive. The aim, she says, is to "strengthen member states' confidence in the criminal justice system of other Member States". Having said that, I believe that the objective is missed because this interference is taking on such proportions in criminal matters that it is sure to worry the peoples of Europe. You have not learned any lessons from Brexit, nor have you learned any lessons from the Hungarian referendum on 2 October.  You also say that this text is applicable to the European mandate, which is not reassuring. The European mandate is a much less protective system than extradition. Under French law, extradition is not a judge-to-judge procedure, but a procedure involving judges, the investigating chamber, and the government, the decree. This means that the individual has two chances instead of one to escape extradition. In the end, this text is a regression and, in my view, does not mark any progress at all.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, the Commission is proposing a text based on the principle of mutual recognition of judgments and the roadmap to strengthen the financial rights of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings. However, ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States should not be limited to only two categories, namely suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings who are deprived of their liberty and wanted persons subject to procedures relating to the execution of a European arrest warrant. Such a piecemeal approach neither enhances legal certainty nor clarifies the degree and quality of the right to legal aid.  It is a fact that there are differences between The Member States as regards the quality and remuneration of the legal aid provided. However, we believe that horizontal legislation on legal aid and representation will only intensify the problems that already exist and will not lead to a solution.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, many people often find themselves in a situation where they need legal aid, whether as a suspect, accused or requested person. In any Member State, such a person has the right to legal aid, whether provisional or ordinary. Above all, if it does not have sufficient funds to afford it on its own. However, the European Union still has no standards to ensure a minimum level of such legal aid across the States of the European Union. While it is true that there is an improvement in the exchange of information within the European Union, individual states are increasingly trusting each other with regard to the criminal justice system. But the different national procedures still vary widely, causing a number of problems. In particular, legal uncertainty and confusion about the scope of the right to legal aid is the main obstacle that suspects, accused or requested persons must face. Another aspect is the granting of legal aid itself, its financial demands and its quality. I therefore believe that this directive will contribute to the harmonisation of this area and to ensuring adequate legal aid in all Member States.   (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr President, I have listened carefully here to the speeches of my colleague Zdechovský, who agrees with the harmonised criminal procedural law, and I am asked if he thinks that it will be appropriate in the future to harmonise certain provisions of substantive criminal law and to consider a single European Criminal Code.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I thank my colleague, the former Minister for Justice, who has dealt with this issue very intensively. I don't think the discussion is that far away at the moment, and it's never going to be that far. The unification of all criminal rights within the 27, 28 and 28 is not possible, and I think it will never be possible, given the historical experience of individual states and the distinction between the application of criminal law.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking Mr de Jong and the shadow rapporteurs for their efforts over many months of intensive and not easy work that have led to the text we are debating today. Tomorrow's vote closes the circle of measures for suspects and defendants in criminal proceedings that were part of the road map launched by the Commission in 2009, of which the one for children suspected and accused, for which I had the honour of being rapporteur, was also part. I think I can see everyone's feeling that we can be satisfied with the work we have been able to do. We have put a further piece in place for the harmonisation of criminal law, for improving judicial cooperation within the European Union and for strengthening the trust between judicial authorities necessary for mutual recognition.  Apart from these more purely technical aspects, however, I would also like to stress the particular political and social importance of this report, which helps to bridge the major differences between the legal systems. Raising the level of procedural guarantees will help to strengthen the sense of belonging to the Union. Having established minimum standards in the field of legal aid will allow those who, whether investigated or accused, lack sufficient resources to cover the costs of assisting a lawyer anyway thanks to state intervention, in accordance with a principle of justice that leaves no one on the sidelines. Particularly significant, then, is the fact that we have succeeded in broadening the scope, which includes all types of legal aid in criminal proceedings, and also in guaranteeing the right to legal aid for persons subject to proceedings executing the European arrest warrant, both in the Member States issuing the warrant and in the Member States in which it is executed. In the light of my previous professional experience, I can only reiterate that effective legal assistance at all stages of criminal proceedings is an essential guarantee, not only for the protection of the rights of suspects or defendants, but more generally for the conduct of due process in all Member States.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Our decisions on this matter should be rational and cost-effective. We have repeatedly declared cost-effective legislation. I was ready to support the directive as presented by the European Commission, as it was perfectly well founded. I would remind you that, in this original version, the Legal Aid Directive was primarily concerned with the first phase of the proceedings, when the suspect may not yet have a chance to use a lawyer and a European arrest warrant, but then, unfortunately, this regulation was stretched without any grounds, without the treaty grounds, which I spoke about a dozen minutes ago. I would like to remind you that the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides the basis for the establishment of only minimum standards for good cooperation between the police, judicial cooperation and mutual recognition of judgments. On the other hand, it does not give rise to the building of new universal rules on criminal procedure. I believe that we should act sparingly and rationally, above all to show a greater amount of trust in the Member States. The European Union can emerge from the crisis if we restore trust between the European institutions and the Member States.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, King Richard III first introduced a form of legal aid into English courts in about 1485. Now Richard is accused of many crimes, but one thing he never did, to my knowledge anyway, was to surrender an English subject to a foreign jurisdiction purely on the basis of unsubstantiated accusations on a sheet of paper. It took Conservative and Labour governments to remove the requirement for evidence in extradition cases – as now enshrined in the infamous European Arrest Warrant. There is nothing that the European Union can teach the English legal system about anything else, including legal aid, but at least the British Government has chosen to opt out of this directive. Nevertheless, it is good to see that other EU Member States are being required to catch up and to provide legal assistance to those accused in criminal proceedings, and to victims of European arrest warrants. But this must include assistance to those in all receiving Member States. Normally I would vote against EU law, but in this case I am inclined to abstain. It does not affect the UK, but it is good and it is only right and proper that other Member States should go to the trouble and expense of providing legal assistance to those who cannot afford it themselves. When Britain leaves the European Union, then we must repeal the European Arrest Warrant and never again extradite someone unless a British court has first considered the evidence against them and come to the conclusion that there is a proper case to answer.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Dear Commissioner, Honourable Mr President- I congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on a job well done. The Directive on the right to temporary legal aid to persons in criminal proceedings deprived of liberty has been presented by the Commission years ago, as the Commissioner has already said. After difficult negotiations, an agreement was reached between the European Parliament and the Council only during the Dutch Presidency and june this year respectively. As has already been said, this is not the first EU directive on procedural rights, the space of personal security is gradually expanding in the European Union, and that is a good thing. I support the report because it provides common and minimum standards on the right to legal aid to suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings when they have been deprived of their liberty, and free legal aid for persons subject to european arrest warrant proceedings. In my opinion, the originally proposed text of the European Parliament was toooptimistic, as it envisaged extending the scope of this directive to cases where the freedom of persons in the proceedings was not withdrawn. However, not all Member States would be in a way to bear this burden. The text now foresees a more realistic scope and is therefore certainly better. On the other hand, I support extending this directive to the provision of regular, not just temporary legal aid, as this will at least seek to ensure a fair trial throughout the criminal proceedings. This will strengthen member states' mutual trust in the justice systems. A provision providing for the possibility of recovery where abuses by persons who are not entitled to regular legal aid occur is also correct. This procedural rights directive is one step on the road to a fair trial in the European Union, but the implementation of common minimum standards of the rule of law should also be more attentive to the EU when it comes to dubious judicial, sometimes politically motivated, processes in certain transitional countries where even the usual standards of the rule of law have not yet been achieved.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Many positive things have already been mentioned today, and I agree with this: that access to the legal system should not be dependent on solvency, that it should not be made more difficult by national borders and that procedures should be subject to as uniform standards as possible. Parliament has been able to make significant improvements in this area. At a time when the European House is facing severe storms and when the impression is being given that nothing is working, this is a positive sign – a signal that it is possible and that cooperation between the institutions can work if there is the will to do so.  We should also take this example as an example for other areas, and we should, above all, be pleased that the common area of security, freedom and justice, a project as important as the internal market, is now undergoing a substantial upgrade.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! There is something fundamentally wrong about a legal system that must not protect its own citizens but must rely 100% on the legal system of other countries.  It is well known that there are quite large differences between the legal systems of the 28 Member States today, both materially and formally. We may all have signed the same conventions and treaties, but in the real world there is a huge difference in how things are run, from Bulgaria and Romania to Finland, Denmark and the United Kingdom to the Central Continent. That difference is not reflected in the arrest warrant, nor is it after this legal basis has been adopted today. This is not just a problem for the people who are actually affected by the fact that they are being subjected to different treatments in different countries. From a purely traditional European point of view, it is a disaster. It is very non-European. In Europe, it has always been our concern that each country could protect its own citizens. However, this regulatory framework prevents member states from protecting their own citizens. It's not worthy.  I have to say that, with the ridiculous cases we have also seen, where the arrest warrant has been used on charges of having stolen a pig, accusations of having stolen some rear tyres, accusations of having had a few grams of hashish in our pockets, we are far out on a drive where these rules should never have applied. That is why we must at least have a trifle limit on what is required, so that the Member States and citizens have the opportunity to protect themselves from this system of rules, which I think is grotesque.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is about the proposal for EU-wide harmonisation of legal aid, and I do not want to refer to legal aid, but to the Commission's justification for why we should now standardise it across Europe, and I quote the Commission literally: 'The objective pursued by the proposal cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States alone, because the right to provisional legal aid is very different in the EU Member States'. The Commission therefore says that the rules are different, which is why they must be standardised, and that is precisely the termination and repeal of the principle of subsidiarity. Of course, the rules are different, because they are made by different parliaments. Among each of our documents in Europe is the European motto: 'United in diversity'. Let us remember it and stop it with this egalitarianism – get out of it!

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – There are currently major differences in the quality of legal aid offered in the various Member States, and I therefore welcome both the European Commission's proposal on the table and the changes we in Parliament have proposed, and I consider it an important step to ensure minimum legal aid in all Member States. The issues raised are quite difficult, and it is therefore understandable that it has taken the European Commission longer to prepare the relevant instruments. However, it is very important that we can jointly ensure adequate and high-quality legal aid. Suspects cannot feel that they are being denied their rights and that the level of legal certainty and the administration of justice is being reduced in the European Union. We must therefore strive to bring national criminal procedures and systems closer together, as harmonisation in this area is very important to ensure a high standard in guaranteeing legal aid in the European Union. I expect that the Member States will have no problem in implementing the relevant legislation in order to increase the legal certainty of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear President, one of the fundamental problems of the Community is the lack of trust. Although it is based on good-minded relations, the fact is that most integration steps encountered some resistance precisely because the members did not trust each other. A good part of this mistrust has its origins in the justice system. Members want their citizens, companies and interests to be protected before the judicial authorities of other members and this is a completely legitimate requirement. This report in this regard represents a step in the right direction. The recognition of the same procedural guarantees and the rights of suspects in European arrest warrant procedures is an important step in building genuine cooperation in the area of justice and strengthening trust between members. The judicial cooperation so far has been only partial and has been characterised by insufficient mutual recognition of judicial authorities' decisions. After the introduction of temporary legal aid, we can expect a significant shift towards better cooperation, which will undoubtedly strengthen mutual trust.  The projected reimbursement of the costs of providing temporary legal assistance to Member States in the event of non-compliance with the criteria for ordinary legal aid is a further guarantee that this proposal will not lead to new abuses. If we want to build trust in the judicial systems of other members, we need exactly such fuses, and therefore I welcome this proposal from the rapporteur.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, today we see yet another example of the madness of freedom of movement and the associated European Union immigration system – a system that totally fails to discriminate between a European Union citizen with an unblemished record and one who has already been a menace in his or her own country. Legal aid is a justifiable financial mechanism to support those of insufficient means to enable them to achieve justice through a national legal and court system. It becomes completely open to abuse when the borderless European Union actually encourages the free movement of criminals and crimes. In the UK alone, British courts are dealing with over 700 notifications involving European Union migrants each week – that is an increase of more than 40% over the past five years – and 12% of the United Kingdom prison population are now foreign nationals. I will not even try to estimate or get the figures for those on bail. Many of these individuals already have criminal records and, once in court, they milk the system. It is not just the United Kingdom system they are milking, it is every court system because of the bizarre situation we are in. In the United Kingdom, the cost of translation services alone is now a significant burden for United Kingdom courts. No one is denying anyone justice. Justice should mean justice, but national justice should come first and United Kingdom citizens’ eligibility and entitlement to legal aid should not be sacrificed to a European Union dictate.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, we need to strengthen the rights of suspects and accused persons, not only to protect their human rights, but also to improve our criminal procedure system and to make it more just and effective. If because of objective factors, such as low income, a bad family situation, a poor standard of living and the high cost of a legal aid lawyer, people did not receive proper professional protection, they became an easy target for unprofessional procedures and staff. The system became lazy, neglectful and unjust. That is why it is necessary in the European Union to set high a common minimum standard of legal aid. This minimum standard also allows the strengthening of mutual trust among judicial authorities and can thus help improve the mutual recognition of decisions in criminal matters. I fully support the report’s author’s approach whereby Member States should ensure that ordinary legal aid has to be provided at all stages of the criminal justice process. Information on legal aid in criminal proceedings should be easily accessible and understandable.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I have been dealing with European criminal law for more than 15 years, so let me make a few comments. I am not in for the self-harmonisation of criminal law at European level, but this is a different story and it has been said several times.  When we were in the Czech Parliament 15 years ago – and I remember that , I was in the Czech Parliament at the time – we enforced the European arrest warrant, so even then we said that further harmonisation of procedural criminal law had to follow so that the arrest warrant could work.  To the audience, this means that citizens of the European Union are extradited from their home country to another European Union country for prosecution. Therefore, a minimum standard of criminal law is necessary. That is why, as I have already said, I am not in for self-harmonisation, but here is a clear reason: to allow citizens who are extradited to another European Union country for prosecution to be guaranteed criminal procedural rights. And i'm sure that includes the right to free legal aid.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the rights of defence, the procedural safeguards in criminal proceedings are basic, as you have said. Although we have regulations on the right to translation, for example, I have personally received many petitions informing me that the citizens who have been detained were not entitled to translation. The right to a fair trial is a citizen's right which must neither be negotiated nor must take into account the place where the citizen is tried, nationality, gender or age. In my view, there is a need for a directive harmonising rights in the European Union on this issue. The outcome of the trial must not depend on the financial possibilities of the person being tried. We must be honest, however, Commissioner, and say that there are people who cannot defend themselves for lack of financial resources. Fair processes for all must be the aim of this harmonisation. I find it inappropriate to formulate in Article 4 of the Commission's proposal because it leaves a loophole for the non-application of free legal aid and I quote 'when this is in the interests of the act of justice'. I believe it must be in the citizen's best interest.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, since 2013 the European Commission has adopted the proposal for a directive on temporary legal aid for suspects or accused persons and on legal assistance in procedures for the execution of the European arrest warrant, in accordance with Article 6 of the ECHR, that is to say the European Convention on Human Rights. This means that suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings should have the right of access to a lawyer, whether they have been deprived of their liberty or not. In other words, each Member State must in practice provide adequate legal assistance to persons who do not have the necessary resources and who are suspected or accused of a criminal offence.  In addition, each country of the Union must provide legal aid to suspects or accused persons without undue delay and before any procedural action requires the presence of a defence counsel. Finally, the right to legal aid must be based on the control of the applicant's resources and each Member State must take measures to improve the very quality of legal aid for suspects or accused persons in order to comply with the ECHR's requirement, namely to ensure a fair trial.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the implementation of the principle of mutual recognition of judicial judgments presupposes that the Member States cooperate more and that they strengthen confidence in each other's criminal justice systems, starting precisely from the way in which the rights of suspects and defendants are protected. The approach adopted by the Commission has the advantage of providing the guarantee of a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States, but it needs, because of its fragmentation, appropriate measures to make the right of defence effective. Firstly, guarantees should be given regarding the quality of the legal assistance offered. Secondly, account must be taken of the preferences of suspects, defendants and wanted men with regard to the choice of lawyer of his own motion. The same principle also applies to the need to ensure continuity in legal representation. It is also important to provide for the possibility of replacing the lawyer of his own motion if the suspect or accused person has lost all confidence in his lawyer and is able to justify it for verifiable reasons.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the objective of all the proposals strengthening procedural rights that we have made in recent years has been to promote the principle of equality of arms, and to provide all parties with the protection of a fair trial. I am confident that we have contributed to increasing mutual trust in Member States’ judicial systems. The Legal Aid Directive will give a strong signal that procedural safeguards for suspects and accused persons are taken very seriously in the European Union, even if this implies costs for Member States. I therefore strongly encourage you to vote in favour of this directive tomorrow.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Rapporteur. I think the debate showed that there is great agreement in Parliament on the need for this directive. I would also like to thank the Commissioner for her efforts at the beginning of the route we have walked with the Council. During the negotiations, her representatives also contributed at the crucial moments. The work just isn't finished. We will now have to look at what the Member States are going to do with this - the Council is not here. Because when you collect information alone, you will depend on good information about what is happening in practice. Is it done properly? Is that quality really monitored or are there going to be further cuts in some Member States on the social legal profession, on legal aid? This requires an active commitment from the Commission, an active commitment by Parliament and also an active commitment by NGOs that are happy there, such as Fair Trials International and others that oversee it.  Then for the future. There was one comment from the Commissioner that i was a little shocked by, because she gave the impression of: now we are done with that criminal justice side. I think there is at least one area, but there may be several, which we really need to get on with, and that is the area of pre-trial detention, of pre-trial detention and the circumstances thereof. I hear too many noises from people who have been transferred to another Member State and then end up in fairly degrading situations. So I wholeheartedly support the call from a number of NGOs and also from a group in Parliament who say that now we must continue with the following proposals. The road map is far from finished. I am also counting on the Commissioner to further implement this issue of 'pre-trial detention'.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place today, 4 October 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. Judicial cooperation in criminal matters faces many difficulties, first and foremost the difference between national legal systems and the jealousy shown by States in wanting to maintain their balance between repressive and guarantor measures. This also necessarily leads to difficulties in recognising the relevant judgments and a road map has therefore been identified which sets certain basic rights valid throughout the Union. These include legal aid, which is introduced by this directive. The levelling-out is not done ambitiously, but the result is still satisfactory. It is important that we continue along this path and that we increasingly want to see the same type-approval of rights that guarantees the highest possible levels of protection.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I would like to thank our rapporteur Denis De Jong, but also my fellow shadow rapporteurs, for our good cooperation throughout this matter. The negotiations have been long and difficult, but we have managed to find an agreement that can be supported by all. We have chosen ambition by going further than the European Commission's proposal.  Through our work, common minimum standards for access to legal aid will be guaranteed throughout the criminal proceedings. The adoption of this text then establishes for suspects and those prosecuted deprived of their liberty the right of access to a lawyer already promoted in Europe. This legislation complements the range of European instruments that strengthen the procedural rights of European citizens. This is in a coherent area of freedom, security and justice in Europe.  But much progress remains to be made. A file has been opened on the negotiating table for far too long: that of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. I then call on the Council to move forward on this text. The Europe of Justice will remain an illusion until we have finalised this issue.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. – I support the amendment of the proposal for a directive that, under the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms and the International Covenant on Political and Civil Rights, they recognise the right to legal aid to those who do not have sufficient resources to pay for legal aid themselves, if the interests of justice so require. The Commission's proposal will thus give us a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on Marietje Schaake's report, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods likely to be used to impose the death penalty, torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment and punishment (COM(2014)0001 – C7–0014/2014 – 2014/0005(COD)) (A7–0267/2015).

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the cross-party collaboration and the successful outcome of the negotiations with the Commission and Council sent three strong messages today: Europe delivers, and it is stepping up its efforts to curb the trade and promotion of torture and death-penalty goods; trade policy helps strengthen human rights; and the European Parliament played a decisive role in achieving this important upgrade and update of the legislation. So I would like to thank very much the shadow rapporteurs, as well as everyone in this House, for working towards the biggest majority we have seen on a trade-related issue in the current parliamentary term. This strong EU position and EP position allowed us to improve key points, despite initial reluctance in Council. I am glad that advertising online for banned goods, and also trade fairs, will be illegal. This extends the ban on services facilitating this dreadful market of torture and death-penalty goods and services. I am glad we included the ban on transit via the EU for prohibited goods and that, in addition, knowledge-based transit bans will be in place for multipurpose goods. We also added the urgency procedure, which allows for rapid bans or controls on new products, and, to make the rules future-proof, we expanded the reach of the urgency procedure to cover all annexes to the legislation, thus enabling the Commission swiftly to add new items to annexed lists of banned or controlled items if this is necessary.  We will add law-enforcement standards, so that, when the competent authorities are looking at the supply of technical systems related to Annex 3 goods, they must see that there is a provision promoting law-enforcement standards that respect human rights and contribute to the prevention of torture. Another key element is the inclusion of several steps for better sharing of information. The updated agreement covers the possibility of the competent authorities sharing information with the national preventive mechanisms established under the optional protocol to the UN Convention against Torture. An Anti-Torture Coordination Group will monitor the application of the rules, with Parliament’s experts attending meetings on the preparation of delegated acts and the updating of annexes. We have made this EU regulation a baseline, and there is room for national measures. Member States are permitted to adopt or maintain additional national measures that restrict certain ancillary services, such as transportation, financial services, insurance, advertising or promotion in relation to Annex 2 goods. And, in order to keep the door open for possible further strengthening, we have asked that the Commission, when reviewing the rules at the end of July 2020, should assess whether they should also include activities of EU nationals abroad. This is something that we in Parliament requested, and I hope it can be included in the review. This whole update would not have been possible without the active involvement of civil society and of a number of people in the EU who care deeply about upgrading and updating our human rights record, and I would like explicitly to thank them as well. I would emphasise that we want to make sure we practise what we preach in Europe, and that we have to make sure that all foreign policy instruments, including for trade, help to address the world’s most pressing human rights issues.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it was actually on Human Rights Day, on 10 December 2015, that we had the first trilogue on this issue of how to reform the so-called Anti-torture Regulation. Thanks to very good cooperation between the Commission and the Parliament and, of course, the Council, we managed to get something I think we can all be very proud of. I welcome this agreement. It is ground—breaking. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Marietje Schaake, and the shadow rapporteurs and, of course, the rapporteur for the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Mrs Barbara Lochbihler.  Many countries have, like the EU, abolished the death penalty for all crimes, but we know that the death penalty still exists, and the abolition of the death penalty worldwide remains one of the flagship objectives of our human rights policies. Today we show how we can concretely deliver trade’s contribution to this. We are leading the way. It is a ground-breaking revised version of the regulation designed to stop the trade in equipment used for the torture or execution of people. The new reforms of the regulation from 2005 is now a robust export—controlled regime designed to prevent EU involvement in trading goods that are intended to be used for capital punishment or torture in third countries. As the rapporteur said, there are some very important new elements in this regulation. It covers such activities as brokering services, concerning goods located outside the EU, for which an authorisation will now be required, technical assistance, which will also require an authorisation, and also advertising. For the first time, we are introducing a ban on the display of goods in trade fairs in the EU. For those products made in third countries and exported in transit through the EU, we are making it more expensive and more difficult by introducing a ban. We simply cannot tolerate that these torture and execution products are circulated through our ports or through our territory.  We know that technology evolves and new products for torture may reach the market. That is why it is imperative that the list of products under export control can be updated quickly. The Commission will now have the possibility to use a fast—track – or urgency – procedure to amend the list of goods to which the regulation applies on the lists or the list of countries benefiting from the general export authorisation. Let me stress that, if this procedure is applied, it does not in any way deprive Parliament and the Council of their right to scrutiny of the delegated acts. This regulation sets a high EU trade standard, which takes into account the need to respect human rights. It is an excellent example of the new value—based trade that is so essential for our trade policy. We have shown leadership when it comes to human rights. It is not only an empty statement, but this is a concrete way to contribute to it. With concrete action, through concrete measures, we show that we are taking the death penalty and torture seriously. We want to make it difficult and to remind countries, such as Saudi Arabia, Iran, China and also the US, that we do not tolerate, and we condemn, these practices. It is a message of support to all those people suffering torture and inhumane treatment in prisons and police stations that we care about them and we are listening to them.  The original regulation already made the point that restrictions on trade are instrumental in promoting respect for human rights and human life and thus it serves the purpose of protecting public morals in compliance with the WTO rules in this respect. In our contacts with third countries, be it with members of parliaments or governments, we should promote our values and explain that these restrictions are justified and proportionate. We should of course continue our fight against abolishing capital punishment for all crimes, and invite countries to apply similar end-use control to their exports. We should also explain that these trade restrictions are not intended to deprive third countries of listed medicinal products, but have to prevent such products from being used for the death penalty. We know that in the past that has actually worked. So authorisations can be granted for exports of medicinal products if it is shown that they are being used for the treatment of patients – i.e. the purpose for which they were originally developed. So I hope that Parliament with the vote today will confirm the agreement that we reached last May. It is indeed a very important decision. A strong vote in this plenary will, of course, send a very powerful signal, showing that trade policy is not only about economies, jobs and investment, but is also a way to promote our values. I want again to reiterate my deepest thanks for the contribution and for the good collaboration we have had with this Parliament.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – Thank you very much, but combinations of innocent medicines could also be lethal under certain circumstances.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Mr President, Commissioner Malmström, I would like to thank commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Yes, there are still companies in the EU that market and export so-called security goods, but which are actually used or can be used for torture or for the implementation of the death penalty. We want to put an end to this today. The EU Anti-Torture Regulation establishes an export control system for goods and activities that are or can be used for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment.  However, so far the list of loopholes that we have had with our previous regulation has been very large. I am therefore very pleased that we have been able to close many of these loopholes and that we have a good revised text in which we have been able to improve a great deal. Let me start by saying, as The AFET rapporteur, what you have said, Mrs Malmström. I think that in our external relations we should make every effort to ensure that other regions also make such export regulations, including in relations with our third countries.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I would first of all like to congratulate rapporteur Schaake on the great work done in this dossier of great technical complexity and enormous political significance. The abolition of the death penalty and inhuman and degrading treatment is part of the high priorities of the Union's human rights policy. The European Union, through this Regulation, reaffirms its policy of eliminating the death penalty in the world. It is a unique instrument, ensuring respect for the human rights enshrined in both the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union and the European Convention on Human Rights, in particular respect for and protection of human dignity, the right to life and the prohibition of torture and inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. This agreement is a very important step in the fight against torture and will set a precedent that I hope will set an example for other parts of the world. As the rapporteur has very well explained, in May this year we reached agreement with the Council on a compromise text which includes a large part of Parliament's recommendations. I'm pleased about it. A number of products intended to inflict torture or the death penalty, as well as their publicity, promotion or transit through the territory of the Union, have been prohibited. A number of controls have been introduced for other types of products to ensure that their use is correct and does not serve for torture or capital punishment purposes. We must not forget that certain instruments or medicines serve to ensure our safety or cure our health, so we must seek a balance, clearly define their legitimate uses. Here's all the difficulty: the same product, well used, can save lives and, poorly used, be used to execute a person. From the European Parliament we have also succeeded in establishing an anti-twist coordination group and adopting guidelines on good practice in verifying the final use of these instruments. In conclusion, the text resulting from the trilogue seems appropriate to us and contributes to the protection of human rights, and makes the European Union a pioneer in the regulation of trade in these products. I hope we can approve it by a large majority.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on her excellent work, on her sensitivity and incorporation of the amendments I have tabled and on the good results achieved in the negotiation, which is also the result of the excellent work of Commissioner Malmstrom and her team, whom I also congratulate. And my special appreciation to Amnesty International and the Omega Foundation for their commendable work and involvement. More than 1,600 people were executed in 2015, while more than 20,000 waited on death row.  The European Union is a world leader in the defence against torture and the death penalty, but it is of no use if it is not reinforced by firm and binding actions such as the one we are now debating. Today we take a big step forward with the adoption of this new Regulation in defence of human rights, acting against torture and the death penalty. With significant progress so that no European national or company can profit from this trade within the European Union. Extending the prohibition and control to all activities necessary for its use, such as intermediation, technical assistance, transport, advertising or exhibition services at trade fairs. Demanding a greater duty of control and information to the Member States, as well as the application of sanctions. And defending the prerogatives of the European Parliament, incorporating our expert officials into the Coordination Group, thanks to the push of the President of our Commission, Mr Lange. With this new Regulation, the European Union , as those who have preceded me in the word have already said so , raises the standards for eradicating torture and the death penalty. And that is why my group is satisfied with the agreement; hopefully we can get the rest of the countries added up so that we can end the worst human rights practices. But there's a way to go. I regret that the catch-all clause has not been incorporated, although the emergency procedure is true, it is a step forward in preventing new trade in instruments that may be considered risky. And, of course, we would also have liked extraterritoriality to be incorporated, although I hope that the Commission's agreement to carry out its assessment in July 2020 will have a happy ending.  Let's keep working. Let us continue to work to achieve greater trade linkage as a fundamental instrument in defence of human rights. There are reasons for optimism today.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – I am speaking on behalf of our shadow rapporteur Sander Loones. Proportionality, clarity and flexibility are the elements of the revision of this 2005 regulation that our group values most. We welcome the introduction of proportionate controls without creating unnecessary burdens, burdens that would limit trade in goods for legal end-use. We also support the technique of specific concise lists of goods that provide clarity and exporters and can be quickly adapted to changing technologies and changing developments in the world. This combination of lists of goods and emergency procedure does not jeopardise the lawful access to medicines and pharmaceutical products. Other amendments to the Regulation may also count on our approval, such as the requirement for prior authorization for intermediary services and technical assistance for goods covered by Annexes III and IIIa and their prohibition of goods listed in Annex II; the prohibition of the transit of goods covered by Annex II and - if the carrier knows that the goods may be used for torture or capital punishment - also for goods listed in Annex III and IIa, and finally the prohibition of advertising and display and sale on trade fairs of certain goods.  We hope with you for a room-wide approval. Our congratulations to rapporteur Schaake and also to Commissioner Malmström.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are approving an update of the regulation on the marketing of goods that can be used for the death penalty or torture, after a demanding trialogue with the Council and the Commission.  I would therefore like, first of all, to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Roth-Her colleagues, for her excellent report. Schaake for the excellent work he has done together with his office, the work of the secretariat of the INTA Committee and Parliament's Legal Service. This work has enabled us to achieve a result that we welcome and which contributes to improving a regulation, that of 2005, which has presented in its practical application some loopholes that had prevented its full implementation.  We believe it is right and important for the Eu ropean Union to ensure that instruments which can be used for inhuman and degrading treatment, which are degrading treatment of human dignity, are not marketed. It is precisely for this reason, precisely because I consider it a sign of civilisation to ban the death penalty and torture, that I would like to take this opportunity to remind you that very serious incidents of torture and violation of human rights took place fifteen years ago in my country, during the demonstrations against the G8 in Genoa. I also remember this because I was present in those days, in what Amnesty International described as the greatest suspension of democratic rights in a Western country since the Second World War.  Well, fifteen years after those very serious acts, after the ruling of the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, which in 2015 condemned Italy for the conduct of the police during the break-in at the Diaz school at the G8 in Genoa, where there was real retaliation to prove the humiliation and physical and moral suffering of the victims, Italy has not yet adopted a measure recognising the crime of torture. I believe that the fact that this is happening in this European Union is absolutely serious.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, we have managed to close many of the loopholes that the previous anti-torture regulation still had, and that is very positive. Now, for example, the transit of goods through the EU is to be banned if there is reason to believe that the goods are being used for torture or the use of the death penalty in the country of destination. However, as there is also an ever-increasing development of technology for potential torture tools in this terrible market, this new rush procedure is now also being introduced. This will enable the Commission to add new products to the list of prohibited or eligible goods without much effort, and will hopefully be able to react quickly to these developments. Finally, we were also able to agree to ban the advertising of torture tools at European trade fairs. In the future, therefore, it will no longer be possible to exhibit torture instruments at trade fairs in an EU Member State. These fairs always attract many interested parties from non-European countries. Finally, it is particularly welcome that national authorities must now pass on information on certain commercial transactions to the national agencies for the prevention of torture, which the signatory states of the Convention against Torture must establish. This demand was particularly important to us from the point of view of human rights, and it was a key demand for us in the Committee on Human Rights that we get this into the regulation. All these changes were long overdue. However, it is now absolutely essential that the Member States implement the new provisions swiftly and consistently, and we should work at all levels to ensure that other countries also make progress in the fight against torture and the death penalty. This export control system, which the EU has created, is the only one of its kind in the world and one of the few examples of trade policy not only being reconciled with human rights, but can serve to enforce and protect it. Unfortunately, the situation in other regions and countries is quite different. Trade in security goods is regulated much less stringently than, for example, trade in conventional military or armaments, despite the fact that, according to Amnesty International, the technology for these dual-use goods has developed significantly in recent years. We have also seen an increase in the number of companies producing and distributing such goods, as well as their geographical spread, particularly in countries with little to no production and trade controls. However, if we want a world without the death penalty and without torture, then similar export control systems must also exist in other countries and regions. And perhaps we should also start working on an international agreement in this area.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, contrary to what is believed, we Europeans have not abolished the death penalty, we have only relocated it. In Europe, in fact, people are no longer killed, but products and medicines made in Europe are used to inflict torture or even the death penalty in unscrupulous countries. Since 2005 there has been a regulation that seeks to put a stop to this traffic, but it needed to be updated and, together with my colleagues and led by the rapporteur, Mrs Schaake, whom I thank, that is exactly what we have done. We have updated the definition of torture, strengthened controls, created a system of exchange of information and rapid updating and even banned the transit of many of these instruments into our territory. The end result does not account for 100 % of our requests, but it is certainly a step forward. To stop the death penalty and torture, the 5 Star Movement votes yes. I wonder, however, what the Democratic Party, which preaches well here in the European Parliament but continues to export weapons and instruments of torture to dictatorships from Italy, will do.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, we have another report here on the creation of impressions and nothing more. Torture and executions will not be prevented by banning the marketing of the items used today because it is very easy to use other, simple, everyday and easily accessible items for this purpose. The virtual drownings at Guantanamo, with a towel and a bottle of water, how are you going to ban them? In the best-case scenario, we'll just be able to make the executions even more painful. They are already discussing in the US the possibility of replacing the hard-to-find and perhaps soon banned lethal injection with the gallows or with the firing squad.  All civilized people condemn torture. My view, however, is that the debate on the death penalty should be reopened. Are we sure we want to send perpetrators of particularly heinous crimes back into society? Some countries of the Union have flexible penalties and excessively safeguard the rights of the perpetrator, but do not care about the rights of the victim. We are content with a minute's silence for the victims. It has been proven that serial killers, terrorists, drug dealers continue their activities and through prison. Why should they have more rights than their hundreds of victims?

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report We should do everything we can to ensure that torture tools such as electric chairs, thumbscrews, stretch benches and others are not used worldwide, that they cannot be imported into Europe, that they cannot be exported from Europe, and that we stop and remove all products that are somehow carried out through Europe from the market and supply chain. That is why our group supports this legislation and the amendment. We are in favour of a transit ban. All products covered by this scheme must be effectively removed by our authorities. We are in favour of banning advertising and at trade fairs. We are opposed to advertising for such products in any medium. We support the ability of Member States to take additional measures. If a Member State notices that something is going wrong, if a Member State realises that there is a gap, then it must be possible to tighten up accordingly quickly.  We are in favour of a ban on mediation and technical assistance. It is downright perverse when citizens of the European Union in other countries are still advising dictators, despots or other organisations on how best to torture people or what instruments should be used to do so.  We support the review clause that is foreseen. We must be sure that, after a few years, we will also check the extent to which our regulation is working. We are in favour of the introduction of the urgent procedure. We must ensure that when new perverse and perfidious methods are invented, they are quickly included in the appropriate annexes. We want the European Commission and the Member States, in all their discussions with third countries around the world, to ensure that all things that somehow help prevent torture methods and other things are used.  We are in favour of strengthening the exchange of information. We need to better motivate, or even force, the authorities in our Member States to exchange information in order to really stop cross-border trade in such products. And we support the new Coordination Group for the Prevention of Torture, because together we want to develop our legislation and ensure that the European Union can continue to set an example for preventing torture and other methods of inhumaneness.  In this sense, our group supports, in principle, free trade relations. However, it is precisely for this reason that we are working to prevent it where free trade is abused. With this in mind, I am pleased that we in this House are pushing this legislation forward with broad support.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the Commission for the excellent work they have done on this report. The anti-torture regulation is an excellent example of the value-based trade on which trade policy should be focused. It demonstrates that values can have, in the right circumstances, priority over business and over profits, and therefore it is to be warmly welcomed. This is also a great success for Parliament, as most of our recommendations have been taken on board. Measures agreed which have already been mentioned include the EU transit ban for torture and capital-punishment goods, which will make sure that, in the future, the EU in no way contributes to the trade in these goods thus inadvertently participating in violations of human rights and international law.
