We now have a system in place which should guarantee that there are no loopholes in this law but, as Daniel Caspary has rightly said, what is now important is the full commitment of all the Member States to continued monitoring of the situation. And, while I welcome the regulation, it is worth pausing in a debate like this to remind ourselves that, incredibly in the modern world, torture is actually still on the increase and the use of the death penalty went up in the last three years for which have statistics. So this is a good step in the right direction, a good victory for Parliament and a good decision by the European Union to strengthen the 2005 regulation, but let us not be complacent about the situation we face in the current world.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done On behalf of my group, I would also like to pay tribute to the rapporteur for the success of the negotiations, including the shadow rapporteurs. With the new regulation, we will certainly not abolish torture. According to Amnesty International, the shame of the use of torture is in dictacity to 82% of the world's states. Torture instruments have even been advertised at trade fairs, including at the scandalous "Enforce Tac" trade fair in Nuremberg, Germany. At the very least, this regulation is supposed to stop. But torturers are inventive. The perpetrators do not need EU technology for waterboarding. That is why I believe that we must also provide much greater financial support to organisations and institutes which, through their courageous use, uncover cases of torture or trafficking in torture instruments. States that are repeatedly tortured should lose any trade preferences on the part of the EU. UN Special Rapporteur De Schutter has rightly called for human rights enforcement mechanisms in international agreements as well. Appropriate regulations must therefore be included in the sustainability chapters of EU trade agreements. Last but not least, a look at Hungary: we must take in and protect refugee victims of torture. We must also provide them with all medical assistance in coping with their traumatisation.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to point out that the Americans, including in Poland, used water stewing as torture, and a ban on water exports should also be introduced. In the Soviet countries, nail-sticking and toothpicking were used. Matches are gone, but a ban on the export of toothpices should necessarily be introduced. And now seriously: I have not seen so much stupidity in this parliament yet. I understand that the people who have done this are well-known people, but the proportion of stupidity to zacności cannot cross certain boundaries. If anyone had read the European Parliament resolution, we would have been the subject of jokes by satirical artists all over the world. Fortunately, no one reads this, and besides, I think that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, this is a very important topic and I think it highlights again the amount of good work that the European Union endeavours to do and its efforts to achieve a good standard of human rights across the globe, especially in areas with which we have dealings in relation to trade. I would like to compliment the rapporteur, Marietje Schaake, for her good work: as always, it has been comprehensive and dedicated. This is really about closing the loopholes, and that is what has been achieved to a large degree. You will never, of course, close loopholes one hundred percent, and it has been pointed out that some goods traded could be used both to save and to kill people. Be that as it may, movements such as abolishing the death penalty are something that we are very strong on, and this is something we have to work towards continually. So this is a positive action by the European Union to help promote human rights across the globe and that is to be commended.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done In fact: shackles with electric shocks during torture or thumbscrews at a trade fair in Europe or drugs for the execution of the death penalty – all made in Europe! No, that must not be a reality. We must make it clear that torture and the execution of the death penalty are not in our canon of values, not in the interests of the European Union, and in this respect we have legislation before us today that ensures that torture tools are no longer exported, that they cannot be advertised, that they must not be exhibited and that there is no transit. And this is a major step in the right direction for a value-based trade policy that makes it clearer that trade is not just about economic relations and has to pursue economic interests, but is indeed based on European Union values. The fact that we got this done was indeed a success for the European Parliament. Many thanks to the rapporteur, Marietje Schaake, but also to Mrs Malmström, for the good cooperation with the European Commission. Unfortunately, I cannot necessarily pass on the thanks to the Council, because we had to urge the Council and the Member States very strongly to adopt this legislation in this way now – especially as regards a rapid test for new products. But we really have a great model on the table now. We should also use this model as a blueprint for legislation that is coming. The Commission recently published legislation on dual-use goods, i.e. the export of goods that can be used both militarily and civilly, last week. Here, too, we must make it clear that we stand by our value-based trade policy. Goods that are misused may not be exported.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Madam President, to refrain from supplying products, medicines and poisons intended to torture or to give death is an act of civilization. That is the meaning of our support for this text. Let us continue to work for the abolition of the death penalty wherever it exists in the world.  We will also need to revise our trade policies so that countries that provide inhumane treatment do not receive preferential trade treatment. To do so, it would be necessary to have the courage to use all the clauses in the partnership agreements to enforce human rights and democracy by suspending these trade or association agreements, as any military cooperation, as long as torture or inhuman treatment are found. This is the condition of the globalization of human progress.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, capital punishment, torture, but also cruelly inhuman or degrading treatment are incompatible with the principles and values that govern the European Union. The fact that some substances or products in the European Union can be used for the execution of human beings by lethal injection is a reality, so it is necessary to take further measures to prevent human rights violations in this respect. In this context, it is important to ensure an adequate combination of the legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures of the European Union in order to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of goods intended for torture, as well as to effectively control elements with potentially lethal and inhumane uses. Major importance and increased efforts must be directed towards export control, but also towards the development of a specific list of goods to be controlled. However, efforts cannot be limited not only in the direction of eradicating torture by reducing the availability of equipment with which abuses can be committed, but also by promoting appropriate controls beyond its borders. In continuation of these efforts, the European Union should also seek to control other services that can contribute to the spread of products that can be used for torture or capital punishment, such as financial services, but especially marketing services. On the other hand, as regards the technical assistance of suppliers, they should be prohibited from providing training, advice, training or from passing on practical knowledge or techniques which could help to carry out judicial executions. Last but not least, the need to adequately monitor the implementation of Member States' commitments, including their obligation to report and exchange information through a secure and encrypted system, should be stressed.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the outcome of the negotiations with the Council and the Commission is a political victory for Parliament and for the European Union as a whole. The proposed legislation closely touches on one of the values of which the Eu ropean Union is the bearer: support for human rights and the fight against the death penalty. There are two general principles which under which this issue is based. Firstly, the European Union, which is leading the way in the fight against the death penalty, must be consistent. We are not credible if we claim to protect human rights in distant countries, while allowing our companies to market in those same states some of the products that contribute to the perpetuation of abuses against human dignity.  Secondly, the text is consistently part of the European trade strategy, a policy aimed at promoting sustainable development and growth, imposing the principles of social protection and justice on globalisation. Our aim is to provide global trade actors with a basis of common rules that will enable the side effects of globalisation to be corrected and prevented. It is essential for the European Union to be at the forefront of this battle of civilisations in order to prevent the changes that are accompanying our time from becoming weapons in the hands of a few, to the detriment of the weakest. The ban on the marketing, promotion and transit of these goods responds precisely to this need, and that is why I hope that this House will speak as unifiedly as possible.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Madam President, I think it is positive and necessary to regulate trade in certain products which can be used to apply the death penalty, inflict torture or degrading treatment, and for that reason I believe that this report is going in the right direction. But it must be made clear that the European Union has no credibility as long as it continues to ignore what its partners do about torture, or what we do ourselves. There are many examples: secret CIA flights, prisons, or that at Guantanamo have been tortured with impunity for fourteen years, not to mention our outsourcing of the deportation of immigrants or the granting of safe country status to Turkey or, under a secret agreement, to Afghanistan. We will have no credibility in our so-called "fight against torture" as long as we continue to profit from arms sales to Saudi Arabia or our partners, such as Israel or the United States, have torture legalized. Roles put up with everything, but if we are really against torture, shouldn't we start by presying and conditioning our relations with relevant allies and actors until they comply with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights? (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: "blue card" question. "Dear Colleague, let me ask you how you understand this emergency procedure by which customs authorities can, for example, confiscate the proceeds of torture. I have not understood how it works.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: "blue card" response. – Well, I think more than one question was a statement to be included in your statistics, but come on, I think there are many mechanisms for our trade relations to be contingent on political action. We know how it can be done, what happens is that there have to be consequences. There are never consequences when human rights are violated if the partner is large; if it's small, of course, we cut relationships immediately.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union is much more than just a market and since the protection of human rights is a fundamental value of the Union, that value must be at the heart of European trade policy. That is why the new anti-torture rules agreed in the trilogue of the European institutions deserve the support of this House, precisely because they are a very important step towards a more responsible and more in line with our values, capable of even being an exemplary reference in this area on a global scale.  I would therefore like to welcome the work of the Commission and the delegation of the Committee on International Trade in the trilogue which has managed to integrate most of Parliament's recommendations into the final text and I would like to point out two fundamental points: the prohibition of advertising and the promotion of goods intended for torture and also the urgency procedure which will allow a rapid response to the movement of new products that may arise on the market and are susceptible to use in acts of torture. With these new rules, the Union's trade policy gets better, our fight for human rights becomes stronger and the European Parliament will continue to fulfil its mission by monitoring the application of these rules so that the Union's trade policy is effectively, in practice, true to the values of the European Union.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Madam President, rapporteur Schaake and the contributions of our colleague Lochbihler have improved the Commission's proposal, which strengthens control of torture instruments and incorporates input from Amnesty International or Omega. However, there are weapons and projectiles not included in the annexes and are therefore not subject to control or prohibition. That's the case with rubber balls. The Commission refers to or hides from the lack of competence and that Community legislation does not prohibit the use of rubber balls. This, together with the fact that the Common Military List and that of dual-use products are applied differently by each Member State, aggravates the lack of guarantees and security. It is time, in my opinion, for us to solve these gaps, so that deaths like that of young Iñigo Cabacas in 2012, caused by the impact of a rubber ball thrown by the Basque autonomous police, never happen again. And it is time for us to apply and also enforce at home what we recommend outside.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, our trade policy can and should be a crucial tool to promote human rights, and this is what this regulation is all about. The EU rightly rejects the use of torture and the death penalty, and the way that we trade must reflect these fundamental values. This legislation will ensure that no EU business can profit from torture and that no company trading for goods for execution or torture can access the EU market. Effective enforcement will be absolutely crucial. But it is worth reminding ourselves that, because this legislation is from the EU – the biggest trading bloc in the world – it can have a real impact in setting global standards in a way that no country could ever achieve unilaterally. I support this legislation and I very much hope that, despite Brexit in my own country, both the UK and the rest of the EU will continue to strive together for a strong, value-based trade policy worldwide.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, a few years ago, at the request of the NGO Reprieve, I have begun action with other colleagues here in the European Parliament to achieve the result which we will finally vote on today. I congratulate rapporteur Marietje Schaake, who led the negotiations between the Commission, the Council and Parliament in defence of Parliament's positions to make crucial changes to the 2005 Regulation, correcting gaps and increasing scope and effectiveness.  This is the case with clauses that restrict and prohibit advisory, transportation, brokerage, marketing and other services that are used to the sale of risky or prohibited products. Companies established in the European Union will no longer be able to promote prohibited equipment at arms fairs, exhibitions and online. We prohibit the provision of technical assistance in the use of medicinal products or other products susceptible to these uses, for torture, the application of the death penalty and we have introduced an emergency procedure that will allow the control of new products that present risks.  It is not enough to be against the death penalty and torture, universally. We need to ensure that the European Union, in trade policy as in others, is coherent and does not in any way lend itself to being complicit in the execution of the death penalty and acts of torture, that our companies, that European companies do not profit from the sale of products that can be used by dictatorships or democracies to cause torture and inflict capital punishment on human beings. Coherence in the defence of human dignity, on the basis of the values enshrined in the Treaty on European Union and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, is fundamental in trade policy as in others.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe needs to reaffirm its leading role in the international arena in the fight against the abolition of the death penalty, torture and inhuman and degrading practices that violate human rights. The Member States must not be complicit, even indirectly, in those who continue to carry out acts of torture and ill-treatment in total disregard of the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  At the heart of the European line must be the right combination of prohibitions and authorisation requirements for trade in the goods covered by the regulation. A mere ban on the marketing of products that can be used for the purpose of carrying out acts of torture and the death penalty is not enough. There must also be a system of authorisation for items intended for multiple uses, which could therefore be misused. I think it would be appropriate to put in place a strict multilateral system of export control in this sector. Particular attention should be paid to medicinal products which can be used to carry out death sentences by lethal injection.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the death penalty, torture and all forms of cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment and punishment are prohibited by international and European treaties. In this context, the European Anti-Torture Regulation must act effectively as a tool to protect people from violent treatment by imposing effective controls on species and activities used for the execution of the death penalty or for torture. This objective requires an immediate reorganisation of the European Commission's controls on the trade in torture instruments, a reorganisation which, unfortunately, has been delayed at multiple levels. Advertising and sales of these products on the internet must therefore be prohibited. In particular, control of exports of dual-use items included in the lists of military equipment, which can also be used for torture, should be intensified. I therefore believe that the European Union cannot, on the one hand, call for the ratification of international conventions against the death penalty in third countries and, on the other hand, to tolerate here in the European Union the use of practices and tools by the Security Corps which are proven to lead to permanent injuries or even deaths.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, as a member of the IMCO Committee I am interested in any regulation relating to trade in the internal market, and therefore this report. However, we do not need to develop a free market at all costs, we are talking about a digital Europe, online commerce, and I think it is very important to see how we can monitor the market in this segment. It is good that the ban on products that are likely to be used for torture is introduced. To condemn torture practices, it is necessary to intervene without hesitation. The restrictions in this area, as set out in this report, actually support the fight against capital punishment and torture. It is good that we have a report showing that supporting the development of free trade does not prevent us from intervening when it comes to dangerous products. I believe, however, Commissioner, that we need to regularly review the list of these dangerous products because inventiveness and innovation also work in the field of these products. I support this report and will vote for it and congratulate the rapporteurs and all the colleagues who worked on the report.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is rare that there is such consensus on a trade-related matter in this plenary, and I salute this, but this is truly an occasion where we can all be proud. The institutions, including Parliament under the very strong and affirmative leadership of the rapporteur, worked very closely together in the trilogues to achieve something really important that has a real effect on the most vulnerable people all across the world. This is being closely watched by members of NGOs, of course, and also by many committed citizens who have been expecting us to take action today. And with your vote in a couple of hours we will do so. What we have been considering here is the impact of trade in instruments that actually cause death and torture – lethal drugs, injections, electric chairs, choke belts, spiked batons – and we have prohibited the promotion of those products. I was shocked to see how such products are displayed at trade fairs all over the European Union or offered in catalogues. Today we are addressing that loophole, which so many of you have talked about, and also making sure that we address transit issues, and that we have a quick procedure for updating so that we can ban new products in a quick and effective manner. This, of course, makes a true contribution. It will not eliminate torture or the death penalty, because we cannot do that with this instrument alone, but it is a contribution and we will continue, with the other tools we have in various dialogues and in our foreign policy, to fight against these things that have no place in a civilised society. We are also sending a very powerful signal: that the European Union stands united in taking this step. So thank you again. I am looking forward to the vote and to working with you to make sure that this legislation is swiftly implemented and that it works in practice.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone for their contributions, including Commissioner Malmström for her leadership across the board in her groups at the Commission. Together we have closed most loopholes, and we must ensure solid monitoring at the Member-State level. It is indeed, as the Commissioner said, hard to imagine the kinds of products and services that are offered at trade fairs and in online or offline catalogues. This must end. Today’s update shows the EU leads in raising the bar globally to take concrete steps to end the death penalty and torture. The increase of torture and the death penalty call for such measures, from Iran to Saudi Arabia or Egypt, from China to the United States. We must push back and challenge these kinds of human rights abuses. In fact, we need more EU-wide leadership to push back against those who challenge the universality of human rights. Today’s trade measures – and I hope they will be adopted with a large majority – will of course not in of themselves end the death penalty or torture. So we must see this step in sync with other measures and instruments the European Union has and must use. We have to keep in mind when we do our work those people who are suffering from repression, violence, torture and the death penalty, often at the hands of their own governments. They must find in the European Union an advocate for their freedom. Today’s regulation is an important element to give meaning to the European Union’s human rights agenda, and I hope for all of your support.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. (The meeting was suspended at 11 a.m. and resumed at 12:05 p.m.)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I would like to inform you that the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The Public Policy adopted the report on the Paris Agreement last night. (Applause) This fulfils the formal condition for the plenary to be able to vote today on this report, which Mr La Via will present to us. This is a historic vote, because with the adoption of this text, we can take the last political step towards ratification by the EU of the Paris Agreement. And our vote would clear the way for the entire convention to exceed the threshold necessary to enter into force worldwide. Less than a year after its adoption in December 2015, this would be an outstanding result. And it would come in time for the next COP-22 climate conference in Marakesch. In doing so, the EU would have shown leadership, important in these times. By way of comparison, eight years passed between the adoption and entry into force of the Kyoto Protocol. We are now less than nine months after the Paris Conference. I am therefore very pleased that you, ladies and gentlemen, have agreed to my proposal to hold this historic vote within an appropriate and solemn framework. We are therefore very honoured that the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Mr Ban Ki-moon, is with us, and I would like to extend a warm welcome to the European Parliament, Mr Secretary-General, to which you are without a doubt one of the great architects of this historic agreement, together with our respect for this extraordinary achievement! (Applause) Today, however, we would also like to thank the French Republic, which, as the host of the COP-21 conference, has made enormous political efforts to bring about the agreement. I am therefore very pleased that the President-in-Office of the COP 21 climate conference is attending our meeting today, and I would like to thank you warmly, Minister Royal, on behalf of the entire French Government, for your great efforts. (Applause) The Secretary-General of the United Nations, Mr Ban Ki-moon, will now honour us with a short speech. After that, we will listen to the chairmen of the political groups and then proceed to the voting procedures.

name: Ban Ki-moon
text: Secretary-General of the United Nations. – Your Excellency Mr Martin Schulz, President of the European Parliament, Your Excellency Mr Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the Commission, Your Excellency Mr Ivan Korčok, President-in-Office of the Council and State Secretary for EU Affairs, Your Excellency Madam Ségolène Royal, President of COP21, Your Excellency Mr Maroš Šefčovič, Vice-President in charge of Energy Union, Your Excellency Mr Miguel Arias Cañete, Commissioner for Climate Action and Energy, Your Excellency Mr Giovanni La Via, Chair of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, honourable EU parliamentarians, Excellencies, distinguished Ministers, ladies and gentlemen, it is a great honour for me, as Secretary-General of the United Nations, to take this opportunity to address once again the distinguished Members of the European Parliament. Thank you for this privilege. I was not originally planning to come to Strasbourg but I diverted my travel to address you at this crucial time, at the invitation of President Schulz, on the importance of Europe’s ratification of the Paris Agreement on climate change. I deeply appreciate your leadership and engagement. The European Union has a long and proud record of leadership on climate change – the defining challenge of our time. As Members of the European Union, your countries have demonstrated, time and again, that you not only recognise the seriousness of this threat but you are also ready to seize the opportunities it brings for building more sustainable, competitive economies and stable and healthier societies. From an early leadership role in the UN Framework Convention negotiations, to support for the Green Climate Fund and other funding mechanisms, to your own efforts in scaling-up clean energy, European Union members have stood strong. Today you have another opportunity to demonstrate global climate leadership. I encourage you to build on your proud legacy and to support the speedy ratification of the Paris Agreement. This would allow the European Union, and its Member States which are in a position to do so, to deposit the ratification instrument at UN Headquarters in New York. Such a swift embrace of an international agreement would be a remarkable achievement at any time. It would be especially impressive for an agreement that addresses one of the most complex and all-embracing issues of our time. In the past few weeks, we have seen tremendous momentum, from all corners of the globe, to bring the Paris Agreement to life this year. Already this week, India has formally joined the agreement. Thirty-one countries joined the agreement at a high-level event which I hosted at the United Nations on 21 September. Already in September, the world’s two largest emitters, China and the United States, have put their political support behind Paris and formally joined the agreement. I commend all of these governments for their vision and leadership. This means we have crossed the first threshold for entry into force. As of today, we have 62 countries which have joined this Paris Agreement. Excellencies, honourable parliamentarians, ladies and gentlemen, I understand and respect the unique decision-making process of the European Union. At the same time, I welcome the decision by the EU Environment Ministers on 30 September to act on a fast track. This will enable individual countries to send their ratifications directly to the United Nations. I appeal to you to approve this fast-track procedure. We are on the verge of passing the 55% threshold. You now have an opportunity to make history by helping lead the world to a better future. I can think of no better way to secure the legacy of Paris than to have the agreement enter into force in record time, with the support of the world’s most powerful economies and its most vulnerable countries. Rapid entry into force would demonstrate anew Europe’s commitment to international cooperation, which is at the heart of the European Union’s identity. It would spur the transformation to the lower-carbon, higher—opportunity, climate-resilient economy that we need in order to keep global temperature increases well below two degrees. And it would help to protect the world’s most vulnerable communities and assist them in adapting to inevitable climate impact. In the name of humanity and for the sake of future generations, I encourage you to support the speedy ratification of the Paris Agreement. At a time of record heat, let us take historic action. At a moment of divisions on many other challenges, let us show that we are united on the biggest one of all. This is our chance to set a course towards a safer, more sustainable and more just future for all, on a healthy planet. Let us seize the moment and be true to the values and aims of our organisation. As you may know, my mandate as Secretary-General ends at the end of this year, when I finish my tenure. It has been a great honour for me to serve this invaluable organisation and to work closely with the European Union and the European Parliament. I take this opportunity to express my deepest gratitude for all the wholehearted support you have given to me and to the United Nations over the past 10 years. I sincerely hope that the European Union will continue to lead in supporting the noble missions of the United Nations for human rights, sustainable development and lasting peace in our world. Thank you for your great leadership and your commitment. Let us work together to build a world better for all. (The House accorded the speaker a standing ovation)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Vielen Dank, Herr Generalsekretär!

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes).

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: First of all, a brief explanation of the procedure. First of all, I give the floor to the chairmen of the political groups, who make a brief statement for the group concerned. I then give the floor to the President of the Commission and to the President-in-Office of the Council. At the end of this round, as has already been said, I shall give the floor, on the basis of our Rules of Procedure, to the rapporteur and committee chairman, Giovanni La Via. We shall then hold the roll-call vote. If adopted, the ratification procedure, the so-called assent procedure, will be completed by the European Parliament. I will then sign a so-called communication letter here in plenary. This letter goes to the President of the Council. Copies of these shall be given to the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Minister Royal and the President of the Commission. With this letter of transmission, the Council is in a position to create the appropriate conditions for the deposit of the documents in New York. This will achieve and even exceed the minimum quota of 55%, so that today's decision creates the basic condition for the entry into force of the Paris Agreement. After the vote, I would ask the President of the Commission, the President of the Council, Mrs Royal and the Secretary-General, as well as Mr La Via, to accompany me in signing.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, President-in-Office of the Council, Secretary-General, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work and for his excellent work. First of all, a warm welcome to the European Parliament, and I would like to say that we too thank you for the work you have done for the world and in partnership with Europe over the last ten years.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Climate change is probably the central task of our generation of politicians, and that is why today is a historic day. We Europeans can be proud of this because we were the leading continent to answer this question. Without Europe's leader, this agreement would not have existed, and for that, in turn, it was a prerequisite that we Europeans were united, that we speak with one voice and that global issues were thus co-decided. It shows what we Europeans are capable of. We Europeans must now also act after signing, which means that the existing commitments must be implemented.  On my group, I would like to say that global problems need global solutions. Despite the populism we are seeing around the world, this agreement shows that the world is capable of solving global problems together. People have a lot of concerns when it comes to global issues, but today is a day of optimism. Today we are showing that we can solve. That's why it's a good day!

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Minister Royal, distinguished Ban Ki-moon, thank you for your ten-year commitment and for the invitation you have addressed to us and which we are collecting. Today's Europe is at last the Europe we want: not europe closed in on itself, but a Europe world that is faithful to its first mission, which is to take care of people and the Earth. Europe must be a project in the service of a better life and not a set of legal wit.  Today we have a historic responsibility and we will honour it. But we need to do more. We must also make other commitments, translate the written, decisive and agreed things and give us even more ambitious commitments. Our planet, Earth, arose billions of years before people's lives manifested themselves. The Earth does not belong to us. It is we who belong to it and we have a duty to preserve it and pass it on to our children.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it is now clear that last Friday’s agreement by EU environment ministers will bring forward the ratification of the Paris Agreement on Climate Change. As such, we recognise that the path is now clear for the European Parliament to give its formal consent, as foreseen by the Treaty.  The adoption of this agreement on the cumulative announcements by the end of the COP 21 of intended nationally determined contributions by 187 parties will now form the basis of a global effort. The ECR Group therefore notes that ratification will enable the EU to join with the United States, China and 60 other parties who have formally submitted their instrument of ratification.  In light of this, the Paris Agreement will now become legally binding before the end of this year. The Paris Agreement carries importance for all stakeholders, whether they be investors, businesses, civil society or policy-makers. Indeed, the global nature of the effort is made manifest by the 189 national climate plans which have been put forward. We should, however, be mindful that this step only marks ratification of the agreement and we await with interest to see how national governments across the EU will seek to implement the promises they have made.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Secretary-General first of all for this last 10 years.   Madame la Présidente, soyez la bienvenue. Je suis content que vous ayez trouvé le chemin vers notre Parlement. Il y a encore sur votre bureau une petite invitation de la commission d'enquête EMIS. J'espère donc que vous connaissez maintenant le chemin. So colleagues, I think that the COP21 Paris Agreement is historic. I think, in my opinion, it is even as historic as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights of 1948. As in 1948, COP21 is proof, in fact, that multilateralism works, and that the global governance of our planet is not a dream, as some people are saying. It proves also that we, Europe, can lead the world in the right direction and that in fact we are stronger together.   Mr Secretary-General, what a dramatic difference between this and the ongoing tragedy in Aleppo: civilians killed, hospitals bombed, and stalemate between America and Russia – the reluctance of the first coupled with the cynical and cruel determination of the other and, I would even say, the failing post-war logic of the Security Council.  I think COP21 and the Paris Agreement demonstrate exactly the opposite: that the international community and Europe can take responsibility, and that in fact multilateralism is the way forward for the next generations.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Ban Ki-moon, I would like to thank Mr Ban Ki-moon for his work I would also like to welcome you to this Chamber on behalf of my group very warmly; it is a great honour for us. The fight against climate change is a global challenge, and we all agree on that. A binding framework has been created to reduce greenhouse gases. However, and I would also like to say this, we see today's act, today's decision, as a starting signal, because we cannot stand by it. We need to approach the way we live, how we produce, how we consume. What is actually general capitalism will not be able to do so. Let us talk about how we, together in the world community, fulfil this responsibility and how we will contribute to a lasting change in our environment, our social community and also the coexistence with animals.  That is why I would like to reiterate my call: the European Union's agreed targets for reducing greenhouse gases are not enough! The trade that has been fixed is not enough at EUR 4 per tonne, it does not go beyond a trade in indulgences. Let us do more together in our responsibility. We are available for this. We want to support this – in responsibility for the future life of our children.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President-in-Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon! I would like to congratulate you and the United Nations on something that has at least succeeded every day when you look at Syria. For what can be said about the Paris Agreement can now also be said about the ratification process, and I am deeply convinced that this agreement is important for international climate protection, but that it is also important for the United Nations, which you will be leading until the end of this year.  I wish you to succeed in the face of the horror reported from Syria and Aleppo.  As Greens in the European Union, we expect Mrs Royal to be not only able to take decisions in the ratification process, but also to be able to act, and to do so ambitiously. The European Union has all the technologies to operate differently: we can generate energy differently, we can organise transport differently. But we have to jump at last. We must not hesitate any more! This consistency, which you are demonstrating here today, will soon be needed in the actions that the leaders of the European Union stand for. What we do in Europe, how we operate in the industrialised countries of the world, is crucial for the future of people outside the European Union – not just today, but tomorrow and the day after. We are not going to discuss the issue of flight here. But the Paris Agreement is indeed a huge challenge, and Europeans have been greedy in recent years.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we too are satisfied with the European Union's ratification of the Paris Agreement. A necessary step, but still crucial and necessary. Unfortunately, we believe that this will not be enough. This is only a first step that must force us not to give up. A first step that must push us to implement new concrete actions to face the most important of the challenges between now and the next decades. I would like to repeat the words of Christiana Figueres: 'if we do not achieve radical change in the next five years, we will have an unacceptable level of human suffering as a result of poverty'. Then we must have the courage to abandon an absurd model, based on unlimited growth with limited resources at our disposal. We must have the courage to replace the word 'growth' with the word 'balance'. And let me quote my nine-year-old son, who some time ago said to me, "Dad, but if we grow up forever, where are we going to bang our heads?" Perhaps that alone would be enough, perhaps it would be enough just to look at the world through the eyes of a child, because it is to them that we bequeath it.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – (Inaudible) ... what they want to do with regard to climate change. The EU has nothing to do with this, and the EU should not ratify this climate agreement. Again, there are happy faces in this room because of this so—called historical landmark, and I understand that as the influence of the EU in this agreement is again evident. The agreements are one-sidedly detrimental to developed countries, the climate effects are not clear at all and citizens must again bear enormous costs. The elite are laughing here while rubbing their hands. They will benefit from these climate action plans, but the hard-working citizens in the Member States will soon pay more for their electricity, their car, their heating, you name it. It is a shame. At the moment that the EU is proudly ratifying this agreement, I see only one bright spot and that is that the Member States are free to fulfil or not fulfil this agreement any way they like, and that is a good thing.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear Secretary-General, We have a solemn sitting on our agenda, but at the same time we will make an important substantive decision. With our vote, the European Union will ratify the Paris Climate Agreement. Although several countries have already done so, including Hungary, this will be a decisive step in terms of entry into force. The Member States of the European Union have been at the forefront of the fight against climate change. Ambitious targets have been set and achieved. However, when it comes to more ambitious targets than ambitious, I would like to make two comments on this. Perhaps it is not a celebration, because we have a multifaceted responsibility for the European population and for a European economy. So, in the case of more radical steps than radical, we must take into account that Europe is only responsible for 10% of emissions and, where appropriate, globally, there is not a reduction, but only a relocation. These aspects must therefore be taken into account in order to ensure the competitiveness of the European economy. On the other note, the most important thing about the Paris climate agreement is that it is legally binding. However, the European Union must also enforce this in all respects, and it is not possible for the United States, as one of the largest emitters, to have an attitude and then to deliver on who comes to power in the presidential election. Advocacy means that all parties do what they want to do.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, Mr Secretary-General, Europe is now demonstrating that it is capable of great things when it knows how to combine its energies and forces. But this Paris agreement did not fall from the sky; we had to contribute to it. That is why I would like to pay tribute here to the President of the French Republic, François Hollande, to the former Minister of Foreign Affairs, Laurent Fabius, and to Mrs Royal, whose hard work and perseverance I would like to stress here, since she has constantly reminded us of our work and our duty to ratify. It's done now.  A year ago, I said in this House that the European Union was not going to sign any agreement and that this agreement should be ambitious, robust and legally binding. It's done today.  So we have the chance to witness a movement that history will remember. I will tell Mr. de Graaff that this is not the first or last time you have missed your appointment with History. But history is progressing because it is a question of dealing with, I would say, perhaps too pathetic, one of the great causes of humanity. We take our future into our own hands and we can be proud to have done what we have done. (Applause)

name: Ivan Korčok
text: Council. – Mr President, I would like to start by expressing our gratitude and appreciation for the leadership the Secretary—General of the United Nations has shown in our common effort to agree on this ambitious Paris Agreement. Secondly, I would like to thank him for the ten years of his service to the international community as Secretary—General of the United Nations. Today the European Union is clearly reaffirming its commitment to continued climate action. Let me thank, therefore, this House, the Parliament and the Commission for their contribution and exemplary cooperation and to you, President, for your determination and efforts to ensure a speedy ratification of the Paris Agreement. This commitment is also about our credibility and responsibility and about the role that the European Union plays on the global stage. The EU worked hard for many years to shape the new climate action agreement and to make it possible last year in Paris. At the extraordinary Environment Council meeting last Friday we worked hard to secure the support of Member States for the decision on the EU ratification of the Paris Agreement. I am glad that later today the Council will formally adopt the decision on ratification. I want to assure this House, on behalf of the Presidency, that, as of today, we will start vigorously with its implementation. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you very much, Mr Korok. We now come to the voting procedure. First of all, I give the floor to the rapporteur and chairman of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Social Affairs, Giovanni La Via.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, as Chair of the Committee on the Environment and rapporteur, I am proud to recommend to the House to give the largest support to the EU ratification of the Paris Agreement.   Almost twenty years ago, the Kyoto Protocol was buried in the US Senate. Since then, the EU has been leading the international action to fight climate change and has worked hard to make Paris a success. Today I want to underline that the Paris Agreement will secure its entry into force in the House of European citizens. It is an historic moment and it is the outcome of great work together: Members of the European and national Parliaments, the EU Member States, the European Commission and the Council Presidencies. In particular, I would like to recognise the work of Commissioner Arias Cañete, with whom I have been in permanent contact during this process.  Today’s vote shows that the European Union delivers on promises made. We must, and we can, hand over to future generations a world that is more stable and prosperous, a healthier and cleaner planet. Today we are closer to it. Today we can! (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: We shall now proceed to the vote on the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Paris Agreement concluded under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. (The vote was taken) (The President announced the result) Votes cast: 679 votes in favour: 610 against: 38 abstentions: 31 (applause) I note that Parliament has approved the agreement. (The President signed the Convention)

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, last Sunday, the Irreecha festival in Ethiopia ended in a massacre. According to Oromo sources, 678 people were killed by security forces shooting into the crowd in cold blood and causing a stampede. Another 700 people have been murdered in Ethiopia in the past 10 months, as marathon runner Feyisa Lilesa denounced at the Rio Olympics. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights and the African Commission on Human and People’s Rights have called for independent observers to enter the country and assess the situation and for an impartial investigation. The EU, which pays lots of taxpayers’ money to the country via ODA, is silent. That silence is deafening. Will you, Mr President, speak up on our behalf in solidarity with the repressed people of Ethiopia and call for an international independent investigation into the Irreecha massacre and the ongoing repression in Ethiopia? (Applause)

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Madam Gomes, we will take note of your comments even though this was not a point of order.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: – That concludes the vote.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 To date, only seven Member States have ratified the Paris Agreement. That is why the European Commission has pushed for an exceptional mandate to present a single instrument of ratification on behalf of the 28 Member States. The Extraordinary European Environment Council of 30 September voted on a text modified in relation to the original, which refers responsibility to the Member States and the Union for meeting their emission reduction commitments. The Union's commitment to periodically and by legal means to achieve the reduction targets declared by the Member States under the Paris Agreement has also been eliminated. Since I believe that the agreement is a starting point for dealing with such an important and sensitive issue as climate change, and therefore ratification by all Member States is strictly necessary, I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement is the first legally binding international agreement to be adopted on climate change. It was adopted at the 21st UNFCCC COP, which took place in Paris from 30 November to 12 December 2015. I voted in favour of both the Union and the seven Member States that have completed the ratification process to deposit their instruments of ratification at the UN headquarters in New York on Friday 7 October, allowing the Paris Agreement to enter into force in time for COP22, which will take place in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016. The Social Democratic group in the European Parliament and the Spanish delegation have worked hard to make the Paris Conference a success, advocating for an ambitious and rapidly implementing agreement. The Socialists believe that the Union cannot fall behind other world powers when it comes to ratifying, so they voted favourably on the resolution enabling the Council to formally adopt the ratification decision by urgent written procedure.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are against this recommendation because we oppose the climate change alarmism supported by green lobbies, often financed by the EU Commission. They are the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of ratification on behalf of the Union of the Paris Agreement, since this is a symbolic gesture of validation of this agreement negotiated by the parties, which must then be ratified and implemented by each Member State of the United Nations. However, I do not share the triumphal rhetoric about this Paris Agreement. While my vote has been favourable, I find this agreement insufficient, since it is fundamentally based on voluntary commitments and market mechanisms that I criticised. I voted in favour of this minimum agreement, being aware that despite the progress, it is still far from an effective response to climate change.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. On 30 September, Member States agreed to the rapid adoption by the European Union of the Paris Agreement, without waiting for ratification by its 28 Member States. This agreement was approved in plenary today, which we welcome. The Paris Agreement will therefore come into force at COP 22 in Marrakech from 7 to 18 November; it is a historic moment for the planet: the international community will be able to lead the fight of the century against climate change. A year ago, the European Parliament called for legally binding climate targets, along with strong financial tools. The ambition is there: on the substance, and also by the speed of adoption by the Union!  It is now up to all of us to make it the starting point for a new European ambition: it requires a European budget that is up to the task, with its own resources, to achieve the ecological and economic transition and to fulfil Europe's commitments. This fight has only just begun.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, because I believe that this will send a strong message from the leadership of the European Union and its Member States as part of their global effort to combat climate change.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The Paris Agreements concluded after COP 21 are paved with good intentions. Together with my colleagues from the National Front, I opposed it, because they will have the major consequence of accelerating the deindustrialization of Europe, reduced to becoming a catchment area for manufactured goods under oppressive environmental and social conditions. Such an agreement is not credible given the high levels of pollution in the United States and China compared to those of European countries.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I am concerned about the potential impact of this on our energy policy. There is a need to find cost-effective means of renewable energy. However, artificial targets caused by an overly alarmist point of view lead to renewables being introduced before the technology is available to ensure that they are economically sustainable. A better approach would be a research-based one, solving the storage problem first before introducing forms of energy production which are, for example, intermittent.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because I believe that, since the European Union played a central role in the negotiation of this agreement, it is therefore right that it should now conclude it. In the coming months, our challenge will be to update the European climate law. However, let us aim not to annihilate the spirit of entrepreneurship with overly restrictive measures and to gradually drive European industry away from our borders.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of concluding the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change on behalf of the EU. The Paris Agreement is a major historic achievement in the fight against climate change and multilateralism. I agree that the ratification decision on the Paris Agreement will underline the clear leadership of the EU and its Member States and make an important contribution to the global fight against climate change.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are against this recommendation because we oppose the climate change alarmism supported by green lobbies, often financed by the Commission. They are the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This report proposes to give the Green Light to the Council for the ratification of the Cop21 Paris Agreement. On the essentials of the subject, I remain opposed to the tartufferie of the Paris Agreements, which will serve above all to accelerate the deindustrialization of Europe and to make it a catchment area for manufactured products produced outside the Old Continent under oppressive social and environmental conditions.  Indeed, it seems to me quite counterproductive to continue the strategy of 'decarbonisation of the economy' of the EU until China (which plans to increase its pollution) and especially the United States have joined European pollution levels in equivalent ton of CO2/habitant.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Paris Agreement is a historic event in the fight against climate change and for multilateralism. It is an ambitious, balanced, fair and legally binding agreement. In particular, it sets a long-term goal of taking global action to keep global temperatures well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. It also establishes a dynamic mechanism to take stock and adjust ambitions over time. The agreement provides for stakeholders to be legally obliged to take national mitigation measures to achieve the objectives set out in their contribution, but also provides for an ambitious solidarity mechanism between rich and less wealthy countries. Convinced that this agreement should accelerate the transition to a climate-resilient and climate-neutral global economy, I voted to adopt it.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which grants its approval to the conclusion of the Paris Agreement. At the Paris Climate Conference (COP21), held in December 2015, 195 countries signed the first global binding climate agreement. To avoid dangerous climate change, the Agreement establishes a global action plan that puts the global warming limit well below 2oC. The Agreement will enter into force in 2020.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The conclusion of the Paris Agreement, at the end of COP21, represented a fundamental step in the history of combating climate change, a decisive turning point towards effective action, collective and global, in a challenge that is among the crucial ones of our time. Europe can only take a leading role in this field, following the commitment already promoted in recent years and directing its efforts towards the creation of an economy that is both sustainable and competitive, designed to guarantee stability and social equity. I therefore voted wholely in favour of the La Via report, which approves the conclusion of the Paris Agreement and allows the European Union to join the 62 parties that have already ratified the agreement. Thanks to ratification by the EU, it will be able to enter into force in time for the COP22 climate conference to be held in Marrakech from 7 to 18 November.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which implies the adoption of the Paris Agreement, adopted by consensus in the last COP 21. Although this is a symbolic vote, since ratification has to be given at Member State level, it is important because it means that the European Parliament commits to the objectives of the Paris Agreement, asking each Member State of the Union to ratify the Treaty. The Agreement shall enter into force within one year from 12 December 2015.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. As hell was paved with good intentions, I preferred to abstain on this report which would allow the Council to ratify the Paris Agreement resulting from COP21. While environmental objectives are laudable, the constraints that Europe chooses to impose on its industries bear little weight in the face of China's economic strategies, which, although it has ratified the agreement, has already planned to increase its pollution. The same is true of the United States, which has certainly politically sent a strong symbol in ratifying the agreement, but which have still not reached European levels of pollution in equivalent tonnes of CO2 per capita. Finally, I understand that the Union is playing the stopwatch here, since ratification depends on its status at the next ICAO world summit in Montreal. The precautionary principle does not seem to apply to our industrial policies.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with what is said in the report analysing the conclusion of the Paris Agreement within the framework of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. I believe that with this agreement the EU has committed itself to securing substantial funding for developing countries without actually obtaining anything in return, either from an environmental or an economic point of view, and I am convinced that it will seriously damage the competitiveness of the productive fabric of our territories. At this time of very serious economic and social crisis in Europe, the Union should not sign agreements that are impossible to maintain unless it demands further sacrifices from our citizens. For all these reasons, I did not support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The Paris Agreement is the first legally binding international agreement on climate change. It was adopted at the 21st UNFCCC COP, which took place in Paris from 30 November to 12 December 2015. I voted in favour of both the Union and the seven Member States that have completed the ratification process to deposit their instruments of ratification at the UN headquarters in New York on Friday 7 October, allowing the Paris Agreement to enter into force in time for COP22, which will take place in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016. The Social Democratic group in the European Parliament and the Spanish delegation have worked hard to make the Paris Conference a success, advocating for an ambitious and rapidly implementing agreement. The Socialists believe that the Union cannot fall behind other world powers when it comes to ratifying, so they voted favourably on the resolution enabling the Council to formally adopt the ratification decision by urgent written procedure.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the Paris Agreement on the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The Paris Agreement is a major historic achievement in the fight against climate change and multilateralism. This agreement is ambitious, balanced, fair and legally binding. The adoption of the COP21 agreement and the announcement of the envisaged nationally determined binding action (INDC) at the end of COP21 is a decisive development for comprehensive and collective global action and will undoubtedly and irreversibly accelerate the transition to a climate-resilient and climate-neutral global economy. This global action aims to channel global development in such a way as to avoid dangerous climate change. The agreement recognises that the highest global greenhouse gas emissions target should be reached as soon as possible and the impact on the climate should be neutralised in the second half of this century. In addition, this agreement provides for an ambitious set of solidarity measures, including appropriate provisions on the financing of climate action and on meeting the needs associated with climate change adaptation and the negative consequences of climate change.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I supported the proposed decision on the conclusion of the Paris Agreement with the greatest pleasure, as it is a historically important milestone in the fight against climate change. The implementation and implementation of the agreement will mean an accelerated transition to a cleaner global economy, aware of the importance of limited natural resources. There is no doubt, however, that the implementation of the agreement definitively means that, in reducing the effects of climate change, it must finally move from words to action. The agreement calls for a halt to global growth in greenhouse gas emissions and for climate neutrality to be achieving after 2050. A key long-term objective of the agreement is to limit global warming to well below 2°C in relation to pre-industrial levels and to work to limit warming to 1,5 °C.  At the same time, the agreement clearly emphasises the transition from fossil fuels to other sources, which I think represents a great potential for the European, as well as for the Slovenian economy and jobs, especially in the area of the bioeconomy and circular economy. The EU has been at the forefront of the fight against climate change for many years and has already set itself an ambitious target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% by 2030 compared to 1990, to which EU Member States have already formally committed. This agreement only builds on those objectives.

name: David BORRELLI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased with today's vote and the European Union's ratification of the Paris Agreement, an historic moment because the ratification of the 28 EU Member States allows the agreement to enter into force quickly (thanks to the achievement of the necessary quotas: ratification of at least 55 contracting parties representing at least 55 % of total emissions). A first step, therefore, but still crucial and necessary. A first step that must now prompt us to implement new concrete actions to face the most important of the challenges between now and the next decades, otherwise this may not be enough. We must not, therefore, give up and it is a pity, from this point of view, that the Union's commitment to periodically and by legal means to verify the achievement of the reduction targets declared by the individual Member States under the Paris Agreement has been eliminated.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report. I believe that the decision to conclude the Paris Agreement will send a strong message and highlight the leadership of the EU and its Member States and their continued efforts to address climate change at international level.  I also consider the entry into force of the Paris Agreement a priority for the European Union, and I call on the Council to take as soon as possible all steps necessary to finalise its position on the ratification of the Paris Agreement.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: in writing. ‒ Like most Members of the European Parliament, I voted today in support of ratifying the Paris Agreement on climate change, probably the most important vote I have cast as an MEP. Now we have the plan, and now we must act. The energy, industry and transport sectors must act to reduce emissions – and so must the land-use sector. Agriculture has significant potential to reduce emissions, through agro-forestry for example. Forestry also has a major role to play as trees and timber soak up carbon, substituting for carbon-intensive steel, concrete and plastic. So let us design a framework of rules that incentivise farmers and the construction industry, working to the motto that ‘Man’s best friend is the tree’.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft Council decision to adopt the Paris Agreement signed in Paris on the 12 December 2015, because I firmly believe that the EU is a world leader in fighting climate change. Moreover, I think this decision strengthens the global role of the EU. Indeed, the Council now has the mandate from Parliament to ask the Member States to ratify the agreement simultaneously with the European Union.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Paris Agreement is a historically important achievement in the fight against climate change. It marked a turning point towards global collective action to achieve a global economy resilient to climate change and zero climate impact. It is necessary to stabilise greenhouse gas emissions as soon as possible and achieve climate neutrality in the second half of the century. The ratification decision on the conclusion of the Paris Agreement will send a strong signal and underline the continued efforts of the EU and its Member States to tackle climate change internationally. Therefore, the official entry into force of the Paris Agreement is a key priority of the European Union.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report proposes to give the European Parliament the approval of the Council for the ratification of the Paris Agreements resulting from COP 21. It is expected to enter into force on the 30th day from the date when at least 55 parties to the Convention, representing at least 55% of global greenhouse gas emissions, have filed with the United Nations documents attesting to their ratification.  However, the European Union must ratify the Agreement by October 7, when a meeting of the parties in Montreal announces its entry into force. We are opposed to the Paris Agreements, which will help accelerate deindustrialization in Europe. Indeed, it is counterproductive to commit to the decarbonisation of our economies until China and the United States have reached European levels of pollution in equivalent ton of CO2 per capita.  These states use environmental dumping as a tool to preserve their industries but especially their jobs. So I voted against it.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Paris Agreement, adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, is one of the most important achievements of our day. Today, more than ever, we see easily the harmful effect that man has on nature. With the approach of the world's states not changing, the looming scenario is a bad one: drought, fires and tropical storms. To prevent all these natural disasters, the United Nations aims to limit the increase in global warming to no more than 2 degrees Celsius by 2100. The conclusion of the Paris Agreement and its signing in New York on 22 April 2016 mark a moment of great importance, as the Union and its Member States have decided to act jointly, leaving the Commission and the Council to sign on their behalf. The Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement is the necessary basis for the conclusion of the Paris Agreement by the EU and its Member States, so I support the recommendation of my colleague Giovanni La Via, as it underlines the leadership of the Union and its Member States, as well as their continued efforts to combat climate change at international level.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement is the first legally binding international agreement to be adopted on climate change. It was adopted at the 21st UNFCCC COP, which took place in Paris from 30 November to 12 December 2015. I voted in favour of both the Union and the seven Member States that have completed the ratification process to deposit their instruments of ratification at the UN headquarters in New York on Friday 7 October, allowing the Paris Agreement to enter into force in time for COP22, which will take place in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016. The Social Democratic group in the European Parliament and the Spanish delegation have worked hard to make the Paris Conference a success, advocating for an ambitious and rapidly implementing agreement. The Socialists believe that the Union cannot fall behind other world powers when it comes to ratifying, so they voted favourably on the resolution enabling the Council to formally adopt the ratification decision by urgent written procedure.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP 21) is a historic agreement. It now has 177 signatories, which is a record for global climate agreements.  This binding agreement provides for effective and long-term measures to keep global temperatures well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, while striving to limit this increase to 1.5 degrees Celsius.  The European Parliament had to give its approval to this agreement so that the European Union could become a full signatory. I voted in favour of this historic agreement.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's positive vote, Parliament has sent out a strong signal. As specified by the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon, who is present in the European Parliament today, "we must seize the opportunity to make history for a better future, allowing the Paris Agreement to enter into force quickly in order to stimulate a more environmentally friendly economy. We need to show that we are united in the face of the climate challenge." I now call on the Council to take the necessary measures to ratify the Paris Agreement as soon as possible, together with the parallel processes of national ratification in the Member States, so as to complete the EU ratification process and deposit the instruments of ratification with the UN before the end of 2016. The ratification process by the Council and the Member States must be completed, especially in view of the recent ratification by the United States and China and the imminence of COP22 in Marrakech in November. It would be embarrassing for Europe to stay out of the decisions that matter in Marrakech and only participate as an observer, due to internal disputes between the Member States. We must not weaken the EU's historic and undisputed role in protecting the environment and the planet.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was a rubber stamp for the EU to join up to the Paris Agreement, agreed at COP21. This is the first time that 195 countries have agreed to a pact to reduce dependence on fossil fuels. There is still a long way to go before these points can be realised, but the agreement was a good start.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the ratification of the Paris Climate Agreement. This will trigger the entry into force of the first-ever universal, legally-binding global climate deal. I am proud to say that without Europe’s strong position on climate, the Paris Agreement would never have happened. The EU has been leading international actions to fight climate change and has worked hard to make the Paris Agreement a success. This is a step in the right direction to hand over to future generations a healthier and cleaner world.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament gave its consent to EU ratification of the UN Climate Protection Agreement, reached in Paris nine months ago. The Paris Agreement on combating climate change, the first ever global binding climate agreement, will enter into force next month, much earlier than expected, thanks to this historic vote. Ratifications of at least 55 countries representing at least 55 % of global emissions are required for the agreement to enter into force. While the first condition had already been fulfilled, this vote makes it possible to meet the second parameter and thus trigger the entry into force. The fight against climate change is not only one of the most important challenges of our time, but also the opportunity to build a more sustainable and competitive economy and more stable societies. I voted strongly in favour.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the ratification of the Paris Agreement on Climate Change. I do believe that it is a good step how to face issues related to preserving, protecting and improving the quality of the environment, as well as protecting human health and promoting measures at international level to deal with regional or worldwide environmental problems. I would like to call on all the parties of the agreement to ensure its swift implementation.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Those of us who have been following this process closely have suffered through many years of global climate summits where urgently needed consensus for action eluded us. While we are consumed by more immediate concerns, it is easy to forget or to belittle the urgency of finally stalling the increase in greenhouse gas emissions, before global temperatures tip over a level that will usher in catastrophic disruption beyond our control. Now that we have unblocked the ratification of the agreement by the EU, in the presence of UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon, the Council of Member States will follow suit and we can have it formalised at the UN headquarters in New York by Friday. But even if we make good on our collective commitments, that is still not good enough to keep temperatures from rising below 2 degrees Celsius. We must keep working together and acknowledge that fundamental choices in the very near future will determine the survival of the species.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the Agreement and stress Europe's commitment to take the lead in efforts to tackle climate change and to make progress towards a low-carbon economy.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Recommendation on the European Union's draft accession to the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change is a step in the right direction. As it is imperative that we make changes aimed at protecting the environment, I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure as the Paris Agreement is a historically important achievement in the fight against climate change and multilateralism. It directs global action to enable the world to avoid dangerous climate change.
