The agreement recognises the need to stabilise greenhouse gas emissions as soon as possible and to achieve climate neutrality in the second half of the century. I also share the rapporteur's view that he welcomes the Commission's draft proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Paris Agreement and considers that it provides the necessary basis for the conclusion of the Paris Agreement by the EU and its Member States. Furthermore, the implementation of the Paris Agreement will be an essential contribution to global efforts to combat climate change. For these reasons, I consider it important that the official entry into force of the Paris Agreement should be a key priority of the European Union.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against this report on the Paris Agreement on climate change. The Paris Agreement is a photocopy of the failed Kyoto Agreement; both agreements are strongly against the industrialised countries and, in reality, totally inefficient in the fight against climate change. An agreement that masks, behind important environmental issues, huge funding to developing countries, such as Arab oil, and which severely penalises our companies, which will be subject to binding regulations and related burdens, in order to favour emerging companies in other countries, having in fact provoked strong unfair competition.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the EU's ratification of the Paris Climate Agreement as this is a bold and collective initiative capable of definitively accelerating the transition to a global economy resilient to environmental change and zero emissions. As proof of this, the agreements include long-term objectives to keep global warming below 2°C, including the presentation of biennial inventories on gas use and the establishment from 2023 of a global budget to objectively assess progress towards what has been signed. There are also packages of provisions on climate finance and on reducing the vulnerability of our systems. The parties are legally bound by the adoption of the internal measures deemed most appropriate in order to achieve what was approved in conjunction with the European target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 40 % by 2030. The entry into force of the Treaty is essential, especially in view of cop22 to be held in Marrakech from 7 to 18 November.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the EU of the Paris Agreement adopted under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The conclusion of the Paris Agreement, as approved at the Conference of the Parties (COP 21) of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) in December 2015, is a victory for multilateralism in the fight against climate change. The fact that the agreement, as well as the nationally determined planned contributions (NDPC), are legally binding on the 187 parties is good news for the global fight against increased greenhouse gas emissions and the achievement of climate neutrality by the end of the century. To this end, I follow the ambitious long-term objective of limiting the temperature increase to 1.5 °C. To this end, I highlight the importance of five-year global balance sheets from 2023 on emissions progress and the obligation to submit a biennial greenhouse gas inventory by all parties. These are important steps towards greater transparency and accountability of states. I also welcome the commitment to benchmarking in scientific research and policy adoption. I call for the rapid deposit of instruments of ratification with the United Nations, maintaining the EU's leadership in this area. From the above, I support the recommendation.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I am pleased that our vote has reached the necessary threshold for the entry into force of the Convention. Not only are we talking, but we are actively campaigning for the fight against climate change!

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of ratification on behalf of the Union of the Paris Agreement, since this is a symbolic gesture of validation of this agreement negotiated by the parties, which must then be ratified and implemented by each Member State of the United Nations. However, I do not share the triumphal rhetoric about this Paris Agreement. While my vote has been favourable, I find this agreement insufficient, since it is fundamentally based on voluntary commitments and market mechanisms that I criticised. I voted in favour of this minimum agreement, being aware that despite the progress, it is still far from an effective response to climate change.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union concluded the Paris Agreement adopted at the 21st session of the Conference of the Parties (COP21) of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change held in Paris in December 2015. I voted in favour of this resolution, because I believe that this agreement represents an historic achievement in the fight against climate change and, in particular, in multilateral and collective action at global level in favour of a climate-neutral economy.  The EU had already set itself an ambitious target: to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at national level by at least 40 % by 2030. This objective is now being strengthened within the framework of the Paris Agenda, which recognises the need to stabilise greenhouse gas emissions as soon as possible and to achieve climate neutrality in the second half of the century. The Paris Agreement not only sets important targets, such as limiting the level of global warming to 1.5°C, but also helps to ensure transparency and accountability in emissions management through a strengthened mechanism that includes several binding measures. For example, the obligation of the parties to submit greenhouse gas inventories and a system of technical review by experts every two years.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Paris Agreement is an ambitious, legally binding agreement, but also a reference agreement for combating climate change and multilateralism. Global warming directly affects every EU citizen. The transition to clean energy is necessary and resources must no longer be based solely on fossil fuels. The agreement was signed by 187 states, which cumulatively covers about 98% of all emissions, making combating climate change a global effort.  I voted for the formal entry into force of the Paris Agreement, but also for joint and effective cooperation between Member States, in order to achieve the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% by 2030.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 At the Climate Conference in Paris in December 2015, 187 countries adopted the UNITED NATIONS Framework Convention on Climate Change, the main aim of which is to achieve a global peak in greenhouse gas emissions as soon as possible and to achieve climate neutrality by the second half of the century. The negative effects of climate change have been so great that global cooperation on the matter has become indispensable. Among other things, the agreement states that global warming should be kept below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial times and that temperature increases should be limited to a maximum of 1.5 degrees Celsius, and that a global clean energy transition is essential. Every five years from 2023 onwards, the Paris document calls for a global assessment meeting to discuss progress, consider the situation and work out further steps. The Member States of the Union are jointly responsible for taking such a decision of great importance, according to the reporter. The climate agreement cannot be signed without the EU, the continent has a leading role in the fight against global climate change. Ratification from the other Parties should take place later this year in order to achieve real results. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the signing, on behalf of the European Union, of the Paris Agreement adopted within the framework of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. It is very important to show the citizens of the European Union that the environment and the prevention of climate change are as important to us as the economy, for example. The implementation of the Paris Agreement will also play an important role in limiting the increase in the global average temperature to below 2°C before the industrial era. I therefore voted in favour because I believe that the formal entry into force of the Paris Agreement will bring the expected benefits, which should make it a priority for all Member States of the Union.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ It is extremely positive that the European Union will be ratifying the Paris Agreement. The implementation of the Paris Agreement will make a crucial contribution to global efforts to tackle climate change. The Council needs to take all necessary steps to finalise its position on the Paris Agreement ratification, as do the Member States, as soon as possible, so as to finalise the EU ratification process and deposit the instruments of ratification with the UN before the end of 2016. That is why I and the European Parliament are calling on the Council to take the final steps towards ratification and implementation.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The conclusion of the Paris COP Agreement in December 2015 is a historic act symbolizing the commitment of all countries of the world to a reduction in global warming caused by human activities. From words to deeds, it is now time to implement the commitments made at this summit. I fully support the ratification of COP 21 by the Member States and the Union, which will allow the agreement to enter into force. So I voted in favour.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In order for the Paris Agreement to enter into force, it was necessary for 55 parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, representing an estimated total of at least 55% of global greenhouse gas emissions, to ratify it. Following Parliament's approval, we were able to reach these thresholds and initiate the procedure for implementing the agreement.  Because the fight against climate change is a fight that we must fight together, I voted in favour of this resolution on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.  The entry into force of the Paris Agreement is a historic event giving our planet a legally binding framework to contain the rise in temperature to 1.5oC.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. The European Parliament has ratified the Paris Agreement, which I welcome as an essential step forward in the fight against climate change. I hope that States will in turn quickly engage in comprehensive and coordinated action for the environment.  This agreement includes several concrete measures, such as the development of clean energy by abandoning fossil fuels, global balance sheets every 5 years from 2023 and the upward review of ambitions over time, a legislative framework that promotes transparency and the obligation to present and justify accounts, and appropriate measures to finance the fight against global warming.  I support all of these measures and I am convinced that they will enable a common management of global difficulties and problems.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. The N-VA delegation has firmly approved the Paris climate agreement. The ratification of the EU brings the entry into force of this historic agreement a step closer and this is necessary. Climate change, together with biodiversity loss and resource scarcity, is one of the most important global challenges. A lack of vigorous policy has irreversible consequences and is detrimental to the planet, people and the economy. The Paris Agreement is the first legally binding global climate agreement and aims to limit global warming to well below 2°C.   We can only effectively fight climate change through global and concerted efforts. Europe has been at the forefront of the fight against climate change for years, but setting a good example is not enough. The EU cannot solve the problem alone. We need allies.  For the N-VA, the future of our children and grandchildren comes first. We must therefore tackle both the consequences and causes of climate change. The initiative of Flemish Prime Minister Geert Bourgeois for a Flemish climate and energy summit illustrates our commitment. The N-VA wants to combine economic growth and prosperity with a low-carbon economy. This implies that we make sustainable, efficient and effective choices that we can sustain for years.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Paris Agreement is a good step forward in protecting the planet to draw the EU's attention to its short- and long-term climate decisions and to achieve the zero emissions target over the next 50 years adopted by the Paris Agreement. This will also encourage investors, businesses and civil society to take measures to contain rising temperatures. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this text, which will make concrete progress in the fight against climate change. It highlights important points: the participation of all in the collective effort to reduce greenhouse gases, the need to rely on offensive diplomacy and innovative financial instruments.  On this point, my group pushed for the establishment of a dedicated financial transaction, decried by the right-wing forces. As far as I was concerned as co-chair of the public services intergroup, ahead of the drafting of this report, I had alerted the ENVI Committee, which has jurisdiction over the substance, to the need to properly articulate the issues of combating global warming and the values of public service, so that the energy transition does not come at the expense of the poorest and most isolated.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted to ratify the Paris Agreement on combating climate change because it is the first ever legally binding global climate agreement and it is urgent that this agreement can enter into force as soon as possible. This fight is not only one of the greatest challenges of our time.  It is also an opportunity to build a more sustainable and competitive business model, as well as more stable societies. For the agreement to enter into force, a double condition had to be met: ratifications representing at least 55 parties and 55% of global emissions were required. The first condition was already met.  The European Parliament's vote also allows the latter to be, triggering the entry into force of the agreement, less than a year after it was signed. Parliament's vote also allows the EU to remain a leader in climate. It also demonstrates that cooperation and joint management of difficulties are the only solution to global problems.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. One year after the COP21 summit, the European Parliament ratified the Paris Agreement, paving the way for it to enter into force. This is a very important moment for the planet. Through this legally binding agreement, 195 states commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions to limit global warming to 2 degrees above pre-industrial levels.  With Parliament's vote, the European Union is joining countries that have already ratified the agreement, such as the United States, India and China, to reach the threshold of 55 states-parties representing at least 55% of the global emissions needed to implement it. The next major climate conference, to be held in early November in Marrakech, should be an opportunity to continue on this path, and to consolidate the achievements of the Paris Agreement.  We can already be proud of how far we have come, but we must remain vigilant and demanding about the reality of what will be done to reduce global warming in practice.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ Mr President, I am willing to support this vote, albeit very cautiously.  The Paris Agreement will pursue emissions reductions through a ‘burden—sharing’ agreement between EU countries. However, the detail of this arrangement has yet to be finalised. There is surely a concern that some EU regions may have to take on a disproportionate burden in relation to these targets. In this sense, while we can debate and discuss and ultimately agree on these far-reaching international agreements, we must remember that the solutions affect ordinary people; farmers, consumers, households. I would therefore urge caution that, when ratifying this agreement, national authorities do not take these obligations lightly. In my own constituency, Northern Ireland, our most recent Programme for Government aims to reduce emissions by 35% on 1990 levels by 2025. The most recent report by the Cross-Department Working Group on Climate Change confirmed that we are there or thereabouts in meeting this goal.  So when voting today we should remember the work that is already underway at local level – and remain conscious of the burdens and sacrifices that have to be made by our citizens in the interests of these goals.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Positive in its whole, although in its articles, there are also issues that do not concern the protection of the environment which the rulers themselves destroyed and are simply now trying to save what is left.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the Paris Agreement marks a turning point towards comprehensive and joint action at global level. Its implementation will accelerate the transition to a climate-resilient and climate-neutral global economy. The Paris Agreement has set a target of keeping temperature rises below 2°C, setting limits on greenhouse gas emissions and, as a priority, helping countries more vulnerable to climate change. The aim of the agreement is to pass on a more sustainable, fairer, healthier planet to future generations. The approval of the European Parliament, which fulfilled the conditions for the entry into force of the Agreement, was key to its implementation. Hungary the first Member States of the European Union to close the internal ratification procedure of the Paris Agreement. Against this background, and in line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the approval of ratification.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the ratification of the Paris Agreement, which provides momentum for its implementation. Climate change is the greatest threat facing us today, and we in Wales need to do all we can to protect the planet and ensure the well-being of future generations. That is why I have called on the National Assembly to also ratify the agreement as soon as possible.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's ratification of the Paris Agreement marks an important moment in the global fight against climate change and allows the agreement to enter into force by the end of 2016. The Paris Agreement aims to keep global temperature rise well below 2°C and to continue efforts to keep it at 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. Although this is a key step, there are still many concerns about the real effectiveness of the agreement and the commitments of the parties. There is still a lack of serious will to address the climate impact of sectors such as agriculture and animal husbandry, and market instruments, such as the ETS, remain as a pillar of climate policies at global level as well, despite the proven ineffectiveness of this mechanism and the risk of favouring only financial speculation. Finally, there is still a danger that technologies such as CCS could be favoured, moving away from the real objective that should be the decarbonisation of our production systems.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement represents a feat of enormous historical significance in the fight against climate change. It is an ambitious, balanced, equitable and legally binding agreement.  It is decisive for comprehensive and collective action at global level, with the aim of transitioning to a global economy resilient to climate change. It shows solidarity with future generations. We must live well within the limitations of our planet. This agreement shall enter into force on the thirtieth day after the date on which at least 55 parties to the Convention, representing as a whole at least 55 % of total greenhouse gas emissions, have deposited their instruments of ratification, acceptance, approval or acceptance. To date, 62 countries responsible for 51.89% of global greenhouse gas emissions have deposited their instruments of ratification. The EU accounts for about 12% of global emissions. With EU ratification, the second criterion of 55 % of emissions is met.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the immense propaganda, the Paris Agreement does not fully meet the targets of reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. In fact, no concrete limits have been agreed on GHG emissions and the set of measures already announced by the overwhelming majority of the 195 countries that have adopted the text are insufficient to meet the proposed warming target. The Agreement maintains and legitimises a market approach to the problem of climate change of which carbon trading is the main (but not only) instrument. An approach based on the commodification and financialization of nature and its resources, which created transmarketable polluting rights and set its price at derisory levels. An approach that revealed to satiety all its ineffectiveness and perversity but in which it is insisted, although there are alternatives. The Agreement abandons the principle of 'common but differentiated responsibility' between developing and industrialised countries, opting for a single system that can deepen injustices between the countries that have contributed the most to the accumulation of carbon in the atmosphere and developing countries. Finally, the Agreement also includes a funding dimension for projects of large transnational groups in developing countries, enhancing the imperialist domination of the resources of these countries.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this draft resolution because I agree with the aims of the Agreement signed at the Paris Climate Conference, in the context of combating dangerous climate change. There are two objectives that I believe the resolution appropriately addresses: to slow down global warming and to reduce gas emissions into the environment.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the planet’s future is at stake.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union and its Member States have been leading the global fight against climate change for many years. The Paris Agreement represents huge progress for the whole world in the fight against climate change, leading to the adoption of many collective action at global level. These measures are intended to contribute to the creation of a globally climate-neutral global economy that is resilient to climate change. Currently, only 2% of global global emissions production is missing from the ratification targets, as the requirement for at least 55 Parties to the Convention has already been met. The Paris Agreement needs to be ratified by the end of 2016 at the latest, thus tying it to the Kyoto Protocol.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because, in my opinion, it changes little compared to the previous agreement, which proved to be unsuccessful, and contains many points that are also questionable from an economic point of view.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change because, although the Paris Agreement does not suffice to tackle global warming, I nevertheless consider it a small step in the right direction.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Paris Agreement is a historically significant landmark achievement for combating climate change and for multilateralism. It represents an ambitious, balanced, equitable and legally binding agreement. The adoption of the Agreement and the cumulative announcements by the end of COP 21 of Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs) by 187 Parties marked a decisive turning point towards comprehensive and collective global action, and, when implemented, will definitively and irreversibly accelerate the transition to a climate resilient, climate neutral global economy. This global action aims to put the world on track to avoid dangerous climate change. I believe that the ratification decision on the conclusion of the Paris Agreement adopted under the UNFCCC will send a strong signal and highlight the leadership of the EU and its Member States and their continuing efforts to address climate change at international level.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the Paris Agreement marks a turning point towards comprehensive and joint action at global level. Its implementation will accelerate the transition to a climate-resilient and climate-neutral global economy. The Paris Agreement has set a target of keeping temperature rises below 2°C, setting limits on greenhouse gas emissions and, as a priority, helping countries more vulnerable to climate change. The aim of the agreement is to pass on a more sustainable, fairer, healthier planet to future generations. The approval of the European Parliament, which fulfilled the conditions for the entry into force of the Agreement, was key to its implementation. Hungary the first Member States of the European Union to close the internal ratification procedure of the Paris Agreement. Against this background, and in line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the approval of ratification.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Ratification of the Paris Agreement under the UNITED NATIONS Framework Convention on Climate Change. The adoption of the Paris Agreement marks a turning point towards comprehensive and joint action at global level. Its implementation will accelerate the transition to a climate-resilient and climate-neutral global economy. The Paris Agreement has set a target of keeping temperature rises below 2°C, setting limits on greenhouse gas emissions and, as a priority, helping countries more vulnerable to climate change. The aim of the agreement is to pass on a more sustainable, fairer, healthier planet to future generations.  The approval of the European Parliament, which fulfilled the conditions for the entry into force of the Agreement, was key to its implementation. Hungary the first Member States of the European Union to close the internal ratification procedure of the Paris Agreement. Against this background, and in line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the approval of ratification.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of ratifying the Paris Agreement on climate change. Parliament's rapid and positive decision is historic because of its importance and the unity that has been demonstrated. The EU has accelerated the process for the Paris Agreement to enter into force as soon as possible, as EU ratification already reaches the minimum required for its implementation, which was 55 countries representing 55% of gas emissions. There is no doubt that the fight against climate change is an example of how the European Union represents all States and exercises common and necessary action at the global level with one voice. The Paris Agreement reflects countries' commitment to reducing greenhouse gases and it will be mandatory for States to submit climate contributions every five years. The essential objective is to prevent average temperatures from increasing by more than two degrees from pre-Industrial Revolution levels.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement is the first legally binding international agreement to be adopted on climate change. It was adopted at the 21st UNFCCC COP, which took place in Paris from 30 November to 12 December 2015. I voted in favour of both the Union and the seven Member States that have completed the ratification process to deposit their instruments of ratification at the UN headquarters in New York on Friday 7 October, which will allow the Paris Agreement to enter into force in time for COP22, which will be held in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016. The Social Democratic Group in the European Parliament and the Spanish Socialist Delegation have worked hard to make the Paris Conference a success, advocating for an ambitious and rapidly implementing agreement. The Socialists believe that the Union cannot be left out of other world powers when it comes to ratifying, so they voted favourably on the resolution enabling the Council to formally adopt the ratification decision by urgent written procedure.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement is the first legally binding international agreement to be adopted on climate change. It was adopted at the 21st UNFCCC COP, which took place in Paris from 30 November to 12 December 2015. I voted in favour of both the Union and the seven Member States that have completed the ratification process to deposit their instruments of ratification at the UN headquarters in New York on Friday 7 October, allowing the Paris Agreement to enter into force in time for COP22, which will take place in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016. The Social Democratic group in the European Parliament and the Spanish delegation have worked hard to make the Paris Conference a success, advocating for an ambitious and rapidly implementing agreement. The Socialists believe that the Union cannot fall behind other world powers when it comes to ratifying, so they voted favourably on the resolution enabling the Council to formally adopt the ratification decision by urgent written procedure.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of the Paris Agreement adopted under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, because I consider the consensus of the European Parliament for the conclusion of the Paris Agreement by the EU and its Member States to be of fundamental importance.  The Paris Agreement will enter into force immediately after at least 55 parties to the Convention (representing an estimated total of at least 55 % of the world's greenhouse gas emissions) have deposited their instruments of ratification, acceptance, approval or accession with the UN. There is currently a growing national push for the Paris Agreement to enter into force in 2016. Hence the importance of the EU as a whole ratifying the agreement taking into account the EU's leadership in the fight against climate change, its role in the Kyoto Protocol and its continued efforts for a subsequent universal treaty. For this reason, I shared the strong signal of support for ratification and therefore the call to the Council and individual Member States to take the necessary measures to complete the ratification process by the end of 2016.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Today we ratified the Paris Climate Agreement. I, too, voted in favour of this resolution, although I do not think that this opens any way for some Member States to take the eu ETS solutions that are bad for some Member States. Polish energy, but also of other Member States, is based on coal. This means that the economies of these countries must necessarily be more carbon-efficient. I have the impression that our EU climate targets will be solved mainly at the expense of the industry of these countries. The mechanisms of this artificial quasi-CO2 emissions market, i.e. the EU ETS, have great speculative potential, which, in my opinion, will not result in what we have committed ourselves to by ratifying the climate agreement. It's not a good thing.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The European Parliament has confirmed the signal of the Paris climate conference. We are serious. And we're speeding up. Just ten months after the UN climate conference in Paris, the EU has ratified the agreement. What matters now is that China and the US take their commitments just as seriously.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I am against this recommendation because I oppose the climate change alarmism supported by green lobbies, often financed by the Commission. They are the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. I voted against the ratification of the Paris climate agreement. What is presented to us as a binding agreement is in fact only what Roman law called a petition in principle. There is no legal requirement for states to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions, sanctions or financial incentives. There is no reliable and binding way to verify and measure the reality of the efforts to which the signatories have committed themselves. I think that the speed with which the United States, China, Brazil, India, among the most polluting countries on the planet, have ratified this agreement, even before the European Union, is a sign of its character above all declaratory. At least for these countries. For its part, the European Union has always been committed to setting itself as a global example of virtue. At the cost of the deindustrialization of the continent and mass unemployment. But in the end, the disastrous carbon footprint of its imports (production methods, long-distance transport) annihilates its efforts as a good student. No gain for the planet will result, but only new economic and social problems for Europeans.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which implies the adoption of the Paris Agreement, adopted by consensus in the last COP 21. Although this is a symbolic vote, since ratification has to be given at Member State level, it is important because it means that the European Parliament commits to the objectives of the Paris Agreement, asking each Member State of the Union to ratify the Treaty. The Agreement shall enter into force within one year from 12 December 2015.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I am delighted that we have ratified the Paris Climate Agreement. This is essential for the future of our planet and is a crucial step in the direction of a low—carbon future. Labour MEPs will continue to work hard in this field, as much more work must follow this agreement.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which will allow the ratification of the Paris Agreements. The agreement reached in Paris is a success. But this success must not stop there! The climate diplomacy of the Member States and the European Union must continue to intensify so that it is a natural part of our relations with other countries. Ratification must be swift because the implementation of each of the national contributions must be followed by concrete effects.  We know the effects of climate change on migration, food security, access to resources, water and energy, the spread of epidemics and social and economic instability. It is therefore essential that monitoring the issue of climate change involves all actors, public or private.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement is the first legally binding international agreement to be adopted on climate change. It was adopted at the 21st UNFCCC COP, which took place in Paris from 30 November to 12 December 2015. I voted in favour of both the Union and the seven Member States that have completed the ratification process to deposit their instruments of ratification at the UN headquarters in New York on Friday 7 October, allowing the Paris Agreement to enter into force in time for COP22, which will take place in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016. The Social Democratic group in the European Parliament and the Spanish delegation have worked hard to make the Paris Conference a success, advocating for an ambitious and rapidly implementing agreement. The Socialists believe that the Union cannot fall behind other world powers when it comes to ratifying, so they voted favourably on the resolution enabling the Council to formally adopt the ratification decision by urgent written procedure.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. I gave my full support to the historic agreement reached in Paris last year on climate change. Now is the time for countries that have ratified the agreement to increase their commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to contain average global warming well below 2 degrees Celsius.  The debate will now focus on the tools to be implemented to make this agreement operational and up to the challenge. To achieve these objectives, I support the creation of innovative financing to combat climate change, such as setting a floor price for a tonne of carbon or reforming the European carbon trading system. The establishment of a genuine circular economy and the boosting of renewable energies are also interesting avenues for action to be developed.  In addition, it is essential to eliminate subsidies for the fossil fuel sector, which will eventually lead to the abandonment of fossil fuels. Efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the transport and agriculture sectors must also intensify. Finally, the issue of climate refugees deserves our full attention.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The 2015 Paris Agreement is a historically significant landmark in the global fight against climate change. The Paris Agreement is a success for the world and a confirmation of the EU’s path towards a low—carbon economy. The EU’s negotiation strategy was decisive in reaching the Agreement. The EU has pushed for ambition, bringing its experience of effective climate policy and tradition of negotiation and rules-based international cooperation.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement is the first legally binding international agreement to be adopted on climate change. It was adopted at the 21st UNFCCC COP, which took place in Paris from 30 November to 12 December 2015. I voted in favour of both the Union and the seven Member States that have completed the ratification process to deposit their instruments of ratification at the UN headquarters in New York on Friday 7 October, allowing the Paris Agreement to enter into force in time for COP22, which will take place in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016. The Social Democratic group in the European Parliament and the Spanish delegation have worked hard to make the Paris Conference a success, advocating for an ambitious and rapidly implementing agreement. The Socialists believe that the Union cannot fall behind other world powers when it comes to ratifying, so they voted favourably on the resolution enabling the Council to formally adopt the ratification decision by urgent written procedure.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support the ratification of the Paris Agreement. Man-made climate change is occurring and it is having devastating impacts on many people across the globe. It is therefore essential that there is a global response to this problem, especially from the developed world. The EU, which played a decisive role in building the coalition of ambition making the adoption of the Paris Agreement possible last December, is a global leader on climate action and needs to continue to lead the way. So far, 62 parties, accounting for almost 52% of global emissions have ratified the Paris Agreement, and after the Council and Member States ratify the agreement it will enter into force. The European Commission has already brought forward the legislative proposals to deliver on the EU’s commitment to reducing emissions in the European Union by at least 40% by 2030, and now work on this legislation needs to begin – but it also needs to be fair towards all sectors of society.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the Paris Agreement marks a turning point towards comprehensive and joint action at global level. Its implementation will accelerate the transition to a climate-resilient and climate-neutral global economy. The Paris Agreement has set a target of keeping temperature rises below 2°C, setting limits on greenhouse gas emissions and, as a priority, helping countries more vulnerable to climate change. The aim of the agreement is to pass on a more sustainable, fairer, healthier planet to future generations. The approval of the European Parliament, which fulfilled the conditions for the entry into force of the Agreement, was key to its implementation. Hungary the first Member States of the European Union to close the internal ratification procedure of the Paris Agreement. Against this background, and in line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the approval of ratification.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Paris Agreement adopted as part of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, as this gives my consent to the conclusion of that Agreement, and I support ratification and entry into force as quickly as possible.  The European Union plays a key role in combating the effects of climate change globally and must therefore focus on the effective implementation of the Agreement through concrete policies and measures. I consider it of utmost importance that this is a uniform and legally binding agreement aimed, inter alia, at limiting the increase in global average temperature, encouraging the transition to clean energy, and respecting as much as possible the principles of accountability and transparency. Avoiding dangerous climate change is in the interest of all global actors, and I therefore support this Recommendation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Our opinion on the harmful effects of the Paris Agreements does not change. They will continue the deindustrialization of Europe and undermine social and environmental structures already well under way in our countries. The strategy to "decarbonize" our economy only weakens us further in the face of otherwise larger and harmful countries such as China and the United States, which, for their part, have been careful not to align themselves with European pollution levels. So I chose to abstain.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are against this recommendation because we oppose the climate change alarmism supported by green lobbies, often financed by the Commission. They are the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement is the first legally binding international agreement to be adopted on climate change. It was adopted at the 21st UNFCCC COP, which took place in Paris from 30 November to 12 December 2015. I voted in favour of both the Union and the seven Member States that have completed the ratification process to deposit their instruments of ratification at the UN headquarters in New York on Friday 7 October, allowing the Paris Agreement to enter into force in time for COP22, which will take place in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016. The Social Democratic group in the European Parliament and the Spanish delegation have worked hard to make the Paris Conference a success, advocating for an ambitious and rapidly implementing agreement. The Socialists believe that the Union cannot fall behind other world powers when it comes to ratifying, so they voted favourably on the resolution enabling the Council to formally adopt the ratification decision by urgent written procedure.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Paris Agreement is one of the most important milestones in the fight against climate change. I voted in favour of the EU's approval of ratification because compliance with the stated objectives of combating climate pollution and a responsible approach to the environment are the basis for maintaining a clean planet for future generations. The EU's 2030 sustainable development agenda targets, which include reducing greenhouse gases by 40% from 1990 levels and increasing the share of renewable energy to at least 27%, are an ambitious commitment by which the EU confirms its commitment to maintaining its commitment to maintaining the global player's lead in the environment and setting an example for other countries.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Giovanni La Via's report on the ratification of the Paris Agreement by the European Union. Through an unprecedented joint ratification procedure, we have officially approved and signed the Paris Agreement, which provides for containing global warming below 2 degrees Celsius and continuing efforts to limit the rise in temperatures to 1.5 degrees Celsius.  I welcome this vote which makes the European Union a major player in the fight against global warming. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Paris Agreement because it is a major agreement for the global issue of global warming. Thanks to this vote, the European Union will be able to quickly notify, along with several Member States, its ratification at the United Nations. It is important that the European Union is a leader on environmental issues.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Paris Agreement is a milestone of historic importance for the fight against climate change and for multilateral cooperation. I therefore voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on this.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Paris Agreement, signed by the 28 EU Member States in New York in April 2016, underlines the importance of action to combat climate change and clearly sets out the objective of achieving a 'climate-neutral global economy'. Among its most important provisions were the idea of limiting global warming below 2°C compared m.in to pre-industrial times (eventually to 1.5°C), as well as a clear message that it is necessary to move away from using scarce natural resources, such as fossil fuels, for clean renewable energy. All countries have also committed to adopting mitigation measures that will enable them to meet their declared targets (the EU has committed to reducing emissions by at least 40% by 2030). They will also meet every five years to present progress reports on reducing greenhouse gas emissions. In total, including european Community countries, 195 countries have declared the agreement to be signed and ratified and agreed to enter into force if ratified by at least 55 signatories responsible for at least 55% of global emissions.  The European Union plays a leading role on the international stage in combating climate change, which is why, in the document adopted today, we call for the agreement to be ratified as soon as possible.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 Climate change, global warming and the rise in average air temperatures are indisputable facts that the world has been facing for some time. For the most part, this is precisely the consequence of human activity, which is why the UN meets at climate change conferences every year and discusses ways and objectives of reducing these changes as much as possible. European Union countries have always set ambitious targets, for example by introducing an emissions trading scheme. However, it is clear that the EU alone cannot completely reduce global warming. This is a joint effort by the countries of the whole world. That is why, last November, in Paris, the UN Climate Conference signed an agreement with binding climate change mitigation targets. This was a major step forward, because without the consent of other major CO2 emitters, European efforts in this area would have been dedicated. That is why I voted in favour of ratifying the Paris Agreement at the European Parliament's plenary session in Strasbourg.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I was proud to vote, along with other Labour MEPs, in favour of the agreement today. It’s vital that we protect our planet for the next generation and seize the opportunities of the low—carbon revolution.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: in writing. ‒ Today we are welcoming good news. The Paris Agreement on climate change from December last year is a great achievement, in an otherwise challenging year for the EU and the United Nations, and its ratification proves that Europeans can work together and reach compromises that work for all citizens. I voted for the ratification of the agreement and I wholeheartedly support it. However, now the real hard work begins! In this Parliament, as well as in Member State parliaments, we must create and implement the policies that ensure we meet the targets set out in Paris. We must ensure we create a ‘just transition’ that does not punish working people and communities, but instead offers new, high-quality jobs for our constituencies and sustainable growth for our economies. Tackling climate change must be turned into an opportunity not just a challenge.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Paris Agreement is a logical step in the follow-up to the Kyoto Protocol, as it is essential that at least enough Contracting Parties accede to the agreement so that their total greenhouse gas emissions account for at least 55% of the global quantity. The ER, in cooperation with the EP, is ought to support the ratification of the Protocol by its resolution. In addition to the EU countries, Norway and Iceland have expressed their intention to participate in the joint action. Pursuant to Article 4 of Regulation No 1260/1999, the 16 Of the Paris Agreement, the level of emissions allocated to the Union must be in line with the emission level commitments of each Member State. In this context, land use and forestry, energy policy and climate change in the period up to 2030 are included in the newly prepared legislation. Both the Union and the Member States shall, in accordance with Article 4 of Directive 91/414/EEC, adopt the measures to ensure that the provisions of This Directive are complie 18 are jointly responsible for preparing an agreement on the notification and maintenance of nationally determined emission reduction contributions that they wish to achieve. The goal by 2030 is to achieve at least a 40% reduction in greenhouse gases. Every 5 years, starting in 2023, the States of the Paris Agreement undertake to evaluate the results and adjust the instruments necessary to achieve the best possible effect. The long-term goal of the agreement is to keep the global temperature rise well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels. Parliament, I hope, will support the objectives of the proposal for a Council decision by a significant majority.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Environmental protection is increasingly emerging as a topic for one simple reason. Humanity is at a point where it is still theoretically possible to save the vital ecosystems that we urgently need to survive on this planet. Ratification of COP21 is a step in the right direction and I am glad that the European Union has a leading initiative in this regard, but as we all know very well, this is only the first step. Moreover, it must be acknowledged that the agreement does not provide states with any binding guidance on how to achieve the objective. Moreover, there could certainly be conflicting discussions about its real legal enforceability. Everything is thus in the hands of individual states, where the agreement will have to undergo proper constitutional ratification. Personally, however, I consider it essential that we immediately follow up this great act with activities aimed at fulfilling it and try to effectively address the pressing problems of our time. I believe that we are able to move in this direction, which is why I voted yes in deciding on COP21.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the Paris Agreement marks a turning point towards comprehensive and joint action at global level. Its implementation will accelerate the transition to a climate-resilient and climate-neutral global economy. The Paris Agreement has set a target of keeping temperature rises below 2°C, setting limits on greenhouse gas emissions and, as a priority, helping countries more vulnerable to climate change. The aim of the agreement is to pass on a more sustainable, fairer, healthier planet to future generations. The approval of the European Parliament, which fulfilled the conditions for the entry into force of the Agreement, was key to its implementation. Hungary the first Member States of the European Union to close the internal ratification procedure of the Paris Agreement. Against this background, and in line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the approval of ratification.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the ratification of the Paris Agreement adopted under the UNITED NATIONS Framework Convention on Climate Change, as this is an important step for global action against climate change. The Consent of the European Parliament opens the way to overcoming the double threshold and the entry into force of the Paris Agreement ahead of the COP 22 Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016. A situation must be avoided where the agreement enters into force without the EU being a party to it, as the EU is a world leader in climate action policies and the world's largest financial donor.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The conclusion of the Paris Agreement was an historic day for Europe and for the whole world. In Paris, an ambitious path was outlined, to be implemented until the end of the century, to limit global warming "well below" 2°C and make efforts to keep it within 1.5°C.  This is an important decision because, as science shows us, rising global temperatures have a negative impact on all regions of the world. Glaciers melt and sea levels rise. In some areas, extreme weather phenomena and precipitation occur more frequently, while others are affected by severe droughts and abnormal temperature increases. The agreement provides for the reduction of the production of greenhouse gas emissions, through national commitment plans to be monitored and reviewed, in the light of progress made, every five years. Funding obligations are also provided to help the poorest countries develop less polluting energy sources. Europe has already done its homework to achieve the Paris objectives by putting concrete policy proposals on the table, while others are still being developed, to achieve EU targets.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained because, of course, the Paris Agreements are paved with good intentions, but they will serve above all to accelerate the deindustrialization of Europe and to make it a catchment area for manufactured goods in third countries under oppressive social and environmental conditions. It is quite counterproductive to continue the EU's strategy of 'decarbonisation of the economy' until China (which plans to increase its pollution) and especially the United States reach European levels of pollution in equivalent ton of CO2/habitant.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted to adopt this report, which validates the ratification of the Paris Agreement, negotiated at COP 21 last December. Indeed, ratification by the European Union allows us to reach the two "thresholds" set by the United Nations (55 countries and 55% of CO2 emissions) for the agreement to enter into force within a month.  This positive vote embodies the commitment of the European Union and its Member States to voluntary and realistic goals in the fight against climate change at the global level: a strong gesture for the future of the planet and that of our children!

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The Paris Agreement to Limit Global Warming aims to limit global warming below 2 degrees. Beyond that, the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) believes that the consequences of global warming will be uncontrollable. In order not to exceed this threshold, each signatory country commits to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions according to their level of responsibility and wealth. Each country will have to submit its contributions every 5 years to achieve this common effort. Finally, to pay off their "climate debt" the rich countries of the North are pledging to mobilize $100 billion a year in aid to adapt to the consequences of global warming.  To enter into force this agreement would require the signature of 55 countries representing 55% of global emissions. Without the European Union 62 countries representing 51.89% of emissions had already signed the agreement including the United States, China and India. With the ratification of the European Union to commit which I supported by this vote it will be done.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I abstained on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. This text will be used above all to accelerate the deindustrialization of Europe and to make it a catchment area for manufactured products under oppressive social and environmental conditions.  It is quite counterproductive to continue the EU's strategy of 'decarbonisation of the economy' until China (which plans to increase its pollution) and especially the United States reach European levels of pollution in equivalent ton of CO2/habitant.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I rejected this report, which proposes to give the Green Light to the Council to ratify the Paris Agreements resulting from COP21. Beyond the procedural issues of ratification, we remain opposed to these agreements.  Indeed, they will above all accelerate the deindustrialization of Europe, making it a gigantic market where manufactured products will pass through overwhelming socio-environmental conditions. Finally, it is utterly illusory to pursue the EU's strategy of 'decarbonisation of the economy', as long as the other trading and industrial powers do not keep up with each other. China (which plans to increase its pollution) as well as the United States are far from reaching European levels of pollution in equivalent ton of CO2 per capita.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement is the first legally binding international agreement to be adopted on climate change. It was adopted at the 21st UNFCCC COP, which took place in Paris from 30 November to 12 December 2015. I voted in favour of both the Union and the seven Member States that have completed the ratification process to deposit their instruments of ratification at the UN headquarters in New York on Friday 7 October, allowing the Paris Agreement to enter into force in time for COP22, which will take place in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016. The Social Democratic group in the European Parliament and the Spanish delegation have worked hard to make the Paris Conference a success, advocating for an ambitious and rapidly implementing agreement. The Socialists believe that the Union cannot fall behind other world powers when it comes to ratifying, so they voted favourably on the resolution enabling the Council to formally adopt the ratification decision by urgent written procedure.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement is the first legally binding international agreement to be adopted on climate change. It was adopted at the 21st UNFCCC COP, which took place in Paris from 30 November to 12 December 2015. I voted in favour of both the Union and the seven Member States that have completed the ratification process to deposit their instruments of ratification at the UN headquarters in New York on Friday 7 October, allowing the Paris Agreement to enter into force in time for COP22, which will take place in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016. The Social Democratic group in the European Parliament and the Spanish delegation have worked hard to make the Paris Conference a success, advocating for an ambitious and rapidly implementing agreement. The Socialists believe that the Union cannot fall behind other world powers when it comes to ratifying, so they voted favourably on the resolution enabling the Council to formally adopt the ratification decision by urgent written procedure.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of ratification on behalf of the Union of the Paris Agreement, since this is a symbolic gesture of validation of this agreement negotiated by the parties, which must then be ratified and implemented by each Member State of the United Nations. However, I do not share the triumphal rhetoric about this Paris Agreement. While my vote has been favourable, I find this agreement insufficient, since it is fundamentally based on voluntary commitments and market mechanisms that I criticised. I voted in favour of this minimum agreement, being aware that despite the progress, it is still far from an effective response to climate change.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This Recommendation approves the conclusion of the Paris Agreement on behalf of the European Union.  The European Union has long been a leader in the fight against climate change and approving this agreement confirms this. The Paris Agreement is a historic milestone in the fight against climate change that has brought together nearly 200 countries in their ambition to reduce CO2 emissions to limit global warming through ambitious, balanced, equitable, and legally binding measures.  I am voting in favour of this momentous Agreement, as it will guide irrevocably and decisively towards a climate-neutral global economy and serve as a precedent that collective and effective global action is possible. We must provide next generations with a more stable and prosperous future through a sustainable and healthy world.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this recommendation on the Paris Agreement. The agreement sets out a qualitative long-term emissions reduction goal.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 The treaty is vague, it does not contain any measurable obligations or mechanisms for enforcing them, so even with the treaty life will go as before, you could say that the treaty is toothless and useless. Nevertheless, it encourages participating states to take action from the EU: action plans, gender policy, regulations, contributions and subsidies. These policies have not worked, and have so far led to much damage, the destruction of land by canola and solar panels, the rise in energy and food prices, tax increases, and the cessation of economic growth. So what should be done when I think these contracts are ineffective? When countries get richer, they naturally limit pollutant emissions and want more forests and parks. And that's good. We must therefore not regulate countries to stagnation. Economic growth, natural care for the environment, safe nuclear energy and the development of modern technologies are the best way to reduce greenhouse gases.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒The Paris Climate Agreement is a key achievement in the fight against climate change, and its adoption has taken a decisive turn towards comprehensive and joint global action and efforts to mitigate global warming. These efforts must not be seen as barriers to economic growth, but as a driver of new sustainable growth and employment.  On 6 March 2015, the EU and the Member States submitted their envisaged and nationally specific contributions to the UNFCCC, which commit to achieving the binding target of reducing domestic greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% by 2030.  This requires active involvement of Member States and support for the Moroccan Presidency in its focus on the contribution of renewables in the fight against climate change. It is necessary to increase the scope of measures by 2020 in order to meet targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, renewable energy and saving energy. Given the impact that the exploitation of raw materials and waste management have on greenhouse gas emissions, the transition towards a global economic model of the circular economy must be adequately covered in COP 22. I believe that a globally agreed push towards innovation in clean and renewable energy technologies, essential to achieve climate goals and boost growth, is needed, so I supported this resolution.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 Today the European Parliament ratifies the largest and first ever binding agreement on climate change. An overwhelming majority in plenary of 610 votes in respect (90%) behind the text. This was a historic vote to ensure that the Paris Agreement on combating climate change will enter into force by the end of the year. For the first time, the agreement commits countries to take concrete measures to limit global warming to below 2°C. Europe is a global leader in the battle against climate change, and today we have strengthened this. Let us not forget that this is just the beginning of a long road and it is up to all of us to turn this agreement into a success.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Paris Agreement aims to achieve climate neutrality through fundamental change in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and a gradual transition to new technologies. In the second half of this century, only as much emissions as nature will be able to cope with will be released. The agreement sets out obligations for all Parties not only in the area of monitoring, but also in reducing emissions. The European Union generates around 12% of the world's greenhouse gas emissions. For the Paris Agreement to be valid, at least 55 Parties to the Convention, which together account for at least 55% of global greenhouse gas emissions, need to ratify and deposit related instruments at the UN. I am pleased that Slovakia is among the seven Member States of the Union that have completed the national process of ratifying the Paris Agreement.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. Following the agreement reached on 30 September by the environment ministers of the 28 Member States, the European Parliament voted today on the Paris climate agreement. Thanks to a large majority in which I participated, the European Commission should quickly ratify the Paris Agreement without going through the ratification of each Member State. To enter into force, the agreement had to be ratified by at least 55 states representing more than 55% of global greenhouse gas emissions. Today, the 28 Member States of the European Union are in addition to the 62 countries that have already ratified the agreement and which account for 52% of global greenhouse gas emissions.  With ratification by the European Union, the Paris Agreement will enter into force at the 22nd UN climate conference to be held from 7 to 18 November in Marrakech. I welcome that.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 As I have stressed before, the Paris Climate Change Treaty (COP21) did not create a clear framework for tackling the phenomenon of climate change because, among other things, it did not address two major problems that we will have to face in the future. The first major problem is that of the production model responsible for global warming and the second is that of climate migration. The Paris Agreement (COP21) makes no reference to the status of a climate refugee or migrant although, for the period 2008-2013 alone, the number is estimated at 166 million. Finally, the process of ratifying this Treaty at EU level and its adoption by the European Parliament before its ratification in the Parliaments of the Member States of the Union is complete is contrary to the letter and spirit of both the Treaty on European Union (EES) and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (EU TREATY).

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained for this text. This text aims to enable the Council to ratify the Paris Agreement resulting from COP21. However, this agreement calls for the deindustrialization of Europe and risks turning our continent into a catchment area for manufactured goods under scandalous social and environmental conditions, which we oppose.  Moreover, it is counterproductive to continue our efforts to "decarbonize the economy", as long as China and the USA remain well above European thresholds on the value of CO2 per capita.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ Cooperation among EU Member States is important in order to address climate change at an international level. Therefore, I voted in favour of the Resolution on the draft Council decision on EU conclusion of the Paris Agreement. The agreement is a basis for effectively combating climate change through the employment of sustainable methods and practices. Limiting global warming is one of the main goals, and European Union Member States are showing their interest and involvement in the matter by having set an ambitious target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% domestically by 2030.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. COP 21, despite its inevitable limitations, is an undeniable success story of multilateral climate diplomacy. And from this perspective, the decision of the 28 Member States of the European Union to collectively ratify the Paris Agreement is a very positive expression of European integration and the affirmation of the Union as a central player in this green diplomacy. It is vital that states remain committed to the implementation of the Agreement.   With this ratification, the Paris Agreement will enter into force at COP 22 in Morocco. The speed of ratifications is a key factor in its proper implementation, and already 62 states representing 52% of global greenhouse gas emissions have ratified the Agreement.  I therefore voted wholeheartedly in favour of this ratification.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Commission's draft proposal for the Paris Agreement because I believe that the EU should play a leading role in the fight against climate change and work towards a later global treaty. I also believe that the decision to conclude the Paris Agreement will send a strong signal and highlight the leadership of the EU and its Member States in efforts to tackle climate change at international level. At the same time, it will make a decisive contribution to the efforts of the rest of the world to tackle climate change.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This is about the Paris Agreement (COP 21). This agreement is intended to protect our climate and our environment, but this agreement is not a step in the right direction and is incompatible with my understanding of climate protection. Here, nuclear energy is seen as a tried and tested means of achieving emission reduction targets. Furthermore, the study by the Corporate Europe Observatory (CEO) shows that the same global players who also support TTIP and CETA sat at cop 21. That is why I rejected this agreement.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the European Parliament's decision to ratify the Paris Climate Change Treaty. I believe that this will help to address the most important issues of climate change at international level.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The EU is a full part of the Paris COP 21 agreement on global warming in addition to its 28 countries. However, the current rules do not allow it to ratify the agreement until the 28 Member States have done so. While some members (such as France) have already ratified the agreement, others are pushing back the deadline (Poland).  The report proposes to allow the EU to ratify the Paris Agreement, before it has been ratified by all member states. This allows the EU to ratify the agreement before its effective date, which is expected to be 30 days after being ratified by at least 55 countries representing 55% of emissions. With this decision, the EU would be allowed to sit on the UN decision-making body that will organise the next stage of the agreement on 7 November, at COP 22 in Marrakech.  In the end, the main aim is to enable the EU to obtain a full seat in a UN body. This will also allow it to congratulate itself on having ratified an outdated agreement since the goal of limiting warming to 2oC is already circumvented and exceeded. All for that! I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report proposes to give the Green Light to the Council for the ratification of the Cop21 Paris Agreement. On the essentials of the subject, we remain opposed to the Paris Agreements, which will serve above all to accelerate the deindustrialization of Europe and to make it a catchment area for manufactured goods under oppressive social and environmental conditions. It is quite counterproductive to continue the EU's strategy of 'decarbonisation of the economy' until China and especially the United States reach European levels of pollution in equivalent tonnes of CO2 per inhabitant. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement represents a major achievement of great historical significance in the fight against climate change and multilateralism, and is an ambitious, balanced, equitable and legally binding agreement. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I was proud to vote in favour of this resolution giving Parliament’s consent to the Paris Agreement. As the EU is one of the principal actors in the fight against Climate Change, it is essential that it continues to play a leading role in addressing global warming.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – In the middle of last century, it was found around the world that our climate was going in the wrong direction. In the meantime, scientific research has shown that industrial activities are at the root of climate change. In 1997, Kyoto was the first to curb emissions of harmful greenhouse gases. Many climate conferences would follow. With varying degrees of success. Because either large industrialised countries such as the US and China remained on the sidelines, or ambitions were adjusted. That is why the Paris Climate Agreement is 'historic' for a variety of reasons. One: because all partners have now taken the climate threat seriously and are immediately committed to limiting the temperature rise to 1.5 °C.  Secondly, rapid ratification is achieved through a strengthened multilateral approach, which provides evidence that global challenges are best addressed if they are addressed together. Now it is important to quickly develop a concrete and ambitious climate policy in order to achieve that target of 1.5°C. This presupposes serious efforts to reduce emissions of harmful gases, introduce new energy technologies and develop a totally sustainable economy. With this ratification, the EU reaffirms its global commitment to a better environment.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The Paris Agreement, adopted on 12 December 2015 under the UNITED NATIONS Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), represents a decisive shift from action by a small number of actors to comprehensive and collective action at world level – the agreement already has 191 signatories. The Agreement shall be open for signature from 22 April 2016 and shall enter into force if at least 55 Contracting Parties to the Convention, which together account for at least 55 % of global greenhouse gas emissions, deposit their instruments of ratification, acceptance, approval or accession with the United Nations. To date, 62 parties have ratified the agreement, which together account for around 52% of global greenhouse gas emissions. I believe that the decision to ratify the conclusion of the Paris Agreement at Member State and EU level would contribute, by the end of 2016 at the latest, to highlighting the position of the EU and its Member States, to their sustained efforts to tackle climate change at international level, as well as to overall international efforts to combat climate change. I am therefore voting in favour in favour.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Conclusion on behalf of the EU of the Paris Agreement adopted under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change. The Agreement was reached last year in the UN Climate Conference in Paris. There is no time to waste, or the human, economic and environmental consequences will become unbearable. By protecting our planet, we will also be setting the path for a smart and sustainable economic growth.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The EU ratification of the Paris Agreement contributes to the conclusion of the 55% threshold needed in order for the agreement to enter into force. By voting in favour of this recommendation, I gave full consent for the urgent ratification and implementation of the Paris Agreement in Europe. A historic vote that marks the first global climate deal, which is legally binding and will come into force in November 2016 – just in time for the COP 22 Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 At the 21st Conference of the Parties to the UNITED NATIONS Framework Convention on Climate Change held in Paris between 30 November and 12 December 2015, the text of an agreement was adopted to strengthen global responses to the challenge of climate change. The Commission called for the Paris Agreement to be signed and ratified as quickly as possible, and in its decision of 18 March 2016, the European Council underlined the importance of the agreement being adopted as soon as possible by the EU and its Member States. At the high-level signing ceremony held in New York on 22 April 2016, the Agreement was corked by the Commission and the Council by the European Union and by all 28 Member States. The ratification of the Agreement requires a decision of the Council, with the agreement of Parliament. In its report, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety proposes that Parliament agree to ratify the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement, adopted in December 2015, is a global victory in the fight against climate change.
