Climate change is underway and human action has been the main cause of climate warming since the middle of the 20th century. The Paris Climate Agreement was a historic achievement in the fight against climate change and is to welcome the commitment made to reduce global emissions to zero net emissions during the second half of the century. The EU must endeave to exert pressure on parties that are not yet in line with the one outlined by the Paris Agreement. I support the need for further efforts to ensure the mobilisation of financial resources to combat climate change in order to reach the us$100 billion target by 2020. From the above, I support the recommendation.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report aims to give the green light to the Council for the ratification of the COP21 Paris Agreement, which will come into force when at least 55 countries representing 55% of global gas emissions have ratified it. China and the United States have already ratified the Agreement, speeding up the implementation process. The Council can only ratify the agreement on behalf of the EU with the approval of the European Parliament.  However, this agreement is highly critical as it risks accelerating the deindustrialization of EU countries and giving even more competitiveness to those countries that have chosen not to ratify it.  The United States or China do not have the same per capita CO2 emission requirements. Finally, this jurisdiction must be left to the states alone and not to the EU. So I decided to vote to abstain.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the conclusion of the Paris Agreement on behalf of the European Union. The mobilization of the international community in the fight against global warming is necessary and must not stop. I therefore welcome the adoption of this agreement, which calls for keeping global warming 'well below 2oC above pre-industrial levels' and 'continuing efforts to limit the rise in temperatures to 1.5oC'.  From now on, we will have to look very carefully. States' compliance with their contributions, as part of the transparency mechanism that will lead a committee of international experts to publicly verify the information provided by countries in terms of monitoring their emissions and the progress made in reducing them.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the devastating effects of climate change, a scientifically proven historical reality, would become irreversible once the limit threshold of a temperature rise of two degrees has been exceeded; Whereas the Heads of Government of 195 countries are committed to limiting this increase to one and a half degrees; demonstrated the unfounded theory that environmental measures curb growth and, on the contrary, convinced that climate change mitigation and adaptation policies represent a long-term investment; taking into account that, over the last thirty years in Europe, the fall in greenhouse gas emissions has been matched by an increase in gross domestic product; observed the reality of the more than 19 million people forced to leave their homes for environmental reasons; considering our responsibility to future generations; finally, analysed the scientific and economic analyses in support of these theses, we express, with strong conviction, a vote in favour of the approval of the Paris Agreement. In view of the long-held negotiations which have lasted twenty years, the outcome of Paris is in fact a political and diplomatic victory, as well as a European one, of the multilateral system itself. The credibility of the United Nations was, in fact, threatened by the failures that preceded and followed the depressing outcome of the Copenhagen Conference.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The Paris Climate Agreement is not only about the environment, but it is one of the last possible global peace agreements. The expected climate change may trigger major withdrawals from nations, which is already causing armed conflicts. In turn, the promotion of clean alternative energy sources consciously replaces the oil and gas that humanity has been waing increasingly bloody wars in recent decades.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ We have reached a world limit in the climate change problem. I have voted for this recommendation, which will bring about important measures in achieving the EU’s objective for the global climate change issue.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2015 Paris Agreement is the first multilateral agreement on climate change covering almost all global emissions. The agreement is a worldwide success and a confirmation of the EU's orientation towards a low-carbon economy.  The Energy Union project provides a broader framework in which the EU can provide an appropriate favourable environment for the energy transition. According to the International Energy Agency, full implementation of climate plans will lead to $13.5 trillion in investments in energy efficiency and low-carbon technologies between 2015 and 2030, with an annual average of $840 billion. In addition, the future Energy Union Research, Innovation and Competitiveness Strategy will take advantage of synergies between the energy sector, the transport sector, the circular economy, as well as industrial and digital innovation. This should increase the competitiveness of current and future low-carbon and energy-efficient European technologies.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which endorses this historic Agreement signed in Paris by 187 parties and which aims to protect the habitat in which we live, leaving it equally agreeable to generations to come. The agreement itself is a clear message to investors in industry, business, civil society and policy makers and reiterates in a broad consensus that the global transition to clean energy is crucial at the moment, and this objective will be achieved by phasing out the use of fossil fuels. The report also calls for the establishment of a strengthened transparency and accountability framework and for all parties involved to submit greenhouse gas inventories and information needed to track their progress. Another strength of this report is that of the dynamic mechanism it is considering in drawing up this balance sheet, but also the measures needed to increase the extremely ambitious objectives in the years to come.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the agreement to the Paris Agreement on climate protection, which will allow the EU to become an official signatory to the agreement and, as a result, the agreement to enter into force. This is a responsible, ambitious, balanced agreement that includes cost-appropriate commitments to reduce CO2 emissions globally. Fulfilling the commitments will allow the world to avoid dangerous climate change, which, for example, poses a risk of drought in the Czech Republic. The agreement recognises that a peak in global greenhouse gas emissions should be achieved as soon as possible and climate neutrality should be achieved in the second half of this century. The development of new technologies and the fall in their price create the conditions for even relatively ambitious climate protection targets to be achieved at a cost that does not threaten the stability and growth of economies, often even boosting them. I believe in the success of the agreement, to which other large CO2 emitters, such as the US, Russia and China, have signed up in addition to the EU. The political will of all stakeholders to transfer commitments from paper to reality is essential.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. \u2012 The Paris Agreement is an achievement of historic importance for the fight against climate change and for multilateralism. The creation of a reference value for climate protection is of the utmost importance. The decision to ratify the conclusion of the Paris Agreement will send a strong signal and highlight the leadership of the EU and its Member States, as well as their on-going efforts to tackle climate change at international level. The implementation of the Paris Agreement will make a key contribution to global efforts to combat climate change and therefore its formal entry into force is a top priority for the European Union.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report because the report mainly favours those states that rely on nuclear power. If the report contained binding targets for the share of renewable energy, my decision would have been different. Unfortunately, Austria has always been affected, although we produce much cleaner than many other countries.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The decision to conclude the Paris Agreement sends a clear signal that combating climate change is a priority for the EU. The Paris Agreement sets important objectives with which the EU is jointly committed by taking steps to combat climate change. It is also important that this agreement is ratified by the EU Member States as soon as possible.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this recommendation for the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.  It should be noted that this agreement is a crucial global step towards strengthening global collective action and accelerating the global transition to a low-carbon and climate-resilient society. It is therefore very important that the agreement enters into force as soon as possible, because only through joint efforts can we strengthen the response to the threat posed by climate change and achieve the objectives set. In addition, the provisions of the agreement will increase the opportunities for economic transformation, job creation and growth.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution giving the European Parliament its approval for the ratification of the Paris Agreement to combat climate change. The entry into force of the agreement less than a year after it was signed is a huge achievement, given that it took eight years for the Kyoto Protocol to enter into force. The European Union, which accounts for around 12% of global greenhouse gas emissions, reaffirms its leading role in combating climate change. Together we are now moving towards implementing the EU's commitment to reduce emissions in the European Union by at least 40 % by 2030. Thanks to EU ratification, the Paris Agreement will enter into force in time for the COP 22 Climate Change Conference to be held in Marrakes.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Paris Climate Agreement, the product of temporary compromises between imperialist centres and powerful capitalist countries, neither wants nor can it address the acute environmental problems created by capitalist development, since it treats the environment as a means of increasing the profitability of business groups, while having a devastating effect not only on uncontrolled fundraising, but also on imperialist wars. The Agreement concentrates on the various 'pollution trading systems', which, as profitable mechanisms for the sale of pollution itself, have been proven to exacerbate environmental degradation. Green technologies aim to open up new investment areas in monopolies, amid fierce competition, which the EU is leading, since it considers its business groups to have a comparative advantage. The sure result of this agreement will also be the deterioration of environmental problems, the living conditions of the people's families. Only an economy and a society based not on capitalist profit, but on meeting popular needs, can ensure a compatible and balanced influence of the working man on nature, on the environment. For such a life the working people must take power and the economy into their own hands, breaking with their capitalist barbarism, monopolies and imperialist associations.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. I have agreed to the ratification by the European Union of the Paris Agreement. This vote allows it to enter into force at the 22nd United Nations Climate Conference to be held from 7 to 18 November in Marrakech. To enter the agreement the agreement had to be ratified by at least 55 states representing more than 55% of global greenhouse gas emissions.  With 63 countries accounting for 64% of global greenhouse gas emissions, the account is good. This is a first victory. Never has an international agreement been ratified so quickly by the signatory countries.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are against this recommendation because we oppose the climate change alarmism supported by green lobbies, often financed by the Commission. They are the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague's proposal because I believe that the ratification of the Paris Agreement is a prompt and effective response to the problem of climate change. The European Union must ratify a project for a better life, a project that can protect and preserve our planet in such a way that it can guarantee a future for future generations. The climate agreement represents a huge challenge and, in the light of global problems, we need a global response, from which the European Union cannot fail. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I supported this report, as I believe it is high time to take concrete actions to combat climate change. The Paris Agreement is a global milestone for enhancing global collective action and accelerating the global transformation to a low-carbon and climate resilient society. The quick ratification decision by the EU on the conclusion of the Paris Agreement adopted under the UNFCCC will send a strong signal and highlight the leadership of the EU and its Member States and their continuing efforts to address climate change at international level.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Paris Agreement aims to keep global temperature rise well below 2°C and to continue efforts to keep it at 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. The agreement will enter into force on the 31st day following the date on which at least 55 parts of the UNFCC, representing at least 55 % of global greenhouse gas emissions, have deposited their instruments of ratification. Today, the joint ratification of the 28 Member States of the Union is a key historic step in the entry into force of the agreement. The agreement is a clear sign to investors, business, civil society and the political class that the global transition to clean energy is vital for future generations and therefore resources must increasingly move away from fossil fuels. I remain critical of attempts to exploit neutralisation technologies such as carbon capture and sequestration, not only because they are highly expensive, but also, above all, because they distance us from the real objective that should be the decarbonisation of our production systems. In any case, today's is an historic moment. I voted in favour of the EU ratification process and I hope that the Member States will choose the same path as soon as possible.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ The Paris Agreement – that’s what citizens understand and welcome. My hope is that the legally binding Paris Agreement is the beginning of a more sustainable earth balance!

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported this legislative resolution, which represents one significant step towards the entry into force of the Paris Agreement. Unfortunately, after the initial euphoria surrounding the agreement reached at the end of 2015, the EU did not take the necessary steps and it seemed as if we had all fell asleep together. The EU ratifies this agreement after it has already been ratified by 62 countries responsible for 51.89% of greenhouse gas emissions, and its decision allows the Agreement to enter into force this year. Aware of my responsibility to future generations, I can say that I am proud that today, on behalf of the citizens of Croatia and the EU citizens I represent here today, I have had the opportunity to support one of the most important decisions this Parliament has made to save our planet.  It is our responsibility not to give in and to continue our work and, in cooperation with the Council and the Commission, to prepare appropriate legislative proposals that will enable the implementation of the Agreement in a way that will strengthen our economy and create new jobs in the development and application of technologies that are compatible with the objectives set.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Protecting the environment is a priority for all. But the European Union does not have to ratify international agreements, it is up to the sovereign states to decide democratically what they want to commit to. Moreover, the zeal of the European Union is counterproductive: it imposes strict standards on its members, but opens its market to countries that produce according to much more flexible criteria. Thus, the European Union is actually promoting global pollution by encouraging industry from third countries to polluters and the transport of ever greater quantities of goods over long distances. Customs barriers protecting the environment and local producers would be far more effective than this type of agreement. It is inconsistent to get involved in COP21 while negotiating TAFTA. So I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. The Paris Agreement is the most important and first legally binding global climate agreement. The most important objective of this agreement is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and limit the increase in global average temperature to well below 2 °C.  The Paris Agreement enters into force on the thirtieth day from the date on which the parties to which at least 55 % of the estimated global greenhouse gas emissions are depositing their ratification instruments to the UN. So far, 19 have deposited their ratification instruments, representing a total of 0.18% of all global greenhouse gas emissions. Believing that it was impossible for the Paris Agreement to enter into force without the EU signing it (the EU and MS expressed their intention to act together in fulfilling the provisions of the Paris Agreement), Parliament gave its approval to ratify the Paris Agreement. Eu ratification allows the treaty to enter into force as the coverage criterion for at least 55% of estimated global greenhouse gas emissions is met, which is why I am extremely proud of today's ratification. The decision to conclude the Paris Agreement again highlighted the EU's leadership in the fight against climate change.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the immense propaganda, the Paris Agreement does not fully meet the targets of reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. In fact, no concrete limits have been agreed on GHG emissions and the set of measures already announced by the overwhelming majority of the 195 countries that have adopted the text are insufficient to meet the proposed warming target. The Agreement maintains and legitimises a market approach to the problem of climate change of which carbon trading is the main (but not only) instrument. An approach based on the commodification and financialization of nature and its resources, which created transmarketable polluting rights and set its price at derisory levels. An approach that revealed to satiety all its ineffectiveness and perversity but in which it is insisted, although there are alternatives. The Agreement abandons the principle of 'common but differentiated responsibility' between developing and industrialised countries, opting for a single system that can deepen injustices between the countries that have contributed the most to the accumulation of carbon in the atmosphere and developing countries. Finally, the Agreement also includes a funding dimension for projects of large transnational groups in developing countries, enhancing the imperialist domination of the resources of these countries.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 With the participation of UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-ban and French Environment Minister Ségolène Royal, the European Parliament approved the Paris Agreement on Climate Change, the so-called COP21.  First of all, I would like to stress that it was the members of social democracy who were most concerned with the creation of this document. But we're only at the beginning of the process. This agreement must now be ratified by all Member States and, in particular, its implementation will be important. We must not just stay put, but we must invest in clean technologies, renewable energy and energy efficiency, a subject that I am addressing as a matter of priority in the Field of the European Parliament. This will be a major challenge for the whole of the European Union, but especially for the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe, to whom the EU should be more helpful in transiting towards a low-carbon economy. Finally, I would like to remind you that the agreement on the new emission allowance market rules (ETS) will be the key to implementing the ambitious agreement. However, the resulting similar one is far from being decided.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The swift decision by the EU to ratify the Paris Agreement on the basis of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) will send a strong signal and highlight the central role of the EU and its Member States, as well as their efforts to prevent climate change at international level. The implementation of the Paris Agreement will play a key role in global efforts to combat climate change and limit the increase in the global average temperature to below 2°C before the industrial era. The formal entry into force of the Paris Agreement is a key priority for the EU. I hereby supported the report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Personally, I have a problem with the way that was chosen for ratification of the Convention. I believe that national parliaments should not be circumvented in these important treaties.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Union's ratification of the Paris climate agreement signed in December 2015. This agreement, adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, is a universal and binding text. If it is respected by the States Parties to the agreement, its implementation will increase the necessary fight against global warming.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The conclusion of the Paris Agreement is one of the most ambitious demonstrations of cooperation, understanding and compromise on climate matters and has been adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change of December 2015. Indeed, the Paris Agreement represents a historic achievement in the fight against climate change and, in my view, appears ambitious, balanced and equitable. Among some of the characteristics that the Agreement includes, it would fundamentally highlight the incentive to cooperate between its 187 Parties, its binding nature, the express need for energy transition under its rules, exemplified by the suggestion of the gradual abandonment of fossil fuels. From my point of view, the implementation of the Paris Agreement, under the signs of international cooperation and the binding ness of its rules, will be a fundamental contribution to the fight against climate change. In this way, I am pleased to be aware of the success of the conclusion of the Agreement, hoping that it will be fulfilled by all parties and proud of the European Union's cutting edge in environmental matters. That said, my vote is in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are against this recommendation because we oppose the climate change alarmism supported by green lobbies, often financed by the Commission. They are the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. October 4, 2016 is a great day. I voted for the EU's ratification of the Paris Agreement, which represents the culmination of a long battle for binding targets to fight, together at the global level, against the greatest challenges of the 21st century, global warming. With the adoption of the Paris Agreement in the European Parliament, as the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon, has said, we are making history by taking effect.  This is a great step for humanity and the planet and, as an MEP, I am proud that the European Union has played a leading role in bringing this agreement to fruition. Now we must look to the future, the entry into force of the Paris Agreement is only the beginning of a long struggle. This vote is not a mere formality but a political signal to translate our commitments through action. At European level, several pieces of legislation are on the table to translate the Paris Agreement, and Parliament will have to live up to the challenge by adopting ambitious emission reduction targets.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Recommendation because I believe that it establishes a dynamic evaluation mechanism that allows for more ambitious targets to be defined over time in matters related to climate finance and adaptation-related needs and the losses and damage associated with the adverse effects of climate change. This recommendation thus creates a better framework for transparency and accountability, including the biennial presentation by all parties of greenhouse gas inventories and the information needed to monitor progress, an assessment by technical experts, a multilateral review and facilitator of the Parties' progress and a mechanism to facilitate and promote compliance with standards. The Paris Agreement sets a global goal for the first time to strengthen capacity, increase climate resilience and reduce vulnerability to climate change.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. In view of the European Union's leadership in the fight against climate change, it would be inconceivable that the Paris Agreement would enter into force without the European Union as a signatory. Ratification of the conclusion of the Paris Agreement adopted under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change will send a strong signal and highlight the leading role of the EU and its Member States, as well as its continued efforts to combat climate change at international level. It will also be a key contribution to global efforts to combat climate change.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement is the first legally binding international agreement to be adopted on climate change. It was adopted at the 21st UNFCCC COP, which took place in Paris from 30 November to 12 December 2015. I voted in favour of both the Union and the seven Member States that have completed the ratification process to deposit their instruments of ratification at the UN headquarters in New York on Friday 7 October, allowing the Paris Agreement to enter into force in time for COP22, which will take place in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016. The Social Democratic group in the European Parliament and the Spanish delegation have worked hard to make the Paris Conference a success, advocating for an ambitious and rapidly implementing agreement. The Socialists believe that the Union cannot fall behind other world powers when it comes to ratifying, so they voted favourably on the resolution enabling the Council to formally adopt the ratification decision by urgent written procedure.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted in plenary to ratify the Cop21 Paris Agreement. After the time of decisions will come the time of deeds, with COP22 taking place in Marrakech, Morocco. This will enable the Paris Agreement to implement the measures adopted in the Paris Agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and effectively combat global warming. The European Union and the major industrial powers must engage with willful on the path of a decarbonised economy, with the cooperation of economic actors. The fight against climate change is also one of respect for human rights.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation. I think this is a historic moment when the vast majority of MePs have shown an understanding that the fight against climate change is necessary here and now. This step has led to the entry into force of the Paris Climate Change Agreement. Now we need to focus and move from languages to jobs. Already today we need to think about the 2050 targets and how we will implement them.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament approving the Paris Agreement. The agreement marks a historic turning point in the global fight against climate change. The limiting of the rise in global temperatures is ensured by confirming the warming threshold below 2oC, as well as setting an ambitious indicative target of 1.5oC.   The planned nationally determined contributions (NDCPs) of the signatory parties ensure comprehensive and collective action, while a new dynamic mechanism will allow for an upward review of the objectives set by the agreement every five years. The text also provides for a framework for transparency and enhanced accountability. Finally, the agreement includes a solidarity mechanism requiring industrialized states to finance aid to poor countries vulnerable to rising temperatures.  The European Parliament's approval of the Paris Agreement paves the way for the ratification of the text by the European Union. This act demonstrates Europe's leading role in the fight against climate change and its unwavering commitment to the transition to clean energy.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement represents a historic milestone in the fight against climate change and is ambitious, balanced, fair and legally binding.  It represents an irreversible turning point on the road to a global economy resilient to climate change, through global action on the path of climate neutrality that is intended to be achieved in the second half of this century. The EU has taken a leading stance in the fight against climate change, given its role in this plan since the Kyoto Protocol. The EU and its Member States should therefore take the necessary measures to complete their national and European ratification processes by the end of 2016, taking into account the ambitious target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40 % domestically by 2030, as well as achieving the emissions reduction commitment for the period 2020—2030.  Like the rapporteur, I agree that the decision to ratify this agreement will give a strong signal and highlight the leading role of the EU and its Member States in combating climate change at international level, and it is therefore important to finalise the ratification process with the Council and its Member States as soon as possible.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which constitutes the ratification by the European Parliament of the Paris Agreement concluded at the end of COP21 in December 2015. The agreement is the first universal and legally binding global climate agreement in terms of environmental protection and greenhouse gas emissions reduction. This ratification must be followed by a concrete and effective implementation that must involve and involve all public and private actors. The European Union must continue to be a central international player and a leader in the fight against climate change. This agreement represents a step in the european Union's action, not an end in itself.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which implies the adoption of the Paris Agreement, adopted by consensus in the last COP 21. Although this is a symbolic vote, since ratification has to be given at Member State level, it is important because it means that the European Parliament commits to the objectives of the Paris Agreement, asking each Member State of the Union to ratify the Treaty. The Agreement shall enter into force within one year from 12 December 2015.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of a draft recommendation on the Paris Agreement, which is part of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The aim of the historic Paris Agreement is to ensure that, from 2050, no more carbon dioxide is emitted worldwide than is absorbed at the same time (CO2 neutrality). The Recommendation emphasises that time arrangements are minimum requirements and that every effort must be made to accelerate CO2 reduction as soon as possible.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of ratifying the Paris climate agreement because it was a hard-negotiated compromise, the beginning of which was the will of the states to reach an agreement. I consider this a great diplomatic achievement. I also see the presence of UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-ban in ratifying the agreement in the European Parliament as an appreciation of the role played by the EU and its Member States throughout the negotiation process.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of ratification on behalf of the Union of the Paris Agreement, since this is a symbolic gesture of validation of this agreement negotiated by the parties, which must then be ratified and implemented by each Member State of the United Nations. However, I do not share the triumphal rhetoric about this Paris Agreement. While my vote has been favourable, I find this agreement insufficient, since it is fundamentally based on voluntary commitments and market mechanisms that I criticised. I voted in favour of this minimum agreement, being aware that despite the progress, it is still far from an effective response to climate change.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's approval marks the beginning of an important new chapter in the global fight against climate change. It will allow the EU to ratify the Paris Agreement and its subsequent entry into force before the end of the year. It is a historic milestone that sets the long-term goal to counter global warming and keep temperatures rising below 2°C above pre-industrial levels. I voted in favour of the agreement in the hope that the joint efforts made by all parties will result in concrete and achievable strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Finally, I believe that it is essential for all the world's economies to take equivalent measures in order to achieve this important objective for the environment and health, while at the same time ensuring fair conditions of competition for our globally competing industrial sectors.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Convention on Climate Change highlights the leading role of the European Union and its 28 Member States in combating climate change. This stance follows a good European tradition which had already been highlighted in the Kyoto Protocol. With a commitment to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by around 40 % domestically by 2030, the Union is thus seeking to help contain the temperature rise below 2°C compared to the pre-industrial season. Because of the importance of this theme, I voted positively.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I do not recognise the EU’s competence in this area.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On 4 October 2016, the European Parliament approved the ratification of the Paris Agreement by the EU. This is a very important, first-ever binding climate agreement. Europe has succeeded in building a front of support for ambitious environmental and climate goals, as EC President Jean-Claude Juncker also stressed in his speech. The ratification of the agreement by the EU, which worked hardest to create it, also has a symbolic tone, as it has exceeded the threshold of at least 55 parties, accounting for at least 55% of global emissions, which will allow the document to enter into force. However, it should be stressed that reduction efforts and the promotion of climate-friendly solutions must be implemented without harming development and innovation, and must take into account in detail the specific nature of the different sectors (e.g. energy, transport, agriculture). It is worth noting that agriculture and forestry have a special relationship with the climate and the environment, as in addition to greenhouse gas emissions into the atmosphere, they are the only ones with great potential to absorb and store compounds that affect climate warming.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, along with colleagues in the European Parliament, I voted to give consent to the ratification of the Paris Climate Agreement in the European Parliament. Although most Member States still have to ratify the Paris Agreement, today’s vote from the European Union now ensures a swift start for COP21.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ The Paris Agreement is a legally binding agreement that marks a turning point of historical importance in the fight against climate change. The fact that the 195 countries adopted the agreement through joint agreements reflects a major shift in joint global action. Key commitments are laid down, such as limiting the rise in global temperature to well below 2 °C, reducing global emissions, the global clean energy transition, establishing national measures to mitigate climate change, etc.  Its ratification in the European Parliament, which we are witnessing today, is a historic moment for all of humanity, as it sends a strong message and highlights the European Union's efforts to address climate change. In doing so, we must not see it only as solving a particular climate problem that we face, but as a change in the overall paradigm of man's relationship to his planet. As a representative of the Greens/ESS, I am extremely proud of the current achievements and the fact that this agreement was voted by a large majority, with the votes of as many as 610 MPs, including mine.  I am of the opinion that better cooperation between countries in the field of sharing scientific knowledge on adaptation and information on practices and policies will be encouraged in the future, thereby contributing to the efficiency of the implementation of the objectives.  In support of this, I point out that the use of clean and green technologies is also the first step on the road to sustainable development that we are all striving for.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the decision to ratify the Paris Treaty to be the most important vote in the EP this year. Each of us must be aware of the urgency of air protection and the need to reduce greenhouse gases so that our planet remains green for generations to come. The seriousness of the vote is also evidenced by the fact that UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has personally visited the European Parliament and, in his brief speech to MEPs, urged the approval of the Paris Agreement and implementation in practice as soon as possible. The Paris Agreement sets a long-term goal of limiting global warming well below 2⁰C above pre-industrial levels and making efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5 ⁰C. The EU has always been at the forefront of climate and air protection, and with today's vote, where 610 Members have spoken in favour of the Paris Agreement, this is testament to this.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the legislative resolution by which the European Parliament agrees with the Council decision on the conclusion of the Paris Agreement adopted under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change on behalf of the European Union. With the consent of the European Parliament, significant progress has been made in ratifying the agreement, which can therefore take effect. For the EU, which is the world's third largest emitter of emissions and also a major world leader in the fight against climate change, this also means that it will not be a mere observer in important negotiations, but will allow it to address the details of the implementation of the Paris Agreement with other parties, in particular other emission giants such as China and the US. The Paris Agreement will enter into force on 4 November 2016, before the COP22 climate change conference in Marrakesh.  The Czech Republic supports the ratification of the agreement on behalf of the EU as a whole. As part of the national ratification process, the Czech Government has already given its consent. The agreement will now be referred to Parliament for approval and then to the President for signature. I believe that other Member States will also take a responsible approach to ratification.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. The European Parliament overwhelmingly approved the ratification of the Paris Climate Agreement. This is important and good news for international climate policy and shows that if there is political will, things can move forward. Multilateral and international cooperation pays off. Ratification by the European Union is exceptional because most EU Member States, including Belgium, have not yet ratified it. This could, in theory, lead to a situation in which the EU is negotiating at the Marrakech climate summit on behalf of Member States which are not empowered to say anything themselves. Member States are wary of this situation, but because countries such as the US and China ratified so quickly, the EU had to go along. The choice was whether to make rapid ratification by the EU or an international mud figure and have nothing to say as an EU. The knife was on the throat. From now on, the emissions of the six Member States that have already ratified will be heading towards the 55% emissions threshold that the climate agreement has brought into force. This plugs a gap of 3.1 percent in emissions. The Paris Agreement officially enters into force at the beginning of November. That is in time for the start of the climate summit in Marrakech.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The Paris Agreement is a great achievement of European diplomacy. Our objectives have also been joined by countries such as China, without which any climate agreement would be ineffective. I am pleased that the Slovak Republic was among the first countries to ratify it.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 Protecting the environment is a global challenge for all mankind and our commitment to future generations at the same time. That is why I voted in support of the Paris Agreement on climate protection. The eu's adoption of the agreement will enter into force and signatory countries will be able to start systematically working towards fulfilling the joint commitments. The agreement is already a historic success in its early stages because, for the first time ever, other major CO2 producers, notably China, Russia and the US, have joined it in addition to the EU. Its main objective is to keep global warming growth below 2 C°, but at the same time as close as possible to 1.5°, thus preventing further dangerous climate change. Another commitment is to gradually limit greenhouse gas emissions so that climate neutrality is achieved in the second half of this century. In my opinion, the agreement is a bold and balanced text. It should not only bring environmental achievements, but also serve as an opportunity for the development of new technologies and the growth of the economy. I appreciate that the agreement works with real, economic stability that does not threaten the costs of implementing it. I believe that all signatory countries will take a responsible approach to the common global commitment.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on the 'draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Paris Convention concluded under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change'. It is an agreement to tackle climate change. The climate changes as long as the earth exists. Climate change policy is based on hypothetical climate models based on computer-aided simulations of the IPCC ("Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change"). Carbon dioxide (CO2) is not a pollutant, but an indispensable component of all life. I therefore do not share the fundamental assumptions of man-made climate change. I do not support a policy on this basis. I do not think that keeping global warming well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels should be a political goal. The planned compulsory reduction of CO2 emissions weakens the economic location and lowers the standard of living. Combating supposedly man-made climate change is destabilising and making our previously secure electricity supply more expensive. The AfD says "yes to environmental protection", but puts an end to the "climate protection policy" and the plans for decarbonization and "transformation of society".

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Climate change is a global problem. They can be recognized everywhere in the world, regardless of their cause. The Paris Agreement is seen as an extremely significant multilateral instrument to prevent climate change, which aims to highlight the importance of energy efficiency, the use of renewable energy sources and the reduction of emissions of harmful substances. The stability of the climate system is important for food safety, energy production, water and biodiversity conservation. It also needs to help less developed countries affected by the effects of climate change, as they lack resources to mitigate and adapt to climate change. The agreement covers key points for resolving the problem and contains long-term objectives that are intended to be achieved. Under the EU Treaty, the European Union aims to contribute to solidarity and sustainable development of the planet Earth in relations with the rest of the world. Under the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, the European Union's environmental policy promotes action to combat climate change internationally. The EU, as an important actor in climate diplomacy, plays one of the leading roles in the fight against climate change. The ratification of the Paris Agreement comes one step closer to its entry into force. Due to the utmost importance of the agreement, I support the recommendation on the draft Decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Paris Agreement adopted as part of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Paris Agreement adopted on the basis of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The Paris Agreement is an important milestone in the fight against climate change, as it is an ambitious, balanced, fair and legally binding agreement. I would like it to be signed as soon as possible by the European Union, which plays a leading role in the fight against climate change. Member States should therefore take the necessary measures to complete the ratification procedures by the end of 2016. This would demonstrate that the European Union wants to continue to play a leading role in the world in the fight against climate change.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Paris Agreement created an important framework for tackling climate change. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement, to send the message that the agreement must be implemented immediately by everyone. However, it is important to make progress on key elements of the Paris agreement and to set more ambitious targets that bind everyone. In order to succeed, unfair profit must cease to define the policies being promoted. The needs of society and people must be put at the heart, not the interests of multinationals and monopolies. That's the only way we're going to protect the environment. In particular, the EU and rich countries must take the lead with perseverance in order to set new targets to combat energy poverty, to end the reckless use of natural resources, to end deforestation, to reduce greenhouse emissions and to develop a comprehensive plan to support and promote renewable energy sources. If this is not done, then the EU will be responsible for trampling on the human right to a quality life.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We believe that the Paris Agreement is not enough to tackle global warming but it is nevertheless a small step in the right direction.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which approves the proposal for a Council decision. I agree with the finding that the Paris agreement is of historic importance in the fight against climate change and also in terms of the number of signatory countries. I think it is important to note that a total of 187 parties have announced their planned national contribution to the agreement by the end of COP 21. The Convention marks a turning point towards comprehensive and joint action at global level and the transition to a climate-neutral global economy. The Paris Agreement enters into force 30 days after at least 55 Parties, collectively responsible for at least 55% of greenhouse gas emissions, have deposited their instruments of ratification, acceptance, approval or accession with the UN. It is important to note that, as a first step, the Commission and the Council signed the Agreement on behalf of the European Union and all 28 Member States during the solemn high-level signing ceremony held on 22 April 2016 in New York. MePs consider it inconceivable that the Paris agreement should enter into force without the EU's signature, taking into account the EU's leading role in the fight against climate change. It therefore urges the Council and individual Member States to take appropriate steps by the end of 2016 at the latest to complete the EU and national ratification process.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a report because the EU and also Finland are committed to the objectives of the Paris Agreement on climate change. However, I would like to stress that the European Commission's proposals to implement the objectives of the Climate Agreement are not, for the time being, heading in the right direction, particularly in the LULUCF and burden-sharing sectors. The specific characteristics of sustainable Forest Management in Finland must be better taken into account in the further preparation of these directives.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. On Tuesday, the European Parliament ratified the Paris Agreement - COP21; a procedure for validating the text which allows not to go through the specific ratification of each Member State. Our signature means above all that we endorse the commitments made in Paris. This is a clear signal that Europe intends to meet its commitments for a transition to a low-carbon economy and society. The challenges remain: to set up an Energy Union, to continue to support the conditions conducive to innovation and the job creation that this transition will generate. Europe must be a leader in the energy transition.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The Paris Agreement has now been signed by 191 countries, and the EU ratification will officially bring the Agreement into force. The Agreement aims to limit global temperature increases at national level through climate pledges. The EU’s contribution to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions will account for a 40% reduction from levels in the 1990s. I voted in favour of the EU ratification of the Paris Agreement to ensure the quick entry into force of the Agreement. The EU has played a significant role in combatting climate change and must now work hard to implement internal policies that will bring to light the promises made. I believe that it is our duty as Europeans to ensure not only a clean and safe environment for us here in Europe, but equally to set an example by promoting environmental ambitions and conscientiousness to other nations who share with us this one world.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. The Paris Agreement, concluded in December 2015 at COP 21, is a historic agreement. It sets out binding standards to stop the ravages of climate change, illustrated in particular by the increase in the number of people refugees for climate reasons.  By this ratification, the European Union, through the voice of its Parliament, is up to this historic requirement. This agreement, by limiting the rise in temperatures to less than 1.5oC and that of greenhouse gas emissions, commits the international community for the future, even if the means of this transition to a new, more sustainable and decarbonized development model are to be implemented, in order to effectively combat global warming.  This should not be the umpteenth good intention, but a new step in an ambitious European strategy that requires a substantial European budget, with its own resources, to achieve the ecological and economic transition and to fulfil Europe's commitments.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the conclusions of the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), as I believe this will highlight the leadership of the European Union and the Member States and continue to address climate change internationally.  In fact, I believe that the implementation of the Paris Agreement will make a key contribution to global efforts to combat climate change and keep the global average temperature rise to a much lower level of 2°C compared to pre-industrial levels. As the implementation of this Convention will achieve the objective of adapting the environmental system to climate change, will allow economic development to continue in a sustainable manner and will not jeopardise food production, I believe that this report should be approved by the European Parliament without delay.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Paris Agreement, adopted on the basis of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, on behalf of the European Union. The Paris Agreement is a historically important milestone in the fight against climate change and in multilateral cooperation. This joint action is to help the world find the right direction and prevent dangerous climate change. The agreement recognises the need to halt global greenhouse gas emissions as quickly as possible and to achieve climate neutrality in the second half of this century.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which implies the adoption of the Paris Agreement, adopted by consensus in the last COP 21. Although this is a symbolic vote, since ratification has to be given at Member State level, it is important because it means that the European Parliament commits to the objectives of the Paris Agreement, asking each Member State of the Union to ratify the Treaty. The Agreement shall enter into force within one year from 12 December 2015.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report and I am convinced the EU can and will play its role. The Paris Agreement is potentially a historic one and we in the EU must do everything possible to give it a chance to succeed at the end of the day.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Paris Agreement is a summary of global efforts to combat climate change and limit the increase in global average temperatures. It is part of the EU's sustainable development policy, which must reconcile economic growth with the need to preserve the environment for future generations. The Member States of the European Union have played an important role in negotiating this agreement. The swift ratification decision will highlight the central role of Member States in animating actions at international level that prevent climate change. In formal terms, the European Union's agreement to the Convention will mean reaching the threshold required for ratification, and therefore the entry into force of the Paris Agreement as early as November this year. For these reasons, I support this recommendation.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Paris Agreement represents a historic milestone in the fight against climate change. At today's session of Parliament, we heard the position of UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon. Joint action for the protection of the environment is our primary task and the EU institutions have a key role to play in this. I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which implies the adoption of the Paris Agreement, adopted by consensus in the last COP 21. Although this is a symbolic vote, since ratification has to be given at Member State level, it is important because it means that the European Parliament commits to the objectives of the Paris Agreement, asking each Member State of the Union to ratify the Treaty. The Agreement shall enter into force within one year from 12 December 2015.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the ratification of the Paris Agreement as it was vital that the Union ratified this Agreement before and thus began work towards agreed objectives on combating climate change.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, Today, in the presence of the UN Secretary-General, we adopted a resolution on the EU's ratification of the Paris Climate Agreement – a historic act because the conditions for the entry into force of the agreement will be fulfilled.  It has currently been ratified by 63 countries to the Climate Convention (with at least 55 countries needed) responsible for around 52% of global greenhouse gas emissions (55%). , the Paris Agreement may enter into force, while it took almost 8 years to ratify the Kyoto Protocol, a precursor to the agreement. This is clear evidence that the world is ripe for global synergies in the fight against climate change, whether it be developed countries or developing countries. I would point out that in Paris, the parties agreed to limit warming to 2c, set a goal of even achieving 1.5c, and in the second half of this century to strike a balance between anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions and their reverse absorption from Earth and the seas. It's a truly historic moment to save the planet.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The Paris Agreement is a historically significant landmark achievement for combating climate change and for multilateralism. It represents an ambitious, balanced, equitable and legally binding agreement. This global action aims to put the world on track to avoid dangerous climate change. Moreover, the Agreement acknowledges that a global peaking of greenhouse gas emissions should be reached as quickly as possible and climate neutrality should be achieved in the second half of this century. I voted in favour because I believe that the implementation of the Paris Agreement will play a crucial contribution to global efforts to tackle climate change.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement represents a before and after in the fight against climate change globally, designing the path to a low-greenhouse gas development model. The leadership shown by the European Union in Paris must be maintained, and early ratification of the Agreement is key to this. In this regard, I supported this decision by which, after the approval of the ministers of the European Union, the Paris Agreement is con welcomed on behalf of the European Union. Rapid ratification by its Member States will consolidate the Union as a leading player in the fight against climate change.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of ratification on behalf of the Union of the Paris Agreement, since this is a symbolic gesture of validation of this agreement negotiated by the parties, which must then be ratified and implemented by each Member State of the United Nations. However, I do not share the triumphal rhetoric about this Paris Agreement. While my vote has been favourable, I find this agreement insufficient, since it is fundamentally based on voluntary commitments and market mechanisms that I criticised. I voted in favour of this minimum agreement, being aware that despite the progress, it is still far from an effective response to climate change.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Today, along with colleagues in Parliament, I voted to give consent to the ratification of the Paris Climate Agreement in the European Parliament. Although most Member States still have to ratify the Paris Agreement, today’s vote from the European Union now ensures a swift start for COP21.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this ratification decision so that a strong signal would be given in terms of the leadership and efforts of the EU and its Member States to combat climate change at international level. We are not a talking club, Europe is back in the climate negotiations. After the European Commission gave its approval earlier, the European Parliament ratified the Paris Climate Agreement. I am very pleased that we in the European Parliament have ratified the climate treaty, and with that we are taking a decisive step towards the entry into force of the agreement. The presence of UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon also said a great deal about the scope of the European Parliament's decision.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement has been called historic. For the first time, all countries have pledged to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and prevent global temperatures from rising by more than two degrees. The final text mentions the 1.5 degree ceiling, but this has a purely symbolic effect and has been included to meet small island countries threatened with submersion. The big problem is that COP-21 has not set goals or set ways to achieve the objectives presented. And postponed the problem to 2030.  And to give a social and solidarity touch-up, a fund has been set up by the rich countries responsible for warming to compensate poor countries with rising sea levels and climate instability. But no one knows how and when the contributions will work, even though we know that multinationals have already positioned themselves to be the major beneficiaries of it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The Paris Agreement (COP 21) on the protection of the climate is not a step in the right direction and is incompatible with our policy for several reasons. For example, under this agreement, nuclear energy, due to its low CO2 emissions, is seen as a tried and tested means of achieving emission reduction targets, while large multinationals such as Monsanto, in the context of the negotiations on the proposal for genetically modified seeds, presented a climate-friendly alternative to conventional cultivation. In addition, a study by the Corporate Europe Observatory (CEO) showed that the same global big players sat at the COP-21 negotiating table that also support TTIP and CETA. Climate protection must not be at the expense of the environment or our health, which is why I did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Climate change is the most significant challenge facing humanity as a whole at present. Its impacts are already being felt around the globe, fuelling conflict, the movement of peoples, and destruction of our ecosystems. My own temperate constituency of North-West England suffered terrible floods last year, partly brought about by a sub-tropical storm. EU Member States must move as quickly as possible to ratify and implement the COP21 Paris Agreement, so that the EU can play a leading role in the global effort to combat climate change.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this legislative resolution and thereby gave my consent to the conclusion of the Paris Agreement. By doing so, Parliament has given its contribution to reaching the required 55 signatories representing 55% of global emissions, to come into effect. This agreement is a milestone in our efforts to stop climate change. Over the past years it has become clear that we have to take action in order to keep climate change under control. This agreement provides a long-term plan that includes 189 nations and the vast majority of emissions worldwide. It sets clear goals and ensures and enhances transparency and accountability with regard to commitments. At the same time, it also helps those nations to fight climate change that do not have the resources to do so. It will provide one of the cornerstones for future sustainable economic development.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Paris Climate Agreement, the product of temporary compromises between imperialist centres and powerful capitalist countries, neither wants nor can it address the acute environmental problems created by capitalist development, since it treats the environment as a means of increasing the profitability of business groups, while having a devastating effect not only on uncontrolled fundraising, but also on imperialist wars. The Agreement concentrates on the various 'pollution trading systems', which, as profitable mechanisms for the sale of pollution itself, have proven to exacerbate environmental degradation. Green technologies aim to open up new investment areas for the sake of monopolies, amid fierce competition, which the EU is leading because it considers its business groups to have a comparative advantage. The sure result of this agreement will also be the deterioration of the environmental problems and living conditions of the people's families. Only an economy and a society based not on capitalist profit, but on meeting popular needs, can ensure a compatible and balanced influence of the working man on nature, on the environment. For such a life the working people must take power and the economy into their own hands, they must break with their capitalist barbarism, monopolies and imperialist associations.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution granting consent to the conclusion of the Paris Agreement. Ratification of the Paris Agreement by the European Union and its 28 Member States will thus be a breakthrough ratification that will help to fulfil the necessary conditions for the Paris Agreement to enter into force. The long-term objective of the new agreement is to keep global warming growth below 2°C, with countries committed to taking measures to ideally raise global temperatures by no more than 1.5°C.  The Paris Agreement is a historic milestone in the fight against climate change and, at the same time, a legally binding instrument that has set itself ambitious targets. These objectives will be achieved by all parties, in particular by reducing greenhouse gas emissions, but also by increasing the share of the use of renewable energy sources. I hope that states will responsibly take up their commitments and together they will be able to achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the La Via report which the Paris Agreement ratifies on behalf of the EU. I welcome this historic step that will allow the Agreement to enter into force today, as 55 parts of the partnership are ratified representing at least 55% of total emissions, following ratifications by the US, China and India. Portugal had already made its contribution, being the fifth EU country to ratify the Agreement in a parliamentary session held on 30 September 2016. I would point out that the Paris Agreement is a global partnership that is a key global partnership for the environmental sustainability of the planet and to give a new impetus to the global economy. In fact, from the Paris Agreement emerges a new notion of universality of hybrid commitment combining binding legal provisions and voluntary commitments, with the aim of achieving a decarbonisation of the global economy through "determined national contributions". I stress that to be a success, the key now is the implementation of concrete decarbonization actions on a universal scale to achieve the goal of limiting the temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. For us in the 5-Star Movement, the Ratification by the European Union of the COP21 Agreement in Paris is a due, crucial and necessary act. Unfortunately, that alone will not be enough. We will have to go further. This is, in fact, a first step which must force us not to give up, a first step which must prompt us to implement new concrete actions. We must have the courage to abandon a model based on absurd unlimited growth with limited resources at our disposal. COP21 is a starting point for tackling and trying to solve climate change problems, it certainly cannot be considered a point of arrival.  Indeed, we have serious doubts about the management of CO2 emissions through the use of financial instruments and we are disappointed that polluting emissions from aircraft and ships have been excluded from the negotiations. We still do not understand why the agricultural chapter has been excluded from the negotiations given that the business of the food multinationals is causing disasters. However, I think it is important that the greats of the earth have found a compromise by actually admitting that there is a climate emergency. It is at this first step that I voted in favour so that we can soon move on to work for the second.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the Decision to ratify the Paris Agreement. I believe that this legally binding agreement will accelerate global efforts to move to a climate-neutral economy and prevent dangerous climate change.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission is calling for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to the amount of EUR 1 651 834 following an earthquake in The Ionian Islands in Greece. The intensity of the earthquake reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale causing significant damage to homes and rendering 20 unusable. Since I believe it is very important to provide the necessary aid in situations such as this, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 1 651 834 to Greece for the earthquake that hit in 2015. The event was a 6.1 on the Richter Scale in which two people lost their lives and 8 people were injured. The Greek Government estimated the total damage to be over EUR 66 million. While in principle UKIP opposes the EU spending British taxpayers’ money, as this was for disaster relief and there was loss of life, we will not oppose its use in this case.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. On 17 November 2015, the Ionian Islands (particularly Leucade and the northern areas of Ithaca and Kefalonia) suffered earthquakes whose damage is estimated at more than EUR 66 million, 2.1% of regional GDP. The objective of this report is to mobilisation the Union Solidarity Fund of EUR 1.7 million in commitment and payment appropriations. Although this is only a small amount in relation to total damage, I voted in favour of this report to contribute to the reconstruction of the area.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – Following the earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands in November 2015, on 5 February 2016 Greece submitted an application to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund.  As there are appropriations still available in the European solidarity fund for 2016, the proposal is to provide the amount of EUR 1 651 834 to Greece, in commitment and payment appropriations. The vote took place on 28 September in the BUDG committee, and adopted with an overwhelming majority +32 in favour, one abstention and one vote against.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report containing a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund to provide aid to Greece after the earthquake that hit the Ionian Islands in November 2015.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece following the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015, because the devastating effects of the magnitude 6.1 Richter earthquake created multiple problems in the daily lives of the inhabitants of the islands. In such exceptional cases, it is imperative that the European Union shows its solidarity in all the affected areas.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The European Commission is proposing to make a sum of EUR 1 651 834 available to Greece from the European Union Solidarity Fund following the earthquake in the Ionian Islands. The earthquake, which struck on November 17, 2015, reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale, destroying many homes and causing death and injuries. Parliament and I, too, voted in favour of this support for Greece and the region concerned in order to help the people on the ground rebuild and to show them that European solidarity is working.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which mobilizes the Solidarity Fund to the tune of 1.7 million euros to help Greece hit by a magnitude 6.1 earthquake on the Richter scale in the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia, in November 2015, damaging 120 homes, 20 of which were totally destroyed, and causing considerable damage to public buildings and infrastructure (hospitals ports, churches, etc., According to the Greek authorities, the amount of damage amounts to 66 million euros, or 2.1% of the GDP of the region concerned, which is above the threshold of qualification for natural disaster at 1.5% of GDP.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that this fund is necessary. EU Member States contribute to a fund from which they can then reclaim money in the event of a natural disaster. However, ultimately there will be no real net benefit in terms of the levels of administration involved. Given that the fund exists, however, I see no reason to doubt that this is a worthwhile cause and I have no objection to the proposal. I therefore felt, overall, that it was appropriate to abstain.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilizing the Solidarity Fund to help the victims and compensate for the damage caused, especially to the road network, by the earthquake that struck the island of Leucade in November 2015.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece after 2015. The Ionian Islands earthquake. This earthquake reached 6.1 points on the Richter scale. 120 homes were damaged, of which 20 were found to be unfit to live. Significant damage has been reported to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural facilities. I therefore agree with the Commission, which proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in order to provide financial assistance in connection with the disaster in Greece.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 1 651 834 to Greece for the earthquake that hit in 2015. The event was 6.1 on the Richter Scale in which two people lost their lives and 8 people injured. The Greek Government estimated the total damage to be over EUR 66 million. While in principle UKIP opposes the EU spending British taxpayer’s money, as this was for disaster relief and there was loss of life, we will not oppose its use in this case.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I have obviously not opposed the mobilization of the EU Solidarity Fund to help Greece following the 6.1 magnitude earthquake that hit the islands of Leucade and Cefalonia in November 2015. The Greek authorities estimate the damage to 2.1% of the gdp of the region concerned, whether it is housing or public infrastructure.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Commission proposes to provide financial assistance under the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in response to a disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015 (earthquakes that affected the Ionian Islands region, including the island of Leucade and the northern areas of the islands of Ithaca and Cephalonia). In line with past practice and the EUSF Regulation, the Commission proposes to apply the rate of 2.5% of total direct damages below the intervention threshold set for Greece. The total amount of the proposed aid is therefore EUR 1,651,834. I voted in favour of this report recommending the swift approval of the Commission's decision proposal in solidarity with the Greek regions affected by this earthquake.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 On November 17, 2015, the Ionian islands of Greece were hit by a violent earthquake with an intensity of 6.1 on the Richter scale. The extensive damage caused by the earthquake, particularly in the islands of Leucade, Itaca and Kefalonia, damaged more than 120 houses, destroyed beaches and bathing establishments, compromised infrastructure networks and cultural sites. The Hellenic Republic has therefore asked the EU to activate the European Union Solidarity Fund, an instrument whose objective is to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergency situations by supporting the population of regions affected by natural disasters. I voted in favour of the Kyrtsos report because I believe that European intervention in this type of situation is essential. Thanks to the aid and resources provided, amounting to EUR 1.65 billion, it will be possible to restore infrastructure, reimburse the costs of emergency measures and help cover certain cleaning costs.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. This report called for the mobilization of funds to help greece's Ionian Islands region from the damage sustained by an earthquake in November 2015. I vote for these funds to be mobilized in solidarity with the people who suffered the damage caused by this natural disaster.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I wanted to vote in favour of the payment of EUR 1,651,834 to Greece, taken from the European Union Solidarity Fund, since it is to deal with this kind of unpredictable disaster and the disastrous consequences that this fund exists.
