We remember the 6.1 magnitude earthquake that struck the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia in November 2015. The Greek government has estimated the cost of this tragic event at 66 million euros, or 2.1% of the region's GDP. This is well above the regional natural disaster qualification threshold, which is 1.5% of GDP. Beyond the expression of all my solidarity with the Greek people, I would also like to point out that the funding of this aid is provided by the payment appropriations already included in the 2016 budget.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 On 17 November 2015, Greece was hit by an earthquake that affected the Ionian islands, in particular Leucade, the northern areas of Itaca and the island of Kefalonia. With this vote, I support the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for EUR 1 651 834 to be used for reconstruction and support for the populations affected. I believe that the Solidarity Fund continues to be an important instrument of support that Europe makes available to Member States affected by major natural disasters, although I hope that we will be able to make its implementation ever faster, because this will greatly increase its effectiveness.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of the Union Solidarity Fund to allocate EUR 1 651 834 in solidarity with the Greek regions affected by the November 2015 earthquake. The earthquakes, of a magnitude of 6.1 degrees, resulted in the deaths of two people, eight were injured and one hundred and twenty homes suffered damage, twenty of which were considered unfit to live in them. There was also serious damage to infrastructure networks and various buildings and cultural attractions.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which examines the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in connection with the disaster in Greece (the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands region, in particular the Leuca and Kefallon islands) on 17 November 2015. Two people died and eight were injured and 120 homes were damaged, of which 20 were found to be unfit to live. Significant damage has been reported to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural facilities. In Leukade, several beaches are most important in terms of the tourism sector. The affected region is classified as 'less developed regions' under the provisions of the European Structural and Investment Funds (2014-2020). The Greek authorities have not notified the Commission of their intention to reallocate funding under the ESI Fund programme and to allocate funds for reconstruction measures. The European Parliament recommends that the Commission's proposal for a decision be adopted swiftly in order to express solidarity with the affected regions of Greece.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to use the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in the wake of the disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015 (earthquake affecting the Ionian Islands, in particular lefkada and the northern parts of Ithaki and Kefalonia). The quakes reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. The Greek authorities initially estimated the direct damage caused by the disaster at a total of EUR 66 073 345. Since the above amount amounts to 2.1% of the GDP of the NUTS 2 region of the Ionian Islands concerned (based on Eurostat data for 2014) and exceeds the 1.5% threshold for regional GDP, the disaster constitutes a regional disaster within the meaning of Article 2(3) of the EUSA Regulation. In accordance with Article 4a(2) of the EUSF Regulation, at greece's request, the Commission has made an advance of EUR 164 798, which is 10% of the contribution from the Fund. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed decision to use the EU Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece after last year's earthquake. The adoption of the decision will give Greece more than EUR 1.6 million in funding to deal with the aftermath of an earthquake that damaged 120 residential buildings and caused the deaths of two people. Extensive damage to the remaining infrastructure and cultural facilities has also been caused, and some of the tourist's most important beaches on the island of Lefkada have been destroyed. The total amount of damage was estimated at EUR 66 million, which exceeds the threshold of 1,5 % of regional GDP and thus meets the criterion for assistance from the Solidarity Fund. It should also be noted that the affected region falls into the category of less developed regions. Since Greece already received EUR 164 798 in March this year, 10 % of the total amount, the remaining assistance from the Solidarity Fund still to be paid is EUR 1 487 036.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this Report on the Mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to assist Greece following the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015. This report recommends the swift approval of the Commission's proposal for the exploitation of EUR 1,651,834, as a sign of solidarity with the Greek regions affected by the 2015 earthquake.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report is intended to compensate the victims of the earthquake that struck the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia. The criteria for natural disaster are met and the sums mentioned are already included in the 2016 budget. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this resolution concerning the allocation of more than EUR 1.5 million to Greece following the earthquake of November 2015, because I strongly believe that European solidarity is the right political answer, especially during hard times.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the autumn-winter 2015 period, the Ionian islands of Greece were hit by an earthquake and several local floods. The damage to public and private infrastructure, businesses, citizens' homes, agricultural companies and the environmental assets of the affected territories has been serious, both in economic and human terms, causing victims and material consequences that are difficult to solve in the short term in a country already severely affected by the crisis. Events, which can be attributed to a single adverse natural phenomenon, must be regarded as a single major natural disaster. The total direct damage, estimated at several million EUR, must be added to the significant indirect damage under the criteria in force for regional disasters, since several NUTS 2 regions are affected and the damage caused in the affected areas represents a significant part of Greece's GDP. The European Parliament must therefore immediately mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for the affected areas by giving them sufficient resources to deal with the damage suffered and to enable the damaged sites to be secured.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to the tune of 1.7 million euros to help Greece overcome financially the damage caused by an earthquake of magnitude 6.1 on the Richter scale, which hit the islands of Leucade and Cefalonia in November 2015. In total, more than 120 homes were destroyed by the earthquake, not to mention the extensive damage to public infrastructure such as hospitals, ports and churches. The Greek authorities estimate the cost of the damage at 66 million euros, or 2.1% of the gdp of the region concerned, in fact exceeding the natural disaster qualification threshold of 1.5%. So I voted for this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to the 17 November earthquake in the Ionian Islands of Greece, the European Parliament proposes the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Funds, funds needed to provide financial assistance in the wake of the disaster. The earthquake intensity was 6.1 on the Richter scale, and the damage was mainly materially damaged, namely 120 damaged dwellings, the loss of two lives, and the injury of 8 people. The affected regions fall into the category of less developed regions, so emergency and rehabilitation costs are around EUR 52 million, of which more than EUR 38 million is used in the transport sector and more than EUR 7 million for the protection of cultural heritage. We voted in favour of this report, because I believe that THERE is a great need for EU solidarity funds for rehabilitation measures, given that we are dealing with a number of less developed regions and the damage is significant.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund allows it to financially support a Member State, an accession country or a region in the event of a major natural disaster. Between 26 January and 3 February 2014, Kefalonia was affected by a strong earthquake of magnitude 5.8 on the Richter scale, followed by dozens of strong aftershocks in the north-east of the island; the earthquake caused more casualties and 3,000 people were left homeless. Many homes were badly damaged and people were forced to sleep several nights in tents or on army ships. Greece's application was received on 28 March 2014, meeting the conditions for granting a financial contribution from the Fund in accordance with Article 4 of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 2012/2002. Being of natural origin, earthquakes fall within the main scope of the Solidarity Fund. In solidarity with the regions of Greece affected, I support the rapid mobilisation of the Commission's proposal for a decision provided for in that report.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. A devastating earthquake struck the Greek Ionian Islands on November 17, 2015. It has caused a great deal of human but also material damage as well as on infrastructure and tourist sites. The European Union Solidarity Fund was established in 2002 to deal with major natural disasters. The mobilization of this fund was therefore justified to help the affected regions. The sum of 1,651,834 euros will be paid to Greece to cover part of the direct damage caused by the disaster. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in relation to an earthquake in Greece on 17 November 2015. Widespread damage has been reported to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites. On the island of Leucade, some of the most important tourist beaches have been destroyed. The total direct damage caused by the disaster in Greece is estimated at EUR 66 073 345.  In Italy, the EU Solidarity Fund was used in 2002 for the earthquake in Molise, in 2009 for the earthquake in Abbruzzo and in 2012 for the earthquake in Emilia Romagna. The European Union has expressed its readiness to activate the Solidarity Fund also in support of reconstruction in the areas affected by the earthquake of 24 August 2016 in Lazio and marche. The resources of the fund can be used to cover non-insurable damage, therefore related to first aid, infrastructure and cultural heritage. The Fund will also make it possible to restore roads, aqueducts, electricity, gas and telephone or transport lines.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ Following an earthquake measuring 6.0 on the Richter Scale that affected the Ionian Islands in November 2015, on 5 February 2016 Greece submitted an application to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund.  EUR 1 651 834 will now be provided to Greece to cope with damaged roads, buildings and other infrastructure from this earthquake which also killed two people.  This fund was set up to provide assistance in instances of natural disasters in the EU Member States.  For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the rapporteur on the need for a swift approval of the Commission proposal to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund as a sign of solidarity with the affected Greek regions and to grant financial assistance relating to the disaster in Greece (earthquakes affecting the Ionian Islands region, in particular the island of Lefkada, northern parts of Ithaki and Kefalonia) which occurred on 17 November 2015.  The proposed mobilisation would not require an amendment to the 2016 budget.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in connection with a disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015. The Greek authorities have estimated the total direct damage caused by the disaster at around EUR 66 million. The total amount of aid proposed by the EUSF is EUR 1 651 834. I voted in favour.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 On November 17, 2015, a magnitude 6.1 earthquake hit some islands in western Greece damaging infrastructure networks, public and private buildings (including a hospital) and cultural sites. The damage estimated by local authorities amounts to over EUR 66 million. I am convinced that the scale of the natural disaster in one of the less developed regions of the country requires us to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide the financial assistance demanded by the Greek Government. I therefore decided to vote in favour of the decision to pay around EUR 1.7 million to help cover the damage. I hope that the decision will be implemented quickly in order to demonstrate the solidarity and closeness of the European institutions to the inhabitants of the airway affected by the earthquake.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We are in favour of the report and recommend the rapid adoption of the Commission's proposal for a decision annexed to this report, in solidarity with the affected Greek regions.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in support of the Ionian regions following the November 2015 earthquake is a positive process that can provide solutions to the affected areas. Indeed, as this Fund has been set up for precisely these purposes, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal as the Commission proposes to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in relation to a disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015 (an earthquake in the Ionian islands, in particular the island of Lefkada, the northern areas of Itaca and the island of Kefalonia). The earthquake reached magnitude 6.1 on the Richter scale and left two dead and eight injured and 120 units damaged, 20 of which were declared unusable. Widespread damage has been reported to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites. On the island of Leucade, some of the most important tourist beaches have been destroyed. At Greece's request, on 18 March 2016 the Commission granted an advance of EUR 164 798, or 10 % of the financial contribution provided for by the Fund, in line with Article 4a(2) of the EUSF Regulation. The proposed mobilisation would not require any change to the 2016 budget or a draft amending budget. This is the first mobilisation decision of 2016 and the total amount of aid proposed complies with the ceiling for the EU Solidarity Fund as set out in the Regulation establishing the MFF.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 In light of the tragic earthquake that struck Italy on 24 August, I can only vote in favour of the support to be given to greeks. The earthquake that rocked the Ionian islands on November 17, 2015 had a magnitude of 6.5 and was also felt in Puglia and Calabria. If the casualties have been limited, the damage is unfortunately not. Thanks to the request for financial assistance which Greece promptly submitted within 12 weeks of the first damage being established, there will be a mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund amounting to EUR 1 651 834. I hope that the Italian Government will have the capacity to do the same as soon as possible, since the damage in central Italy is estimated at around a total amount of 4 billion. We are all well aware of how certain tragedies cause far greater losses than monetaryly quantifiable damage. I would therefore like to remind you of the 297 deaths that the whole of our nation had to mourn, as was also recently observed during the Strasbourg plenary in September through the minute's silence respected by the entire European Parliament.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece following the earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands in November 2015, and I noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to ensure rapid, effective and flexible aid to the population of a Member State, as well as to countries negotiating their membership in the event of a major natural disaster. This fund complements member states' public funds in emergency situations, including the urgent recovery of infrastructure, temporary accommodation and emergency services to meet the immediate needs of the population, as well as the clean-up of disaster-affected areas.  On 17 November 2015, Greece was affected by a 6.1 earthquake on the Richter scale - it affected the Ionian Islands region - causing people to die, destruction of homes, significant damage to the infrastructure network and buildings and places of cultural interest, with some of the most important beaches being turistically destroyed. Following the disaster Greece requested assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund.  I supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 1,651,834 in authorisation and payment appropriations under the European Union Solidarity Fund in order to alleviate the pain, suffering and loss of those affected by this disaster.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report so that the European Union can support Greece in the tragic earthquake of 17 November 2015 in the Ionian Islands, through the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund, to help the areas most affected, such as the island of Leucade, the areas north of Itaca and the island of Kefalonia, in the reconstruction of homes and in the safety of the citizens themselves. The European Commission will apply a rate of 2.5 % of the total direct damage amount for all damages up to the threshold, giving Greece a financial contribution of EUR 1 651 834.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this financial assistance towards rehabilitating victims of the disaster which took place at the Ionian Islands region of Greece last year, providing for an anticipated Fund contribution, in line with Article 4(a) of the EUSF Regulation, and a total amount of aid proposed of just over EUR 1.5 million.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. On 17 November 2015, the Ionian Islands (particularly Leucade and the northern areas of Ithaca and Kefalonia) suffered earthquakes whose damage is estimated at more than EUR 66 million, 2.1% of regional GDP. The objective of this report is to mobilisation the Union Solidarity Fund of EUR 1.7 million in commitment and payment appropriations. Although this is only a small amount in relation to total damage, I voted in favour of this report to contribute to the reconstruction of the area.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund is the main instrument for demonstrating the Union's solidarity action, providing important financial support to Member States or regions affected by major disasters. In the light of these considerations, I welcomed the granting of aid to Greece following the earthquake in the Ionian Islands.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 On November 17, 2015, Greece was struck by an earthquake with a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. Two people lost their lives, eight were injured and 120 homes were damaged. Significant damage to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites has also been reported. Material damage amounts to more than 2.5% of regional GDP, thus classifying this event as a regional disaster. I voted for financial assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund for the Greek people, which has been badly affected by this earthquake. Solidarity underpins the founding of the EU and I believe that only together can we overcome the crises we face within the Union.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. In November 2015, a 6.1-magnitude earthquake on the Richter scale struck the Greek island of Ion.  The Greek authorities have identified more than EUR 66 million in damage, in addition to personal damage, infrastructure has been significantly damaged and sites of great importance for tourism have been damaged. In February 2016, the Government submitted a request to the European Commission to benefit from the european Union Solidarity Fund's dedicated support for such cases. The European Commission also approved the eur 1 651 834 grant. The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to ensure that the Union is able to respond to emergencies quickly, efficiently and flexibly and express its solidarity with the populations of disaster regions, so I supported the proposal.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I fully supported the proposal because I believe that member states should always be willing to help, especially in the event of natural disasters. The coverage of the damage and effects of the earthquake has far exceeded the financial capacity of the Ionian Islands. The EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) aims to provide financial assistance to eligible Member States affected by large-scale natural disasters or regional exceptional disasters. In the event of an earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands, solidarity must not be left indifferent, especially since there is a special assistance fund in such situations. Hence my decision to vote in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission decided to grant EUR 1.65 million from the EU Solidarity Fund to Greece following the earthquake in the Ionian Islands in November 2015. This disaster severely impacted on roads, ports, public buildings, homes, cultural sites and tourist areas. The aid will help to restore infrastructure, reimburse the cost of emergency measures and cover some of the clean-up operations, in a gesture of solidarity with the Greek regions affected. For these reasons, I am in favour of this report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Last November, Greece was severely affected by the earthquake in the Ionian Islands. Given that the EU's main objective with regard to the Solidarity Fund is to express solidarity with the people of regions affected by natural disasters through a rapid and effective response, I fully support the rapporteur's position recommending the swift approval of the Commission's proposal for a decision in solidarity with the regions of Greece affected.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes to provide financial assistance following the earthquake in Greece on 17 November 2015 in the Ionian Islands region. The earthquakes reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale and caused extensive human and material damage. At Greece's request, the European Commission has already granted an advance of 10% of the expected financial contribution, with the remaining balance payable amounting to EUR 1,487,036. Considering that the European Union must support European citizens affected by natural disasters and should be part of the reconstruction effort, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund to help Greece in the wake of the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015. The purpose of this Solidarity Fund is to enable the European Union to provide effective assistance to a Member State facing the damage caused by a major natural disaster. It therefore has every vocation to be mobilized for the Ionian Islands.  The earthquake with a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale that hit these islands caused catastrophic damage. Considerable damage has been done to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites. The beaches of the Ionian Islands, which are an important source of tourism revenue for the region, were also destroyed by the earthquake. In order for the local population to rebuild their cities and their economic apparatus, we must support the decision of the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise EUR 1,651,834 for Greece.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to use the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in the wake of the disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015 (earthquake affecting the Ionian Islands, in particular lefkada and the northern parts of Ithaki and Kefalonia). The quakes reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. The Greek authorities initially estimated the direct damage caused by the disaster at a total of EUR 66 073 345. Since the above amount amounts to 2.1% of the GDP of the NUTS 2 region of the Ionian Islands concerned (based on Eurostat data for 2014) and exceeds the 1.5% threshold for regional GDP, the disaster constitutes a regional disaster within the meaning of Article 2(3) of the EUSA Regulation. In accordance with Article 4a(2) of the EUSF Regulation, at greece's request, the Commission has made an advance of EUR 164 798, which is 10% of the contribution from the Fund. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I am particularly in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund as I come from an Italian region with strong seismic activity and therefore believe that it is an important initiative to help the population of the Greek islands affected by the November 2015 earthquake. I therefore hope that the Commission will quickly approve the allocation of the necessary financial aid. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands region of Greece in November 2015 caused extensive damage. Many port and road infrastructure have been destroyed, and cultural sites have been severely damaged. It is natural that the Union should be able to help the affected regions, and show solidarity with the affected populations.  The European Union's financial aid of EUR 1.65 million to Greece will enable the restoration of infrastructure, reimbursement of relief costs and part of the clean-up operations. It will help the inhabitants to recover from this disaster, to rebuild and to revive tourism activity.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to mobilise the Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece within EUR 1 651 834 in the wake of the November 2015 earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands. The damage caused by it represents 2.1% of the island's GDP and exceeds the threshold needed to qualify for aid for a "regional disaster". The earthquake of 17 November 2015 caused enormous damage to the Ionian Islands and the amount allocated will cover some of the damage without creating an additional burden on the European budget.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU must be flexible when there are grounds for compensating countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to use the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in the wake of the disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015 (earthquake affecting the Ionian Islands, in particular lefkada and the northern parts of Ithaki and Kefalonia). The quakes reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. The Greek authorities initially estimated the direct damage caused by the disaster at a total of EUR 66 073 345. Since the above amount amounts to 2.1% of the GDP of the NUTS 2 region of the Ionian Islands concerned (based on Eurostat data for 2014) and exceeds the 1.5% threshold for regional GDP, the disaster constitutes a regional disaster within the meaning of Article 2(3) of the EUSA Regulation. In accordance with Article 4a(2) of the EUSF Regulation, at greece's request, the Commission has made an advance of EUR 164 798, which is 10% of the contribution from the Fund. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece following the earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands in November 2015. The principle of solidarity, helping each other out, has long been an important value in Wales. The European Union has emergency funding to help in crises such as this. The UK Government does not make use of this support, which is why Wales has missed out in the past.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (the 'Fund') aims to enable the Union to respond rapidly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express its solidarity with the population of the disaster-affected regions, and the Fund's intervention should not exceed the maximum annual amount of EUR 500 million. Greece has submitted a request to mobilise the Fund following an earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands in November 2015. I therefore agree that the Fund of EUR 50 million should be mobilised to meet the request made by the Greeks.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: the aim is to mobilise the Solidarity Fund to the tune of 1.7 million euros to help Greece following the 6.1 magnitude earthquake that hit the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia in November 2015.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The Ionian Islands in Greece were hit in November 2015 by an earthquake that caused widespread destruction and prompted the Greek authorities in February 2016 to submit a request to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF). Now, almost a year after the disaster, the European Parliament approves the mobilisation of the EUSF. As appropriations are still available in the EUSF for 2016, the proposal is to provide the amount of EUR 1 651 834 to Greece in authorised and payment appropriations. It is entirely justified for the EU to mobilise this support for Greece, in addition to a known framework of continued aggression against Greece, notably through successive troika memoranda that have destroyed economic structures and devastated it socially. We voted in favour. But this situation puts the need to change the EUSF mobilisation rules back on the agenda in order to enable a more expeditious and timely mobilisation. It is not understood that it is only almost a year after the disaster that there is a mobilisation of support which is often needed immediately, either to defend the safety of persons and property or to suffer the damage caused, seeking to normalise the economic and social life of the affected region as soon as possible.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund (EUSF) with the intention of providing financial assistance to Greece in connection with the disaster on 17 November 2015.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as this benefits ordinary people.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund serves to provide financial support to Member States coping with the consequences of natural disasters. In this particular case, it is a release of EUR 16 551 834 for Greece, whose regions have to cope with an earthquake that reached an intensity of 6.1 degrees Richter scale. The total cost is estimated by the Greek authorities at EUR 66 million. The financial assistance in question will not constitute an increase in the budget for 2016.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of aid for the Greek population affected by the earthquake in November 2015.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU must be flexible when there are reasons to compensate countries affected by natural disasters, which is why I am voting in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund to help Greece following the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ This report contains a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece following the earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands in November 2015.  I support a swift approval of the Commission proposal to mobilise EUR 1 651 834, in a sign of solidarity with the Greek regions affected by the earthquake of 2015.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to use the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in the wake of the disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015 (earthquake affecting the Ionian Islands, in particular lefkada and the northern parts of Ithaki and Kefalonia). The quakes reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. The Greek authorities initially estimated the direct damage caused by the disaster at a total of EUR 66 073 345. Since the above amount amounts to 2.1% of the GDP of the NUTS 2 region of the Ionian Islands concerned (based on Eurostat data for 2014) and exceeds the 1.5% threshold for regional GDP, the disaster constitutes a regional disaster within the meaning of Article 2(3) of the EUSA Regulation. In accordance with Article 4a(2) of the EUSF Regulation, at greece's request, the Commission has made an advance of EUR 164 798, which is 10% of the contribution from the Fund. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – The Commission proposes to use the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in the wake of the disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015 (earthquake affecting the Ionian Islands, in particular Lefkada and the northern parts of Ithaki and Kefalonia). The quakes reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. The Greek authorities initially estimated the direct damage caused by the disaster at a total of EUR 66 073 345. Since the above amount amounts to 2.1% of the GDP of the NUTS 2 region of the Ionian Islands concerned (based on Eurostat data for 2014) and exceeds the 1.5% threshold for regional GDP, the disaster constitutes a regional disaster within the meaning of Article 2(3) of the EUSA Regulation. In accordance with Article 4a(2) of the EUSF Regulation, at greece's request, the Commission has made an advance of EUR 164 798, which is 10% of the contribution from the Fund. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilizing the EU Solidarity Fund to provide assistance in connection with a catastrophe in Greece on 17 November 2015, namely earthquakes affecting the Ionian Islands region. The earthquakes reached a magnitude of 6.1 degrees on the Richter scale, two people lost their lives, eight were injured and one hundred and twenty homes were damaged, twenty of which were deemed unfit to live in them. There was also serious damage to infrastructure networks and various buildings and cultural attractions.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, because I believe that offering support to the Greek authorities and to the populations affected by the earthquake of 17 November 2015 is a great test and demonstration of solidarity. The earthquake that struck the islands of Kefalonia and Leucade in 2015 and the northern part of Itaca has in fact caused considerable economic damage and unfortunately also tragic fatalities in an area with an economic and social fabric already severely tested by the economic crisis. The EU's decision to provide financial assistance to the affected territories is therefore a step in the right direction. Furthermore, the decision does not require a revision of the financial expenditure forecasts and allows the EU to continue to have the necessary resources to support the territories affected in the event of new natural disasters. This is an important sign of how the peoples of Europe are and can show solidarity with each other, and I hope that these support instruments will be further strengthened in the future, given the many natural disasters that unfortunately continue to occur in Italy as well.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Solidarity in the event of natural disasters is a central part of the European community of values. I feel it is our duty to assist the Member State concerned in such exceptional situations and to provide rapid assistance.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 1 651 834 to Greece for the earthquake that hit in 2015. The event was a 6.1 on the Richter Scale in which two people lost their lives and 8 people injured. The Greek Government estimated the total damage to be over EUR 66 million. While in principle UKIP opposes the EU spending British taxpayer’s money, as this was for disaster relief and there was loss of life, we will not oppose its use in this case.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. This report called for the mobilization of funds to help greece's Ionian Islands region from the damage sustained by an earthquake in November 2015. I vote for these funds to be mobilized in solidarity with the people who suffered the damage caused by this natural disaster.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Solidarity Fund, as I believe we should be providing assistance to Greece following the earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands in November 2015.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond in a rapid, efficient and flexible manner to emergency situations in order to show solidarity with the population of regions struck by natural disasters. On 5 February 2016, the Commission received an application for the Fund for financial assistance relating to a disaster in Greece (earthquake affecting the Ionian Islands region, in particular the islands of Lefkada and Kefalonia) which had occurred on 17 November 2015. After careful consideration it was decided that Greece meets the conditions for providing a financial contribution from the Fund.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance to Greece following the earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands in November 2015. The earthquake reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. Two people lost their lives, eight were wounded and 120 housing units were damaged, of which 20 were considered unsuitable for living. Extensive damage to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites was reported. Some of the most important beaches in terms of tourism were destroyed on Lefkada. The proposed mobilisation would not require an amendment to the 2016 budget and a draft amending budget. Providing financial assistance in this regard would undoubtedly strengthen European Solidarity whilst also providing humanitarian and administrative aid.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. On 5 February this year, an earthquake struck the Ionian Islands in Greece, mainly the island of Lefkada, the northern part of Ithaki and Kefalonia. The earthquake had a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. Two people were killed, eight were injured and 120 homes were damaged, 20 of which were declared uninhabitable. There is significant damage to infrastructure, buildings and cultural sites. Greece has therefore also requested financial support from the European Union Solidarity Fund. I voted in favour of the mobilisation of funds from this fund, because people affected by natural disasters desperately need our help.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ Damage by the earthquake of November 2015 on the Greek Ionian Islands represents 2.1% of the Islands’ GDP, and therefore qualifies as a regional disaster. EUR 1 651 834 (2.5% of the total direct damage) of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) will be mobilised. Given the tragic events, and because this mobilisation will still leave enough funds available for other EUSF applications, my Group and I have voted in favour of this proposal. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to use the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in the wake of the disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015 (earthquake affecting the Ionian Islands, in particular lefkada and the northern parts of Ithaki and Kefalonia). The quakes reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. The Greek authorities initially estimated the direct damage caused by the disaster at a total of EUR 66 073 345. Since the above amount amounts to 2.1% of the GDP of the NUTS 2 region of the Ionian Islands concerned (based on Eurostat data for 2014) and exceeds the 1.5% threshold for regional GDP, the disaster constitutes a regional disaster within the meaning of Article 2(3) of the EUSA Regulation. In accordance with Article 4a(2) of the EUSF Regulation, at greece's request, the Commission has made an advance of EUR 164 798, which is 10% of the contribution from the Fund. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ A decision of Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece following the earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands in November 2015 is included in this report. I voted in favour.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, which serves to enable financial assistance to enable the recovery of regions affected by natural disasters as fast as possible. November 17, 2015 Greece was hit by strong earthquakes, particularly the Ionian Islands region, the island of Lefkadu, and the northern parts of Ithka and Kefalonia. In this regional natural disaster, two people lost their lives, eight people were injured and 120 housing units were damaged, 20 of which are considered unfit for life. Major damage to the infrastructure network, buildings and cultural sites has also been reported. Some of the most tourist-important beaches on Lefkada have also been destroyed. In line with past practice, the Commission proposes to apply a rate of 2.5 % of total direct damage to all damages up to the threshold. The total amount of the proposed assistance is EUR 1 651 834. I certainly support the mobilisation of this Fund in order to show a sign of solidarity towards the affected regions as soon as possible.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The earthquake that greece suffered last November and which caused considerable damage justifies the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund. In addition, the estimate of damage caused exceeds the regional natural disaster qualification threshold, and the payment credits used to finance aid are already part of the 2016 budget. All the criteria were therefore put together for me to vote in favour of this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 1 651 834 to Greece for the earthquake that hit in 2015. The event was 6.1 on the Richter Scale in which two people lost their lives and 8 people injured. The Greek Government estimated the total damage to be over EUR 66 million. While in principle UKIP opposes the EU spending British taxpayer’s money, as this was for disaster relief and there was loss of life, we will not oppose its use in this case.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported providing assistance to Greece via mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund in relation to the earthquake which took place in November 2015, to help quick recovery of the Ionian Islands region, which the disaster mainly struck. The Ionian Islands are strongly dependent on tourism and since infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites with some of the most important tourist beaches were hit, financial assistance is crucial.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Georgios Kyrtsos' report on the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund for Greece following the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in 2015. At Greece's request, the Commission granted an advance of EUR 164,798 on 18 March 2016, representing 10% of the Fund's expected financial contribution.  After deducting the amount already paid for the 10% advance, the remaining balance amounted to EUR 1,487,036. I welcome this decision, which should help to rebuild the damage caused by this earthquake.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to mobilise the European Union's European Solidarity Fund to help Greece following a devastating earthquake that struck greece in November 2015, in the name of the necessary solidarity between EU Member States in the face of natural disasters.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Writing. \u2012 I am personally in favour of any decision to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in relation to emergencies arising. This case concerns the disaster that occurred in Greece (earthquakes that hit the Ionian Islands region and in particular the island of Lefkada and the northern part of Ithaca and Kefalonia) on 17 November 2015. The Greek authorities initially estimated the total direct damage caused by the disaster at EUR 65 919 000. On 9 March 2016 this amount was updated to EUR 66 073 345. , destruction may be classified as a 'regional disaster' within the meaning of Article 2(3) of the EUSE Regulation. Following Greece's request, on 18 March 2016 the Commission granted an advance of EUR 164 798, i.e. 10% of the projected contribution from the Fund, in accordance with Article 4a(2) of the EUSM Regulation. The total amount of aid to be paid is EUR 1 651 834.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of mobilising the Solidarity Fund for Greece. Aid must be given to the victims of the earthquake, which is a top priority for a country that has already been hit so badly by the refugee crisis.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance for the reintegration into the labour market of workers who have been made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to use the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in the wake of the disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015 (earthquake affecting the Ionian Islands, in particular lefkada and the northern parts of Ithaki and Kefalonia). The quakes reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. The Greek authorities initially estimated the direct damage caused by the disaster at a total of EUR 66 073 345. Since the above amount amounts to 2.1% of the GDP of the NUTS 2 region of the Ionian Islands concerned (based on Eurostat data for 2014) and exceeds the 1.5% threshold for regional GDP, the disaster constitutes a regional disaster within the meaning of Article 2(3) of the EUSA Regulation. In accordance with Article 4a(2) of the EUSF Regulation, at greece's request, the Commission has made an advance of EUR 164 798, which is 10% of the contribution from the Fund. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since it provides a well-needed assistance of EUR 1.65 million for Greece allowing the main infrastructure to be restored and the cultural heritage that was strongly affected by the 2015 earthquake to be protected, as well as to respond to the immediate needs of people in Ionian Islands.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The greek islands were hit by an earthquake in 2015. The European Solidarity Fund was set up precisely to help countries affected by natural disasters. Unfortunately, this fund only has a budget of EUR 500 million per year, of which only €1.6 million is foreseen in the report. All the help is good for the victims, but I find the envelope itself very little, compared to how much is spent on unnecessary things in the Union.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ It is necessary to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in order to provide a financial contribution to Greece in the wake of the earthquakes that affected the Ionian Islands region. The earthquakes reached magnitude 6.1 on the Richter scale. Two people lost their lives, eight were wounded, 120 housing units were damaged, of which 20 were considered unsuitable for living. Extensive damage to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites was reported. Some of the most important beaches in terms of tourism were destructed. The affected region falls under the category of ‘less developed regions’ under the European Structural and Investment Funds (2014-2020). Therefore, in a sign of solidarity with the affected Greek population and regions, the EU should provide assistance to Greece.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. In November 2015, Greece was hit by a terrible earthquake that caused considerable damage on some islands. As we know, this has caused and will continue to cause a great economic predictability for Greece and for the region affected in particular. We have therefore approved the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in such a way as to support Greece with a total of EUR 1 651 834, of which 10 % has already been paid to the Greek authorities. It is precisely in times of crisis such as this that we must show our solidarity and help those affected by serious tragedies. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted to mobilize the Solidarity Fund to the tune of 1.7 million euros to help Greece, following the 6.1 magnitude earthquake that hit its islands in November 2015.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to help Greece in the wake of the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015.  The 6.1-magnitude earthquake struck the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia. 120 homes were damaged, 20 of which were completely destroyed, and extensive damage also affected public infrastructure (hospitals, ports, churches, etc.).  The Greek authorities estimate the direct damage caused to 66 million euros, or 2.1% of the GDP of the region concerned, which is above the regional natural disaster qualification threshold (1.5%).

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. In November 2015, an earthquake with a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale affected the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia. Private housing, public hospitals, churches, the number of damaged or destroyed infrastructure is impressive.  The Greek authorities have estimated the direct damage caused to the tune of 66 million euros or 2.1% of the GDP of this region, a rate above the threshold of 1.5% necessary for the qualification of natural disaster. The aim here is to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund to the tune of EUR 1.7 million. Funding for this assistance is provided by the payment appropriations already included in the 2016 budget. Logically, I voted to mobilize this fund.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it proposes to mobilisation the Solidarity Fund, which recommends that the Commission's proposal be adopted quickly in solidarity with the Greek regions affected by the 2015 earthquake.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. On 17 November 2015, the Ionian Islands (particularly Leucade and the northern areas of Ithaca and Kefalonia) suffered earthquakes whose damage is estimated at more than EUR 66 million, 2.1% of regional GDP. The objective of this report is to mobilisation the Union Solidarity Fund of EUR 1.7 million in commitment and payment appropriations. Although this is only a small amount in relation to total damage, I voted in favour of this report to contribute to the reconstruction of the area.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I am not against the mobilisation of aid money for Greece in the context of the aftermath of last year's earthquake. This is EUR 1.6 million, a fraction of what insurance companies pay. If the EU is sending an essentially negligible EUR 1 million a year after the earthquake, there is something wrong with this system. In my think, rather, solidarity should be left to individual citizens and Member States that can react flexibly.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This proposal calls for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide financial assistance following the devastating earthquakes in Greece in 2015, followed by loss of life, damage to infrastructure, buildings and cultural facilities. The Greek authorities estimated the damage to be generated at EUR 66 million, representing 2.1% of their GDP, and what constitutes this disaster a regional disaster. This region falls under the European Structural and Investment Fund into less developed regions. As a result, they were granted funding from the Solidarity Fund, 38 million for the transport sector and over 7 million for the protection of cultural heritage.  In solidarity with the affected Regions of Greece, I consider it necessary to ensure the swift approval of these funds, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. – I support the suggestion to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece following the earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands in November 2015. We should show our solidarity with the Greek people and to help them to restore their communities.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Ionian Islands, which suffered a strong earthquake in 2015, are among the less developed regions. The earthquake caused direct damage of EUR 66 million, including the death and injury of persons and the destruction of residential buildings. Transport infrastructure was destroyed and cultural heritage was also affected by the damage. Greece will receive eur 1 651 834 of assistance from the Solidarity Fund in accordance with its rules for emergency measures and the restoration of affected infrastructure and assets.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece following the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015, because I consider it complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this report. The aim is to provide financial assistance of 1.7 million euros to Greek citizens living in the Ionian Islands region, following the 6.1 magnitude earthquake that struck the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia in November 2015. We have customary reservations about the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which should not be used to replace the actions of the government, which is already benefiting from the great financial support from the EU budget through different funds. Nevertheless, we cannot oppose this financial aid for European citizens who have lost their homes, access to hospitals, ports, churches and other essential infrastructure.  Finally, we would rather support the citizens of a Member State that has suffered a natural disaster than waste the EU budget on helping illegal migrants, through other EU funds for Greece!

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal of Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund stresses that such fund will enable the European Union to respond in a rapid, efficient and flexible manner to emergency situations in order to show solidarity with the people affected by natural disasters. Hence, my vote in favour. The report numbered the casualties, the wounded, and the damages left by the earthquake in Greece. However, with the following mobilisation of funds, Greece can look forward to rebuilding infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites that were reported completely damaged.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide financial assistance in relation to the disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015. The destruction can also be classified as 'regional' in accordance with the EUSE Regulation, the cost of eligible essential actions has been estimated at EUR 52,374 million and of this amount, more than EUR 38 million relates to the transport sector and more than EUR 7 million to the protection of cultural heritage. In addition, the European Solidarity Fund seeks to enable the Union to react quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies in order to express its solidarity with the population of the regions affected by natural disasters, as in the present case of Greece with the earthquakes that hit the Ionian Islands region and in particular the island of Lefkada.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The Greek region of the Ionian Islands was shaken by a 6.1 magnitude earthquake on the Richter scale. This Solidarity Fund was set up precisely for such strokes of fate. I therefore agree with the report, and therefore with aid for the reconstruction of the structurally weak region.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance to Greece as a result of the earthquake in the Ionian Islands region, in particular in the Lefkada and Kefalolian islands. Financial assistance will be used to rebuild infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites affected by the earthquake.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Ionian Islands were affected by a 6.1 earthquake on the Richter scale last year.  Greece has estimated direct damages of more than 66 million and will spend $38 million on rebuilding transport infrastructure and $7 million on affected cultural sites. The Commission is proposing 1.6 million aid through the 'Solidarity Fund' created for states and their regions in the grip of increasing natural disasters with the climate change that our modes of production and consumption cause. This is a meagre aid in terms of the amount of damages.  However, $48 million remains of the Fund to cover the remaining months of 2016. I am voting for the release of this emergency aid, while deploring that the amount is so small.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Solidarity Fund is mobilizing 1.7 million euros to help Greece following the earthquake that struck the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia in November 2015. The Greek authorities estimate the direct damage to be 66 million euros or 2.1% of the region's GDP, which is above the regional natural disaster qualification threshold (1.5%). Funding for this aid is provided by the payment appropriations already included in the 2016 budget. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance for a disaster in Greece (an earthquake that affected the Ionian islands region, namely the island of Lefkada and the northern regions of Cephalonia and Ithaca), which occurred on 17 November 2015, is essential to help these regions.  The earthquakes reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. Two people lost their lives, eight were injured, 120 homes were damaged, of which 20 were deemed unfit to live. There has been significant damage to infrastructure networks, buildings and places of cultural interest. Some of the most important beaches were destroyed in Lefkada. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of using funds to deal with damage caused by the 17 November 2015 earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands. The region requires all the support possible to repair the extensive damage to infrastructure, cultural locations and sites vital to the islands.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. On 17 November 2015, earthquakes hit the Ionian Islands region, including the island of Leucade and the northern areas of the islands of Ithaca and Cephalonia. These earthquakes reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. Two people died, eight others were injured, 120 homes were damaged, 20 of which were deemed uninhabitable. Considerable damage has been done to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites. I would like to express my sympathy and solidarity to the families of the victims of this tragedy and to all those who have lost a loved one. The economic, social, human and environmental damage that these disasters have caused cannot be ignored. That is why I am supporting the financial assistance of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) up to EUR 1,651,834 in commitment and payment credits to ensure the most urgent needs. It is the EU's duty to coordinate and strengthen its instruments so that it can act effectively in the face of this situation.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – On 17 November 2016, Greece was struck by a strong earthquake. The affected region was the Ionian Islands, the most affected were the islands of Lefkada and Kefalonia, where the intensity of the earthquake reached up to 6.1 degrees Richter scale. Two people were killed, eight were injured and around 120 housing units were damaged. In addition, extensive damage has been reported to regional and municipal networks of infrastructure, private and public buildings (including the local hospital) and other infrastructure, but also to cultural monuments. . Total damages amounted to EUR 66 073 345. Greece has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EU Solidarity Fund in the context of the earthquake, fulfilling all the conditions laid down for the application, so I support the mobilisation of EUR 1 651 834 in financial assistance from the EU Solidarity Fund. As this mobilisation is fully financed using part of the EUR 50 000 000 budget included in the 2016 budget, an amending budget is not required for this purpose.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report to provide assistance to Greece in order to repair damage caused by an earthquake that hit the Ionian Islands region, and in particular Lefkada, northern parts of Ithaki and Kefalonia, on 17 November 2015. The earthquake measured 6.1 on the Richter scale. Two people lost their lives, eight were wounded, and 120 houses were damaged. The Greek authorities reported extensive damage to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites, with some of the most important tourist beaches destroyed on Lefkada. The aid will help restore infrastructure, reimburse the cost of emergency measures and cover some of the clean-up operations. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity to disaster-stricken regions within Europe.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to ensure that the Union is able to respond to emergencies in a rapid, efficient and flexible manner and to express solidarity with the populations of disaster regions. Greece applied for the fund on 5 February 2016 in the wake of the earthquake that struck the Ion islands on 17 November 2015. The Greek authorities have established the extent of the direct damage caused by the earthquake at EUR 66 073 345. This amount exceeds the 1.5% threshold for regional GDP and the earthquake is therefore considered a regional disaster. The Commission has therefore submitted a proposal for a decision to the European Parliament and the Council on the use of EUR 1 651 834 from the Solidarity Fund to Greece in the form of commitment and payment appropriations. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The aim here is to mobilise the Union Solidarity Fund to the tune of 1.7 million euros to help Greece following the 6.1 magnitude earthquake that hit the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia in November 2015. 120 homes were damaged, 20 of which were completely destroyed, and extensive damage also affected public infrastructure (hospitals, ports, churches, etc.). The Greek authorities estimate the direct damage caused to 66 million euros, or 2.1% of the GDP of the region concerned, which is above the regional natural disaster qualification threshold (1.5%). Funding for this assistance is provided by the payment appropriations already included in the 2016 budget. Vote in favour.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The EUSF aims to provide a rapid, efficient and flexible response to emergencies and to express its solidarity with the population of disaster-affected regions. The EUSF was requested to provide financial assistance following the disaster in Greece as a result of the earthquake of magnitude 6.1 on the Richter scale, which affected the Ionian islands region, namely the island of Lefkada and the northern regions of Cephalonia and Ithaca, which occurred on 17 November 2015. This calamity caused the death of two people, eight were injured, 120 homes were damaged, of which 20 were considered unfit to live. There was also considerable damage to public infrastructure (infrastructure networks, buildings and places of cultural interest, as well as some of the most important beaches turistically destroyed in Lefkada). I advocate the mobilisation of the EUSF in this case for meeting the requirements, for the impact on the local community and economy and for the massive damage that has hit the region, not only public infrastructure, but also private properties and businesses, as well as the cultural and tourism sector.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This vote concerns the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund to the tune of 1.7 million euros to help Greece following the 6.1 magnitude earthquake that hit the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia in November 2015. 120 homes were damaged, 20 of which were totally destroyed, and extensive damage also affected public infrastructure (hospitals, ports, churches, etc.).  The Greek authorities estimate the direct damage caused to 66 million euros or 2.1% of the GDP of the region concerned, which is above the regional natural disaster qualification threshold (1.5%). Funding for this aid is provided by the payment appropriations already included in the 2016 budget.  I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund to help Greece following the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015. These earthquakes, with a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale, resulted in the death of two people and considerable property damage. The European Union must show solidarity when a little developed region is the victim of a violent natural event.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the KYRTOS report on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund to help Greece in the wake of the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015. Solidarity between Member States is now needed more than ever. In the face of human tragedies or situations of natural disasters, the European Union can provide essential financial support for the moral and material reconstruction of hard-hit European countries and citizens.  Unfortunately and tragically, Greece was hit by an earthquake in the autumn of 2015. As this country had already been hit hard by the economic crisis and then fully mobilised in the face of the migration crisis, it was important for me, and for the European Parliament, to help them.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure proposing to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in relation to a disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015 (an earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands, in particular the island of Lefkada, the northern areas of Itaca and the island of Kefalonia). The earthquake reached magnitude 6.1 on the Richter scale and left two dead and eight injured and 120 units damaged, 20 of which were declared unusable. Widespread damage has been reported to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites. On the island of Leucade, some of the most important tourist beaches have been destroyed. The affected region falls into the category of "least developed regions" under the European Structural and Investment Funds (2014-2020).

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The european Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the EU to respond quickly, flexily and effectively to emerging disaster situations. That is exactly what Greece needs right now. Hundreds of people have lost their homes in the earthquake that hit the Yen Islands, and we now have the opportunity to help. After a disaster like this, we really realize how powerless we are to the power of nature. The European Union is based on solidarity and we must show that we can count on each other in need. I am confident that, thanks to the money from the fund, the reconstruction of housing estates can finally begin and we will be able to take some of the burden off the shoulders of the people affected by the disaster.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because I have found Greece to be in high need of financial support due to the ‘regional disaster’ which took place in the Ionian Islands on 17 November 2015.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – This year, Greece applied for the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund after the country was rocked by a strong 6.5 magnitude earthquake on the Richter Scale in November 2015, which affected the Ionian Islands, in particular the islands of Lefkada and the northern parts of Itaca and Kefalonia. This earthquake caused significant damage to numerous infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites, amounting to more than EUR 65 million.  I support the implementation of Solidarity Fund instruments because I believe they show European citizens that Europe does not forget them in the difficulties caused by natural elements. In 2014 and 2015, my country Bulgaria was also hit by several disasters and we submitted applications for assistance from the Fund. While these aids did not fully cover the damage caused by natural disasters, they still helped financially a part of the Bulgarian population by demonstrating the empathy and solidarity that Europe must show at such times. I am of the opinion that in the European Parliament we need to proceed as quickly as possible with the approval of this financial assistance in order for the people of the Ionian Islands to understand that they are not alone in these difficult times for them.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because of the need for emergency aid for Greece after the earthquake.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Ionian Island was badly damaged by an earthquake last year. The EU Solidarity Fund aims to respond flexibly to crisis situations and to support the population of affected regions. Providing financial assistance to Greece is essential in order to effectively restore the island's living arrangements, infrastructure and cultural sites.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report providing financial assistance of EUR 1,651,834 from the EU Solidarity Fund to repair the damage caused by the earthquakes that hit the Ionian Islands region, in particular Lefkada, the northern parts of Ithaca, and Kefalonia on 17 November 2015. The account of the devastating earthquake includes human casualties, extensive damage to homes, infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural monuments, while some of the most important tourist beaches in Lefkada were destroyed. Financial assistance will help to restore infrastructure, to repay the emergency measures taken and to cover the costs of certain essential actions. The importance of the European Union Solidarity Fund, which aims to enable the Union to react quickly, effectively and flexibly to emergencies in order to express its solidarity with the population of areas affected by natural disasters, is also recognised.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Only 2.5% (i.e. EUR 1,651,834) of the total amount (EUR 66,073,345) estimated to have been caused by the devastating earthquake in the Ionian Islands and in particular in Lefkada, Ithaca and Kefalonia, in November 2015, will be granted to Greece by the mobilisation of the "EU Solidarity Fund", revealing how illusory the allegations of the EU's alleged "solidarity" are. The EU funds, from which a minimum amount has been disbursed for 11 months, do not make up for the losses of private individuals, i.e. working-class households, the self-employed and other micro-professionals affected. As the European Commission has repeatedly said, what is being financed is the restoration of infrastructure undertaken by business groups while excluding projects that do not yield large profits and are therefore not a priority for large capital.  The SYRIZA-ANEL government, which supports and implements the above EU guidelines to the letter, also has a great responsibility. At a time when it gives plenty of money and subsidies to business groups, it offers earthquake patients, as well as the people as a whole, only barbaric anti-popular measures. The Communist Party of Greece (KKE) European Parliamentary Group voted in favour of mobilising any funds from the Fund, but stressed the real and urgent need for full compensation for people's households and small professionals for disasters.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 1 651 834 to Greece for the earthquake that hit in 2015. The event was 6.1 on the Richter Scale in which two people lost their lives and 8 people injured. The Greek Government estimated the total damage to be over EUR 66 million. While in principle UKIP opposes the EU spending British taxpayer’s money, as this was for disaster relief and there was loss of life, we will not oppose its use in this case.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of this proposal, as I fully agree with my colleague that we should use the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to the Greek islands affected by the 2015 earthquake. The creation of this fund is aimed precisely at delicate and emergency situations such as this one. The European Union aims to provide assistance to Member States in situations of particular difficulty. I therefore believe that there must be a united and unequivocal response from the Union. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to assist Greece following the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015. Greece's affected regions fall into the category of "less developed regions" under the European Structural and Investment Funds, with a 6.1-magnitude earthquake on Richter causing enormous damage. Major damages have been reported to infrastructure networks, facilities, but also to cultural sites. Also, the amount of damage accounts for 2.1 % of the regional GDP of nuts 2 Ionian Islands, exceeding the threshold of 1.5 % of regional GDP, which is a condition for declaring a regional natural disaster. The proposed amount of mobilisation will not require amendments to the 2016 budget and in solidarity with the affected Regions of Greece, I support the Commission's proposal.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The solidarity fund is mobilizing 1.7 million euros to help Greece following the 6.1 magnitude earthquake that struck the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia in November 2015. One hundred and twenty homes were damaged, twenty of which were totally destroyed, and considerable damage also affected public infrastructure (hospitals, ports, churches, etc.).  The Greek authorities estimate the direct damage caused to 66 million euros or 2.1% of the GDP of the region concerned, which is above the regional natural disaster qualification threshold (1.5%). Funding for this aid is provided by the payment appropriations already included in the 2016 budget. In these circumstances, I therefore vote in favour of the proposed aid.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the expeditious mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to grant financial assistance in relation to the natural disaster that struck Greece on 17 November 2015 (earthquakes hitting the 6.1-magnitude Ionian Islands region on the Richter scale). Two people lost their lives, eight people were injured and 120 residential units were also damaged. Major damage to the infrastructure network, buildings and cultural sites has also been reported. Some of the most tourist-important beaches on Lefkada have also been destroyed. Greek authorities estimated the total direct damage at EUR 66 073 345. As this amount represents 2.1 % of the regional GDP of nuts 2 Ionian Islands and thus exceeds the threshold of 1.5 % of regional GDP, this natural disaster is considered a 'regional natural disaster'. The Greek authorities estimated the cost of emergency operations at EUR 52 374 000 (EUR 38 million transport sector, EUR 7 million for the protection of cultural heritage).

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. The Ionian Islands in Greece were hit in November 2015 by an earthquake that caused widespread destruction and prompted the Greek authorities in February 2016 to submit a request to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF).
