Now, almost a year after the disaster, the European Parliament approves the mobilisation of the EUSF. As appropriations are still available in the EUSF for 2016, the proposal is to provide the sum of EUR 1 651 834 to Greece in authorisation and payment appropriations. It is entirely justified for the EU to mobilise this support for Greece, in addition to a known framework of continued aggression against Greece, notably through successive troika memoranda that have destroyed economic structures and devastated it socially. We voted in favour. But this situation puts the need to change the EUSF mobilisation rules back on the agenda in order to enable a more expeditious and timely mobilisation. It is not understood that it is only almost a year after the disaster that there is a mobilisation of support which is often needed immediately, either to defend the safety of persons and property or to suffer the damage caused, seeking to normalise the economic and social life of the affected region as soon as possible.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in order to provide assistance to the Ionian Islands affected by the earthquake in 2015. The 6.1 Richter earthquake caused injuries and deaths of residents, damage to public buildings, private dwellings, cultural sites, ports and road infrastructure. The latter is crucial for the Greek economy, which is largely based on the services sector and, more specifically, tourism. The EUR 1.65 billion to be provided by the Solidarity Fund should help the Greek authorities in Lefkáda, Ithaca and Kefalonia to deal with the listed damages, restore infrastructure and help pay for clean-up operations. Although it is very sad that Greece has been affected by a natural disaster relatively soon since the catastrophic floods that hit greece at the end of 2015, I am glad that this is where the Solidarity Fund exists. Although this instrument was designed in response to the floods that particularly affected the Central European region in 2002, its mobilisation has convinced us for several times that European solidarity works and is applicable to all Member States, without exception.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 On 17 November 2015, a disaster occurred in Greece when an earthquake reaching 6.1 on the Richter scale hit the Ionian Islands, in particular the Islands of Lefkada and Kefalonia. In this natural disaster, some buildings, monuments and infrastructure were extensively damaged, but unfortunately there was also a loss of human life. On the island of Lefkada, beaches were destroyed, which played a key role in terms of tourism. The funding to be provided to Greece comes from the European Union Solidarity Fund, whose key role is to respond flexibly and effectively to unexpected events. In the context of recent events, I would also like to support greece's efforts to create a framework for the prevention and management of the risk of natural disasters, given that greece's territory is one of the most seismically active in Europe.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in connection with a disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015. It is an earthquake that has affected the Ionian Islands, in particular the island of Leucade, the northern areas of Itaca and the island of Kefalonia. At Greece's request, on 18 March 2016 the Commission granted an advance of EUR 164 798, or 10 % of the financial contribution provided for by the Fund. Earthquakes are manifestations of nature that too often, even in Italy, have caused death and devastation. I am convinced that more needs to be done with regard to the prevention and safety of the most vulnerable homes and population centres and that, in any case, solidarity with the populations affected by earthquakes must be one of the European Union's priorities. That is why I voted in favour of financial support for Greece.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up in 2002 to provide financial assistance to eligible Member States affected by large-scale natural disasters or regional exceptional disasters. The Commission proposes to use EUR 1 651 834 from this fund to help Greece in the wake of the series of earthquakes that struck the Ionian Islands region on 17 November 2015. The damage caused by this earthquake represented 2.1% of the GDP of these islands and therefore exceeded the threshold required to apply for the mobilisation of funds for a 'regional natural disaster'. The EUSF will cover 2.5% of the total direct damage caused by the earthquake. The full amount of EUR 1 651 834 can be covered by advances already entered in the 2016 budget, with sufficient appropriations remaining in the budget for new applications for mobilisation from the EUSF later in the year. The Ionian Islands region has been hit by a natural disaster that has caused enormous damage. I hereby supported the report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Unlike the so-called globalisation fund, for which I often have doubts, I must unequivocally agree with this proposal, because I believe that the Solidarity Fund actually helps citizens of EU countries.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted to provide Greece with financial assistance under the European Union Solidarity Fund to help the areas affected in November 2015 by the earthquake that hit the Ionian Islands in the country. Deaths, many injuries and destroyed homes were the toll of this catastrophic episode for these territories. I am pleased to see that the Union is characterising its solidarity by making a concrete contribution to this phase of reconstruction.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This report consists of the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in order to provide financial aid to Greece in the light of natural disasters in the past year. On November 17, 2015, the Ionian Islands were subjected to an earthquake with a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. The earthquake had vast consequences, such as the loss of the lives of two inhabitants, eight wounded and extensive damage to infrastructure systems, buildings and cultural points. The estimated damage was around EUR 66 million, which in the region concerned represents 2.1 % of GDP and may thus qualify as a regional disaster. With regard to previous practices, the Commission proposed the granting of financial support by the Fund in the size of 2.5 % of the total damage suffered. Amounting to this figure at €1,651,834 and with the Commission already advanced with 10% in March, mobilisation of €1,487,036 remains. Because it is an appropriate use of the EUSF, whose purpose is to contribute in situations of this nature, I vote in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 1 651 834 to Greece for the earthquake that hit in 2015. The event was 6.1 on the Richter Scale in which two people lost their lives and 8 people injured. The Greek Government estimated the total damage to be over EUR 66 million. While in principle UKIP opposes the EU spending British taxpayer’s money, as this was for disaster relief and there was loss of life, we will not oppose its use in this case.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance for a disaster in Greece (an earthquake that affected the Ionian islands region, namely the island of Lefkada and the northern regions of Cephalonia and Ithaca), which occurred on 17 November 2015. The affected region falls into the category of 'least developed regions' for the purposes of the European Structural and Investment Funds (2014-2020) and where two people lost their lives, eight were injured, 120 homes were damaged, of which 20 were deemed unfit to live. There has been significant damage to infrastructure networks, buildings and places of cultural interest. Some of the most important beaches were destroyed in Lefkada. As for respect for the rights of the human person, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of the Union Solidarity Fund to allocate EUR 1 651 834, as a sign of solidarity with the Greek regions affected by the November 2015 earthquake. Earthquakes, of a magnitude of 6.1 degrees, resulted in the deaths of two people, eight of whom were injured and 120 homes were damaged, 20 of which were deemed unfit to live in them. There was also serious damage to infrastructure networks and various buildings and cultural attractions.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilizing the European Union Solidarity Fund to help Greece in the wake of the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015. A series of catastrophic earthquakes struck the island of Leucade, damaging 120 homes, 20 of which were deemed uninhabitable.  These earthquakes have also caused considerable damage to municipal and provincial infrastructure networks, public and private buildings and other infrastructure, as well as cultural sites. Given all these elements, it seemed important and urgent to vote in favour of this financial aid.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which seeks to allocate funds to Greece from the European Union Solidarity Fund. This fund is intended to enable the Union to respond rapidly, effectively and flexibly in disaster situations in order to show solidarity with the population of regions affected by natural disasters. The need to use the fund came after the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands. The 2016 budget therefore is intended to provide greece with an amount of EUR 1 651 834 in commitment and payment appropriations.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. In November 2015 Greece was besolow by tragic earthquakes, with a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale, which mainly affected the Ionian Islands, causing the deaths of two people, injuries in eight, more than a hundred houses destroyed and extensive damage to public infrastructure and tourist-cultural heritage. The losses calculated by the Greek authorities amount to more than EUR 65 million, and this disaster has been classified as a regional disaster, in line with the criteria in line with the Regulation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. This region is classified as the 'least developed region' for the purposes of the European Structural and Investment Funds and, so far, the Commission has already made an advance of 10 % of the contribution of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), which aims to deal quickly, efficiently and flexibly with emergency situations arising from natural disasters. I agree with the total amount of financial aid - EUR 1 651 834 (in payment and authorisation appropriations to be granted to Greece under the EUSF), as it complies with the ceiling of EUR 552 million applicable to the EUSF and does not require any amendment to the 2016 budget.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to provide financial aid, with the help of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), to Greece, which was hit by an earthquake on 17 November 2015. Indeed, the Ionian Islands were hit by earthquakes with a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale.  Two people lost their lives and the direct damage is estimated to be 66.073 billion euros according to the Greek authorities. Thus, by this vote Parliament authorizes the Commission to grant just over 1.5 billion euros to help Greece, especially the Ionian Islands. These funds will be used to rebuild damaged infrastructure and cultural and natural sites severely affected by the earthquake.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 On 17 November 2015, Greece was hit by a terrible earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands in particular. At the request of the same country, the European Commission has granted an advance of 10 % in relation to its contribution from the Solidarity Fund. The payment of the remaining money requires the agreement of the European Parliament, which we have granted today.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. This report called for the mobilization of funds to help greece's Ionian Islands region from the damage sustained by an earthquake in November 2015. I vote for these funds to be mobilized in solidarity with the people who suffered the damage caused by this natural disaster.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. On 17 November 2015, the Ionian Islands (particularly Leucade and the northern areas of Ithaca and Kefalonia) suffered earthquakes whose damage is estimated at more than EUR 66 million, 2.1% of regional GDP. The objective of this report is to mobilisation the Union Solidarity Fund of EUR 1.7 million in commitment and payment appropriations. Although this is only a small amount in relation to total damage, I voted in favour of this report to contribute to the reconstruction of the area.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this because I believe aid should be decided on by nation states.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in order to provide assistance to Greece following the earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands in November 2015. This covers the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for an amount of EUR 1 651 834, this will be financed through the partial use of the EUR 50 000 000 in commitment and payment appropriations already entered into the 2016 budget, an amending budget is therefore not required.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund was established in 2002 to provide financial assistance to eligible states affected by a major natural disaster or an exceptional regional disaster. On 17 November 2016, Greece was hit by a series of earthquakes affecting the Ionian region, causing damage of 2.1% of the total GDP of these islands. I therefore voted in favour of providing financial assistance to Greece in the context of these earthquakes.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In November last year, the Ionian Islands of Greece were hit by earthquakes reaching 6.1 degrees On the Richter scale. As a result, two people were killed, eight were injured, 120 housing units were damaged, 20 of which are already uninhabitable. Extensive damage has also occurred on networks of infrastructure, other buildings and cultural monuments. As I believe that the EU Solidarity Fund is for such events, I supported the release of resources for Greece. The total cost of repairing the damage caused by the earthquakes was estimated by the Greek authorities at almost EUR 66.1 million. This means that this disaster can be regarded as a regional natural disaster and, therefore, Greece is entitled to funds from the Fund. Already in March this year, the Commission paid 10 % of the expected contribution as an advance payment. The total amount of aid proposed would be more than EUR 1,6 million on the basis of the 2,5 % rate applied by the Commission. These funds should reach the people affected by the disaster as a matter of speed so that they can cope with the consequences and return to normal life.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The report on the proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund foresees the mobilisation of part of the Fund for the purpose of reassing the aftermath of several earthquakes affecting the Ionian island region to Greece on 17 November 2015, in particular the island of Lefkada, northern parts of Ithaca and Kefania. The European Union Solidarity Fund is dedicated to precisely such cases and is designed to help a Member State or candidate country affected by a major catastrophe. The cost of emergency activities, as defined in Article 3 of the Solidarity Fund Regulation, is estimated by the Greek authorities to be EUR 52,374 million, of which 38 million relate to the transport sector and 7 million to the protection of cultural heritage. Following the Greek request, on 18 March 2016 the Commission granted EUR 164 798 or 10 % of the fund's expected aid. The total amount of the proposed aid is EUR 1 651 834. I support solidarity in such cases, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the pillars of European cooperation is solidarity between Member States and mutual assistance in unforeseen events such as natural disasters. Slovakia also benefited from the Solidarity Fund in the amount of EUR 5.7 million when the High Tatras were hit by a catastrophic storm in 2004.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the 'proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund'. If there could be a useful function of the EU, then I would opt for supranational insurance against natural disasters. I therefore support the use of the European Union Solidarity Fund within the framework of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. This will provide EUR 1 651 834 in payments to Greece to help in the face of an earthquake that shook the Ionian Islands in November 2015.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. The European Union Solidarity Fund (FSEU) was set up to respond to large-scale natural disasters and to express European solidarity with regions affected by the disaster. The European Union Solidarity Fund has been mobilised to assist Greece following the November 2015 earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands of €1,651,834. This mobilisation will be fully financed through a partial use of EUR 50 000 000 of commitment appropriations and payment appropriations. The funds have already been introduced in the 2016 budget and therefore no budget change is needed. I support the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to Greece, as I think it is necessary to show solidarity with the population of regions affected by natural disasters and at least mitigate huge losses through financial means.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece following the earthquake that struck the 1980s. Two people died as a result of the quake, eight were injured and 120 residential units were injured. Many buildings were damaged, as were the tourist's most important beaches on the island of Lefkada. Both the earthquake and the application meet all the criteria for granting assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund, while the region also falls into the category of less developed regions, which is why I supported the report.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report proposes mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece following the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015. By voting in favour of this report, we are sending a message of solidarity to the affected Greek regions.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU must be flexible when there are grounds for compensating countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ On 17 November 2015, an earthquake that measured 6.1 on the Richter scale hit the Ionian Islands region, in particular Lefkada, northern parts of Ithaki and Kefalonia. Two people lost their lives, eight were wounded and 120 houses were damaged. The Greek authorities reported extensive damage to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites, with some of the most important tourist beaches destroyed on Lefkada. This report contains a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council to mobilize the European Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece following the earthquake. The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond in a rapid, efficient and flexible manner to emergency situations in order to show solidarity with the population of regions struck by natural disasters. BUDG recommends a swift approval of the Commission proposal to mobilize EUR 1651 834. The aid will help restore infrastructure, reimburse the cost of emergency measures and cover some of the clean-up operations. I support this report, as I believe that Greece is eligible to receive the European Solidarity Fund.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. It is normal for us to show solidarity. The Commission proposes to provide financial assistance under the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to respond to a disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015 (earthquakes that affected the Ionian Islands region, including the island of Leucade and the northern areas of the islands of Ithaca and Cephalonia).  The earthquakes reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. Two people died, eight others were injured, 120 homes were damaged, 20 of which were deemed uninhabitable. Considerable damage has been done to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites. Some of the most important beaches on the island of Leucade from a tourist point of view have been destroyed.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ On 17 November 2015 the Ionian Islands region suffered a series of devastating earthquakes reaching a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. The devastation included two deaths, many injuries and the damage and destruction of 120 homes, accounting for approximately EUR 66 million. I voted for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, a crucial financial mechanism which will provide badly needed monetary assistance to the Ionian region in a bid to undo the damage and restore the lives, homes, infrastructure and the livelihoods of the people in the affected region.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. After the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015, Greece applied to mobilise funds from the Fund on the basis of a regional disaster of EUR 1 651 834, which I supported. As the European Union Solidarity Fund was set up to enable an emergency response to be responded swiftly, efficiently and flexibly, demonstrating solidarity with the population of regions affected by natural disasters or emergency regional disasters, Greece's request is eligible to mobilise its resources.  Therefore, I consider it right to provide assistance to the population directly affected by the earthquake in order to enable them to live with dignity.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide assistance to Greece following the earthquake that struck the 18th-century 1980s. The Commission proposes to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for financial assistance related to the natural disaster in Greece (the earthquake that struck the 17 November 2015 17th islands, in particular the island of Lefkada and the northern part of the Islands of Ithaca and Kefalonia). The total amount of aid is EUR 1 651 834. It is the first decision to mobilise the Fund in 2016 and the proposed total amount of aid is in line with the provisions on the EU Solidarity Fund ceiling of EUR 552 million.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. This report called for the mobilization of funds to help greece's Ionian Islands region from the damage sustained by an earthquake in November 2015. I vote for these funds to be mobilized in solidarity with the people who suffered the damage caused by this natural disaster.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Solidarity Fund is mobilizing 1.7 million euros to help Greece following the earthquake that struck the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia in November 2015. 120 homes were damaged, 20 of which were totally destroyed, and extensive damage also affected public infrastructure (hospitals, ports, churches, etc.).  The Greek authorities estimate the direct damage caused to 66 million euros or 2.1% of the GDP of the region concerned, which is above the regional natural disaster qualification threshold (1.5%). Funding for this aid is provided by the payment appropriations already included in the 2016 budget. I voted for it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Solidarity Fund is an important instrument for supporting Member States affected by a large and regional disaster. The case of an earthquake in the Ionian Islands is one such, so it is important to provide funding and help restore the state before the devastation. Greece has met all the technical requirements needed to apply for solidarity fund support. Solidarity is characteristic of European communities at difficult times, which is why I voted in favour of helping Greece.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The report summarises the ep and the EiT's decision to assist in the earthquake in the Greek Ionian Islands in November 2015 against the European Union Solidarity Fund. The Committee on Budgets recommends the swift adoption of the report in order to disburse the allocated funds as soon as possible. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. This report called for the mobilization of funds to help greece's Ionian Islands region from the damage sustained by an earthquake in November 2015. I vote for these funds to be mobilized in solidarity with the people who suffered the damage caused by this natural disaster.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilizing the Union Solidarity Fund to assist Greece following the earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands in November 2015, as the use of the fund for this circumstance is appropriate with the objectives and regulations stipulated.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I support the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in connection with the disaster in Greece (the earthquake that shocked the Ionian Islands region, in particular the Lefkada and Kefalolian islands).

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. The Commission proposes mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to grant financial assistance relating to a disaster in Greece (earthquakes affecting the Ionian Islands region) that occurred on 17 November 2015. The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond in a rapid, efficient and flexible manner to emergency situations in order to show solidarity with the population of regions struck by natural disasters. The Fund is not to exceed a maximum annual amount of EUR 500 000 000. I voted in favour because I believe that this aid will help communities in the Ionian Islands to restore infrastructure, reimburse the cost of emergency measures and cover some of the clean-up operations.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. It is a common objective for Greece to return to the path of growth and job creation. To achieve this, a key factor is competitiveness; which, in turn, can only be achieved through the implementation of the structural reforms recommended by the Union as a whole to the Greek Government. I therefore support with my vote this statement by the Commission and its purpose, which is but to assess what progress Greece has made in the agreed reforms, since these are a condition for outstanding disbursements under the second tranche of the third financial assistance programme that we Europeans grant to Greece.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. On 17 November 2015, the Ionian Islands (particularly Leucade and the northern areas of Ithaca and Kefalonia) suffered earthquakes whose damage is estimated at more than EUR 66 million, 2.1% of regional GDP. The objective of this report is to mobilisation the Union Solidarity Fund of EUR 1.7 million in commitment and payment appropriations. Although this is only a small amount in relation to total damage, I voted in favour of this report to contribute to the reconstruction of the area.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. \u2012 The Commission proposes to make funds from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSSFEU) available to provide financial assistance in connection with the earthquake in Greece on 17 November 2015 in the Ionian Islands region, in particular the island of Lefkada, the northern part of Ithaki and Kefalonia. The earthquake had a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. Two people were killed, eight people were injured, 120 homes were damaged, 20 of which were declared uninhabitable. There is significant damage to infrastructure, buildings and cultural sites. At Lefkada, some of the largest beaches in the field of tourism were destroyed. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that Europe should do its part here.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The Ionian Islands, including the islands of Leucade and Cephalonia, were hit in November 2015 by a series of earthquakes reaching a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale. The damage has been considerable for this tourist area and therefore particularly important for the local economy. The damage was estimated at 52.374 million euros, or 2.1% of Greece's GDP, and this country, which is largely affected by austerity policies, really did not need that, if I may put it that way. It is therefore the least that the European Union is involved in the reconstruction of infrastructure, as it usually does in other countries in similar circumstances when the damage is greater than 1.5% of GDP. It was even urgent for her to do so. I therefore voted for this text in solidarity with Greece, but regretted that this decision can only be taken now, eleven months after the events, and that the amount allocated is so small.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. After the earthquake that struck the Ionian Islands in November 2015, Greece submitted a request to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund. As appropriations are still available in the European Solidarity Fund for 2016, the proposal is to provide greece with eur 1 651 834 in authorisation and payment appropriations. We do, but we regret the length of the process.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The Commission proposes to use the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide Financial Assistance to Greece due to a natural disaster (6.1 magnitude earthquake on the Richter scale) in the Ionian Islands region. The Solidarity Fund was set up for precisely these purposes and is intended to provide Greece with a total of €1.65 million in aid to help the structurally weak region rebuild. I think this measure is useful and I have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Solidarity Fund is meant to assist Member States in recovering from natural disasters. As the name suggests, it is another expression of the EU value of social solidarity.  I joined fellow Labour MEPs to press the UK Tory government to apply for Solidarity Funds when the North of the UK, and particularly my own constituency of the North West of England, were hit by devastating floods in late 2015. The government eventually agreed to request the funds and filed a partial application, but shamefully, it has since failed to complete that application.  In the meantime, Greece has filed an application which has been approved for support after an earthquake. It is sad to see that while the Tories had the opportunity to receive more funds to support communities in the North West, they have chosen not to pursue this.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today voted on the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance in connection with a disaster in Greece on 17 November 2015, an earthquake that affected the Ionian Islands, in particular the island of Lefkada, the northern areas of Itaca and the island of Kefalonia. The earthquake reached a magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale and left two dead and eight injured, damaging 120 housing units, 20 of which were declared unusable. This is combined with widespread damage to infrastructure networks, buildings and cultural sites. The Greek authorities have estimated that the total direct damage caused by the disaster amounted to approximately EUR 66 million; the total amount of aid proposed by the EUSF and approved today in plenary is EUR 1 651 834.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Only 2.5% (i.e. EUR 1,651,834) of the total amount (EUR 66,073,345) estimated to have been caused by the devastating earthquake in the Ionian Islands and in particular in Lefkada, Ithaca and Kefalonia, in November 2015, will be granted to Greece by the mobilisation of the "EU Solidarity Fund", revealing how illusory the allegations of the EU's alleged "solidarity" are. The EU funds, from which a minimum amount has been disbursed for 11 months, do not make up for the losses of private individuals, i.e. working-class households, the self-employed and other micro-professionals affected. As the European Commission has repeatedly said, what is being financed is the restoration of infrastructure undertaken by business groups while excluding projects that do not yield large profits and are therefore not a priority for large capital.  The SYRIZA-ANEL government, which supports and implements the above EU guidelines to the letter, also has a great responsibility. At a time when it gives plenty of money and subsidies to business groups, it offers earthquake patients, as well as the people as a whole, only barbaric anti-popular measures. The Communist Party of Greece (KKE) European Parliamentary Group voted in favour of mobilising any funds from the Fund, but stressed the real and urgent need for full compensation for people's households and small professionals for disasters.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: Written. The PVV voted against the mobilisation of these funds because compensation from the EU for the financial impact of the 2015 earthquake has already been more than granted by the hundreds of billions that member states have poured into the Greek Treasury and the billions of debt relief granted by the banks.  No agreement made with Greece has been implemented in the amounts transferred by the taxpayers of the Member States to Greece. According to the PVV, there is therefore no reason to think that any funds from the Solidarity Fund will be used to repair the earthquake damage on the Ionian islands.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Greece's request to mobilise the Solidarity Fund. In February this year, Greece requested the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in relation to the damage caused by the Ionian Earthquake in November 2015, which amounted to up to 2.1% of regional GDP. I supported this proposal not only because the disaster caused by the earthquake in Greece fulfils all the conditions for financial assistance from the Solidarity Fund, but above all as a principle that the European Union also means aid and support for Member States that may find themselves in crisis situations due to various unforeseen causes. I believe that, with the financial assistance provided by this fund, Greece will be able to repair the destroyed infrastructure and cultural monuments and thus restore disrupted tourism.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the decision to use the European Union Solidarity Fund, within the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016, to provide an amount of EUR 1 651 834 for Greece. On 5 February 2016, Greece submitted an application to use the fund in the lead-up to the earthquake that struck the 18th islands in November 2015. I support the intention of the European Union Solidarity Fund to enable the Union to respond quickly, effectively and flexibly to emergencies, thus showing its solidarity with the populations of areas affected by natural disasters.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Finland's application concerns 2161 workers made redundant by Microsoft and eight downstream suppliers and manufacturers. In Finland, employment in the technology sector has fallen sharply in recent years, following a European trend, contrary to what has happened for the US and China. As I think it is important for Finland to receive these funds, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this budgetary (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 5 364 000 (60% match funding) for 1 441 Finnish workers who have been made redundant. This is nothing more than EU dole money. UKIP opposes British taxpayers’ money being used to offset poor economic decisions in other countries and by the EU.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. Finland requested assistance from FEAG following the dismissal of 2,161 Microsoft Mobile OY workers and 8 of its suppliers and product transformers. Although European aid does not guarantee continuity of employment in the sector in an area badly affected by the decline of Nokia and the Finnish electronics industry, they do represent an improvement in the situation of dismissed workers, so I voted in favour.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – This EGF application materialised when Nokia initially moved production lines to the Far East, then closed down some more specialised production areas too and sold the mobile phone operation to Microsoft in 2013. The situation has replicated itself this time around when Microsoft have done the same thing. Like all EGF applications, there are good and bad elements to this. However, the decision comes down to the same question each time: whether to deny support for redundant workers over trying to make a larger political statement to the EU and to the companies who are relocating or restructuring. We supported this application in BUDG and also in EMPL.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which gives the green light for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (WEF) in Finland, mainly in the Helsinki-Uusimaa, Etel-Suomi and Lunsi-Suomi regions. Solidarity must not be an empty word in Europe!

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at the request of Finland, because it is of major importance to assist beneficiaries in their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Written. The European Globalisation Fund is a useful tool to mitigate the impact of eu closures, but it remains only a wipe for the bleeding afterwards. However, more proactive efforts are needed to save and/or even bring industry back to our continent. In this respect, the EU is, by all the rules and burdens, a brake rather than an engine. The Member States themselves must be able to pursue an active (re)industrialisation policy and adopt an economic patriotism. It may be somewhat cynical that the fund paid out EUR 5.4 million for the closure of a Finnish division of a multinational that posted a net profit of USD 12.2 billion in 2015.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The EGF supports skills, counselling and support for people who have become unemployed as a result of globalisation or global severe economic crises. This report deals with the support of 2035 employees of Microsoft in Finland who have lost their jobs due to the economic development and global competition of the company. An amount of EUR 5 364 000 will therefore be made available to the country. I am in favour of this project because it gives workers new perspectives.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 1889 employees at Microsoft and 146 in some subcontractors, Finland requested the support of the Globalization Adjustment Fund (EMF) to the tune of EUR 5.36 million to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of 1,141 of these workers.  The global distribution of jobs in the information technology sector has largely come at the expense of the EU, which is competing with emerging countries, particularly in Asia. In 2014, the number of jobs in this sector fell by 2% in Finland. Similarly, these job losses are linked to the decline in market share of phones operating with Microsoft's operating system.  However, there is no reference to the effects of the euro on Competition from Finland. When its neighbour, Sweden, saw its GDP grow by 15% since 2007, Finland saw its gdp contract by 1%.  The fund aims to timidly mask the consequences of EU trade and monetary policies and to disempower large companies without requiring consideration. However, I voted for this aid, which is useful for the reintegration of workers suffering from the free-trade lubies of the European Commission.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Finland, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, which provides for 5,364,000 euros in aid for the mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, in order to help employees who have been laid off at Microsoft to find a job. The support provided by this fund is welcome to revitalize and support this industry. In addition, the Finnish authorities began providing personalised services to the workers concerned on 11 September 2015, long before seeking assistance from the WEF. Nevertheless, I regret that the payment of this aid is carried out in the face of redundancies, when it could have been valuable to help the company to restructure itself. There is an urgent need to act and understand that our companies are the victims of the lack of structural reforms necessary to adapt to the challenges of globalization.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft). A drastic decline in nokia's phone market has forced Microsoft to eliminate 2,300 jobs in Finland. This is a major shock to workers, and Microsoft has submitted an application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which was set up to provide additional assistance to workers affected by major structural changes in world trade patterns. In view of the situation, I welcome the commission's proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF for Finland's needs in order to support the return of workers made redundant from Microsoft to the labour market.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 5 364 000 (60% match funding) for 1441 Finnish workers who have been made redundant. This is nothing more than EU dole money. UKIP opposes British taxpayer’s money being used to offset poor economic decisions in other countries and by the EU.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 1,889 Microsoft employees and 146 of some subcontractors, Finland has requested the support of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to the tune of EUR 5.36 million to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of 1,141 of these workers. The EGF can indeed be mobilised if a link between layoffs and major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization is established.  However, the global distribution of jobs in the information technology sector has largely come at the expense of the EU, which is competing with emerging countries, particularly in Asia.  I voted in favour of this report, knowing that this 'adjustment fund' is only a bad thing: if it really wants to combat the deleterious effects of globalisation, the European Union must abandon the dogma of the free movement of goods and people and no longer stand in the way of the implementation of protectionist measures. Workers do not have to endure the free-trade lubies of the Eurocrats.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade. On 11 March 2016, Finland applied for a financial contribution from the WEF following redundancies at Microsoft and 8 downstream suppliers and producers in Finland. There were 2,035 layoffs during this period between September 11, 2015 and January 11, 2016, including 1,889 workers at Microsoft. These mass layoffs come against a backdrop of exacerbation of international competition, particularly in the telephony sector, which has already cost Finland more than 5,000 jobs in technology companies in 2014.  In view of the situation experienced by Finnish workers and the need to make Europe a project of solidarity and not just a free trade area, I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to mobilise the EGF for EUR 5,364,000, or 60% of the total cost of the actions proposed by Finland.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument designed to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The significant changes that have taken place in recent years in the structure of world trade, and in particular in the ICT sector, have led to a loss of positions of Europe, a leader in the sector in the early 2000s thanks to Nokia, in favor of China and the United States, benefiting from the introduction of operating systems such as android and iOS. The decline of Nokia and consequently of finnish electronics as a whole has led Microsoft to announce plans to restructure the company's telephony business, with the loss of 2 300 jobs in Finland. My vote in favour of the Sarvamaa report stems from the need to mobilise the EGF to provide assistance to the 1 441 workers made redundant by Microsoft and eight downstream suppliers and producers in Finland. This measure will provide a coordinated package of instruments, including training and mobility allowances as well as business start-up grants and training, retraining and vocational training programmes.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, this time it is Microsoft in Finland, who had already absorbed unemployed people who came from Nokia, but who, by mobilizing much of their production, are again unemployed. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. On the other hand, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I supported the granting of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to Finland, including the 2,161 laid-off workers at Microsoft and its eight downstream suppliers and producers. Once again, we see the catastrophic results of the so-called European trade policy. In recent years, ICT jobs, as in many other fields, have been relocated outside the EU, particularly in Asia, where labour is cheaper. The figures speak for themselves and are frightening: in 2014, the number of people employed in technology companies in Finland fell by 2%, representing more than 5,000 employees; for 2014, the sector employed 285,000 people in Finland, while in 2008 the total number was still 326,000. At the same time, the number of employees for this sector continued to grow in the USA as well as in China.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report authorising the mobilisation of EUR 5 364 000 from the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, for the benefit of 1 441 workers made redundant by Microsoft Mobile in Finland. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a key instrument for supporting European citizens in this time of crisis. However, the EU should put employment policies in Europe at the top of its list of priorities, rather than running for cover by supporting workers who have lost their jobs, precisely because of its crazy choices.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of EUR 5 364 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the reintegration into the labour market of 1 441 workers, dismissed by Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight of its suppliers in Finland. These funds shall be devoted to financing measures for laid-off workers, including advisory measures, employment and business services, training, wage subsidies or business-building subsidies.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which examines the Commission's proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF for Finland's needs in order to support the return to the labour market of workers made redundant from Microsoft and 8 of its supply and downstream companies in Finland, which are active in computer programming, consultancy. The Finnish authorities argue that the main reason for the redundancies at Microsoft is the declining market for its phones. They are linking this reduction in the workforce to the significant structural changes in world trade trends resulting from globalisation and point out that the EU's share of all jobs in the ICT sector has decreased, while the corresponding share of China and the US has increased. Although Nokia dominated mobile phone markets between 2000 and 2010, then Android and iOS operating systems used by various Asian-based manufacturers took a dominant market position. The Finnish authorities pointed to a trend that affects the finnish electronics industry as a whole and is linked to a decrease in the market share of Nokia, which has sold its mobile phone operations to Microsoft. In 2014, Microsoft announced its plans to cut its total workforce by 18,000 jobs in 2015, including 1,100 jobs in Finland, and in 2015 announced plans to restructure the phone business, which provides for the elimination of 2,300 jobs in Finland.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. Finland has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) regulation to Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight related suppliers with reference numbers "EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft" following redundancies of 2 161 related suppliers. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. Finland is planning six types of measures for redundant workers affected by the application: coaching and other preparatory measures; employment and business services; vocational training in the labour market; payment subsidies; start-up aid; reimbursement of travel, accommodation and removal expenses. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I also supported the decision to use the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, a request submitted a few months ago by Finland with a desire to reintegrate workers made redundant at Microsoft or formerly Nokia and its suppliers into the labour market. The application relates to 1441 of the 2161 redundancies and amounts to EUR 1 365 000. The redundancies were linked to large structural flows in the field of information and communication trade, resulting in increased employment in Asia. Nokia dominated the mobile phone market in the first decade of the 21st century, but was pushed out by Asian manufacturers using Android and iOS operating systems. Finland has been facing these problems for a long time, as the decline of Nokie has affected the entire Finnish electronics industry. After the sale of the nokia to Microsoft, there was a 1,100 staff reduction in 2014 alone in Finland, and a further 2,300 people were expected to lose their jobs in 2015 and 2016. Eu assistance is therefore very important for re-employment and assistance to workers made redundant.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which is related to the dismissal of 2,161 people at Microsoft in Finland. Surpluses are caused by the main structural changes in world trading customs, so the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help redundant people integrate into the labour market.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report proposes to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help Finland re-cash 1,141 workers who have been laid off from Microsoft. Even if this report does not mention the real causes of this mass dismissal, employees do not have to bear the Commission's mistakes in protecting the EU's economic borders. Therefore, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this proposal for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), because the European Union has the duty to alleviate the situation of people facing negative effects caused by globalisation. The EGF has the aim of providing support to workers who are suffering negative consequences of the phenomenon. Finland asked for an intervention after the redundancies made by Microsoft Mobile and I supported the EU’s financial aid to Finland.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is useful for providing support to redundant workers and self-employed workers whose activities have ceased as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, due to the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis or due to a new economic and financial crisis of a supra-regional nature. The Fund must be used to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market, updating their training and giving it financial support at the same time. The EGF should therefore be mobilised to make a financial contribution to workers in companies that have suffered serious failures as a result of the changing international IT market and the new business strategies of Microsoft and its partner companies.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to provide Finland with a financial contribution of 5.36 million euros from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the dismissal of 1889 employees at Microsoft and 146 employees at some of its subcontractors. This financial assistance is intended to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of these laid-off workers.  On the one hand, this request by Finland fulfils the conditions for granting the EGF, granted if the link between layoffs and changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalisation is established. On the other hand, we consider it our duty to show solidarity with the Finns who are suffering, as in France, the consequences of savage globalisation.  However, instead of addressing the roots of deindustrialization such as unfair international competition, this fund aims only to mask the disastrous consequences of the European Union's trade and monetary policies. I still voted for this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the EU Regulation, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in global trade practices, and in this case we are talking about workers made redundant from Microsoft and 8 other suppliers and downstream producers of this company in Finland. Global trade practices resulting from the globalisation process have led to a considerable decrease in employment in the ICT sector, which is felt most strongly in Finland, where the sector is decisive for the economy. I voted in favour of this report because I think it is very important for Finland to receive this support for the workers made redundant.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EAF) is intended to provide support to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in the structure of world trade.  The application submitted to the Commission by Finland on 11 March 2016 satisfies the conditions for the granting of a financial contribution from the EAGGF.  The decline in popularity of Microsoft's platform led to a steep decline in market share, as it was already quite small. This was also the main reason for the redundancies at Microsoft Finland is entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 5 364 000, representing 60 % of the total costs of EUR 8 940 000, so the worrying situation created by the unemployment of persons with high skills and education, who would normally have had a good chance of taking up a job will be remedied as soon as possible.  I support that report and stress that the Union must be a main support for bringing a balance back to the economic market in Finland.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked Microsoft employees at Finland's request. This demand is justified given the very high level of competition in the field of mobile telephony. The sum of 5,364,000 euros will be mobilised to help 2161 laid-off employees reintegrate into the world of work.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade.  The application in question was submitted by Finland in relation to 1 441 redundancies at Microsoft, mainly due to the decline in the market share of its mobile phones. I note that the staff reductions in the electronics sector in Finland are linked to the decline of Nokia, which sold its mobile phone operations to Microsoft. I regret, and I will reiterate this in every explanation of vote, that Italian companies are not able to benefit more from this fund because of the lack of support from local and national institutions. Between 2007 and 2015, Italy submitted only 15 applications to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, 3 of which in 2007, only one in 2008, zero between 2009 and 2010, 7 in 2011, 2 in 2012, zero in 2013, one in 2014 and one in 2015.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Fund provides assistance to persons who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in world trade patterns. This EGF application materialised when Nokia initially moved production lines to the Far East, then closed down some more specialised production areas and sold its mobile phone operation to Microsoft in 2013. Microsoft have now done the same thing.  I voted in favour of activating the fund for the 2161 workers made redundant in Finland.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Finland to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Microsoft and eight of its suppliers and downstream producers in Finland, operating in computer programming, consultancy and related activities. The Finnish authorities state the workforce reductions are linked to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation by recalling that the EU share in the ICT sector employment has decreased, while the share of China and the United States has increased.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Finland has applied for EGF assistance to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Microsoft and eight suppliers and producers downstream in Finland, operating in NACE Revision 2 Division 62. As economic growth should be used to alleviate the situation of those affected by the negative effects of globalisation, I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the application because we believe it fulfils the conditions for the granting of a financial contribution by the EGF.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at the request of Finland in the case of employees at Microsoft. As this Fund provides resources for the benefit of workers, I believe that the proposal has a positive purpose and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 29 July 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilising the EGF in favour of Finland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Microsoft and eight downstream suppliers and producers in Finland, operating in NACE Revision 2 Division 62. The Commission concluded, in accordance with all the applicable provisions of the EGF Regulation, that the application fulfils the conditions for financial assistance from the Fund. The Finnish authorities claim that the redundancies at Microsoft are mainly due to the decline in the market share of its mobile phones due to the increase in the market share of China and the United States. In order to mobilise the Fund, the Commission submitted to the budgetary authority a request for a transfer totalling EUR 5 364 000 from the EGF reserve. In the event of disagreement, a trialogue procedure will be initiated, as provided for in Article 15(4) of the EGF Regulation.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution to mobilise EUR 5 364 000 for the 1 441 workers made redundant by Microsoft Mobile in Finland. Staff reductions in information and communication technologies are due to the significant changes in world trade caused by globalisation. It is worth recalling that in the same area of employment technologies, the EU's share is falling while that of China and the UNITED States continues to increase..

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am having to vote in favour of this measure because recourse to the EGF is undoubtedly necessary. Indeed, there is an urgent need to ensure that the 2 035 employees made redundant by the US IT giant can benefit from the best possible assistance, as we hope will be the case with the contribution of EUR 1 365 000 that we voted for. The report proposed by my colleague clearly shows that the Microsoft crisis is caused by a sharp reduction in sales of related products, and the organisational speed with which Finland has already established measures to prepare former Microsoft employees for new jobs is laudable. It emerges powerfully once again, however, not only how global competition in the IT sector can lead to turbulence on national labour markets, but also the decrease in competitiveness that the Union is facing even in countries that have always been known to be at the forefront. This framework can only encourage me in my work to fight for effective regulatory strategies to achieve a peak in European productivity in the not too distant future.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Support the Sarvama report which allows the use of EUR 5,364,000 from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight of its suppliers and downstream producers in Finland. The redundancies were caused by the decrease in the market share of their mobile phones with Microsoft's Windows operating system from more than 50% in 2009 to 0.6% in the second quarter of 2016. The redundancies fall within the trend affecting the entire Finnish electronics industry since Nokia's decline in its home country. Through the use of this Fund, created to provide additional support to workers for major structural changes in world trade, it will be possible to support these workers through measures ranging from guidance/interpretation and facilitating job search to support for business creation or personalised professional requalification.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the changed economic conditions and the mobile phone market have led nokia to lose about 45 % of its market share and to reduce its staff at its offices in Helsinki-Uusimaa, Etela-Suomi and Lansi-Suomi, leaving around 2 000 workers redundant. Through the use of the EGF, in conjunction with the activities of the Finnish Public Employment Service, six types of measures will be offered, ranging from mentoring to vocational training, which will enable former employees to have constant support and re-enter the labour market. The financial contribution from the EGF will cover 60 % of the total costs and will amount to around EUR 5 million.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The ICT sector plays a key role in the Finnish economy with it having the highest employment percentage in ICT amongst all Member States. The redundancies in Microsoft are linked with the trend that has affected the entire Finnish electronics industry since the decline of Nokia and for which four previous applications have been presented.  Those made redundant have highly varying competencies, 89 % of them are between 30 and 54 years of age. I support this assistance since it will help these people through targeted vocational labour training and provide start-up grants.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. Finland requested assistance from FEAG following the dismissal of 2,161 Microsoft Mobile OY workers and 8 of its suppliers and product transformers. Although European aid does not guarantee continuity of employment in the sector in an area badly affected by the decline of Nokia and the Finnish electronics industry, they do represent an improvement in the situation of dismissed workers, so I voted in favour.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 29 July 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilising the EGF in favour of Finland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Microsoft. Finland argues that the distribution of ICT employment between the EU and other economies has changed in recent years at the expense of the EU's share. These effects have been particularly felt in Finland, for whose economy the ICT sector plays a key role. In particular, the Finnish authorities claim that the redundancies at Microsoft are mainly due to the decrease in the market share of its mobile phones, due to the introduction of the Android system. I voted in favour because I am convinced that the instrument is the quickest way to offer concrete help to workers, showing Europe and its face of solidarity.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to support workers affected by major structural changes in global trade practices. According to the Finnish authorities, the main reason for the redundancies at Microsoft is the declining market share of microsoft's mobile phones. Microsoft laid off 1,441 employees out of a total of 2,161. I voted for the allocation of EUR 1 365 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for guidance measures, training, wage subsidies and other measures to help redundant staff.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Although globalisation generally creates economic growth, it can also lead to changes that negatively affect the labour market in one or more Member States. To remedy this, the Union has set up the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, a set of legislative and budgetary instruments designed to support workers affected by major structural changes in world trade or made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, and to support their reintegration into the labour market. Finland has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following redundancies of 2 161 people at Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight related suppliers and downward processing companies. The Finnish authorities claim that the primary reason for Microsoft's redundancies is the declining market share of its mobile phones. The authorities tie labour reductions to significant structural changes in world trade as a result of globalisation, recalling that the EU has decreased in ICT employment, while China and the US have increased their share. Although Nokia dominated the markets in the first decade of the 2000s, Android and iOS operating systems used by various Asian manufacturers have since taken market leadership. The Commission found that the conditions for a financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled for the application. Parliament approved the request at its meeting today, which I voted in favour of.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of finland's request for assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because I believe that this fund should be used in these situations. The application submitted by Finland is the result of the dismissal of 2161 employees from Microsoft, the main reason for the redundancies is the decrease in sales of mobile phones with Microsoft software. These workers cannot be left unassy, every step must be taken to improve their situation on the labour market. For these reasons, I voted in favour because I am convinced that Finland will use the funds allocated from this fund to increase employment and support growth.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The main reason for workforce reductions at Microsoft is the declining market share of phones (Lumia) that use Microsoft Windows operating system. I am in favour of these redundant workers benefitting from the European Globalisation Adjustment fund, as its main purpose is to serve as a flexible instrument in the EU budget to provide support, under specific conditions, to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of mass redundancies caused by major changes in global trade.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report focuses on a call for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which aims to help Member States that are experiencing a reduction in activities and employees in a particular professional sector. In this report, the mobilization of the fund is requested by Finland for the mobile telephony sector. Finland submitted this request following numerous layoffs, particularly at Microsoft. This request concerns 1,441 employees and represents 5.3 million euros. Considering that the Union must promote the transition of its economy towards growth and employment-promoting sectors through support for laid-off workers, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this report on Finland's request for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF). The WEF was designed to help workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade.  Following a decline in its market share in the telephony sector, Microsoft laid off 2161 of its workers in Finland. Therefore, there is every reason to use the EGF. The list of personalized services, funded by the WEF, to help its workers find jobs combines business-friendly measures and initiatives for workers. It is this kind of comprehensive strategy, integrating all actors and interests, that the European Union must encourage.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) regulation to Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight related suppliers with reference numbers "EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft" following redundancies of 2,161 people. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. Finland is planning six types of measures for redundant workers affected by the application: coaching and other preparatory measures; employment and business services; vocational training in the labour market; payment subsidies; start-up aid; reimbursement of travel, accommodation and removal expenses. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. The plenary followed the position of the Committee on Budgets, of which I am a member, and voted to grant EUR 5,364,000 requested by the Finnish authorities following a series of redundancies at Microsoft (Microsoft Mobile Oy) and 8 suppliers and producers. This assistance will help to co-finance active measures for 2,161 people focused on job search assistance, training, career reorientation, etc. The main reason for the downsizing at Microsoft is to look in the decline in market share of its phones (Lumia) in favor of operating systems designed in the USA, but used by several Asian manufacturers. Globalisation is clearly a serious problem for European producers.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. In recent years, the distribution of employment in the ICT (information and communication technologies) sector between the EU and other economies has come at the expense of the EU. The effects have been particularly felt in Finland, where the ICT sector plays a key role in the economy.  Microsoft's restructuring in 2016 resulted in the dismissal of more than 2,000 employees, including eight of the company's suppliers and producers, downstream. It is legitimate for the European Union to help these laid-off workers through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. EUR 5.354 million has been allocated to fund an employment training and skills upgrading programme or entrepreneurship support programmes.  But, in addition to the one-off and specific assistance that the Fund can provide, there is an urgent need for the European Union to put in place a real strategy to better anticipate economic changes, to preserve SMEs, to implement a forward-looking investment policy, and to develop genuine trade defence instruments.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is not the right instrument for tackling this problem and I and my group are against funds to be allocated to this fund because the outcome that is achieved is not effective. How to tackle unemployment and changes occurring in sectors where globalisation is most clearly reflected must be addressed with policies that create growth and jobs. So will the victims of globalisation be able to switch to other sectors.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be allocated, in essence, to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies because this creates skilled unemployed people and does not address the present situation.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) regulation to Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight related suppliers with reference numbers "EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft" following redundancies of 2,161 people. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. Finland is planning six types of measures for redundant workers affected by the application: coaching and other preparatory measures; employment and business services; vocational training in the labour market; payment subsidies; start-up aid; reimbursement of travel, accommodation and removal expenses. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. It is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures, and so I voted in favour of this application. I regret that the UK Government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. "Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism.
