We have previously accepted that the Fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, particularly in the light of the Swedish National Audit Office's analysis, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The EGF was created to provide additional support to workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take action to get their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: this aid is useful for the reintegration of workers who do not have to endure the free-trade lubies of the European Commission.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The application refers to a total of 2 161 workers made redundant at Microsoft and eight downstream suppliers and producers (1 889 employees) between September 2015 and January 2016, with 3 Finnish regions being affected (Helsinki-Uusimaa, Southern Finland, Western Finland). Initially, Microsoft reinstated some Nokia workers who received support from the Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGF). Nokia moved production lines to the Far East, then closed some of the most specialized production areas, eventually selling to Microsoft in 2013 the production of mobile phones, for now until that is being shut down. Another example of relocation, another procession of destruction and unemployment, a few thousand more victims of ruling neoliberalism. The resolution formulates the usual recommendations. But it makes no reference to the fact that workers from Nokia's redundancies have already received 'aid' from the EGF, and there has therefore been a failure in the assumption of that fund as regards at least the provision of safe and long-term contracts to workers, which relativises the weight of those recommendations. If it is necessary to support the laid-off workers, it is still deplorable how this instrument has been used.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I do not consider this measure to be a useful tool for developing policies that promote growth and the creation of new jobs, nor can it provide a comprehensive answer on redundant workers.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it benefits ordinary workers.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund serves to cover losses for businesses and companies in member states that have to cope with the consequences of the financial and economic crisis, which has often forced them to lay off employees. In the present case, this is a request from Microsoft and 8 of its suppliers in Finland. It concerns the mobilisation of a total of EUR 1 365 000 from the EGF in favour of Finland and 1 441 out of a total of 2 161 redundancies.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of aid for the 1 441 unemployed workers in Finland.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be allocated, in essence, to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies, because this creates skilled unemployed people and does not address the present situation.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The application relates to 2161 redundancies of the enterprise Microsoft (Microsoft Mobile Oy) in Finland, operating in the economic sector classified under NACE Rev. 2 division 62 (Computer programming, consultancy and related activities) during the reference period from 11 September 2015 to 11 January 2016. The EGAF funding of EUR 5 364 000, which I support, will contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for 1441 targeted beneficiaries following redundancies, with the aim of providing assistance for integrating the affected persons into the labour market. The redundancies were caused by major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) regulation to Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight related suppliers with reference numbers "EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft" following redundancies of 2,161 people. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. Finland is planning six types of measures for redundant workers affected by the application: coaching and other preparatory measures; employment and business services; vocational training in the labour market; payment subsidies; start-up aid; reimbursement of travel, accommodation and removal expenses. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) regulation to Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight related suppliers with reference numbers "EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft" following redundancies of 2,161 people. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. Finland is planning six types of measures for redundant workers affected by the application: coaching and other preparatory measures; employment and business services; vocational training in the labour market; payment subsidies; start-up aid; reimbursement of travel, accommodation and removal expenses. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in connection with Finland's EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft application. Europe and the world are immersed in a profound process of globalization which, despite being a source of trade and wealth creation, can also carry risks to which we must be very attentive. As a result of this process, there are sectors that are more exposed to international competition, so from the EU we must respond to those citizens who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation. FeAG supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalization or the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council mobilising a contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 5 364 000 presented by Finland in relation to the 2621 redundancies of the Company Microsoft Mobile OI because I believe it is right to support Finnish workers, already heavily affected by the closure of Nokia plants, in the long process of professional relocation. We are talking about a sector, information technology, in which the EU suffers heavily from the major international competitors and in which mainly young, highly qualified engineers under 50 work, who would have no difficulty in normal employment conditions. I therefore think that the funding of personalised services such as mentoring services, vocational training services, employment services, recruitment incentives, start-up grants and allowances for travel, overnight and removal expenses is very important and that the finnish authorities' decision to pair these interventions with other measures already provided for in structural fund expenditure is a step in the right direction. I think it is important, however, that the Commission monitors the use of these incentives and, in general, the various sources of funding for employment programmes, in order to avoid speculative behaviour on the part of companies.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Among other things, the ICT sector is affected by globalisation-related emigration. These trends in emigration have particularly negative effects on the Finnish economy. The EGF offers a good and rapid European response to a global problem. It provides job and career coaching, training, employment and business services, salary allowances, grants for business start-ups and travel, accommodation and relocation allowances.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this budgetary (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 5 364 000 (60% match funding) for 1441 Finnish workers who have been made redundant. This is nothing more than EU dole money. UKIP opposes British taxpayer’s money being used to offset poor economic decisions in other countries and by the EU.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, this time it is Microsoft in Finland, who had already absorbed unemployed people who came from Nokia, but who, by mobilizing much of their production, are again unemployed. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. On the other hand, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (proposal from Finland - EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of significant changes in the structure of world trade. On 29 July 2016 The Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Finland in order to support the re-entry into the labour market of workers made redundant at Microsoft and with eight of its suppliers and downstream producers in Finland. The collapse at Microsoft was caused by the collapse of Nokia using Microsoft's tools, which stopped dominating the mobile phone markets.  In my opinion, it is therefore necessary to create appropriate instruments to help the large number of redundant workers to find their way into the current labour market.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the use of this fund, as it provides crucial support to workers who need to retrain and reskill following the changes in world trade patterns and their impact upon work.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this application for EUR 5 364 000 of EGF assistance for 2161 workers and 8 suppliers and downstream producers made redundant from Microsoft in Finland. Unfortunately, this application is a continuation of the decline of Nokia, which Microsoft acquired, and the knock-on impacts of the decline of the EU’s share of the ICT sector, on which Finland’s economy is particularly dependant. The software sector is particularly susceptible to the effects of globalisation, having become highly international, with industry competing for the same customers, and increasingly location and personnel background are having less significance.  I am pleased to see that the provision of the personalised services package put together by the Finnish authorities will make up 80% of the total use of the application and includes job and career coaching, training, employment and business services, start-up grants and allowances for travel and overnight costs. I am also pleased to see that the income support measures under the application amount to 16.64% of the overall package of personalised measures, which is well below the 35% limit, and that these actions are conditional on the active participation of the targeted beneficiaries in job-search or training activities.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. 'I believe that people should not be the victims of failing European socio-economic policies and short-sighted commercial interests. In this case, it concerns the dismissal of 2 161 employees of Microsoft and related suppliers in Finland. However, I think this is a wipe for the bleeding. Companies, and the Member States themselves, should come up with appropriate support measures themselves, because now we are pumping money from the Member States, whereas a multinational such as Microsoft should have sufficient resources for a decent social plan. Large companies put their employees on the streets after years of loyal service, because they move their production to places where they can find cheaper labour. I strongly reject these degrading practices, and with the resources from the European Fund, we are at least ensuring that workers who have been sent away are not left out in the cold.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The European Global Adjustment Fund (EGF) helps workers develop new skills when they have lost their jobs due to changing global trade patterns. In the case of Finland, the EGF would provide EUR 5.3 million out of EUR 8.9 after the dismissal of 2 161 workers. In the case of Sweden, it would provide EUR 3.9 million out of EUR 6.5 million after the dismissal of 1 556 workers. Though I fully support policies that create growth and jobs, my Group and I do not believe that the EGF is the right tool for putting in place such policies, which is why I have voted against this proposal. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) regulation to Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight related suppliers with reference numbers "EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft" following redundancies of 2,161 people. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. Finland is planning six types of measures for redundant workers affected by the application: coaching and other preparatory measures; employment and business services; vocational training in the labour market; payment subsidies; start-up aid; reimbursement of travel, accommodation and removal expenses. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund’s main role is to provide assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. This report includes a decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in Finland, mainly in the regions Helsinki-Uusimaa, Etelä-Suomi and Länsi-Suomi. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application submitted by Finland -EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft) after 2,161 workers were made redundant at Microsoft Mobile Oy, and eight suppliers and downstream producers of the company, operating in the economic sector more specifically in the field of programming, consulting and related activities. The European Commission confirms that the conditions set out in Article 4(1) (a) of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund regulation are met and that Finland is entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 5 364 000 under that Regulation, amounting to 60 % of the total cost of EUR 8 940 000. I support this Report and believe that union financial assistance in this situation should be dynamic and accessible as quickly and efficiently as possible.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. It seems entirely appropriate to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the event that Microsoft's redundancies are directly linked to the harmful effects of globalisation. We can only regret that other indispensable links are not established with competition from emerging countries, or the weight of the euro on competitiveness.  In the end, the European Union deplores the effects of the causes it cherishes: the use of the Fund contradicts the EU's trade and monetary policy. However, I agree with the positive effect that this assistance will have on workers, innocent victims of this case. I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this budgetary (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 5 364 000 (60% match funding) for 1441 Finnish workers who have been made redundant. This is nothing more than EU dole money. UKIP opposes British taxpayer’s money being used to offset poor economic decisions in other countries and by the EU.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Petri Sarvamaa's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. It, created in 2006, helps people who have lost their jobs. This fund will release an envelope of 5,364,000 euros for the 2,161 sacked employees. This amount will be used to finance training, counselling and support services to promote the return to employment of these laid-off workers. I am pleased that this report has been adopted by a large majority.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for sacked employees of Microsoft in Finland. This fund was created to help those who find themselves impacted by certain negative consequences of globalization, for example by funding new training.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Microsoft's workers have slipped into unemployment through no fault of their own, so that in order to reintegrate them into the labour market, education and training are needed.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns, due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) regulation to Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight related suppliers with reference numbers "EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft" following redundancies of 2,161 people. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. Finland is planning six types of measures for redundant workers affected by the application: coaching and other preparatory measures; employment and business services; vocational training in the labour market; payment subsidies; start-up aid; reimbursement of travel, accommodation and removal expenses. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The main aim of the fund is to help people who have lost their jobs to reintegrate into the labour market. The EU should mobilise the fund to support Finland’s submitted application EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft for a financial contribution from the EGF, following 2161 redundancies in Microsoft Mobile Oy and 8 of its suppliers and downstream producers in Finland. The main reason behind the redundancies in Microsoft is the declining market share of its mobile phones. They link the workforce reductions to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation by recalling that the EU share in the ICT sector employment has decreased, while the share of China and the United States has increased. ICT plays a key role in the Finnish economy, with 6.7% of employees working in the ICT sector in 2014 – the highest percentage amongst all Member States. The EGF is expected to support redundant workers through further education, training or entrepreneurship. Another reason why I supported the mobilisation of the fund is that the Finnish authorities have implemented all the necessary measures to activate and receive the EGF fund.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Sarvamaa's report. The reason for my agreement lies in what this measure represents: Europe's awareness of the need for a further effort to manage the crisis. The measure concerns a mobilisation of EUR 1 365 million for Finland. It covers 1 441 of microsoft's 2 161 redundant workers. This is a concrete measure to help us deal with the emergency, which now takes on ordinary connotations, and to support workers in need of help and retraining.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the Globalization Adjustment Fund to the tune of 5.36 million euros for the reintegration into the labour market of 1,141 workers laid off by Microsoft and its subcontractors in Finland, following competition from Asian countries in the field of communication technologies.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund on demand EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft. Following the dismissal of 1889 workers at Microsoft and 146 of some subcontractors, Finland sought the support of the Globalization Adjustment Fund (EMF) to the tune of EUR 5.36 million to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of 1,141 of these workers.  The global distribution of jobs in the information technology sector has largely come at the expense of the EU, which is competing with emerging countries, particularly in Asia. In 2014, the number of jobs in this sector fell by 2% in Finland (5000). However, there is no reference to the effects of the euro on Competition from Finland. While its neighbour, Sweden, has seen its GDP grow by 15% since 2007, Finland has seen its gdp contract by 1%.  As usual, this WEF aims to timidly mask the consequences of EU trade and monetary policies and to disempower large companies without requiring consideration. However, this aid is useful for the reintegration of workers who do not have to endure the free-trade lubies of the European Commission.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Finland has applied for this fund following numerous redundancies (1886 at Microsoft, 146 at some of its subcontractors). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) can be mobilised if a link is made between these redundancies and the major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalisation. The situation in Finland is that globalisation has largely pushed the EU backwards in the telecommunications sector, particularly to the benefit of Asian countries. This could also be linked to the effects of the euro, as Finland's GDP has fallen by 1% since 2007. At the same time its neighbour Sweden, which is not part of the euro area, saw its growth by 15% over the same period... If this WEF is merely a hide-and-seek of the harmful consequences of the various EU policies, it helps to right wrongs and help employees who have nothing to do with it. So I voted for it.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it gives the green light to the EGF's contribution to the reintegration into the labour market of 1,441 workers, dismissed by Microsoft Mobile Oy and 8 of its suppliers in Finland.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. Finland requested assistance from FEAG following the dismissal of 2,161 Microsoft Mobile OY workers and 8 of its suppliers and product transformers. Although European aid does not guarantee continuity of employment in the sector in an area badly affected by the decline of Nokia and the Finnish electronics industry, they do represent an improvement in the situation of dismissed workers, so I voted in favour.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree that Finland should be sent EUR 5 million in social assistance as a result of the closure of Microsoft's mobile phone factory. I do not agree with the existence of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I consider it meaningless, money is supposed to remain in people's pockets instead of being redistributed by the EU. Special assistance to some workers is unfair.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund helps workers find new jobs and develop new skills when a company goes bankrupt or moves out of Europe.   2,161 workers from Microsoft (Finland) and 1,556 from Ericson (Sweden) were left with no income. The Finnish government accused Microsoft of failing to keep its commitments to make Finland a centre and to keep research jobs. Broken promises or not, companies have suffered as a result of globalization. People prefer phones with newer operating systems.  The fund would pay Finland 5.3 out of €8.9 million and Sweden €3.9 out of €6.5 million. The following services are to be offered to workers: guidance and other preparatory measures, employment services, vocational training, wage subsidies, business start-up grants. This efficient money you use can really help.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers suffering from the major structural consequences of the global financial and economic crisis and to help reintegrate them into the labour market. The Union's share of global employment of the ICT sector has decreased over the past few years, and this sector plays a key role in the Finnish economy.  In March 2016. Finland has applied to mobilise the EGF, in relation to layoffs at Microsoft (Microsoft Mobile Oy), which cites declining market share from mobile sales as the main reason for the layoffs. They link the shrinking workforce to major structural changes in globalisation-influenced world trade, which has reduced the EU's share of ICT employment, while China's share of the US has increased.  In July 2016, The Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF in Finland's favour to support the reintegration of workers made redundant by Microsoft, with a sum of EUR 5 364 000. Since Microsoft Mobile Oy has fulfilled its legal obligations in managing workers, provided them with the prescribed care and assistance in seeking new employment, I supported this proposal.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I support the suggestion to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to assist Finland’s workers in respect of redundancies in the information and communications technology sector.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Major structural changes in world trade patterns caused 2,161 workers to be laid off at Microsoft Mobile Oy and its other 8 suppliers and downstream manufacturers. This is mainly due to the decline of this company in the global mobile phone market, which is expected to lead to further redundancies by restructuring the company. Finland has therefore requested mobilisation from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 1 365 000. This assistance complies with the fund's rules and will affect 1 441 redundancies.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (a request submitted by Finland), because I consider it complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this report. It aims to provide financial assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) amounting to EUR 5.36 million. This envelope would be allocated to former Finnish Microsoft employees, as well as to subcontractors who have been made redundant.  These job losses are linked to declining market share of Windows operating system phones, as well as strong competition from Asian countries, including China. Unfortunately, once again, the EGF is only used to deal with the consequences and not the causes of the massive destruction of jobs in Europe. Therefore, the report does not mention the negative effects of the introduction of the euro on Competition from Finland. As usual, the EGF therefore aims to mask the consequences of the EU's trade and monetary policies and to disempower large companies. However, this assistance is useful for the reintegration of workers. We are therefore, in spite of these considerations, in favour of providing material assistance to these people.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ I have expressed a favourable vote towards the Report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Fund, for this has been created with the aim of providing additional assistance to workers suffering from the impacts of major structural changes in world trade patterns. In general, I consider that the report includes a set of advantages and benefits for the economy and citizens involved.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Finland and to reintegrate workers made redundant at Microsoft and 8 suppliers and producers in Finland into the labour market. Under this application, individualised services will be provided to workers who have been made redundant. The measures to be taken concern vocational guidance, vocational training, salary subsidy as well as overnight allowances and removal costs in the event that the dismissed parties set up other undertakings in other areas. At this point it should be stressed that the above measures, according to the Commission, are active measures of the labour market.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Adaptation to globalisation poses major problems for us. That is why there is, among other things, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This fund supports redundant workers. This particular case concerns the mobilisation of this fund for the benefit of workers in Finland. These were dismissed by Microsoft and some subcontractors. I see the support of these workers as my obligation.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support Parliament's report, which proposes to allocate EGF funds to Finland in order to support the return of workers made redundant from Microsoft to the labour market.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Another case of the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (WEF) in the IT and telephony sector in the Scandinavian countries, once again symbolic of the evils of the European Union's industrial and trade policy. It concerns Microsoft in Finland, which lays off nearly 2,000 employees, with cascading effects on subcontractors and suppliers. For some of these workers, they had just been fired from Nokia and had already benefited from this European aid.  However, the report does not question the fact that their new jobs were therefore not secure in the long term, which is the aim promoted through the WEF. Worse, it indicates that as competition is global, "the location or cultural context of the staff is of limited importance"! The WEF is therefore fulfilling its role as a 'relocation aid'.  However, I abstain so as not to deprive Finnish workers of this aid.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 1889 workers at Microsoft and 146 of some subcontractors, Finland sought the support of the Globalization Adjustment Fund (EMF) to the tune of EUR 5.36 million to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of 1,141 of these workers. The EGF can indeed be mobilised if a link between layoffs and major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization is established.  In this case, however, the global distribution of jobs in the information technology sector has largely come at the expense of the EU, which is competing with emerging countries, particularly in Asia.  As usual, this WEF aims to timidly mask the consequences of EU trade and monetary policies and to disempower large companies without requiring consideration.  However, this aid is useful for the reintegration of workers who do not have to suffer the consequences of unfortunate choices made by the European Commission and irresponsible leaders. I therefore voted in favour of this issue.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights.  The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Finland to give this aid to finland which submitted the EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft application for a financial contribution from the EGF, under the intervention criteria laid down in Article 4(1)(a) of the EGF Regulation, following 2161 redundancies at Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight its suppliers and producers downstream in Finland operating in the economic activity sector classified in DIVISION 62 of NACE Revision 2 (Consultancy and related computer programming activities).  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the tools at the European Union’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted upon by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions for mobilising the EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 1 441 people.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The software industry is severely affected by the opening up to the global economy. Characterized by strong internationalization, competition in this sector is global. According to Finland, layoffs are therefore to be sought in the decline in the market share of its phones. The European Union's share of ICT employment has declined to China and the United States.  It was in this context that, on 11 March 2016, Finland submitted a request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for redundancies of 2,161 people at Microsoft and eight downstream suppliers and producers in Finland. I support the European Union's financial assistance to laid-off workers, who are unemployed at Microsoft and eight of its suppliers and downstream producers in Finland. This support will help them reintegrate into the labour market. The WEF's financial contribution of EUR 5,364,000 will help workers reintegrate into the labour market. Beyond that, I am determined to defend the implementation of a strategy for an ambitious, forward-looking European re-industrialisation policy.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which proposes to give Finland EUR 5 364 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help 1 441 former workers at Microsoft and eight of its suppliers and downstream producers to find new jobs. The main reason for the job losses at Microsoft is the declining market share of its phones (Lumia) that use the Microsoft Windows operating system. Most of the Microsoft redundancies were in the Helsinki-Uusimaa, Etelä-Suomi and Länsi-Suomi regions. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity to disaster-stricken regions within Europe.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 11 March 2016, Finland submitted an application to the Commission for the use of the Fund in order to help workers made redecurred into the labour market from Microsoft in Finland and eight related suppliers and down-processing companies. The measures affect 1,441 of the 2,161 workers made redundant. The dismissed workers are requested to provide six types of personalised services, such as (i) consultancy and other preparatory measures, (ii) employment and business services, (iii) vocational training in the labour market, (iv) payment allowances, (v) start-up aid and (vi) reimbursement of travel, accommodation and removal expenses. The Commission found that the conditions for the financial contribution from the Fund were fulfilled for the application and that the measures envisaged constituted active labour market measures included in the eligible activities and therefore submitted a proposal for a decision to Parliament and the Council on the use of eur 5 364 000 from the Fund for Finland in the form of commitment and payment appropriations. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 1,889 workers at Microsoft and 146 others at some subcontractors, Finland sought the support of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 5.36 million to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of 1,141 of these workers. As usual, this fund aims to timidly mask the consequences of the Union's trade and monetary policies and to disempower large companies without requiring consideration. However, it is useful for the reintegration of workers who do not have to endure the free-trade lubies of the European Commission, so it is necessary to vote in favour of this aid.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The EGF was created with the purpose of giving complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. In the present case, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Finland to support the reintegration into the labour market of redundant workers at Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight downstream suppliers and producers in Finland operating in the economic sector classified in DIVISION 62 of NACE Review 2 (Consultancy and related computer programming activities). I stress the importance of improving the employability of all workers made redundant through tailored training and the recognition of qualifications and skills acquired throughout their professional career, and it is vital that the proposed training is adapted not only to the needs of redundant workers but also to the real environment of enterprises. I believe that measures aimed at the reintegration of workers should be adopted.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This vote relates to the mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to the tune of 5.36 million to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of 1,141 workers laid off in Finland by Microsoft and 146 among some subcontractors, due in particular to the increasing competition from emerging and especially Asian countries in the field of telephony and new information and communication technologies. However, even if there is no reference to the effects of the euro on Competition in Finland, this aid is useful for the reintegration of workers who do not have to endure the free-trade lubies of the European Commission. So I voted for it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund requested by Finland following redundancies at Microsoft and 8 downstream suppliers and producers between September 2015 and January 2016.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund intervenes to support sacked employees due to major changes in the structure of world trade resulting from globalisation, due to the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis, or due to a new global financial and economic crisis. In this case, the amount of the EGF mobilized amounts to 5,364,000 euros for 2161 eligible beneficiaries.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Mobilisation Adjustment Fund, requested by Finland, for Microsoft. When jobs are at risk, when economic changes require the retraining or training assistance of employees of companies in difficulty, I welcome the financial assistance that the European Union can provide. The fight against unemployment is the priority of the European Union; unfortunately, the current labour market situation and the consequences of the 2008 economic crisis continue to affect employment in Europe. All the tools we have must be used to safeguard jobs in our small and large businesses.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 To make the most of the great opportunities offered by globalization, you must first know how to mitigate the effects. That is why we welcome the report on the activities, impact and added value of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund between 2007 and 2014. The Fund has shown itself to be an important instrument of solidarity for workers who are victims of mass redundancies caused by structural changes in world trade, through assistance, retraining and reintegration activities, as well as the promotion of business activity. In addition, the report puts in black and white the need to pay attention to the impacts of trade policies and agreements on the European labour market, as well as to stress the importance of social dialogue and to urge the Commission to ensure that job losses only take place as a last resort. The response to globalisation cannot and must not be seen as an attitude of mistrust and closure, but must be seen as a great opportunity that needs active adaptation in order to reap the benefits, while maintaining as strong points of reference the achievements of the European social model and the protection of workers.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 On 29 July 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilising the EGF in favour of Finland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Microsoft and eight downstream suppliers and producers in Finland, operating in NACE Revision 2 Division 62. The Finnish authorities claim that the redundancies at Microsoft are mainly due to the decline in the market share of its mobile phones due to the increase in the market share of China and the United States. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. I therefore voted in favour of the measure.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Support from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has also found a place in Finland where it is really needed. I remember nokia dominating the entire mobile market in the early 2000s, and then over the years iOS and Android became more popular, which slowly led to Nokia's decline. The downsizing of a company of this size has a serious impact on the entire labour market, resulting in the loss of many jobs. Finding a new job is not easy, it requires a lot of energy, patience and help. The aid focuses on areas such as starting new businesses and reimbursement of travel or removal expenses.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ On 29 July 2016, Finland’s proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF was adopted by the Commission in order to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant at Microsoft. I voted for this report that will mobilise a total amount of EUR 1 365 000 from the EGF for Finland that will help 1 441 workers made redundant.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – In recent years, numerous European and foreign companies have closed their offices and subsidiaries in EU Member States as a result of the short-sighted neoliberal economic policy at European level. Especially in the information and communication technologies sector, this leads to the closure of many skilled jobs and deepens the EU's uncompetitiveness globally as regards the creation of innovative technological products and services. Taking into account the difficult situation faced by European citizens fired by companies that are gradually shutting down their activities in Europe in the face of aggressive globalisation and a severe financial and economic crisis, as is the case with Finns working in Microsoft, I believe that mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is one of the initiatives that the European Parliament must necessarily support. This fund will provide microsoft workers until recently with access to necessary advice, guidance and financial means to help them discover and develop their skills and mobility in a way that they will quickly return to work and overcome the economic difficulties they now have to deal with.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Finland in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Microsoft. The report notes that the main reason for the redundancies at Microsoft is the declining market share of its Microsoft Windows operating system phones from 50% in 2009 to 0.6% in the second quarter of 2016.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. With the Globalisation Fund, the European Union has a budgetary instrument that provides financial support to workers affected by the far-reaching global structural changes in world trade patterns. This fund starts exactly where society needs it most, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Microsoft was forced to lay off people as a result of the decline in the market share of phones using the Microsoft Windows operating system. The measure concerns 1441 redundancies and is intended to help them re-enter the labour market.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in the shape of world trade.  The report gives the green light to the mobilisation of the EGF in Finland and concerns 2,161 redundancies in the Microsoft business active in the financial sector. EGF funding of EUR 5,364,000 will contribute to the cost of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, assistance for 1,441 beneficiaries following redundancies, with a view to helping to integrate affected people into the labour market. The redundancies were caused by major structural changes in the shape of world trade due to globalisation. For all these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 5 364 000 (60% match funding) for 1441 Finnish workers who have been made redundant. This is nothing more than EU dole money. UKIP opposes British taxpayer’s money being used to offset poor economic decisions in other countries and by the EU.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt obliged to vote in favour of this proposal. The effects that globalisation may have, in certain circumstances, may have a negative effect and it is therefore necessary for the institutions to intervene in solidarity. The Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade or the global economic and financial crisis, and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. The Union is therefore committed to alleviating what can be such effects through immediate and effective financial support. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I support the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund as required by EGF/2016/001 F1/Microsoft. The IT industry is one of the fastest growing industries of today, and consequently the need for a new, highly educated workforce is growing. Competition in the IT industry is relentless, whether it is the European Union market, but also outside it. Unfortunately, in this situation there is a decrease in the volume of operations of individual IT companies or a shutdown of individual sectors when they lose certain market shares. In this situation, many workers lose their jobs, especially when it comes to large companies. An additional problem these workers face is the lack of competence to be competitive in the labour market.  This is why I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund needs to help IT workers gain the necessary qualifications and find a new job more easily. By strengthening the competences of EU national workers, we are investing directly in the competitiveness of the entire IT sector of the European Union, which is struggling to cope with growing competition in the world, especially in Asian countries.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 1889 workers at Microsoft and 146 of some subcontractors, Finland sought the support of the Globalization Adjustment Fund (EMF) to the tune of EUR 5.36 million to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of 1,141 of these workers. Of course, there is no reference to the effects of the euro on Competition from Finland. When its neighbour, Sweden, saw its GDP grow by 15% since 2007, Finland saw its gdp contract by 1%. As usual, this WEF aims to timidly mask the consequences of EU trade and monetary policies and to disempower large companies without requiring consideration. However, this aid is useful for the reintegration of workers who do not have to endure the free-trade lubies of the European Commission. In support of the workers, I therefore vote for.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Finland has applied to mobilise the EGF in connection with redundancies at Microsoft (Microsoft Mobile Oy) (this situation is the result of the downfall of Noquia, which sold its mobile phone business to Microsoft). The Commission has adopted a proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF for Finland's benefit in order to support the reinsugment into the labour market of workers made redundant at Microsoft and in eight of its suppliers and downstream producers in Finland. It refers to 1,441 workers who have been made redundant. The EGF should therefore be mobilised to provide a financial contribution of EUR 5 364 000 for the application submitted by Finland. This is the 7th EGF mobilisation in 2016. €22,000,000 has been mobilised so far, meaning €143,500,000 remains for this year. (The EGF must not exceed the maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million). The Purpose of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to support redundant and self-employed workers who have ceased their activity due to major structural changes in the flows of globalisation, due to the continuation of the global financial and economic crisis or the new global and economic crisis, and to help these workers re-enter the labour market. It is for these reasons that I also support this mobilization.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. The application refers to a total of 2 161 workers made redundant at Microsoft and eight downstream suppliers and producers (1 889 workers) between September 2015 and January 2016, with 3 Finnish regions affected (Helsinki-Uusimaa, Southern Finland, Western Finland). Initially, Microsoft reinstated some Nokia workers who received support from the Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGF). Nokia moved production lines to the Far East, then closed some of the most specialized production areas, eventually selling to Microsoft in 2013 the production of mobile phones, for now until that is being shut down. Another example of relocation, another procession of destruction and unemployment, a few thousand more victims of ruling neoliberalism. The resolution formulates the usual recommendations. But it makes no reference to the fact that workers from Nokia's redundancies have already received 'aid' from the EGF, and there has therefore been a failure in the assumption of that fund as regards at least the provision of safe and long-term contracts to workers, which relativises the weight of those recommendations. If it is necessary to support the laid-off workers, it is still deplorable how this instrument has been used.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Finland, as more than 2,000 employees have been laid off in this country this year, not only from Microsoft, but also from its chain of suppliers and manufacturers. This mass layoff was due to Microsoft's record-breaking 50 percent decline in the market for phones that use the Microsoft Windows operating system. For Finland, as a country in whose economy information and communication technologies play a key role, this development, the elements of which we find to a lesser extent in other Member States, is very painful. In particular, I voted in favour of the granting of EUR 5,346 million, which should facilitate further active participation in the labour market for redundant workers. In cooperation with the Finnish authorities, this includes, for example, staff coaching, training, wage subsidy, grants for start-ups, allowances for travel, accommodation and moving expenses. I also supported the establishment of cooperation between Microsoft and EURES through the labour mobility programme, which should give workers a positive incentive to exercise their right to free movement. I firmly believe that the Finnish economy, which has long been severely affected by changes in the structure of world trade caused by globalisation, can respond as appropriately as possible to these difficult challenges with European help.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Finland is applying for EGF support following the dismissal of 2,161 employees at Microsoft and eight of its suppliers and downstream manufacturers. The main reason for microsoft's redundancies is its declining market share of phones using the Microsoft Windows operating system. The EGF co-financed measures will help 1441 workers by providing them with vocational coaching and individual advice, employment and entrepreneurship services, a range of vocational training, services for new entrepreneurs and grants to start-ups, incentives to hire staff, training allowances and removal allowances. The total estimated cost of the package will be EUR 8.9 million, of which the EGF will provide EUR 5.3 million. I support measures to introduce policies that are conducive to growth and employment. I hereby supported the report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, I am not convinced in the long term that we should constantly use the globalisation fund only for the old Member States. Today we have applications from Sweden and Finland and from Ericsson and Microsoft, so i guess everyone will get their picture.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), established in 2006, helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of structural changes in international trade, such as relocations or business closures. In this case, I voted in favour of granting aid requested by Finland to support the 2,161 former employees (licensed between September 2015 and January 2016) of companies operating in the mobile telephony sector.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 As a mechanism set up to support workers affected by the effects of structural changes in world trade patterns, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is geared towards cases such as the present. The application to the Fund to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Microsoft was submitted to the Commission on 11 March 2016. At the root of the labour cuts made is apparently the decrease in the market share of Microsoft's mobile phones, as well as the major structural changes in global trade patterns arising from globalization, more specifically increased competition from China and the United States. The dismissal of 1 441 employees of the company - a serious social consequence of the above-mentioned crisis - therefore justifies the mobilisation of the EGF. In order to support the 1 441 European citizens in this precarious situation and to benefit from such relevant measures as access to consultancy services and training aimed at re-entering the labour market, I am voting in favour of approving the report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 5 364 000 (60% match funding) for 1441 Finnish workers who have been made redundant. This is nothing more than EU dole money. UKIP opposes British taxpayer’s money being used to offset poor economic decisions in other countries and by the EU.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I voted in favour, as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns, and the Finnish authorities say that microsoft's labour cuts are reducing the market share of their mobile phones.  Understanding the relationship between redundancies and major structural changes in world trade patterns arising from globalisation, recalling that the Union's share of ICT employment has declined, while the share corresponding to China and the United States has increased. It is essential to reverse this downward trend, which affects the entire Finnish electronics industry, with the loss of 2,300 jobs in Finland expected, and which is related to the decline of Nokia, which sold its mobile phone business to Microsoft.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of EUR 5 364 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the reintegration into the labour market of 1 441 workers, dismissed by Microsoft Mobile Oy and 8 of its suppliers in Finland. These funds shall be designed to finance measures for laid-off workers, including advisory measures, employment and business services, training, wage subsidies or business-building subsidies.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help the 1889 workers who lost their jobs at Microsoft in Finland and the 146 workers at 8 suppliers and downstream producers. Finland, like the European Union as a whole, has faced increased competition in the information and communication technology market in recent years. It is therefore important to help all those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of globalization.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. A significant decline in nokia's phone market share has forced Microsoft to lay off 2,300 employees in Finland. Of these, 89% of workers range between 30 and 54. The decline in the information and communication technology sector leads to difficult conditions for these people to take up employment. Under these conditions, Microsoft has submitted an application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which aims to provide additional assistance to workers affected by major structural changes in world trade patterns.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this European Parliament resolution on the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EFAG) in favour of Finland, with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are laid off by Microsoft and eight suppliers and producers operating in the consultancy and programming sector. It is intended to mobilise a total value of €1.365 000 from the EEAG to support the reintegration into work of 1,441 of the 2 161 workers made redundant as a result of the decrease in the market share of Microsoft mobile phones and the european Union's own share of employment in the Information and Communication Technology sector. Since the Commission has concluded that the necessary conditions for the allocation of the EFAG are met and this financial support is channelled into vocational monitoring measures, training, grants for recruitment and business creation, there are no reasons for approving this mobilisation and I therefore voted in a favourable direction.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 For the seventh time in 2016, we are voting on a request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This is the turn of Finland, which has asked Europe for help, amounting to EUR 1 365 000, in order to help 2161 workers made redundant. I voted in favour of this report because it also demonstrates the importance and greatness of the true European Union.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, this time it is Microsoft in Finland, who had already absorbed unemployed people who came from Nokia, but who, by mobilizing much of their production, are again unemployed. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. On the other hand, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: in writing. – In March this year, Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Fund, as 2035 workers, both from Microsoft and from downstream producers, were made redundant and lost their jobs. Indeed, one of the biggest challenges the EU and its Member States face is managing the downsides of globalisation. Every one of us is affected, and we really need to alleviate the situation of people facing the negative effects of globalisation. However, I firmly believe that protectionist measures such as the EGF would exacerbate the difficulties we are facing rather than resolving them. What we need in Europe today are measures that will create jobs, businesses and start-ups – an active strategy to promote competitiveness, innovation, research, development and new technologies throughout the EU.  I usually vote against all applications to the European Globalisation Fund whatsoever. Nevertheless, in current times of a severe economic crisis and rising populism, I chose not to vote against and abstained from voting.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. Finland requested assistance from FEAG following the dismissal of 2,161 Microsoft Mobile OY workers and 8 of its suppliers and product transformers. Although European aid does not guarantee continuity of employment in the sector in an area badly affected by the decline of Nokia and the Finnish electronics industry, they do represent an improvement in the situation of dismissed workers, so I voted in favour.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because we do not receive this fund from the EU.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following an application from Finland. This was set up in order to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support measures aimed at setting policies that promote economic growth and the creation of new jobs. However, I do not consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a proper and effective instrument for developing these policies. I therefore voted against this resolution in line with the ECR's position.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important tool for addressing the effects of structural changes in world trade patterns. It has long proven to be a mechanism for supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to the collapse of their employer and are also located in a less developed region where employment opportunities are scarce. Microsoft employees have also found themselves in this situation in several locations in Finland, which is why I have agreed to release funds from the Globalisation Fund. According to the information provided by the Finnish authorities that made the request, the main reason for the redundancies at Microsoft is the company's declining share of the mobile phone market. The request also states that the entire electronics industry in Finland is under pressure due to the decline of Nokia, which sold its mobile phone division to Microsoft. The Commission received a request for assistance in favour of Finland in July this year, with the intention of supporting the re-entry of workers made redundant from Microsoft and eight of its suppliers and downstream producers. Finland is expected to be paid almost EUR 1.4 million to be used for retraining 1 441 out of a total of 2 161 redundancies. These former Microsoft employees will receive personalized services such as coaching, business support, wage subsidies, or travel cost contributions.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund has an annual budget of €150 million and provides assistance in cases where more than 500 workers are made redundant in one company in one sector and one region as a result of major structural changes in world trade. The assistance is reflected in job search, career counselling, education, retraining, mobility and the like. On 29 July 2016, the European Commission adopted a proposal to mobilise the fund in favour of Finland to support the reintegration of the labour market in connection with workers made redundant in Finland by Microsoft and eight suppliers and related producers. The Finnish Government stated that the main reason for these redundancies was Microsoft's declining share of the mobile device market. The decline in the number of workers is linked to major shifts in global trade, where the number of employees in the EU's IT sector is decreasing and increasing in the US and China. Aid to Finnish workers will take the form of six different services – from education to initial capital for start-ups. As the Fund is working well and in this case it is a situation for which it was set up, I supported the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important tool for maintaining employment in the regions. Finland is retraining 2,161 workers made redundant from Microsoft and its supply firms. It is a pity that Slovakia did not apply for assistance from this fund in similar cases.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (request by Finland – EGF/001 FI/Microsoft). We are constantly deciding on subsidies from this fund. The EGF has a maximum annual budget of €150 million for the period 2014-2020. I fundamentally reject this fund as a waste of taxpayers' money. The fund subsidises support measures when a company has not been able to compete with its business model. The Fund also means overstepping the EU's competences. It is absurd to adopt such bailouts at EU level rather than at national level in the event of the inability of individual companies or sectors to compete. This is at least a violation of the principle of subsidiarity and also a violation of economic policy lessons. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund must be closed and wound up immediately.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was created to provide additional assistance to workers directly affected by major structural changes. On 11 March 2016, Finland applied to EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft for a financial contribution following redundancies at Microsoft and its eight suppliers and downstream manufacturers in Finland. Following the evaluation of the application, the Commission concluded, in accordance with all the applicable provisions of the Regulation, that the conditions for granting a financial contribution from the EGF had been met. Finland claims that fewer and fewer people have been recruited in the ICT sector in the EU over the past few years, while in other economies the situation has been reversed. The software industry is highly international and competition is taking place globally.  I support the proposal for this resolution, as I believe that support for workers who have become redundant could play an important role in revitalising the industry if their further education and training is sufficiently supported, and employment prospects.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of european globalisation adjustment funds for the role made by Finland –Microsoft. Microsoft Mobile Oy and eight suppliers and downstream producers in Finland were forced to lay off 2161 workers as a result of the negative effects of globalisation, which are seen through the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows or the consequences of the global financial and economic crisis. Since the application was complete and so Microsoft Mobile Oy meets all the conditions, I supported the report.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in the shape of world trade. On 29 July 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilising the EGF in favour of Finland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Microsoft. The personalised services to be provided under this application to dismissed workers are divided into the following categories: vocational guidance measures and other framework measures, employment and business services, vocational training, salary subsidy, grant for setting up businesses and travel allowances, overnight stays and removal costs.  With this in mind, we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be allocated, in essence, to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies because this creates skilled unemployed people and does not address the present situation.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Nokia's problems, once a leader in the mobile phone industry, began with the expansion of Apple and Samsung smartphones. Both companies quickly established their dominance on the market, leaving the Finnish company far behind. Microsoft's acquisition of the Finnish company's mobile business and patents in 2013 was supposed to be a rescue for it. Unfortunately, the redmond giant in the smartphone market itself did not do well. The market share of phones using the Microsoft Windows operating system fell from more than 50 % in 2009 to 0.6 % in the second quarter of 2016. Microsoft announced plans to cut its overall workforce by up to 18,000 in 2015, including 1,100 in Finland, while in 2015 it announced plans to restructure its phone manufacturing division, expecting 2,300 jobs to be lost in Finland. The Government in Helsinki plans to implement six types of measures for the redundant workers covered by the proposal: coaching and other preparatory measures, employment and entrepreneurship services, vocational training, wage subsidies, start-up grants, travel allowances, accommodation and removal. They are primarily intended to adapt workers to the future labour market and develop the skills they need. That is why I have decided to support this proposal.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because the approval of the Microsoft application is very important for Finland. The structural change caused by globalisation for the Finnish IT sector has been exceptionally drastic, reflected in mass redundancies and unemployment. EU support is welcome.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ This report is about approving the mobilisation of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund in Finland, mainly in the regions Helsinki-Uusimaa, Etelä-Suomi and Länsi-Suomi. The European Globalization Adjustment Fund is a legislative and budgetary instrument to provide additional support to workers who are suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns or of the global financial and economic crisis and to assist their reintegration into the labour market. The application relates to 2161 redundancies in Microsoft in Finland, operating in the economic sector during the period from 11 September 2015 to 11 January 2016. The EGAF funding of EUR 5 364 000 will contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for 1441 targeted beneficiaries following redundancies, with the aim of providing assistance for integrating the affected persons into the labour market. The redundancies were caused by major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. I support this report as I believe that the 2161 redundancies of Microsoft are eligible to receive aid.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. According to the Finnish authorities, the main reason for the layoffs at Microsoft is to look for a decline in the market share of its phones. To establish the link between downsizing and major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization, they point out that the European Union's share of ICT employment has declined, while that of China and the United States has increased.  While, during the first decade of the 2000s, Nokia dominated the markets of mobile telephony, Android and iOS, operating systems used by various Asian manufacturers, have grown in recent years to the point of becoming the leaders.  The European Parliament has heard them.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Finland, as of recently, has had a significant decline in its Microsoft market share as a result of the shifting trend in the production of mobile phones. Particularly, this reduction is the result of the shift from EU production in the ICT sector to the Asian-based manufacturing that has come to dominate the market. This trend has affected the entire Finnish electronic industry, amounting to 2 300 job losses in the mobile phone sector alone. I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Finland, entitling the struggling Finnish economy to a financial contribution of around EUR 5 million, which will be allocated to payroll and unemployment insurance, labour training, subsidies, and innovation grants in the aim of better managing sectorial adjustment.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This report proposes to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to support laid-off workers at Microsoft and its eight suppliers and downstream producers in Finland.  To directly assist redundant workers, Finland has prepared six measures, such as guidance measures, employment services and business services, vocational training, salary subsidies, corporate start-up grants and travel allowances, accommodation and removal costs. I fully support measures that create jobs and grow. However, I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is not an effective tool to bring workers back to the labour market and will not help the Finnish economy. So I voted no.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: I supported the EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft application. On 29 July 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Finland in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Microsoft and eight post-production stage suppliers and producers in Finland classified in NACE Revision 2 Division 62 (Computer programming, consultancy and other related activities). Redundancies are linked to major structural changes in global trade flows as a result of globalisation, which has led to a declining share of EU jobs in the ICT sector and an increase in china and the US share.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, this time it is Microsoft in Finland, who had already absorbed unemployed people who came from Nokia, but who, by mobilizing much of their production, are again unemployed. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action.
