On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. On the other hand, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 1889 workers at Microsoft and 146 of some subcontractors, Finland sought the support of the Globalization Adjustment Fund (EMF) to the tune of EUR 5.36 million to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of 1,141 of these workers.  The EGF can indeed be mobilised if a link between layoffs and major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization is established. In this case, however, the global distribution of jobs in the information technology sector has largely come at the expense of the EU, which is competing with emerging countries, particularly in Asia.  In 2014, the number of jobs in this sector fell by 2% in Finland (5000). Similarly, these job losses are linked to the decline in market share of phones operating with Microsoft's operating system.  The WEF aims to mask the consequences of EU trade and monetary policies and to disempower large companies without requiring consideration. However, this aid is useful for the reintegration of workers who do not have to endure the free-trade lubies of the European Commission.  So I'm voting for it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument to offset the negative effects of mass redundancies, which are the repercussions of global changes in the labour market and trade. Finland is seeking funding from the fund to support more than two thousand redundant Microsoft employees. The main reason for the mass layoffs in the company is the company's declining share of the global market. The measures co-financed by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help a large group of more than 1 400 m.in through vocational advice and training. They will also create an incentive for entrepreneurs to hire workers.  Policies that promote growth and employment deserve support. In general, however, I am sceptical about whether the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund mechanism is indeed a tool that can effectively help redundant workers to integrate into the labour market. I believe that each situation requires an individual and careful assessment. The mobilisation of funds from the Fund on this particular issue is, in my opinion, justified, which is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the proposal gives the green light for the application of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in several regions of Finland. Microsoft would provide €5,364,000 to deal with a wave of layoffs affecting 2,161 people and integrate the unemployed into the labour market. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, this time it is Microsoft in Finland, who had already absorbed unemployed people who came from Nokia, but who, by mobilizing much of their production, are again unemployed. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. On the other hand, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Finland's (Microsoft) application and Sweden's (Ericsson) application because I agree with the use of the funds for both cases.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that the Finnish authorities started providing personalised services to affected workers on 11 September 2015, well before the application for egf support was submitted for the proposed harmonised service package, as these actions are eligible for the EGF financial contribution.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application from Finland – EGF/2016/001 FI/Microsoft). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) has been created in order to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. On 29 July 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Finland to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Microsoft and eight of its suppliers and downstream producers in Finland, operating in the NACE Rev. 2 division 62 (computer programming, consultancy and related activities). I voted in favour because I believe that the design of the coordinated package is compatible with the shift towards a resource-efficient and sustainable economy.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was introduced in 2007 as a flexible instrument wherein the Union budget supports, under specific conditions, those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in the patterns of world trade, caused by globalisation or the globalized economic and financial crisis. Through this report, the European Parliament supports the Commission's proposal to grant Finland EUR 5.3 million from the EGF to help 1 441 former Microsoft employees and eight of its suppliers find new jobs. Under the firm conviction that the Union's commitment to unemployment citizens must materialise in concrete actions, I voted in favour of this decision.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. Finland requested assistance from FEAG following the dismissal of 2,161 Microsoft Mobile OY workers and 8 of its suppliers and product transformers. Although European aid does not guarantee continuity of employment in the sector in an area badly affected by the decline of Nokia and the Finnish electronics industry, they do represent an improvement in the situation of dismissed workers, so I voted in favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering from the effects of major structural changes due to globalisation. On 29 July 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal to make EGF funds available to Finland to support the return to the labour market of workers forcibly made redundant by Microsoft and eight suppliers and downstream producers in Finland. The application amounted to EUR 1 365 000 from the EGF for Finland. The application covers 1 441 of 2 161 employees who have been made redundant. I agreed with this report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. When Microsoft acquired Nokia in 2013, it pledged to make Finland a hub of operations in Europe. But between September 2015 and January 2016, 1,889 Finnish employees were laid off by the company. In all, including suppliers, no less than 2,161 people lost their jobs. The multinational is not bothered: Satya Nadella, the CEO of Microsoft, received a salary of $17.7 million for its last fiscal year and Microsoft posted a sharp increase in net profit (up 38%) $17 billion in 2016. Its founder and second largest shareholder, Bill Gates, founder was ranked first in Forbes' ranking of the world's richest men again this year, with $75 billion in personal wealth.  In these circumstances, it is unacceptable that public funds should be sought to finance the return-to-employment assistance of the 2,161 Finnish employees left behind! Microsoft is fully able to bear the consequences of its actions and pay for the workers the company wanted to sacrifice. I am voting against this text.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The application refers to a total of 2 161 workers made redundant at Microsoft and 8 downstream suppliers and producers (1,889 microsoft-only workers) between September 2015 and January 2016, with 3 Finnish regions affected (Helsinki-Uusimaa, Southern Finland, Western Finland). Initially, Microsoft reinstated some Nokia workers who received an EGF. Nokia moved production lines to the Far East, then closed some of the more specialized production areas, eventually selling to Microsoft in 2013 the production of mobile phones for now until it was shut down. That is, following the acquisition, Microsoft Mobile was created in April 2014 and approximately 25,000 Nokia employees were assigned to Microsoft, including 4,700 people based in Finland. Just a few months later, Microsoft announced its plans to close 18,000 jobs, with 1,100 Finnish workers eventually having reached the current number of workers made redundant. This situation is intolerable and deserves our full repudiation. Our favourable vote stems from respect and understanding of the difficult situation of the workers affected. Our fight is against this Bedouin capitalism, demanding firm measures against these practices.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to support workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. Specifically, this proposal concerns the mobilisation of this fund for the benefit of workers in Finland who have been made redundant by Microsoft and its suppliers. I think these measures are useful and I have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an expression of the EU’s core value of social solidarity. Far from being just a neo-liberal club, the EU protects communities from the harsher impacts of globalisation, and provides social support for communities affected by job losses. The UK Government could have made much more use of this fund regarding job losses in the steel industry, for example.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been set up to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns. The application relates to 2,035 workers fired by Microsoft. The main company operates in the economic sector of 'Programming, consulting and other IT-related activities'.  The report notes that the main reason for layoffs at Microsoft is the down market share of their phones that use the Microsoft Windows operating system.  It is emphasized that the software industry is very international and that competition in the sector is global, i.e. all market players can compete for the same customers and the location and cultural background of the staff have limited meaning. The report states that this request is the continuation of a number of cases that revolve around Nokia's decline in Finland. My vote is in favour of this report, as we must protect the areas most affected by re-industrialisation in order to go forward and be able to adapt to the new economic needs.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The mobilization request we approved today was submitted by Finland and concerns 2 161 workers made redundant by Microsoft (Microsoft Mobile Oy) and eight suppliers and manufacturers downstream. The main enterprise operates in the defined field of "programming, IT consulting and related activities". Microsoft's redundancies are mainly concentrated in the Helsinki-Uusimaa, Etelä-Suomi and Länsi-Suomi regions. The current application follows a number of previous applications from Finland, all caused by Nokia's decline in its home country. For example, in 2014 the number of employees of technology companies in Finland fell by 2 % compared to the previous year and, also in 2014, this sector employed 285 000 people in Finland compared with 326 000 in 2008. Over the same period, the share of ICT staff in developed countries has increased for China and the US at the same time, while it has fallen for Europe. The total financial contribution requested from the EGF amounts to EUR 5 364 000, or 60 % of total costs. I am generally in favour of mobilising this fund, although I am aware that this is probably not the best way to help redundant workers.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: Written. \u2012 The PVV voted against the mobilisation of these funds because a global player like Microsoft does not suffer the adverse effects of globalisation, but is itself a driving force behind globalisation.  In addition, there is no longer a 'global crisis', a condition for granting funding.  The fund will therefore only facilitate, with the allocation of € 5,364 million., an internationally operating company such as Microsoft in the elimination of employment in a Member State of the European Union.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support Finland's request to provide EUR 5.3 million from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Microsoft will have to make mass redundancies in Finland due to changes in world trade, and the funds from this fund should be intended to help these employees re-employ or start a business. In this case in particular, funds from the Fund should have been used to support career guidance, individual guidance, training or start-up service. However, as in all previous cases of requests to mobilise this fund, I believe that there are insufficient data to demonstrate its effectiveness. All available data show that the rate of re-employment of redundant workers varies greatly from country to country and, of course, their successful re-employment depends on their education, skills and the possibilities of the region, rather than the training provided with the help of this fund. That is why I believe that the existence of the fund as such would need to be assessed much more thoroughly than it has been up to now, and only on the basis of such an assessment to decide whether these funds cannot be used in a better and more efficient way, which would not only help the employees made redundant, but at the same time not only apply to large companies, but would also help the employees of small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Decision on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide financial assistance in the form of further education, training and entrepreneurship plans for redundant Microsoft workers in Finland.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. \u2012 The EU Globalisation Fund is intended to provide grants to people who have become unemployed following the closure of European companies. The Christian Democrats are opposed to this fund for two reasons. Firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed must be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at EU level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. I therefore vote consistently against the payments from the Fund. The alliance also repeatedly pointed to the fund's existence during its reign. For ericsson employees who are losing their jobs, this is a personal tragedy, but it is Sweden that should take responsibility for supporting them in the transition phase to a new job – not the EU.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Sweden's application relates to redundancies at Ericsson. At the origin of these redundancies is the closure of production lines in various Ericsson plants and also the closure of an entire plant in Katrineholm. The reasons that led to the closure of factories and production lines for Ericsson can be identified in stagnant growth and fierce competition with Asian products. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this budgetary (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 3 957 918 (60% match funding) for 918 Swedish workers who have been made redundant. This is nothing more than EU dole money. UKIP opposes British taxpayers’ money being used to offset poor economic decisions in other countries and by the EU.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. Sweden requested assistance from the EGF following the dismissal of 1,556 Ericsson workers. Although European aid does not guarantee continuity of employment in a sector very exposed to international competition, they do mean an improvement in the situation of dismissed workers, so I voted in favour.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. –A total of 1 556 workers made redundant, all working for Ericsson in Sweden and due to the partial or entire closure of wireless telecom hardware production lines at various Ericsson sites. As a matter of interest, Ericsson has doubled its recruitment worldwide, yet it has been gradually cutting staff in Sweden (from 21 178 in 2005 to 17 858 in 2014).  The Swedish company sold its entire mobile phone development and production line to competitor Sony in February 2012, which has been a partial reason for job losses. Since this application, rumour has it that Ericsson will announce further lay-off plans, probably about 3 000 in Europe (approximately 17 000 left in Sweden). Swedish trade unions have no confirmation of this yet.  We supported this application in the Committee on Budgets (BUDG) and also in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL).

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted for this report giving the green light for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) in Sweden, mainly in the Stockholm and Astra regions. Solidarity must not be an empty word in Europe.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament, of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at the request of Sweden, because it is of major importance to assist beneficiaries made redundant for their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Written. The European Globalisation Fund is a useful tool to mitigate the impact of eu closures, but it remains only a wipe for the bleeding afterwards. However, more proactive efforts are needed to save and/or even bring industry back to our continent. In this respect, the EU is, by all the rules and burdens, a brake rather than an engine. The Member States themselves must be able to pursue an active (re)industrialisation policy and adopt an economic patriotism.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The EGF supports skills, counselling and support for people who have become unemployed as a result of globalisation or global severe economic crises. This report concerns a sum of EUR 3 957 918 to be made available to the country of Sweden. 918 out of 1556 workers lost their jobs during the reference period between 11 September 2015 and 11 January 2016. Ericsson operates mainly in the production of electronic products, in particular computer programs and computers. The report highlights that the company is struggling with stagnating growth and ever-increasing competition from Asian producers. In this case, too, I support the plan to support the workers concerned by mobilising the fund and to give them new perspectives.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Sweden has requested EUR 4 million in aid from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to deal with more than 1,500 redundancies in its telephone sector in order to reintegrate affected workers into the labour market.  Ericsson has mainly cut positions in its telecommunications equipment production sector to relocate this business directly or indirectly to Asia (especially India) in order to reduce costs and face ever-increasing global competition.  If these aids are to be voted on for laid-off workers, this must not overshadow the responsibility of EU policies sowing free trade and unfair global competition driven by an irrational rejection of intelligent protectionism.  So I voted for this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Sweden, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I regret the establishment of this instrument at European level and I await the planned revision of the legal basis. This device is widely requested, but I allow myself, on a case-by-case basis, the possibility of voting in favour of its mobilization. I therefore abstained because the situation around Ericsson's employment policy in the field of software is not clear enough.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson). Ericsson's telecom hardware production line, which was relocated to Asia, has been made redundant to 1,556 workers. In order to ensure a faster return to the labour market for workers who have been made redundant, Sweden has submitted a request to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which has been set up to provide additional assistance to workers affected by major structural changes in world trade patterns. In view of the situation, I welcome the commission's proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF for Swedish purposes in order to support the return to the labour market of workers made redundant from Ericsson.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 3 957 918 (60% match funding) for 918 Swedish workers who have been made redundant. This is nothing more than EU dole money. UKIP opposes British taxpayer’s money being used to offset poor economic decisions in other countries and by the EU.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This is a request from Sweden to seek assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 4 million to deal with more than 1,500 redundancies in its telephone sector for their reintegration into the labour market.  Since this fund exists, it may as well be used to help European workers in distress. However, this should not overshadow the responsibility of EU policies endorsing unchecked free trade and unfair global competition, and hence the hypocrisy of this 'Globalisation Adjustment Fund'.  Once again, instead of seeking to mitigate the effects, it is the causes that should be tackled by protecting European employees from savage globalisation.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade. On 31 March 2016, Sweden applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following the dismissal of more than 1,500 people at Ericsson in Sweden. In recent years, Ericsson has concentrated most of its production and development facilities in Asia, where not only are the fastest growing markets, but also lower-cost workers. As a result, the company has gradually reduced its workforce in Sweden (from 21,178 employees in 2005 to 17,858 in 2014), while at the same time experiencing spectacular growth worldwide (from 56,055 employees in 2005 to 118,055 in 2014). The Commission proposes that the EGF should contribute to the coordinated package of personalised services to the tune of EUR 3,957,918. In view of the situation experienced by Swedish workers and the need to make Europe a project of solidarity and not just a free trade area, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument designed to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The major changes in the structure of world trade in recent years, and in particular in the global ICT sector, have seen a loss of Europe's position in favour of China and the United States. In this context, Ericsson, while still hiring in Europe, is expanding its activities in Asia, deciding to aim for the growth of the software sector to the detriment of the hardware production and development sector. My vote in favour of the González Pons report stems from the need to mobilise fig to provide assistance to the 918 workers made redundant by Ericsson in Sweden, particularly in the Stockholm, Östra Mellansverige, Sydsverige and Västsverige areas. This measure will provide a coordinated package of instruments including training and mobility allowances as well as business start-up grants and training, retraining and vocational training programmes.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, in this case in Sweden, for workers affected by the relocation of the Ericsson Company that has been gradually moving its production to Asia, leading to a reduction in staff at its plants in Sweden. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. On the other hand, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I chose to vote for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following a request from Sweden for Ericsson employees. 1556 employees, most of them working in the telecommunications equipment industry, of this large Swedish firm have been laid off. A flagship company of the 1990s and 2000s, Ericsson, thanks to the game of so-called "happy globalization" has been forced to relocate a large part of its production to Asia, where production costs are much lower (notably thanks to cheap labour). For example, Ericsson's workforce in Sweden increased from 21,178 employees in 2005 to 17,858 in 2014; the largest share of employees in one of the flagships of the European telecommunications industry is now ... India! The very fact that this "adjustment fund" is needed to heal the wounds of a dying European industry unfortunately shows once again that wild free trade has only the benefit of the destruction of jobs.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report authorising the mobilisation of the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, to the amount of EUR 3 957 918 for 1 556 redundant Ericsson Sweden workers. The EGF remains a concrete and indispensable instrument for supporting workers and businesses affected by the crisis and the malfunctioning of the internal market, although I will continue to fight to make it less and less bureaucratic and to make it leaner and more flexible.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of EUR 3 957 918 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the reintegration into the labour market of the 918 workers laid off by Ericsson in Sweden. These funds will be intended to co-finance personalized services for laid-off workers, such as counselling and professional guidance; protected and assisted employment and rehabilitation measures; education and training; and job search assignments. In addition, special attention will be paid to participants of fifty years or more in the offer of motivation and professional planning.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which examines the Commission's proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF to help Sweden support workers made redundant from Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson in the manufacturing sectors of computers, electronics and optical products. The Swedish trade union Unione says that Ericsson still employs workers in Europe, but only those with completely different skills. The company does not normally re-employ employees with hardware manufacturing and development skills. The company's growth is currently mainly due to the development of software. Although some software is also being developed in Europe, asia is the largest part of its growth, where Ericsson is expanding its operations. The personalised services to be provided to redundant workers consist of four types of measures: (i) counselling and vocational guidance, broken down into: comprehensive assessment and individual planning, vocational guidance and motivational training and career planning, (ii) sheltered and supported employment and rehabilitation measures, (iii) education and training, (iv) jobseekers' allowances.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. Sweden submitted its request for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) under reference number "EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson" on 31 March 2016. Of the 1 556 redundant workers eligible for the EGF contribution, 918 are expected to participate in the measures. At the same time as growth in the IT and telecommunications sectors has stagnated, Ericsson has reduced the production of telecommunications hardware and gradually reduced its staff in Sweden in the face of stronger competition from Asian manufacturers. For the regions concerned, a relatively large group of older workers from similar backgrounds have been dismissed and the vast majority of these workers do not have the skills sought in the local labour market. Personalised services for redundant workers co-financed by the EGF include: counselling and career advice; protected and supported employment and rehabilitation measures; education and training; as well as financial support for job search. Participants aged 50 and over will receive special attention during motivational training and career planning. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I had no reservations about the support for the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund requested by Sweden to help solve the problems of redundancies at SE/Ericsson. Although Ericsson, which is mainly growing in the field of software, still employs in Europe, it is not possible to find re-employment for many hardware workers. The company is expanding its development outside Europe. Around EUR 4 million of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be earmarked for counselling and career guidance, retraining, education and job-search allowances, with 918 of the 1556 redundancies involved.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which is related to the dismissal of 1556 people at Phonektiebolaget LM Ericsson in Sweden. Surpluses are caused by the main structural changes in world trading customs, so the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help redundant people integrate into the labour market.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report proposes to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help Sweden re-settle most of the 1,500 laid-off workers at Ericsson, which has relocated these jobs to Asia. Even if this report does not mention the real causes of this mass dismissal, employees do not have to bear the Commission's mistakes in protecting the EU's economic borders. I vote in favour of this text

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal on mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the application by Sweden after several redundancies in the economic sector. Indeed, I am confident that this instrument will provide additional support to workers who are suffering from the consequences of major structural changes. The European Union has the duty to help its people when globalisation penalises them.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is useful for providing support to redundant workers and self-employed workers whose activities have ceased as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, due to the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis or due to a new economic and financial crisis of a supra-regional nature. The Fund must be used to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market, updating their training and giving it financial support at the same time. It is therefore appropriate to mobilise the EGF in order to make a financial contribution to workers in companies that have suffered serious failures as a result of the change in the international IT market and the new business strategies of Ericsson and its partner companies.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to provide Sweden with a financial contribution of 4 million euros, from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), following the dismissal of 1,500 employees at Ericsson, which operates in the telephony sector. This financial assistance will help to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of these sacked employees.  On the one hand, this request by Sweden fulfils the conditions for granting the EGF, granted if the link between layoffs and changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalisation is established. On the other hand, we consider it our duty to show solidarity with the Swedes who are suffering, as in France, the consequences of savage globalisation.  Nevertheless, these aids must not obscure the European Union's responsibility for the deindustrialization and mass unemployment that our fellow citizens suffer. As such, it is essential to combat unfair international competition exacerbated by social, environmental and monetary dumping by emerging countries, including a moratorium on all tariff concessions granted under free trade agreements.  I did, however, vote in favour of this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in global trade practices, and in this case we are talking about workers made redundant from Telephonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson whose job is to manufacture computers of electronic and optical products in Sweden. Global trade practices resulting from the globalisation process have led to an outsourcing of these activities to Asia, where the fastest growing markets are located and where a quality equivalent to the much lower expenditure in the production of telecommunications equipment can be ensured. Of the workers made redundant, 70% are men and 30% are women between the average age of 30 and 60. I voted in favour of this report, considering it very important that Sweden receive this support for the workers made redundant. This support is also undoubtedly also a boost to the country's economy.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Parliament has accepted Sweden's request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help Ericsson's sacked employees. The sum of 3,957,918 euros will be mobilised to help 1556 laid-off employees reintegrate into the world of work. This demand was justified, given the very high global competition faced by the telecommunications equipment production sector, particularly against Asian producers.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade.  This application was submitted by Sweden in relation to 918 redundancies at Ericsson which, unfortunately, does not sum up workers with skills in hardware production and development. In fact, today the growth of the company is mainly based on software development. Although some of the software is developed in Europe, the growth of the sector is mainly in Asia, where Ericsson is expanding its activities. I regret, and I will reiterate this in every explanation of vote, that Italian companies are not able to benefit more from this fund because of the lack of support from local and national institutions. Between 2007 and 2015, Italy submitted only 15 applications to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, 3 of which in 2007, only one in 2008, zero between 2009 and 2010, 7 in 2011, 2 in 2012, zero in 2013, one in 2014 and one in 2015.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ In this case, 1 556 workers working for Ericsson in Sweden were made redundant due to the partial or entire closure of wireless telecom hardware production lines at various Ericsson sites. The Swedish company sold its entire mobile phone development and production line to competitor Sony in February 2012, which has been a partial reason for job losses. Further lay-offs are expected in Europe. In order to avoid total devastation for these workers and the local economies in the areas they live in, I voted in favour of activating the fund.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Sweden, to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant at Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson operating in the manufacture of computer, electronic and optical products trailers mainly in the regions of Stockholm. Although Ericsson is still hiring in Europe, this is only people with an entirely different set of skills than in hardware production and development. Most of the company’s growth is in software development and is also mostly happening in Asia(6), where Ericsson is expanding its activities.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 As it faces stagnant growth and tighter competition with Asian manufacturers at the same time, Ericsson has gradually reduced the production of telecommunications hardware. On 31 March 2016, Sweden submitted an application to mobilise the EGF in relation to redundancies at Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson. The financial contribution requested under the EGF for this proposal is just under EUR 4 million. I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the application and consider that it fulfils the conditions for the granting of a financial contribution by the EGF.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at the request of Finland in the case of Ericsson employees. Given that this Fund provides support for the benefit of workers, I believe that the proposal has a positive purpose and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. On 5 September 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilising the EGF in favour of Sweden, to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson, active in NACE Division 26 Review 2 (Manufacture of computers and electronics and optical products), especially in nuts4 2 level regions in Stockholm , Östra Mellansverige, Sydsverige and Västsverige. The Commission concluded, in accordance with all the applicable provisions of the EGF Regulation, that the application fulfils the conditions for financial assistance from the Fund.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing. \u2012 In this case I voted in favour of the report for mobilising EUR 3 957 918 for the 1 556 redundant workers in Ericsson Sweden. The redundancies were the result of the closure of the Katrineholm plant and several branches in the country.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the use of tools to provide additional support to workers who are suffering the consequences of tumultuous structural changes in the world of trade or the global crisis and to witness their new and beneficial job affirmation. Therefore, the contribution of EUR 3 957 918, or 60% of the total cost of the proposed measures, to facilitate 918 former Ericsson employees to reintroduce themselves into the world of work is a suitable response, among others, for the implementation of training programmes in order to enrich specific skills and enable new quality positions to be achieved despite the different basic preparations. Ericsson, a company operating in the field of communication technology and services, is laying off employees in the hardware sector in Europe, but also hiring in the software development sector. At the same time, the Swedish multinational is implementing its production in Asia, a key destination for global outsourcing thanks to the low-cost manufacturing and skills it is acquiring in the IT sector. Stagnant growth and increasingly fierce competition with Asian markets are sluggishly sluggishing the Union. I therefore hope that these toxins, which weaken an increasingly contaminated social environment, can be expelled as soon as possible.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Support the Esteban González Pons report which allows the use of EUR 3,957,918 from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Erickson (Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson) in Sweden and eligible for EGF contributions. The redundancies were caused by stagnant growth and increased competition from Asian countries that have become an outsourcing destination leading To Erickson gradually reducing its workforce in Sweden. Through the use of this Fund, created to provide additional support to workers for major structural changes in world trade, it will be possible to support these workers through measures ranging from guidance/interpretation and facilitating job search to support for business creation or personalised professional requalification.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, through the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to cover 60 % of the necessary expenditure, it will be possible to help ericsson's redundant employees to be reintegrated into the labour market. A joint intervention between the Swedish public service and the European Fund will accompany workers in a personalised training programme to acquire new skills required by the labour market.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) towards redundancies in a Stockholm region where 918 out of 1 556 redundant workers eligible for the EGF contribution are expected to participate in the measures indicated in the report. Since the request in is in line with Article 4(1) of the EGF Regulation, I support this aid directed to the families of these workers who fell victims of such redundancies. I welcome the special emphasis that will be placed on participants aged 50 and above, when providing motivational coaching and career planning. The employability of all workers by means of adapted training and the recognition of skills and competences is of vital importance for their future active participation in society.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. Sweden requested assistance from the EGF following the dismissal of 1,556 Ericsson workers. Although European aid does not guarantee continuity of employment in a sector very exposed to international competition, they do mean an improvement in the situation of dismissed workers, so I voted in favour.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilising the EGF in favour of Sweden to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Ericsson. Sweden claims that the redundancies occurred in the operational sphere of Ericsson's telecommunications hardware production. In recent years, Ericsson has outsourced production and development activities in Asia. In addition, according to the Swedish union Union, the company does not reintegrate workers with expertise in hardware production and development, as the company's growth is mainly based on software development. I voted in favour because I am convinced that the instrument is the quickest way to offer concrete help to workers by showing the true face of solidarity in Europe.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in global trade practices. Due to declining sales, Ericsson has laid off 918 workers in Sweden. I voted to direct EUR 3 957 918 from the budget of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the Swedish authorities, which will help these European citizens to re-enter the labour market.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to help people who lose their jobs as a result of profound structural changes in world trade. The EU has an annual budget of EUR 150 million for this. Sweden applied for the aid in March 2016, mainly in the regions of Stockholm, Östra Mellansverige, Sydsverige and Västsverige. Layoffs affect the IT and telecommunications sectors, and the main problem is the rise of Asian companies in Sweden. This is why Ericsson needs to continuously reduce its number of employees. It aims to help redundant workers reintegrate into the labour market by using the aid. Under the decision, Sweden is entitled to EUR 3.9 million, which applies to 918 redundant workers. As older redundant workers do not have the skills needed in the local labour market, the report welcomes Sweden's activities and decisions towards redundant workers, including priority employment with participants aged 50 and over. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request made by Sweden for assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it is undeniably the purpose of this fund to help in such cases. The application submitted by Sweden is the result of ericsson's dismissal of 1556 employees. These redundancies are due to the partial or complete closure of production lines. Of course, I believe that, in such a situation, every effort must be taken to support these people and help them re-enter the labour market. I have always supported all measures aimed at increasing employment and growth, which is why I voted in favour in this case.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Redundant Ericsson workers will benefit through a EUR 3 957 918 contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as the Fund’s main aim is to provide financial support for workers who are suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I agree that the redundant workers should receive this support.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report focuses on a call for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which aims to help Member States that are experiencing a reduction in activities and employees in a particular professional sector. The Ericsson company used this fund to the amount of 6 million euros for the benefit of 1,244 employees. Considering that the EU must promote the transition of its economy to growth and employment-promoting sectors through support for laid-off workers, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this report on Sweden's request for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF). It is important that the European Union supports all workers who have been made redundant because of the effects of globalisation and that it helps them to reorient themselves. We therefore approve the mobilization of the EGF, the European fund dedicated to this type of support, for the training, reorientation and rehabilitation plan of the 1556 dismissed workers of Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson in Sweden.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Sweden submitted on 31 March 2016 an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) under reference number "EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson". Of the 1 556 redundant workers eligible for the EGF contribution, 918 are expected to participate in the measures. At the same time as growth in the IT and telecommunications sectors has stagnated, Ericsson has reduced the production of telecommunications hardware and gradually reduced its staff in Sweden in the face of stronger competition from Asian manufacturers. For the regions concerned, a relatively large group of older workers from similar backgrounds have been dismissed and the vast majority of these workers do not have the skills sought in the local labour market. Personalised services for redundant workers co-financed by the EGF include: counselling and career advice; protected and supported employment and rehabilitation measures; education and training; as well as financial support for job search. Participants aged 50 and over will receive special attention during motivational training and career planning. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I am pleased that the plenary has followed the position of the Budgets Committee, of which I am a member, and has today voted to grant EUR 3,957,918 for the financing of personalised services for 1,556 people from Ericsson who have been affected by a collective dismissal.  Europe's information technology and telecommunications sectors are currently experiencing intense competition from Asian manufacturers. Asia has also become an important relocation destination.  This is a major problem for the future of European industry and workers must be helped to face the consequences of this ruthless confrontation.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The global economic and financial crisis has hit many sectors of European industry hard. Confronted simultaneously with stagnant growth and increased competition with Asian producers, Ericsson has been steadily reducing its production of telecommunications equipment for nearly two decades.  In the first half of 2015, Ericsson announced 1,611 job losses at seven Swedish sites. It is legitimate for the European Union to help these laid-off workers through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. EUR 4 million has been set up to fund an employment training and skills upgrading programme or entrepreneurship support programmes.  But beyond the one-off and specific assistance that the Fund can provide, it is urgent that the European Union put in place a real strategy to better anticipate economic changes, preserve SMEs, implement a forward-looking investment policy, and develop genuine trade defence instruments.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is not the right instrument for tackling this problem and I and my group are against the funds to be allocated to this fund because the outcome that is achieved is not effective. The way to deal with unemployment and changes occurring in sectors where globalisation is most clearly reflected must be addressed with policies that create growth and jobs. So will the victims of globalisation be able to switch to other sectors.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be allocated to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies because this creates skilled unemployed people and does not address the situation.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Sweden submitted on 31 March 2016 an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) under reference number "EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson". Of the 1 556 redundant workers eligible for the EGF contribution, 918 are expected to participate in the measures. At the same time as growth in the IT and telecommunications sectors has stagnated, Ericsson has reduced the production of telecommunications hardware and gradually reduced its staff in Sweden in the face of stronger competition from Asian manufacturers. For the regions concerned, a relatively large group of older workers from similar backgrounds have been dismissed and the vast majority of these workers do not have the skills sought in the local labour market. Personalised services for redundant workers co-financed by the EGF include: counselling and career advice; protected and supported employment and rehabilitation measures; education and training; as well as financial support for job search. Participants aged 50 and over will receive special attention during motivational training and career planning. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. It is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures, and so I voted in favour of this application. I regret that the UK Government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. "Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We have previously accepted that the Fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, particularly in the light of the Swedish National Audit Office's analysis, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The EGF was created to provide additional support to workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take action to get their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. Sweden has submitted an application following redundancies in the area of manufacturing computer equipment, communication equipment, electronic and optical products, and which provides that 918 of the 1 556 redundant workers eligible for the EGF contribution will participate in the measures.  I voted in favour of the financial contribution of EUR 3 957 918.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: this time it is a request from Sweden to seek assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of 4 million euros to deal with more than 1,500 layoffs in its telephone sector with a view to their reintegration into the labour market.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This request, made by Sweden, concerns 1 556 workers made redundant, all employees of Ericsson, due to the closure of its hardware production unit for wireless communication. There are 5 most affected regions: Stockholm and Östra Mellansverige, Sydsverige and Västsverige. The majority of redundancies occurred in the Kista area (762 workers). Ericsson shifted most of its hardware production and development to Asia (mostly to India), from 56,000 employees in 2005 to more than 118,000 in 2014 globally. This means that while doubling global recruitment, it has gradually been reducing it in Sweden (from 21,178 in 2005 to 17,858 in 2014). In 2012, the Swedish company sold all of its mobile phone development and production to its competitor Sony. Here's predatory and exploitative capitalism at its best. Without prejudice to positive aspects, the resolution does not recognise or point out the fundamental problem. On the contrary, it implicitly assumes the defense of neoliberalism – the cause of relocations, through its large dominance on a global scale – by saying that it understands Ericsson's reasons. Support for redundant workers is fair and necessary. But above all, it is necessary to put an end to the policies that are the cause of these redundancies.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I do not consider this measure to be a useful tool for developing policies that promote growth and the creation of new jobs, nor can it provide a comprehensive answer on redundant workers.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it is beneficial to workers.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund serves to cover losses for businesses and companies in member states that have to cope with the consequences of the financial and economic crisis, which has often forced them to lay off employees. In the present case, this is ericsson's request. It concerns the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 3 957 918 from the EGF in favour of Sweden. It concerns 918 workers who have become redundant.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of aid to 1 556 Swedish workers made redundant.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be allocated, in the first place, to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies, because this creates skilled unemployed people and does not address the situation.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) funding of EUR 3 957 918 will contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for 918 targeted beneficiaries following redundancies in the NUTS level 2 regions of Stockholm (SE11), Östra Mellansverige (SE12), Sydsverige (SE22) and Västsverige (SE23), with the aim of providing assistance in integrating the affected persons into the labour market. The redundancies were caused by major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 Sweden submitted on 31 March 2016 an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) under reference number "EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson". Of the 1 556 redundant workers eligible for the EGF contribution, 918 are expected to participate in the measures. At the same time as growth in the IT and telecommunications sectors has stagnated, Ericsson has reduced the production of telecommunications hardware and gradually reduced its staff in Sweden in the face of stronger competition from Asian manufacturers. For the regions concerned, a relatively large group of older workers from similar backgrounds have been dismissed and the vast majority of these workers do not have the skills sought in the local labour market. Personalised services for redundant workers co-financed by the EGF include: counselling and career advice; protected and supported employment and rehabilitation measures; education and training; as well as financial support for job search. Participants aged 50 and over will receive special attention during motivational training and career planning. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Sweden submitted on 31 March 2016 an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) under reference number "EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson". Of the 1 556 redundant workers eligible for the EGF contribution, 918 are expected to participate in the measures. At the same time as growth in the IT and telecommunications sectors has stagnated, Ericsson has reduced the production of telecommunications hardware and gradually reduced its staff in Sweden in the face of stronger competition from Asian manufacturers. For the regions concerned, a relatively large group of older workers from similar backgrounds have been dismissed and the vast majority of these workers do not have the skills sought in the local labour market. Personalised services for redundant workers co-financed by the EGF include: counselling and career advice; protected and supported employment and rehabilitation measures; education and training; as well as financial support for job search. Participants aged 50 and over will receive special attention during motivational training and career planning. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EAG) in relation to Sweden's EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson application. Europe and the world are immersed in a profound process of globalization which, despite being a source of trade and wealth creation, can also carry risks to which we must be very attentive. As a result of this process, there are sectors that are more exposed to international competition, so from the EU we must respond to those citizens who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation. FeAG supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalization or the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council mobilising a contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 3 957 918 submitted by Sweden in connection with the redundancies of the Ericsson company, which will benefit some 900 workers.  The closures decided by Ericsson in different regions of the country are a very serious event for Sweden as they touch on different professional profiles, both workers and employees and engineers, young and/or old, difficult to relocate to traditional industry. Workers are therefore once again paying the price of the crisis in the sector and the various production relocations to China and other countries with low labour costs. The EGF funding of personalised professional and career counselling services, measures in the field of protected and assisted work and rehabilitation, education and training services and job-seeking allowances is important and necessary, but it is not enough. The EU must go further and tackle the problems of the European it industry as a whole, with a precise and effective strategy for reviving a sector that is crucial to the continent's future.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The Swedish economy is suffering from the trends in ict migration. The resulting increase in unemployment can be effectively cushioned by the EGF.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this budgetary (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 3 957 918 (60% match funding) for 918 Swedish workers who have been made redundant. This is nothing more than EU dole money. UKIP opposes British taxpayers’ money being used to offset poor economic decisions in other countries and by the EU.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, in this case in Sweden, for workers affected by the relocation of the Ericsson Company that has been gradually moving its production to Asia, leading to a reduction in staff at its plants in Sweden. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. On the other hand, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (proposal from Sweden - EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of significant changes in the structure of world trade.  The collapse in Ericsson was due to a change in the production profile. The company is moving away from the production of computer hardware and developing software-related production. As a result, it removed a significant part of its production from Europe and moved to Asia. The obvious effect of this action is a significant reduction in the level of employment in Europe.  In my opinion, it is therefore necessary to create an answer to the instruments that will help the large number of redundant workers to find their way into the current labour market.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: redundancies in telecom hardware production in Sweden, which relates to 1 556 workers made redundant in Ericsson (Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson). These redundancies are linked to major structural changes in world trade patterns.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this application for EGF assistance of EUR 3 957 918 for 1 556 workers made redundant at Ericsson resulting from the closure of production lines at various Ericsson sites and the closure of an entire plant in one instance. The Swedish authorities’ rationale for the impact of globalisation in this sector is that it has experienced outsourcing to Asia which is seeing the strongest growth in the sector and their ability to provide similar quality at a lower cost. It is notable that a relatively high number of those workers made redundant are older workers who do not have the skills required in their regions’ labour markets. The package of personalised measures will include counselling and career guidance, sheltered and supported employment and rehabilitation measures, education and training and job search allowances. It is welcome that there will be a special emphasis placed on participants aged 50 and over in the provision of motivational coaching and career planning. I note that while the income support measures are high at 33.92% of the overall package of personalised measures, I believe it to be justified given the significant number of older workers concerned and the provision of individual support to participants with learning disabilities.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. 'I believe that people should not be the victims of failing European socio-economic policies. In this case, it concerns the dismissal of 1 556 Ericsson employees in Sweden. However, I think this is a wipe for the bleeding. Companies, and the Member States themselves, should come up with appropriate support measures themselves, because now we are simply pumping money from the Member States around. Large companies put their employees on the streets after years of loyal service, because they move their production to places where they can find cheaper labour. Ericsson has moved production to Asia in recent years, mainly to India. While Ericsson doubled its recruitment worldwide, staffing is being cut in Swedish locations. I strongly reject these degrading practices, and with the resources from the European Fund, we are at least ensuring that workers who have been sent away are not left out in the cold.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) helps workers develop new skills when they have lost their jobs due to changing global trade patterns. In the case of Finland, the EGF would provide EUR 5.3 million out of EUR 8.9 million after the dismissal of 2 161 workers. In the case of Sweden, it would provide EUR 3.9 million out of EUR 6.5 million after the dismissal of 1 556 workers. Though I fully support policies that create growth and jobs, my Group and I do not believe that the EGF is the right tool for putting in place such policies, which is why I have voted against this proposal. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Sweden submitted on 31 March 2016 an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) under reference number "EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson". Of the 1 556 redundant workers eligible for the EGF contribution, 918 are expected to participate in the measures. At the same time as growth in the IT and telecommunications sectors has stagnated, Ericsson has reduced the production of telecommunications hardware and gradually reduced its staff in Sweden in the face of stronger competition from Asian manufacturers. For the regions concerned, a relatively large group of older workers from similar backgrounds have been dismissed and the vast majority of these workers do not have the skills sought in the local labour market. Personalised services for redundant workers co-financed by the EGF include: counselling and career advice; protected and supported employment and rehabilitation measures; education and training; as well as financial support for job search. Participants aged 50 and over will receive special attention during motivational training and career planning. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund’s main role is to provide assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The report includes a decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Sweden, mainly in the regions of Stockholm and Östra Mellansverige. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application submitted by Sweden - EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson) as I consider it necessary to assist the redundanced workers of Ericsson, especially because it is a relatively large group of older workers in the Stockholm area, Östra Mellansverige, Sydsverige and Västsverige. It predicts that the measures will cover 918 of the 1,556 redundant workers eligible for EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund) contributions. The Commission underlines that the conditions set out in Article 4(1) of the EGF Regulation have been met and that Sweden is entitled under that Regulation to a financial contribution of EUR 3 957 918, amounting to 60 % of the total cost of EUR 6 596 531, which will allow the return to the labour market for, as already mentioned, 918 targeted beneficiaries.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The choice of Ericsson to relocate to Asia and participate in the crazy global competition is obviously the cause of these layoffs. Once again, while it is commendable to help these sacrificed workers, we cannot ignore the responsibility of European policy in its support for ultra-globalism and the rejection of intelligent protectionism. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this budgetary (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 3 957 918 (60% match funding) for 918 Swedish workers who have been made redundant. This is nothing more than EU dole money. UKIP opposes British taxpayer’s money being used to offset poor economic decisions in other countries and by the EU.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Esteban Gonzalez Pons' report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, established in 2006, helps people who have lost their jobs. This fund will unlock just over three million for the 1,556 sacked employees. This amount will be used to finance training, counselling and support to promote the return to employment of these laid-off workers. I am pleased that this report has been adopted by a large majority.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for sacked employees of Ericsson in Sweden. This fund was created to help those who find themselves impacted by certain negative consequences of globalization, for example by funding new training.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Ericsson's workers have slipped into unemployment through no fault of their own, so that in order to reintegrate them into the labour market, training and further training are necessary.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns, due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Sweden submitted on 31 March 2016 an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) under reference number "EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson". Of the 1 556 redundant workers eligible for the EGF contribution, 918 are expected to participate in the measures. At the same time as growth in the IT and telecommunications sectors has stagnated, Ericsson has reduced the production of telecommunications hardware and gradually reduced its staff in Sweden in the face of stronger competition from Asian manufacturers. For the regions concerned, a relatively large group of older workers from similar backgrounds have been dismissed and the vast majority of these workers do not have the skills sought in the local labour market. Personalised services for redundant workers co-financed by the EGF include: counselling and career advice; protected and supported employment and rehabilitation measures; education and training; as well as financial support for job search. Participants aged 50 and over will receive special attention during motivational training and career planning. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to provide support for workers made redundant and self-employed persons whose activity has ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. In this regard, the main aim of the fund is to help people who have lost their jobs to reintegrate into the labour market. In light of this, the EU should mobilise the fund to support Sweden’s submitted application EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson for a financial contribution from the EGF, following redundancies in the economic sector classified under the NACE Revision 2 Division 26 (manufacture of computer, electronic and optical products). In this case, 918 redundant workers eligible for the EGF contribution will have new opportunities to reintegrate into the labour market.  It is important to emphasise efforts undertaken by Swedish authorities to break traditional gender barriers, including encouraging male beneficiaries to find jobs in the health sector. Furthermore, we should welcome the Swedish authorities’ efforts to provide a personalised package of training programmes and coaching that will enable most of the redundant employees to find high-quality new jobs. I supported mobilisation of the fund because the Swedish authorities have implemented all necessary measures to activate and receive the EGF.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. As we all know, major structural changes in world trade and the economic crisis are greater for workers, and the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) plays a leading role in this context. Sweden has applied for a financial contribution from the EGF to support the reintegration into the labour market of 918 workers made redundant at Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson.
