In view of the fact that the request for assistance meets the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, I have decided to vote in favour of the report, which offers concrete help to these workers in difficulty.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the globalisation adjustment fund to the tune of 4 million euros for the reintegration into the labour market of 1,500 workers laid off by Ericsson in Sweden, following competition from emerging countries in the production of telecommunications equipment.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund on the EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson demand. This is a request from Sweden to seek assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of 4 million euros to deal with more than 1,500 layoffs in its telephone sector with a view to their reintegration into the labour market.  Ericsson has mainly cut positions in its telecommunications equipment production sector to relocate this business directly or indirectly to Asia (especially India) in order to reduce costs and face ever-increasing global competition.  If these aids are to be voted on for laid-off workers, this must not overshadow the responsibility of EU policies sowing free trade and unfair global competition driven by an irrational rejection of intelligent protectionism.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Sweden has made a request here to request the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. It is asking for 4 million Euros to compensate for the dismissal of 1,500 employees in the telephone sector. Ericsson has relocated part of its production to Asia (especially India), where labour costs are much lower. Of course, I voted in favour of this aid, even if it is only a pale remedy for the devastating effects of globalization, and it does not address the causes.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of the EGF for the re-integration into the labour market of the 918 workers, dismissed by Ericsson in Sweden.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. Sweden requested assistance from the EGF following the dismissal of 1,556 Ericsson workers. Although European aid does not guarantee continuity of employment in a sector very exposed to international competition, they do mean an improvement in the situation of dismissed workers, so I voted in favour.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree that Sweden should be sent EUR 4 million in social assistance as a result of the redundancies at Ericsson. I do not agree with the existence of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I consider it meaningless, money is supposed to remain in people's pockets instead of being redistributed by the EU. Special assistance to some workers is unfair.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. \u2012 From Nokia Cluj to Sidex-Mittal Steel In Galați, Romania has been hit by massive redundancies, as a consequence of either international economic crises or irresponsible management of national or multinational companies. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EAF) helps workers overcome such crises by funding retraining programmes. Finland is one of the countries that has requested access to this fund. More than 2,000 Microsoft workers were sent out as a result of declining market demand for phones produced by the US company. The money could help 1,441 workers refocus on the labour market. Approximately EUR 9 million would be spent on retraining programmes, of which just over 5 million should be covered by the EAGGF. On the other hand, faced with a similar situation, Sweden also requested access to that fund. In the Scandinavian country, Ericsson has laid off more than 1,500 workers. The professional rehabilitation measures provided for by Sweden involve an expenditure of more than EUR 6 million, with almost 4 million to be spilled by the EAGGF. I strongly support the measures that lead to the creation of new jobs and the adaptation of industries to the current requirements.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from major structural changes in world trade. In September this year, the Commission adopted a proposal on a decision to mobilise the EFG to help Sweden reintegrate workers into the labour market, dismissed as surpluses at Phonektiebolaget LM Ericsson.  This is the eighth application submitted for companies in the computer and electronic and optical products manufacturing sector, relating to mobilisation totalling EUR 3 957 918 from the EGF for Sweden, with 918 workers becoming redundant. Most of the company's growth today is based on software development, and most of the growth in this sector is happening in Asia, where Ericsson is expanding its activities. This financial assistance shall be provided with personalised services provided to workers in the process of their care, consisting of counselling and career guidance measures, subsidised employment, education and training and assistance in active job search.  As the Commission concluded in accordance with the provisions of the EFG Regulation that the conditions for this financial assistance were met, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the suggestion to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to assist Sweden in respect of redundancies in the telecommunications sector.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Swedish company Ericsson has been reducing the production volume of telecommunications hardware for twenty years due to increasing competition from Asian manufacturers. This was reflected in the staff cuts, where 1 551 people were made public. Sweden has requested assistance from the Fund amounting to EUR 3 957 918. The application complies with the conditions and rules of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The amount is intended to take measures to reinte the employment process for 918 redundancies.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (a request submitted by Sweden) because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this report. The aim is to provide Sweden with financial assistance of 4 million euros so that it can cope with the consequences of more than 1,500 redundancies in the telephone sector. The aim is to use this fund for the benefit of those made redundant, with a view to their reintegration into the labour market.  Indeed, Sweden is a victim of globalisation because Ericsson has cut jobs in its telecommunications equipment production sector. The purpose of these deletions (in order to reduce its costs) was to relocate, directly or indirectly, this activity in Asia. Again, the report does not underline the responsibility of EU policies that sow free trade and unfair competition, thereby pushing large companies to take such actions. Despite these reservations, we do not oppose aid to sacked employees: the real victims of these policies.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ Regarding the Report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I voted in favour as it emphasises that citizens will have access to a personalised package of training programmes and coaching that will allow them to find new high-quality jobs. On the other hand, the report also focuses on recognising that skills and competences gained throughout a worker’s professional career are of great importance to improve the employability of all workers. With that being said, I believe that many workers will benefit from the list of favourable aspects listed throughout the report.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Here, too, we are talking about supporting workers made redundant by globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is intended to provide financial support to redundant workers in Sweden. Telefonaktiebolaget (AG in Sweden) had to lay off employees. I am concerned about the financial support of these workers.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP's report, which proposes to allocate egf funds to help Sweden support the return of workers made redundant from Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson to the labour market.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Swedish-born firm, Ericsson, is laying off more than 1,500 of its workers in the country and soon more in Europe. At the same time, it has doubled its recruitment worldwide. This report justifies the relocation of one of the world's leading telecommunications companies who would be "confronted simultaneously with stagnant growth and tougher competition with Asian producers".  These are more precisely the effects of the relocation of production sites of European and American firms to Asia and the Swedish-Japanese alliance Sony Ericsson, the 5th largest manufacturer of phones in the world. No questions are proposed about the total absence of protectionism at European borders which has caused these job and technology losses for the past ten years.  However, the Scandinavian countries were at the forefront of telecoms thanks to highly qualified employees who will now find it difficult to find a job in a sector-niche in the midst of a stampede.  The Swedish state blames the coup and makes a commitment to rehire some of these workers. In the end, this 'European Globalisation Adjustment Fund' fulfils its role as 'relocation aid'. However, I abstain so as not to deprive the workers concerned of this aid.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This is a request from Sweden for funding from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 4 million to deal with more than 1,500 redundancies in the telephone sector for their reintegration into the labour market. I voted for these aids to laid-off workers, but they must not overshadow the responsibility of EU policies.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Sweden to give such aid to Sweden, which submitted the EFG/2016/002 SE/Ericsson application for a financial contribution from the EGF, following redundancies in the economic activity sector classified in NACE Rev Division 26. 2 (Manufacture of computer equipment, communication equipment, electronic and optical products) mainly in the level 2 regions of STOCKHOLM NUTS (SE11), Östra Mellansverige (SE12), Sydsverige (SE22) and Västsverige (SE23), and 918 of the 1 556 redundant workers eligible for the EGF contribution are expected to participate in the measures. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the tools at the European Union’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions for mobilising the EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 918 people.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I support the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Sweden, to the tune of EUR 3,957,918, to help 918 workers re-enter the labour market. I believe it is essential to help workers, to ensure them stable and sustainable jobs in the long term, and to support them in their reintegration into the labour market.  On 31 March, Sweden submitted a request by the EGF to intervene in relation to the dismissals at Ericsson. The Swedish company has been forced to gradually reduce the number of its employees in Sweden, from 21,178 workers in 2005 to 17,858 in 2014, representing almost a fifth of its workforce. These layoffs are directly related to major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization.  To remain competitive in the long term against Asian manufacturers and to maintain its dominant position in services and technology, this former pioneer of telephony had to change his strategy. In an ever-changing world, it is essential to help workers reintegrate into the labour market.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which proposes a contribution for Sweden amounts to EUR 3 957 918, in order to help find new jobs for 918 workers made redundant by Ericsson in a climate of stagnating growth and increasingly tough competition from Asian producers. These redundancies were due to the partial or complete closure of wireless telecom hardware production lines at various Ericsson sites (Borås, Karlskrona, Kista/Stockholm, Kumla, Linköping and Gothenburg) in Sweden, and the closure of an entire plant in the city of Katrineholm. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity to disaster-stricken regions within Europe.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 31 March 2016, Sweden submitted an application to the Commission to use the Fund to help workers made redundant from Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson in Sweden reintegrate into the labour market. The measures affect 918 redundant workers. Dismissed workers are requested to provide four types of personalised services, such as (i) advice and career advice consisting of detailed analysis and personalised planning, guidance, counselling and motivational training, as well as career planning, (ii) protected and supported employment and rehabilitation measures, (iii) education and training, (iv) financial support for job search. The Commission found that the conditions for the financial contribution from the Fund were fulfilled in the case of the application and that the measures envisaged constituted active labour market measures included in the eligible activities and therefore submitted a proposal for a decision to Parliament and the Council on the use of the Fund for EUR 3 957 918 in the form of commitment and payment appropriations. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This is a request from Sweden to seek assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 4 million to deal with more than 1,500 redundancies in its telephone sector for their reintegration into the labour market.  Ericsson has mainly cut positions in its telecommunications equipment production sector to relocate this business directly or indirectly to Asia (especially India) in order to reduce costs and face ever-increasing global competition. If these aids are to be voted on for laid-off workers, this must not overshadow the responsibility of the Union's policies sowing free trade and unfair global competition driven by an irrational rejection of intelligent protectionism.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The EGF was created with the purpose of giving complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. In the present case, the Commission adopted a proposal for a Decision on mobilising the EGF in favour of Sweden to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in TELEFONAKTIEBOLAGET LM Ericsson, NACE Revision 2, division 26 (Manufacture of computer equipment, communication equipment, electronic and optical products).  I stress the importance of improving the employability of all workers made redundant through tailored training and the recognition of qualifications and skills acquired throughout their professional career, and it is vital that the proposed training is adapted not only to the needs of redundant workers but also to the real environment of enterprises. I advocate the mobilisation of this fund for the reintegration of workers.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. As with Finland's request, this time it is a request from Sweden to seek assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 4 million to deal with more than 1,500 layoffs in its telephone sector for reintegration into the labour market.  Indeed, Ericsson has mainly eliminated positions in its telecommunications equipment production sector to relocate this activity directly or indirectly to Asia (especially India) in order to reduce its costs and face ever-increasing global competition. If these aids are to be voted on for laid-off workers, this must not overshadow the responsibility of EU policies sowing free trade and unfair global competition driven by an irrational rejection of intelligent protectionism. So I voted for this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Ericsson in Sweden. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund intervenes to support sacked employees due to major changes in the structure of world trade resulting from globalisation, due to the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis, or due to a new global financial and economic crisis. In this case, the amount of the EGF mobilized amounts to 3,957,918 euros for 1556 sacked employees.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Mobilisation Adjustment Fund, requested by Sweden, for Ericsson. When jobs are at risk, when economic changes require the retraining or training assistance of employees of companies in difficulty, I welcome the financial assistance that the European Union can provide. The fight against unemployment is the priority of the European Union; unfortunately, the current labour market situation and the consequences of the 2008 economic crisis continue to affect employment in Europe. All the tools we have must be used to safeguard jobs in our small and large businesses.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 On 5 September 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilising the EGF in favour of Sweden to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson, active in NACE Division 26 Review 2 (Manufacture of computers and electronics and optical products). This application concerns 918 workers made redundant. I voted in favour of this measure to allow the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which was set up specifically to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of globalisation.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Thanks to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the EU is able to combat unemployment. We've been looking at a number of ways to take advantage of it. By adopting this report, we have decided to support Ericcson and its staff in Sweden. The company is ready to hire a new workforce, but expectations for skills have now changed. This is why the Adaptation Fund is of great help, allowing, inter alia, to participate in retraining. Thus, those made redundant will be able to re-enter the Swedish labour market, or even in their original company. This is also good news for those at risk of redundancy, who can keep their jobs thanks to training.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ On 5 September 2016, Sweden’s proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF was adopted by the Commission in order to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant at Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson. I voted for this report that will mobilise a total amount of EUR 3 957 918 from the EGF for Sweden and that will help 918 workers made redundant.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – The financial support provided by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund must be provided to European information and communication technology (ICT) workers in order to avoid the risk of them becoming structurally unemployed as a result of irresponsible liberalisation of the internal European market.  In recent years, the trend in the ICT sector has increased towards the dominance of Asian producers as well as contractors due to the low cost of production factors in this region, such as the workforce. Swedish firm Eriksson, in order to maintain its competitiveness, followed this trend by closing jobs in Sweden at the expense of opening new ones in Asia. All this has left skilled workers in a situation of structural unemployment, as their skills are no longer sought on the local Swedish market. In this context, I am convinced that if we want, as far as ICT is concerned, that the EU develops and there is no structural unemployment, we need to help through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for workers like those who previously worked in Eriksson.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. With the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the European Union has a budgetary instrument in place to provide financial support to workers affected by the far-reaching global structural changes in world trade patterns. This fund starts exactly where society needs it most, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Due to changes in world trade, Ericsson was forced to lay off a number of workers. The aim of the action is to support their return to the labour market through education and training, vocational guidance and job search support.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the provision of support from the European Adjustment Fund to Sweden and with a view to the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by TELEFONAKTIEBOLAGET LM Ericsson, because I considered that the country's application fulfils the conditions for the granting of a financial contribution from the European Adjustment Fund. The Swedish authorities have also provided all the necessary assurances requested. With these funds, workers made redundant will have access to personalised services such as (a) counselling and professional planning based on in-depth evaluation and individualised planning, guidance and incentives advice, (b) protected and supported employment and rehabilitation measures, (c) education and training and (d) job search allowance, so that, with this assistance to be given to them, , to be able to reintegrate into the labour market.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 3 957 918 (60% match funding) for 918 Swedish workers who have been made redundant. This is nothing more than EU dole money. UKIP opposes British taxpayer’s money being used to offset poor economic decisions in other countries and by the EU.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the effects of globalisation in Sweden, I believe that a united response from the Union is needed through the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The institutions have specially prepared the use of these instruments to support and shelter workers from what we can regard as the negative consequences of globalisation. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I support the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund as required by EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson. Faced with strong competition from Asian countries, Ericsson was forced to reduce hardware production and reorient itself to software production and development. This transition unfortunately resulted in a technological surplus of 1,556 workers for Ericsson. An additional problem these workers face is the lack of competence to be competitive in the labour market.  Ericsson's former workers, while lacking the necessary skills, show a high affinity for the IT sector, and that is why I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund needs to help these workers gain the necessary qualifications and find a new job more easily.  By investing in their development, we are also investing in the development of the European Union's IT sector, which is facing strong competition and needs strong support to cope with growing challenges.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. As with Finland's request, this time it is a request from Sweden to seek assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 4 million to deal with more than 1,500 layoffs in its telephone sector for reintegration into the labour market.  Ericsson has mainly cut positions in its telecommunications equipment production sector to relocate this business directly or indirectly to Asia (especially India) in order to reduce costs and face ever-increasing global competition.  If these aids are to be voted on for laid-off workers, this must not overshadow the responsibility of EU policies sowing free trade and unfair global competition, driven by an irrational rejection of intelligent protectionism. In support of the EU's victim workers, I am voting for this aid.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Sweden applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following the redundancies of ericsson workers (Phonektiebolaget LM Ericsson) in Sweden. The Commission has adopted a proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF in Sweden's favour in order to support the reinsugment of redundance workers from Ericsson. The application applies to 918 workers who have been made redundant. The EGF should therefore be mobilised to provide a financial contribution of EUR 3 957 918 for the application submitted by Sweden. The Purpose of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to support redundant and self-employed workers who have ceased their activity due to major structural changes in the flows of globalisation, due to the continuation of the global financial and economic crisis or the new global and economic crisis, and to help these workers re-enter the labour market. It is for these reasons that I also support this, the sixth egf mobilisation request in 2016.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This request, made by Sweden, concerns 1 556 workers made redundant, all employees of Ericsson, due to the closure of its hardware production unit for wireless communication. There are 5 most affected regions: Stockholm and Östra Mellansverige, Sydsverige and Västsverige. The majority of redundancies occurred in the Kista area (762 workers). Ericsson shifted most of its hardware production and development to Asia (mostly to India), from 56,000 employees in 2005 to more than 118,000 in 2014 globally. This means that while doubling global recruitment, it has gradually been reducing it in Sweden (from 21,178 in 2005 to 17,858 in 2014). In 2012, the Swedish company sold all of its mobile phone development and production to its competitor Sony. Here's predatory and exploitative capitalism at its best. Without prejudice to positive aspects, the resolution does not recognise or point out the fundamental problem. On the contrary, it implicitly assumes the defense of neoliberalism – the cause of relocations, through its large dominance on a global scale – by saying that it understands Ericsson's reasons. Support for redundant workers is fair and necessary. But above all, it is necessary to put an end to the policies that are the cause of these redundancies.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Sweden and Ericsson, as more than 1 500 workers have been laid off at the company in the last six months. Since the reduction in staffing levels was only the end result of stagnant growth and the company's strategy to continue most of its hardware production to Asia with a much cheaper workforce, this case, including according to the European Commission, meets the conditions set for obtaining support from the Globalisation Fund. The overall trend of decline in hardware production leaves all Swedish regions with relatively large groups of older citizens with a similar portfolio of education and experience who are forced to seek new jobs. I therefore supported the mobilisation of almost EUR 4 million to assist these disadvantaged groups by 2018, for example in the form of individual planning, courses, establishing communication with new employers or in the form of traineeships. I also supported that these support activities be in line with the further development of a sustainability-based economy. It is extremely important to achieve the highest possible involvement of local authorities, which have the deepest knowledge of the labour market and its problems at regional and local level. At the same time, the affected areas also have to cope with the integration of a significant number of newly arrived migrants.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is necessary, in order to provide additional support to Swedish workers affected by the consequences of the global economic and financial crisis, for Parliament to approve this proposal. The Aim of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is to provide support to redundant workers and self-employed workers whose activities have ceased as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation. This is a very important tool that can provide practical help to those in difficulty. I voted in favour of this proposal for a decision.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Sweden is applying for EGF support after the dismissal of 1 556 employees at Ericsson. The main reason for ericsson's redundancies is the partial or complete closure of wireless telecommunications equipment production lines at various Ericsson plants in Sweden.  Measures co-financed by the EGF will help 918 workers by providing them with career guidance and guidance, protected and supported employment measures and rehabilitation, education, training and jobseeker's allowances. The total estimated cost of the package will be EUR 6.5 million, of which the EGF will provide EUR 3.9 million.  I support measures to introduce policies that are conducive to growth and employment. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), established in 2006, helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of structural changes in international trade, such as relocations or business closures. In this case, I voted to grant aid requested by Sweden for 1556 former employees of Ericsson.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to ensure complementary support for workers affected by the effects of structural changes in world trade patterns. Since its creation, the Fund has allowed thousands of newly unemployed to access professional advisory services for reintegration into the labour market, but is also supportive of the creation of their own businesses and new opportunities for education and training. Following the dismissal of 918 employees of Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson, the application to the Fund was submitted in March 2016. The Commission has found that the application is in line with the applicable provisions of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund Regulation and that, in casu, the mobilisation of the fund amounts to €3 957 918. This report defends the insofismable importance of the EGF as an emergency tool to address the scourge of unemployment in the context of today's social market economy. My vote is therefore in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary (single vote) report. This vote was to approve giving EUR 3 957 918 (60% match funding) for 918 Swedish workers who have been made redundant. This is nothing more than EU dole money. UKIP opposes British taxpayer’s money being used to offset poor economic decisions in other countries and by the EU.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I consider it imperative to be sympathetic to workers who have lost their jobs in large-scale redundancies due to major structural changes in world trade patterns arising from globalisation or crises. This report concerns the dismissal of 918 employees by Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson, which operates in the 'Manufacture of computer equipment, communication equipment, electronic and optical products' and on which the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Sweden in order to support reintegration into the labour market.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of EUR 3 957 918 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the reintegration into the labour market of the 918 workers, dismissed by Ericsson in Sweden. These funds will be intended to co-finance personalized services for laid-off workers such as counselling and professional guidance; protected and assisted employment and rehabilitation measures; education and training; and job search assignments. In addition, special attention will be paid to participants 50 years of age or older in the offer of motivation and professional planning.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help the 1244 Swedish workers who have lost their jobs at the several Ericsson production sites in Sweden. It is important that the European Union can financially support these workers to find jobs and develop their skills.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. Faced with difficulties and strong competition from Asian manufacturers, Ericsson has reduced the production of telecom hardware. As a result, 1 556 workers were dismissed in Sweden. It should be noted that due to the fact that a large group of older workers with similar education and experience are dismissed at the same time, the former workers will find it difficult to find a job after dismissal because they do not have the right skills for the local labour market. A sum of EUR 3 957 918 will be allocated to those who have lost their jobs.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 In light of the relevant structural changes that have occurred in recent years in world trade patterns, especially in the information and communication technology sector, much of the production is expanding its operations to Asia and reducing the number of staff in Europe.  In particular, several European companies have been forced to make collective redundancies in these sectors. This is also the case of the Swedish company Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson, which operates in the division of the manufacture of computer equipment, for communication, electronic and optical products, and which was found in the contingency of laying off 918 workers, the result of the relocation of the software development area to Asia.  After examining sweden's application for a bid, the regulatory conditions necessary for the mobilisation of the FEAG, totalling €3 957 918, were met to support measures for workers in favour of counselling and vocational guidance, education, training and allowances for active job search, so I considered that there was no reason to stand up to it.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With this report, for which I voted in favour, the European Parliament approved the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund requested by Sweden. This case concerns the redundancy of 918 workers for whom Sweden has applied for EUR 3 957 918 and, with the approval of the European Parliament, these funds will be allocated as soon as possible.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, in this case in Sweden, for workers affected by the relocation of the Ericsson Company that has been gradually moving its production to Asia, leading to a reduction in staff at its plants in Sweden. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. On the other hand, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. Sweden requested assistance from the EGF following the dismissal of 1,556 Ericsson workers. Although European aid does not guarantee continuity of employment in a sector very exposed to international competition, they do mean an improvement in the situation of dismissed workers, so I voted in favour.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has as its main function to support people who, due to major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalisation or even due to some kind of macroeconomic and financial crisis, have lost their jobs. I voted in favour of this implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to support workers who have been made redundant by Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as the UK does not receive this funding.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: redundancies in telecom hardware production in Sweden which relates to 1556 workers made redundant in Ericsson (Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson). These redundancies are linked to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support measures aimed at setting policies that promote economic growth and the creation of new jobs. However, I do not consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a proper and effective instrument for developing these policies. I therefore voted against this resolution in line with the ECR's position.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is also an important tool to address the effects of structural changes in world trade patterns. It has long proven to be a mechanism for supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to the collapse of their employer and are also located in a less developed region where employment opportunities are scarce. Ericson employees also found themselves out of work in several locations in Sweden. I agreed to release funds from the Globalisation Fund because the situation in which these former employees find themselves fulfils the conditions for drawing from the Globalisation Fund. The main reason for their dismissal, according to the Swedish trade unions, is ericson's reorientation. According to the information available, Ericson still hires people in Europe, but only people with different skills than those possessed by redundant workers. Employees with skills in hardware manufacturing and development are no longer of interest to this company and have therefore been made redundant. Today, the company is already focused on software development. This should provide Sweden with almost EUR 4 million to be used to help the 918 workers who have become redundant. I hope that the personalised retraining services to which they will be entitled will help them to get back into the work process quickly.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund has an annual budget of €150 million and provides assistance in cases where more than 500 workers are made redundant in one company in one sector and one region as a result of major structural changes in world trade. The assistance is reflected in job search, career counselling, education, retraining, mobility and the like. On 5 September 2016, the European Commission adopted a proposal to activate the Globalisation Adjustment Fund in respect of workers made redundant in connection with Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson in Sweden. Unionen also issued a statement saying that Ericsson continues to employ others in Europe, but workers with completely different skills and experience. Employment for hardware workers is almost gone, as growth in this area is taking place in Asia. In this case, the fund's assistance would comprise four different activities (career counselling, support employment, education, and financial support for jobseekers). The Fund will provide about one third of the funding. This is a very similar situation to that of the Finnish case, where it is also the mobile telephony sector. I believe that, in such cases, workers made redundant should be offered support in returning to the labour market, which is why I supported the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 In Europe, we are facing industry exits and layoffs of skilled workers. The long-term objective of the Commission and the European Parliament is to stop this trend and to create the conditions for production with higher added value to return to the European Union. For people made redundant from Ericsson in Sweden, we offer retraining programmes supported by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. It is a pity that Slovakia did not apply for assistance from this fund in similar cases.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (request by Sweden – EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson). We are constantly deciding on subsidies from this fund. The EGF has a maximum annual budget of 150 million euros between 2014 and 2020. I fundamentally reject this fund as a waste of taxpayers' money. The fund subsidises support measures when a company has not been able to compete with its business model. The Fund also means overstepping the EU's competences. It is absurd to adopt such bailouts at EU level rather than at national level in the event of the inability of individual companies or sectors to compete. This is at least a violation of the principle of subsidiarity and also a violation of economic policy lessons. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund must be closed and wound up immediately.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was created to provide additional assistance to workers directly affected by major structural changes in global sample trade. On 31 March 2016, Sweden applied to EGF/2016/002 SE/Ericsson for a financial contribution from the EGF following redundancies at Ericsson in Sweden. Following the evaluation of the application, the Commission concluded, in accordance with all the applicable provisions of the Regulation, that the conditions for granting a financial contribution from the EGF had been met.  The events that caused these layoffs are the complete and partial closure of telecommunication equipment production lines at various Ericsson facilities, and the complete closure of the factory in the city of Katrineholm. The application concerns 1 556 laid-off Ericsson workers. I support the proposal for this resolution, as I believe that support for redundant workers could play an important role in revitalising the industry if their further education and training is sufficiently supported and employment prospects.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the role made by Sweden –Ericsson. Of the 1556 workers made redundant, 918 are eligible for a contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Ericsson's globalization has been going on for two decades, as it is cutting back on the production of telecommunications equipment, with stagnation of growth and at the same time stronger competition from Asian manufacturers. As the application fulfils all the criteria for allocating funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I supported the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be allocated to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies because this creates skilled unemployed people and does not address the situation.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The IT and telecommunications industries are dominated by manufacturers from Asia, to which production is transferred. Ericsson has also benefited from this solution, which is gradually reducing the number of employees in Sweden (from 21 178 in 2005 to 17 858 in 2014), but is growing significantly worldwide (from 56 055 in 2005 to 118 055 in 2014). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of significant changes in the structure of world trade. The application submitted this year by Sweden concerns almost 1 000 people made redundant from Ericsson (Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson). Ericsson still employs employees in Europe, but these are only people with completely different qualifications than previously dismissed employees who had skills in the production and development of computer equipment. Today, the main source of growth for the company is software development. It is therefore necessary to mobilise EU aid for the retraining of workers made redundant in Sweden.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft report. Ericsson's situation is reminiscent of finland's case with Microsoft, where, as a result of the drastic restructuring of the IT sector, EU support for regions affected by redundancies and unemployment is welcome.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ This report is about approving the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in Sweden, mainly in the regions of Stockholm and Östra Mellansverige. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a legislative and budgetary instrument to provide additional support to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns or of the global financial and economic crisis, and to assist their reintegration into the labour market. The application relates to 1 556 redundancies at the enterprise Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson in Sweden operating in the economic sector, during the period 11 September 2015 to 11 January 2016. The EGF funding of EUR 3 957 918 will contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for 918 targeted beneficiaries following redundancies in the NUTS level 2 regions of Stockholm (SE11), Östra Mellansverige (SE12), Sydsverige (SE22) and Västsverige (SE23), with the aim of providing assistance in integrating the affected persons into the labour market. The redundancies were caused by major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. I support this report as I believe that the 1 556 redundancies at Ericsson are eligible to receive aid.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. It is normal for us to show solidarity. On 5 September 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the EGF in favour of Sweden in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of dismissed workers of Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson, which operates in the economic sector under Division 26 (Manufacturing of Computer, Electronic and Optical Products) of NACE Rév. 2 mainly in the NUTS(4) 2 regions of Stockholm (SE11), 'Stra Mellansverige' (SE12), Sydsverige (SE22) and Vestsverige (SE23). This is the eighth application considered in the 2016 budget and the fifteenth for the computer, electronic and optical products manufacturing sector; it relates to the mobilization of a total of EUR 3,957,918 of the EGF in favour of Sweden. It affects 918 laid-off workers.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Similar to the case of Finland and Nokia, Sweden’s Ericsson too faces similar challenges with the shifting of global software development from Europe to the rapidly growing sector in Asia. I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund intended to compensate for Sweden’s decline in its software production market share. The funds will be allocated to workers who have been made redundant, for the purpose of counselling and career guidance, employment rehabilitation, education and training as well as job search allowances. I believe that with these funds, the redundant workers in Sweden concerned will be able to reintegrate successfully into the labour market.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against a request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund submitted by Sweden for laying off Ericsson workers. As stated in the Commission proposal itself, the reason for the redundancies of workers is to move the concentration of most production and development facilities to Asia, where equal quality can be achieved at lower costs. It is obvious that the proposed measures will not help the Recovery of the Swedish Economy or keep production in the Member States of the European Union. In order to achieve this, it is necessary to create favourable conditions for retaining and attracting large producers in the European Union, which can be achieved by cutting red tape and lowering taxes.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 Proposal to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: I supported the egf/2016/002 application SE/Ericsson. On 5 September 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Sweden in order to support the reintegration of workers made redundant by Telefonaktiebolaaget LM Ericsson, which operates in the sectors classified in NACE Revision 2 Section 26 (Manufacture of computers, electronic and optical products). Ericsson still employs in Europe, but only people with completely different skills, and workers with knowledge in hardware manufacturing and development are generally not re-employed by the company.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, in this case in Sweden, for workers affected by the relocation of the Ericsson Company that has been gradually moving its production to Asia, leading to a reduction in staff at its plants in Sweden. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. On the other hand, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This is a request from Sweden to seek assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of 4 million euros to deal with more than 1,500 layoffs in its telephone sector with a view to their reintegration into the labour market.  Ericsson has cut positions in its telecommunications equipment production sector to relocate this business directly or indirectly to Asia (especially India) in order to reduce costs and face ever-increasing global competition. If these aids are to be voted on for laid-off workers, this must not overshadow the responsibility of EU policies and unfair global competition driven by an irrational rejection of intelligent protectionism.  I'm voting for.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument to offset the negative effects of mass redundancies, which are the repercussions of global changes in the labour market and trade. Sweden is applying for support from the Fund after the dismissal of 1 556 employees at Ericsson. The main reason for the redundancies is the partial or complete closure of wireless telecommunications equipment production lines at various plants throughout Sweden. Measures co-financed by the EGF will provide 918 workers with advice, sheltered and supported employment measures, as well as education and training allowances for jobseekers.  Policies that promote growth and employment deserve support. In general, however, I am sceptical about whether the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund mechanism is indeed a tool that can effectively help redundant workers to integrate into the labour market. I believe that each situation requires an individual and careful assessment. The mobilisation of funds from the Fund on this particular issue is, in my opinion, justified, which is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the proposal gives the green light for the application of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in several regions of Sweden. The fund would provide €3,957,918 for the management of Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson's wave of redundancies affecting 1,556 people and the integration of the unemployed into the labour market. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report, as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and aid to young people without education or employment, in this case in Sweden, for workers affected by the relocation of the Ericsson Company that has been gradually moving its production to Asia, leading to a reduction in staff at its plants in Sweden. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. On the other hand, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Finland's (Microsoft) application and Sweden's (Ericsson) application because I agree with the use of the funds for both cases.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – Many of the redundant management staff are engineers, some of whom are specialised only in ericsson-specific unique areas, but I welcome the confidence of the Swedish Public Employment Service that a package of individualised curricula and coaching will help many of these redundant workers find new quality jobs.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was introduced in 2007 as a flexible instrument wherein the Union budget supports, under specific conditions, those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in the patterns of world trade, caused by globalisation or the globalized economic and financial crisis. Through this report, the European Parliament supports the Commission's proposal to give Sweden EUR 3.9 million to help 918 former employees of several Ericsson production plants find new jobs. Under the firm conviction that the Union's commitment to unemployment citizens must materialise in concrete actions, I supported this decision with my vote.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. Sweden requested assistance from the EGF following the dismissal of 1,556 Ericsson workers. Although European aid does not guarantee continuity of employment in a sector very exposed to international competition, they do mean an improvement in the situation of dismissed workers, so I voted in favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. \u2012 On 31 March 2016, Sweden submitted an application to appeal to the EGF following redundancies at Ericsson (Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson) in Sweden. The funds they request from the EGF is EUR 3 957 918, which will help 918 individual beneficiaries to return to the labour market. I agreed with this report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Ericsson laid off 1,244 Swedish workers between September 2015 and January 2016. And the company has just announced the dismissal of 3,000 to 4000 additional workers in Sweden once again. At the same time, for several years now, the company has been recruiting at low cost in Asian countries. All is well for the multinational: its net profit is 1.6 billion euros in 2015 and the dividends paid to shareholders are constantly increasing (up 23% between 2013 and 2016) despite the "terrible" situation of Ericsson that we portray the specialized media. Clearly, Ericsson is not bankrupt and the current layoffs are just responding to a logic of offshoring jobs to Asia. Ericsson has the means to finance the social consequences of his policies. It would be enough to pay a little less dividends. It is not for the European budget to finance "these policies of adjustment to globalisation" even if that is the name of this fund because, for me, it actually encourages relocations. So I voted against this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This request relates to 1 556 workers made redundant, all Ericsson employees in Sweden, due to the closure of its hardware production unit for wireless communication. There are 5 of the most affected regions: Stockholm, Östra Mellansverige, Sydsverige and Västsverige, and with the majority of redundancies in the Kista area (762 workers made redundant). Ericsson has shifted most of its hardware production and development to Asia (mostly to India), from 56,000 employees in 2005 to more than 118,000 in 2014 globally. This means that while doubling global recruitment, it has gradually been reducing it in Sweden (from 21,178 in 2005 to 17,858 in 2014). This situation is intolerable and deserves our full repudiation. Our favourable vote stems from respect and understanding of the difficult situation of the workers affected. Our fight is against this Bedouin capitalism, demanding firm measures against these practices.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to support workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. Specifically, this proposal concerns the mobilisation of this fund for the benefit of workers in Sweden who have been made redundant by the LM Ericsson telephone stock. I think these measures are useful and I have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ This is an instrument which successive UK governments either chose not to use, but which could have in the past supported British communities. It is an important expression of common European solidarity.  Far from the false Euro-sceptic myth that ‘the EU pays to close factories’, these funds help workers retrain and stops communities from being torn apart.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been set up to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns. This application concerns 918 of 1,556 workers laid off in the period from 11 September 2015 to 11 January 2016.  Ericsson operates mainly in the economic sectors of manufacturing computer, electronic and optical products and programming, consulting and other it-related activities. Ericsson's layoffs are mainly found in the Stockholm and Estra Mellansverige regions of Sydsverige and the V.Stsverige. The report notes that Ericsson is experiencing a stagnation in growth and competition with Asian producers. The Commission is asked to detail, in future proposals, the sectors in which workers are likely to find employment and whether the offer of training aligns with future economic prospects and market needs. My vote is in favour of this report, as we must protect the areas most affected by re-industrialisation in order to go forward and be able to adapt to the new economic needs.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 In March, Sweden submitted an application to mobilise the EGF in relation to redundancies at Ericsson. The events behind the just under a thousand redundancies are the partial or total closure of wireless telecommunications hardware production lines at various Ericsson sites in Sweden, as well as the closure of an entire plant in Katrineholm.  Faced simultaneously with stagnant growth and tighter competition with Asian manufacturers, Ericsson has gradually reduced the production of telecommunications hardware in a process that began almost twenty years ago. In 2012, the company also sold its entire mobile phone development and production line to competitor Sony, which decided to concentrate its production lines mainly in Asia.  The financial contribution requested under the EGF for this proposal is just under EUR 4 million. I am generally in favour of mobilising this fund, although I am aware that this is probably not the instrument that best can help redundant workers, but in the absence of viable alternatives I nevertheless believe that it should be supported; For this reason, I voted in favour.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: Written. \u2012 The PVV voted against the mobilisation of these funds. The demands of the European Fund (redundancies must arise from the global crisis and caused by globalisation) are not met.  The fund only facilitates, with the allocation of 6,958 mln. an international company such as Ericsson when jobs are cut in a Member State of the European Union. This has been demonstrated once again as Ericsson has announced that it will stop all production in Sweden and lay off another 3 000 people. There is no doubt that another grant application will be submitted.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 As with Finland's application for Microsoft, I did not give my vote to the report in the case of Sweden's request to mobilise the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Ericsson has laid off 1,556 employees and Sweden, with the help of the required UER 3.9 million from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, wants to help these laid-off employees either get a new job or help start a business. The planned tools are mainly training courses, trainings, career guidance or job search allowances. However, I believe that there is insufficient data in relation to the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to demonstrate its added value. All available data show that the rate of re-employment of redundant workers varies greatly from country to country and, of course, their successful re-employment depends on their education, skills and the possibilities of the region, rather than the training provided with the help of this fund. For this reason, I believe that the existence of the fund as such would need to be assessed much more thoroughly than has been the case up to now, and only on the basis of such an assessment to decide whether these funds cannot be used in a better and more efficient way, which would not only help the employees made redundant, but at the same time not only apply to large companies, but would also help the employees of small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), which will provide financial assistance to laid-off workers from Ericsson in Sweden. Assistance to be co-financed by the EGF comprises: advice and career guidance; protected and supportive employment and rehabilitation measures, education and training and job-seeking allowance.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Deputy Public Prosecutor at the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic has asked for the waiver of Mr Syps' parliamentary immunity. Giorgos Grammatikakis in connection with the prosecution of an alleged crime. Since the prosecution does not concern opinions or votes cast in the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of ending this lengthy judicial process.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – The Greek authorities are proposing to prosecute Giorgos Grammatikakis, in conjunction with others, for failing to comply with certain legal obligations. The proposed proceedings concern a discussion held on 8 March 1996 on the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance policy – in addition to the compulsory insurance policy – for all employees of the University of Crete and allegedly unlawful payments being made in successive instalments over the period 2000-2002.  A previous proceeding on the same case covered the period from 2000 onwards and resulted in the acquittal of all the accused.  UKIP would vote to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, as requested by Giorgos Grammatikakis himself in order to put an end to this long judicial process.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The request for suspension of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Giorgos Grammatikakis has been requested by the Greek judicial authorities for events that occurred in 1996, when he was rector of the University of Crete, the nature there is an accusation of illegal payments by the university to private insurance , has made me vote in favour of the pleading to suspend this MEP's immunity so that the judicial procedure can take its course in Greece.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mr Grammatikakis' immunity.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Mr Giorgos Grammatikakis, a Greek member of Parliament from the S and D group, himself is calling for his immunity to be lifted. So I voted for it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This vote is not a roll-call vote, and therefore in the interests of democracy and transparency I would like to confirm that I voted in favour of this resolution. I note that Mr Grammatikakis also is content with this decision.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammar. The Deputy Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic referred a request for waiver of the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, which relates to the procedure intended by the Prosecutor of The Rethymno to initiate an abuse of trust in the performance of his duties, a criminal act committed with others in Rethymno (Crete) between 2000 and 2002. Since the process to be initiated is clearly unrelated to the status of Giorgos Grammatikakis as a Member of the European Parliament, as it relates to his previous duties as rector of the Senate of the University of Crete, I therefore support the waiver of giorgos grammatical immunity, as requested by Giorgos Grammatical, himself, in order to complete this lengthy judicial process.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ The Greek authorities are proposing to prosecute Giorgos Grammatikakis, in conjunction with others, for failing to comply with certain legal obligations. The proposed proceedings concern a discussion held on 8 March 1996 on the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance policy – in addition to the compulsory insurance policy – for all employees of the University of Crete and allegedly unlawful payments being made in successive instalments over the period 2000-2002. A previous proceeding on the same case covered the period from 2000 onwards and resulted in the acquittal of all the accused. UKIP would vote to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, as requested by Giorgos Grammatikakis himself, in order to put an end to this long judicial process.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Giorgos Grammatikakis himself has asked for the lifting of his immunity in order to put an end to this long judicial process, motivated by illegal payments he allegedly made twenty years ago when he was rector of the council of the University of Crete. Furthermore, there is no indication that the underlying intent of the proposed prosecution is to politically harm the MEP concerned. I am therefore in favour of the lifting of his parliamentary immunity.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of Mr Grammatikakis' immunity so that all the light could be shed in this matter.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I voted in favour of the request for waiver of mr Giorgos Grammatikakis' immunity. The request was supported by the Same Member to put an end to a lengthy judicial process linked to the prosecution of an alleged crime that would have been committed in the period 1996-2000, when Giorgos Grammatikakis was rector of the University of Crete and did not hold the role of Member of the European Parliament.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I supported the request for the lifting of immunity by my colleague in the Committee on Culture, Giorgos Grammatikakis, who himself requested it in order to put an end to a long legal process as soon as possible. He is suspected of being involved in an illegal payments case while he was rector of the council of the University of Crete. There is therefore no connection with his work as a Member of the European Parliament, or even with opinions or votes cast in this institution. Moreover, it does not appear that the prosecution of him is motivated by an intention to harm him politically. There was therefore no objection to the lifting of his immunity.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I took part in the vote on the Marinho and Pinto report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, bearing in mind that the person concerned himself has requested it and in the light of the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs, which states that the proposed procedure is not manifestly related to the status of Member of the European Parliament of Giorgos Grammatikakis, since it refers to his previous post as rector of the Cloister of the University of Crete.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the request to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, a Member of the European Parliament, in connection with the proceedings concerning suspicion of a criminal offence. This process, which is to be initiated, is clearly unrelated to the status of Giorgos Grammatical As a Member of the European Parliament, as it relates to his previous duties as rector of the Senate of the University of Crete. This process is extended to include the period 1996-2000, which includes the last senate hearing of the University of Crete, in which Giorgos Grammatikakis was also present as rector and where the matter was discussed, but no decision was taken. Moreover, there is no indication that the process initiated is intended to cause political harm to the MEP concerned. Parliament is surprised that immunity is being requested to be waived after about 20 years of respective events and that the Greek justice system has failed to initiate proceedings against Giorgos Grammar during this period and intends to do so now that he has become a Member of the European Parliament. It should be noted that a justice system that is so slow will never be truly right, because the individuals concerned are no longer the same as they were 20 years ago; whereas justice must be carried out in a timely manner in order for justice to justify its name. Thus, the European Parliament decides to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammatics, as requested by Giorgos Grammatikakis himself, in order to complete this lengthy judicial process.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support the lifting of Giorgos Grammatikakis' parliamentary immunity.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report relates to the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, suspected of having made illegal payments when he was rector of the council of the University of Crete. On the one hand, the prosecution of Giorgos Grammatikakis clearly has no connection with his status as an MEP, as they are linked to his previous mandate as rector of the Council of the University of Crete. On the other hand, these proceedings also do not concern an opinion or vote issued by the Member in the performance of his duties, within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. Furthermore, there is no indication that the intent underlying the prosecution is to politically harm the MEP concerned. That is why I have spoken in favour of the request to waive his parliamentary immunity.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this waiver. The case relates to accusations about an event that occurred 20 years ago and the MEP in question does not dispute the waiver. Since the MEP is in favour of this case being taken to court so the full details can be set out, I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for waiver of the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis. The same, well before becoming an MEP, had been involved in student demonstrations for which a trial had been opened which ended with the acquittal of all the defendants. He himself wants his immunity waived so that the trial, which had been blocked against him, can be completed.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the request for the waiver of my colleague's immunity.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Giorgos Grammatiakis. Since the Member himself has stressed that he wishes the proceedings to be completed unhindered in order to demonstrate his innocence, which I firmly believe in, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure given the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, transmitted on 1 April 2016 by the Deputy Prosecutor to the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic in relation to the action proposed by the Public Prosecutor of Rethymnos, for the offence of abuse of confidence in the performance of his duties, committed in competition with others in Rethymnos, Crete, in the period 2000-2002. The proposed action relates to a discussion held on 8 March 1996 on the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance policy, in addition to the compulsory insurance policy, for all employees of the University of Crete, as well as alleged unlawful payments made in succession during the period 2000-2002. The proposed action is clearly irreparable to Giorgos Grammatikakis' status as a Member of the European Parliament, as it refers to his previous position as President of the Academic Senate of the University of Crete.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Mr Grammatikakis, which was requested by the same Member, so that the judicial process in which he has been involved for a long time can be brought to an end.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Rules on waiver of immunity need to be applied consistently and with clarity. Although it is regretful that the waiver of immunity is being requested some 20 years after the events have occurred and the Greek justice system was not able to bring proceedings against Giorgos Grammatikakis during this period and intends to do so now while he is a Member of the European Parliament, the circumstances for waiver do fulfil the established criteria.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The request for suspension of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Giorgos Grammatikakis has been requested by the Greek judicial authorities for events that occurred in 1996, when he was rector of the University of Crete, the nature there is an accusation of illegal payments by the university to private insurance , has made me vote in favour of the pleading to suspend this MEP's immunity so that the judicial procedure can take its course in Greece.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the request to waive the immunity of Mr Giorgos Grammatikakis, against whom legal proceedings are pending. The proceedings concern a meeting in which there was talk of the possibility of concluding a private insurance policy for all employees of the University of Crete, of which Mr Grammatikakis was rector. Mr. Giorgos Grammatikakis himself agreed to waive his immunity in order not to make legal proceedings difficult.
