In view of the fact that I believe that every MEP should be a righteous person, setting an example to the citizens of the European Union, I voted in favour of the waiver of mr Grammatikakis' immunity.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the waiver of the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, as in this way he will be better able to prove his innocence or otherwise.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. U2012 The pleading for suspension of Giorgos Grammatikakis' immunity, it is in relation to the procedure proposed by the Prosecutor of Rethymnon for an abuse of confidence in the performance of his duties, committed jointly in Rethymnon, Crete, during the period 2000 and communicated to the plenary session of 27 April 2016, Parliament, showing its surprise at the fact that the suspension of immunity is requested some twenty years after the events and , that the Greek judicial system has not been able to act against Giorgos Grammatikakis during this period and intends to do so now, when he is a Member of the European Parliament and considering that a judicial system acting slowly will never really be fair, because the people involved are no longer the same as they were twenty years ago, decides to suspend the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis , at the request of the person concerned himself, with a view to ending this lengthy judicial procedure.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, member of the European Parliament, in the context of a legal action brought for an alleged offence. The case took place more than 20 years ago and the Greek courts were unable to bring proceedings against the Member and is therefore not related to the status of a Member of the European Parliament. I agree with the waiver of parliamentary immunity, once it has the agreement of the Member himself.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: Giorgos Grammatikakis' lifting of parliamentary immunity is motivated by illegal payments he allegedly made 20 years ago when he was rector of the council of the University of Crete. Giorgos Grammatikakis himself has asked for the lifting of his immunity in order to put an end to this long judicial process. There is no indication that the intention behind the proposed prosecution is to politically harm the MEP concerned.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Grammatikakis in the context of a legal action brought for an alleged offence relating to the non-compliance with certain legal obligations.  The case at issue concerns the discussion, which dates back to 1996, on the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance contract, in addition to the compulsory insurance contract, for all workers of the University of Crete and the making of allegedly illegal payments in successive instalments during the period 2000-2002.  The case is in no way related to the status of a Member of the European Parliament, since it concerns the functions that this Member had previously as Rector of the Senate of the University of Crete. This procedure is not considered to be intended to cause political harm to the Member concerned.  The case in question was filed for other defendants due to the 15-year limitation period for the alleged crimes, while others were definitively acquitted of all charges by the Court. The waiver of immunity is entirely justified. We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed proceedings are clearly unrelated to Giorgos Grammatikakis’s status as a Member of the European Parliament, given that they relate to his former position as Rector of the Senate of the University of Crete. I voted in favour of the request to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, as requested by Giorgos Grammatikakis himself in order to put an end to this long judicial process.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ The Greek authorities are proposing to prosecute Giorgos Grammatikakis, in conjunction with others, for failing to comply with certain legal obligations. The proposed proceedings concern a discussion held on 8 March 1996 on the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance policy – in addition to the compulsory insurance policy – for all employees of the University of Crete and allegedly unlawful payments being made in successive instalments over the period 2000-2002. A previous proceeding on the same case covered the period from 2000 onwards and resulted in the acquittal of all the accused. UKIP would vote to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, as requested by Giorgos Grammatikakis himself, in order to put an end to this long judicial process.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. To the extent that this waiver of immunity is granted by Mp Grammatikakis himself, it made sense to accede to his request and vote in favour of this report. On the other hand, this is a matter unrelated to the exercise of the Member's mandate, since the alleged events occurred in the course of his former professional activity. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this request as I support the reasons of the proposal to waive the immunity.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift Giorgos Grammatikakis' immunity, as this will resolve a lengthy court case. The application for waiver of immunity was submitted after 20 years, indicating a lack of efficiency in judicial justice systems.  Therefore, I believe that Mr Grammatikakis will have the opportunity to prove before the court his arguments concerning the alleged offence of failing to fulfil certain legal obligations.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The illegal activities of MP Giorgos Grammatikakis can only lead to the lifting of his parliamentary immunity. There is no reason to believe that these prosecutions are politically detrimental to the Member, either in terms of his status or his activities as a parliamentarian, since they relate to events that occurred before his election. So I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – The Greek authorities are proposing to prosecute Giorgos Grammatikakis, in conjunction with others, for failing to comply with certain legal obligations. The proposed proceedings concern a discussion held on 8 March 1996 on the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance policy – in addition to the compulsory insurance policy – for all employees of the University of Crete and allegedly unlawful payments being made in successive instalments over the period 2000-2002. A previous proceeding on the same case covered the period from 2000 onwards and resulted in the acquittal of all the accused. UKIP would vote to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, as requested by Giorgos Grammatikakis himself, in order to put an end to this long judicial process.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the decision on Giorgos Grammatikakis' request to waive parliamentary immunity. This procedure is a formality which, without deciding on the merits of the case, is intended to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work.  I am pleased that this report has been adopted by a large majority.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting against this report. On the basis of the facts, the lifting of immunity is, in my view, unjustified and would have a major impact on Mr Grammatikakis' parliamentary work.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons of the proposal to waive the immunity.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted to lift Mr Grammatikakis' immunity because he himself is asking for the lifting of his immunity.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted to lift Giorgos Grammatikakis' parliamentary immunity, simply because it is requested by the person himself. This is a matter that has nothing to do with his mandate in the European Parliament.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The lifting of Giorgos Grammatikakis' parliamentary immunity is motivated by illegal payments he allegedly made 20 years ago when he was rector of the council of the University of Crete. He himself asked for the lifting of his immunity in order to put an end to this long judicial process. The proposed prosecution clearly has no connection with Giorgos Grammatikakis' status as an MEP, as it is linked to his previous tenure as rector of university council. Furthermore, there is no indication that the underlying intent of the proposed prosecution is to politically harm the MEP concerned. So I voted for the application.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The request for suspension of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Giorgos Grammatikakis has been requested by the Greek judicial authorities for events that occurred in 1996, when he was rector of the University of Crete, the nature there is an accusation of illegal payments by the university to private insurance , has made me vote in favour of the pleading to suspend this MEP's immunity so that the judicial procedure can take its course in Greece.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiver of Mr Grammatictis' immunity, he himself asked for it. This is a 20-year-old case concerning the payment of employees' pension insurance. Let the Greek courts handle this.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ A request to lift mp Giorgus Grammatikakis' parliamentary immunity was submitted by prosecutors of the Greek Supreme Court, for misconduct in 2000-2002. The prosecutor submitted this request so that the mp could be tried on abuse of office, due to decisions made at the University Senate during his time as rector of the university.  Although Parliament is surprised by the Greek judiciary's decision to prosecute alleged events after 20 years, it grants a request to lift parliamentary immunity at the request of MP Grammatikakis, so that this judicial process can be accessed. Because of all of the above, I supported this report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Prosecutor of the Hellenic Republic has requested that the immunity of Greek MEP Giorgos Grammatikakis be waived in connection with the investigation into his actions in March 1996, when he was an employee of the University of Crete. The proceedings concern alleged unlawful payments made between 2000 and 2002. The Member himself requested the waiver of immunity, as the case is not being investigated by the authorities concerned in 20 years' time. The whole procedure is in line with Protocol No 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union, which is why I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammatiakis following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. Giorgos Grammatikakis himself has called for the lifting of his parliamentary immunity to end the judicial process, the result of illegal payments he allegedly made 20 years ago as rector of the council of the University of Crete. The prosecutions clearly have no connection to the status of a Member of the European Parliament. Furthermore, they do not concern cases under Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union (notice or vote issued in the performance of parliamentary functions). Finally, there is no reason to believe that these prosecutions were initiated in order to politically harm Mr Grammatikakis.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This motion deals with the waiver of the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis. Apparently, it took the Greek legal system about twenty years to initiate proceedings. I therefore reject the motion.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the European Parliament's proposal to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammar, as requested by the European Parliament itself, in order to speed up the completion of the lengthy judicial process.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report calls for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Greek MP Giorgos Grammatikakis. The request follows the request of the Assistant Prosecutor to the Greek Supreme Court.  The alleged offence relates to a discussion that took place on 8 March 1996 on the possibility of concluding a new group private insurance policy for all employees of the University of Crete and on alleged illegal payments made in successive installments over the period 2000-2002.  The offence is therefore unrelated to his mandate as an MP. Furthermore, since the prosecutions do not concern an opinion or vote cast by the Member in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union, I vote for the lifting of immunity.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The lifting of Giorgos Grammatikakis' parliamentary immunity is motivated by illegal payments he allegedly made 20 years ago when he was rector of the council of the University of Crete. He himself asked for the lifting of his immunity in order to put an end to this long judicial process. The proposed proceedings clearly have no connection to Giorgos Grammatikakis' status as an MEP, as they are related to his previous tenure as rector of a university council. Furthermore, there is no indication that the intention underlying the proposed proceedings is to politically harm the MEP concerned. So I voted for the application.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties.  The Central District Court of Pest has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of a Member of the European Parliament, Giorgos Grammatikakis. The Deputy Prosecutor in the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, as part of a lawsuit brought for an alleged offence.  The case at issue concerns the discussion on 8 March 1996 of the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance contract, in addition to the compulsory insurance contract, for all workers of the University of Crete and the making of allegedly illegal payments in successive instalments during the period 2000-2002.  The case in question is not related to the status of deputy, since it relates to his previous duties as Rector of the Senate of the University of Crete.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The Deputy Prosecutor at the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic has filed an application to lift parliamentary immunity against Mr Giorgos Grammatikakis, currently a Member of the European Parliament, for breach of trust in the performance of his duties. Since the alleged offence at the origin of the prosecution is linked to the previous mandate of Mr Giorgos Grammatikakis, when he was rector of the Council of the University of Crete, the proceedings under consideration do not concern an opinion or vote issued by the Member in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. That is why I voted in favour of lifting giorgos Grammatikakis' parliamentary immunity.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request for the waiver of the immunity of MEP Giorgos Grammatikakis since he asked to proceed himself in order to put an end to the long judicial process.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 On 1 April 2016, the Deputy Attorney General of the Hellenic Republic requested the waiver of the immunity of MEP Giorgos Grammatikakis in connection with a procedure proposed by the Public Prosecutor's Office of the City of Retimno in the course of his duties in the period 2000-2002. The Committee on Legal Affairs notes in its report that the proposed judicial procedure is clearly not related to the position of Mep Giorgos Grammatikakis, but to his previous position as Rector of the Senate of the University of Crete, and there is no indication that it was initiated with a view to causing political damage to that Member. It therefore proposes to Parliament, in accordance with the request of the Grammatikakis Member concerned, that immunity be suspended. However, the report states that the proposed court proceedings related to a meeting held on 8 March 1996 and that a previous court case in relation to the same case had already dealt with the period from 2000 onwards and that it resulted in the acquittal of all the defendants. It also expresses its disquiet at the fact that the suspension of immunity is requested 20 years after the events have taken place and that the Greek judicial system has not prosecuted Giorgos Grammatikakis during that period, and intends to do so only now, during his time as a Member of the European Parliament. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The lifting of Giorgos Grammatikakis' parliamentary immunity is motivated by illegal payments he allegedly made 20 years ago when he was rector of the council of the University of Crete. He himself asked for the lifting of his immunity in order to put an end to this long judicial process. The proposed prosecution clearly has no connection with Giorgos Grammatikakis' status as an MEP, as it is linked to his previous term as rector of the Council of the University of Crete. It does not concern an opinion or vote issued by the Member in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. Furthermore, there is no indication that the intention underlying the proposed prosecution is to politically harm the MEP concerned. Vote in favour.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, after all the legal procedures required have elapsed, because the offence in question is not in any way related to the performance of the duties of the Member and, finally, because that is the will of the Member himself.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This vote concerns the lifting of the immunity of MP Giorgos Grammatikakis, suspected of illegal payments made 20 years ago when he was rector of the council of the University of Crete. Since the Member himself has requested the lifting of his immunity and the prosecution is unrelated to his political or parliamentary activity, I have decided to vote in.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the lifting of Mr Grammatikakis' parliamentary immunity. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State, or by a Member himself, to lift parliamentary immunity is heard by a committee of the European Parliament. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of parliamentary immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report according to the evaluation made by the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI).

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I spoke out against the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, since the prosecution envisaged is obviously not related to the status of Giorgos Grammatikakis as a member of the European Parliament, but relates to his former position as Rector of the Senate of the University of Crete.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the waiver of the immunity of my fellow MEP, Giorgos Grammatikakis, in accordance with his own wishes, so that he could go to court and put an end to the case. I am sure of Mr Grammatikaki's acquittal as his alleged "offence" refers to a meeting of the Senate of the University of Crete, which was the last of his long tenure as Rector of the Foundation (1990-1996). The "offence" charged against him was committed 20 years ago! Two hundred or more of his colleagues were also prosecuted in this case, who were formally acquitted in 2004 and 2016 by the Greek Courts.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ The Greek authorities are proposing to prosecute Giorgos Grammatikakis, in conjunction with others, for failing to comply with certain legal obligations. The proposed proceedings concern a discussion held on 8 March 1996 on the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance policy – in addition to the compulsory insurance policy – for all employees of the University of Crete and allegedly unlawful payments being made in successive instalments over the period 2000-2002. A previous proceeding on the same case covered the period from 2000 onwards and resulted in the acquittal of all the accused. UKIP would vote to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, as requested by Giorgos Grammatikakis himself, in order to put an end to this long judicial process.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the request for waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, considering that the Member has waived his right to be heard, in accordance with Rule 9(5) of the Rules of Procedure and in view of previous rulings by the Court of Justice of the European Union, I decide to follow my group's line. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The lifting of Giorgos Grammatikakis' parliamentary immunity is motivated by illegal payments he allegedly made 20 years ago when he was rector of the council of the University of Crete. The proposed prosecution clearly has no connection with Mr Grammatikakis' status as an MEP. It does not concern an opinion or vote issued by the Member in the course of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. Furthermore, there is no indication that the underlying intent of the proposed prosecution is to politically harm the MEP concerned. Finally, Mr. Grammatikakis himself asked for the lifting of his immunity in order to put an end to this long judicial process. In these circumstances, I vote for the report calling for the lifting of immunity.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The application for waiver of immunity was forwarded on 1 April 2016 by the Deputy Attorney General of the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic in connection with the proposed procedure for abuse of trust, together with other persons, in the performance of his duties in Rethimno (Crete) between 2000 and 2002. The rapporteur expresses surprise that the application for waiver of immunity has been submitted now, after twenty years, and because the Greek justice system could not initiate proceedings in the meantime. Since the proceedings were initiated at the initiative of my colleague Grammatikakis, I support the decision to lift immunity. The proposed initiation of proceedings is not related to the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament, but to the previous function of rector of the Senate of the University of Crete.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns a request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Grammatikakis in the context of a legal action brought for an alleged offence relating to the non-compliance with certain legal obligations. The case at issue concerns the discussion on 8 March 1996 of the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance contract, in addition to the compulsory insurance contract, for all workers of the University of Crete and the making of allegedly illegal payments in successive instalments during the period 2000-2002. The case concerns the functions he previously held as Rector of the Senate of the University of Crete, so it has no relation to the status of a Member of the European Parliament. This process is not considered to be politically motivated and we voted in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ The Greek authorities are proposing to prosecute Giorgos Grammatikakis, in conjunction with others, for failing to comply with certain legal obligations. The proposed proceedings concern a discussion held on 8 March 1996 on the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance policy – in addition to the compulsory insurance policy – for all employees of the University of Crete and allegedly unlawful payments being made in successive instalments over the period 2000-2002. A previous proceeding on the same case covered the period from 2000 onwards and resulted in the acquittal of all the accused. UKIP would vote to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, as requested by Giorgos Grammatikakis himself, in order to put an end to this long judicial process.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Deputy Prosecutor at the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, a Member of the European Parliament, as part of the initiation of an investigation procedure relating to an alleged offence.  The action brought relates to the abuse of trust in the exercise of his duties, as Rector of the Senate of the University of Crete, practiced with the participation of others, during the period 2000-2002.  The case at issue concerns the discussion on 8 March 1996 of the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance contract, in addition to the compulsory insurance contract, for all workers of the University of Crete and the making of allegedly illegal payments in successive instalments during the period 2000-2002. In view of the fact that the judicial procedure does not concern opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that there is no reason to suppose that the intention underlying the legal action is to undermine the political activity of the Member, this request, which I voted in favour of, decides to lift immunity from Mr Grammatikakis.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The procedure for withpdoning the parliamentary immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, requested by himself, is not related to his activity as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, taking into account that the person concerned himself has requested it, and in the light of the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs, which states that the proposed procedure is not manifestly related to the status of Member of the European Parliament of Giorgos Grammatikakis, since it refers to his previous post as rector of the Cloister of the University of Crete.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of the immunity of Mr Giorgos Grammatikakis, which is done at his request, so that the Greek justice system can carry out its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, and finally to put an end to a judicial process concerning alleged illegal payments made during the period 2000-2002.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request to waive the immunity of Giorgos Grammatics. The Greek authorities are seeking to bring Giorgos Grammatikakis, together with others, liable for non-compliance with certain legal obligations. The accusations are clearly unrelated to the status of Giorgos Grammatical As a Member of the European Parliament. They relate to the activities previously carried out by the said Member of Parliament when he served as rector of the Senate of the University of Crete. However, it is astonishing for Members that immunity is being requested to be waived after about 20 years of respective events and that the Greek justice system has failed to initiate proceedings against Giorgos Grammar earlier during this period. It is clear that such a delay is not acceptable.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Grammatikakis. This is a request made by the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic on 1 April 2016 and relates to a legal action brought for an alleged offence. Since this is alleged conduct carried out outside his mandate as an MEP (relating to his previous duties as Rector of the Senate of the University of Crete) and there is no reason to believe that there are intentions underlying the legal action to undermine his political activity, I voted in favour of this request for waiver of parliamentary immunity , as was expressed by the colleague concerned, who said he wanted to see this long judicial process ended.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The request for suspension of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Giorgos Grammatikakis has been requested by the Greek judicial authorities for events that occurred in 1996, when he was rector of the University of Crete, the nature there is an accusation of illegal payments by the university to private insurance , has made me vote in favour of the pleading to suspend this MEP's immunity so that the judicial procedure can take its course in Greece.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of proposal as I do not believe it is right for him to have his immunity in this matter.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution to waive the parliamentary immunity of MEP Giorgos Grammatikakis. The Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic has requested that the appointed Member be waived of parliamentary immunity in connection with proceedings relating to an alleged offence. The misdemeanor relates to a discussion that took place on 8 March 1996 on the possible conclusion of a new private collective insurance – beyond compulsory – for all employees of the University of Crete, where The Member Giorgos Grammatikakis was chairman of the Senate of the University of Crete at the time. Given that the request for waiver of immunity is made 20 years after the events occurred and that the Greek judiciary was unable to initiate proceedings against Giorgos Grammatikakis, the Member himself asked the European Parliament to waive immunity at his own request in order to put an end to this lengthy trial. This was also the reason why Parliament granted the request to waive parliamentary immunity.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Any suspected criminal activity involving Members of the European Parliament must be properly investigated. I appreciate that my colleague Grammatikakis has decided to ask the European Parliament to waive his immunity himself, thus contributing to the swift termination of the trial, which has been dragging on for several years.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the request for the waiver of the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis. The person concerned made the request himself in order to finally get the matter hovering above him off the table.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Members of the European Parliament in the territory of their own Member State enjoy immunity equivalent to the immunity granted to members of parliament of that Country. In the case of Greece, a Member shall not be prosecuted, arrested or detained or subject to any other measures to restrict freedom without prior parliamentary approval, as long as his or her term of office persists. The Greek judicial authorities are proposing criminal proceedings against Giorgos Grammatikakis for abuse of trust.  I support the report on the application for waiver of giorgos Grammatikakis' immunity, at his own request, requested by the Attorney General of the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic, in order to end this lengthy court case for the alleged crime committed.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the request of the Greek authorities to waive the immunity of Mr G. Grammatikakis, which he himself asked for, in order to help the justice system complete its work.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I have accepted the lifting of my colleague's immunity so that he can defend himself in the courts of his country.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of waving the immunity of Member of Parliament Giorgos Grammatikakis, as requested by the Greek authorities as well as by Giorgos Grammatikakis himself, for failing to comply with certain legal obligations. The charges facing Grammatikakis concern a discussion held on 8 March 1996 on the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance policy – in addition to the compulsory insurance policy – for all employees of the University of Crete and allegedly unlawful payments being made in successive instalments over the period 2000-2002. Because the proposed proceedings are clearly unrelated to Giorgos Grammatikakis’s status as a Member of the European Parliament, given that they relate to his former position as Rector of the Senate of the University of Crete, he should therefore not be granted the immunity provided by his current position, but be prosecuted in his former capacity in order to end this long judicial process.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the request for the waiver of the immunity of Representative Giorgos Grammatikakis in connection with his alleged violations at a meeting of the Council of the University of Crete on March 8, 1996, when Representative Grammatikakis was rector of that university. The discussion during the meeting relates to the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance policy, in addition to the mandatory insurance policy, for all employees of the University of Crete and allegedly illegal payments during the period from 2000 to 2002. Since it can be concluded from the above that the proceedings against Grammatikakis are not related to his position as a Member of the European Parliament but to his position as rector of the Council of the University of Crete, which Grammatikakis himself has also confirmed, I believe that he can be deprived of his immunity provided that he is provided with a fair and impartial trial.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a decision on the request for waiver of the immunity of Jorgos Gramatikakis. In the case of the court before the Supreme Court, he is accused of an abuse of trust in the performance of his duties and in the light of the fact that Jorgos Gramatikakis waived his right to plead defence in accordance with Article 9(5) of the Rules of Procedure and in view of the fact that he himself had requested the waiver of immunity in order to close lengthy legal proceedings.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The lifting of Giorgos Grammatikakis' parliamentary immunity is motivated by illegal payments he allegedly made 20 years ago when he was rector of the council of the University of Crete. He himself asked for the lifting of his immunity in order to put an end to this long judicial process. The proposed proceedings clearly have no connection to Giorgos Grammatikakis' status as an MEP, as they are related to his previous term as rector of the Council of the University of Crete. They do not concern an opinion or vote issued by the Member in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. Furthermore, there is no indication that the intention underlying the proposed proceedings is to politically harm the MEP concerned. I voted for it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Greek prosecutor requested that Giorgos Grammatikakis' immunity be waived in connection with the ongoing proceedings in the country. The allegations made against the Member relate to the actions of the University of Cretan initiated by the meeting of the University Senate in 1996. Giorgos Grammatikakis served as rector of the university at the time, while he has only served as a Member of the European Parliament since 2014. It follows clearly that the ongoing proceedings in the main proceedings are not directly linked to the performance by Giorgos Grammatikakis of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. He also acknowledged that his immunity should be waived in order not to hamper the course of legal proceedings. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The rapporteur proposes to waive immunity. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis. The request for waiver of the immunity of Giorgos Grammatikakis, forwarded on 1 April 2016 by the Deputy Prosecutor at the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic, concerns proceedings proposed by the Rethymno Public Prosecutor for breach of trust in the performance of his duties, committed in conjunction with others, at Rethymno, Crete, over the period 2000-2002. The proposed proceedings are clearly unrelated to Giorgos Grammatikakis’s status as a Member of the European Parliament, given that they relate to his former position as Rector of the Senate of the University of Crete. I voted in favour because I believe that the proposed proceedings do not concern opinions expressed or votes cast in the performance of the duties of the Member of the European Parliament in question within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The request for suspension of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Giorgos Grammatikakis has been requested by the Greek judicial authorities for events that occurred in 1996, when he was rector of the University of Crete, the nature there is an accusation of illegal payments by the university to private insurance , has made me vote in favour of the pleading to suspend this MEP's immunity so that the judicial procedure can take its course in Greece.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Grammatikakis in the context of a legal action brought for an alleged offence relating to the non-compliance with certain legal obligations.  The case at issue concerns the discussion on 8 March 1996 of the possibility of concluding a new private collective insurance contract, in addition to the compulsory insurance contract, for all workers of the University of Crete and the making of allegedly illegal payments in successive instalments during the period 2000-2002.  The case is in no way related to the status of a Member of the European Parliament, since it concerns the functions that this Member had previously as Rector of the Senate of the University of Crete. This procedure is not considered to be intended to cause political harm to the Member concerned.  The case in question was filed for many co-defendants members of the University of Crete's Senate and the ELKE Commission due to the 15-year limitation period for the alleged crimes, while others were definitively acquitted of all charges by the court in May 2016.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The waiver of immunity was requested only about twenty years after the events took place, and the Greek legal system was unable to bring proceedings against Giorgos Grammatikakis during that period. That is why I did not vote in favour of the report.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report proposing the waiver of immunity for Greek MEP Giorgos Grammaticikakis. In the case of such requests, it is very important to remember that parliamentary immunity applies only to the period when the person concerned has already exercised a parliamentary mandate, and at the same time the event for which the waiver of immunity is requested must be directly linked to the exercise of that mandate. In this case, however, the conditions for maintaining immunity are not met. The incident in which proceedings are brought against Mr Grammatikakis in Greece has nothing to do with the exercise of his parliamentary mandate. The Member himself agrees with the waiver of immunity, and I have therefore seen no reason not to support this report.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's decision on the request for waiver of the immunity of Jorgos Gramatikakis, since the request for waiver of immunity in connection with the criminal proceedings against him does not relate to the status of Jorgos Gramatikakis as a Member of the European Parliament or to the opinion or vote delivered or cast by Jorgos Gramatikakis in his vote in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Dear Fellow Members, I ask you to imagine the following situation: You are going to a demonstration, exercising your fundamental human right to expression. The protest will be brutally crushed, you will be handcuffed, imprisoned, and then you will be subjected to arbitrary prosecution. Then imagine that you are patriots, you express strong opinions, you have systemic critical opinions, and then suddenly you find yourself accused of an act of terrorism punishable by life imprisonment.  If these situations are imagined, they will have no doubt that a yes vote should be made, as I have done, on the proposal that everyone has the right to protection in criminal proceedings, and that this must be ensured free of charge and to a high standard for those in need.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I have already commented on this material, which I support, as part of the catch the eye procedure. I would now like to add to the explanation of vote that I am also identified with what the final form of the directive looks like.  In my opinion, it is very right that a particular form of free legal aid is left to a country-specific decision. This means, for example, who will be able to provide this form of free legal aid in which state.  Let me have one more little something. In order for this legal provision to work in practice, it is very important that the European Commission communicates with member countries and that there is a dialogue with them on how much money each Member State will release to fulfil this directive. Because it is one thing to implement free legal aid and another thing is real money for which free legal aid can be provided. Otherwise, it will remain only with an empty directive, which will not effectively improve the position of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I also support this draft report, and I also support the final content of the resolution that has been adopted, or the form of the report, that is to say, the directive that accompanies it. In my view, this is an expression of the principle of subsidiarity, that is to say, indeed, in judicial matters, it is essential that this principle be reflected and that the Member States can then influence the specific form of the legal acts which are also intended to affect them in the field of judicial cooperation. This is also reflected in this free legal aid. In the Czech Republic, there has been discussion for several years about what the specific content should be and who should be the provider of this free legal aid.  And I would very much like us to make this and our national debate in our national court, of course, and for the European Union to give us some free hands in this regard, which will then be reflected in the content of the national legislation. For this reason too, because this directive complies with this, I could have supported it.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – I supported the present report because the right to a fair trial is one of the fundamental preconditions for justice. It should be guaranteed in cases involving judicial cooperation in criminal matters on the basis of a European arrest warrant. The Commission's proposal seeks to ensure a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. However, it is limited to the right to provisional legal aid for suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings who are deprived of liberty and to the right to provisional legal aid for requested persons subject to a European arrest warrant procedure. I therefore supported Parliament's position, which proposes extending the scope of the proposed directive to provide greater legal certainty.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, extradition has been around for centuries – millennia even. Ramesses II of Egypt signed the first extradition treaty all the way back in 1259 BC. I believe that extradition treaties work. I have concerns, though, about the European Arrest Warrant, which had led to certain miscarriages of justice in the United Kingdom. However, I am very much in favour of legal aid because money should never be a barrier to justice for anyone. I am also concerned, though, that these are matters for Member States to decide, in terms of who should and should not be granted legal aid. So, with these conflicting concerns and because I feel that there should always be proper evidence before any extradition is granted, I felt it appropriate in this case to abstain.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The directive in question on provisional access to legal aid is the latest of six directives aimed at implementing the roadmap for strengthening the procedural rights of suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings adopted by the Council in November 2009.  The proposal for a directive lays down minimum rules on the right to legal aid for suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings which are deprived of their liberty, and in certain other situations. It also ensures that legal aid is made available in proceedings for the execution of a European arrest warrant at the time of the arrest of the person wanted in the executing State. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have abstained on this legislative report. UKIP supports the right for access to legal aid for suspects and accused persons. However, as the UK government has chosen to opt out of this directive, we do feel the need to cast opinion on legislation that does not affect the UK.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I understand that access to justice is a fundamental right, and this is what is reflected in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. The only way to ensure access to this right on an equal footing is through free justice which does not exist in the Union today. The original report contained some very positive elements which would go in this direction, but after negotiations with the Council it has been greatly weakened, as many of the Member States do not guarantee this right. With the text presented, only persons in a situation of deprivation of liberty would be covered by this type of assistance. We understand that this is an improvement on the current situation of unprotection, but clearly insufficient, contrasting markedly with the position adopted at the time by the European Parliament, so I have decided to abstain.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – My GUE/NGL colleague Dennis De Jong is the rapporteur of this file and it sought to enhance the provision of legal aid to citizens across the EU. The file sought to create a base standard for the provision of legal aid and the quality of the legal assistance provided. The file also sought to ensure that in the case of European Arrest Warrants, legal aid is accessed from the issuing Member State. Whilst Dennis wanted the report to go further and include legal aid provisions for persons before liberty is suspended, the Council shot that down. However, the final report is still positive and a step in the right direction.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this report. At a time when the emphasis is on creating as many new criminal law instruments as possible to combat terrorism and other forms of crime, it is important to remember that the basis of a Union based on the rule of law is to ensure that fundamental rights of defence are respected for those who are accused or suspected by our criminal justice systems.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of their liberty and legal assistance in procedures for the execution of the European arrest warrant, because we must not forget, at a time when more and more tools are being created to tackle terrorism and other forms of crime , that the foundation of a Union based on the rule of law is the right to defend the accused.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. While the Commission's proposal would only guarantee the right to 'provisional' legal aid, the LIBE Committee suggested broadening the scope of the proposed directive to include the right to 'ordinary' legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings as well as for persons whose surrender is requested as part of a procedure relating to the execution of a European arrest warrant. Member States should ensure, among other things, that: ordinary legal aid is provided at all stages of criminal proceedings; Systems to ensure the quality and independence of court-appointed lawyers are in place, in particular an accreditation system, as well as initial training and continuing vocational training; the suspect, the person being prosecuted or the person whose surrender is requested has the right to request the replacement of the court counsel appointed to them. This is a new step in the development of a European criminal law, when it is a competence of the Member States. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. Judicial Europe is on the move, but it is moving slowly. However, this is one of the areas where Europe can demonstrate its added value to its citizens. Free movement within the EU and national division of judicial powers is a boon for offenders. It needs to be addressed, it is obvious. Confidence in the respective legal systems requires confidence in Member States' legal aid systems. That is why I voted for this resolution.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on temporary legal assistance for suspects or accused persons whose freedom is restricted and legal aid in the context of the European arrest warrant procedure. The Commission's proposal is a welcome step in ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. However, the Commission's proposal does not strengthen legal certainty, nor does it become clear to suspects or accused persons how effective they will be in exercising their right to legal aid and the quality of legal aid. I therefore agree that the scope of the directive should include the right to temporary and normal legal aid in all cases.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have abstained on this legislative report. UKIP supports the right to access to legal aid for suspects and accused persons. However, as the UK Government has chosen to opt out of this directive, we do not feel the need to cast opinion on legislation that does not affect the UK.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. According to the text, suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings should be given an effective remedy if their rights were to prove to have been violated. However, I am against this legal aid, which is a new step in the development of a European criminal law, when it is a competence of the Member States.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this text on legal aid because this proposal for a directive is no less than to guarantee the effectiveness of the directive on the right of access to a lawyer. This legal aid would be granted for a suspect or person prosecuted in criminal proceedings, or incurred for a person whose surrender is requested in the context of the Proceedings relating to the European Arrest Warrant, following an assessment of the applicant's resources and the merits of the application.  In the LIBE Committee, we also considered it necessary to suggest broadening the scope of the proposed directive to include the right to 'ordinary' legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted in certain proceedings and not just the right to 'provisional' legal aid as proposed by the Commission. In order to avoid possible abuse, the reimbursement of legal aid costs could be claimed exceptionally from suspects, particularly if they knowingly provided the competent authorities with false information about their personal financial situation.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the de Jong report on legal aid for suspects and defendants in criminal proceedings and for persons wanted in proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant.  This is a particularly important issue which is one of the cornerstones of the rule of law. Those who do not have the necessary financial means must be guaranteed the right to avail themselves of a lawyer through legal aid. The text adopted is a concrete step forward in overcoming the different interpretations of the right to a fair trial, guaranteeing a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. Despite some provisions that are perhaps too timid to overcome differences in the quality of legal aid, the text proposes a fair line for judicial cooperation in criminal matters that is truly fair and effective.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to improve the rights of defendants or defendants in criminal proceedings. Having common minimum standards governing these rights should promote mutual trust between judicial authorities and thus facilitate the application of the principle of mutual recognition. A certain degree of compatibility between Member States' legislation is essential to improve judicial cooperation in the Union. Thanks to the work of the rapporteur of our group, significant improvements have been made to the Commission's proposal; inter alia, extend the scope beyond deprivation of liberty, allowing provisional and ordinary legal assistance in all circumstances. It is important to note that it reflects aspects such as that the initial phase of the proceedings, especially when defendants or defendants are deprived of their liberty, is the time when they are most vulnerable and when they need the legal assistance of a lawyer most. In the trilogue negotiations, the work done in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs suffered some setbacks because of the Council's resistance. Still, it is a significant step forward. I therefore vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I objected to this report by the LIBE Committee, which further pushes the European Commission's desire to develop a genuine European criminal law at the expense of national law. The report argues for the establishment of an "ordinary" right to legal aid for persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings, as well as for persons whose surrender is requested as part of a procedure relating to the execution of a European arrest warrant. The approach of the Europeanists is perverse in that it involves attacking the sovereignty of Member States from the point of view of the rights of individuals. European nations, if this directive is followed, would now be confined to an audit role: ensuring that ordinary legal aid is provided at all stages of criminal proceedings; guarantee the quality and independence of public defenders, etc. But the Member States are already states of law and most are already ensuring such practices at the national level, in France since 1841! A draft directive which is therefore only useful only its ideological scope.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr de Jong's report is well structured and unseeded. I believe that the text is acceptable and I therefore supported it with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the Legal Aid Directive.  In 2013, the European Commission adopted a proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on provisional legal aid for suspects or accused persons in custody and on legal aid in the context of procedures relating to a European arrest warrant.  For this reason, it is important that there should also be a directive guaranteeing legal aid where there is an arrest warrant. For this reason, I have voted in favour of the directive.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I supported the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on provisional legal aid to suspects or accused persons deprived of their liberty and to legal aid in the European arrest warrant procedure. The report, which is a proposal for an agreement at first reading, takes into account the differences between Member States in relation to the quality of legal assistance they offer and the need to include guarantees on the quality of legal assistance referred to in the Directive. Thanks to the amendments introduced by the S&D Group, the report affects legal aid and the expansion of the covered area covering all types of legal assistance in criminal proceedings.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with temporary legal assistance to suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and legal aid measures in european arrest warrant proceedings. The right to legal aid is a daunting question, which perhaps explains why it took a relatively long time for the Commission to present the current measure. However, this should not prevent the European Parliament from considering a proposal for a directive as a matter of priority for the new term of office. The different interpretation of the right to a fair trial, including the right to legal aid recognised, inter alia, in Article 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and Article 6 of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, creates obstacles to the exercise of fair and effective judicial cooperation in criminal matters. It is therefore necessary to adopt the remaining measures of the Action Plan as soon as possible, in particular the draft Directive on legal aid. The Commission's proposal is a welcome step in ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. However, this proposal confines itself to the right of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings to temporary legal assistance when deprived of their liberty and to the right to temporary legal aid and legal aid for requested persons subject to the European arrest warrant procedure. Additional aspects of legal aid eligibility are addressed in a separate Commission recommendation.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I supported that report on the right to legal aid. Legal aid is a sensitive subject, as there is no uniform interpretation of the right to a fair trial between the Member States and their judicial systems, and consequently free legal aid. Despite the longer period of preparation of the proposal for a directive in this area by the Commission, the proposal allows for the provision of a minimum level of legal aid in all EU Member States, which is reinforced by the adopted amendments in the European Parliament. I also welcome the eligibility criteria for legal aid, as they provide some clarity on the whole process. Nevertheless, differences in the cost of judicial proceedings between Member States should also be taken into account.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this Legal Aid Report for suspects and accused persons and for wanted persons in proceedings based on a European arrest warrant. Despite some shortcomings, this is a positive step for the European Union and the rule of law. Common minimum standards (such as the right to a free lawyer in a country issuing a European arrest warrant/country to which a European arrest warrant has been issued) must now be implemented, and we must work to raise standards and further consolidate procedural, fundamental and defence rights, guaranteed to those charged or suspected by our criminal-legal system.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This text is a new step in the development of a European criminal law, even though it is a competence of the Member States. So I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal for a directive aimed at ensuring the right of access to a lawyer for suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings and for requested persons who are the subject of European Arrest Warrant proceedings. I voted in favour of this proposal, because I think it is needed to strengthen the trust of Member States in each other’s criminal justice systems.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report recommends broadening the scope of the European Commission's proposed directive to include the right to ordinary legal aid for individuals prosecuted in criminal proceedings. Member States would thus be obliged to provide legal aid at all stages of the criminal proceedings and to guarantee the quality and independence of the lawyers appointed by the court.  In addition, it grants suspects the right to request, on one occasion, the replacement of the legal counsel appointed to them and the right to appeal a decision to refuse this legal aid. I voted against this report, which is a new step in the development of a European criminal law when it is an exclusive competence of the Member States.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has adopted a proposal for a directive on provisional legal assistance for suspects or accused persons who are deprived of their liberty and legal assistance in the european arrest warrant proceedings, with implementation assuming that Member States give each other confidence to their criminal judicial systems, even the way in which the rights of suspects or accused persons are safeguarded. In particular, however, national practices are different and there are large differences between Member States in the quality of legal aid offered, which depends in particular on the fees paid to lawyers for free legal aid. In cases where fees are too low, lawyers will not devote enough time and effort to providing high-quality free legal aid. We voted in favour of the report, considering that there must be a single judicial policy in all Member States, and that this differentiation between states and the approach to legal aid should be one and the same, regardless of the fees that lawyers receive.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposed Directive lays down common minimum rules on the right to legal aid for suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings where they are deprived of their liberty and persons subject to European arrest warrant proceedings.  The objective of this Directive is to ensure that such persons have access to legal aid in order to be able to effectively exercise their right to have access to a lawyer, as provided for in the Directive on access to a lawyer. I voted in favour of this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament because I believe that this directive will contribute to mutual trust between the Member States, which will lead to better European cooperation in criminal matters. In the early stages of the proceedings, suspects or accused persons are particularly vulnerable, and access to a lawyer is essential to protect their rights to a fair trial.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it allows for the establishment of common minimum rules on the right to legal aid for suspects, persons prosecuted and persons whose surrender is requested. Thanks to the common minimum rules, this report strengthens Member States' confidence in the criminal justice system of other Member States.  It also facilitates mutual recognition of criminal decisions. Member States are encouraged to take steps to improve the quality and effectiveness of legal aid services. This report requires Member States to grant access to legal aid, beyond provisional legal aid, because those who are requested to be handed over are not always deprived of their liberty.  This will also strengthen mutual trust and make effective the right to dual defence in the context of European Arrest Warrant proceedings.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, I voted in favour of this directive harmonizing at EU level the institution of legal aid for suspects and defendants deprived of their personal freedom or involved in proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant. The scope of the Directive includes admission to legal aid at both provisional and final State expense and provides legal certainty for the suspect, accused or wanted person as regards eligibility criteria. Differences in income and cost levels between Member States exclude the possibility of providing detailed rules on the level of fees. However, the directive includes minimum guarantees concerning the quality of the legal assistance offered. Specific provisions are also laid down to take into account, as far as possible, the preferences of suspects, defendants and wanted people with regard to the choice of ex of office lawyer.  The same applies to the need for continuity in legal representation and the replacement of the lawyer of his own motion if the suspect, accused or wanted person has lost all confidence in his lawyer and is able to justify it for verifiable reasons.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which seeks to enhance the provision of legal aid to citizens across the EU. The file seeks to create a base standard for the provision of legal aid and the quality of the legal assistance provided. The file also seeks to ensure that in the case of European Arrest Warrants, legal aid is accessed from the issuing Member State. Whilst I am disappointed that the report did not include provisions for persons before their liberty is suspended, the final report is still positive and a step in the right direction.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the text which works at ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. The proposal focuses on the right to provisional legal aid for suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings who are deprived of liberty, and the right to provisional legal aid and to legal aid for requested persons who are subject to European Arrest Warrant proceedings.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposed directive on provisional access to legal aid is the latest in a package of six directives to implement the roadmap for strengthening the procedural rights of suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings. Having a direct impact on the state budget, the issue of legal aid is not an easy subject; although it dictates a minimum standard, it does not raise it as much as would have been desirable.  However, parliament's contribution should be emphasised, as it has succeeded in extending the scope beyond the provisional period, thus guaranteeing ordinary legal assistance. In any case, this is an important measure aimed at guaranteeing a minimum standard of procedural rights, which is also and above all useful for the mutual recognition of criminal decisions. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and consider the Commission's proposal to be a positive step towards ensuring the minimum level of legal aid in all Member States.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of their liberty and legal assistance in procedures for the execution of the European arrest warrant is a right step in the effort to strengthen the right of the accused to a fair trial. We must always seek to improve the functioning of justice and I believe that this report helps to this end. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure as on 27 November 2013 the European Commission adopted a proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the provisional admission to legal aid for suspects or defendants deprived of personal liberty and on admission to legal aid in proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant. The Commission's proposal is a positive step towards ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. It is, however, limited to the right to provisional admission to legal aid for suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings deprived of personal liberty and to the right to provisional and definitive admission to legal aid for wanted people who are the subject of proceedings executing the European arrest warrant. In addition, the rapporteur is aware of the differences between Member States as regards the quality of legal assistance offered. This depends, among other things, on the fees paid to lawyers for legal aid. However, it is therefore even more important to include at least some guarantees regarding the quality of legal assistance offered in the directive.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report, which seeks to regulate legal aid for suspects or defendants deprived of personal liberty and admission to legal aid in proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant.  At present, the Italian legal system provides for broader guarantees than those of many other EU countries. This guarantee, starting with Article 24 of the Constitution, is provided for and has been implemented over the years by our jurisprudence. I therefore support the inclusion of this measure in the European arrest warrant procedure as well.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 An issue of such complexity requires support: all too often in our countries we are witnessing, because of different practices, cases in which those who do not have the opportunity to defend themselves automatically lose the right to a fair trial.  The Commission had provided for provisional aid for suspects and defendants in criminal proceedings as well as for wanted people with a European arrest warrant, but it was possible to extend it to being ordinary and definitive. This is intended to increase the effectiveness of the right of access to legal aid at the state's expense for those who do not have sufficient means to cover legal costs. Reasonably, checks will also be made on the means and merits in order to assess with objective means the actual unavailability of resources on the part of the accused and, at the same time, the urgency, complexity, seriousness of the case and the severity of the penalties applicable.  I believe it is essential to stress that the quality and independence of office defenders must be best ensured in all countries, as must the right of the accused to request the replacement of the lawyer where he or she does not prove professional.  I hope that what has been voted on will allow for straight and short processes. I would also like to take this opportunity to remind you of the disastrous situation in our prisons and call for solutions to be found.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on provisional legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and legal aid in European arrest warrant proceedings, and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The proposal for a Directive on legal aid is also part of the Roadmap for strengthening the procedural rights of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings, adopted in 2009 and which over the years has been complied with. Reaching compromises in this area has been particularly difficult, given the diversity of legal cultures and also the sensitivity of criminal proceedings - an angular part of the essential core of state sovereignty. For this reason, and despite the long process, the harmonisation achieved is extremely important and has to be valued. In legal aid in particular, the result achieved could have been better. Parliament's position was to support suspects and accused persons with economic shortfall, regardless of deprivation of liberty. However, the Council was uncompromising and had been blocking the adoption of this instrument since 2014. Still, Parliament was able to extend the scope of the Directive by ensuring that it protected not only provisionally but permanently as well. Parliament has therefore decided to accept this compromise which, if not the best, will certainly guarantee the effective exercise of the right to defence by many Europeans.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal because it represents a positive step towards guaranteeing a minimum level of legal aid for nationals of Member States, while limiting itself to the provisional level for suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings deprived of personal liberty and to the provisional and definitive level for wanted people subject to proceedings executing the European arrest warrant.  I consider the changes made to the final text in relation to the original proposal to extend the scope of the directive to include the right to legal aid and not just to interim legal aid to be important, thus including support for the accused at all stages of the proceedings.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the proposal to help those not having sufficient means themselves to pay for legal assistance, where the interests of justice so require. Proper legal assistance will facilitate further the mutual recognition of judgments and judicial decisions and enhance police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters in matters with a cross-border dimension. Accreditation for legal aid lawyers as well as continuous professional training will continue to sustain the competence of legal aid lawyers. Children are particularly vulnerable when involved in criminal matters and require particular attention through the implementation of special measures that provide for procedural safeguards. Consequently I support this report.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I understand that access to justice is a fundamental right, and this is what is reflected in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. The only way to ensure access to this right on an equal footing is through free justice which does not exist in the Union today. The original report contained some very positive elements which would go in this direction, but after negotiations with the Council it has been greatly weakened, as many of the Member States do not guarantee this right. With the text presented, only persons in a situation of deprivation of liberty would be covered by this type of assistance. We understand that this is an improvement on the current situation of unprotection, but clearly insufficient, contrasting markedly with the position adopted at the time by the European Parliament, so I have decided to abstain.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to put an end to the differences between Member States on the procedural rights of suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings, given that this situation contradicts judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the Union established by Article 82 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEI).  Parliament gave its opinion on the Commission's proposal for a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. Parliament believes that the approach can be improved by clarifying those elements that remain uncertain in the Commission's proposal, such as the level of quality and costs of legal aid, and the criteria for eligibility for legal aid.  I am convinced that establishing common minimum standards for the right to legal aid for suspects, defendants and wanted people will serve to strengthen cooperation and trust between the criminal justice systems of the Member States and, with them, the mutual recognition of decisions in criminal matters.

name: Andi CRISTEA
