text: in writing. \u2012 On 27 November 2013, the European Commission adopted a proposal by the European Parliament and the Council on provisional legal assistance for suspects or accused persons who are deprived of their liberty and legal aid in european arrest warrant proceedings. Judicial cooperation in criminal matters within the Union is based on the principle of mutual recognition of judicial decisions and judicial decisions, but national practices are different. For those who do not have the necessary financial resources, free legal aid is the only solution to facilitate access to a lawyer. I voted to ensure a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. The right to a fair trial, including through the provision of free legal aid, is a step towards fair and effective judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 On 30 November 2009, the Council adopted a roadmap aimed at strengthening the rights of suspects and accused persons. The roadmap identifies the right to legal advice and legal aid , the latter being inextricably linked to the right to access to a lawyer. For those who do not have the necessary financial means, only legal aid can ensure that this right is enforced. As a result of the difficult interinstitutional negotiations, we have finally succeeded in adopting a text that is acceptable to all and which Parliament approved today and which I voted in favour of. Compared to the original draft directive tabled by the European Commission in 2013, the text adopted today has brought about a number of changes, cleared up and, among other things, extended the scope of the directive from temporary legal aid for suspects and accused persons deprived of their liberty to ordinary legal aid, so that much more persons will be covered by the Directive.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I have chosen to vote against the application for legal aid for suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings and for persons subject to a warrant in European arrest warrant proceedings. My decision is due to the fact that, although the text put to the vote is the result of trilogue negotiations, I do not see the appropriateness of extending the scope of the directive. It also does not seem appropriate to me to allocate legal aid to 'temporary' and 'ordinary' aid. For these reasons, I voted against. I believe that the legislative act that is currently in place is sufficient.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Terrorism is a new reality that requires an effective political system in place to really and truly safeguard our citizens. The European Union is also based on the rule of law, which includes a collection of procedural, fundamental and defence rights guaranteed to those who are accused or suspected of criminal actions. I am in favour of this agreement as it would lay down common minimum rules on legal aid for suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings and also for those persons who are the subject of a European Arrest Warrant. I believe that criminal law is a key component in creating an Area of Freedom, Security and Justice.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report follows the European Commission's proposal in November 2013 for a directive on legal aid. This text aims to strengthen the rights of European citizens by establishing common minimum standards in all Member States on the right to legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings. Considering that this text will ensure better protection for European citizens and strengthen mutual trust between states in the area of justice, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The adoption by a very large majority of this text on legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings and for persons whose surrender is requested in the context of the Proceedings relating to the European Arrest Warrant is an important step in strengthening the procedural rights of European citizens.  As rapporteur on this text for my political group, the EPP, I have insisted that strong minimum standards for access to legal aid be guaranteed for any suspect or person prosecuted deprived of their liberty in one of the Member States of the European Union. This harmonisation of our criminal procedures is essential to the construction of the Europe of Justice which I defend.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal aid for suspects and accused persons deprived of their liberty and legal aid in proceedings relating to the European arrest warrant can be considered as part of the roadmap adopted on 30 November 2009 to strengthen the procedural rights of accused persons in criminal proceedings, with the aim of creating common minimum standards in the Member States. After difficult negotiations, the mutually acceptable text has emerged and, as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation, I am voting in favour of the initiative. In my view, a satisfactory compromise has been reached in the trialo-trial negotiations, which successfully contribute to the setting of common European minimum standards and do not impose a disproportionate burden on criminal proceedings.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution approving the adoption at first reading of the draft directive on provisional legal aid for suspects and persons deprived of their liberty, as well as legal aid in the context of the European Arrest Warrant procedures. The aim of this directive is to ensure that European citizens throughout the Union enjoy a minimum of judicial rights, but also to improve mutual trust between the different criminal justice systems of the Member States in order to improve the correct use of the European Arrest Warrant. Legal aid contains six specific measures: the right to interpretation and translation; The right to information the right to access a lawyer, the right to the presumption of innocence; and specific procedural safeguards for children. The EU already had minimum guarantees for access to a lawyer, but with this new directive, all European citizens will be able to make use of these rights and not just those who can afford a lawyer.  European citizens will all have the same rights wherever they are in the UNION.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The right of access to legal aid gives any individual who is being prosecuted a criminal offence the opportunity to benefit from a judicial assistant, for example a lawyer or interpreter, regardless of his or her income.  This right is one of the fundamental principles enshrined in Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights and Article 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. Since 2009, the EU has had legislation to guarantee all its citizens the right of access throughout Europe. While all Member States recognise this legal instrument, there are still disparities between States in the quality of aid provided.  With the adoption of the revision of this directive, European citizens will now be able to fully benefit from this right regardless of income, regardless of the Member State in which they are at the time of their arrest.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ We can all agree that the right to a fair, independent and impartial trial is the cornerstone of an effective judicial system and just society.  Those charged with offences have the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and this is essential to ensuring that the public have confidence in our courts and democratic processes as a whole.  In this sense, I support the premise that those detained under a European Arrest Warrant should have an entitlement to legal representation, and that this eligibility should be subject to the same tests applied at a national level for the same offence.  In Northern Ireland, we have increasingly seen legal aid used under the auspices of human rights law by those liable for terrorist atrocities in an effort to evade the rulings of national courts in the United Kingdom. Only last week the ECHR rejected appeals by two republican terrorists liable for the Omagh Bombing in 1998 which killed 28 people.  Whilst ensuring free and fair access to legal representation is vital, provision must also be centred toward addressing the needs of innocent victims and ensuring that the balance of protections do not tip toward the perpetrator.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on my colleague De Jong's report as I am concerned that the proposals made by the European Commission run counter to the principle of subsidiarity and lead to the 'Europeanisation' of criminal law.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States should not be limited to two categories, namely suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings who are deprived of their liberty and wanted persons subject to procedures relating to the execution of a European arrest warrant. Such a piecemeal approach neither enhances legal certainty nor clarifies the degree and quality of the right to legal aid.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal aid for suspects and accused persons deprived of their liberty and legal aid in proceedings relating to the European arrest warrant can be considered as part of the roadmap adopted on 30 November 2009 to strengthen the procedural rights of accused persons in criminal proceedings, with the aim of creating common minimum standards in the Member States. After difficult negotiations, the mutually acceptable text has emerged and, as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation, I am voting in favour of the initiative. In my view, a satisfactory compromise has been reached in the trialo-trial negotiations, which successfully contribute to the setting of common European minimum standards and do not impose a disproportionate burden on criminal proceedings.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the Union is based on the principle of mutual recognition of judgments and judicial decisions. The Council approved the Roadmap for strengthening the procedural rights of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings which it identifies as the right to legal sponsorship and aid. The Commission's proposal is an important step towards ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. However, I believe that defendants, suspects or wanted persons may feel inhibited from seeking legal aid if Member States can demand the costs of provisional legal aid for not meeting the eligibility criteria. It is therefore fair to limit the recovery of costs to cases where defendants, suspects or persons sought intentionally provide false information.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: a new step in the development of a European criminal law, when it is a competence of the Member States.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The right to legal aid is intrinsically linked to the right of access to a lawyer. The European Commission's proposal aims to ensure a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. However, it is restricted to the right to provisional legal aid for suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings who are deprived of liberty, as well as the right to provisional legal aid and legal aid for persons sought in proceedings for the execution of European arrest warrants. The Commission presented, in a separate recommendation, additional aspects of the right to legal aid. The rapporteur considers that this fragmented approach may reflect the sensitivity of the matter, but does not increase legal certainty or make it clear to suspects or accused persons to what extent they will actually be entitled to legal aid or what the quality of legal aid will be. The scope of the Directive should include the right to provisional and ordinary legal aid in all circumstances. In general, this report is moving in a positive direction, which we support. For several Member States it represents an unquestionable advance. But it still falls short of the concrete measures and resources, which guarantee the universality of free access to legal and legal aid for the accused, as one of the most basic rights to defence and dignity.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it will increase the opportunities for justice to be done.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 There are currently major differences in the quality of legal aid offered in individual Member States. The European Commission's proposal on the table represents an important step towards ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. The issues raised are quite difficult, and it is therefore understandable that it has taken the European Commission quite a long time to prepare the relevant instruments. It is very important that we can jointly ensure adequate and high-quality legal aid. Suspects cannot feel that they are being denied their rights and that the level of legal certainty and the administration of justice is being reduced in the European Union. We must work together to bring together individual national criminal procedures and systems, as harmonisation in this area is very important to ensure a high standard in guaranteeing legal aid in the European Union. In this case, a good compromise has been reached for citizens living in individual Member States of the European Union. Member States should have no problem in implementing the relevant legislation in order to increase legal certainty for citizens of the European Union.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report: I agree that legal aid for suspects or defendants deprived of personal liberty and admission to legal aid in proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant should also be regulated at European level.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States should not be limited to two categories, i.e. only to suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings who are deprived of their liberty and to wanted persons subject to procedures relating to the execution of a European arrest warrant. Such a piecemeal approach neither enhances legal certainty nor clarifies the degree and quality of the right to legal aid. For the above reasons I am voting against the report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which calls for the scope of the Directive to be widened to cover all cases of legal aid, and not just those of ‘provisional’ legal aid, as per the Commission proposal. I believe persons subject to a European Arrest Warrant should have the right to legal aid for a lawyer both in the Member State which issues the arrest warrant and in the Member State which executes the arrest warrant. At a time when the focus seems to be on creating as many new criminal law instruments as possible to tackle terrorism and other forms of criminality, it is important to remember that the bedrock of a Union based on the rule of law is the collection of procedural, fundamental and defence rights guaranteed to those who are accused or suspected by our criminal justice systems.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal aid for suspects and accused persons deprived of their liberty and legal aid in proceedings relating to the European arrest warrant can be considered as part of the roadmap adopted on 30 November 2009 to strengthen the procedural rights of accused persons in criminal proceedings, with the aim of creating common minimum standards in the Member States. After difficult negotiations, the mutually acceptable text has emerged and, as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation, I am voting in favour of the initiative. In my view, a satisfactory compromise has been reached in the trialo-trial negotiations, which successfully contribute to the setting of common European minimum standards and do not impose a disproportionate burden on criminal proceedings.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal aid for suspects and accused persons deprived of their liberty and legal aid in proceedings relating to the European arrest warrant can be considered as part of the roadmap adopted on 30 November 2009 to strengthen the procedural rights of accused persons in criminal proceedings, with the aim of creating common minimum standards in the Member States. After difficult negotiations, the mutually acceptable text has emerged and, as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation, I am voting in favour of the initiative. In my view, a satisfactory compromise has been reached in the trialo-trial negotiations, which successfully contribute to the setting of common European minimum standards and do not impose a disproportionate burden on criminal proceedings.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the view that, in accordance with Article 82 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the Union is based on the principle of mutual recognition of judgments and judgments. The application of this principle requires Member States to have confidence in the criminal judicial systems of others, including in the way in which the rights of suspects or accused people are safeguarded. The different interpretation of the right to a fair trial, in particular through legal assistance, constitutes an obstacle to fair and effective judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The Commission's proposal is a positive step in ensuring a minimum level of legal assistance in all Member States.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the agreement at first reading on the text negotiated by my colleagues in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, which introduces common minimum standards for legal assistance to suspects and persons accused in criminal cases or subject to a European arrest warrant. With the adoption of this important piece of legislation, Europe is taking a further step towards strengthening cooperation and mutual recognition in the field of criminal justice. This is something that I think is very important to emphasise: the guarantees established allow adequate protection in all European countries and set quality standards for legal assistance for the accused, guaranteeing equal treatment.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on provisional admission to legal aid for suspects or defendants deprived of personal liberty and on admission to legal aid in proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant because I am firmly convinced of the need to strengthen the rule of law and legal and procedural guarantees at a particular historical moment such as the one in which we live , characterised by terrorism and the increase in cross-border crime. For the have-nots, sponsoring at the expense of the State is the only way to guarantee the right of defence and a fair trial. I therefore welcome the efforts made by the Group of the Party of European Socialists to introduce uniform rules at European level that guarantee free assistance, without the risk of any reimbursement of costs incurred, for suspects and defendants without personal freedom, and not only in the provisional stages of the procedure as initially requested by the Commission. I believe that this legislation, although limited to the situations listed in it, is an important first step towards bringing the quality of legal assistance in the various Member States closer together, taking into account the differences in costs and professional fees.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The principle that all citizens are equal before the law must not be restricted by the financial situation of a suspect or accused person. With this report, the European Union is sending out a strong signal for a fair, free and independent judiciary in all Member States.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this legislative report. UKIP supports the right for access to legal aid for suspects and accused persons. However, as the UK Government has chosen to opt out of this directive, I do not feel the need to cast an opinion on legislation that does not affect the UK.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to improve the rights of defendants or defendants in criminal proceedings. Having common minimum standards governing these rights should promote mutual trust between judicial authorities and thus facilitate the application of the principle of mutual recognition. A certain degree of compatibility between Member States' legislation is essential to improve judicial cooperation in the Union. Thanks to the work of the rapporteur of our group, significant improvements have been made to the Commission's proposal; inter alia, extend the scope beyond deprivation of liberty, allowing provisional and ordinary legal assistance in all circumstances. It is important to note that it reflects aspects such as that the initial phase of the proceedings, especially when defendants or defendants are deprived of their liberty, is the time when they are most vulnerable and when they need the legal assistance of a lawyer most. In the trilogue negotiations, the work done in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs suffered some setbacks because of the Council's resistance. Still, it is a significant step forward. I therefore vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I believe it is a welcome step towards ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. However, this level is the limit of the right to free provisional legal aid offered to suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings who are deprived of their liberty and the right to free provisional legal aid for wanted persons who are the subject of proceedings relating to the European Arrest Warrant. It is important that suspects, defendants or wanted persons benefit from legal certainty with regard to eligibility criteria. The right of defence or the right to translation must not depend on the country in which the process takes place, nationality, gender or the social category to which the person belongs. The eligibility criteria mentioned in the Commission recommendation provide some clarification for the time being, but without fully harmonising. Fairness for citizens, regardless of costs, must be put in the same balance so that the rights of citizens in such situations are balanced.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive on legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and legal aid in European Arrest Warrant proceedings. This is one of a set of proposals intended to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which is part of a package proposed by the European Commission to improve procedural rights and harmonise them at European level. This report sets out the common minimum rules under which a person accused or suspected in criminal proceedings or subject to a European arrest warrant can apply for legal aid.  Two tests to be carried out by the Member States will enable an independent authority to decide the right to legal aid according to, among other criteria, the resources and situation of the person and the seriousness of the offence. I welcome the fact that the European Parliament has succeeded in applying these rights to aid throughout the criminal proceedings and that a right of appeal can be exercised in the event of a refusal.  In addition, Parliament has made the information related to this aid available, which is important because all citizens need to know their procedural rights.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. This proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council aims to set common minimum standards on the right to provisional legal aid for suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings when they are deprived of liberty and for provisional legal aid and legal aid for persons subject to proceedings. This proposal seeks to improve the rights of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings. Having common minimum standards governing these rights should boost mutual trust between judicial authorities and thus facilitate the application of the principle of mutual recognition. A certain degree of compatibility between the legislation of Member States is crucial to improve judicial cooperation in the EU.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with the majority of Parliament, supported this report, which is the last of six measures on the procedural rights roadmap, which was launched in 2009. The EU already has minimum rules for the right of access to a lawyer but this new directive on legal aid will mean that all citizens can use this right and not just those who can afford it. All EU Member States have national legal aid schemes but this directive will mean that EU citizens have the same minimum rights wherever they are in the EU. In addition, I was happy that there is now provisional legal aid for the initial stages of criminal proceedings and ordinary legal aid for all stages of the proceedings in line with the conditions laid down in the directive. The final outcome also includes the possibility to use a means and merits test to find out whether a person is eligible for legal aid either because they lack financial resources or because it is in the interest of justice for a particular case. This, I believe, is a fair and equitable process.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. This report, which is the result of negotiations with the Council and the Commission, supports provisional and proper mutual legal assistance for suspects and accused persons and advocates minimum standards in court proceedings. The ALFA believes that minimum standards such as the right to translation, the presumption of innocence and access to a lawyer are correct and that they cannot be effectively regulated at national level because of the free movement of persons within the EU. Personally, I see these standards as a matter of course and fair treatment for an individual and have therefore voted in favour of the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. For it leads to discord and discord.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal aid for suspects and accused persons deprived of their liberty and legal aid in proceedings relating to the European arrest warrant can be considered as part of the roadmap adopted on 30 November 2009 to strengthen the procedural rights of accused persons in criminal proceedings, with the aim of creating common minimum standards in the Member States. After difficult negotiations, the mutually acceptable text has emerged and, as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation, I am voting in favour of the initiative. In my view, a satisfactory compromise has been reached in the trialo-trial negotiations, which successfully contribute to the setting of common European minimum standards and do not impose a disproportionate burden on criminal proceedings.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I welcome the strengthening of legal mechanisms in Europe with the agreement endorsed by the European Parliament and the Council on a body of common minimum rules governing the right to legal aid. In France, this mechanism already exists, but in other European Union countries, the effectiveness of the right of access to a lawyer was not always guaranteed for persons prosecuted or suspected who do not have sufficient resources. Legal aid will now be possible for suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings but will not apply to minor offences because of the excessive financial burden this would have represented for the Member States. It should also be noted that this assistance will apply to persons who are requested to be handed over in the context of European Arrest Warrant proceedings. Finally, each state will remain free to apply the test it deems most relevant - a resource or merit test - to determine whether legal aid can be granted or not.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Directive from Parliament and the Council on temporary legal assistance for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and legal assistance in european arrest warrant procedures on the grounds that this new directive provides legal assistance to all citizens, not just those who can afford it financially.  All Member States of the European Union have national legal aid systems, but this directive provides all citizens with the same minimum rights wherever they are within the EU. This also strengthens mutual trust between Member States in the area of criminal justice systems, and increases the proper application of the European arrest warrant.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text, arguing for an extension of "ordinary" legal aid for suspects and individuals prosecuted criminally as well as those subject to a European arrest warrant, attacks prerogatives that fall solely within the competence of member states. There is a clear desire to go further and further towards the constitution of a European criminal law, which I strongly oppose. That is why I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have abstained on this legislative report. UKIP supports the right to access to legal aid for suspects and accused persons. However, as the UK Government has chosen to opt out of this directive, we do not feel the need to cast opinion on legislation that does not affect the UK.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive because it is crucial to ensure fair trials and access to justice for EU citizens. The procedural rights of suspected or accused persons in criminal proceedings must be guaranteed equally across the EU. This directive broadens already existing legal rights, such as the right to interpretation and translation, the right to information, the right of access to a lawyer, the presumption of innocence and special safeguards for children. The legal aid directive ensures essential rights for EU citizens who cannot afford a lawyer or court proceedings for both ‘provisional’ and ‘ordinary’ legal aid.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Dennis De Jong's text on legal aid. Created in 1972 in France, legal aid is a fundamental principle that is not present in all European countries. Thus, in order to set minimum standards in all Member States, I supported this draft directive which provides for the obligation for Member States to introduce legal aid for persons deprived of their liberty.  I am pleased that this report has been adopted by a large majority.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which concerns the right to legal aid for citizens suspected of having committed or prosecuted as a criminal offence, as well as for citizens who are the subject of a European arrest warrant. Everyone must be able to be defended, and the right to defence is a fundamental right in democracy. In addition, the legislation provides for an assessment of the resources and the merits of the application as prerequisites for obtaining such legal aid.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report on legal aid for suspects and accused persons in the Union. There are some centralising elements in this report, but every citizen, regardless of where he or she has to answer to the courts in the EU, should have the same opportunities and safeguards as in his or her home country.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which will assist in increasing Member States’ confidence in each other’s legal systems and ensure that in countries where virtually no legal aid exists, new and improved systems can be established. Once fully implemented by Member States, the legal aid directive should give an important boost to social advocacy by strengthening the right to access to a lawyer for those who do not have sufficient financial means. In addition, it ensures quick and effective legal representation from the start of proceedings. The UK has opted out of the proposal and will not be affected by this legislation.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. This report, which results from negotiations with the Council and the Commission, supports provisional and regular legal aid for suspects and accused persons and advocates minimum standards in court proceedings. The ALFA believes that minimum standards such as the right to translation, the presumption of innocence and access to a lawyer are correct and that they cannot be effectively regulated at national level because of the free movement of persons within the EU. Personally, I see these standards as a matter of course and fair treatment for an individual and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Temporary legal aid for suspects and accused people deprived of their liberty and legal aid in proceedings relating to the European arrest warrant. The draft Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal aid for suspects and accused persons deprived of their liberty and legal aid in proceedings relating to the European arrest warrant can be considered as part of the roadmap adopted on 30 November 2009 to strengthen the procedural rights of accused persons in criminal proceedings with a view to creating common minimum standards in the Member States. After difficult negotiations, the mutually acceptable text has emerged and, as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation, I am voting in favour of the initiative. In my view, a satisfactory compromise has been reached in the trialo-trial negotiations, which successfully contribute to the setting of common European minimum standards and do not impose a disproportionate burden on criminal proceedings.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. "Any one of us may, through no fault of our own, be in a position to be prosecuted by official bodies. In many cases, it's absurd. In one case, prosecutors do not operate without any real control, acting on political orders. In particular, for people who have been abused in a foreign environment and abroad, the proposal contains fair, fair, reasonable and rule-of-law rules, which have been added by the LIBE Committee with additional guarantee rules. The proposal for a directive on temporary legal aid for suspects and accused people deprived of their liberty and legal aid in proceedings relating to the European arrest warrant should therefore be clearly supported.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a directive on temporary legal aid for suspects or accused persons detained and legal assistance in European arrest warrant proceedings, as judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the Union is based on the principle of mutual recognition of convictions and judgments.  The application of this principle implies that Member States have mutual confidence in their criminal justice systems as well as in the way in which the rights of suspects and accused persons are protected, but there are differences in national practices, including in interpreting the right to a fair trial and ensuring effective legal assistance. This may prove to be an insurmountable obstacle to maintaining fair and effective judicial cooperation in criminal matters, and in this context the proposal for a directive is a positive step towards ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States and the associated costs. The criteria for granting legal aid provide greater clarity without leading to full harmonisation, as it would be impossible and unnecessary to provide detailed legislation at Union level, given the differences between the amount of costs of legal proceedings in the Member States.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution because there is no doubt that for those suspects, accused and requested persons who lack the necessary financial means, the right to legal advice and legal aid is the only way to take advantage of their right of access to a lawyer. Unfortunately, there is a difference in the quality of legal assistance offered by Member States. For one reason or another, in some Member States fees for the lawyers are too low so that they are not willing to devote enough time and effort to providing high quality legal aid. Therefore, the provision that allows suspects, accused and requested persons to show their preference and wishes with regard to their legal aid lawyer should be taken into account and included in the directive. Provision should also be made for replacement of the legal aid lawyer, if the suspected, accused or requested person has lost all confidence in the lawyer and can motivate this on verifiable grounds. Thus, we will not only reinforce the right to legal aid for suspects, accused and requested persons but will also ensure that they face a fair trial.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The Commission's proposal is aimed at ensuring minimum legal aid in all Member States against suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings deprived of their liberty, as well as the right to provisional and even definitive admission to legal aid for wanted persons subject to proceedings executing the European arrest warrant.  In order for this principle to be implemented, there must be greater harmonisation of mutual criminal justice systems, including provisions to protect the rights of suspects and defendants. It is also important to stress the possibility of replacing the official defender with a trusted one.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it marks a new stage in the development of a European criminal law, this time in terms of the standardisation of legal aid. However, I believe that criminal justice is and must remain a prerogative of the

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. This directive aims to expand access to legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted deprived of their liberty, and to harmonize this scheme at European level. By strengthening the procedural rights of European citizens, we are moving towards the Europe of Justice. This is an important step towards achieving a real common judicial space worthy of the name! I therefore voted in favour of the De Jong report for the adoption of this directive at first reading.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings and for persons whose surrender is requested as part of the European Arrest Warrant proceedings. Here we are witnessing a new stage in the development of a European criminal law, when it is a competence of the Member States.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. This is very clearly yet another attempt to develop a European criminal law. The Commission, aided in this by the work of the LIBE Committee, is insidiously biting on the competences of the Member States, which I cannot accept. Indeed, with this directive, Member States should ensure that legal aid is paid at all stages of the criminal proceedings, or that accreditation is put in place to ensure probity and independent of duty counsel. I cannot condone such interference by the European Union in the affairs of States, which is moreover in a regal area, namely justice. I voted strongly against this text.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it states that a rule should be included in the Directive which, as far as possible, should take into account the preference and wishes of suspects or accused persons and wanted persons with regard to the choice of their ex officio lawyer. The same is true of the need for continuity in legal representation, if the suspect, accused or sought so desires. There must also be a rule for the replacement of the ex officio lawyer, if the suspect, accused or wanted person has lost confidence in the lawyer and may motivate him for verifiable reasons, since that rule does not even appear in the Recommendation. The report takes into account the differences between Member States in relation to the quality of legal assistance they offer. It states that taking into account differences in income and cost levels between Member States, it is not possible to lay down rules on the level of fees. However, the report stresses that this makes it even more important to include at least certain guarantees as to the quality of legal assistance provided for in the Directive.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I understand that access to justice is a fundamental right, and this is what is reflected in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. The only way to ensure access to this right on an equal footing is through free justice which does not exist in the Union today. The original report contained some very positive elements which would go in this direction, but after negotiations with the Council it has been greatly weakened, as many of the Member States do not guarantee this right. With the text presented, only persons in a situation of deprivation of liberty would be covered by this type of assistance. We understand that this is an improvement on the current situation of unprotection, but clearly insufficient, contrasting markedly with the position adopted at the time by the European Parliament, so I have decided to abstain.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The objective of this proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council is to lay down common basic rules on the right to provisional legal aid for suspects or accused persons who are deprived of their liberty in criminal proceedings and on provisional legal assistance and legal assistance to persons subject to the European detention procedure.  The Council and the European Parliament stressed the importance of establishing common basic rules to ensure a minimum level of legal assistance in all Member States. I give my positive vote as these rules would strengthen the mutual trust of the Member States in the criminal systems of others, which is essential for the application of the principle of mutual recognition of judgments and judgments, a pillar on which judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the Union is based.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. This report, which is the result of negotiations with the Council and the Commission, supports provisional and regular legal aid for suspects and accused persons and advocates minimum standards in court proceedings. The ALFA believes that minimum standards such as the right to translation, the presumption of innocence and access to a lawyer are correct and that they cannot be effectively regulated at national level because of the free movement of persons within the EU. Personally, I see these standards as a matter of course and fair treatment for an individual and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which provides rules on access to ordinary legal aid.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. Although I do not agree with the existence of a European arrest warrant, according to which states are obliged to extradite persons for prosecution abroad. However, when a European arrest warrant exists, I support the right of the accused arrestees to a lawyer and a fair trial.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. I am in favour of legal aid to suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings. Money should not be a barrier to access justice. Legal aid is an expression of the principle of subsidiarity in the legal field. I agree that the field of application of the Directive should also be extended outside of those who are subject to a European arrest warrant. Providing legal aid does not necessarily mean providing financial resources. In this regard, the Commission should communicate with Member States regarding the work of pro bono legal assistance offered to people undergoing criminal proceedings.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Article 6. Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms and Article 14 of the The International Agreement on Civil and Political Rights recognises the right to legal aid to persons who do not have sufficient resources to pay for it themselves. The purpose of this Directive is to ensure the effectiveness of the right of access to a lawyer as set out in Directive 2013/48/EU of the European Parliament and the Council so that Member States finance the services of lawyers for suspects or accused persons and for requested persons in surrender proceedings.  This Directive upholds the fundamental rights and principles recognised in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the European Convention on Human Rights, including the prohibition of torture, the right to freedom and security, an effective remedy, a fair trial, the presumption of non-compliance and the right to defend itself. In order to ensure the effectiveness and quality of legal aid, Member States must take the necessary measures to ensure that the standard of legal aid services provided is sufficiently high to protect the right to a fair trial. In any event, this Directive applies in full when a suspect or accused person is deprived of liberty, irrespective of the stage of criminal proceedings.  This proposal is a step in ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The main aim of this proposal is to set out common minimum rules governing the right to provisional legal aid for suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings. The draft directive aims to:  ensure the effectiveness of the right of access to a lawyer at an early stage in the criminal proceedings for suspects and accused persons deprived of liberty; ensure that requested persons in European arrest warrant proceedings have access to legal aid to ensure the right of access to a lawyer in both the executing and issuing Member State. The EP suggested broadening the scope of the proposal to include the right to ‘ordinary’ legal aid to suspects and individuals charged in criminal proceedings, as well as for those whose surrender is sought in the context of the execution of a European arrest warrant. I voted in favour and I think that is very important to make this protection framework not lower than existing higher standards in certain Member States and the standards in the Charter and the European Convention on Human Rights.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the EU is based on the principle of mutual recognition of judgments and other judicial decisions. In practice, however, member countries' internal procedures differ. This has created the need to establish a minimum level of protection for persons without reducing the higher protection afforded by individual Member States. The proposed Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on preliminary legal assistance for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and on legal assistance in European arrest warrant proceedings regulates the right to minimum legal aid in all Member States, the right of access to a lawyer and a fair trial. Member States shall ensure that suspects, accused persons and requested persons have effective remedies in cases of infringement of their rights under this Directive, such as the right to judicial review. I support the proposal because it guarantees a minimum level of protection for persons in criminal matters, which will certainly help to eliminate unjustified and unlawful prosecution, investigation and conviction.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of their liberty and legal assistance in procedures for the execution of the European arrest warrant, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 4 October 2016 and because I consider this report to be complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This text wants to extend the right to legal aid: from "temporary" aid, it would be "ordinary" for suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings. This would also be the case for persons whose surrender is requested as part of a procedure relating to the execution of a European arrest warrant. Furthermore, the text requires Member States to ensure that a number of measures are put in place: that ordinary aid be in force at all stages of the criminal procedure, that systems guaranteeing the quality and independence of court-appointed lawyers are put in place, etc. Thus, it is a real European criminal law that is being put in place, which we are opposed to.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ To comply with the Union’s core values, I voted in favour of the report on provisional legal aid for suspects, which grants the suspects with the right to request aid, for example, access to a lawyer in case a European arrest warrant has been issued. The Commission made the decision of proposing a step that ensures a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. The Parliament looks forward to cooperate with the Commission to make sure that certain measures be adopted as soon as possible.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the proposal for an EP and Council directive on temporary legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of their liberty and legal assistance in procedures for the execution of the European arrest warrant because the right to a fair trial is included and recognised, inter alia, in Article 47 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and also in Article 6 of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. In addition, the scope of the Directive should include the right to temporary but also to ordinary legal aid. I also believe that it is necessary for the accused to have legal certainty as regards the eligibility criteria as well.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The fundamental intention behind this report, to ensure certain minimum standards of the Rule of Law within the Union, is understandable. However, I see little need for action here; as long as the right to a fair trial guaranteed by Article 6 of the ECHR is satisfied, there is no need to move forward with the centralisation of the EU. Furthermore, each Member State should be able to determine the legal form of legal aid itself. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the European Commission's proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal assistance for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and legal assistance in procedures for the execution of a European arrest warrant.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Article 82 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (FUE Treaty) provides that judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the Union is based on the principle of mutual recognition of judicial judgments and decisions. Implementation of this principle presupposes mutual trust of Member States in their respective criminal justice systems, including how the rights of suspects or persons prosecuted are protected.  In practice, however, national practices are varied in this regard. Also in 2013 the European Commission adopted a directive on legal aid to ensure the right to a fair trial, as recognised in particular by Article 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. This report sets out how it will be implemented. Thus, it ensures that "the provision of an interpreter" is integrated into legal aid. Or it details cases in which "Member States can provide, as an exception, the reimbursement of the costs of provisional legal aid." I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. While the Commission's proposal would only guarantee the right to 'provisional' legal aid, the LIBE Committee suggested broadening the scope of the proposed directive to include the right to 'ordinary' legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings as well as for persons whose surrender is requested as part of a procedure relating to the execution of a European arrest warrant. I voted against this new step in the development of a European criminal law, when it is a competence of the Member States.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and the Council aims to establish a set of common minimum standards on the right of suspects or accused persons to provisional legal aid in criminal proceedings, if deprived of liberty, and the right to legal aid, provisional or otherwise, of persons subject to the proceedings provided for in Framework Decision 2002/584/JAI on the European arrest warrant ('wanted persons'). The directive aims to ensure that suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings who are deprived of liberty and persons subject to proceedings for the execution of European arrest warrants have access to legal aid to make effective their right of access to a lawyer, as provided for in the Directive on this matter. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this legislative resolution as it seeks to enhance citizens’ rights particularly by strengthening the procedural rights of suspected and accused persons in criminal proceedings.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. After two years of negotiations, I am pleased that the European Parliament has just adopted a new directive on the right to legal aid. The right of access to a lawyer is a fundamental right guaranteed by European legislation. However, as we know, in practice, this right is not accompanied by measures to make it effective.  For lack of resources, some people may find themselves alone in the face of the charges against them. I refuse to endorse a two-tiered justice system. We had to ensure the effectiveness of legal aid systems in the Member States. The European Union had to set a minimum floor to be respected. The façade systems, which exist only on paper, must stop. Of course I would have preferred to go one step further by fully aligning the right of access to a lawyer with the right to legal aid.  That was not possible. Unfortunately, the legislation is limited to guaranteeing legal aid in situations of deprivation of liberty. But let's be clear, this must include the interrogation period. We cannot allow people to be subjected to questions from the police without the right to a pro deo lawyer.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The European Union has long sought to strengthen cooperation in areas such as mutual recognition of judgments and criminal matters. The sphere of judicial cooperation necessarily includes the creation of a common framework for the rights of accused persons or persons deprived of liberty. I believe that harmonisation in the form of a european standard of human rights is in demand in this regard. EU legislation has been improving the criminal laws of individual Member States for a long time, but there is still room for improvement. One of the weaknesses is the realisation of the right to guaranteed legal aid – provisional, orderly and in all circumstances. However, we also need to remember the practical aspects of guaranteeing effective legal aid, such as the remuneration of solicitors, when drafting legislation. The financial possibilities of citizens vary considerably from one Member State to another, so it is important to eliminate the risk of neglect of clients who are not sufficiently solvent from the point of view of a solicitor. The present report addresses this sensitive issue, so I express my support for it.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which lays down common minimum rules on legal aid for suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings, and for those persons who are the subject of a European Arrest Warrant, with the aim of strengthening mutual trust and, thus, mutual recognition in criminal matters. The Directive will complete the current procedural rights package, which was and is a key component in creating an Area of Freedom, Security and Justice.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal aid for suspects and accused people deprived of their liberty and legal aid in proceedings relating to the European arrest warrant was adopted by the European Commission on 27 November 2013. The right to legal aid is inextricably linked to the right to access to a lawyer. For those who do not have the necessary financial means, only legal aid can ensure the exercise of the right to access to a lawyer. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs proposes that Parliament adopt the proposal at first reading with 45 amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. We consider that criminal law and procedure are at the heart of the powers that Member States must retain. The various rules proposed here to regulate legal aid within the framework of the European Arrest Warrant, whatever their merits, go against this conviction and our commitment to the legal sovereignty of States in criminal matters. For this reason of principle, we oppose this text.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal deals with provisional legal aid for suspects or defendants deprived of liberty and legal aid in proceedings for the execution of European arrest warrants. Legal aid can guarantee the effective exercise of the right of access to a lawyer for whom it does not have the necessary financial means.  I endorse the rapporteur's position by considering that defendants, suspects or persons wanted may feel inhibited from seeking legal aid if Member States can demand the costs of provisional legal aid for not meeting the eligibility criteria. In this way, it seems fair to limit the recovery of costs to cases where defendants, suspects or persons sought intentionally provide false information. I believe that the scope of the Directive should cover the right to provisional and ordinary legal aid in all circumstances. The Directive should therefore have the same scope as Directive 2013/48/EU on the right of access to a lawyer.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This vote concerns legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings and for persons whose surrender is requested in the context of the European Arrest Warrant proceedings. This directive thus orders Member States to ensure that legal aid is provided at all stages of the criminal proceedings, that systems to ensure the quality and independence of court-appointed lawyers are put in place, or that any suspect has the right to apply for the replacement of the lawyer appointed by the court.  Considering that this is a new step in the development of a European criminal law, which bites on the exclusive competences of the Member States, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings and for persons whose surrender is requested as part of the European Arrest Warrant proceedings. The aim of this text is to establish common minimum standards, in particular to enable the effectiveness of the right of access to a lawyer for suspects and persons prosecuted, in all Member States with regard to legal aid in order to strengthen the procedural rights of European citizens.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure concerning legal aid for suspects and defendants in criminal proceedings and for persons wanted in proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant. The Commission's proposal is a positive step towards ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. Although there are differences between Member States as regards the quality of legal assistance offered, in particular for fees, there are guarantees in the directive to protect it.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I am convinced that everyone deserves a fair trial and high-quality judicial protection and should not be affected by any financial factors. We can actually achieve this by developing minimum standards within the framework of an EU directive. Let us recall that the directive on the right to interpretation and translation in criminal proceedings, which now seems natural, was launched in the same way years ago. I trust that the situation of defendants in need of legal aid will soon improve.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report because it has for priority the implementation of a mechanism which shall provide a decent level of legal aid within the Member States. Therefore, this will help ensure a legal mechanism based on mutual trust in each other’s justice systems between the Member States.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported Mr Young's report, as I believe that European citizens who are suspects, detained or accused in a given case, also those wanted on a European arrest warrant, should be able to have legal protection before the European courts, even when they do not have sufficient means to secure a legal remedy themselves whenever justice so requires.  I believe that the scope of the directive must cover both temporary and normal legal aid in all situations. In order to ensure the quality of legal aid granted, States must take the necessary measures to ensure the quality of the service provided with regard to legal aid and to ensure the proper application of the legislation in a fair trial. The various interpretations of the right to a 'fair trial', including through legal aid recognised in Article 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and Article 6 of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, hinder the provision of cooperation with regard to criminal procedures. This is the reason why the draft legal aid directive must be adopted as soon as possible.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported by vote the report adopted today because the right to access a lawyer is a fundamental one, which ensures the conditions for a fair trial. In this respect, today's report concerns the new directive which will include both the right to free and ordinary legal aid in all circumstances. I am in favour of this report because it includes a provision which will also be contained in the Directive and which will include the possibility of replacing the public defender if, for good reason, the suspect or defendant or the wanted person has completely lost confidence in him.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP-Council Agreement at first reading, which strengthens the rights of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings who have been deprived of liberty and those on which a European arrest warrant has been issued by providing them with access to legal aid in the early stages of criminal proceedings where they are most vulnerable. It leaves it to the Member States to decide who fulfils the conditions for granting legal aid and allows Member States to recover costs if the person is not entitled to legal aid. Unlike the Commission's original proposal, the scope of the Directive was extended to ordinary legal aid and not only to provisional legal aid. I welcome the inclusion of a review of property conditions and the justification that can be used to determine whether a person is entitled to legal aid. The purpose of the review of property conditions is to assess whether a person actually lacks the means to pay for legal aid, while the examination of the justification makes it possible to assess whether the granting of legal aid in the light of the circumstances of the case is in the interests of justice.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report as this would be a further step towards centralisation. In addition, legal aid already exists in Austria.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim of the Directive is to lay down common minimum standards in criminal proceedings. The practices of the rights to process criminal proceedings differ in the practice of the Member States, and in order to harmonise them, the Commission is taking steps to ensure that the right to high-quality and legal aid is unambiguously accessible to all suspects and accused persons.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. I believe that uniform rules must apply throughout the EU to suspects or accused persons with a restricted freedom and to legal aid in the context of the European arrest warrant procedure. These rules will strengthen the rights of suspects and accused persons and establish common minimum standards on the rights to a fair trial. It should be noted that in the Member States, persons requested under the European arrest warrant do not always have access to legal aid. Moreover, regardless of the rights of suspects or accused persons, there is disproportionate damage to judicial cooperation. It is therefore essential to remove existing barriers and to strengthen mutual trust between judicial authorities and to facilitate the application of the principle of mutual recognition. It should be noted that judicial cooperation must be based on mutual trust and trust in the different judicial systems.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed agreement will establish common minimum rules on legal assistance to suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings, as well as to persons subject to the European arrest warrant, with a view to strengthening mutual trust and, therefore, mutual recognition in criminal matters. The directive will complete the current package of procedural rights, which were and are key components for the creation of an area of freedom, security and justice. Extending the scope to cover all kinds of legal aid in criminal proceedings, and not just 'temporary' legal aid, is a victory.  Furthermore, the right of persons subject to a European arrest warrant to be entitled to legal aid from a lawyer both in the Member State issuing the arrest warrant and in the Member State executing the arrest warrant is undoubtedly of paramount importance. For all these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Directive on legal aid for defendants who cannot afford access to a lawyer, including those arrested under the 'European extradition warrant', fully responds to the popular saying 'to burn you, John, to rub you with oil'. At a time when repressive mechanisms are being strengthened in the EU and its Member States (e.g. with the new Regulation on Europolice) and new ones are being created, such as the 'European Coast Guard and Border Guard', the EU institutions are pretending to be interested in the rights which they are stiflingly restricting with a giant grid of repression. The directive pursues two main EU objectives, firstly, to try to embellish the vast web of repression and the beating of popular freedoms, with the first aim of the labour-grassroots movement and, secondly, to impose a single system of EU criminal law rules with the same objective.  Its civil liberties, individual, social and democratic rights, including those of the actual exercise of power, the working people will only be able to enjoy them when they take power into their own hands, clashing with the monopolies, their associations, their mechanisms and the exploitative system they serve.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have abstained on this legislative report. UKIP supports the right to access to legal aid for suspects and accused persons. However, as the UK Government has chosen to opt out of this directive, we do not feel the need to cast opinion on legislation that does not affect the UK.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague's proposal because I believe that it is essential to guarantee the effectiveness of the right to use a lawyer, thus ensuring that it is the Member States that provide the necessary assistance to those who are deprived of their personal freedom from the initial stages of criminal proceedings or in the case of proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant. The European Union has always been at the forefront of the protection of human rights, rights which, in order to be defined as such, must necessarily be guaranteed even in the presence of a procedure. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this dossier because I believe it enhances the rights for citizens and make the text clearer, in particular with the inclusion of the right to ordinary legal aid and not only to provisional legal aid. Furthermore, I consider very important the inclusion of a means test and a merits test, which may be used to determine whether a person is eligible for legal aid.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposal for a directive on temporary legal assistance for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and legal aid in proceedings under a European arrest warrant. Judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the Union should be based on the principle of mutual recognition of judgments and judicial decisions. The implementation of this principle presupposes that Member States have confidence in each other's criminal justice systems, including how the rights of suspects accused persons are protected.  This is a welcome step in ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. The right to free legal aid is closely linked to the right of access to a lawyer, and for those who lack the necessary financial resources, only free legal assistance can ensure the right of access to a lawyer. It is important that the accused, suspects or wanted persons receive a certain measure of legal certainty relating to eligibility criteria. The eligibility criteria set out in the Commission Recommendation provide clarity but do not bring full harmonisation. This seems justified, as it would simply be impossible and unnecessary to enter detailed European legislation, given the differences between Member States as regards the costs of legal proceedings.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. While the Commission's proposal would only guarantee the right to "provisional" legal aid, the LIBE Committee suggested broadening the scope of the proposed directive to include the right to "ordinary" legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings as well as for persons whose surrender is requested as part of a procedure relating to the execution of a European arrest warrant. We are witnessing a new stage in the development of a European criminal law, when it is a competence of the Member States. Only the democratic institutions of a sovereign people should be able to change criminal law. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of minimum standards of legal aid for suspects and defendants in criminal proceedings and for persons subject to a European arrest warrant is a key step forward. By helping to strengthen mutual trust and, consequently, mutual recognition in criminal matters, the directive complements the current procedural rights package, which is a key element in the creation of a common area of freedom, security and justice. The final good text is also the result of the work carried out by the S&D Group, which has succeeded in broadening the scope of the directive by extending legal aid to all cases and not just, as the Commission wanted, to provisional admission to legal aid. In addition, it has been possible to assert the right of a person subject to a European arrest warrant to legal aid both in the Member State issuing the warrant and in the Member State executeing.  At a time when there is a proliferation of legal instruments to combat terrorism and other forms of crime, a Union based on the rule of law needs procedures and rights guaranteed for all. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The Commission's proposal is an important step in ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. However, the Commission's proposal is limited to the right to temporary legal assistance for a suspect or defendant in criminal proceedings deprived of liberty, as well as the right to temporary legal aid and legal assistance for wanted persons in proceedings under a European arrest warrant. Parliament's most important achievement is to extend the directive to all legal aid cases, not just temporary legal aid as proposed by the Commission. It is also a great victory for the S&D group that advocated such an approach. I support the adoption of this report, as we will finally have some rules on legal aid that will apply in all criminal proceedings across the EU, because at a time when the focus is on the fight against terrorism, the protection of fundamental human rights must not be forgotten.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The general orientation set by the Commission proposal is limited in its content despite improving the existing legal protection framework. We point out as less positive technical elements of conditioning this guarantee to the financial condition of the person concerned, along with an assessment of the merits, that is, the assessment of the interest of justice, situations that are included in the committee's proposal and which stand out with greater assertiveness in the proposal presented by the European Parliament, thus demonstrating the presence of some mechanisms that place limitations on ensuring universality in access to justice. The presence of a non-regression clause cautions that rights and guarantees enshrined in any Member State that provide for a higher level of protection, as is the case with Portugal, cannot be derogated from or limited. A proposal which falls far short of what the PRC enshrines in Article 20(1) of this: "Access to the law and courts is guaranteed access to the law and courts to defend their legally protected rights and interests, and justice cannot be denied by insufficient economic means". We also note that no reference is made to what have been the political options that in many countries, as in Portugal, have deepened structural problems of the justice system.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 Within the framework of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the Union should be based on the principle of mutual recognition of judgments and judicial decisions. Nevertheless, in practice, the procedures of individual Member States in this respect are shown to be very different. This problem therefore constitutes a major obstacle to mutual and effective judicial cooperation. I therefore very much welcome the Commission's proposal, which should harmonise minimum levels of legal aid in all Member States. At the same time, I am also very glad that the Commission's original proposal has been extended to all types of legal aid in criminal matters. I also supported the requirement that persons who are subject to a European arrest warrant should have the right to legal aid and to a lawyer both in the Member State issuing the arrest warrant and in the person executing the arrest warrant.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 On 27 November 2013, the European Commission adopted a proposal for a directive on provisional admission to legal aid for suspects or defendants deprived of personal liberty and on admission to legal aid in proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant.  Judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the Union, based on the principle of mutual recognition of judgments and judicial decisions, is, in my view, one of the most important aspects of the European area of freedom and justice. This report addresses a number of issues relating to the scope of the directive. The Commission's proposal is a positive step towards ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. I therefore voted in favour of its approval.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings and for persons whose surrender is requested as part of the European Arrest Warrant proceedings. This text is positive because it strengthens the procedural rights of European citizens through the implementation of common minimum standards in EU Member States.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have abstained on this legislative report. UKIP supports the right to access to legal aid for suspects and accused persons. However, as the UK Government has chosen to opt out of this directive, we do not feel the need to cast opinion on legislation that does not affect the UK.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 The implementation of mutual recognition of judgments and judicial decisions presupposes that each Member State relies on the criminal justice systems of the other Member States, including how the rights of suspects or accused persons are safeguarded. Differences in the interpretation of the right to an impartial court constitute an obstacle to justice and the effectiveness of cooperation in criminal matters.  In this way, the Commission's proposal is an important step towards ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States.
