The rapporteur considers that the current approach may reflect the sensitivity of the matter, but does not increase legal certainty or make it clear to suspects or accused persons to what extent they will actually be entitled to legal aid or what the quality of legal aid will be.  It also considers that defendants, suspects or wanted persons may feel inhibited from seeking legal aid if Member States can demand the costs of provisional legal aid for not meeting the eligibility criteria.  Finally, the rapporteur considers that Member States have difficulty collecting data on the implementation of the Directive for each individual case.  In this context, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. At noon, MEPs added a stone to the edifice of European justice policy. The compromise reached on 30 June 2016 with the Council on the proposed directive on legal aid grants many rights to litigants. Too often in practice, this right is not accompanied by measures to make it effective. In the absence of resources, some people may find themselves alone in the face of the charges against them, which can weaken the application of the presumption of innocence. Fortunately, the determination of the European Parliament's negotiators has paid off, as the directive adopted includes, among other things, the provision ensuring that legal aid is guaranteed during all criminal judicial proceedings. In another victory, the police and the prosecutor's office will have a very limited role in the appointment of the pro deo lawyer. It would have been paradoxical for the police to be able to both investigate a person and at the same time make decisions about the defence of that person.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 We must continue to work towards strengthening the rights of suspects and accused persons by establishing common minimum standards on the right to a fair trial. The existence of common minimum standards governing these rights will help to increase mutual trust between judicial authorities, thereby facilitating the application of the principle of mutual recognition. It is essential that there is a degree of compatibility between the laws of the Member States in order to improve judicial cooperation in the Union. These minimum rules should also take into account the differences between the traditions and legal systems of the Member States.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I supported the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on provisional legal aid to suspects or accused persons deprived of their liberty and to legal aid in the European arrest warrant procedure. The report, which is a proposal for an agreement at first reading, takes into account the differences between Member States as to the quality of legal assistance they offer and the need to include guarantees on the quality of legal assistance referred to in the Directive. Thanks to the amendments introduced by the Socialist group, the report affects legal aid and the expansion of the covered area covering all types of legal assistance in criminal proceedings.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposed directive on legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted, as well as legal aid in the context of the European Arrest Warrant proceedings. The Commission's proposal is an important step towards ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States.  Other aspects of the right to legal aid were included in a separate recommendation from the Commission. It took a long time to propose the current instruments, which is why the remaining measures in the roadmap, including the draft legal aid directive, must be adopted as soon as possible.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. It deals with temporary legal assistance for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and legal aid measures in european arrest warrant proceedings. The different interpretation of the right to a fair trial, including the right to legal aid recognised in Article 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and Article 6 of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, creates obstacles to the exercise of fair and effective judicial cooperation in criminal matters. It is therefore necessary to adopt as soon as possible the remaining measures of the Action Plan and, in particular, the draft directive on legal aid.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 It is in the initial phase of the process, especially when deprived of liberty, that suspects or accused are in a situation of greater vulnerability and in greater need of legal assistance.  This proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and the Council aims to strengthen the rights of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings by creating common minimum standards governing these rights, helping to increase mutual trust between judicial authorities. It is therefore essential that there is compatibility between the laws of the Member States to improve judicial cooperation in the Union. However, the approach initially proposed did not increase legal certainty or make it clear to suspects or defendants to what extent they will be entitled to legal aid or what the quality of legal aid will be, so the right to support should be included in all circumstances.  It was considered relevant to also include in the Directive the provision that the preference/will of suspects or accused persons should be taken into account, as far as possible, as regards the choice of lawyer, and that it should be replaced in the event of a loss of confidence.  I voted in favour of the proposal put forward by the rapporteur, I voted in favour of it.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on provisional legal aid for suspects and persons deprived of their liberty, as well as legal aid in the context of the European Arrest Warrant proceedings. Parliament's position goes beyond the Commission's proposal. The aim is to establish common minimum rules on the right to legal aid throughout the criminal proceedings. This report ensures that the right of access to a lawyer is guaranteed for suspects and persons deprived of their liberty, without undue delay.  The aim of this text is to strengthen the Europe of justice by expanding the European instruments relating to the procedural rights of European citizens.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote we approved legal aid in all Member States in favour of suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings deprived of personal liberty. More specifically, this is a provisional admission to legal aid, since the Member States in the Council did not wish to give more rights for purely economic matters.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to improve the rights of defendants or defendants in criminal proceedings. Having common minimum standards governing these rights should promote mutual trust between judicial authorities and thus facilitate the application of the principle of mutual recognition. A certain degree of compatibility between Member States' legislation is essential to improve judicial cooperation in the Union. Thanks to the work of the rapporteur of our group, significant improvements have been made to the Commission's proposal; inter alia, extend the scope beyond deprivation of liberty, allowing provisional and ordinary legal assistance in all circumstances. It is important to note that it reflects aspects such as that the initial phase of the proceedings, especially when defendants or defendants are deprived of their liberty, is the time when they are most vulnerable and when they need the legal assistance of a lawyer most. In the trilogue negotiations, the work done in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs suffered some setbacks because of the Council's resistance. Still, it is a significant step forward. I therefore vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on provisional legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty, as well as legal aid in proceedings for the execution of a European arrest warrant. It contains some amendments to the Directive, which was presented by the Commission in 2013. They aim to strengthen citizens' rights by extending the scope of the directive.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I understand that access to justice is a fundamental right, and this is what is reflected in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. The only way to ensure access to this right on an equal footing is through free justice which does not exist in the Union today. The original report contained some very positive elements which would go in this direction, but after negotiations with the Council it has been greatly weakened, as many of the Member States do not guarantee this right. With the text presented, only persons in a situation of deprivation of liberty would be covered by this type of assistance. We understand that this is an improvement on the current situation of unprotection, but clearly insufficient, contrasting markedly with the position adopted at the time by the European Parliament, so I have decided to abstain.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this because the UK Government has opted out of this scheme.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted for the draft directive on legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and legal aid in European arrest warrant proceedings. This is one of a set of proposals intended to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the legal aid system exists in all EU Member States, a comparison of national legal aid systems shows that there are fundamental differences in the philosophy, organisation and management of legal aid systems in the Member States. I am glad that, despite these differences between Member States (quality of legal aid, fees granted to a lawyer for legal aid, differences in income and costs), minimum rules are laid down in order to facilitate, to the extent necessary, the mutual recognition of judgments and other judicial decisions, as well as police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters having a cross-border dimension. I also supported the draft legislative resolution because I consider ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States to be a very positive step. Although the Commission's proposal is limited to the right to preliminary legal aid for suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings who are deprived of liberty covered by the European arrest warrant procedure, I believe that the Member States will do their best to ensure that effective preliminary legal aid is available to everyone without undue delay before any procedural step that must be taken under national or European law is taken in the presence of a lawyer.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a directive on provisional legal aid. The report, as amended, reflects the reality of the criminal process and the practical aspects related to the provision of free legal aid better than the original proposal. In particular, I appreciate the extension of the directive's material scope to the usual legal aid and not only to provisional legal aid, which applies only to the first stage of criminal proceedings before a final decision on legal aid is taken. The right to legal aid will now be ensured not only at the initial stage, but at all stages of the criminal proceedings. Only in this way can the right to a fair trial be fully guaranteed throughout the criminal proceedings. I also support the inclusion of a review of the property circumstances of persons and the justification for legal aid. Only then can it be assessed whether a person's funds to pay for legal aid are actually lacking or whether the granting of legal aid is in the interests of justice. The proposal also complements the basic rules of interpretation for such an assessment and the possibility for Member States to recover legal aid costs provided where persons do not meet the criteria for granting it or have deliberately provided false information to the competent authorities about their financial situation.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The Directive on temporary legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and persons in proceedings under the European arrest warrant contains minimum harmonised rules on when and how Member States are obliged to pay for legal representation in those situations. The report mentions, in particular, situations in which a Member State will ensure that legal representation is paid when an individual cannot afford it, and lays down minimum rules for such situations. This Directive will harmonise eu-wide rules for determining the cases in which an individual acquires the right to legal aid. At the same time, exceptions are also provided for minor offences or offences, alcohol verification procedures and the like. The directive to which this report refers will be part of the wider context of legislative proposals by the European Commission, which aim to strengthen the procedural rights of suspects or accused persons. As the report foresees the harmonisation of the rules and the introduction of common standards in this area, I have decided to support it.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. This report, which is the result of negotiations with the Council and the Commission, supports provisional and regular legal aid for suspects and accused persons and advocates minimum standards in court proceedings. The ALFA believes that minimum standards such as the right to translation, the presumption of innocence and access to a lawyer are correct and that they cannot be effectively regulated at national level because of the free movement of persons within the EU. Personally, I see these standards as a matter of course and fair treatment for an individual and have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Every citizen of the European Union has the right to a fair trial and assistance in the event of an investigation or prosecution. We are extending the right of deprived persons to access lawyers and unifying the rules for providing free legal aid to those who cannot afford their own lawyer.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on provisional legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty, as well as on legal aid in proceedings for the execution of a European arrest warrant. Legal aid fulfils an important function. However, there is no reason to regulate them uniformly across the EU. If individual Member States are to be required to make up for a lack of non-existent rules and finally to introduce appropriate rules, then this is a lack of the rule of law that should have gone in the way of these states joining the EU. Or, if this is not a condition for accession to the EU, then it does not need to be regulated in a uniform MANNER in the EU. Accordingly, the Commission's justification for its proposal is poor. It justifies the need for an EU regulation by arguing that the Member States have different rules here. However, this is not a shortcoming, but rather a welcome expression of the different ideas of the respective national legislators. These differences must be welcomed, not leveled, in the spirit of subsidiarity and national autonomy.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. In 2013, the Commission adopted a proposal for a directive from Parliament and the Council on temporary legal assistance for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and legal assistance in proceedings under a European arrest warrant. The right to legal aid is closely linked to the right to defend it. Suspects and defendants who are in a more serious material condition should be allowed to defend themselves through free legal assistance. The right to legal aid and a fair trial is also guaranteed by the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. The Treaty on the Functioning of the EU provides for the judicial cooperation of Member States in criminal matters and mutual recognition of judicial decisions and judgments. However, the national practices of states vary from member to member. I support the report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on temporary legal assistance for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and legal aid in proceedings based on a European arrest warrant. The report is one step closer to achieving a guaranteed minimum of legal assistance and full harmonisation of the issue in all Member States.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal assistance for suspects or accused persons deprived of their liberty and persons in european arrest warrant proceedings. I support the amendment of the proposal for a directive that, under the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms and the International Covenant on Political and Civil Rights, they recognise the right to legal aid to those who do not have sufficient resources to pay for legal aid themselves, if the interests of justice so require. The Commission's proposal will thus give us a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal for a directive on provisional legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty in the context of proceedings relating to a European arrest warrant, as I believe that this is a balanced proposal which gives Member States sufficient scope to determine the conditions which are necessary for the granting of legal aid under this Directive. Access to legal aid is generally one of the prerequisites for due process and ultimately for the rule of law.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report on this directive because, in addition to the general assistance and legal assistance provided to suspects, defendants who are deprived of their liberty and to persons who are in the process of executing a European warrant, certain criteria are also proposed for the quality of the assistance to be provided. Establishing common minimum standards to safeguard one of the most basic rights of suspects or accused persons will strengthen mutual trust between judicial authorities and thus facilitate the application of the principle of mutual recognition.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States should not be limited to two categories, namely suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings who are deprived of their liberty and wanted persons subject to procedures relating to the execution of a European arrest warrant. Such a piecemeal approach neither enhances legal certainty nor makes clear the degree and quality of the right to legal aid.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal aid for suspects and accused persons deprived of their liberty and legal aid in proceedings relating to the European arrest warrant can be considered as part of the roadmap adopted on 30 November 2009 to strengthen the procedural rights of accused persons in criminal proceedings, with the aim of creating common minimum standards in the Member States. After difficult negotiations, the mutually acceptable text has emerged and, as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation, I am voting in favour of the initiative. In my view, a satisfactory compromise has been reached in the trialo-trial negotiations, which successfully contribute to the setting of common European minimum standards and do not impose a disproportionate burden on criminal proceedings.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 Legal certainty is one of the most important rights and guaranteeing equal legal protection in all Member States is a prerequisite for the recognition of criminal convictions. In matters of legal certainty, competence is in many respects with the Member States, and it is therefore absolutely essential that Parliament does not extend its report too far, while respecting human rights and guaranteeing everyone the right to a fair trial.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Cooperation in the judicial field is one of the chapters in which Member States still have a long way to go to harmonise regulations and practices. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides for respect for the principle of mutual recognition of judicial decisions and judicial decisions through mutual trust in the criminal judicial systems of the Member States. This principle also covers provisional legal aid for persons suspected or accused of being deprived of liberty and legal aid in the proceedings relating to the European Arrest Warrant. In practice, national systems differ, which affects respect for the right to free advice and legal aid, especially in the case of people who do not have the necessary financial resources. That is why the Commission's proposal to regulate this area is an important, but not sufficient, step towards ensuring a minimum level in all Member States. It boils down to persons suspected or indicted in criminal proceedings who are deprived of their liberty and to persons wanted who are the subject of the European arrest warrant. The difference between the fees of lawyers in the various Member States, the quality of public services and the lack of regulation of the preference of the suspect or defendant are subjects to be covered by the Commission Directive. I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The fragmented approach currently being pursued by the Commission may illustrate how sensitive the subject is, but it does not increase legal certainty and does not allow suspects or prosecuted persons to know to what extent they will benefit from the right to legal aid and the quality of legal assistance. Therefore, the scope of the directive should include legal aid, both provisional and ordinary, in all circumstances. In this regard, the scope of the directive should be identical to that of the 2013/48/EU directive on the right of access to a lawyer. Prosecuted persons, suspects and those who are requested for surrender may be reluctant to apply for legal aid, if Member States can claim interim legal aid expenses if they do not meet the eligibility criteria. It therefore seems legitimate to limit cost recovery to situations in which the suspect, the person being prosecuted or the person whose surrender is requested knowingly provided false information.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Enshrined in the European Convention of Human Rights, the right to legal aid and representation for all persons, regardless of their socio-economic position is a fundamental human right. This service is essential to strengthening the rights of suspects and accused persons. By establishing minimum rules on the protection of procedural rights of suspects or accused persons, the proposal aims to guarantee the effectiveness of the right of access to a lawyer at an early stage in the criminal proceedings for suspects, accused and vulnerable persons. I voted in favour of the proposal because I believe that, although all EU Member States have national legal aid schemes, this directive will mean that EU citizens have the same minimum rights wherever they are in the EU. Further, I believe that this directive represents a positive step to ensuring faire trials and access to justice for all EU citizens, not just those who can afford it.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I voted yes because I think this report represents a step in the right direction. The recognition of the same procedural guarantees and the rights of suspects in European arrest warrant procedures is an important step in building genuine cooperation in the area of justice and strengthening trust between members. The judicial cooperation so far has been only partial and has been characterised by insufficient mutual recognition of judicial authorities' decisions. After the introduction of temporary legal aid, we can expect a significant shift towards better cooperation, which will undoubtedly lead to a strengthening of mutual trust, which I wholeheartedly support.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary free legal assistance for suspects or accused persons who have been deprived of their liberty and persons in european arrest warrant proceedings. The Commission's proposal is a welcome step in ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States. The application is limited to the right to temporary legal aid for suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings deprived of their liberty, as well as the right to temporary legal aid and legal assistance for requested persons in European arrest warrant proceedings. In particular, inclusion in the Directive deserves the provision to take utmost account of the preferences and preferences of suspects or accused persons and requested persons when choosing a lawyer offering legal assistance.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to improve the rights of defendants or defendants in criminal proceedings. Having common minimum standards governing these rights should promote mutual trust between judicial authorities and thus facilitate the application of the principle of mutual recognition. A certain degree of compatibility between Member States' legislation is essential to improve judicial cooperation in the Union. Thanks to the work of the rapporteur of our group, significant improvements have been made to the Commission's proposal; inter alia, extend the scope beyond deprivation of liberty, allowing provisional and ordinary legal assistance in all circumstances. It is important to note that it reflects aspects such as that the initial phase of the proceedings, especially when defendants or defendants are deprived of their liberty, is the time when they are most vulnerable and when they need the legal assistance of a lawyer most. In the trilogue negotiations, the work done in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs suffered some setbacks because of the Council's resistance. Still, it is a significant step forward. I therefore vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. This report, which is the result of negotiations with the Council and the Commission, supports provisional and regular legal aid for suspects and accused persons and advocates minimum standards in court proceedings. The ALFA believes that minimum standards such as the right to translation, the presumption of innocence and access to a lawyer are correct and that it makes sense to introduce European minimum standards because of the free movement of persons within the EU.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. While the Commission's proposal would only guarantee the right to 'provisional' legal aid, the LIBE Committee suggested broadening the scope of the proposed directive to include the right to 'ordinary' legal aid for suspects and persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings as well as for persons whose surrender is requested as part of a procedure relating to the execution of a European arrest warrant. We are therefore witnessing a new stage in the development of a European criminal law, when it is a competence of the Member States. I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Decisions at European Union level should be taken in a rational and cost-effective manner. The directive, in the original proposal drawn up by the European Commission, made this request. It provided for the harmonisation of national procedures so as to guarantee legal aid for persons in the first stage of criminal proceedings, when they may be deprived of the actual possibility of using a lawyer, and in proceedings arising from a European arrest warrant. However, the legal solutions provided for in the directive as it stands go a step further and are not based on primary law. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides the basis only for minimum protection and not for the building of common criminal law provisions. Such broad regulation does not serve to build member states' confidence in the institutions of the European Union. For these reasons, I voted against the resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal seeks to lay the foundations for joint minimum legal assistance in respect of temporary legal aid for suspects and accused defendants deprived of their liberty and legal aid in proceedings relating to the European arrest warrant. I supported the adoption of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to improve the rights of defendants or defendants in criminal proceedings. Having common minimum standards governing these rights should promote mutual trust between judicial authorities and thus facilitate the application of the principle of mutual recognition. A certain degree of compatibility between Member States' legislation is essential to improve judicial cooperation in the Union. Thanks to the work of the rapporteur of our group, significant improvements have been made to the Commission's proposal; inter alia, extend the scope beyond deprivation of liberty, allowing provisional and ordinary legal assistance in all circumstances. It is important to note that it reflects aspects such as that the initial phase of the proceedings, especially when defendants or defendants are deprived of their liberty, is the time when they are most vulnerable and when they need the legal assistance of a lawyer most. In the trilogue negotiations, the work done in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs suffered some setbacks because of the Council's resistance. Still, it is a significant step forward. I therefore vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Free Legal Aid Directive to suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings and persons sought by the European arrest warrant procedure, as it provides harmonised minimum standards to ensure the effectiveness and right to access a lawyer and strengthen mutual trust, knowledge and mutual cooperation between Member States.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – The Directive should include a provision which should take into account, as far as possible, who suspects or accused persons and applicants give priority to, when appointing a lawyer providing legal aid and their wishes. The same applies to the need to continue legal representation if the suspect, accused person or requested person so requests.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on provisional legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and legal aid in European arrest warrant proceedings. According to Article 82 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the Union shall be based on the principle of mutual recognition of judgements and judicial decisions. The implementation of this principle presupposes that Member States put trust in each other’s criminal justice systems, including in the manner in which the rights of suspects of accused persons are safeguarded. In practice, however, national practices vary in this respect. For those who are lacking the necessary financial means, only legal aid can make the right to access to a lawyer effective. I voted in favour because I believe that the proposal of the Commission is a welcome step in ensuring a minimum level of legal aid in all Member States.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The analysis of the European Legal Assistance Directive (presented by the Commission in November 2013) began to be carried out by Parliament in 2014. At the end of June this year, agreement was reached with the Dutch Presidency to amend certain points of the Commission's original proposal. This report contains these amendments, which place particular emphasis on the scope of the implementation of the directive and the inclusion of media and merit reviews to become a beneficiary. The first provides for an extension, becoming not only provisionally assistance, but throughout the judicial process. While it is true that the final text has not been as ambitious as we expected — since, despite reaching all legal aid in criminal proceedings, its implementation is subject to national criteria that are not only based on the economic, but on merits – it stands as a first step towards future improvements that require more time to be accepted by those countries that would prefer to dispense with the proposal in its entirety. In this way, I considered it appropriate to vote in the affirmative.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I understand that access to justice is a fundamental right, and this is what is reflected in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. The only way to ensure access to this right on an equal footing is through free justice which does not exist in the Union today. The original report contained some very positive elements which would go in this direction, but after negotiations with the Council it has been greatly weakened, as many of the Member States do not guarantee this right. With the text presented, only persons in a situation of deprivation of liberty would be covered by this type of assistance. We understand that this is an improvement on the current situation of unprotection, but clearly insufficient, contrasting markedly with the position adopted at the time by the European Parliament, so I have decided to abstain.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report, which will assist in increasing Member State’s confidence in each other’s legal systems and ensure that in countries where virtually no legal aid exists, new and improved systems can be established. Once fully implemented by Member States, the Legal Aid Directive should give an important boost to social advocacy by strengthening the right to access a lawyer for those who do not have sufficient financial means. In addition, ensuring quick and effective legal representation from the start of proceedings. The UK has opted out of the proposal and will not be affected by this legislation.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'This Directive aims to ensure that the right of access to a lawyer can actually be exercised by suspects or defendants or persons wanted in surrender proceedings. Given that we live in a democracy and the rule of law, it is only natural that everyone should be entitled to legal aid in any circumstance. I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Judicial cooperation is gradually taking place within the European Union. It is based on the principle of mutual recognition of judgments and judicial decisions. This text complements a directive on the right to counsel (2013/48/EU) in order to advance the implementation of the right to a fair trial set out in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights by supplementing the right to counsel by the implementation of legal aid allowing all persons prosecuted, regardless of their financial situation, to be able to be assisted by a lawyer from the very beginning of the procedure until the end of the procedure, it is a minimum standard to which no Member State should be able to escape. Without such guarantees, European justice would retain a "censorious" character, including the European Convention on Human Rights.  I welcome the work of the rapporteur, my Dutch colleague, Dennis De Jong, who has worked to establish a genuine right to legal aid and not provisional legal aid as originally proposed by the Commission.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The right to legal aid is intrinsically linked to the right of access to a lawyer, for which the European Parliament and the Council adopted Directive 2013/48/EU of 22 October 2013. For those who do not have the necessary financial means, only legal aid can ensure the effective exercise of the right of access to a lawyer. Defendants, suspects or persons wanted may feel inhibited from seeking legal aid if Member States can demand the costs of provisional legal aid for non-complying with the eligibility criteria. It is fair to limit the recovery of costs to cases where defendants, suspects or persons sought intentionally provide false information. Overall, this report is moving in a generally positive sense, which we support. But it falls short of recognition, measures and concrete resources, which guarantee the universality of free access to legal and legal aid for defendants, as one of the most elementary rights to defence and dignity. We voted for it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The Commission's proposal for a directive on legal aid is a way of increasing unification and centralisation. The intention to ensure certain minimum standards of the rule of law within the Union is, of course, a move in the right direction; However, as long as the right to a fair trial guaranteed by Article 6 of the ECHR is satisfied, it should be left to the Member States themselves to legislate for legal aid. I have therefore abstained from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the advocacy of suspects or defendants deprived of personal liberty and on legal aid in proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant. One of the main objectives of the report is to establish common minimum standards for legal aid for suspects in criminal proceedings and for persons subject to a European arrest warrant with the aim of strengthening mutual trust and, in this way, mutual recognition in criminal matters, which is fundamental to the creation of an area of freedom , security and justice.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report, which will assist in increasing Member State’s confidence in each other’s legal systems and ensure that in countries where virtually no legal aid exists, new and improved systems can be established. Once fully implemented by Member States, the Legal Aid Directive should give an important boost to social advocacy by strengthening the right to access a lawyer for those who do not have sufficient financial means and will hopefully benefit women who often face barriers to accessing legal aid. In addition, this will ensure quick and effective legal representation from the start of proceedings. The UK has opted out of the proposal and will not be affected by this legislation.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Directive on legal aid for defendants who cannot afford access to a lawyer, including those arrested under the 'European extradition warrant', fully responds to the popular saying 'to burn you, John, to rub you with oil'. At a time when repressive mechanisms are being strengthened in the EU and its Member States (e.g. with the new Regulation on Europolice) and new ones are being created, such as the 'European Coast Guard and Border Guard', the EU institutions are pretending to be interested in the rights which they are stiflingly restricting with a giant grid of repression. The directive pursues two main EU objectives, firstly, to try to embellish the vast web of repression and the beating of popular freedoms, with the first aim of the labour-grassroots movement and, secondly, to impose a single system of EU criminal law rules with the same objective.  Its civil liberties, individual, social and democratic rights, including those of the actual exercise of power, the working people will only be able to enjoy them when they take power into their own hands, clashing with the monopolies, their associations, their mechanisms and the exploitative system they serve.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that every person should have the right to legal aid, whether or not he has sufficient resources to cover the financial costs. The European Union does not yet have uniform standards in this area, which can cause a number of problems that suspects and accused persons have to face. The presented directive clearly describes the process of granting legal aid, the financial demands or the quality assurance of legal aid. I support this directive because I believe that it will help to ensure better access to legal aid, but also to harmonise the system of criminal procedural law across the States of the European Union.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a directive on provisional legal aid for suspects or accused persons deprived of liberty and on legal assistance in European Arrest Warrant proceedings. This directive complements the directives already adopted on procedural rights in criminal proceedings, namely the Directive on the right to interpretation and translation, on the right to information and on the right of access to a lawyer. In particular, the main objective of this Directive is to lay down minimum standards to ensure that the basic level of the right to legal aid is respected in all Member States. I think that this directive is practically beneficial, as the situation with regard to the granting of either preliminary or regular legal aid varies from one Member State to another. At the same time, the setting of minimum standards will be particularly beneficial in terms of strengthening trust between Member States as well as recognising judicial decisions, as states will know that at least minimum common standards have been maintained in criminal proceedings.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the De Jong report for agreeing to the application of minimum rules on legal aid throughout the European Union. I would particularly stress that the European Socialist Group has achieved the extension of the scope of the Directive to cover all cases of legal aid and not only cases of provisional legal aid, but also provided for the original proposal of the European Commission. At a time when legal instruments in criminal and criminal matters are multiplying to combat terrorism, it is essential to remember that the European Union is based on the rule of law and that this translates into the harmonisation of fundamental and procedural principles of defence which must be guaranteed to suspects or accused of the commission of a crime.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal assistance lays down common minimum rules on the right to legal aid for suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings and persons in proceedings under a European arrest warrant (requested), irrespective of their legal status, nationality or nationality. The proposal for a directive supports the fundamental rights and principles recognised by the Charter and the ECHR, in particular the right to an effective remedy and the right to a fair trial, the presumption of innocence and the rights of the defence. In the light of the foregoing, I believe that the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on temporary legal assistance will make it possible to strengthen the procedural rights of suspects, accused or requested persons in criminal proceedings, which is why I supported it.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, what can the European Union do to stop the migration of people, the mass and increasingly unbearable migration to Europe, taking into account the rights of people who are in a miserable situation, as well as the rights of indigenous people in Europe. Well, primarily by treating the roots – wars, armed conflicts. And what would that take? It also prevents the financing of ISIS and other terrorist organizations. What would that take? The supply of weapons to a wide variety of dictatorships or proxy wars should be thoroughly monitored and prohibited by the Member States of the European Union or by such companies. More than that, any transactions that might be aimed at financing ISIS and other terrorist organizations should be carefully monitored - because someone is maintaining them. What are they doing instead? Hundreds of pages of documents are produced on the export of drugs capable of the death penalty. They control it, they regulate it, and they don't control the arms trade and they don't fund ISIS. That's not the answer.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, this report finally brings out the law, thriving business escarment sending products that can be used for executions, torture, degrading treatment, and those who wish to do such activities will finally be able to answer to the law. The regulation prohibits, for example, the use of single-use goods intended for torture or execution, and if they are goods with multiple functionalities, then there is an authorisation system precisely so that they cannot be used for executions or torture. Also, medicines need to be controlled precisely in order not to be used for lethal injections - it is the trade in these drugs. Very briefly, this report will lead to the abolition of the death penalty and torture around the world. Let's hope so.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported this amendment to the regulation. It seems logical to me that, at a time when the European Union and its institutions are leaders in the fight against the death penalty in the world and against the inhuman treatment of people, it makes sense that we are not only following political declarations and, say, criticism of countries that use the death penalty widely, but that we are also taking decisions – and that is today's decision – to really reduce the death penalty in the world. to reduce the treatment of people in the form of torture.  In my opinion, the prohibition of certain substances that can be used for the death penalty, certain goods and any restrictions on the trafficking of certain goods is a completely logical consequence of our policy against the death penalty. That is why I supported this regulation and consider it the right decision.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I was very pleased to support this resolution today and to vote with my group on all matters. This is very important and there is great credit due to Marietje Schaake, the rapporteur, for the good work she has done. It is somewhat incongruous that a European Union that is so committed to peace and human rights across the globe would also be exporting goods which could be used for torture and capital punishment. It is absolutely right that we should move to end that practice wherever it may be. I am pleased to say that in my own country, Ireland, there is no evidence of any such practice. There have been no applications made by Irish companies under the regulation and the Department of Jobs is not aware of any of those goods being either exported or imported. I hope that will become the norm across the European Union. We are trying to help in the whole area of human rights, and especially to end the death penalty, which is another manifestation of man’s inhumanity to man.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, indeed, if the European Union's foreign policy in the area of human rights defence is to have any particular practical significance and if the next concrete steps are to be reflected in our decision-making, this amendment to the regulation is undoubtedly necessary and necessary, and I am glad that I was also able to support it. The reason for this is that goods that can be used precisely for execution, that is, to deprive life, torture, to inhuman treatment, such goods should be penalised.  Since the adoption of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights, the European Area has been regarded as an area where the treatment of persons in an inhumane way is to be teded against. Of course, the death penalty is inadmissible. For this reason too, I repeat that I am glad to have been able to support this proposal.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, on the issue of capital punishment, I think my views are fairly well known. I am no fan of the death penalty in itself. At the same time, I believe it is the sovereign right of countries across the world to make their own decisions on that subject. So I do not believe it is appropriate for us to impose a particular worldview upon those nations. I do have some concerns about unintended consequences in that we could end up with a situation where methods used end up being more painful rather than less. If this report were about capital punishment alone, I might very well have voted against this report; but it is not. This report is also about torture and I recognise the very difficulties which the report and this legislation is trying to prevent and to protect against. Therefore overall I felt it was appropriate for me to abstain.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The regulation is intended to introduce catch-all and end-use clauses with the aim of prohibiting the export of goods intended for torture and medicines used in death sentences. Since I believe that we need a common approach between all Member States that allows for necessary and proportionate controls on medicinal products, but which do not involving additional costs that may restrict trade in goods with legitimate end-uses, I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new European legislation against business linked to torture and the death penalty, as a pioneering human rights initiative in the world. It introduces binding executive measures that will prevent any european participation in this appalling business. It strengthens the export ban and control introduced in 2006, making it more effective. And it extends its application to new products, such as drugs for lethal injection, and to services such as transportation, online advertising, technical assistance or commercial intermediation.  No foreign commercial agent may re-exhibit torture material at Union trade fairs. And the responsibility of the Member States in their duty of control and information is strengthened. When Spain assumed the presidency of the Council of the Union in 2010, the Socialist Government of Rodríguez-Zapatero called on the Union to reform in this regard. Today, the Union has taken a step further against torture and capital punishment, and the Social Democrats have been able to demonstrate that trade policy is and must be a fundamental tool for promoting progress and human rights in the world.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. UKIP objects to the EU dictating our terms of trade, so we would have been minded to vote against, however due to the sensitive nature of the report we did not oppose. There are practical problems in defining ‘items of torture’. Our concern in the future is that conventional and innocuous items could be added the list of restricted goods and may affect legitimate trade. UKIP of course condemns any form of torture.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report seeks to regulate trade in certain products that can be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or degrading treatment, which I consider very necessary and for this reason I voted in favour of the report. However, although I have supported the report with my vote, I believe that the Union has no credibility in the fight against torture as long as it continues to be subordinate to the United States (for example, there is evidence that torture has been routinely practiced at Guantanamo with complete impunity for 14 years). The report contains numerous proposals with which I fully agree, such as asking to ensure that Union exports to third countries do not contribute to what the Union considers to be 'inhuman' practices, such as electric chairs, or cage beds. But unfortunately the Union has no credibility in its so-called 'fight against torture' as long as we continue to profit from the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia, or as long as our partners have torture and the death penalty legalised. If we are really against torture, we should start by reviewing our relations with third countries, until they comply with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. This report is a good move. That of a Europe that proposes a global standard to eradicate torture.  The updated rules will help EU authorities respond more quickly to emerging trends in torture and inhuman treatment, including by regulating their online sales, etc.  In recent years, we have seen how a change in EU practices has led to the disappearance of the death penalty in many partner countries.  This effort is expected to continue once the regulations come into force.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In this way and with its updated rules, the European Union lays down universal standards for the eradication of torture.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Regulation (EC) No. 1236/2005 of June 2005 aims to prevent and prohibit all exports of material specially designed to inflict the death penalty, torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment (inflicted by a civil service officer or any other official except if it is legitimate sanctions) etc.  The European Commission proposes to make the following changes: restrictions and prohibitions are extended to brokerage services and transit when the broker knows that they could be used for torture...  The term torture and degrading treatment is overly extended, including prison overcrowding, lack of medical care, prohibition of contact with the outside world, etc.  Finally, the text is quite unenforceable because it does not speak of certainties or elements that goods or services would be used for torture or degrading elements but of "may serve...". The European Parliament therefore proposes to further harden this purely ideological text. So I voted against this report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. The Union must not relax its efforts to eliminate torture, by reducing the supply of material used to inflict ill-treatment, by preventing legislation from being turned or diverted, and by promoting effective controls across its borders.  Trade instruments are one element of a comprehensive strategy that uses all the UNION's external levers of action.  I therefore voted in favour of this resolution because it is essential to ensure the consistency of the Union's exports.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union can be hailed as one of the leading champions in the fight against the practice of torture and execution, which is why it should demonstrate that quality throughout one of its biggest activities – trade. This report urges to close all the loopholes that are present in the current trade strategy that allows for pharmaceuticals to travel in and out of the EU, and that are then misused for the purpose of torture or execution (such as lethal injection). It enforces both Annex II and III and establishes an urgency procedure or a ‘fast track,’ for future pharmaceuticals to be added to the lists of banned substances without a consequential delay. This report stresses the fact that in the case of other pharmaceuticals and medicines which are not on the list of possible torture and execution substances, their trade cannot and will not be hindered. This report is a milestone in Europe’s fight against the death penalty and the use of torture throughout the world. It provides a solid basis for Member States to work off and add on to, allowing the EU to uphold its values not only domestically but also internationally.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on trade in certain goods which could be used for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The eu's main instrument against torture and the death penalty is the rules for controlling trade in torture tools in 2005. They prohibit the export of goods (e.g. electric chairs, guillotine or automatic injection systems) and control the marketing of goods which may be used for these purposes (e.g. tools or materials used to quell riots). In 2010, the European Parliament called on the European Commission to update these rules, as certain legal loopholes have prevented restrictions on trade or advertising. In view of the European Parliament's calls, therefore, I agree with the need to ensure an appropriate mix of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external policies in order to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of goods for torture and to effectively control goods that can be used for life-threatening and inhumane purposes.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. UKIP objects to the EU dictating our terms of trade, so we would have been minded to vote against, however due to the sensitive nature of the report we did not oppose. There are practical problems in defining ‘items of torture’. Our concern in the future is that conventional and innocuous items could be added the list of restricted goods and may affect legitimate trade. UKIP, of course, condemns any form of torture.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Since June 2005, Regulation (EC) 1236/2005 governs trade in goods that can be used for capital punishment, torture, etc.  The purpose of this regulation is to prevent and prohibit the export of material specially designed to inflict the death penalty, torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment.  However, this new text seems to me to be unworkable because it extends this prohibition to any object "likely" to such use.  That is why I abstained.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Following the European Parliament's awareness-raising action since 2010, the Commission has launched a review of the EU's export control system with a view to strengthening the protection of human rights by subjecting to checks the goods and activities used, or likely to be misappropriated, to impose the death penalty, torture or other inhuman or degrading treatment.  This draft opinion of my colleagues in the INTA committee aims, in particular, to introduce a targeted end-use clause to enable Member States to ban or suspend the transfer of certain assets which clearly have no practical use other than that of imposing capital punishment, torture or other ill-treatment. They also propose a series of measures to ensure effective implementation of this regulation and the establishment of a periodic review mechanism. Considering that export controls are instruments of foreign trade policy that can contribute to the achievement of broader strategic objectives such as the abolition of the death penalty and the fight against torture, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time when the international context is seeing a proliferation of human rights violations, the European Union's action in this field must be even more decisive.  The Schaake report, which I supported today with my vote, lays down some important provisions that make it possible to overcome the difficulties that have been identified in the application of the 'anti-torture' regulation of 2005, a regulation that prohibits the export of goods that have only the use of capital punishment or torture as a practical use. Chains to immobilise people, torture tools and medicines for lethal injections must not be sold by European companies to third countries.  The approved text defines some key points of this strategy: the ban on the online sale and purchase of advertising services for prohibited goods that have no practical use other than capital execution or torture, their ban on transit through EU territory, rapid action to add new products to the list and, finally, the establishment of a coordination group against torture , with experts from Parliament, to monitor the application of the rules.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as we are satisfied with the Commission's proposal, and even more so, following a very constructive process of amendments. While I am aware that the new regulation alone will not eliminate the death penalty or prevent torture globally, I believe it is a step forward in this regard.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report on the proposed regulation on the trade of certain goods that could be used for the purpose of imposing capital punishment, torture or other cruel punishment or treatment. While the objective of the regulation may seem laudable - namely to prevent and prohibit the export of material specially designed to inflict torture, the death penalty, or any cruel or inhuman treatment - the proposed measures seem to me to be difficult to apply because criteria for verifying with certainty that these goods will be used for such practices have not been established. Moreover, the term 'degrading treatment' is being irresponsibly extended by including, for example, prison overcrowding, a problem which, although real, will not be solved by punishing Member States. The sovereignty of the latter is finally being undermined as they are forced to suspend the transfer of security equipment not included in the annexes of the European regulation.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While I fully agree with the aims of this legislative proposal, I believe that there are some unclear passages in it that could open up critical issues, so I preferred to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the new European rules against business linked to torture and the death penalty, as a pioneering initiative for human rights in the world. It introduces binding executive measures that will prevent any european participation in this appalling business. It strengthens the export ban and control introduced in 2006, making it more effective. And it extends its application to new products, such as drugs for lethal injection, and to services such as transportation, online advertising, technical assistance or commercial intermediation. No foreign commercial agent may re-exhibit torture material at Union trade fairs. And the responsibility of the Member States in their duty of control and information is strengthened. When Spain assumed the presidency of the Council of the Union in 2010, the Socialist Government of Rodríguez-Zapatero called on the Union to reform in this regard. Today, the Union has taken a step further against torture and capital punishment, and the Social Democrats have been able to demonstrate that trade policy is and must be a fundamental tool for promoting progress and human rights in the world.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the trade in certain goods that could be used for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. EU-wide export controls are an external trade policy instrument that serves a wide range of broader policy objectives. The Anti-Torture Regulation is a unique instrument contributing to the protection of human rights by controlling goods and activities that are used or could be misused for executions, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Anti-Torture Regulation contributes to a long-term EU policy aimed at abolishing the death penalty and preventing torture worldwide. The Regulation contributes to the achievement of these objectives by combining prohibitions with the requirements for the authorisation of the marketing of the goods indicated. It regulates the sale of goods intended solely for torture and execution and the provision of related technical assistance and a system of authorisation for goods of varying uses which could be misused for torture and execution by lethal injection. It is therefore essential to ensure an appropriate mix of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external policies in order to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of goods for torture and to effectively control goods that can be used for life-threatening and inhumane purposes.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-wide export controls are a foreign trade policy instrument for broader policy purposes. Export controls are an important policy tool for the European Union. Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 against torture is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights, the global eradication of the death penalty and torture by controlling products and activities that can be used in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation lays down the European Union's long-aspirations to combine prohibitions with the licensing requirements for trade in the products listed in its Annexes. It introduces a ban on means of torture and the execution of the death penalty only and related technical assistance (Annex II) and establishes a licensing system for products suitable for torture and lethal injection executions in the event of abusive use (Annex III). The draft opinion also proposes the development of a equipment coordination group and the implementation of a periodic review mechanism and a more systemic information sharing and reporting system in order to strengthen control and effectively implement the Regulation. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this proposal.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. - Control of trade in torture goods has been needed for a long time, and I am pleased that we have finally voted on the proposal for a regulation that seeks to regulate this area in the most appropriate way possible. I also supported the proposal unreservedly. The production and sale of torture goods and their use are one of the most discarded things, which must be strictly controlled and severely punished. I therefore believe that it is necessary to ensure the coherence of EU export controls for military, firearms and torture equipment. I also welcome the Commission's proposals to prevent the use of verified medical products for lethal injection. Effective control of this area should also adequately monitor the implementation of member states' commitments, including the obligation to report and exchange information through a secure encrypted system.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The global abolition of the death penalty is one of the main objectives of the European Union's human rights policies. It is precisely through the revision of this directive that Community action to protect human dignity, the right to life, as well as the prohibition of torture and other inhuman and degrading punishments could be put into practice.  With this new procedure, the European Union is not simply putting a stop to the marketing of all those instruments which, in some States, could be used to carry out torture or death sentences, but also prohibits the advertising and transport throughout Europe of these instruments. It is also worth emphasising the flexibility and precision that this revision brings to the 2005 regulation: an updated version of the 'blacklist' has been drawn up listing all the objects that have the sole function of torturing or causing death, in order to respond to the development of new technologies in the field.  I therefore welcome this review as a concrete example of a trade policy that promotes Community values.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report. This is a good example of how the EU sets global standards in eradicating torture. The updated rules will help EU authorities respond as quickly as possible to new trends in the development of torture and inhuman treatment. Over the past few years, we have seen how a change in EU practice has led to the abolition of the death penalty in many partner countries such as the US. I think this is a good basis for continuing this trend when regulation takes effect.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This Commission report proposes to extend these prohibitions in force since 2005 to brokerage services, and to the transit of these goods. In addition, it extends these provisions to prison overcrowding and lack of medical care. Parliament is further tightening the text by proposing, for example, to extend it to corporal punishment. The lack of certainty as to the precise definition of these assets leads me to a certain caution. I therefore vote abstention on the Commission's text. I also vote abstention on the text of Parliament.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ A clearer regulation on trade in goods used for capital punishment and torture is needed. Thus, I voted in favour of this resolution mostly with the idea that the Union has abolished capital punishment for all crimes and has made an international commitment on that issue. Then, stricter authorisations to the supply of brokering services and technical assistance in respect of goods that are used for the purpose of capital punishment have been approved with this vote.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The "Regulation against Torture" is a unique instrument that serves to ensure the protection of human rights by controlling goods and activities that could be used to carry out the death penalty or to inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The 'regulation against torture' is part of the EU's policy of eliminating the death penalty worldwide and preventing torture.  It is important to ensure the right combination of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of goods for torture purposes and to effectively control items with potential lethal and inhuman uses. It is necessary to ensure that export control regimes are valid in the long term and are flexible in order to adapt rapidly to technological developments and developments in the world. Effective implementation by national authorities of controls, audits, sanctions, guidelines and awareness-raising actions is also of paramount importance.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. As a reminder, The original Regulation (EC) No. 1236/2005 already prohibited any export and importation of equipment specially designed to impose the death penalty or inhumane treatment.  Companies specializing in the production of goods that can be used for the death penalty or torture must have an export authorization issued by the national competent authority on written request.  This proposed amendment calls for tougher the original regulation by extending these restrictions to brokerage and transit services. In addition, the text proposes to include prison overcrowding, lack of medical care and the prohibition of all contact with the outside world in the definition of torture.   We are, of course, opposed to the transit of equipment only designed for the death penalty and torture. Nevertheless, we consider that the current legislation sufficiently frames this activity.  That is why I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Export control at EU level are foreign trade policy instruments that serve a multitude of broader policy objectives. "Regulation against torture" (EC) No 1493/1999 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 December 1999 on 1236/2005 is a unique instrument which contributes to the protection of human rights by means of the control of goods and activities used or likely to be used fraudulently to impose the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. This regulation contributes to the EU's long-standing policy of eliminating the death penalty around the world, and preventing torture. It contributes to the achievement of the objectives by combining prohibitions with licensing requirements for trade in listed goods.  I was in favour of this report, considering that the revision of EU controls on trade in torture instruments is extremely important in the current European context.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 In Europe, the death penalty was abolished entirely, with the exception of Belarus, which imposed it as a sentence even this year. The preservation of the death penalty is, moreover, one of the reasons why Belarus is the only European country that is not a member of the Council of Europe. Moreover, the abolition of the death penalty is a precondition for EU membership and is considered a cruel and inhumane practice. The European Union challenges the death penalty, regardless of motivation, whether it is one of deterring crime or punishing war crimes (the last EU Member State, Latvia, abolishing the death penalty for all types of crime in 2012). In view of this, the EU continues its long-standing policy of eliminating the death penalty in the world by regulating the prohibition of trade in goods and related 'single-use' technical assistance for torture and execution and an authorisation system for 'multifunctional' goods that could be misused for torture and execution by lethal injections. Furthermore, I support this report, as the EU needs to regularly update checklists to include all relevant devices or technologies that appear on the market.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new European legislation against business linked to torture and the death penalty, as a pioneering human rights initiative in the world. It introduces binding executive measures that will prevent any european participation in this appalling business. It strengthens the export ban and control introduced in 2006, making it more effective. And it extends its application to new products, such as drugs for lethal injection, and to services such as transportation, online advertising, technical assistance or commercial intermediation.  No foreign commercial agent may re-exhibit torture material at Union trade fairs. And the responsibility of the Member States in their duty of control and information is strengthened. When Spain assumed the presidency of the Council of the Union in 2010, the Socialist Government of Rodríguez-Zapatero called on the Union to reform in this regard. Today, the Union has taken a step further against torture and capital punishment, and the Social Democrats have been able to demonstrate that trade policy is and must be a fundamental tool for promoting progress and human rights in the world.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Union's Charter of Fundamental Rights abolishes the death penalty and torture. Both practices are formally prohibited in all EU Member States. The Union has a duty to disseminate these principles to the rest of the world.  It is therefore essential to regulate the trade in goods that could be used for the purpose of imposing the death penalty or torture. Through this legislation we guarantee trade with third countries based on a value system.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that Europe needs to reaffirm at international level its leading role in the fight for the abolition of the death penalty, torture and inhuman and degrading practices that violate human rights.   The 'Regulation against Torture' (Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005) is a single instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights through the control of goods and activities that are used or could be misused to practise the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It is therefore essential to ensure uniformity in the control of EU exports, including with regard to dual-use military firearms and articles included as instruments of torture.  The strengthening of controls on torture instruments provides for the introduction of a specific annex, IIA.  The purpose of this Annex is to prevent controlled medicinal products from being used to carry out death sentences by lethal injection. The EU should also establish a general export authorisation for countries that have made strict international commitments, in particular the ratification of Protocol 13 to the European Convention on Human Rights.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which was a revision of the 2005 anti-torture Regulation, to ensure that no new technologies were allowed to slip through gaps in legislation. The ‘Anti-torture Regulation’ contributes to the EU policy of eliminating the death penalty worldwide, and of preventing torture. It helps achieve these goals by combining prohibitions with licensing requirements for trade in listed goods. It governs a ban of trade in ‘single-use’ torture and execution items and related technical assistance (Annex II) and an authorisation system for ‘multi-purpose’ items that could be misused for torture and executions by lethal injections (Annex III). This revision will ensure that online and offline marketing and transit of prohibited goods are also caught by legislation. Clearance at EU borders will also now be necessary for certain goods such as specific chemicals.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which proposes to control the export of goods which are used for the death penalty and torture. It is essential to ensure coherence of the EU’s export controls including military, dual use, firearms and torture goods lists, without subjecting items to duplicate controls (with the exception of complementary controls preventing illicit drug trafficking) to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of torture goods and effectively control items with potential lethal and inhumane uses.
