I agree with the approach of necessary and proportionate controls without superfluous burdens restricting trade which has legitimate end-use purposes.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is a regulation that eliminates certain legislative shortcomings, present in the 2005 one, through the introduction of clauses that will prohibit the export not only of goods intended for torture but also of medicines used in death sentences or for other treatments.  Banning the death penalty and torture are fundamental objectives of European trade and foreign policy and it is essential that EU companies do not contribute to these practices.  The 5 Star Movement is firmly opposed to the death penalty and torture. My vote was positive.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has a clear and firm stand on how to deal with death penalty or torture issues; we just say no to it. This report reflects very well the EU position also in the international trade area. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the EU has to tighten the rules concerning trade of goods related to capital punishment and torture. I also believe that the EU should lead by example and set standards on global level to be respected by other trade partners.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s ban on the trade in goods or services for the purposes of inflicting cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment of people, anywhere in the world, stems from a principle that should remain absolute. For this reason, and in order to better ensure that the private sector in the EU stays out of such trade, a ban on the marketing and promotion of this category of products is an important improvement in the review of the 2005 regulation. Banning these goods from transiting through the EU territory is another logical corollary to this basic principle of our foreign policy, which righty encompasses dual purpose artefacts, such as crowd control implements or certain, when there is a risk that they will be used in torture or executions. Loopholes in the legislation will be closed, and enforcement should be monitored more effectively. I hope the Commission review, due by mid-2020, will register an improvement in the way the EU’s ban on torture goods works in practice, thanks to the present legislative changes.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Torture and the death penalty are still some of the most serious and odious forms of human rights violations. Therefore, the European Union, which is founded on the principles of the rule of law and respect for human dignity, must consolidate its role as a world leader in the fight against such cruel treatment, including through its own foreign and trade policy. The ban on the marketing, promotion also via the Internet and the transport of goods in Annex I to the regulation are just some of the provisions that have been unanimously accepted by this House to prevent the EU from in any way encouraging illegal practices. In the light of rapid technological developments and the development of new products, the possibility of activating emergency clauses to update the list of prohibited goods for trade will make the regulation even more effective and immediate. The procedure will only have a real impact if there is no disparity in the implementation of controls by the customs authorities of the Member States. It is therefore important to set up a coordination group, which already exists for other categories of exports, which will regularly examine the application of the regulation. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and consider that the 'Anti-Torture Regulation' (EC) No 1257/1999 should be amended accordingly. It is a unique instrument which contributes to the protection of human rights through checks on the species and activities used or which could be misused for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. Especially in modern times, we must be strict about what is associated with torture or degrading treatment of people. I believe that this report helps to tighten up the rules and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the review of the regulation which aims to further strengthen the EU's role as a responsible world leader and player in the fight against the death penalty and the elimination of torture. The aim of the measure is to strengthen the provisions relating to ancillary services related to the transfer of goods, as well as transit, technical assistance and trade promotion. In accordance with the position repeatedly expressed by Parliament, it aims to introduce targeted end-use clauses so that Member States prohibit or suspend the transit of security-related articles not listed in Annexes II and III which are clearly usable, in practice, only for the purposes of capital punishment, torture or other ill-treatment, or where there are reasonable grounds for believing that capital punishment would be facilitated or carried out. , torture or other ill-treatment. It also proposes the creation of a coordination group on equipment and the introduction of a regular review mechanism and a more systematic information and reporting regime, in order to strengthen the control of the Regulation and its effective implementation.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote for this report. The issue of trade in products that could be used for the death penalty and torture is a very sensitive one. While I agree with the aims of the legislative proposal, I believe that its adoption should not impose excessive burdens on companies that legitimately trade in products that are not linked to torture or the death penalty. I also believe that there is no point in exploiting issues of this importance.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this measure in the hope that in future it will be possible to eliminate all forms expected to repress or nullify the human being and his dignity, just as required by the founding values of the EU. In this respect, the policies adopted with regard to the transit of goods that can be used to commit cruel treatment are laudable: it must be monitored and diverted through a timely exchange of information between customs authorities, made even more efficient by the establishment of a coordination group against torture.  In view of the times in which we live, it is also important to prohibit advertising and any way of promoting, including via the Internet, the sale and use of the goods in question, as the document promptly provides.  I also voted in line with the group on Amendment No 41 tabled by Mr Lange to ensure that exports of medicines or other goods that can be used to torture or kill are regulated mainly to those countries that have not abolished the death penalty.   I welcome, together with the provisions, the adoption of the urgent procedure for possible amendments to the various annexes to the regulation in order to ensure immediate responses to the climate destabilised by the presence of foreign fighters and ISIS affiliates pervading the Union.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 concerning trade in certain goods which could be used for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, and I noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 In June 2005, the Council of the European Union adopted Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods which may be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment allowing by delegated act to review the control lists (contained in its annexes). These EU control mechanisms are not only trade control mechanisms, but cover political guidelines, in particular preventing and prohibiting the production, trade and use of goods intended for torture or which can be used for lethal or inhumane purposes. I therefore support the Schaake Report on the revision of Regulation No 1236/2005 which strengthens controls on torture instruments by adding a new specific annex to prevent medicines from being used to apply the death penalty by lethal injection, prohibiting brokerage services for prohibited goods, by creating a General Export Authorisation of the Union and providing for a new urgency procedure which will allow a rapid response to the movement of new products that may arise on the market and which are susceptible to use in acts of torture.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I welcome the increased export bans and restrictions on products that can be used for executions or torture. The same applies to the urgent procedure: the EU Commission needs this leeway in order to be able to react quickly so that products can be added to the list of exports in need of authorisation in the short term if they are suspected of being used for torture or for executions. The EU does not tolerate torture or the death penalty.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this regulation as I welcome the updating of the lists of goods subject to controls as it is important to ensure the right combination of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of goods for torture purposes and to effectively control articles with potential lethal and inhuman uses.  I also consider it important to extend the restrictions on technical assistance and brokerage services in relation to any prohibited goods if the broker or technical assistance provider is aware that the goods in question are or may be intended for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ We need an appropriate set of measures ensuring that medicinal products are not used for capital punishment, for torture or for other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It is important that Member States give due consideration to this report and ensure that relevant information is provided to their customs administration and other relevant national authorities tasked with upholding the provisions of the law. I favour the introduction of a targeted end-use clause in order for Member States to suspend or halt the transfer of security-related items not listed in Annexes II and III that clearly have no practical use other than for the purposes of capital punishment, torture or other ill-treatment. Additional safeguards against the risks which are already in place should be monitored, abided with and enforced in the spirit of a Community coherent approach, ensuring unity within the Union on such a sensitive matter.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report seeks to regulate trade in certain products that can be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or degrading treatment, which I consider very necessary and for this reason I voted in favour of the report. However, although I have supported the report with my vote, I believe that the Union has no credibility in the fight against torture as long as it continues to be subordinate to the United States (for example, there is evidence that torture has been routinely practiced at Guantanamo with complete impunity for 14 years). The report contains numerous proposals with which I fully agree, such as asking to ensure that Union exports to third countries do not contribute to what the Union considers to be 'inhuman' practices, such as electric chairs, or cage beds. But unfortunately the Union has no credibility in its so-called 'fight against torture' as long as we continue to profit from the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia, or as long as our partners have torture and the death penalty legalised. If we are really against torture, we should start by reviewing our relations with third countries, until they comply with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The "Regulation against Torture" is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights through the control of goods and activities that are used or could be misused to practice the death penalty or inflict torture or other treatment. Its review is an important example of the Eu ropean Union's action to set global standards for the eradication of torture and is also a strong signal to the EU's partners.   I therefore welcomed the proposed amendment because I believe that trade instruments can help to overcome, at least in part, the absence of multilateral export control regimes in the area of goods that can be used for torture purposes.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 'Regulation against Torture' is the only instrument contributing to the protection of human rights through the control of goods and activities fraudulently used to impose capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Appropriate synchronisation between EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade, or use of goods intended for torture is important. Ensuring compliance with controls by national authorities, when we are talking about external commercial transactions that have become increasingly complex, is a necessity. I voted for a Community approach that maintains a level playing field, through the adequacy of a system of periodic reporting and review, in line with export control regimes.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The report amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods applicable in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The amendments are intended, above all, to reduce the death penalty and torture, in particular on the grounds of respect for human rights. The amendments complement, clarify and raise new aspects of the regulations already in force. They shall specify, inter alia, the definition of exporter and transit. They also complement the omnibus provisions and expand the list of devices suitable for detention and torture, as well as the list of medicines that can be used for lethal injections. It recommends the establishment of expert groups for more effective export control and publicly available annual reports summarising member states' annual activities. In order to achieve this objective, it is also vital to ban brokerage activities that may be related to prohibited products.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of a regulation that prohibits the trafficking of certain goods that could be used for the execution of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.  This is a very important regulation aimed at improving the sense of security among citizens. It sets out in detail what objects this Regulation covers and describes a unique procedure for those equipment and goods which, in addition to being used for illicit purposes, also have legal application. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Capital punishment, torture and any other treatment or punishment should be banned in all countries. The European Union must be on the forefront to eradicate torture. I voted in favour of this report as it will help EU authorities to react more quickly to new emerging trends. The revision of this regulation aims to contribute to the elimination of the death penalty worldwide and prevent torture through EU-wide controls on exports of torture goods and drugs used for lethal injection.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the report on the proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods that could be used for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The revision of the 2005 regulation has, in fact, made it possible to update the necessary products whose marketing is prohibited within the European Union, as well as the inclusion of the ban on the advertising and promotion of these products, including online, and their transit through EU territory. It also provides for an 'urgent procedure', aimed at the rapid inclusion of new products that could be considered risky, and a review clause, which will make it possible to verify the effectiveness of the legislation and revise it, if necessary, by 2020. The provisions introduced through the review aim to increase the effectiveness of a regulation with the wider objective of reaffirming the European Union's direct commitment to the fight to defend the right to life and the dignity of the individual: a very positive example of how European trade policy can increasingly be a means of strengthening the protection of human rights within and beyond the Union's borders.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report follows the European Commission's proposal to revise the regulation against property for torture and the trade in certain goods that could be used for the purpose of imposing capital punishment, torture or other cruel treatment or punishment.  The report aims, among other things, to expand the list of controlled assets that can be used to impose the death penalty by lethal injection, and to strengthen restrictions on brokerage and technical assistance services.  Exports of drugs used as lethal injections will also be more strictly controlled.  Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important, however this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en-block by the EU.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of amending the regulation on the trade of certain goods that could be used for the purpose of imposing capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.  The export of goods that can be used to inflict the death penalty or torture must be strictly controlled.  That is why I am particularly in favour of Member States leaving the possibility of putting in place additional measures at national level with regard to these goods.  In order to actively combat torture, we must also encourage the exchange of information with national prevention mechanisms.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-wide export controls are a foreign trade policy instrument for broader policy purposes. Export controls are an important policy tool for the European Union. Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 against torture is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights, the global eradication of the death penalty and torture by controlling products and activities that can be used in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation lays down the European Union's long-aspirations to combine prohibitions with the licensing requirements for trade in the products listed in its Annexes. It introduces a ban on means of torture and the execution of the death penalty and related technical assistance (Annex II) and establishes a licensing system for products suitable for torture and lethal injection executions in the event of misuse (Annex III). The draft opinion also proposes the development of a equipment coordination group and the implementation of a periodic review mechanism and a more systemic information sharing and reporting system in order to strengthen control and effectively implement the Regulation. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 As a Member of the European Parliament and as a European, I stand against the death penalty and all kinds of torture. I would like to see closer cooperation between the national authorities of the EU Member States in order to improve controls and to carry out awareness-raising initiatives. In this respect, I support the revision of the legislation to stop the export and promotion of goods that can be used for the death penalty or torture, such as medicines for lethal injections or instruments of torture. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported the adoption of stronger rules to prevent the trade in goods and services that may contribute to torture or the death penalty.  The prohibition of the death penalty and the prohibition of torture are key objectives of European trade and foreign policies. As such, it is essential that EU companies do not contribute in any way to these practices.  To ensure this, the EU has developed specific tools, including regulations establishing trade restrictions, which prohibit the export of products that have no practical use other than execution or torture, as well as products that have been designed for other purposes but which could be used for torture or execution.  Despite these provisions, certain loopholes have allowed the trading or brokerage and advertising of such products to continue. In addition, in the face of changes and the development of new technologies, it was essential to strengthen European legislation.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. According to Amnesty International, at least 1,634 people were sentenced to death and executed in 25 countries last year, and torture cases in 141 countries, three-quarters of the world's countries, have been recorded.  At EU level, the Charter of Fundamental Rights prohibits the death penalty and stipulates that "no one can be subjected to torture, inhuman or degrading punishment or treatment". The Union also promotes respect for fundamental rights around the world.  Since 2005, the EU has had a trade instrument to limit exports of goods or products used to impose the death penalty and torture, such as electric tongs, spiked screws or certain medicines used in lethal injections.  This new regulation amends existing legislation and now also regulates brokerage services and technical assistance for these goods and takes into account developments induced by the development of new technologies.  Trade policy is thus put at the service of promoting the values of the European Union.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the file. Whilst initially there were some concerns regarding the extraterritoriality and ‘catch-all’ clauses, these issues were successfully resolved. I fully support the current text which focuses on issues arising from the export of pharmaceutical products which could be used for lethal injections. The agreed text as it stands today not only introduces a prior authorisation regime for brokering services and technical assistance, but also prohibits the transit of goods listed in Annex II, the advertising and promotion at exhibitions and trade fairs of goods listed in Annex II. Further, it permits Member States to adopt or maintain additional national measures and to establish a coordination group, enables the possible urgency procedure and introduces the review clause. I am convinced that the changes negotiated propose effective measures to complement existing legislation in adapting to these challenges. Trade in such drugs must actively be prevented and this report is a decisive and important step towards this objective.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote against because we believe that the report will have no real effect and that there is no way to deprive the media of either executions or torture. We are in principle against torture, but we believe that the death penalty should be reviewed, especially in cases of particularly heinous crimes.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-wide export controls are a foreign trade policy instrument for broader policy purposes. Export controls are an important policy tool for the European Union. Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 against torture is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights, the global eradication of the death penalty and torture by controlling products and activities that can be used in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation lays down the European Union's long-aspirations to combine prohibitions with the licensing requirements for trade in the products listed in its Annexes. It introduces a ban on means of torture and the execution of the death penalty and related technical assistance (Annex II) and establishes a licensing system for products suitable for torture and lethal injection executions in the event of misuse (Annex III). The draft opinion also proposes the development of a equipment coordination group and the implementation of a periodic review mechanism and a more systemic information sharing and reporting system in order to strengthen control and effectively implement the Regulation. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report concerning trade in goods which could be used for capital punishment, torture, or other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment. There are currently many loopholes in international trade export controls which allow the movement of these goods. Amnesty International and other NGOs have been very supportive of this report, and it is a major step forward in tackling the problem. It is important to my constituents in Wales that we try protect the human rights of all people.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The purpose of this Regulation is to prevent EU exports from contributing to human rights violations in third countries. It therefore reviews EU controls on trade in torture instruments.  This legislation aims to fill the gaps in the current EU regime, including new clauses restricting and prohibiting advisory, transport, brokerage, advertising and promotion services for risky or prohibited products, such as at trade fairs, exhibitions and on the Internet.  The Regulation also provides for a new urgency procedure, which will allow a rapid response to the movement of new products that may arise on the market and which are susceptible to use in acts of torture.  I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Abstention: the text is quite unenforceable because it does not speak of certainties or elements that goods or services would be used for torture or degrading elements but of "may be used...".

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 I can only agree with any measure aimed at preventing and prohibiting the production, trade and use of goods for torture purposes and effectively controlling items with potential lethal and inhuman uses. The regulation will make it possible to eliminate certain legislative shortcomings in this area and will ensure greater uniformity in EU export controls.  The fight for the abolition of the death penalty and the fight against all forms of torture and other inhumane treatment or cruel punishments represent a battle of civilisation to be fought according to an all-encompassing approach that does not exclude the prohibition of harmful commercial practices. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005, which aims to combat torture, is an instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights by controlling products and activities that are used, or may be used, abusively to impose the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation lays down a ban on trade in 'single-use' products intended for torture and executions and their technical assistance (Annex II) and a system for authorising fair products that can be misused to inflict torture and carry out executions by lethal injection (Annex III). It is now proposed to strengthen controls on torture instruments. Lists of specific articles provide clarity to exporters and importers and help to ensure compliance with the rules. In a context where external trade operations are increasingly complex, the key role of the effective implementation of controls, verifications, sanctions, guidelines and awareness-raising actions carried out by national authorities is underlined. A periodic reporting and review system seems appropriate, in line with other export control schemes. The objectives of the Regulation appear to be fair and the means it defines proportionate.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it prohibits the export and import of equipment or goods suitable for the purpose of torture and the death penalty only and introduces a further restrictive regime, based on specific authorisations, for exports of equipment/goods potentially used for such purposes. The same report also allows Member States to adopt or maintain additional national measures limiting the operation of certain ancillary services related to such exports.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has a privileged global position in the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms. It is therefore very important for the European Union to constantly update eu export control and control legislation, which focuses on trade in torture instruments. It is necessary to ensure consistency of EU export controls as regards lists of military goods, dual-use goods, firearms and torture goods, so as not to duplicate controls on these items. In addition to technical assistance and brokering services, the EU should, where possible, seek to control other services that may contribute to the dissemination of goods that can be used for torture or capital punishment, such as, inter alia, marketing or financial services.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because I agree with the need to restrict trade in certain goods used for the death penalty, torture or other treatment, but I would not like to see the risk of excessive bureaucratic costs being passed on to the producers.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because I believe that it will have no real effect, since there is no way to deprive you of the means either for executions or for torture. I am against torture, but I nevertheless believe that the death penalty should be reviewed, especially in cases of particularly heinous crimes.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ This is a much welcome example of the EU setting a global standard in eradicating torture. The updated rules will help EU authorities to react more quickly to new emerging trends in torture and inhumane treatment, namely by regulating their sale on line, etc. In recent years we have seen how a change in EU practices has led to the demise of the death penalty in many partner countries such as the US. This will be set to continue when the regulation comes into force. I welcome in particular the inclusion of a ‘catch-all clause’ in the EP position. With the new ‘urgency procedure’, customs authorities will be able to act just as fast in detaining torture goods. Moreover, there will be an outright ban on displaying and selling torture goods at trade fairs, updated rules on banning advertising to include online sales of torture goods, and the transit of the prohibited products will be outlawed.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-wide export controls are a foreign trade policy instrument for broader policy purposes. Export controls are an important policy tool for the European Union. Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 against torture is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights, the global eradication of the death penalty and torture by controlling products and activities that can be used in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation lays down the European Union's long-aspirations to combine prohibitions with the licensing requirements for trade in the products listed in its Annexes. It introduces a ban on means of torture and the execution of the death penalty and related technical assistance (Annex II) and establishes a licensing system for products suitable for torture and lethal injection executions in the event of misuse (Annex III). The draft opinion also proposes the development of a equipment coordination group and the implementation of a periodic review mechanism and a more systemic information sharing and reporting system in order to strengthen control and effectively implement the Regulation. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-wide export controls are a foreign trade policy instrument for broader policy purposes. Export controls are an important policy tool for the European Union. Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 against torture is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights, the global eradication of the death penalty and torture by controlling products and activities that can be used in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation lays down the European Union's long-aspirations to combine prohibitions with the licensing requirements for trade in the products listed in its Annexes. It introduces a ban on means of torture and the execution of the death penalty and related technical assistance (Annex II) and establishes a licensing system for products suitable for torture and lethal injection executions in the event of misuse (Annex III). The draft opinion also proposes the development of a equipment coordination group and the implementation of a periodic review mechanism and a more systemic information sharing and reporting system in order to strengthen control and effectively implement the Regulation. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report convinced that export controls at EU level are an instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights through controls on articles and activities that are used, or could be abused, to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel treatment or punishment , inhuman or degrading. The revision of eu controls on trade in torture instruments should have been carried out a long time ago, constituting updates to checklists in the right direction. It is important to ensure the appropriate combination of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures aimed at preventing and prohibiting the production, trade and use of torture items and, indeed, inhuman and potentially lethal control products.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new European legislation against business linked to torture and the death penalty, as a pioneering human rights initiative in the world. It introduces binding executive measures that will prevent any european participation in this appalling business. It strengthens the export ban and control introduced in 2006, making it more effective. And it extends its application to new products, such as drugs for lethal injection, and to services such as transportation, online advertising, technical assistance or commercial intermediation.  No foreign commercial agent may re-exhibit torture material at Union trade fairs. And the responsibility of the Member States in their duty of control and information is strengthened. When Spain assumed the presidency of the Council of the Union in 2010, the Socialist Government of Rodríguez-Zapatero called on the Union to reform in this regard. Today, the Union has taken a step further against torture and capital punishment, and the Social Democrats have been able to demonstrate that trade policy is and must be a fundamental tool for promoting progress and human rights in the world.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new European legislation against business linked to torture and the death penalty, as a pioneering human rights initiative in the world. It introduces binding executive measures that will prevent any european participation in this appalling business. It strengthens the export ban and control introduced in 2006, making it more effective. And it extends its application to new products, such as drugs for lethal injection, and to services such as transportation, online advertising, technical assistance or commercial intermediation.  No foreign commercial agent may re-exhibit torture material at Union trade fairs. And the responsibility of the Member States in their duty of control and information is strengthened. When Spain assumed the presidency of the Council of the Union in 2010, the Socialist Government of Rodríguez-Zapatero called on the Union to reform in this regard. Today, the Union has taken a step further against torture and capital punishment, and the Social Democrats have been able to demonstrate that trade policy is and must be a fundamental tool for promoting progress and human rights in the world.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is essential to express my full support for the agreement reached on trade in goods that could be used for the death penalty, torture or other punishment. I believe that it is right for the European Union to monitor reinforced legal and illegal channels of trade in instruments that could be used against the individual and cause the death or mortification of life. The protection of the health and safety of citizens must be a top priority in our political and human commitment and we must implement, with the utmost severity and tenacity, the most decisive measures for scrupulous checks on the transit and sale, even online, of goods that can be used against the person, vigorously carrying out Europe's concrete and solid commitment to combating the death penalty. , where it is still recognised.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. As the European Union, we reject the death penalty. However, this principle must not stop at our EU external borders. I therefore support the report and the extension of the ban, which it calls for, to include mediation activities and technical assistance. Close exchange of information between the various national customs authorities should also be encouraged. An unnecessary burden on exporters must be avoided.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. UKIP objects to the EU dictating our terms of trade, so we would have been minded to vote against, however due to the sensitive nature of the report we did not oppose. There are practical problems in defining ‘items of torture’. Our concern in the future is that conventional and innocuous items could be added the list of restricted goods and may affect legitimate trade. UKIP, of course, condemns any form of torture.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as we are satisfied with the Commission's proposal, and even more so, following a very constructive process of amendments. While I am aware that the new regulation alone will not eliminate the death penalty or prevent torture globally, I believe it is a step forward in this regard.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I believe it is essential to contribute to the abolition of the death penalty around the world and to prevent torture. An important step is to strengthen provisions on the transfer of goods, transit, technical assistance and commercial marketing, with a view to prohibiting trade in goods intended for torture and execution or with 'multifunctional' goods which could be misused for torture and execution by lethal injections. Increased efforts are needed at EU level, and trade instruments are part of a global approach to eradicating torture, by prohibiting the transfer of elements that could lead to the facilitation or commission of judicial executions, torture and other mistreatment. At the same time, it is essential to ensure the coherence of the European Union's export controls with regard to military goods, firearms and goods that can be used for torture and other inhuman or degrading treatment, without the need to double the controls. The list of prohibited products needs to be revised. I voted for this report because I believe that the economic and commercial development of the internal market should not facilitate torture through products created and marketed online or offline.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal as it importantly represents a significant update of the rules which will stop the export, transit, marketing and promotion of goods that can be used for torture or inhumane treatment.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it complements the current regime for banning exports and imports of goods for torture and execution.  From now on, trade in certain drugs that can be used to impose the death penalty will also be better controlled, as will related technical assistance and brokerage services related to any of the listed assets that could be used for torture.  The values of the European Union based on respect for life and human dignity must indeed be protected and promoted all over the world.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new European legislation against business linked to torture and the death penalty, as a pioneering human rights initiative in the world. It introduces binding executive measures that will prevent any european participation in this appalling business. It strengthens the export ban and control introduced in 2006, making it more effective. And it extends its application to new products, such as drugs for lethal injection, and to services such as transportation, online advertising, technical assistance or commercial intermediation.  No foreign commercial agent may re-exhibit torture material at Union trade fairs. And the responsibility of the Member States in their duty of control and information is strengthened. When Spain assumed the presidency of the Council of the Union in 2010, the Socialist Government of Rodríguez-Zapatero called on the Union to reform in this regard. Today, the Union has taken a step further against torture and capital punishment, and the Social Democrats have been able to demonstrate that trade policy is and must be a fundamental tool for promoting progress and human rights in the world.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. It is important to ensure the right mix of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of torture goods as well as effectively control items with potential lethal and inhumane uses. It is essential to ensure coherence of the EU’s export controls including military, dual use, firearms and torture goods lists, without subjecting items to duplicate controls.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new European legislation against business linked to torture and the death penalty, as a pioneering human rights initiative in the world. It introduces binding executive measures that will prevent any european participation in this appalling business. It strengthens the export ban and control introduced in 2006, making it more effective. And it extends its application to new products, such as drugs for lethal injection, and to services such as transportation, online advertising, technical assistance or commercial intermediation.  No foreign commercial agent may re-exhibit torture material at Union trade fairs. And the responsibility of the Member States in their duty of control and information is strengthened. When Spain assumed the presidency of the Council of the Union in 2010, the Socialist Government of Rodríguez-Zapatero called on the Union to reform in this regard. Today, the Union has taken a step further against torture and capital punishment, and the Social Democrats have been able to demonstrate that trade policy is and must be a fundamental tool for promoting progress and human rights in the world.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support this report, which updates the current Anti-Torture Regulation and provides stricter EU rules on the trade in goods or substances that may be misused for torture and capital punishment. Under the new regulation, the current ban on certain goods will be expanded to also include marketing services and the transit of already forbidden goods via the EU. Moreover, these new anti-torture rules will be more flexible and can be quickly adapted to changing technologies and topical developments. The eradication of the death penalty and torture is an important goal of Europe. The EU condemns the death penalty and torture everywhere. Therefore, it is crucial that we have a strong and credible policy to make sure that Europe does not contribute to these practices. Thankfully, with these new updated rules we are broadening the scope of the regulation, making sure we include more of the worldwide trade in these products and ensure that Europeans are not involved.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. This report deals with the export of goods that can also be used for the execution of the death penalty or for torture. Of course, I too would prefer a world without torture and the death penalty. While the intention is understandable, it should be clear that these export bans do not make torture or the death penalty impossible. With the death penalty in particular, the goods to be exported would probably even be in the interests of humanity. For example.B stoning is possible everywhere – a poison injection would probably be the more humane alternative. In this report, therefore, we were primarily concerned with reducing the negative side effects on trade in goods that do not serve the above-mentioned purposes. As the report is a sensible compromise in this sense, I voted in favour of it. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. For it leads to discord and discord.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-wide export controls are a foreign trade policy instrument for broader policy purposes. Export controls are an important policy tool for the European Union. Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 against torture is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights, the global eradication of the death penalty and torture by controlling products and activities that can be used in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation lays down the European Union's long-aspirations to combine prohibitions with the licensing requirements for trade in the products listed in its Annexes. It introduces a ban on means of torture and the execution of the death penalty and related technical assistance (Annex II) and establishes a licensing system for products suitable for torture and lethal injection executions in the event of misuse (Annex III). The draft opinion also proposes the development of a equipment coordination group and the implementation of a periodic review mechanism and a more systemic information sharing and reporting system in order to strengthen control and effectively implement the Regulation. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending the Council Regulation on trade in certain goods that could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment for strongly opposing the death penalty and any form of torture.  I support technical enhanced ones that will allow for stronger controls and a level playing field across the EU without creating excessive administrative burdens. This empowers Europe's global role to respect universal human rights.  It is also necessary to perfect the export control system in order to make it flexible and adaptable to technological changes and developments, but it is also important to take into account the complexity of foreign trade transactions, and to monitor the implementation of Member States' obligations.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The text proposed by Parliament is already failing to establish clearly whether or not there is a real risk that a particular traded goods or service will be used for torture, degradation or other purposes.  Moreover, it gives these terms too broad and excessive extension of their legal meaning, while abusively restricting trade in goods and exerting too much pressure on States on this subject. I have made the decision to abstain.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. UKIP objects to the EU dictating our terms of trade, so we would have been minded to vote against, however due to the sensitive nature of the report we did not oppose. There are practical problems in defining ‘items of torture’. Our concern in the future is that conventional and innocuous items could be added the list of restricted goods and may affect legitimate trade. UKIP, of course, condemns any form of torture.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new European legislation against business linked to torture and the death penalty, as a pioneering human rights initiative in the world. It introduces binding executive measures that will prevent any european participation in this appalling business. It strengthens the export ban and control introduced in 2006, making it more effective. And it extends its application to new products, such as drugs for lethal injection, and to services such as transportation, online advertising, technical assistance or commercial intermediation.  No foreign commercial agent may re-exhibit torture material at Union trade fairs. And the responsibility of the Member States in their duty of control and information is strengthened. When Spain assumed the presidency of the Council of the Union in 2010, the Socialist Government of Rodríguez-Zapatero called on the Union to reform in this regard. Today, the Union has taken a step further against torture and capital punishment, and the Social Democrats have been able to demonstrate that trade policy is and must be a fundamental tool for promoting progress and human rights in the world.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of measures that will contribute to the protection of human rights via controls on items and activities that are used for or could be misused for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. With foreign trade transactions becoming ever more complex, it is important to ensure the right mix of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of torture goods and effectively control items with potentially lethal and inhumane uses.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Marietje Schaake's report, which follows on from a 2005 regulation on the trade in goods for torture.  The text prohibits the export, advertising and transport of products for which there are no practical uses other than torture (electric chairs, lethal injections). However, flexibility is granted for the trade of products designed for other purposes (riot weapons, anaesthetics) that are subject to enhanced control.  As part of its development, we have insisted that this proposal does not impede the lawful trade of European companies and does not create unnecessary constraints on them.  I am pleased that this text has been adopted by a large majority.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report revising certain European rules in order to prevent trade in goods and services that may contribute to torture or the death penalty. This corresponds to the values defended by the European Union and in which I believe.  This includes a ban on the promotion and marketing of these goods and a strengthening of the transit ban on products banned in the EU.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report. Export controls at EU level are tools of foreign trade policy and serve a number of broader policy objectives. The 'Anti-Torture Regulation' (EC) No 1782/2003 is hereby amended as follows: It is a unique instrument which contributes to the protection of human rights through checks on the species and activities used or which could be misused for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report put to the vote contains positive aspects to the banning of torture and the death penalty – an issue that I have always been committed to. The inclusion of the necessary goods in a corresponding list is an important step that Europe no longer indirectly supports other countries in the exercise of torture or the death penalty. The report is positive.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005, concerning trade in certain goods which could be used for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, offers a balanced approach and ensures that human rights serve as the underlying principle. I welcome that the Member States are given flexibility to apply stricter controls and additional measures. One of the major improvements constitutes also the possibility for competent authorities to share information with national preventive mechanisms under the Optional Protocol to the UN Convention against Torture. Better coordination and informing each other is necessary to be up to date on the situation around the world, especially regarding authoritarian states. We need to be willing and able to share information concerning trading goods which fall under this regulation to avoid any conscious participation in capital punishment, torture and other cruel, in human or degrading treatment or punishment.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal, as the deal represents a significant update of the rules which will stop the export, transit, marketing and promotion of goods that can be used for torture or inhumane treatment.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I was happy to support the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on trade in certain goods that could be used for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It is necessary to prohibit intermediaries in the Union from providing intermediation services in respect of goods the export and import of which are prohibited, since such goods have no practical use other than for the execution of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The prohibition of the provision of such services will serve to protect public morality and to respect the principles of human dignity, which form the basis of the European values that form part of the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-wide export controls are a foreign trade policy instrument for broader policy purposes. Export controls are an important policy tool for the European Union. Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 against torture is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights, the global eradication of the death penalty and torture by controlling products and activities that can be used in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation lays down the European Union's long-aspirations to combine prohibitions with the licensing requirements for trade in the products listed in its Annexes. It introduces a ban on means of torture and the execution of the death penalty and related technical assistance (Annex II) and establishes a licensing system for products suitable for torture and lethal injection executions in the event of misuse (Annex III). The draft opinion also proposes the development of a equipment coordination group and the implementation of a periodic review mechanism and a more systemic information sharing and reporting system in order to strengthen control and effectively implement the Regulation. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since the report reaffirms the EU’s strong commitment to be the frontrunner in defence of human rights at global level, prohibiting the trade of goods which could be used for degrading treatment.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on trade in certain goods that could be used for the purpose of capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The right to life and the protection of human dignity are fundamental European values and it is therefore necessary to prevent the distribution of goods and services that could be used for the purpose of capital punishment or torture. I believe that the report provides for specific legislative and practical measures that will help to achieve and implement this objective.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this measure, the EU is further testing its role as a world leader and responsible player in the fight against the death penalty and the elimination of torture. The regulation we amended had too many grey areas and left some loopholes that have allowed these instruments of death to be traded, brokered and advertised in the past. Thanks to today's vote and the agreement reached with the Council, it will not only be illegal to buy and sell these tools online, but also to export, advertise and display them. None of these goods will be able to circulate in Europe, just as we have provided for a ban on brokerage and technical assistance services. The list of prohibited products is not closed. Thanks to today's vote, the Commission will soon be able to add new products among those that are banned or subject to control. However, it is essential that Member States play their part through a secure and encrypted communication system and exchange of information.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ Undoubtedly, human rights lie at the heart of the EU foreign policy and the EU actively promotes and defends them around the world. The EU is the leading institutional actor that holds a strong and principled position against the death penalty and torture. It is important that the EU uses all its available tools of diplomacy and cooperation assistance to work towards the abolition of the death penalty and torture. In this context, the EU should implement new legislation that prevents trade in certain goods and services that may contribute to capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Mrs Schaake's report is an instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights through the control of goods and activities used (or could be misused) to practise the death penalty or torture, combining bans with authorisation requirements for trade in the goods covered by this regulation. Such action should include not only confidential and bilateral approaches, but also explicit declarations and initiatives, to ensure concrete, preventive and meaningful responses to people at risk or suffering torture. I have therefore decided to support this report.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained because this text is a mess of regulations to try to prevent the export to third countries of services or goods of the European Union that could be used for degrading human acts up to torture (for example, a dual-use medicine).  The objective is laudable, but this unilateral text is unworkable. It will further bureaucratise the Union but will not prevent anything. Suppliers will source these multi-use goods elsewhere.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The adoption of this regulation strengthens export bans on products that can be used for death or torture. These products are, for example, pharmaceuticals, used in lethal injections to kill, such as those that are unfortunately used in the United States.  Thanks to this type of ban and awareness campaigns on the use of their products for European laboratories, the US prison administration is now struggling to obtain these products. With this shortage, it is all American prison and judicial structures that are faced with their contradictions and shortcomings. That is why I have supported this strengthening of the ban on the export of these products, like any other product that could be used for torture or inhuman treatment.  During the debates, I also took the opportunity to invite us to examine not only what we sell but also to whom we sell it.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on the trade of certain goods that could be used to impose capital punishment, torture or other cruel punishment or treatment.  This text is a mess of regulations to try to prevent the export, supply to third countries of services or goods of the European Union that could be used for inhuman or degrading acts up to torture (this can be a dual-use medicine).  This unilateral text of the Union is unenforceable and will further bureaucratise the Union but will not prevent anything.  Suppliers will source these multi-use goods elsewhere.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The current regulation aims to prevent and prohibit all exports of material specially designed to impose the death penalty, torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment... The European Commission has proposed to tighten this regulation with more restrictive conditions: extension to brokerage services and transit, extension of the term of the scope of degrading treatment...  Finally, this hardening is unworkable, in that it positions itself on the eventuality ("may be used to"). The European Parliament, for its part, proposes to go even further, for example by extending the scope of the text to corporal penalties and other types of goods, and in a binding way for the Member States. Fundamentally, I remain, of course, opposed to any form of torture. But, unable to accept that the European Union is imposing more restrictive conditions on states, I abstained on this report.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new European legislation against business linked to torture and the death penalty, as a pioneering human rights initiative in the world. It introduces binding executive measures that will prevent any european participation in this appalling business. It strengthens the export ban and control introduced in 2006, making it more effective. And it extends its application to new products, such as drugs for lethal injection, and to services such as transportation, online advertising, technical assistance or commercial intermediation.  No foreign commercial agent may re-exhibit torture material at Union trade fairs. And the responsibility of the Member States in their duty of control and information is strengthened. When Spain assumed the presidency of the Council of the Union in 2010, the Socialist Government of Rodríguez-Zapatero called on the Union to reform in this regard. Today, the Union has taken a step further against torture and capital punishment, and the Social Democrats have been able to demonstrate that trade policy is and must be a fundamental tool for promoting progress and human rights in the world.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new European legislation against business linked to torture and the death penalty, as a pioneering human rights initiative in the world. It introduces binding executive measures that will prevent any european participation in this appalling business. It strengthens the export ban and control introduced in 2006, making it more effective. And it extends its application to new products, such as drugs for lethal injection, and to services such as transportation, online advertising, technical assistance or commercial intermediation.  No foreign commercial agent may re-exhibit torture material at Union trade fairs. And the responsibility of the Member States in their duty of control and information is strengthened. When Spain assumed the presidency of the Council of the Union in 2010, the Socialist Government of Rodríguez-Zapatero called on the Union to reform in this regard. Today, the Union has taken a step further against torture and capital punishment, and the Social Democrats have been able to demonstrate that trade policy is and must be a fundamental tool for promoting progress and human rights in the world.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This report seeks to regulate trade in certain products that can be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or degrading treatment, which I consider very necessary and for this reason I voted in favour of the report. However, although I have supported the report with my vote, I believe that the Union has no credibility in the fight against torture as long as it continues to be subordinate to the United States (for example, there is evidence that torture has been routinely practiced at Guantanamo with complete impunity for 14 years). The report contains numerous proposals with which I fully agree, such as asking to ensure that Union exports to third countries do not contribute to what the Union considers to be 'inhuman' practices, such as electric chairs, or cage beds. But unfortunately the Union has no credibility in its so-called 'fight against torture' as long as we continue to profit from the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia, or as long as our partners have torture and the death penalty legalised. If we are really against torture, we should start by reviewing our relations with third countries, until they comply with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council introduces new rules to prevent trade in goods and services that can be used in executions or torture. The 2005 Trade Restrictions Regulation was already a success as a key instrument for combating the death penalty. It prohibits the export of products intended for capital punishment or torture and controls trade in others originally designed for another purpose, but which can be used to inflict torture or executions. Despite this success, the Union cannot settle for the 2005 Regulation and must continue its policy of eliminating the death penalty worldwide, as well as preventing torture. In this line is moved this proposal, which thanks to Parliament's efforts includes the prohibition of advertising products used to provide cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment to people in other countries. I welcome the new proposal, as this is a comprehensive approach that will contribute to the protection of human rights.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. This report deals with the export of goods that can also be used for the execution of the death penalty or for torture. Of course, I too would prefer a world without torture and the death penalty. While the intention is understandable, it should be clear that these export bans do not make torture or the death penalty impossible. In this report, we were primarily concerned with reducing the negative side effects on the trade of goods that are not used for the purposes mentioned. Syringes can, of course, be used for the execution of the death penalty, but above all they can also serve many useful medical purposes. As the report is a sensible compromise in this sense, I voted in favour of it.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of controlling the export of goods that are used for torture or the death penalty.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I'm against restricting trade. Objects are not to blame for being used somewhere to torture or carry out the death penalty, and the moral acceptability of such exports must be considered by manufacturers and individual workers. The proposed system will also be administratively challenging for companies that export goods that will not even end up being used for the death penalty and torture. I believe that neither guillotines nor electric chairs and things like that are produced in the Czech Republic, which is why I abstained.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No. 1236/2005 is a single instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights through controls on objects and activities used for or could be misused for the execution of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.  It is important to ensure an appropriate combination of EU legislative, administrative and case law in preventing and prohibiting the production, trade and use of goods that could be used for capital punishment or other cruel treatment. The EU must step up its efforts to eradicate torture by reducing the availability of such equipment, promoting adequate control beyond its borders, and it is also necessary to ensure control over the export of military equipment, firearms and torture and inhumane treatment goods. A targeted end-use clause should be introduced in order for Member States to stop the transfer of cases intended to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment. Member States are encouraged to promote best practices among suppliers of technical assistance in order to contribute positively to the fight against torture. The EU must update in a timely way checklists that include all such facilities, devices and equipment that may enter the market.  I believe it is necessary to find a balance in the supervision, interest of society and possible misuse of certain products, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The main proposals of this  amendment to the Council regulation are: to strengthen export controls targeting capital punishment; to create additional measures concerning listed goods as, for example, the proposal prohibits brokers in the Union from providing brokering services in relation to goods whose export and import are prohibited as such goods have no practical use other than for capital punishment; to clarify the definition of torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment; to create a system of exchange of information between customs authorities. I support these amendments and I think that the European Parliament has made the draft more clear and workable.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the adoption of an amended regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Council Regulation on trade in certain goods which can be used for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The regulation is part of a long-standing EU policy aimed at abolishing the death penalty and preventing torture around the world. The measures included in the proposal for a regulation strengthen control in the area of trade and export of goods and substances which may serve inhumane ways of carrying out the death penalty. The Commission shall periodically review the implementation of this Regulation every three years and submit a report on the outcome to the EP.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. It is therefore necessary to take account of the fact that, in the case of the United States of America,

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. Today, a 2005 regulation (No. 1236/2005) prohibits exports and imports of equipment specially designed to impose the death penalty, torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment. The text in question wishes on the one hand to extend restrictions and prohibitions (by interfering a little more in the sovereignty of States) and on the other hand, suffers from several inaccuracies which make it, in part, unenforceable.  On the other hand, certain concepts are overly extended, which makes sense the very purpose of such a regulation.  However, we support the idea that these imports and exports must be combated.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is currently working on its policy of eliminating the death penalty worldwide and preventing torture. To accomplish this goal, the rapporteur highlights the need for effective enforcement of controls, verifications, penalties, guidance and outreach carried out by national authorities to prevent the misuse of trading goods for crimes against humanity (i.e. capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment). Therefore, I voted in favour in order to take action on the matter.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The European Union too rarely grants its trade policy to the "diplomacy of values" it promotes. This gap is clearly reflected in two areas, neglected by most of the trade agreements to which the European Union is a party: the environment, and human rights.  Therefore, the European institutions are right to claim to be at the forefront of promoting the fight against the death penalty on a global scale (by the way, banned by the ECHR), but this posture would only fall within the declaration of intent if the Union did not have the right instruments. In this regard, the Schaake report is moving in the right direction. European companies thrive on the trade in goods used for torture, executions or degrading treatment. By voting for the Schaake report, we are not only banning the export of this type of goods (e.g. electric chairs) by companies based in the Union, but we are also prohibiting transit through the European Union, advertising (for example: a German company recently promoted 60,000 volt electric shock handcuffs), exposure at dedicated fairs and training in their use.  I have been an outs and all my support for this fair trade report.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the proposal for an EP regulation, which concerns the change of the regulation on trade in certain items which may be used for the death penalty but also other forms of degrading and inhuman treatment or punishment, because, in this way and through its established policy, the EU can contribute to the elimination of the death penalty, the prevention of torture and at the same time help to achieve these objectives by combining a specific authorisation programme for trade of similar Goods. It is necessary to ensure controls on EU exports, including lists of military equipment, dual-use items, firearms and torture instruments. Finally, I stress the key role that national authorities will have to play in effectively enforcing controls on these species and in establishing a system of regular reporting and review.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Here, goods that can be used to torture people are to be subject to export controls. For example, certain medicinal products used for the execution of the death penalty are to be included in this list. I support that.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP's report amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods which could be used for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Anti-Torture Regulation contributes to a long-term EU policy aimed at abolishing the death penalty and preventing torture worldwide. The Regulation contributes to the achievement of these objectives by combining prohibitions with the requirements for the authorisation of the marketing of the goods indicated.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. A 2005 "anti-torture" regulation establishes measures to restrict trade in goods that can be used for torture.  The report before us is intended to update this regulation. Thus the new version also prohibits the promotion and marketing of this type of goods on the internet.  The report also prohibits any type of training aimed at "transmitting operational knowledge or qualifications that may enable executions, torture or other ill-treatment".  I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Regulation (EC) No. 1236/2005 of June 2005 aims to prevent and prohibit all exports of equipment specially designed to inflict the death penalty, torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment.  The European Commission's proposal to amend the regulation is more restrictive and the prohibitions are extended to brokerage and transit services when the broker knows that the goods could be used to torture.  The terms "torture" and "degrading treatment" are overly broad, including, for example, prison overcrowding or lack of medical care.  The European Parliament's proposal also aims to tighten the original text by, for example, requiring Member States to suspend the transfer of security equipment not included in the annexes.  If the subject matter is laudable, it is misguided by an overly liberticidal formal approach. I have thereby abstained on both proposals.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 In June 2005, the Council of the European Union adopted Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods which may be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inotherane or degrading treatment or punishment.  The Regulation entered into force on 30 July 2006. I agree with this proposal and the prohibition of trade in these substances.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution which aims at creating a legally binding agreement that prohibits the exportation of medical products that may be used for capital punishment, torture or any other inhuman punishment.
