It is essential that the Union upholds its stance against capital punishment around the world and lives up to its own values of protecting life.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – It remains worrying that a high number of countries are still applying the death penalty while other countries and regimes are considering reintroducing the death penalty. That is why Europe continues to oppose the death penalty worldwide. That is why it is also necessary for Europe to commit itself to the abolition of the death penalty in all areas of its foreign policy. To this end, in 2005 the EU adopted an export control system for trade in goods that can be used for torture and the death penalty. Since this regulation, it has been prohibited to export such products to countries and regimes that have not abolished the death penalty. In order to further tighten up these regulations, an updated export control system is envisaged which provides for stricter customs controls, a ban on advertisements, publicity and marketing services for products that can be used in torture or executions and a better exchange of information between Member States. The EU is resolute in its commitment to better protection of human rights and the abolition of the death penalty. That is why it is necessary for the EU not only to play a leading role politically and diplomatically, but also to do so in all parts of its foreign policy.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The Anti-Torture Regulation contributes to the protection of human rights by controlling items and activities that are or could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel and inhumane treatment. It is a combination of prohibitions and licensing requirements for trade in the goods in question. The legislative update of the regulation is a positive step. On the one hand, it is necessary to control the export of goods that could be used for torture or the death penalty, but the requirement that there should be no unnecessary burdens that restrict legal trade is also in place. Adapting control regimes to make them more flexible and adaptable to developments in the world and changing technologies, and the consistency of EU export controls with regard to lists of military goods, dual-use goods, firearms and torture goods so as not to duplicate checks on these items are essential steps. The regulation of legal access to medicines and pharmaceutical products, of which the EU is a key manufacturer, is of great importance. The effective implementation of controls and verifications of the application of sanctions, the provision of guidance and the provision of support activities carried out by national authorities is crucial. In this case too, it is necessary to ensure a level playing field and a Community approach and adequate monitoring of member states' compliance with their obligations.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which aims to contribute to the elimination of the death penalty worldwide and prevent torture through EU-wide controls on exports of torture goods and drugs used for lethal injection. This is a much welcomed example of the EU setting a global standard in eradicating torture. The updated rules will help EU authorities to react more quickly to new emerging trends in torture and inhumane treatment, namely by regulating their sale on line etc. In recent years we have seen how a change in EU practices has led to the demise of the death penalty in many partner countries such as the US. This will be set to continue when the regulation comes into force.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of strengthening the 2005 regulation banning trade in items that could be used for torture or executions in third countries, in order to address loopholes identified by civil society and make this ambitious piece of legislation (the first of its kind worldwide) even more effective.  I welcome in particular the fact that the European Parliament’s views on brokering and technical assistance, including advertising and promotion, transit through the Union’s territory of such goods, and the review clause, have been included in the final version of the compromise agreed with the Council and the Commission.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 against torture is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights through the control of products and activities applicable to the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Combining prohibitions with licensing requirements for trade in listed products will help to achieve a global eradication of the death penalty and torture. It introduces a ban on devices that can only be used for torture and the execution of the death penalty, and establishes a licensing system for products suitable for torture and lethal injection executions in the event of abusive use. In 2014, the Commission proposed to the European Parliament and the Council an amendment to that Regulation in order to review EU control over the trade in torture equipment and update the list of products under control. In its report, the Committee on International Trade recommends that Parliament adopt the draft at first reading with 38 amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Regulation 1236/2005 of June 2005 aims to prevent and prohibit the export of materials specifically designed to inflict the death penalty, torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment (inflicted by a civil service officer or other official unless they are legitimate sanctions). Goods and technical assistance for the sole use of the death penalty or torture, listed in the appendix, are prohibited from exporting and importing.  Those that can be used for such purposes are subject to authorisation. If, on principle, one can only agree, on the other hand the text has been modified by various catch-all provisions, which create a certain legal uncertainty and allow the apprehension of a large number of goods, therefore it is better to abstain.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation "Fight against Torture" (EC) No 1236/2005 is a single instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights by controlling products and activities that are used or may be misused to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.  The Anti-Torture Regulation contributes to the EU's long-standing policy of eliminating the death penalty worldwide and preventing torture. It contributes to achieving these objectives by combining prohibitions with licensing requirements for the trade of listed products.  I support the need to review the rules on EU controls on trade in torture instruments, as well as the updating of control lists.  It is essential to ensure an appropriate combination of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures in order to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of torture products and effectively control products susceptible to lethal and incapitaluses.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text relates to a proposed regulation to amend the proposal for trade in certain goods that could be used for the purpose of imposing capital punishment or torture.  Indeed, since 2005, trade in such goods has been governed by Regulation (EC) No. 1236/2005, which prohibits its export or importation unless a very strict exemption is granted following a written request.  The European Parliament is proposing to toughen this text by ensuring that a European can no longer provide brokerage services for this product outside the Union's borders. However, considering that this is a competence that must be up to the States, I have decided to abstain in the vote on this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the trade in certain goods that could be used to impose capital punishment, torture or other cruel punishment or treatment.  The purpose of this text is to establish a trade-ban regime for all goods specifically intended for torture and executions and related technical assistance and an authorisation regime for goods that may be used for the same purpose when diverted.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The "Regulation against Torture" (Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005) is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights through the control of goods and activities that are used or could be misused to practice the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.  In this regard, I considered that I voted in favour of the measure amending the regulation, in which the European Union aims to further strengthen its role as a responsible leader in the fight against the death penalty and in the elimination of torture by strengthening the provisions relating to ancillary services related to the transfer of goods, as well as on transit, technical assistance and trade promotion.  It is important to ensure the right combination of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of goods for torture purposes and to effectively control items with potential lethal and inhuman uses.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The death penalty is an uncivilized revenge, not a punishment. In states with autocratic regimes, the death penalty is a huge threat, because it is the strongest tool for siding critics and opponents – forever. The impossibility of rehabilitation, the release of executed political prisoners, has such a powerful deterrent effect on opponents of the dictatorship that it discourages the overwhelming majority from showing resistance, thereby making the distorted system even more concrete.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that calls for human rights protection and for the EU’s policy of eliminating the death penalty worldwide or any other type of human torture.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported this report because I believe that, as one of the organisations with a strong commitment to ensuring peace and promoting values such as the right to free speech, rights of isolated groups, etc. in the world, the European Union must consistently ensure respect for those values, including by controlling, and in particular, the unused European goods in the application of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. I also gave my support to the report because I support the establishment of an anti-torture coordination group ensuring the presence and voice of each Member State. I believe that the functioning of this group would support the examination of all issues relating to the application of Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 and the exchange of information between the various representatives. This will build pan-European know-how that will improve the application of the Regulation and contribute to the fight against trade in goods that could be used for the purpose of capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment at global level.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, supporting the concern that the trade with certain goods could be used for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Prohibiting such services is essential to protect public morals and to respect the principles of human dignity which underpin European values, as embodied in the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Furthermore, it is necessary to prohibit brokers in the Union from providing brokering services in relation to goods whose export and import are prohibited as such goods have no practical use other than for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. I am also in agreement with the prohibition of commercial marketing and promotion of any transit of goods listed in Annex II, regardless of the origin of such goods, unless such goods will be used for the exclusive purpose of public display in a museum, taking into consideration their historic significance.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the recasting of the existing rules in order to increase the ability to effectively prevent the production, trafficking and use of torture-related goods and to effectively control goods that could be used to kill or treat people inhumanely.  In particular, it is about preventing controlled medicinal products from being used to carry out the death penalty by lethal injection, introducing a prohibition on brokering services in the field of prohibited goods and extending the prohibition on brokering services and providing technical assistance in the field of controlled goods in cases where the supplier or intermediary knows or has reason to believe that the goods could be used for torture, and finally the introduction of a general Union export authorisation for countries which, in accordance with Protocol No 13 of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights or the Second Optional Protocol of the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights, have made clear international commitments.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the proposal put to the vote contains some positive aspects which are included in the list of enhanced bans on torture and the death penalty by including the necessary goods.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The EU wants to include stronger requirements for trade in certain goods that can be used to carry out the death penalty or torture. This regulation needs to be updated in order to further strengthen EU action at global level in the fight against the death penalty and the abolition of torture.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report.  I believe that it is necessary to impose extremely strict requirements on trade in goods that can be used for capital punishment or torture. In particular, adequate respect for human life and fundamental human rights must be ensured and the public interest and moral norms must be protected.  It is necessary to prohibit the export and import of such equipment. It is to be welcomed that the rules have been supplemented by provisions that will discipline or, in some cases, strictly control not only the export of the goods in question, but also their transit through EU territory or advertising. The implementation of the measures envisaged will ensure that economic operators do not benefit from trade in goods which are practically used only for the execution of capital or torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report prohibits the export of products that have no practical use other than that for the execution or torture of people (e.g. electric chairs and automatic systems for intravenous injections of medicinal substances designed for human execution). It also introduces controls on trade in products designed for other purposes but could be used for torture or execution of people. As has also been pointed out, it is important to properly combine EU legislative measures with administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of torture instruments and to effectively control objects that may be used for lethal and inhuman purposes. The absence of multilateral export control systems in the field of torture instruments inevitably makes this task difficult. The adoption of this regulation is another step in our efforts to abolish the death penalty and torture everywhere in the world. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation on the issue of a special permit for objects which, whether intended directly or by their nature, can be used for the execution of the death penalty or for torture highlights the hypocrisy of the EU and its institutions. Instead of completely prohibiting their production, especially of articles intended solely for such purposes, or placing conditions prohibiting their use for such purposes, they supposedly put conditions on their marketing even though they know that they can move seamlessly through various channels. The text of the agreement with the Council, as it has come back, is even worse than the original one since it eliminates any stricter provisions for their movement. It also removes the general clause that existed for examining, where appropriate, the actual use, by destination, of any object that could be used for such purposes, while the dependence of the authorisation on the knowledge of traders or brokers of the purpose for which they are intended constitutes a genuine impregnate. You would not expect anything different from the EU pretending to be 'sensitive' to the death penalty and torture, while its imperialist wars are drowning peoples in blood and while its war industry is one of the most golden areas of action in the capital.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. UKIP objects to the EU dictating our terms of trade, so we would have been minded to vote against, however due to the sensitive nature of the report we did not oppose. There are practical problems in defining ‘items of torture’. Our concern in the future is that conventional and innocuous items could be added the list of restricted goods and may affect legitimate trade. UKIP, of course, condemns any form of torture.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas there is a need to prepare new European rules to prevent trade in goods and services that can be used to perpetrate torture or the death penalty; that the prohibition of these goods and services is aimed at protecting public morality and respecting the principles of human dignity at the basis of European values, as enshrined in the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union; that the European institutions have always been at the forefront of the fight against torture and the death penalty, it is essential to regulate in a precise and careful manner the export and import of goods used for these purposes. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I supported this report as I consider it important to control the export of goods which are used for the death penalty and torture. I welcomed the Commission proposal as adequate. The European Parliament report stressed that unnecessary burdens for exporters must be avoided.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a Regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013; 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods that could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, as it demonstrates, in particular, the EU's concern to prevent to the fullest extent the undesirable effects of products manufactured in the EU. The execution of the death penalty, torture and inhuman treatment are only of some purpose for which EU products may be used, which is contrary to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and not only that, but also is in stark contrast to respect for human dignity and human rights. This Regulation adopts some newspapers in relation to the Council Regulation and thus complements its shortcomings. The Regulation prohibits brokerage services relating to those products where there is reasonable grounds to suspect that those goods could be used for these undesirable purposes. It also stipulates that any export of goods requires the authorisation of the competent authorities. These two examples show that the EU is doing its utmost to prevent any form of inhumane treatment.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Regulation (EC) No. 1236/2005 of June 2005 aims to prevent and prohibit all exports of equipment specially designed to inflict the death penalty, torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment.  Goods and technical assistance for goods for the sole use of the death penalty or torture, listed in Appendix II, are prohibited from exporting and importing. Goods and technical assistance for products that can be used for the death penalty or torture, listed in Appendix III, must have an export permit. The European Commission proposes to extend restrictions and prohibitions to brokerage and transit services when the broker knows they could be used for torture and to broaden the definition of "torture and degrading treatment" by including prison overcrowding, lack of medical care, prohibition of all contact with the outside world, etc.  The text is also unenforceable because it does not speak of certainties or elements about the use of goods or services for torture but of "may serve...". The European Parliament is proposing to toughen it up further. Opposed to any form of torture, I of course refuse the export of instruments of torture, but this text is too vague and unenforceable as it stands. So I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The proposal for a text of the revised Regulation contains many changes aimed at further contributing to the abolition of the death penalty worldwide and preventing torture through EU control and prohibition of the export of goods that can be used for torture or the execution of the death penalty. With its amendments, the EP wants to further expand the scope of the revised Regulation. The most important amendments to the text proposed by the Commission relate to: prohibition of transit of goods (meaning transport of goods, specified in annexes, which is not from the Union, destination is outside the Union but which passes through the CUSTOMS TERRITORY of the EU), the prohibition of commercial advertising and promotion of goods specified in the annexes, the prohibition of providing training or transfer of knowledge or skills that could be used for the purpose of execution, torture and other abuse , the introduction of a comprehensive clause which will require even authorisation to export goods not specified in the annexes where it is intended for the needs of capital punishment, torture and other inhumane treatment. The EU has already delivered positive results in reducing the death penalty in partner countries, and with the entry into force of this Regulation, the EU's fight to abolish the death penalty and ban torture globally continues.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005, which aims to combat torture, is an instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights by controlling products and activities that are used, or may be used, abusively to impose the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation lays down a ban on trade in 'single-use' products intended for torture and executions and their technical assistance (Annex II) and a system for authorising fair products that can be misused to inflict torture and carry out executions by lethal injection (Annex III). It is now proposed to strengthen controls on torture instruments. Lists of specific articles provide clarity to exporters and importers and help to ensure compliance with the rules. In a context where external trade operations are increasingly complex, the key role of the effective implementation of controls, verifications, sanctions, guidelines and awareness-raising actions carried out by national authorities is underlined. A periodic reporting and review system seems appropriate, in line with other export control schemes. The objectives of the Regulation appear to be fair and the means it defines, proportionate.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support this proposal, as putting it into practice should strengthen and consolidate the EU's role in its efforts to eradicate the death penalty and torture altogether. The proposal focuses on the fight against trafficking in goods intended for torture or execution of the death penalty and calls for a complete ban on licences for trafficking in such goods (e.g. lethal injections, other pharmaceuticals and other goods, precisely specified on specific lists). At the same time, it also strengthens the provisions relating to ancillary services linked to the transfer of goods and the provisions relating to transit, technical assistance and commercialisation. I welcome the establishment of a regular review mechanism, a more systematic exchange of information and a strengthening of supervision of the implementation of the Regulation. I believe that more effective controls and better cooperation in this area will increase the chances of eradicating trade in goods that would be intended for inhuman or degrading treatment or lead to death.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal for a regulation aims to amend the previous regulation of 2005 concerning goods that can be used to impose the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment.  In the new regulation, the Commission proposes to insert an annex designed to prevent the goods in question from being used to impose the death penalty by lethal injection, to extend the restrictions on technical assistance services and to include the possibility of an urgent procedure to amend Annexes 2, 3 and 3a. The European Parliament voted in October 2015 on a number of amendments that amended the proposal, later opening the informal trialogue with the Council, which ended positively on 24 May 2016.  I am firmly opposed to the death penalty and consider this proposal for a regulation to be very important in order to protect the right to life of every human being. That is why I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Regulation 1236/2005 prohibits the export and import of equipment and goods which have no other application than torture or the execution of the death penalty. A list of them is given in Annex II to that Regulation. The same act requires that exports of equipment and goods which are suitable for the above purposes but which also have other legitimate uses be subject to special authorisations. Such goods are assessed individually. Regulation 1236/2005 was amended in 2011 to control the export of substances that can be used in lethal injections during executions. The tripartite text introduces a system of prior authorisations for the provision of brokering and technical assistance services for goods in Annex III or IIIA. Brokering and technical assistance related to the goods in Annex II shall be prohibited. Prohibits the transit of the goods listed in Annex II and the goods in Annexes III and IIIA. Prohibits the advertising and promotion of goods in Annex II. It allows Member States to adopt or maintain additional national measures restricting certain services in respect of the goods in Annex II. It shall set up a coordination group in which experts from the Member States and the Commission will exchange information on administrative practices. It applies the urgency procedure to Annexes II, III, IIIA and IIIB and introduces a review clause. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which revises European rules to combat trade in goods or services that can contribute to torture or the death penalty.  Specifically, we voted for a ban on the marketing or transit of material that can be used for cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment of people in third countries.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. For many years, the European Union has maintained a firm position against the application of death sentences, torture, as well as other cruel, inpartororan or degrading treatment or punishment. The adoption by the Council of Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 reiterates its intention to eliminate such practices. Thus, by establishing export control mechanisms at Union level, it is possible to prohibit the export of goods whose destination may be related to acts of torture or be used for lethal purposes. The revision of the Regulation aims to strengthen and update the checklists in the annexes to the diploma, as well as to extend the prohibition on brokerage and technical assistance services to controlled products, introduce a General Union Export Authorisation and create urgent procedures to enable rapid amendment to its annexes. Because it is essential to ensure an appropriate combination of legislative, administrative and judicial measures against the transaction of products likely to be lethal or inhumane, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. UKIP objects to the EU dictating our terms of trade, so we would have been minded to vote against, however due to the sensitive nature of the report we did not oppose. There are practical problems in defining ‘items of torture’. Our concern in the future is that conventional and innocuous items could be added the list of restricted goods and may affect legitimate trade. UKIP, of course, condemns any form of torture.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I consider it imperative to ensure an appropriate combination of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures in order to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of torture goods and effectively monitor products that may be used for lethal or inotherane purposes. The lack of multilateral export control regimes for torture goods, unlike the 'dual-use' regime, inevitably hampers the task. However, the EU cannot limit its action to eradicate torture by reducing the availability of abusive equipment, putting an end to practices of circumventing legislation and promoting appropriate controls across its borders. Trade instruments are part of a comprehensive approach that uses all EU instruments for external action. It is essential to ensure consistency of EU export controls, including controls on lists of military material, dual-use products, firearms and torture goods, without subjecting products to double and/or unnecessary controls that may create superfluous burdens and restrict trade for a legitimate purpose.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. By an unambiguous vote of 612 votes to 11, and 54 abstentions, MEPs approved a strengthening of EU rules against the trade in goods that could be used for torture or the death penalty by third countries. It will now be banned throughout Europe to advertise goods used for torture, such as electric chairs, including at trade fairs. Their transit into the territory of the European Union will be entirely prohibited, as will that of "controlled" goods (i.e. designed for other purposes but which can be used for torture, like some riot weapons), as long as they are destined to end up in the wrong hands.  Is it necessary to recall that the death penalty is still applied in 58 states and territories around the world and that 2015 was a particularly bleak year in this regard?  Amnesty International has recorded its highest number of executions since 1989, peaking at least 1,634 people. Similarly, the NGO has reported cases of torture in at least 141 countries over the past five years, even though 156 states around the world are signatories to the UN Convention against Torture.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union shall assume its role in the control of products and activities that are used, or may be used, abusively to impose the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. These proposals follow the EU's long-standing policy aimed at eliminating the death penalty worldwide and preventing torture. It contributes to achieving these objectives by combining prohibitions with licensing requirements for trade in the listed products. This Regulation lays down a prohibition on trade in 'single-use' products intended for torture and executions and their technical assistance, as well as a system for authorising versitable products which can be misused to inflict torture and carry out executions by lethal injection. The revision of EU controls on trade in torture instruments has long been awaited and updating the checklists is another step in the right direction.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new European legislation against business linked to torture and the death penalty, as a pioneering human rights initiative in the world. It introduces binding executive measures that will prevent any european participation in this appalling business. It strengthens the export ban and control introduced in 2006, making it more effective. And it extends its application to new products, such as drugs for lethal injection, and to services such as transportation, online advertising, technical assistance or commercial intermediation.  No foreign commercial agent may re-exhibit torture material at Union trade fairs. And the responsibility of the Member States in their duty of control and information is strengthened. When Spain assumed the presidency of the Council of the Union in 2010, the Socialist Government of Rodríguez-Zapatero called on the Union to reform in this regard. Today, the Union has taken a step further against torture and capital punishment, and the Social Democrats have been able to demonstrate that trade policy is and must be a fundamental tool for promoting progress and human rights in the world.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which opposes the sinister trade in torture tools.  This report is an important step in bridging the gaps in the prevention of torture and ill-treatment in Europe.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. It aims to close the gaps in trade in certain goods that could be used for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Despite the pre-existing bans, companies have discovered ways to sell and promote certain goods. The European Parliament has therefore called on the European Commission to update these rules. First of all, online and offline commercial marketing, transit restrictions and an expanded list of goods are included.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Export control mechanisms at EU level are trade policy instruments at the service of a wider set of policy objectives. Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005, which aims to combat the use of torture, is an instrument that promotes the protection of human rights by controlling products and activities that are, or may be, misused to apply the death penalty, inflict torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The regulation to combat torture aims to contribute to the EU's long-standing political objective of eliminating the death penalty worldwide and combating the use of torture. The revision of Community controls on trade in torture instruments has been long awaited. It is therefore important to ensure an appropriate combination of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures in order to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of torture goods and effectively monitor products that can be used for lethal or inother-called purposes. Because I agree with the content of this report, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the revision of the regulation on the trade of certain goods that could be used for the purpose of imposing capital punishment, torture or other cruel punishment or treatment.  This update of the regulation strengthens current EU legislation to continue to prevent companies from contributing to the exercise of the death penalty or torture of third countries by directly or indirectly marketing certain goods. Provisions are also in place for the EU to respond quickly and adapt to the development of new technologies. This text reminds us that international trade must respect and contribute to the promotion of the values of the European Union on the international stage.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as we are satisfied with the Commission's proposal, and even more so, following a very constructive process of amendments. While I am aware that the new regulation alone will not eliminate the death penalty or prevent torture globally, I believe it is a step forward in this regard.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal on trade in certain goods that could be used for the execution of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The proposal includes the banning of goods that could be used for the execution of the death penalty and torture. This also applies to all mediation activities and the provision of technical assistance in connection with the goods listed. The customs authorities must exchange certain information in order to impose sanctions on the economic operator who committed the infringement.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report seeks to regulate trade in certain products that can be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or degrading treatment, which I consider very necessary and for this reason I voted in favour of the report. However, although I have supported the report with my vote, I believe that the Union has no credibility in the fight against torture as long as it continues to be subordinate to the United States (for example, there is evidence that torture has been routinely practiced at Guantanamo with complete impunity for 14 years). The report contains numerous proposals with which I fully agree, such as asking to ensure that Union exports to third countries do not contribute to what the Union considers to be 'inhuman' practices, such as electric chairs, or cage beds. But unfortunately the Union has no credibility in its so-called 'fight against torture' as long as we continue to profit from the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia, or as long as our partners have torture and the death penalty legalised. If we are really against torture, we should start by reviewing our relations with third countries, until they comply with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Strengthening the 2005 regulation will allow better control of trade in goods that are or could be misused to carry out the death penalty or inflict torture.  I voted in favour of this legislative update as it aims to close the loopholes in the basic text by ensuring the right combination of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of tools with potential lethal and inhuman uses. In addition, more restrictions have been introduced on marketing, promotion and transit within the Territory of the Union and a system of prior authorisation for the intermediation and technical assistance of controlled goods.  I hope that this approach will ensure effective controls and checks without unnecessary burdens that hinder legitimate business activities.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this as I do not believe the EU should control what nation-states should and should not trade.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted in favour of the report on Trade in certain goods which could be used for capital punishment, torture or other treatment or punishment. The new rules outlined in the report represent an update of the EU’s 2005 Anti-torture Regulation and list goods and substances that are either banned for export, such as electric chairs, or need export clearance at EU borders.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ This report bans the export and import of equipment and goods that can only be used for torture or capital punishment. As I am against torture and believe this is not the way how confessions are needed to be made, I voted in favour.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the legislative resolution because I consider the update of the regulation on the marketing of certain goods that can be used for capital punishment, torture or other treatment or punishment to be the right move. I believe that the modification of the regulation will strengthen the EU's role as a major and responsible global actor in the fight against the death penalty, torture or other ill-treatment or punishment. Although it is generally the case that goods produced in the EU in accordance with legislation or legally imported into the EU benefit from freedom of movement, I believe that in these cases it is essential for the national authorities to carry out more effective checks and apply harsher sanctions against violators. I believe that EU-wide export controls are among the very good instruments of foreign trade policy, serving a range of broader policy objectives. I expect the Member States, in accordance with the targeted end-use clause, to ensure that transfers of safety-related goods which clearly have no practical use other than for the purpose of capital punishment, torture or other ill-treatment are prohibited or suspended.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the legislative resolution on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods that could be used for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. I consider the revision of the current 'Anti-Torture Regulation' (EC) No 1236/2005 to be an important step forward, which will contribute on a global scale to greater protection of human rights, the end of the death penalty and the prohibition of torture. Immediate updating and effective control of goods or activities that are used or could be misused to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment is therefore more than appropriate. I therefore welcome the inclusion of substances that are used for legitimate therapeutic purposes but can be used for the death penalty at high doses in injection, i therefore welcome the inclusion of substances that are used for controlled goods. From the point of view of Czech exporters, I consider it essential, in particular, to introduce a general export authorisation for designated goods to selected third countries. Together with other measures, this will make a significant contribution to streamlining the control of the goods identified, while reducing the administrative burden on exporters.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The export control mechanism was first designed at European level in 2005 by Regulation No 1236/2005 and has helped to respect human rights in third countries. The new regulation will expand this control mechanism further, while filling out major gaps in existing export controls of products that could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other similar treatment and punishment. The report also includes a ban on the transit of these products, as well as a ban on advertising and promotion of products prohibited for export. Under the new Regulation, Member States will be obliged, through national preventive mechanisms established under the auspices of the UN Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment, to provide information on the controls they have carried out over trade in the said products. I support the report and the announced regulation, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. This report deals with the export of goods that can also be used for the execution of the death penalty or for torture. Of course, I too would prefer a world without torture and the death penalty. While the intention is understandable, it should be clear that these export bans do not make torture or the death penalty impossible. With the death penalty in particular, the goods to be exported would probably even be in the interests of humanity. For example.B stoning is possible everywhere – a poison injection would probably be the more humane alternative. In this report, therefore, we were primarily concerned with reducing the negative side effects on trade in goods that are not used for the purposes mentioned. As the report is a sensible compromise in this sense, I voted in favour of it.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The Countries of the European Union have waived the use of the death penalty. In accordance with the principles of the protection of life, they will not provide countries where executions or torture are carried out with the means and tools that make this activity possible or easier. This will also apply to transit through the customs territory of the European Union or to the sale and promotion of such items on the Internet.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I abstained from the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods that could be used for the execution of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. I am a staunch opponent of the death penalty. Man can be wrong and should not impose penalties that cannot be reversed or remedied. I do, of course, share the aim of the proposal for a regulation that it would be good not to support states that provide for and impose the death penalty by trading in the goods they need. However, I do not believe that the EU should have the competence to regulate trade. This competence should be within the member states. I cannot therefore agree with the proposal, which has little objection in substance.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ "Anti-torture Regulation" (EC) No 1236/2005 is a single legal instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights by controlling things and activities that are used or can be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or punishment. It consists of a ban on trade in one-off torture and murder and related technical aids as well as authorisation systems for multipurpose items that may be misused for torture or murder.  As foreign trade becomes more complex, it is important to establish as efficiently as possible controls, checks, penalties and guidance carried out at Member State level, but also at Union level. It underlines the necessary oversight of implementation at Member State level, including their obligation to report on the situation and exchange information. Therefore, I support the report on the proposal for a Regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1002/2013. 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods that could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Council Regulation on trade in certain goods which could be used for the execution of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation for the Prevention of Torture, which brings control of goods and activities used for the purposes of torture, will make a significant contribution to reducing these cruel acts. I support a legislative update that will contribute to the updating of the checklists and the correct mix of EU legislation to prevent and ban the production and use of goods for torture and trade in them.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods that could be used for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It is one of the instruments that protect human rights, which aims to contribute to ending the execution of the death penalty worldwide and the prohibition of torture, by restricting the trafficking of goods used in these activities. I believe that this is the right step contributing to the protection of life, human rights and freedoms, while at the same time reducing cruel inhuman behaviour.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Anti-Torture Regulation is an instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights through the control of the species and activities used or could be misused for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It is important to properly combine EU legislative measures with administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of torture instruments and to effectively control items that may be used for lethal and inhumane purposes.  The Commission proposes to strengthen controls on torture instruments by proposing ways and the rapporteur in turn supports the approach to necessary and proportionate controls without unnecessary burden. For all the above reasons, we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report will have no substantive effect because there is no way to deprive the media of either executions or torture. We are, on the basis of principles, against torture, but we nevertheless believe that the death penalty should be reviewed, especially in cases of particularly heinous crimes.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-wide export controls are a foreign trade policy instrument for broader policy purposes. Export controls are an important policy tool for the European Union. Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 against torture is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights, the global eradication of the death penalty and torture by controlling products and activities that can be used in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation lays down the European Union's long-aspirations to combine prohibitions with the licensing requirements for trade in the products listed in its Annexes. It introduces a ban on means of torture and the execution of the death penalty and related technical assistance (Annex II) and establishes a licensing system for products suitable for torture and lethal injection executions in the event of misuse (Annex III). The draft opinion also proposes the development of a equipment coordination group and the implementation of a periodic review mechanism and a more systemic information sharing and reporting system in order to strengthen control and effectively implement the Regulation. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision because I believe that this will reaffirm the European Union's leading role in the fight against the death penalty and torture in the world. In the case of devices and agents used for the execution of death sentences and torture, the 'emergency procedure' now in place allows States to block the export, transfer and transfer of such articles even on obvious suspicions, and will also be able to prohibit the sale of such articles on the Internet, advertising, training and knowledge transfer. Having made a substantial contribution to reducing this repugnant and inhumane practice in partner countries in the previous period, I hope that this decision by the EP, which enjoys broad political support, will continue to do so more effectively, until torture and the death penalty are completely eradicated.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Until now, the ban on the sale and export of equipment that could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or inhuman and degrading punishment has been regulated by the EU Regulation of 2005. However, it did not address key issues, including m.in ban on promoting and advertising tools used to torture people. Under the new regulation, the promotion and advertising of goods that are clearly used for execution or torture, such as electric chairs, automatic infusion pumps used to administer poison injections, leg chains or spike sticks, will be prohibited. The ban will also cover exhibitions and arms fairs organised on the territory of the European Union. I believe that the European Union should not in any way facilitate torture and the use of the death penalty by providing tools that can be used to do so. That is why the document also rightly includes provisions prohibiting the transport of such goods through EU territory, even if they are ultimately intended to reach third countries. Moreover, the Regulation properly addressed the issue of the transport of items that have been designed for other purposes but can be used for torture. Under new EU law, carriers will be required to stop transporting items if they know they may end up in bad hands.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 The end of the trilogue negotiations on this report was an important achievement and I voted categorically in favour of this report. With regard to trade policy, we can also contribute to the realisation of human rights and, in particular, to the abolition of the death penalty and torture.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union exports a wide range of goods worldwide. These include a number of products that can be used as torture and execution tools, for example through lethal injections. To this end, control at EU level is required in order to avoid the use of exported products in ways that contravene the 2005 European Torture Regulation or the death penalty, a procedure that the EU wants eliminated worldwide. This is not currently possible due to the absence of multilateral export control regimes in question, in particular with regard to military goods, dual-use goods, firearms, medical products. One solution could be the creation of a general Union export authorisation for countries that have made commitments in accordance with Protocol 1 to the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the European Economic Community. 13 to the European Convention on Human Rights or the Second Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. It would contain specific product lists, providing added clarity for exporters, and a number of checks, checks, sanctions, guidelines and information from national authorities. The European Parliament must be properly involved in this process. I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text proposed by my Dutch colleague. Export controls, which apply throughout the UNION, are instruments of foreign trade policy that contribute to the achievement of a wider range of strategic objectives. Regulation (EC) 1236/2005 "against torture" is a privileged means of strengthening the protection of human rights by subjecting to controls the goods and activities used, or likely to be diverted, to inflict the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ In respecting fundamental human rights, the EU supports the movement for the global abolition of capital punishment in every manner it can. Regrettably, however, capital punishment remains intact in many third countries with which the EU shares trade ties with. Nevertheless, the respect for human rights is one of the core values of the European Union and remains an essential element in the Union’s relationships it fosters with third countries. Although there already exists a regulatory framework which prohibits the export and import of goods which can be used to apply the death penalty or to inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment and punishment, there remains a need to tighten the regulation through the use of export authorisation requirements on goods that could be used for the purpose of torture or other ill-treatment. I too share the desire to eradicate capital punishment around the word, as was done in the EU in 2012, and this is why I voted in favour of the legislative proposal.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted to amend the Regulation on trade in certain goods that could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The aim of this regulation is to eliminate the death penalty in the world and prevent the torture of people by suspending the transfer of items that have no practical purpose other than the execution of the death penalty or torture.  One of the determinants of the regulation is that the competent authorities of the Member States do not issue authorisations if there is reasonable grounds that the goods could be used for the death penalty or torture.  In my view, the Anti-Torture Coordination Group established by this Regulation is necessary, in particular, to establish direct cooperation between the competent authorities and to achieve an effective exchange of information on administrative practices.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods which could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment I have supported. The Anti-Torture Regulation contributes to the EU's long-standing policy on abolishing the death penalty worldwide and preventing torture. It is important to ensure an appropriate mix of EU legislation and administrative, legal and external measures in order to prevent and prohibit the production and use of torture goods and to effectively control goods with potentially deadly and inhumane use.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ The 2005 Anti-Torture Regulation contained loopholes. Although the Regulation banned certain equipment which could be used for torture or the death penalty, its transit through the EU territory was permitted. With these amendments, this loophole is closed. Aside from transit, the marketing and promotion of this equipment is also prohibited.  These are important steps forward into enforcing the total ban on torture and the death penalty.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as we are satisfied with the Commission's proposal, and even more so, following a very constructive process of amendments. While I am aware that the new regulation alone will not eliminate the death penalty or prevent torture globally, I believe it is a step forward in this regard.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. I am strongly opposed to the death penalty and supported the EU proposal of a UN moratorium on death penalty. The EU cannot be credible and consistent with its core and fundamental values if the EU and its Member States allow to trade goods and products used for capital punishment. These are not normal products that can be traded like any others.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The purpose of this 2005 regulation is to prevent and prohibit the export of material specially designed to impose the death penalty, torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment.  The national competent authority issues authorisations on a written request for up to 12 months if it does not have strong suspicions about the use for torture and the death penalty.  The European Commission wants to restrict and ban brokerage and transit services when the broker knows they could be used for torture... The term torture and degrading treatment is overly extended, including prison overcrowding, lack of medical care, prohibition of contact with the outside world, etc.    The European Parliament, for its part, proposes to tighten the text even further. This text will be unenforceable and ineffective.  I choose abstention.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Export control is not just an external trade tool. It can also effectively promote the protection of human rights in those countries which are recipients of goods and services potentially serving the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The consistency of Union export controls in this area should m.in. by updating the list of tools to be subject to this control. Regulation 1236/2005 on the prevention of torture also applies to exports of equipment and goods which may be used for torture, although this is not their exclusive use. Their export should be subject to special conditions. The proposed amendments to the Regulation also allow Member States to adopt or maintain additional measures to restrict anading services related to goods (e.g. advertising, transport, financial services). The regulation will undoubtedly strengthen the european Union's responsible role in combating the death penalty and torture in the world. I strongly support this resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Anti-Torture Regulation contributes to the global eradication of the death penalty and torture, which is a long-time ambition of the EU. It helps to achieve these objectives by combining prohibitions with the licensing requirements for trade in listed products. It introduces a ban on devices and technical assistance for torture and the execution of the death penalty only, and establishes a licensing system for products suitable for torture and lethal injection executions in the event of misuse. In agreement with the S&D group's position, I supported the adoption of the report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as we are satisfied with the Commission's proposal, and even more so, following a very constructive process of amendments. While I am aware that the new regulation alone will not eliminate the death penalty or prevent torture globally, I believe it is a step forward in this regard.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation on trade in certain products that can be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment as trade is also a very important tool that we must use to protect human rights, combat torture and eradicate the death penalty in the world. The amplification of this export control mechanism is therefore very good news.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – The purpose of this Convention is to address these problems at international level if it is established that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the State in which the child is habitually resident. The Convention also provides for a system to ensure that the abducted child is returned immediately.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 concerning trade in certain goods which could be used for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The ‘Anti-Torture Regulation’ (EC) No 1236/2005 is a unique instrument that contributes to protection of human rights via controls on items and activities that are used for or could be misused for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The ‘Anti-Torture Regulation’ contributes to the long-standing EU policy of eliminating the death penalty worldwide, and of preventing torture. It helps achieve these goals by combining prohibitions with licensing requirements for trade in listed goods. I voted in favour because I believe that it is of crucial importance to ensure a right mix of the EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of torture goods and effectively control items with potential lethal and inhumane uses.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The prohibition of torture and ill-treatment is a key pillar of the United Nations human rights conventions, signed by the Union, one of whose core values is the promotion of respect for fundamental rights around the world. In June 2016, the Eurochamber reached agreement with the European Council on products that can be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment with the aim of preventing Union exports from contributing to human rights violations in third countries. Voting in favour of this agreement, which will allow Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 to be amended in the light of developments since it entered into force (2006), with particular attention to export control rules, new controls on intermediation services and technical assistance, and the prohibition of advertising of certain products.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. This report seeks to regulate trade in certain products that can be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or degrading treatment, which I consider very necessary and for this reason I voted in favour of the report. However, although I have supported the report with my vote, I believe that the Union has no credibility in the fight against torture as long as it continues to be subordinate to the United States (for example, there is evidence that torture has been routinely practiced at Guantanamo with complete impunity for 14 years). The report contains numerous proposals with which I fully agree, such as asking to ensure that Union exports to third countries do not contribute to what the Union considers to be 'inhuman' practices, such as electric chairs, or cage beds. But unfortunately the Union has no credibility in its so-called 'fight against torture' as long as we continue to profit from the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia, or as long as our partners have torture and the death penalty legalised. If we are really against torture, we should start by reviewing our relations with third countries, until they comply with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ With my EPLP colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because there will be an updated ‘urgency procedure’ which would allow the prevention of the export of goods listed in the annexes which present a ‘clear and immediate’ risk that they will be used for torture. There will also be an outright ban on displaying and selling torture goods at trade fairs.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report by my liberal colleague Schaake. EU-wide export controls are foreign trade policy instruments that serve a wide range of broader policy objectives. This regulation is part of the long-standing EU policy of combating the death penalty worldwide and preventing torture. The Regulation prohibits trade in goods which can only be used for torture and executions and related technical assistance and establishes a system for authorisations for goods which can be used for various purposes and could be misused for torture and executions by lethal injection .

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The death penalty violates the right to life as enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights. Torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment, prohibited by these same texts and ad hoc international conventions, violate fundamental rights and in particular the right to dignity and thereby our humanity.  It is our duty to ban them on European soil and to encourage Member States to respect these texts.  It is equally important to prohibit competing in any way outside our borders.   There is therefore an urgent need to prevent the export, transit and re-export of goods that can be used for such penalties and to allow companies to make profits on such illicit trades. Similarly, any technical assistance that may contribute to the execution of such acts must be strictly prohibited.  Sanctions in this area should be harmonized and tightened. This proposed regulation goes in that direction. So I voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005, which aims to combat torture, is a single instrument contributing to the protection of human rights by controlling products and activities that are used, or may be used, abusively to impose the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation lays down a ban on trade in 'single-use' products intended for torture and executions and their technical assistance (Annex II) and a system for authorising fair products that can be misused to inflict torture and carry out executions by lethal injection (Annex III). The Commission proposes to strengthen controls on torture instruments. In a context where external trade operations are increasingly complex, the role of effective implementation of controls, checks, sanctions, guidelines and awareness-raising actions carried out by national authorities is crucial. We voted for it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The "Anti-Torture Regulation" (EC) imposes export controls on certain military goods and, for the purpose of torture, certain goods. The report proposes that certain medicinal products that can be used for lethal injections to carry out the death penalty be included in this list. This project must be supported, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. I voted against the draft because I believe that this draft has been formulated too vaguely. The headline alone is so vaguely worded that virtually any trade in medicines or goods can be criminalised, because virtually any object can be used to torture people or otherwise mistreat or humiliate them. The fact that torture continues to be severely punished should be self-evident, but punishing individuals for simple trade in undefined objects that could also be bought by third parties for torture purposes is without any legal basis or legal norm!

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it represents a significant update of the rules which will stop export, transit, marketing and promotion of goods that can be used for torture or inhumane treatment. This is a key step in the promotion of peace and human rights and the prevention of violence, and part of the central role that the EU plays on the international scene. This report also allies with the work of the PGA (Parliamentarians for Global Action) of whom I am a member.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation because it is in defence of human rights. Regrettably, in some places in the world, torture and the death penalty are still executed. The least that we can do is prevent that they use our products for such goals and practices. Doing so is consistent with European values and with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Coherence in the controls of EU exports plays an important role herein. This legislation will enhance such coherence and strengthens the existing legislation. It also recognises the rapid pace of technological developments, the role these play in this matter and the challenge this poses to us. At the same time we need to ensure that controls are proportionate and that they are not creating unnecessary administrative burdens.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation on the issue of a special permit for objects which, whether intended directly or by their nature, can be used for the execution of the death penalty or for torture highlights the hypocrisy of the EU and its institutions. Instead of completely prohibiting their production, especially of articles intended solely for such purposes, or placing conditions prohibiting their use for such purposes, they supposedly put conditions on their marketing even though they know that they can move seamlessly through various channels. The text of the agreement with the Council, as it has come back, is even worse than the original one since it eliminates any stricter provisions for their movement. It also removes the general clause that existed for examining, where appropriate, the actual use, by destination, of any object that could be used for such purposes, while the dependence of the authorisation on the knowledge of traders or brokers of the purpose for which they are intended constitutes a genuine impregnate. You would not expect anything different from the EU pretending to be 'sensitive' to the death penalty and torture, while its imperialist wars are drowning peoples in blood and while its war industry is one of the most golden areas of action in the capital.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 Devices such as gallows, electric chairs and lethal injections have virtually no use other than for the purpose of the death penalty or inhuman treatment. I therefore see no reason why the EU, which openly opposes the death penalty and other unusual punishments, should support the sale of such devices. I appreciate that the proposal deals not only with the transit of those goods through the EU, but also with an urgent procedure concerning the prohibition of a new type of goods, if absolutely necessary. I therefore clearly support this proposal and believe that it will help to combat trade in these devices effectively.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The current regulation entered into force on 30 July 2006. It was intended to prevent the supply of goods to end-users who could use equipment or goods originating in the EU to torture or carry out the death penalty. As the 10-year practice has shown, unfortunately, such cases have happened. The fundamental mistake was that the current regulation, while restricting the sale of goods, did not block the transfer of technologies which were subsequently used by non-EU countries.  I believe that technical assistance providers from companies established in the European Union should not benefit from the marketing of technologies that could cause suffering or death to people. I therefore support the proposal for a new regulation that would ban the provision of technical assistance by any entity registered in EU countries if the equipment, goods or technologies it sold could be used for torture or capital punishment.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation on the trade in goods that can be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. This proposal amends and tightens the current arrangements, prohibits not only the export and import of products that can be used to carry out the death penalty, but also introduces a licensing system for goods that may have dual use. At the same time, the transport of such goods, their service or promotion are prohibited compared to the current arrangements. As an absolute advocate of abolishing the death penalty, I agree with this adjustment. In my opinion, it is very important not only to ban the export and import of these goods, but also, of course, all services related to such goods. After all, we cannot turn a blind eye to the fact that such goods would be transported through our territory or even repaired here. I believe that the tightened legislation will effectively help to eliminate the presence of such goods on the territory of the European Union, as well as to exclude that Member States could become transit countries, indirectly supporting the countries carrying out the death penalty.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Schaake report because I agree to the phasing-out of exports of goods that may be used to impose the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, in particular in countries which still apply the death penalty. The new rules will allow EU authorities to react more quickly to new forms of torture or cruel treatment by regulating their online sale, for example. I see that trade is not an end in itself, but a tool that should serve to improve people's lives and therefore I believe that the EU can and should use its trade influence to promote human rights.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods which could be used for the execution of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. I believe that it is important to control trade with third countries in goods that could be used for the execution of the death penalty or for torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Warnings by companies that controls should not hinder legitimate trade are also justified. It is therefore necessary, in the implementation of the Regulation, to maintain a balance between the interest of undertakings towards unsusmable legal trade and the control of the possible use of certain products for the death penalty, torture or other cruel treatment or punishment.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The following strategic agreement concerns the exchange of information in the following areas: specialist knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, as well as the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. From 2017, the new Europol Regulation will enter into force within the European Union, providing for a new procedure in which the role of the European Parliament is strengthened. The procedure requires Parliament to give an opinion and not simply give its approval, as is the case at the moment. For the reasons described above and in line with my positions on international agreements with third countries, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP MEP’s have voted against this legislative report. UKIP does not support the right for the EU to make agreements with third countries.
