UKIP also does not recognise the mandate of Europol and therefore have also voted against this report on the basis that it increases its legitimacy and influence.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. My position is clearly opposed to such strategic cooperation agreements on judicial and legal issues where there is a great lack of transparency that prevents us from knowing how the data of the citizens of the Union and of the migrant and stateless persons residing here are used. Moreover, this rejection increases for countries with little guarantee of compliance with the most basic judicial rights, such as China. It is striking that this agreement was concluded shortly before the adoption of Europol's new regulation which ensures much greater transparency and openness, particularly in cooperation agreements with third countries, so I understand that there is a willingness of the agency to continue operating opaquely. That is why I voted against the agreement.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – On the Europol China agreement on strategic cooperation, I voted against. We consistently vote against these files given the bloated remit and unaccountable nature of Europol and the human rights standards of the third country in question. Strategic intelligence cooperation with a country with as poor a human rights standard as China should be opposed. I voted against the report.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I have given my consent to the strategic agreement between Europol and the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China which involves the exchange of information, but no personal data.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving Europol's conclusion of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and the European Police Office (Europol), because this will strengthen the fight against organised crime and improve cooperation in the field of enforcement of international law.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. In order to be more effective in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, Europol has initiated, in accordance with the 2009/934/JAI decision, the procedure for concluding an agreement on strategic cooperation with the Ministry of Public Security of China. Strategic agreements involve the exchange of information to the exclusion of personal data, while operational agreements involve the exchange of information, including personal data.  The terms of cooperation governed by the strategic agreement provide for exchanges of information that may include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, participation in training activities, and the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations.  With this proposal, the Council is expected to adopt an implementation decision authorizing Europol to approve the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol.  I opposed this agreement because of the risks of industrial espionage.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I am concerned about the power of Europol, and believe that the UK should make our own decisions on security and policing matters, and therefore on principle would vote against this proposed Agreement. I am also unconvinced that certain human rights issues in China are sufficiently addressed with regard to this co-operation, and would like to see any such co-ordinated ventures properly debated in Westminster.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I have decided to abstain because the relationship between China and Europol cannot be thought of without considering the trade relations between the European Union and China and the granting of market economy status to China.  To the extent that these are not currently satisfactory, it does not seem to me to be coherent to discuss other cooperation measures.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ Because of previous adopted articles, any attempt at an agreement for an exchange of information between Europol and any third states or international organisations has to pass through the approval of the European Parliament. In this report, an agreement between Europol and the People’s Republic of China is being discussed. China has been increasing in its capabilities and sources regarding information about organised crime. China itself is home to several high-profile criminal groups. All these were the reason proposed for this report, yet the report brings us very close to the blurred lines of exchange of individual privacy and personal data. The report would be giving both sides close access to this kind of data.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal approving the agreement between the European Police Office (Europol) for strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol.  Europol has a clear operational need to cooperate with China. According to Europol, China as a source, destination and transit country is becoming increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, such as aid for irregular migration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime, euro counterfeiting, intellectual property rights violations, corruption in the sport sector, cybercrime and money laundering-related crime. I therefore support the conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with China, as it will make a significant contribution to the fight against organised crime and will contribute to increasing cooperation in international law enforcement.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 This report concerns the approval of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between China and Europol. Such a strategic agreement precludes the exchange of personal data and, consequently, the issue of data protection does not play a role in this case. The information exchanged may include the field of expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analysis and information on criminal investigation procedures and crime prevention methods, as well as training activities and the provision of advice and support for specific criminal investigations. The Strategic Cooperation Agreement between China and Europol would help and strengthen the fight against organised crime and contribute to strengthening international law enforcement cooperation. On this basis, I supported the adoption of the report.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP does not support the right for the EU to make agreements with third countries. UKIP also does not recognise the mandate of Europol and therefore has also voted against this report on the basis that it increases its legitimacy and influence.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Strategic agreements involve the exchange of information to the exclusion of personal data, while operational agreements involve the exchange of all information, including personal data.  I therefore objected to this agreement, which provides for the Council to adopt an enforcement decision authorising EUROPOL to approve the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and EUROPOL.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In order to be more effective in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, EUROPOL has initiated the process of concluding a strategic cooperation agreement with China's Ministry of Public Security.  This agreement involves the exchange of information (excluding personal data), and covers expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on methods of crime prevention, participation in training activities, as well as the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations. The aim of this agreement is to support and strengthen the action of the competent authorities of the Member States and their mutual cooperation in the prevention of organised crime, terrorism and other serious forms of crime. I voted in favor of it.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The People's Republic of China now plays an increasingly important role as a country of origin, transit and destination in the fight against organised crime. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the Moraes report approving the strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. It will make it possible to exchange information on specialist knowledge, reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures and training activities.  Given the presence in Asia of several high-impact organised criminal groups, cooperation on issues such as illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime, cybercrime and money laundering will prove particularly beneficial, strengthening the action of both sides in the field of justice and security. It should be stressed that the agreement does not provide for the exchange of personal data, thus guaranteeing the protection of the rights of European citizens.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting against this report which it establishes in accordance with Article 23(2) of decision 2009/371/JHA, by which the Council, in order to approve the conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third states and organisations, should consult the European Parliament. These agreements include the exchange of strategic and classified information, as well as the exchange of personal data. I vote against it, since I consider the establishment of such information-sharing agreements with a country where there are a significant number of duly documented cases of human rights violations. Our group's position on judicial cooperation with third countries is that it should only occur when sufficient guarantees of respect for human rights are given.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. It is good that Europe wants to collaborate - dare I say so - with China, through its Agency Interpol, against organised crime, which we know is becoming more and more global. It is good that this report specifies that China is increasingly becoming a country of origin, destination and transit for all kinds of trafficking and crimes.  However, let us not hide our faces, because even though China would become the world's leading economic power in the near future, the regime remains at present a dictatorship that censors the internet, imprisons opponents without trial and violates human rights all day long.  But politics is the art of the possible. I voted for this report because we have to choose the least evil and because the rapporteur makes it clear that the exchange of personal data is excluded from this agreement. But without blindly condoning the behavior of our Chinese "partners", as others too often do.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this report on an agreement on strategic cooperation between China and Europol.  Of course, the rapporteur states that the strategic agreement in question will exclude the exchange of personal data. However, the nature of the information exchanged remains sensitive: expertise, but also general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures, etc.  However, given China's special status, which is not yet recognized as a market economy but highly competitive, it may be unwise to share such information with this power.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the proposal for an agreement on strategic cooperation between the People's Republic of China and Europol. I believe that greater cooperation between europol and Europol will ensure more effective policies and counter-actions in the fight against crime, and I have therefore supported the report with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the draft Council Implementation Decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol. The information exchanged could include expertise, general status reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods and training activities, as well as the provision of support and advice in specific criminal investigations. However, the exchange of personal data is excluded from the strategic agreement. As Europol warns, China is gaining an increasingly relevant role as a country of origin, destination and transit in the fight against organised crime, in areas such as aid to illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, violations of intellectual property rights or corruption in sport , as well as other activities related to cybercrime and money laundering.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the proposal on the proposed support for strategic cooperation between Europol and China. This strategic agreement does not include the exchange of personal data, so the issue of data protection is irrelevant in this case. Information could be exchanged in the areas of expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures, methods of crime prevention, training activities, as well as advice and assistance in specific criminal investigations. Europol seems to have a clear operational need to cooperate with China. Europol argues that China as a source, destination and transit country is becoming increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, such as aid for irregular migration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime, euro counterfeiting, intellectual property rights violations, corruption in the sports sector, cybercrime and money laundering-related crimes. In addition, china has several organised criminal groups with a significant impact. Parliament supports the conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with China, as it will help to combat and strengthen the fight against organised crime, as well as contribute to increasing cooperation in the field of international law enforcement.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to successfully combat organised crime, the exchange of information with law enforcement agencies of third-country partners is of the utmost importance. As a country of origin, destination and transit, China is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, according to the European Police Office (Europol). This is why the agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and China is important, enabling the exchange of expertise, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, as well as the provision of advice and support for specific criminal investigations. Europol clearly needs to cooperate with China, so I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed decision on the Europol-China Agreement on Strategic Cooperation. Cooperation in the exchange of information on strategic analyses, criminal investigation procedures and methods for crime prevention, training and counselling and support in individual criminal investigations will undoubtedly help to limit or prevent organised crime between Europe and Asia. It should be pointed out that the agreement does not include the exchange of personal data. Europol's cooperation with China is important given the fact that China is increasingly important as a country of origin, destination and transit in the fight against organised crime, in particular trafficking in human beings, drug trafficking, counterfeiting and infringements of intellectual property rights, money laundering, etc.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this Report on the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and China, under which the EP consults on whether to give its consent to a strategic agreement between Europol and the People's Republic of China, which includes information sharing but not personal data.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between Europol and the Chinese Ministry of Public Security because I share the strategic goal of increasing our effectiveness in preventing serious forms of crime. Only the cooperation between global actors in security matters can improve the prevention efforts we carry out.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU and its Member States share responsibility for maintaining the security, justice, freedom and protection of the fundamental rights of EU citizens.  Pushing for the creation of common institutions to harmonise activities by implementing genuine cooperation between supervisory authorities at national and Union level, and on the other hand increasing cooperation with police forces in third countries, is essential to improve strategic and operational cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and their trading partners. , with a view to strengthening the efficiency of the fight against terrorism, mafias, smuggling and international crime, so as to increase both the security of EU citizens and that of partner countries.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Europol has entered into an agreement with the Chinese Ministry of Public Security on strategic cooperation to increase effectiveness in the fight against organised crime.  These strategic agreements provide for the exchange of information on expertise, general reports, the results of strategic analyses, criminal investigation procedures, methods of crime prevention or the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations.  Although these strategic agreements effectively exclude the exchange of personal information, I have opposed this text in order to protect Member States from the potential risk of industrial espionage by China.  The fight against crime must not come at the expense of safeguarding our jobs and industries. So I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal concerns the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and China, a strategic agreement comprising specialised knowledge, reports on the general situation, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on methods of crime prevention, training activities and the provision of advice and support in certain criminal investigations. China is increasingly relevant as a country of origin, destination and transit in the fight against organised crime, such as organised forms of illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime, counterfeiting of the euro, infringements of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport, as well as activities related to cybercrime and money laundering.  I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with China would support and intensify the fight against organised crime and would contribute to strengthening international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 Information has always been a powerful and valuable resource, and information that helps prevent crime, combat organised crime or any other type of crime that may go unnoticed due to a lack of communication between two entities states is particularly valuable. Therefore, the conclusion of international agreements on the cooperation of the Union with third states or international organisations, of course, after consulting the European Parliament, which expresses the clear need for Europol to cooperate in this case with China, helps to combat organised crime and can contribute to strengthening international cooperation in the field of law enforcement. I support the report on the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between China and Europol, because it not only is starting an operational mechanism with China, an increasingly representative state in origin, destination and transit in the fight against organised crime, but excludes the exchange of personal data from the head of the place.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China because it is clear that Europol needs to work with China.  China is playing an increasingly important role as a country of origin, transit and destination in the fight against organised crime, the aiding of illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, infringements of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport, cybercrime and money laundering activities. It also appears that there are several organised criminal groups in China. I am therefore in favour of concluding this strategic cooperation agreement with China, because I believe that it can be a valuable aid and support to the fight against organised crime and help to strengthen international cooperation on legality.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which would see the EU exchanging operational, strategic, technical and classified information with China. Cooperation agreements on information exchange with certain third countries have the potential to lead to the deterioration of human rights, and should be treated with extreme caution. For these reasons I voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with China, since it would aid and reinforce the fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement co-operation. The agreement involves the exchange of operational, strategic and technical information and does not contain provisions on personal data.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The cooperation agreement between Europol and China concerns the exchange of information, but personal data are excluded. The information may cover specialist knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, as well as the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. However, it cannot be said that this is non-sensitive data and, furthermore, the new procedure in which Parliament plays an enhanced role in concluding agreements with third countries is not yet being used. I therefore preferred to abstain.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Organised crime and terrorism do not stop their activities at the borders of the European Union in order to combat its activity. In view of their transactional nature, coordinated action and exchanges of information are also needed with non-Community countries. Europol has the important task of making Europe safer, including through strategic cooperation agreements with third countries, such as China. The People's Republic of China, in fact, plays an increasingly important role as a country of origin, transit and destination in the fight against international crime. I voted in favour because good international cooperation is a prerequisite for effectively combating organised crime.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report as there appears to be a clear operational need for Europol to cooperate with China.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and the European Police Office (Europol). It is obvious that the reclassifications that we are facing because of the migration issue and the economic crisis lead to the need for stronger controls. At the same time, however, there is concern about the practices we want to implement and the rights of the citizens we are called upon to defend. I believe that this report fails to cover all the issues to a sufficient extent and that is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal concerning the idea of approving a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. This strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data and therefore the issue of data protection is not relevant in this case. The information exchanged could include specialist knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training activities. There seems to be a clear operational need for Europol to cooperate with China. According to Europol, China plays an important role as a country of origin, transit and destination in the fight against organised crime, such as financing illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, infringements of intellectual property rights, cybercrime and money laundering-related activities. There are several important organised criminal groups in China. The rapporteur is in favour of concluding this strategic cooperation agreement with China, as it would be an aid and support to the fight against organised crime and would help to strengthen international cooperation in the field of law enforcement.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive opinion for this resolution on Europol's strategic agreements with China. It should be recalled that Europol is the European Police Office and that its aim is to improve cooperation between the police forces of the Member States in order to combat terrorism, illicit drug trafficking and other serious forms of international organised crime. These are therefore strategic agreements relating only to the exchange of operational, strategic and technical information and not operational cooperation agreements. This agreement therefore excludes the exchange of personal data with China.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the name of combating international crime, I can only express my full support for the strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the People's Republic of China. This agreement encompasses the exchange of operational, strategic and technical information and, while excluding the exchange of personal data, provides for synchronicity regarding the specific knowledge required, the results of strategic analyses, investigative procedures and prevention methods, as well as training and support in specific cases. Given that today's scenario sees China as the source, destination and place of transit of illegal immigration, human trafficking, counterfeiting and corruption, the strategic harmony just approved will allow a more modern and conscious fight against organised crime, as well as much closer international cooperation. As emerged from a 2011 CNEL report, Chinese organised crime has long been present on our territory and mainly deals with human trafficking, prostitution, gambling, extortion and above all counterfeiting of our brands and textile products. I therefore trust that these phenomena will be gradually abated by the cohesion of as many States as possible and that they will have access to strategic agreements of the same magnitude.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People’s Republic of China and Europol and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Within its mandate, Europol may conclude agreements with third countries and other organisations in order to establish ways of cooperation, in particular in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. In this context, it is up to Parliament - given the agreement reached - to consent to its signature by Europol. This is given its assent, demonstrated compliance with all legal requirements and guaranteed all safeguards for European citizens. This agreement with China is of particular importance, as it is public and notorious that it is a country of origin, transit and destination of organized crime groups with global impact.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because China is becoming increasingly important in the fight against organised crime as a country of origin, destination and transit. The information exchanged through the Agreement may include information on criminal investigation procedures and methods of preventing criminal offences, participation in training and the provision of advice and assistance in individual criminal investigations. And in this way we will achieve better cooperation in the fight against organised crime.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as europol's strategic cooperation with China can lead to the conclusion of important operational cooperation agreements with the police in order to prevent and combat organised crime while also reducing the transit of terrorist groups through the exchange of strategic and technical information. It is important to develop a shared strategy to combat those criminal phenomena that are still particularly present in China, such as the aiding of illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime, counterfeiting of the euro, infringements of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport, cybercrime and money laundering activities.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. Such a strategic agreement, as clearly stated in this report, excludes the exchange of personal data.  There is scope for having criminal investigation procedures, information on crime-prevention methods, training activities, and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations.  This will help us reinforce the fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. My position is clearly opposed to such strategic cooperation agreements on judicial and legal issues where there is a great lack of transparency that prevents us from knowing how the data of the citizens of the Union and of the migrant and stateless persons residing here are used. Moreover, this rejection increases for countries with little guarantee of compliance with the most basic judicial rights, such as China. It is striking that this agreement was concluded shortly before the adoption of Europol's new regulation which ensures much greater transparency and openness, particularly in cooperation agreements with third countries, so I understand that there is a willingness of the agency to continue operating opaquely. That is why I voted against the agreement.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 China plays an increasingly important role as a country of origin, transit and destination in the fight against organised crime. I therefore welcomed its inclusion on the list of countries with which Europol can enter into negotiations with a view to concluding a draft cooperation agreement. I believe that this is a first and important step towards more structured support in the fight against organised crime. Strategic cooperation, through the exchange of information, can only give impetus to strengthened initiatives in the field of law enforcement, thereby contributing to a significant strengthening of cooperation in the fight against cross-border organised crime.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The latest reports show a significant improvement in the fight against crime and organised crime in China, where several very dangerous criminal groups operate. In this respect, cooperation between Europol and the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China is a necessity. This Agreement refers to the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. Such a strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data. I voted for this cooperation in the fight against organised crime, a global phenomenon that directly affects each of us.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament approved today the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between China and Europol. Since Europol needs cooperation with China, I voted in favour of the agreement. China has a growing role to play in the fight against organised crime. Not only are there several influential organised crime groups linked to China, but there is a long "tradition" of organised illegal activities such as illegal immigration supported by facilitators, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime, euro counterfeiting, infringement of intellectual property rights, sports corruption, cybercrime and money laundering activities. I am pleased that the agreement contributes to the effectiveness of the fight against organised crime and also contributes to strengthening international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and China, which concerns the exchange of information excluding personal data. It should be noted that China is now a country of origin, destination and transit in the fight against organised crime. The agreement covers important issues such as the sharing of expertise or the results of strategic analyses and the advice and support of specific investigations. I voted in favour because I support any action to increase security.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ According to Europol, China is increasingly relevant as a source-, destination- and transit-country in the fight against organised crime. I believe that the conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with China would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement co-operation.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 China can now play an important role in the international fight against organised crime as a country of origin, transit and destination of proceeds from crime such as trafficking in human beings, drug trafficking, infringements of intellectual property rights, cybercrime and money laundering-related activities. The strategic cooperation agreement with China is a key element in the fight against these phenomena. I therefore voted in favour of the agreement.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes the approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion by the Council of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and China.  China is home to several organized crime groups and is considered an important transit country for organized crime.  Considering that this technical and strategic cooperation between the Union and the People's Republic of China will strengthen the fight against organised crime networks, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report for the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol.  We need a framework for cooperation between Europol, which has a mandate to make Europe safer and to help a country's law enforcement agencies, and China, through which many criminal organisations operating in Europe operate.  The conclusion of such agreements is important in order to strengthen our cooperation, particularly in the fight against terrorism. However, it was imperative that this agreement guarantee the protection of the personal data of European citizens.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to successfully combat organised crime, the exchange of information with law enforcement agencies of third-country partners is of the utmost importance. As a country of origin, destination and transit, China is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, according to the European Police Office (Europol). This is why the agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and China is important, enabling the exchange of expertise, general situation reports, strategic analytical results and information on criminal investigation procedures and crime prevention methods, as well as the provision of advice and support for specific criminal investigations. Europol clearly needs to cooperate with China, so as a member of the FIDESZ People's Party delegation, I am voting in favour of this initiative.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 Chinese organised crime in the EU is a growing problem for member countries' security in areas such as trafficking in human beings, drugs and money laundering. I voted in favour of this report in order to improve cooperation between Europol and China in the fight against organised crime and to strengthen international cooperation on law enforcement. Better control will also lead to greater transparency in political and economic relations.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported Mr Moraes's report on the China-Europol Strategic Cooperation Agreement, as these types of agreements with third countries are essential to help fight organised crime. Increasingly, China is either the source or transit country of a large number of international crimes such as trafficking in human beings and drugs, currency counterfeiting and in particular the euro, but also violations of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport, cyber crime and money laundering. The agreement with China aims to improve the exchange of information such as specialized knowledge, situational reports, strategic analyses, etc., with the exception of the exchange of personal data. The agreement also provides for general training and cooperation and support in separate criminal investigations.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 China is a strategic partner of Russia and the EU's close operational cooperation with China is important in the fight against organised crime. The question of the protection of personal data does not concern the present case, since this agreement excludes the exchange of such data.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to successfully combat organised crime, the exchange of information with law enforcement agencies of third-country partners is of the utmost importance. As a country of origin, destination and transit, China is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, according to the European Police Office (Europol). This is why the agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and China is important, enabling the exchange of expertise, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, as well as the provision of advice and support for specific criminal investigations. Europol clearly needs to cooperate with China, so as a member of the FIDESZ People's Party delegation, I am voting in favour of this initiative.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Europol, China is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime as a country of origin, transit and destination, in areas such as aid for illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, violations of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport , as well as activities related to money laundering and cybercrime. This document concerns the proposal for the adoption of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. The information exchanged could include expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation processes, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, provision of advice and support in certain criminal investigations.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: with this proposal, the Council is expected to adopt an enforcement decision authorizing EUROPOL to approve the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and EUROPOL.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns the approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. The information exchanged may include specific knowledge, reports on the general situation, results of the strategic review, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training activities and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. Like other EU agencies, Europol is a structure designed to impose a path of progressive federalisation, in addition to particularly sensitive areas that touch at the heart of state sovereignty, because they interfere with rights, freedoms and guarantees. Since its creation, it has been given powers that attack the sovereignty of states, and their activity has been carried out without any democratic control. We believe that Europol should not overdo it with national police and their activities and we advocate cooperation between the internal and external security structures of the various countries. Our vote to reject this report is therefore inextsideable from our position of principle on Europol.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I welcome the conclusion of the agreement between Europol and China on the exchange of information, excluding personal data, on strategic cooperation. The vote is justified by China's growing role as a transit and destination country in the fight against organised crime and by meeting the requirements necessary for the conclusion of the agreement. This agreement includes, among other aspects, the exchange of information on criminal investigation procedures and methods of crime prevention.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, as the agreement is more about big business than citizens.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 This strategic agreement is about cooperation between Europol and China. This agreement will not provide for the exchange of personal data, as this strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data and therefore their protection is not legally relevant. Following a thorough information collection process, it is clear that there are technical and operational needs for the exchange of information between Europol and China. The conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with China will help and strengthen the fight against organised crime and will contribute to improving cooperation in the field of international law enforcement.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report because I support the need for the exchange of operational, strategic and technical information between different actors.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 China is a strategic partner of Russia and the EU's close operational cooperation with China is important in the fight against organised crime. The question of the protection of personal data does not concern the present case, since this agreement excludes the exchange of such data. That is why I am voting in favour of the Europol-China Agreement on strategic cooperation.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament is being consulted on whether to give our consent to the Strategic agreement between Europol and the Ministry of Public Security of the People’s Republic of China. Strategic agreements involve the exchange of information, but not personal data. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to successfully combat organised crime, the exchange of information with law enforcement agencies of third-country partners is of the utmost importance. As a country of origin, destination and transit, China is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, according to the European Police Office (Europol). This is why the agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and China is important, enabling the exchange of expertise, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, as well as the provision of advice and support for specific criminal investigations. Europol clearly needs to cooperate with China, so as a member of the FIDESZ People's Party delegation, I am voting in favour of this initiative.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to successfully combat organised crime, the exchange of information with law enforcement agencies of third-country partners is of the utmost importance. As a country of origin, destination and transit, China is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, according to the European Police Office (Europol). This is why the agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and China is important, enabling the exchange of expertise, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, as well as the provision of advice and support for specific criminal investigations. Europol clearly needs to cooperate with China, so as a member of the FIDESZ People's Party delegation, I am voting in favour of this initiative.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report after finding that the fundamental rights of citizens are respected. This strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, so the issue of data protection is not relevant in this case. The information exchanged could include expertise, general status reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods and training activities, as well as the provision of support and advice in specific criminal investigations. There are clear operational needs for Europol to cooperate with China. According to Europol, China is gaining an increasingly relevant role as a country of origin, destination and transit in the fight against organised crime, in areas such as aid for illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, violations of intellectual property rights or corruption in sport , as well as other activities related to cybercrime and money laundering. In addition, China is home to several heavily influenced organized crime groups.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the legislative resolution tabled by the European Parliament on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol, because I firmly believe that cooperation between Europol and China is, at this historic moment, , useful and also necessary. I believe that the transmission and exchange of information between the EU and China is essential, particularly in order to combat the aiding of illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings. I also think that cooperation between the different authorities should also extend to other areas, such as the violation of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport, cybercrime and money laundering, given the increasingly important role that China must play globally in the fight against organised crime. I am pleased with the conclusion of this agreement because it will certainly help to strengthen international cooperation on respect for human rights, the law and the rule of law. I therefore hope that collaborative projects and strategies can be launched immediately.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Close cooperation in the field of crime tracking is essential in times of global and criminal networks. We can also only fight the fight against global terrorism together.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this legislative report. UKIP does not support the right for the EU to make agreements with third countries. UKIP also does not recognise the mandate of Europol and therefore I voted against this report on the basis that it increases its legitimacy and influence.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting against this report which it establishes in accordance with Article 23(2) of decision 2009/371/JHA, by which the Council, in order to approve the conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third states and organisations, should consult the European Parliament. These agreements include the exchange of strategic and classified information, as well as the exchange of personal data. I vote against it, since I consider the establishment of such information-sharing agreements with a country where there are a significant number of duly documented cases of human rights violations. Our group's position on judicial cooperation with third countries is that it should only occur when sufficient guarantees of respect for human rights are given.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Strategic Operational Cooperation Agreement between Europol and China concerns the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. Importantly, however, it excludes the exchange of personal data. This cooperation will therefore include expertise, reports on the overall situation, the results of strategic analyses, information on investigative procedures and methods of crime prevention, training activities, as well as advice and support in specific investigations. China is an increasingly important point on the map of organised crime: facilitating illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related offences, counterfeiting of the euro, intellectual property infringements, corruption in sport and cybercrime and money laundering activities. In addition, China is home to organised crime groups with significant influence in Europe, which fully justifies Europol's cooperation with China. In my opinion, the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement with China is important for the fight against organised crime. It will improve its effectiveness and contribute to stepping up international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. This strategic cooperation agreement with China would aid and reinforce the fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to abstain. This proposal concerns the proposed approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. Such strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, so the issue of data protection is not relevant in this case. However it is especially relevant knowing that China is increasingly relevant as a source, destination and transit country in the fight against organised crime, such as cybercrime and money laundering related activities. I believe that the cooperation with China is indeed a necessary move; however, I see a lot of improvement that still needs to be made in order to have efficient cooperation.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained with my Group in the vote on the report on a proposal for a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the People’s Republic of China which provides for the exchange of information, excluding personal data, such as general situation reports, information on criminal investigation procedures and crime-prevention methods, training activities and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. While I have no issue with the agreement itself, the reason for my abstention is that this new agreement was proposed on the basis of the current 2009 Europol decision while a newly negotiated decision between the Parliament and Council on the procedure for concluding international agreements has since been decided which significantly strengthens safeguards for the classification of EU documents and the protection of personal data of European citizens. It would therefore be more appropriate for this proposed agreement to be adopted after the new Europol Regulation has entered into force in May 2017, to ensure proper scrutiny of the agreement and the implementation of the rigorous new provisions and safeguards

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ This Strategic Agreement was approved by the Europol Management Board in April 2016, and covers the exchange of information such as general situation reports, information on criminal investigation procedures and results of strategic analysis. It excludes personal data. Given the growing importance of China in the fight against organised crime and the increased security such an agreement would provide, I have voted favourably. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to successfully combat organised crime, the exchange of information with law enforcement agencies of third-country partners is of the utmost importance. As a country of origin, destination and transit, China is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, according to the European Police Office (Europol). This is why the agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and China is important, enabling the exchange of expertise, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, as well as the provision of advice and support for specific criminal investigations. Europol clearly needs to cooperate with China, so as a member of the FIDESZ People's Party delegation, I am voting in favour of this initiative.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I am pleased that the European Parliament has authorised the conclusion of a technical, strategic and operational cooperation agreement between China and Europol. This cooperation is all the more important because China can be of great support in the fight against organized crime networks and human trafficking. In my view, this cooperation is desirable and acceptable insofar as the exchange of personal data is excluded.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament is consulted on whether to give consent to the strategic agreement between Europol and the Ministry of Public Security of the People’s Republic of China. It is important to specify that the strategic agreements involve the exchange of information, but not personal data.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted abstained on the Council Draft Implementing Decision, which authorizes the European Police Office (Europol) to conclude a Strategic Cooperation Agreement between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol (08364/2016 - C8-0217/2016 -2016/0808(CNS)), following the position of the ALDE Group in the European Parliament.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Europol's desire to conclude an agreement on strategic cooperation with China involves sharing certain information with China, on the pretext of greater effectiveness in the fight against crime.  Although personal data is excluded from strategic agreements, the risk of espionage is, in my view, too great. So I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP does not support the right for the EU to make agreements with third countries. UKIP also does not recognise the mandate of Europol and therefore has also voted against this report on the basis that it increases its legitimacy and influence.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Claude Moraes' report, following a Council decision allowing Europol to partner with China for strategic security cooperation.  This collaboration does not include the exchange of personal data between the European Union and China and will be tasked with combating organised crime, counterfeiting and cybercrime more effectively.  I support this initiative, which is part of the desire to strengthen security on our territory by promoting international cooperation, a subject at the heart of European diplomacy.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on a strategic agreement between China and Europol because it guarantees a total commitment by both sides to prevent and combat organised crime, terrorism or other crimes with cooperation in the exchange of operational, strategic and technical information, without affecting personal data.  In these difficult times, we must maintain the maximum relations with third countries in the field of intelligence.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The conclusion of an international agreement with a third country or an international organisation must be accepted in advance by the Council of the EU and the European Parliament. The Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and China concerns the exchange of strategic, operational, technical or classified information. Its short circuit also involves the exchange of personal data. However, as the agreement under way is a strategic agreement, personal data will remain undisclosed and the information to be exchanged will relate to general situations, strategic analyses, crime prevention and investigation procedures.  Cooperation with China is particularly important as it is believed that this is where criminal organised groups responsible for the illegal organisation of migration, drug trafficking, arms and living goods, cybercrimes, corruption and money laundering are created. And the effective fight against organised crime is particularly important in an era of escalating terrorist attacks.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report is about improved strategic cooperation between Europol and the People's Republic of China. The exchange of personal data is completely excluded. As this highly sensitive issue does not occur in cooperation, I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. This strategic cooperation agreement with China would aid and reinforce the fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement co-operation.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a proposed strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. I would like to stress that such a strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data and the question of the protection of personal data is therefore irrelevant in this case. The information to be exchanged could include expertise, general situation reports, the results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training activities and the provision of advice and support for specific criminal investigations. I believe that there is a clear operational need to establish cooperation between Europol and China. According to Europol, China's importance as a country of origin, destination and transit country in the fight against organised crime, such as facilitating illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, infringements of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport and activities related to cybercrime and money laundering, is growing. Moreover, China is home to several major organized criminal groups. I therefore fully support the conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with China, as it would help in the fight against organised crime and would strengthen this fight and promote better international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to successfully combat organised crime, the exchange of information with law enforcement agencies of third-country partners is of the utmost importance. As a country of origin, destination and transit, China is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, according to the European Police Office (Europol). This is why the agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and China is important, enabling the exchange of expertise, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, as well as the provision of advice and support for specific criminal investigations. Europol clearly needs to cooperate with China, so as a member of the FIDESZ People's Party delegation, I am voting in favour of this initiative.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against since cooperation between two power enforcing agencies without having high human rights standards is not in conformity with the aims of our party and with our previous practice.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, China's dynamic development is not only reflected in the economy, but also plays an increasingly important role in international crime, and is even a major frontrunner in certain sectors of organised crime. These areas include illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime, euro counterfeiting, infringement of intellectual property law, sports corruption, cybercrime and money laundering activities. The proposal, which aims to develop strategic cooperation between Europol and China on the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information, should therefore be clearly supported.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol.  There are clear operational needs for Europol's cooperation with China. The information to be exchanged may include specialised knowledge, general situational reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigations, information on methods of crime prevention, training activities and advice, support for individual criminal investigations. I believe that China is increasingly important as a source country, destination country and transit country in the fight against organised crime, such as facilitated illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings related to drugs, crime, counterfeiting of euros, intellectual property rights violations, corruption in sport, as well as cyber crimes and money laundering activities. I support this Strategic Cooperation Agreement with China as it would support and strengthen the fight against organised crime and contribute to strengthening cooperation in the field of international law enforcement.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The EU and China are two of the biggest traders in the world. China is the EU’s second largest trading partner and the world’s second fastest growing economy. Nevertheless, according to Europol, China is increasingly relevant as both source and transit country for organised crime, such as human trafficking, drug related crimes, euro-counterfeiting, intellectual property rights infringements, sport corruption, money laundering and cybercrime. Looking from this perspective, the strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China is of great importance because it would aid and reinforce the international fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement co-operation. Last but not least, it will create a good environment for the development of relations between China and Europe.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The proposal before us concerns the strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. According to Europol, China plays a very important role as a country of origin, transit and destination in the fight against organised crime, as well as against the aiding of immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, money laundering, and the violation of intellectual property rights. In the light of these reasons, Parliament proposes the adoption of the draft decision by the Council, which authorises Europol to conclude the agreement with China. I believe that this agreement is a strong aid to the fight against organised crime and also helps to strengthen international cooperation in the field of law enforcement. I am therefore in favour of it.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it calls for a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China.  However, China is not a reliable partner in that it practices industrial espionage.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the agreement on strategic cooperation between China and Europol, even though the strategic agreements (unlike the operational agreements) concluded by Europol involve the exchange of information to the exclusion of personal data.  With a country like China, reciprocity problems are to be feared. Moreover, the case of China is particular and sensitive given the threat of industrial and other espionage.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The report discusses the conclusion of a strategic agreement between EUROPOL and China. Strategic agreements involve the exchange of information, apart from personal data, while operational agreements include these. Our group often abstains when it comes to strategic agreements, while we oppose operational agreements to avoid any disclosure of personal data.  In this case, the agreement is certainly strategic, but it concerns a country whose risks we may fear, such as industrial espionage, for example. Therefore, I objected to that agreement.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report for the adoption of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China because it will contribute to the fight against organised crime, strengthening it, as well as strengthening police cooperation at the international level.  The strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, but includes that the information exchanged could include expertise, general status reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods and training activities, as well as the provision of support and advice on specific criminal investigations.  According to Europol, China is gaining an increasingly relevant role as a country of origin, destination and transit in the fight against organised crime, in areas such as aid for illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, violations of intellectual property rights or corruption in sport , as well as other activities related to cybercrime and money laundering, also houses several heavily influenced organized crime groups.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. My position is clearly opposed to such strategic cooperation agreements on judicial and legal issues where there is a great lack of transparency that prevents us from knowing how the data of the citizens of the Union and of the migrant and stateless persons residing here are used. Moreover, this rejection increases for countries with little guarantee of compliance with the most basic judicial rights, such as China. It is striking that this agreement was concluded shortly before the adoption of Europol's new regulation which ensures much greater transparency and openness, particularly in cooperation agreements with third countries, so I understand that there is a willingness of the agency to continue operating opaquely. That is why I voted against the agreement.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This document refers to the adoption of a proposal for a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. This is an agreement that will contribute to the fight against organized crime, strengthening it, as well as strengthening police cooperation at the international level.  I am voting in favour of the proposal because of the importance and operational need for Europol and China to cooperate. China is becoming a major player in this area as a country of origin, destination and transit against organized crime, as well as playing an increasingly relevant role in issues such as aid to illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings or cybercrime.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this proposed agreement to empower Europol to improve law enforcement and combat terrorism.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the strengthening of Europol's police powers and the conclusion of a cooperation agreement with the Chinese police is a strengthening of Europol's powers.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The Council is responsible for approving international cooperation agreements, which may include the exchange of strategic, operational and confidential information. This proposal concerns the approval of such an Agreement between the Ministry of Public Security of China and Europol, which includes the exchange of personal data as a strategic agreement. It also includes the exchange of specific knowledge, the adoption of reports and information on new methods and research processes and cooperation in investigations. There are clear needs and benefits from establishing Europol's cooperation with China, as China is an increasingly important player in the international fight against organised crime, illegal migration, human trafficking and cybercrime.  I supported this report and the conclusion of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement with China, as it will enable the fight against organised crime and contribute to improving international cooperation on this issue.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal provided that the Council adopts an implementing decision by which Europol is authorised to approve the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People’s Republic of China and Europol. The aim is to increase effectiveness in preventing and combating serious forms of crime with cooperation. Such agreements have the objective of supporting and strengthening action by the competent authorities of the Member States and their mutual cooperation in preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more Member States, and may concern the exchange of operational, strategic or technical information, including personal data and classified information. I support broadening the cooperation between EU and China in the field of security.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 This agreement concluded between Europol and China will help to strengthen the fight against international crime organised from that country. These include, in particular, illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings and drugs, cybercrime, counterfeiting of the euro, money laundering. The provision and exchange of information shall not concern the exchange of personal data. They're excluded from the deal. At the same time, the cooperation agreement will help to strengthen the enforcement and respect for international law.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. China, with its 1.3 billion inhabitants, has several criminal organizations, which it fights through the development of the fight against organised crime: measures against aid to illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, money laundering, counterfeiting of the euro, or corruption in sport.  Europol, the European Intergovernmental Criminal Police Agency, needs to work with China.  This strategic agreement will allow, among other things, the exchange of expert opinions, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on methods of crime prevention, as well as training or counselling activities in the context of specific investigations. Moreover, the agreement categorically excludes the exchange of personal data.  This agreement with China will facilitate and intensify the fight against organized crime and contribute to strengthening international police cooperation, while ensuring the protection of personal data. I therefore vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol, I chose abstention because the report is not complete.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This text is an agreement on strategic cooperation. Unlike operational agreements, it therefore does not provide for the exchange of personal data. It provides for exchanges of information such as expertise, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on methods of crime prevention, etc.  While we support cooperation with China to increase efficiency in preventing serious forms of crime, we oppose this strategic cooperation that does not guarantee the protection of our data and processes.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive for the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the PRC and Europol. Such cooperation will benefit both sides not only in their fight against organised crime but also by contributing to enhancing international law enforcement cooperation. On the other hand, the international cooperation agreements with third countries, in this case China, will bring a handful of benefits that will result in limiting the harm and side of effects of problems such as illegal immigration, human trafficking, drug related crimes, cybercrime and money laundering activities.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the draft executive decision of the Council on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol, which, however, excludes the exchange of personal data and does not concern the present case. The exchange of information may include specialised knowledge, reports on the general situation, information on the investigation of crimes. Finally, such a strategic cooperation agreement with China will help and strengthen the fight against organised crime while contributing to cooperation in the enforcement of international law.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This is about enhanced cooperation and the exchange of information between Europol and China. Strengthening cooperation to combat organised crime should be supported, but I am critical of central europeanisation of policing with Europol as an institutional centre. That is why I abstained.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP resolution on the Council Implementing Decision approving the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol. Europol has a clear operational need to cooperate with China. Europol argues that China is becoming increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, such as aid for irregular migration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime, counterfeiting of the euro, etc.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report focuses on the approval of a cooperation agreement between Europol and the People's Republic of China.  It should be noted that this European Police Office arbitrarily collects personal data in Europe and may refuse to share it with the citizens concerned who request it.  However, it is important to ensure that the countries with which the European Union concludes these police cooperation agreements offer all the guarantees of respect for freedoms. But following the scandals of giant spying on European governments and institutions by the NSA and the German authorities, we are no longer in a position to provide these guarantees on the European side.  I also note that for China, the agreement legitimately excludes the exchange of personal data when with North Americans, this had not been a problem, even after the NSA scandal.  Finally, one can question this eagerness to conclude cooperation agreements between Europol and third countries, even though a new Europol regulation is being discussed, and it introduces new, more transparent procedures for this type of agreement.  I am voting against this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. In accordance with the 2009/934/JAI decision, EUROPOL initiated the process of concluding an agreement on strategic cooperation with the Ministry of Public Security of China in the area of prevention and combating serious forms of crime.  This agreement with China presents, in our view, a significant risk of industrial espionage. From then on, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This document concerns the proposal for the adoption of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. Such a strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data and is why, in the present case, the issue of data protection is not relevant. The information exchanged may include expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation processes, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, advice and support in certain criminal investigations. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of furthering cooperation between Europol and their counterparts in China, as cooperation and the exchange of information is essential for citizens’ well-being. It is important to note that this agreement excludes the exchange of personal information, therefore addressing concerns about privacy and data protection.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Parliament was consulted on the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between China and Europol. This new international agreement reinforces Europol's cooperation with third countries, which is an essential tool in Europol's work.
