However, I would like to stress that the conclusion of this agreement should have been made after the new Europol regulation, which is due in May 2017, came into force.  The new regulation provides for enhanced safeguards, including data protection. Moreover, after the new regulation comes into force, the European Parliament will have more prerogatives in concluding such international agreements.  Parliament's role in these matters must absolutely be defended. That is why it is important that the conclusion of any new agreement obeys the new rules that are coming into force in the near future.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Within the framework of its mandate, EUROPOL is empowered to conclude cooperation agreements with third parties with a regard to strengthening cooperation in the areas of law enforcement, the fight against organised crime, terrorism or other serious forms of crime. In the context of enhanced cooperation with China, information of an operational, strategic or technical nature would inevitably be exchanged in this context, but any personal data will be excluded from such exchange. I consider that enhanced cooperation with China is also becoming increasingly urgent in this sphere, as China is considered a country of origin, destination and transit destination for various forms of crime, such as illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings and drugs, cybercrime, infringements of intellectual property rights, money laundering, counterfeiting of currency, corruption, etc. It is therefore essential for us, as leaders in the enforcement of international law and international standards, to participate in the gradual elimination of such negative phenomena, also in order to ensure trade relations. The report has my support.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which concerns the proposed approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China since it would aid and reinforce the fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement co-operation. Such strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, so the issue of data protection is not relevant in this case.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Police Office (Europol) has a clear operational need to cooperate with China. According to Europol, as a country of origin, destination and transit, China is of increasing importance in the fight against organised crime. Moreover, China is home to several influential organised crime groups. The conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third countries or international organisations shall be approved by the Council after consultation of Parliament. The Council has now proposed to approve the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between China and Europol. The agreement excludes the exchange of personal data and, consequently, the issue of data protection does not play a role in this case. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament approve the Council's draft, as it would help and strengthen the fight against organised crime and contribute to strengthening international law enforcement cooperation. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Europol has initiated the process of concluding an agreement on strategic cooperation with the Ministry of Public Security of China. This proposal provides for the Council to adopt an enforcement decision authorise Europol to approve the agreement, which involves the exchange of information, excluding personal data. We are used to abstaining in this case, and voting against it when it comes to operational agreements. The case of China, however, is special, given the risk of industrial espionage. It is not possible to support this adoption.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Strategic Cooperation Agreement between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol is a strategic cooperation agreement on the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. In this case, it excludes the exchange of personal data, so the issue of data protection is not relevant. The information exchanged may include expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation processes, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, advice and support in certain criminal investigations. According to Europol, China is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, in situations such as aid for illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, violations of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport, as well as activities related to money laundering and cybercrime. I am in favour of concluding the agreement because I believe that it will be an important step in the fight against organised crime and will contribute to greater international cooperation aimed at law enforcement.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This vote on the agreement on strategic cooperation between China and Europol aims to be more effective in preventing and combating serious forms of crime.  They contain the exchange of information to the exclusion of personal data, while operational agreements involve the exchange of information, including personal data.  However, noting that this is both a strategic but also operational agreement with China, a country where the risk of industrial espionage is not negligible, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the approval of the European Police Office's conclusion of the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the Republic of China and Europol.  This agreement, which excludes the exchange of personal data, will enable better combat of organised crime networks, in particular through the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure concerning the proposal to approve a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. The issue of data protection is not relevant in this case as this agreement excludes the exchange of personal data while they could include specialist knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods. China is playing an increasingly important role as a country of origin, transit and destination in the fight against organised crime, such as financing illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime or counterfeiting of the euro. It is therefore strategic and essential for Europol to cooperate with europol.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 We live in a time when Europe is facing a number of security challenges. Europol, the EU agency fighting international crime, has a particularly important role to play now. The most effective instrument of the European Police Office, cross-border data exchange and coordination, is strengthened by agreements with new partners. I am therefore excited about the expansion of this cooperation with China. In China, the EU can find a strategic partner who, with its technological development, will open up new horizons in the fight against international organised crime.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will improve cooperation between Europol and China in fighting against any illegal activities which may include organised crime and illegal immigration. One relevant mention is that any exchange of personal data within this Europol-China agreement is strictly forbidden by this report.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I note Mr Moraes's report, as the conclusion of this Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and China is extremely important for the EU. The exchange of information on specialised knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analyses and information on criminal investigations will contribute to the fight against illegal migration, trafficking in human beings, organised crime and infringements of intellectual property rights.  Bulgaria is one of the countries that are the final or intermediate destination of Chinese products violating the intellectual property rights of world-famous brands. In recent weeks alone, the Customs Agency has detained more than 15,000 watches on suspicion that the items are counterfeit and violate the rights of more than 25 trademarks. More than 1,000 children's toys and 58,000 pairs of work gloves have also been detained over suspicions they are fake. The origin of the goods established according to the invoices is namely the People's Republic of China.  I supported this Agreement because its conclusion will improve and strengthen the fight against organised crime and contribute to strengthening cooperation in the field of international law enforcement.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report approving cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People’s Republic of China and Europol because this agreement meets the objective of supporting and strengthening action of the EU Member States and third States pursuant to the list determined by Decision 2009/935/JHA. I strongly believe that the strategic agreements should involve the exchange of information, but excluding personal data, and can be concluded by Europol only after approval by the Council. This addresses the urgency and flexibility of the steps needed to be taken by Europol to prevent and combat serious forms of crime, and the oversight comes through approval required by the Council after consultation with the Management Board of Europol. The operational agreements involve the exchange of information including personal data, but I approve the necessity of such exchanges in the light of the stringent oversight that requires not only the Council’s approval, via the Management Board, but also the opinion of the Joint Supervisory Body of Europol as it concerns the exchange of personal data.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report because there are some good aspects in the report, but I am very sceptical about Europol. There is no general guarantee that personal data will be excluded from this data exchange.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. China and the EU make sense to keep their cooperation on a permanent level, with the proposal covering an agreement on strategic cooperation, including areas on illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings and more. Nevertheless, the european Parliament's monitoring function has been ignored in reaching an agreement, which must be respected and remembered when concluding subsequent such agreements.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. In particular, this agreement will help to combat and strengthen the fight against organised crime. In addition, it will be possible to accelerate the enhancement of cooperation in international law enforcement and to ensure appropriate strategic cooperation between Europol and China. It should be noted that the provisions of the agreement do not cover the exchange of personal data. They therefore do not regulate the issue of data protection. It should be noted that the new agreement will ensure the efficient exchange of information in the areas of expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures, methods of crime prevention, training activities. In addition, in order to increase mutual cooperation more effectively, it will be possible to provide advice and assistance in specific criminal investigations.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP does not support the right for the EU to make agreements with third countries. UKIP also does not recognise the mandate of Europol and therefore has also voted against this report on the basis that it increases its legitimacy and influence.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Because of the global dynamics, it is necessary to establish a cooperative relationship between the various information and security agencies. Considering that the proposal is aimed at a strategic agreement aimed at the exchange of information, general situations, methods of crime prevention, as well as the provision of advice and support in the context of specific criminal investigations. Given that the conclusion of this agreement would be an aid to the fight against organised crime through the sharing of knowledge with a state such as China, which is increasingly active in combating these types of organisations. Given that this type of cooperation does not provide for the exchange of sensitive and personal data which may to some extent harm those directly concerned, I feel I must express my positive opinion. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – As a member of the Delegation for relations with China in the European Parliament I supported this implementing decision. Its purpose is to authorise the conclusion of the mutual cooperation agreement between Europol and China. I believe that it will benefit both parties as it involves the exchange of operational, strategic and technical information.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. I support the conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with China, as it would help fight organised crime and contribute to strengthening international police cooperation. According to Europol, China is an increasingly important source, destination and transit country in the fight against organised crime, such as illegal immigration, human trafficking, drug crimes, counterfeiting of money, infringements of intellectual property rights, sports corruption, as well as cybercrime and money laundering. In addition, China is home to several highly influential organized crime groups. This proposal concerns the proposed approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. Such a strategic arrangement excludes the exchange of personal data, but relates to the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or confidential information. Information sharing may include expertise, general situational reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on methods of crime prevention, training activities and the provision of advice as well as support in individual criminal investigations.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. In order to be more effective in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, EUROPOL has initiated, in accordance with the 2009/934/JAI decision, the process of concluding an agreement on strategic cooperation with the Ministry of Public Security of China.  The terms of cooperation governed by the strategic agreement provide for exchanges of information that may include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, participation in training activities, and the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations.  It seems to me that the European Union is putting its Member States at great risk with such an agreement because it will pass on a lot of confidential data to China. So I'm voting against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ In the consultation process, Parliament was asked to accept the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and China. The Strategic Cooperation Agreement excludes the exchange of personal data. Under this agreement, information such as: general situation report, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, specialist knowledge, etc. will be exchanged. The operational need for cooperation between Europol and China exists as China is increasingly important as a source, destination and transit country in the fight against organised crime, including: illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug crime, counterfeiting of the euro, infringement of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport, as well as cybercrime and money laundering activities. I accept this Agreement, however, the question arises as to why the conclusion of such agreements is being hassleed before the new Europol Regulation, which gives more powers to Parliament, is coming into force.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns the approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the People's Republic of China. The information exchanged may include specific knowledge, reports on the general situation, results of the strategic review, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training activities and advice and support in individual criminal investigations. Like other AGENCIES of the European Union, Europol is a structure created to impose the implementation of the path of Federalisation. Since its inception, the EU has given it powers to attack the sovereignty of states, developing its activity without any democratic control. We believe that Europol should not overlap with national police and their activities, and we advocate cooperation between the internal and external security structures of the various countries. We voted against it.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the conclusion of strategic cooperation between Europol and China in the field of strategic information sharing. China's importance as a country that is increasingly becoming a transit country and a country of origin of organised crime is gradually growing. This crime includes, for example, trafficking in human beings, infringements of intellectual property rights, drug-related crime and, last but not least, counterfeiting of the euro. At the same time, China is home to several major organized criminal groups. In order to strengthen the fight and improve international law enforcement cooperation, the Europol-China Agreement should significantly assist in detecting and preventing crime, increasing expertise and improving investigative procedures for dealing with crimes on both sides. I consider the protection of the privacy of European citizens to be an absolutely essential aspect of the agreement, as the agreement excludes the exchange of personal data.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to ensure greater support for the fight against organised crime, the Council approved the conclusion of the strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the Minister for Public Security of the People's Republic of China. Specifically, the agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, so the issue of data protection is not relevant in this case. The information exchanged could include specialist knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, as well as the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. The rapporteur is in favour of concluding this strategic cooperation agreement with China. I believe that it would help to strengthen international cooperation in the field of law enforcement and, therefore, I voted in favour of its approval.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 China is an increasingly important country of origin, destination and transit in the fight against organised crime, such as facilitating illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, intellectual property infringements, corruption in sport and cybercrime and money laundering activities. In addition, various organised crime groups with significant influence are based in China. The Agreement between China and Europol includes expertise, reports on the general situation, the results of strategic analyses, information on investigative procedures and methods of crime prevention, participation in training, advising and assisting in specific investigations. This agreement will help to combat crime and increase security. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to approve the conclusion by the European Police Office - Europol - of a strategic cooperation agreement with China.  This necessary cooperation will be strengthened in particular in the context of the fight against organised crime networks, which have no borders.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This report endorses the Council's draft authorising Europol to conclude a strategic cooperation agreement with China. According to Europol, China is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime as the country of origin, transit and destination of various organised crime networks. I would like to point out that this cooperation agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, and in turn there is an exchange of expertise (benchmarking), training activities, information on criminal investigation processes, methods of crime prevention, among other matters that are highly relevant in the fight against organised crime. Because this cooperation is promoting the progress of the rule of law in the field of relations between Europol and China, while safeguarding the privacy of European citizens, I vote in favour of this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP does not support the right for the EU to make agreements with third countries. UKIP also does not recognise the mandate of Europol and therefore has also voted against this report on the basis that it increases its legitimacy and influence.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 This document concerns the proposal for the adoption of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. Such a strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, so in this case the issue of data protection is not relevant. The information exchanged could include expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, etc. It is permissible to think that there are clear operational needs for Europol to cooperate with China. According to Europol, China is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime as a country of origin, transit and destination, in areas such as aid for illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, violations of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport , as well as activities related to money laundering and cybercrime. The rapporteur is in favour of concluding this Strategic Cooperation Agreement with China, as it supports and intensifies the fight against organised crime and will contribute to greater international cooperation in the interests of law enforcement. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. THIS afternoon, MEPs approved a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China, by 460 votes in support, 126 against and 90 abstentions. Like the one that exists with Russia or was signed with Brazil in April 2016, this agreement will allow both sides to exchange certain information - excluding personal data - and to help each other in the fight against organized crime. China is Europe's second largest trading partner and plays a growing political role in the world. But the Chinese authorities also face great challenges.  In particular, according to Europol, China's weight as a country of origin, transit, or destination of organised crime is steadily increasing.  In the sights of the European Union and China: illegal immigration, human trafficking, drug crime, counterfeit currency, intellectual property violations, and cybercrime. The conclusion of this agreement is a sign of the seriousness of China's commitment to strengthen the fight against organised crime, and is part of Europol's strategy to develop strategic partnerships to ensure the safety of European citizens.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. According to Europol, China is increasingly a relevant partner in the fight against organised crime. This agreement relates to the exchange of classified operational, strategic and technical information (expertise, strategic analysis, information on criminal procedures, methods of crime prevention, etc.). It does not include the exchange of personal information.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the draft Council Implementation Decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol. The information exchanged could include expertise, general status reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods and training activities, as well as the provision of support and advice in specific criminal investigations. However, it excludes the exchange of personal data from the strategic agreement. As Europol warns, China is gaining an increasingly relevant role as a country of origin, destination and transit in the fight against organised crime, in areas such as aid to illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, violations of intellectual property rights or corruption in sport , as well as other activities related to cybercrime and money laundering.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and China.  Such cooperation with China seems necessary since the country's weight as a country of origin, transit or destination in the fight against organised crime is proven.  This report will strengthen international cooperation with China on repressive matters.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report. It aims to ensure the exchange of data and closer cooperation between Europol and China. At first glance, this may seem to be a welcome initiative. Data sharing could prevent large-scale international crime. However, the situation is not so simple. The Chinese authorities are constantly violating human rights by persecuting political opponents or people who do not believe in the mode – lawyers, journalists, activists. Therefore, the exchange of strategic research, working methods and other information can contribute to an even greater increase in the persecution of these persons and the use of new methods.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. There are currently unquestionable operational needs for closer cooperation between Europol and the Chinese authorities. China is a key country in the fight against organised crime as a country of origin, transit and destination in areas such as aid for illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, violations of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport, as well as activities related to money laundering and cybercrime. This report therefore concerns the proposal for a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China, and the information exchanged will include expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation processes and crime prevention methods, training activities or advice and support in certain criminal investigations, which requires this analysis , discussion and voting in the European Parliament. I voted in favour of the conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with China, as it aims to step up the fight against organised crime, thereby contributing to greater international cooperation.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the draft enforcement decision of the Council, which approves the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol. The text also calls on the Commission to carry out an assessment of the provisions of the cooperation agreement and to inform Parliament and the Council of the conclusions of this assessment.   It is important that the European Union continues to strengthen its international security cooperation.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting against this report which it establishes in accordance with Article 23(2) of decision 2009/371/JHA, by which the Council, in order to approve the conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third states and organisations, should consult the European Parliament. These agreements include the exchange of strategic and classified information, as well as the exchange of personal data. I vote against it, since I consider the establishment of such information-sharing agreements with a country where there are a significant number of duly documented cases of human rights violations. Our group's position on judicial cooperation with third countries is that it should only occur when sufficient guarantees of respect for human rights are given.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and the European Police Office (Europol). Europol is the European Union's law enforcement agency and helps national law enforcement authorities to combat serious international crime and terrorism. The aim of the agreement is to prevent organised crime, terrorism and other serious criminal offences, which is to be done through the exchange of strategic and technical information.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. My position is clearly opposed to such strategic cooperation agreements on judicial and legal issues where there is a great lack of transparency that prevents us from knowing how the data of the citizens of the Union and of the migrant and stateless persons residing here are used. Moreover, this rejection increases for countries with little guarantee of compliance with the most basic judicial rights, such as China. It is striking that this agreement was concluded shortly before the adoption of Europol's new regulation which ensures much greater transparency and openness, particularly in cooperation agreements with third countries, so I understand that there is a willingness of the agency to continue operating opaquely. That is why I voted against the agreement.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, the European Parliament approved the conclusion of the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and the European Police Office (Europol). Recent studies have shown that Over the past decade, Chinese organised crime has become part of the crime environment in a number of EU countries. Criminal activities include extortion, trafficking in human beings, the production and trafficking of illegal drugs, counterfeiting of the euro, infringements of intellectual property rights, clandestine betting, counterfeiting of consumer goods, cybercrime and money laundering-related activities. There is therefore a clear operational need for Europol to cooperate with China. The key to the success of the fight against organised crime lies in the exchange of information and expertise concerning criminal groups at EU level and with the countries concerned, such as China. Europol can play a decisive role in supporting and strengthening the action of the competent authorities of the Member States and mutual cooperation. I therefore voted in favour of concluding this strategic cooperation agreement.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. My vote in favour of this strategic agreement between Europol and China is due to the need to step up the fight against organised crime. Exchanges of expertise, modes of prevention, training activities on both sides and support for criminal and criminal investigations themselves are important. Greater international cooperation in terms of transnational security is needed and this agreement is a positive step in this direction.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not recognise the EUs competency in this area.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted for the agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and China. This agreement is an important step towards reinforcing the fight against organised crime and enhancing international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 China is an important country in the fight against organised crime. It is the country of origin, destination and transit of organised crime. I support cooperation between Europol and third countries, in this case China. This agreement between Europol and China will help in the fight against crime and will make it possible to increase security within the EU. Since this agreement is a strategic agreement and not an operational one, it excludes the exchange of personal data. I therefore voted to adopt this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Motion for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by Europol of an agreement on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol. This strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data. The information to be exchanged could include expertise, general situation reports, results of crime, training activities and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. According to Europol, China is growing in importance as a country of origin, destination and transit in the fight against organised crime, such as organised illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug crime, counterfeiting of the euro, infringements of intellectual property rights, corruption in education, as well as cybercrime and money laundering activities.  This agreement will therefore help and strengthen the fight against organised crime and will contribute to improving cooperation in the field of the enforcement of international law.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Europol helps EU Member States fight organised crime. Since organised crime simply does not stop at the EU's borders, cooperation with other countries around the world and international organisations is of paramount importance. Although such cooperations are welcome, the agreements under scrutiny should take the practice of prosecuting crime in a partner country and the associated respect for human rights. Parliament's report proposing the conclusion of such an agreement with China provides for the exchange of operational and technical data, including personal and confidential data. According to Europol, China is becoming increasingly relevant to the prosecution of organised crime, as in many cases it is the source, target or transit country of various criminal activities. The problem of the proposed agreement lies in china's respect for human rights in the field of crime enforcement, while identifying criminals and terrorists differently. As many as 280 human rights activists and lawyers have recently been detained by China, around 40 of them still detained, according to an organised crime group. At the same time, laws are in the process of ing all online companies in China to have a Chinese cyber police officer in the company to oversee the "dissemination of rumors." In view of the aforementioned controversial Chinese methods of prosecuting organised crime, I decided to vote against the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Organised crime often crosses the borders of one country or continent at present. Expanding cooperation with other states, including the exchange of data on suspects or financial transactions, is a valuable contribution to the global fight against crime.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. \u2012 This strategic agreement between Europol and China aims at exchanging information, excluding personal data. Europol shall conclude such agreements with the consent of the Council. The European Parliament was also asked to give an opinion in the framework of the approval procedure. China is increasingly relevant as an actor in the fight against organised crime, including people smuggling and money laundering. This agreement allows us, among other things, to rely on specialised knowledge from Chinese authorities and to obtain strategic information. As this agreement combats organised crime and increases security within the Union, N-VA fully supported this report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I abstained from the European Parliament resolution on the draft Council implementing decision on the approval of the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol. I recognise that, for reasons of security, there is a clear operational need to cooperate with China. China is becoming increasingly important as a country of origin, destination and transit in the fight against organised crime, such as aiding illegal immigration and activities related to trafficking in human beings, drug crime and money laundering. In addition, some of the most dangerous organised criminal groups come from China. However, I am opposed to Europol in its present form. Europol is violating the interest in national autonomy and its competences are interfering too deeply with the concerns that Member States should have. I cannot therefore support the proposal.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. —The Council Decision, after consulting the European Parliament, authorizes the conclusion of an agreement on Europol's international cooperation with third countries, including the exchange of relevant information and the exchange of personal data. As the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and China excludes the exchange of personal data, the information to be used mutually relates to the exchange of knowledge, general condition, analysis, advice and support in crime prevention and in the process of criminal investigations.  Given that a number of the most influential organised crime groups originate in China, this approach contributes to the fight against organised crime as well as illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime and other organised crime activities. Therefore, I support the Report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the Draft Implementing Decision of the Council authorising the European Police Office (Europol) to conclude a Strategic Cooperation Agreement between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and the European Police Office (Europol) by Europol. The Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and China will bring about the exchange of information in the field of expertise, reports on the general situation, the results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures, but not the exchange of personal data. Therefore, any concerns regarding the protection of personal data and the processing of personal data are superfluous. I support the conclusion of the agreement, as China is important in the area of organised crime as a country of origin, destination and transit, as Interpol also endorses.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today the granting of consent to the Council decision approving the conclusion of an agreement between Europol and China, as it is one way of fulfilling europol's mandate, which is entitled to conclude cooperation agreements with third countries in order to prevent and combat organised crime, terrorism and other serious crimes. This is an agreement on the exchange of strategic and technical information, not the exchange of personal data, which could then be used against individuals advocating, for example, respect for human rights. I would also add that the conclusion of this treaty does not alter my negative opinion as regards the possibility of granting market economy status to China within the WTO.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 China is a strategic partner of Russia and the EU's close operational cooperation with China is important in the fight against organised crime. The issue of the protection of personal data does not concern the present case, as this agreement excludes any exchange of such data.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to successfully combat organised crime, the exchange of information with law enforcement agencies of third-country partners is of the utmost importance. As a country of origin, destination and transit, China is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, according to the European Police Office (Europol). This is why the agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and China is important, enabling the exchange of expertise, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, as well as the provision of advice and support for specific criminal investigations. Europol clearly needs to cooperate with China, so as a member of the FIDESZ People's Party delegation, I am voting in favour of this initiative.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's opinion agreeing with the Council's approval of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and the People's Republic of China. I have taken into account that Europol has already concluded an agreement with a third country (Brazil) with the same content. It is clear that, in terms of the fight against international organised crime, China's scale, the role of a priority source and transit country, in particular in the areas of international illegal trade and smuggling, trafficking in drugs and counterfeit goods, money laundering and cybercrime, are indispensable partners in the effective defence of European security interests. To this end, the Agreement will help to make better use of the different possibilities of the exchange of methods, information and experience. However, I consider it an important condition that the agreement excludes the release of personal data to the other party, so that there should be no concern about the treaty from the point of view of the data protection of European citizens.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Cooperation between the European Union and the People's Republic of China has reached an impressive level in all areas in recent years. In addition to economic cooperation, another important sector of strategic cooperation is public order. This is an area of maximum interest, particularly in the context of the growing terrorist threat to contemporary society. In relation to China, an important component of cooperation is the fight against organised crime, in the form of illegal immigration, human and drug trafficking, counterfeiting of the euro, infringement of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport, cyber attacks and money laundering. The current cooperation agreement excludes the exchange of personal data and covers in particular the exchange of reports on the general situation, strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation and crime prevention procedures, training activities and certain criminal investigations. The adoption of this agreement complements the series of cooperation initiatives between Europol and other structures of the main international actors, with a view to making work to prevent and combat cross-border crime more effective. It is a necessary measure, which is why I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I followed the work of my colleague Moraes. The proposal under consideration is the approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. Since this type of strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, the issue of data protection does not arise in this case. The information exchanged may include expert opinions, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on methods of crime prevention, as well as training activities or advice and support in the context of specific criminal investigations. Europol seems to have a clear need for operational cooperation with China. According to Europol, China's weight as a country of origin, transit or destination is steadily increasing in the fight against organised crime, including aid to illegal immigration, human trafficking, drug-related crime, counterfeiting of the euro, intellectual property rights violations and corruption in sport, as well as other activities related to cybercrime and money laundering. In addition, China has several highly influential criminal organizations.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the People’s Republic of China provides for the exchange of information which has become increasingly relevant in the fight against organised crime. There seem to be clear operational needs for Europol to cooperate with China. According to Europol, China is increasingly relevant as a source, destination and transit country in the fight against organised crime, such as facilitated illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, euro-counterfeiting, intellectual property rights infringements, sport corruption, as well as cybercrime and money laundering related activities. Furthermore, China is home to several high-impact organised criminal groups. I voted in favour of the Europol-China agreement because I am certain that the only way of combatting international crime and enhancing international law enforcement is through increased cooperation and mutual assistance.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: in writing. – This is yet another one of those agreements signed between Europol and third states in order to strengthen their mutual cooperation in preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious transnational crimes. Such strategic agreements involve the exchange of information, excluding personal data. The information exchanged could include specialist knowledge, general situation reports, results of strategic analysis, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. This time the third state in question is China. We are all aware of the systematic violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms committed by the Chinese Government, some of which are measures that directly fall under the justice and home affairs area. At the same time, China’s definition of whom constitutes a criminal or a terrorist it is often markedly different from what the EU’s is. Therefore, I have voted against authorising any kind of police cooperation with China, as doing so would be tantamount to becoming an accomplice of the Chinese Government in the curtailment and violation of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to conclude a Strategic Cooperation Agreement between the European Police Office (Europol) and China, as I believe it will strengthen the fight against organised crime and enhance international law enforcement cooperation. I believe that China is an increasingly important country in the fight against organised crime as the source state of many influential criminal groups linked to human trafficking, drug-related crime, euro counterfeiting, money laundering, corruption in sport and cybercrime.  I would point out that cooperation will be achieved through the exchange of information covering expertise, the results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and methods of crime prevention, and will not involve the exchange of personal data. It can be concluded from this that the conclusion and implementation of this strategic agreement will be of utmost benefit to both the Member States of the European Union and China in the fight against organised crime.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and the European Police Office (Europol) by Europol. Europol's cooperation with China seems necessary from an operational point of view. Europol states that China is increasingly important as a country of origin, destination and transit in the fight against organised crime, such as facilitating illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, counterfeiting of the euro, infringements of intellectual property rights, corruption in sport, as well as activities related to cybercrime and money laundering. In addition, China is a haven for several highly influential organised crime groups.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ The strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China will contribute to crime prevention and investigation, especially transnational and organised crime, drug trafficking and trafficking in human beings, and money laundering. It does not include the exchange of personal data. This type of strategic cooperation is in the best interests of Europe and European citizens. Such cooperation cannot be halted or suspended for purely political or ideological reasons.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting against this report which it establishes in accordance with Article 23(2) of decision 2009/371/JHA, by which the Council, in order to approve the conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third states and organisations, should consult the European Parliament. These agreements include the exchange of strategic and classified information, as well as the exchange of personal data. I vote against it, since I consider the establishment of such information-sharing agreements with a country where there are a significant number of duly documented cases of human rights violations. Our group's position on judicial cooperation with third countries is that it should only occur when sufficient guarantees of respect for human rights are given.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. In order to be more effective in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, EUROPOL has initiated, in accordance with the 2009/934/JAI decision, the process of concluding an agreement on strategic cooperation with the Ministry of Public Security of China.  Strategic agreements involve the exchange of information to the exclusion of personal data, while operational agreements involve the exchange of information, including personal data.  The terms of cooperation governed by the strategic agreement provide for exchanges of information that may include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, participation in training activities, and the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations.  I usually abstain when it comes to strategic agreements, and vote against it when it comes to operational agreements (since this is the possibility of exchanging personal data).  The case of China, however, is particular given the risk of industrial espionage. So I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 China plays a critical role in the fight against organised crime. In recent years, they have become a country of origin, destination or transit relevant to the objectives of criminal organisations. Their action also threatens the security of Europe m.in. by facilitating illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related offences, counterfeiting of the euro and cybercrime and money laundering activities. The Strategic Agreement between Europol and China involves the exchange of expertise, strategic analyses, information on investigative procedures and methods of crime prevention. It also opens up the possibility of training, mutual advice and support in specific investigations. Importantly, the agreement will not cover personal data. It will undoubtedly help to combat crime and increase the security of Union citizens. For these reasons, I support the conclusion of a strategic agreement between Europol and China.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The strategic agreement between Europol and the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China provides for the exchange of information but excludes the sharing of personal information. I voted in favour of the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between China and Europol, as this would help to combat organised crime and contribute to strengthening international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting against this report which it establishes in accordance with Article 23(2) of decision 2009/371/JHA, by which the Council, in order to approve the conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third states and organisations, should consult the European Parliament. These agreements include the exchange of strategic and classified information, as well as the exchange of personal data. I vote against it, since I consider the establishment of such information-sharing agreements with a country where there are a significant number of duly documented cases of human rights violations. Our group's position on judicial cooperation with third countries is that it should only occur when sufficient guarantees of respect for human rights are given.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted against the proposal of the Council because concluding an Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between Europol and China that entails the exchange of information on crime prevention methods, training activities, and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations, among other things, would be tantamount to becoming an accomplice of the implementation by the Chinese Government of a series of laws and decisions in the field of justice and home affairs that severely curtail basic human rights and freedoms in the country.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – This proposal concerns the proposed acceptance of strategic cooperation between Europol and China. Such agreements may relate to the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. The operational cooperation agreement shall include the exchange of personal data.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People’s Republic of China and Europol. This agreement excludes the exchange of personal data. The information exchanged could include specialist knowledge, general situation reports, results of strategic analysis, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime-prevention methods, training activities, and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. Council Decision 2009/371/JHA provides the legal basis for the establishment of the European Police Office (Europol). The mandate gives this European agency the power to reach cooperation agreements with third countries in order to improve law enforcement cooperation with a view to preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other forms of criminality considered serious. The Council's proposal to authorise the Strategic Cooperation Agreement with China assessing this parliamentary report includes the exchange of operational, strategic and technical information. Under no circumstances does it provide for the transfer of personal data. Through the document, which I supported with my vote, the Eurochamber approves the draft Council implementation decision on the authorisation for Europol to conclude the agreement with China, a country hosting criminal groups whose actions have a major impact at the international level and is therefore an important source of information on organised crime.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. My position is clearly opposed to such strategic cooperation agreements on judicial and legal issues where there is a great lack of transparency that prevents us from knowing how the data of the citizens of the Union and of the migrant and stateless persons residing here are used. Moreover, this rejection increases for countries with little guarantee of compliance with the most basic judicial rights, such as China. It is striking that this agreement was concluded shortly before the adoption of Europol's new regulation which ensures much greater transparency and openness, particularly in cooperation agreements with third countries, so I understand that there is a willingness of the agency to continue operating opaquely. That is why I voted against the agreement.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report. When the new Europol Regulation enters into force, the EU may need to reassess strategic cooperation between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and Europol.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. When we hear the recurring debates on China in the European Parliament, it is surprising to say the least that we are subject to an agreement on police cooperation with china. This strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Chinese intelligence aims to prevent serious forms of crime.   While it explicitly excludes the exchange of personal data, and I welcome it, this agreement is similar to most cooperation agreements with Europol and is therefore characterized by a great vagueness about the type of information that will be exchanged. What kind of information about criminal investigation procedures is being talked about? What kinds of results of strategic analysis are being talked about?   How long has it been agreed to be how long it has been to keep the information?   What are the goals?  Once again, it's total blur.  And in the case of an agreement with a state where respect for human rights is at least a real issue, we are entitled to expect much more transparency.  I am voting against this text, which has been essentially adopted by MEPs from the EPP and conservative and socialist groups; Liberals abstained largely.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns the approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and China. The information exchanged may include specific knowledge, reports on the general situation, results of the strategic review, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. Like other AGENCIES in the European Union, Europol is a structure designed to impose the implementation of the path of federalisation. Since its inception, the EU has given this structure powers that attack the sovereignty of states, developing its activity without any democratic control. We believe that Europol should not overdo it with national police and their activities and we advocate cooperation between the internal and external security structures of the various countries. We voted against it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The proposal includes strategic cooperation and increased exchange of information between Europol and China to strengthen the fight against organised crime. The exchange of personal data is completely excluded in this agreement. The intention is to be supported, but I am critical of the central Europeanisation of policing with Europol as an institutional centre. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Europol-China Strategic Cooperation Agreement. This agreement between Europol and the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China provides for the exchange of information, but not personal data, as China has not yet adapted to the high standards proposed by the European Union on data protection.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ This strategic cooperation agreement with China would aid and reinforce the fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement co-operation. According to Europol, China is increasingly relevant as a source, destination and transit country in the fight against organised crime, such as facilitated illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, organ harvesting, drug-related crimes, euro-counterfeiting, intellectual property rights infringements, sport corruption, as well as cybercrime and money laundering related activities. Furthermore, China is home to several high-impact organised criminal groups. This is the kind of international cooperation that is needed in a globalised world in order to keep citizens safe. Europol is an important part of the EU’s infrastructure that helps keep British citizens safe and protected from crime. The UK government urgently needs to answer questions about what it wants the relationship with Europol to be going forwards.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The mandate of Europol (Decision 2009/371/2009) empowers the EU agency to conclude cooperation agreements with certain third countries to improve police cooperation with a view to preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other serious forms of crime. The proposal for a strategic cooperation agreement with China involves the exchange of operational, strategic and technical information; under no circumstances do provisions relating to personal data. The purpose of the Council's implementation decision is to authorise the conclusion of the cooperation agreement between Europol and China. All the dominant political groups supported this approach, and I am voting in favour of signing this agreement as I consider it essential to exchange information for the fight against organized crime.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the heart of the Strategic Agreement is the exchange of information relating to international crime in order to prevent and combat terrorism and other serious crimes. I consider cooperation between Europol and China to be a step in the right direction, as there are several major organised groups in China that can have an impact at global level. Among other things, China can also serve as a suitable transit country for other organized groups. For these reasons, I support this strategic cooperation agreement, as the measures it brings will contribute to the fight against international crime.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed approval of the China-Europol Strategic Cooperation Agreement. I believe that if the country with which Europol wishes to conclude a cooperation agreement meets all the requirements laid down and cooperation with Europol can be beneficial, there is no reason not to support these agreements. China's importance in this case is not inconsiderable, because cooperation with it will be beneficial in the fight against organised crime, in particular linked to illegal migration, trafficking in human beings or money laundering. There are many criminal organisations in the fight against which China is recording significant successes that can help the European Union to move forward in this area in terms of exchanging expertise or strategic analyses. An important fact is also that, as this is a strategic cooperation agreement, no personal data will be exchanged within it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China and the European Police Office (Europol) by Europol. According to Europol, China is a haven for several highly influential organised crime groups. I therefore believe that operational cooperation with China with a view to preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other serious crimes is essential for an effective security policy in Europe and the world.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - My fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. This report is also closely linked to the root causes of migration, as it is about relations between the European Union and Africa. I voted in the spirit of what an African university professor who felt responsible for his country and continent said to me at a conference when I asked what the European Union could do to end the misery in Africa. He said what he could do was to end the multifaceted, corrupt relationship between corrupt European political and economic leaders, Western, European, multinational and African, local, corrupt leaders, which involves the looting of Africa's natural resources, raw materials and other resources. Europe therefore has a grave responsibility in the misery in Africa that cannot be cured by the mass migration of African people.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported this report because it is clear that the Coton Agreement will expire in 2020, and we will need to talk about how we will establish or continue trade relations with Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. And this report describes the possibilities with which I agree in principle.  I think that in the future it is appropriate to consider certain economic partnership agreements so that the European market is not only open to the economies of our partners, but also to a kind of reciprocity, to the mutual opening of markets. Even in the knowledge of the need to support the economies of african states, the Caribbean and the Pacific. Especially in the context of today's great migration wave, it is necessary to support African states where poverty is so great that it forces its people to head to Europe or to richer parts of the world.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, we voted today to set the framework for a new agreement with the countries of Africa, the Pacific and the Caribbean by 2020. I certainly voted for this report and I will explain why, but At the same time I would like to show my disappointment that the agreement with the United States on trade that brought a flourishing trade to all of Europe and all small and medium-sized firms has been denounced by three Socialist ministers.  Returning to the Agreement with Africa, the Pacific and the Caribbean: it is very important to have a political dialogue with the countries of this region and it is very important to invest in their development, and here the private sector has a vital role because it has to make these investments and we need to achieve sustainable development there, a development that will go forward and not be for a year or two , especially in this context where we have a migration crisis, we are in the midst of a migration crisis and the main solution is to eradicate poverty and develop those countries, so that people have jobs, stay at home, develop the economy in those countries and also, obviously, make a condition of respect for human rights, respect for democracy, because only independent and free people can build healthy societies.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – As a member of the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly and also a member of the Committee on Development, I have been involved in development cooperation for more than 10 years. I supported the present report because I believe that it is our duty to help less developed countries. Moreover, the migration crisis has shown what will happen if we fail to provide effective aid where people suffer from hunger and deprivation. We must therefore take seriously our commitments, whether it is funding or providing know-how to improve the functioning of state institutions, education or health. We have received a number of reports within the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly. However, I lack reports to assess whether our recommendations had a sense of improvement in the situation in developing countries, while at the same time evaluating the effectiveness of the use made of the funds spent.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: Madam President, the agreements of so-called economic partnerships with the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific are reticent on the part of all governments, regardless of their political colour. The truth is that they are not partnership agreements. This is an incredible machine for producing immigration, since it immediately triggers a decline in the revenues of the States concerned and, therefore, of the health, social, educational and equipment action for these countries, and above all an invasion of our goods, which result in the killing of the local economy, of increasing unemployment and of pushing the people of the countryside towards the cities - those countryside where food farming is ruined by the products of agriculture of our countries. This mechanism increases the production of monocultures, which cause pollution damage and mutilation of all traditional modes of cultivation in these regions. Finally, it causes, of course, the exile of the people from the countryside to the city and from the city to the outside world. I believe that history will judge very harshly the blindness that we show, in a moment like this, by voting on agreements of this nature and by subjecting the governments of this area to absolutely unbearable pressure.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, 80% of the world’s least developed countries are ACP nations. Trade is not the only solution, but is an essential part of the solution, for trade creates jobs; trade generates wealth which allows those countries to import, trade lifts people out of poverty, trade motivates entrepreneurs and trade leads to development. What we should be doing is breaking down tariffs and breaking down other barriers to trade. That is why I believe that this report is spectacularly missing the point, because it mentions trade really very little – really only at the end of the report. And it mentions it in the context of politicising that very trade. I believe that this report is completely missing the point of what we need to be doing.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The beginning of relations between the EU and the ACP dates back to the post-colonial period, institutionalised through the first Lomé Convention. Today, the partnership between the EU and the ACP is governed by the Cotonou Agreement, which is based on three fundamental pillars: aid, trade and economic cooperation. Despite the positive results that have been achieved so far, there is still a lot of work to be done and among the elements on which the partnership must focus in the future are the growth of the ACP countries, the new geopolitical realities, globalisation and régionalisation.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the non-legislative report. The EU wants to expand its influence over the less economically developed countries of the African, the Caribbean and the Pacific states group (ACP) with the use of the EUR 30 billion of the European Development Fund (EDF), which is outside of the EU budget. The ACP institutions see low level attendance and produce few results. The EU finances 50% of the costs the ACP secretariat. UKIP does not support the growing EU influence and the waste of funds on a failing EU project.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report aims to establish what the relationship between the Union and the african, Caribbean and Pacific countries should look like after 2020. It should be noted that partnership agreements have always had numerous negative impacts on the economies of the ACP countries, so I think a new type of partnership, just and equal, respecting the sovereignty of countries and promoting the development of countries' productive capacities, protecting traditional agriculture and combating land grabbing , and overexploitation, as long as it also has legal mechanisms to combat labour exploitation, modern slavery, the illicit flow of capital and the financing of terrorism and armed conflict. I also think it is important to stress the importance of ending foreign interference in the internal affairs of the ACP countries, as well as the end of neocolonial policies and the dismantling of all foreign military bases. However, this report does not propose any of these changes which I consider fundamental to the future of EU-ACP relations following the end of the Cotonou agreement in 2020, so my vote went against this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020, because this cooperation is an important achievement, both at acp and EU level and at the level of their parliaments, in order to continuously improve the effectiveness of their cooperation.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The European Union wants to continue what it sees as the progress of the Cotonou agreements. These are based on three pillars (development, trade relations and political dialogue). Apart from the fact that the Union does not have to have diplomacy in any form, the Cotonou agreements were a disaster for Africa.  By substituting a progressive free trade system for the paternalistic system in which the countries of the North agreed to pay more tariffs to enable the accelerated development of this area, the Cotonou agreements participated with other factors such as the policy of international institutions to delay the creation of African industries protected by high tariffs, which was France's objective with the cooperation project.  Instead, Africa's huge cities, particularly due to a massive rural exodus, are real centres of consumption but mostly not production centres.  Finally, we can only be surprised at the lessons that the Union allows itself in this text to give on corruption. I therefore objected to this text.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which was the subject of an opinion of the Committee on Budgets.  The simultaneous expiration of the Cotonou Agreement and the Multi-Year Financial Framework provides an opportunity to decide on the budgeting of the European Development Fund.  This suggestion promotes the ACP-EU relationship.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a post-2020 acp-EU relationship between the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) and the EU. I therefore agree with the need to establish a mechanism for monitoring, reporting and reviewing the ACP-EU mutual monitoring, accountability and review mechanism for the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in the Member States, with the involvement of ACP and EU representatives not only from central governmental authorities, but also from parliaments, regional and local authorities, civil society and the scientific community, with annual conclusions and recommendations on national, regional and global review processes and follow-up.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Economic Partnership Agreement serves to ensure the smooth and gradual integration of ACS countries into the world economy, in particular through regional integration and the full exploitation of South-South trade. Specific activities should be carried out in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, through regional agreements tailored to specific regional needs and the common interests of the EU and the region in particular. In order to assess the agreement, it must be said that african countries account for the vast majority of ACCS countries, with a population of almost one billion, compared with only 39 million in the Caribbean and 11 million in the Pacific. Thus, relations with Africa play a crucial role in the agreement, not only because of the number of inhabitants, but also because it can be one of the starting points for immigration to Europe. It would be in Europe's fundamental interest to conclude agreements with African countries to help the population stay in place, for example by developing agriculture, industry and trade to local needs and by transfering the necessary know-how free of charge. On the other hand, as can be said from the passages cited in the report, the main objective is to turn African countries into the world economy, which in practice means acquiring their markets by multinational companies. I abstained when I voted on this report.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the non-legislative report. The EU wants to expand its influence over the less economically developed countries of the African, the Caribbean and the Pacific states group (ACP) with the use of the EUR 30 billion of the European Development Fund (EDF), which is outside of the EU budget. The ACP institutions see low-level attendance and produce few results. The EU finances 50% of the costs of the ACP secretariat. UKIP does not support the growing EU influence and the waste of funds on a failing EU project.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. By substituting a progressive free trade system for the "paternalistic" system, where the countries of the North agreed to pay more tariffs to enable the accelerated development of this area, the Cotonou agreements have contributed, along with other factors, such as the policy of international institutions, to delay the creation of African industries protected by high tariffs. Thus, African cities, which have become gigantic due to a massive rural exodus, are mere centres of consumption and not centres of production.
