We need to work on cooperation that is more beneficial to all parties.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report of initiative by the socialist Norbert NEUSER (S-D, DE) on the future of ACP-EU relations beyond 2020 because international solidarity seems to me to be more indispensable than ever.  The report highlighted the value of ACP-EU cooperation and stressed the need to improve it by establishing a new structure that would retain the ACP-EU acquis, such as commitment to human rights and gender equality, human development, good governance and democracy, and the goal of establishing the rule of law. My colleagues in the Committee on Development also felt that sustainable development, the fight against poverty and inequality, as well as human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law should be placed at the centre of the agreement.  They also called for the creation of an ACP-EU collegial mechanism for monitoring, justifying the action taken and revising the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals in Member States on a regular basis.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 80 % of the world's least developed countries are located in regions of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific; However, this was a negative factor which was at the basis of the birth of cooperation between the ACP countries and the European Union as set out in the Lomé Convention and then, since 2000, in the Cotonou Convention. The objective set by the latter agreement has been to reduce and eliminate poverty, pursuing the objectives of sustainable development and the progressive integration of these countries into the world economy. The expiry of the agreement in 2020 requires further reflection within the EU, which is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the Neuser report, which outlines some prospects for the future of relations between the two regions. We need to create a new structure that preserves the parts of the ACP-EU acquis with a universal character, such as the commitment to human rights, good governance and democracy, but at the same time allows the main activities to be carried out in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. Political dialogue, the Sustainable Development Goals and the 2030 Agenda must be at the heart of new agreements that also provide for the establishment of peer monitoring, reliability and review mechanisms that periodically monitor the implementation of the objectives envisaged.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution as we believe that it does not reflect the main current challenges of EU-ACP relations. We believe that the post-Cotonou process should provide a fair and balanced framework between equal partners in which to discuss, among other important issues, fair trade issues with all ACP countries, but bearing in mind that trade liberalization is not in itself positive for sustainable development. I reject that there is no call in the resolution to create any binding instrument to identify private sector responsibilities for human rights violations and impunity of transnational corporations. In addition, I stress the importance of respecting, as indicated in SDG 17.15, the sovereignty of the associated countries and that they have a democratic political space to regulate and make decisions for the dignity of their people, a principle not reflected in the resolution.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. Africa is in ruins. Africa is devoured by civil wars. The most fanatical Islamism continues its inexorable bloody path from North to South. Just yesterday, the UN Under-Secretary-General warned the world against the announced deaths of tens of thousands of children in Nigeria, terrorized by Boko Haram barbarians. In the Sahel, massacres and abductions by the Aqmi follow one another. Elsewhere, China is recolonizing a continent that Europe hastily left half a century ago. And we react with eternal repentance. All this is our fault, so we need to inject even more billions into the barrel of development aid from the Danaïdes. Despite all the studies showing that development aid of the past has served no purpose. What are the words of our Parliament? Empty words to convince us that the ACP-EU partnership plays an important role in achieving the Millennium Development Goals, when we see that this is not the case. Please, why didn't the rapporteur spare us this language of wood!

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which is a stark example of European blindness to the failure of its own policies. The report wishes to endorse the so-called progress made by the Cotonou Agreements, which have had many negative consequences for African countries. The main "progress" of these agreements was to impose a brutal free trade on the ACP countries, not allowing them to develop or protect their industries with tariffs, which could have allowed the accelerated development of this area, as France wanted with the cooperation project. This policy has led to a massive rural exodus, with africa's major cities becoming centres of consumption, but real wastelands of production. Consequence? 80% of the so-called "least developed" countries are part of the ACP zone. At the same time, the Union, which is trying to replace the Member States in their diplomacy, has evaded a genuine policy of co-development which, in addition to the economic development of these countries, would provide a future for young Africans who are now forced to uproot themselves by emigration.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 This text recognises that the ACP-EU Partnership Agreement has so far been ineffective in combating poverty in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, which account for 80% of the world's least developed areas. However, instead of rethinking the better use of the resources already available, the text insists favourably on the creation of new funds in favour of migration. I therefore believe that the resolution is unbalanced in favour of the usual good-natured rhetoric which does not lead to any concrete results for the ACP countries. For these reasons, I did not intend to support the text with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I've abstained. The report contains a lot of good proposals to maintain the core points of the ACP-EU acquis even after 2020, such as: commitment to human rights, gender equality, human development, the inclusion of civil society, good governance and democracy, the rule of law and the exchange of best practices within a common framework. It is also positive that there is a demand for a central role in a new agreement to be given the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs. However, the report also advocates a trade dimension within the framework of the EPA, which basically means greater trade liberalisation and unequal conditions for the ACP countries. Unfortunately, there is also a lack of wording on combating land grabbing and concrete strategies to prevent the economic exploitation of the most vulnerable groups. Nor is there any complete rejection of using the ACP-EU to stop refugees and migrants, or against militarism. With this justification, I have abstained from voting.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The current Partnership Agreement with the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) – Cotonou Agreement – was signed in 2000, effective until 2020, and proposes a framework for cooperation relations focused on three main axes: political dialogue; development cooperation and the fight against poverty; and trade cooperation and regional economic integration. The amount of financial support for the ACP countries for the period 2014-2020 amounts to EUR 30 506 million. The report, to which I voted in favour, proposes to review the partnership framework with the ACP countries to ensure their adaptation to new risks (terrorism, refugees, good governance, peace and security, climate change, SDP), to establish joint action in global for a and to achieve better results in the goal of eradicating poverty.  In addition, the report stresses the need to ensure control mechanisms with the full participation of civil society and national parliaments; maintain the conditionality of the Agreement on the basis of respect for human rights and the rule of law; strengthen legal procedures and make them operational for the fight against corruption, as well as support the parliamentary dimension of the new Agreement through the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament calls for the fight against poverty and inequality to be considered as the main objectives of African, Caribbean and Pacific cooperation (ACP) and EU cooperation and, finally, their complete elimination and the promotion of sustainable development.  Parliament stresses that the new agreement must, above all, be a political project based on the principle of responsibility, clearly abandoning the 'donor-beneficiary' approach. In addition, cooperation should take place in areas of common interest where common benefits can be expected, not only in terms of economic benefits, but also in the areas of peace and security, human rights and the rule of law, good governance and democracy, migration, the environment, climate change and other areas relating to the well-being of both the ACP and the EU population. The European Parliament therefore calls on the national parliaments and regional and local authorities of acp and EU countries to play a more active role in all phases of ACP-EU policies and activities, from future planning and programming to implementation, evaluation and monitoring, in particular with regard to the principle of subsidiarity. Calls also on all parties to the new agreement to grant local and regional governments greater autonomy and capacity to enable them to carry out their duties effectively and to make an important contribution to the development of the ACP countries.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The overall objectives of the Cotonou Agreement, which entres the relations between the European Union and the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACCS), clearly include "poverty reduction and ultimately eradication, in line with the objectives of sustainable development of the ACCS countries and their gradual integration into the world economy". The partnership builds on certain fundamental values and principles, including respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, democracy based on the rule of law and transparent and accountable governance. Unfortunately, progress on the objectives of poverty reduction and the integration of ACCS countries into the world economy has so far been insufficient. This is of particular importance today, because some ACS countries are is ising out large numbers of economic migrants, making it even more difficult to deal with the influx of refugees from war zones in Europe. The new agreement should be primarily a political project based on the principle of responsibility and should clearly put the donor-beneficiary mentality behind it. I believe that cooperation should be achieved in areas of common interest where mutual benefits can be expected, not only in economic terms, but also in the areas of peace, security, human rights and the rule of law, good governance and democracy, migration, the environment, climate change. Cooperation should contribute to the well-being of the population of both the ACCS and the EU member states. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I supported the resolution on strengthening relations between the Common African, Caribbean and Pacific States, on the one hand, and the EU, as it is an important partnership in which the EU's role is crucial. Europe must continue to provide diversified assistance to those countries, as as many as 80% of the world's least developed countries are located in these regions. Development aid, which will reduce migratory pressures from these countries, especially African ones, into the EU, is, in my view, crucial – both to create more favourable and safer living conditions in those countries and to a sustainable influx of economic migrants into Europe. The partners of the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States and the EU must channel all their energy towards combating poverty and inequality and eradicating them outright, and must also promote the strengthening of sustainable development. Cooperation must, in particular, be based on mutual benefits for partners, in particular with regard to peace and security, human rights and the rule of law, migration, the environment and climate change. I really hope that cooperation will bring results and, therefore, greater prosperity in countries that have been struggling with poverty, hunger and political instability for many years.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this Resolution on the Future of Relations between the ACP and the EU after 2020.  Cooperation between the ACP and the EU is a valuable and unique achievement that has strengthened ties between the ACP peoples and their parliaments over the past 40 years. I believe that a new structure should be adopted in which those parts of the acquis of ACP and EU countries will be retained, which by their very nature are universal (e.g. respect for human rights and gender equality). I also believe that the common framework and regional agreements should be legally binding.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report aims to extend the Cotonou agreements beyond 2020. However, these free trade agreements have been particularly harmful to the ACP area, preventing states from promoting the emergence of local industries, given the absence of protective tariffs. Direct cooperation between Member States and ACP countries is far more effective than this interference by the European Union Commission in the internal affairs of the ACP area, further spreading an ideology that is not adapted to the African reality. For all these reasons, I'm voting against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed the resolution on the future of ACP-EU relations beyond 2020 because a new structure of cooperation must be adopted and a new commitment to human rights and democracy needs to be approved. Moreover, I believe the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals have to be the focus of the new agreement and its implementation has to be monitored. Last but not least, I share the call on all the parties to the agreement to give to local and regional governments a greater autonomy in order to enable them to play a significant role in the development of ACP countries.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important to rebuild the relationship between the ACP and the EU on a new basis, creating a partnership that promotes strategic interests and shared values. It must pursue the Sustainable Development Goals and ensure respect for human rights. It is essential that the ACP countries participate fully in the review process, which should also take into account the growing importance of régionalisation. It would also be appropriate to carry out an in-depth analysis of past achievements and failures of the existing framework before taking decisions on the future of ACP-EU relations. Cooperation must be intensified, especially in areas of common interest, in order to address today's global challenges more effectively. This new partnership must be based on the principles of mutual growth and development between the EU and Africa; facilitating the industrialisation of the African continent and the development of agriculture and encouraging investment in innovation policies and sustainable development. The future partnership should also provide for more effective joint action on conflict prevention, as a stable security environment is an essential condition for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Through this report, the European Union wishes to maintain its relations with the ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean, Pacific) before 2020, when the Cotonou agreements expire.  As a reminder, these agreements were intended to contribute to the development of the ACP countries by promoting their integration into international trade, establishing a constructive dialogue with their national authorities and integrating economic and associative actors into the implementation of projects.  However, these agreements have proved dramatic in those countries that have been forced into a progressive free trade system that prevents them from protecting their nascent industries and agriculture through tariff barriers.  In this context, the European Union no longer has the slightest diplomatic legitimacy to establish relations with third countries, especially since it is an exclusive competence of the Member States.  That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 More than 80% of the Least Developed Countries (LDCs) come from ACP regions, which gives particular importance to the EU-ACP partnership (Partnership Agreement between members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States). Following the signing of the Cotonou Agreement, there have been changes in the political and economic landscape of the ACP Group and within the European Union, and the future of ACP-EU relations should be based on a new reflection on the potential and future obstacles for cooperation between the two entities.  The results for the objectives of eradicating poverty and integrating THE ACP countries into the world economy have not been convincing to date, given that half of the ACP Member States are still among the least developed countries (LDCs) and that the ACP Member States together account for less than 5% of world trade and around 2% of world GDP.  I voted in favour of this report, strongly arguing that the conclusion of a new agreement, at the heart of which the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals (ODS) are placed, as well as the creation of robust monitoring mechanisms are extremely necessary.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Cotonou Agreement is the framework for EU relations with African, Caribbean and Pacific states (ACP countries). It was adopted in 2000 for a period of 20 years and includes a political dimension, economic and trade cooperation and development cooperation. The main objectives of the Cotonou Agreement are the reduction and eradication of poverty and the progressive integration of THE CPA countries into the world economy, while respecting the Sustainable Development Goals.  Over the past two decades, the EU and the ACP Group have developed, their relations marked by major developments. In a rapidly changing and increasingly multipolar world, the future of ACP-EU relations depends on a new framework that is to apply universally to all countries, which has a radical impact and change in development prospects. All means of implementation and all actors involved will be mobilised. I voted in favour of this draft legislative resolution of the EP because I would like to stress the economic and political importance of Asia which will surely continue to grow, adding to this the emergence of other economic powers in Africa and Latin America.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The acquis of the Cotonou agreement is the result of a combination of factors. It brings together a large number of States Parties, through development cooperation, political cooperation and economic and trade cooperation, and has a common institutional framework and an important budget: the European Development Fund.  This partnership is based on a set of fundamental values and principles, including respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, democracy based on the rule of law and transparent and accountable management.  I have spoken in favour of this report because the relevance of the Cotonou agreement is no longer to be demonstrated. The report stresses several key objectives for 2030: to make the new agreement a political project based on the principle of ownership and to abandon the donor-recipient mentality; Strengthen political dialogue; Strengthen the autonomy of local and regional governments; Allow private sector financing in the development process under certain conditions; use economic partnership agreements as tools for regional development and integration.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because the Cotonou Agreement has been a good platform for cooperation between the EU and the ACP countries for years, just think of the large number of countries taking part in the agreement and the links established between their peoples and parliaments. However, it is noted that half of the ACP countries are still among the least developed countries in the world, and that overall these countries account for less than 5 % of world trade and about 2 % of global GDP. The mobilisation of national resources in the ACP countries and the funds of the diaspora can be an important source of development financing. The new cooperation agreement will have to provide for a stronger parliamentary dimension, through the much-desired Joint Parliamentary Assembly (APP). This will have the main objective of facilitating an open and democratic parliamentary dialogue. Further efforts will also have to be made in the field of development cooperation, the promotion of democracy and human rights. The new agreement must therefore reflect an ambitious political project and make good governance a cornerstone, leaving behind, as the report rightly points out, the deleterious donor-beneficiary mentality.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on a legal framework for cooperation between the EU and its 28 Member States, and 79 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, the Caribbean and Pacific. In financial terms, between 1975 and 2013 the ACP side has received more than EUR 78 billion of development aid through the European Development Fund (EDF). However, in practice this has not materialised in sustainable development, especially in the last decade by the enhancement of asymmetric trade relations built around the so-called Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs). This report was about what direction the relationship should take into the future. As very few progressive elements were included in the final text, I voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which seeks to contribute to the debate on the future of the EU-ACP partnership beyond 2020, when the Cotonou Agreement will expire. It defines the European Parliament’s priorities, which include maintaining the legally binding provisions of the Cotonou Agreement based on three pillars: political dialogue, cooperation and trade. It proposes, though, a number of changes in order to make the partnership even more effective and adapt to the political, structural and demographic changes of recent years.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Being convinced of the importance of relations between the ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean, Pacific) and the European Union, I voted in favour of this report on future relations between the EU and the 79 ACP countries, whose partnership is currently governed by the Cotonou Agreement, but which will expire in 2020.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States and the EU creates effective and beneficial political, economic, development and trade cooperation. I agree that there is a need to put in place a new structure, which would better reflect the importance of human rights, gender equality and the rule of law. I also welcome the call for stronger involvement in political dialogue and for an ACP-EU peer monitoring, so that the implementation policies with regard to the Sustainable Development Goals in Member States would be monitored.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Over the past forty years, the partnership between the European Union and the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries has been a valuable tool for strengthening development cooperation and trade. I believe that the new agreement should primarily be a political project based on sustainability and reducing disparities. Only sustainable and sustainable development can guarantee an effective fight against poverty, the primary objective of EU-ACP cooperation. We must put the donor-beneficiary mentality behind us in order to build a strong partnership with reliable monitoring mechanisms and a peer review system that periodically monitors the implementation of common objectives. Finally, it is important to involve civil society, in particular the local groups directly concerned, in the negotiations for the new agreement, and to give a voice to the most vulnerable groups such as minorities, young people and women, who are all too often not in a position to assert their demands. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report and stress that, if we consider that the European Union cannot be a closed club of countries dealing only with the development of the European Union itself, but that, on the contrary, the European Union has a responsibility but also a role to play beyond its limits, then we should also consider that the agreement reached between the Caribbean countries , the Pacific and Africa and the Member States of the European Union are the culmination of a modern European Union that responds to the calls of the whole of humanity and is everywhere where there is a problem. I believe that, if one studies this agreement, in the sixteen years of its existence, one will realise that, no matter how many problems there are, no matter how many difficulties and obstacles arise, it is a very useful agreement that really offers these countries and contributes both to sustainable development and to their development and integration into the world economy.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the future of relations between the African, Caribbean and Pacific States with the European Union could contain very important elements in the development of relations between all parties involved. However, exclusive targeting of economic data cannot be accepted without a parallel focus on issues of protection of citizens' rights, transparency and social welfare. I therefore voted against.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report, which examines a number of proposals with a view to renewing the ACP-EU Agreement (Partnership Agreement between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, on the other). The agreement to date has not brought any benefit to poverty reduction in acp areas. Among the proposals is also the establishment of a Joint Parliamentary Assembly (APP) which would become yet another pointless political instrument.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am aligned with the report on the future of relations between the countries of Africa, the Pacific and the Caribbean and the Union, since it strengthens the spirit of cooperation between our nations, giving new life to common sectors and interests.  In particular, I welcome the correspondence between the proposed new objectives and the needs encountered in the wake of demographic, structural and sounder institutional refinement. Indeed, while the report remains in line with the principles set out in the Cotonou Agreement with regard to the eradication of poverty, democratic principles, the affirmation of the rule of law and support for more sustainable development, it adds, however, many ideas on the principle of subsidiarity and respect for cooperation, including at regional level.  Among the aspects to be highlighted is the monitoring, reliability and review mechanism between countries aimed at regular monitoring of the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals. Similarly, the establishment of a Joint Parliamentary Assembly will build a new forum for the most open, democratic and fruitful dialogue and confrontation. This is accompanied by economic partnership agreements, milestones for integration and growth.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the future of ACP—EU relations beyond 2020 and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The current EU-ACP Partnership Agreement, signed on 23 June 2000, has since been the framework for the EU's relations with 78 countries in sub-Saharan Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. That agreement, revised in 2005 and 2010, as provided for in its provisions, was concluded for a period of 20 years and reached a term of validity on 29 February 2020.  It is a legally binding instrument that creates common institutions and defines a framework for dialogue with each of its members, with great political importance, economic and trade cooperation, as well as a dimension of cooperation for financing development (articulated with the European Development Fund).  I support the Neuser Report because I believe it is important that this multifaceted dimension in the ACP-EU partnership based on respect for the acquis of human rights, good governance and democracy (also included in economic partnership agreements) should be emphasised in relations after 2020, and that a new agreement includes the sustainable development objectives and the 2030 Agenda and from an institutional point of view a strong parliamentary dimension and the inclusion of regional substructures.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I welcome the call for the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals to be placed at the heart of a new agreement and for a strong monitoring mechanism to be established. With a legally binding common framework and legally binding regional agreements, we will make an effective contribution to achieving the objective of sustainable development.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as I believe it is useful to improve the effectiveness of ACP-EU cooperation and adapt it to the new challenges resulting from the political, structural and demographic changes of recent years. We also need to create a new structure that maintains the commitment to human rights, good governance and democracy, while the main activities should be carried out in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, that is to say, they must have as their framework general agreements that are then adapted to the specific regional needs and mutual interests that exist between the Union and its region.  It is also important that the private sector can be heard during the programming policy-making process so that it can play a key role in the development process and can then help finance it, provided that investments are made with respect for people, property, the environment and in line with the UN guiding principles on business and human rights. I also hope that, under the new partnership, more attention can be paid to local producers and farmers on a small scale, as well as creating a favourable environment for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MPMI).

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The report calls on the parties to strengthen their efforts to build capacity in the ACP countries and to harness and make good use of domestic resources by, in particular, strengthening tax systems, ensuring sound management of natural resources and fostering industrialisation and the processing of raw materials for local, regional and world markets. Equally important is the call for the EU and the ACP partners to step up cooperation on combating money laundering and tax evasion. In parallel we should also seek how to enhance visibility and increase transparency in the use of EU development funds. This would facilitate these countries’ integration into the world economy. Meanwhile, financial aid has to be intertwined with concrete cooperative projects directed at improving infrastructure and educational and social systems in the ACP countries.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report aims to establish what the relationship between the Union and the african, Caribbean and Pacific countries should look like after 2020. It should be noted that partnership agreements have always had numerous negative impacts on the economies of the ACP countries, so I think a new type of partnership, just and equal, respecting the sovereignty of countries and promoting the development of countries' productive capacities, protecting traditional agriculture and combating land grabbing , and overexploitation, as long as it also has legal mechanisms to combat labour exploitation, modern slavery, the illicit flow of capital and the financing of terrorism and armed conflict. I also think it is important to stress the importance of ending foreign interference in the internal affairs of the ACP countries, as well as the end of neocolonial policies and the dismantling of all foreign military bases. However, this report does not propose any of these changes which I consider fundamental to the future of EU-ACP relations following the end of the Cotonou agreement in 2020, so my vote went against this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 More than 80 % of the world's least developed countries are in ACP regions. The ACP-EU partnership remains an important scenario in the light of the Sustainable Development Goals, the main aim of the Cotonou Agreement – identified in poverty reduction and eradication – and the values on which the EU's external action is based, such as respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, democracy based on the rule of law and transparent and accountable governance.  I voted in favour of this report, because I believe that economic partnership agreements remain a fundamental instrument for promoting the integration of the ACP States into the global economy, making full use of the potential of regional integration and promoting peace and security at local and cross-border level.  The new cooperation agreement introduces interesting innovations, such as the Joint Parliamentary Assembly, which will be involved in all relevant discussions concerning the post-2020 ACP-EU partnership, thus ensuring the inclusive and multilateral participation of stakeholders.  The report also stresses the need for an instrument dedicated to security expenditure related to development cooperation, going beyond the approach to the European Development Fund (EDF) as the main source of funding for the African Peace Fund.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, on the one hand, and the European Community, is based on development, political, economic and trade cooperation. The overall objective of the Cotonou Agreement is to eradicate poverty. More than 80% of the least developed countries come from these regions. The private sector is the centre of sustainable development. Sustainable development could ensure an international security environment. I voted for further cooperation between the EU and the African, Caribbean and Pacific group of states to more effectively address the global challenges of the present, such as climate change, food security, migratory flows, terrorism, extremism or international crime.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The AKCS-EU cooperation is based on the so-called Cotonou Agreement, which expires in 2020. The time has come, then, to evaluate the results of the current convention and to outline the forthcoming convention, which will hopefully lead to a more effective partnership. The parliamentary resolution adopted today, which I also supported with my vote, provides proposals for the draft in preparation. The report recalls the need to maintain political relations in the future rather than a mere donor-beneficiary relationship between the ACS and the EU. It therefore stresses that the principles of EU development assistance should be applied on an equal basis to all developing countries and that developed ACCS countries should be phased out of the EU development assistance system. It calls for the fight against and eradication of poverty and inequality and the promotion of sustainable development to remain the main objective of this cooperation. Furthermore, it calls for the fundamental elements of the Cotonou Agreement on human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law to continue to form the basis of the new agreement and for good governance to be included as essential elements. The new convention should also reflect recent political, structural and demographic changes, pay more attention to the role of regions and encourage greater involvement of society and the private sector.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I have decided to abstain on the resolution on the future ACP-EU relationship after 2020. The European Union's relations with the ACP countries are very important, so the objectives of this agreement should be precisely defined. In my opinion, the resolution as it stands is too general, it refers to political dialogue, support for development and economic and trade cooperation. In my opinion, these are generalities that need to be fine-tuned, which is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The Partnership Agreement between the EU and the ACP Group is the largest existing North-South partnership which dates back to 1975. The successive Lomé Conventions (1975–2000) and the Cotonou Agreement (2000–2020) have provided the legal basis for this partnership. The Cotonou Partnership Agreement signed in 2000 will expire in 2020. I am in favour of this report as I believe that in a changing global context a new relationship agreement is needed to maintain and promote an effective and close cooperation between the EU and the ACP countries.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported this measure in which the European Parliament urges the Commission to review and strengthen relations between the EU and the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries.  This report, in fact, is Parliament's contribution to the follow-up to the Cotonou Agreement, launched in 2000 and expiring in 2020, by which the EU regulated political and trade relations – including in terms of financial aid – with the ACP countries. Extremely important international issues such as the fight against poverty, the fight against climate change, the management of migratory flows and the fight against terrorism need a common platform for the EU and the countries concerned to work together to solve problems whose solution can only be joint. The Cotonou Agreement has helped to strengthen relations with the ACP countries and to develop a framework for doing so. However, many things have changed since the agreement came into force, so its updating is a good opportunity to review and improve the modalities of political and economic cooperation with our ACP partners.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report follows the public consultation launched by the European Commission on the future of the partnership between the European Union and the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) after 2020.  While the Cotonou agreement has strengthened political ties between the two sides and developed close cooperation to combat poverty, the results remain insufficient.  In this European Parliament report, MEPs set out a list of priorities to be considered in the context of future EU-ACP cooperation. The report stresses the continuation of the Cotonou agreement by establishing a legally binding framework agreement based on three main principles: political dialogue, cooperation and trade.  Considering that the ACP States are important political and trade partners for the European Union and that it is necessary to draw the consequences of previous partnerships in order to improve future relations with the ACP States, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the future of ACP-EU relations beyond 2020. Tackling poverty in the world and in Africa is paramount.  The current framework has not allowed sufficient action to do so. By re-engineering our relations with ACP countries through regional agreements, we will be better able to provide targeted and concrete solutions for the human and economic development of these countries.  I also consider that the greater involvement of parliamentary actors, civil society and the private sector, envisaged in this report, is essential in our efforts for the progress and security of our partners.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The Cotonou Agreement, which governs relations between the European Union (EU) and the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP), expires at the end of 2020.  The situation, both in the European Union and in the ACP, has changed over the past 20 years due to internal developments but also external challenges such as climate change. It is therefore important, as 2020 approaches, that the EU-ACP framework focus on environmental protection, migration management and the fight against inequalities within and between countries.  This strategic cooperation must take into account the objectives of co-growth and co-development. To do this, we need to identify priority areas of action, such as Africa's energy independence, sustainable management of natural resources or diversification and strengthening of its economic fabric.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ Mr President, 80% of the world’s least developed countries are from the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group (ACP). It is only right and proper therefore that we in Europe work together as nation states to cooperate with these nations and support balanced development of their societies.  Too often in the past, the EU placed prerequisite social obligations on these countries that are unachievable and which sadly have led to lost potential in terms of how we can contribute to a better future and higher standard of living for people in those communities. The number one driver both socially and economically in these countries is to provide sustainable investment, creating local jobs and giving people, young and old, a true stake in society. This gives structure and organisation to societies and will nurture greater respect for democratic values.  With the Trust Fund for Africa, these institutions have sent a message to governments of these nations that mass migration to the EU brings financial reward for them. This is not sustainable. A new ACP-EU settlement should therefore focus on incentivising economic development in indigenous communities, sustainable land use and agricultural production and above all enhanced access to education for young people.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2020, the Cotonou Agreement, on which the Relationship between the European Union with 79 African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries is based, expires, the most comprehensive agreement the European Union has signed with these countries. It institutionalises relations and gives both commercial and economic character and political character within the EU-ACP General Assembly.  I supported the resolution on the Future of ACP-EU Relations after 2020, as it sets out what the future relationship between the two regions should be, namely to improve the effectiveness of cooperation and adapt to the challenges of the 21st century. The resolution also calls for the fight against fraud, corruption, the eradication of poverty and inequality and a shift towards the principle of ownership by developing countries of sustainable development initiatives and projects in order to eliminate the donor-recipient mentality.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the report because we consider it to be a disguised example of neo-colonial policy, with direct interventions in the internal affairs of third countries. The Union, promising economic rewards, exercises cultural imperialism by imposing its own values, which it has the vanity to regard as universal.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the future of ACS-EU relations. The report covers important topics such as the elimination of the donor-beneficiary relationship so far and the development of an equal, autonomy-based relationship. With this new approach, the EU can provide more effective and realistic assistance to the region's pressing problems such as poverty and social inequalities. The report supports the integration of the European Development Fund (EDF) into the budget, which would thus be able to provide more targeted and transparent funding for regional initiatives. I agree with the importance of developing dialogue and coherent policy coordination. Against this background, cooperation with countries in the region (African Union, UN) should be based on a more open networking in the coming period. I consider it important to support the private sector, as well as to promote the aforementioned autonomy. In my opinion, the development of the region must be supported by the above aspects, which is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. In March 2016, the Commission and the E SEAS published the results of the public consultation launched on 6 October 2015 on the future of the EU-ACP partnership beyond 2020, when the Cotonou Agreement expires. The objective was to take stock of the agreement and develop proposals to make the partnership more effective. This report aims to contribute to the debate by defining Parliament's priorities for future EU-ACP relations. It is emphasized that it maintains the Cotonou acquis, i.e. an agreement on a legally binding framework based on three pillars: political dialogue, cooperation and trade. It then examines a number of possible developments, such as more regionalization, the EDF budget, strengthening political dialogue and greater participation of civil society and the private sector. It also stresses that the fight against poverty is also called for to remain a primary objective of ACP-EU cooperation, although it is noted that a new agreement must first and foremost be a political project and clearly leave behind the donor-recipient mentality.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 More than 80 % of the world's least developed countries are in ACP regions and, as a whole, account for less than 5 % of world trade and approximately 2% of world GDP. Around €900 million is set aside for the African Peace Facility and around €1.4 billion from the EDF reserve will be used for the EU Trust Fund for Africa. ACP-EU cooperation is a valuable and unique achievement that has strengthened links between acp peoples and countries and EU Member States and their national parliaments over the past 40 years. However, in order to improve the effectiveness of cooperation and adapt to new challenges, it is necessary to adopt a new structure that maintains the parts of the ACP-EU acquis that are universalin nature, such as commitment to human rights and gender equality, human development, good governance and democracy, the objective of the rule of law and the exchange of best practices under a common framework.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: one can only be surprised at the lessons that the EU allows itself in this text to give on corruption (point 11).

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 As we have stated, an inflection is necessary in the relationship between the EU and the ACP countries, a relationship now framed by the Cotonou Agreement. This is not the vision behind this report, quite the contrary. When a deeper and more critical approach was required with regard to the relations of dependency and subordination to which acp countries have found themselves subject and the role of EU policies in establishing such relations, the report underlaws, as to the essential, the course taken in recent years. When criticism of the so-called ECONOMIC PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENTS (EPAs) imposed by the EU and the consequences of their implementation was required, the EPAs are not criticised or scrutinised, on the contrary, they are seen as the instrument that should frame relations between the EU and the ACP countries, because they are supposed to be promoting growth and development. When a new framework of cooperation was required, genuinely capable of promoting the sovereign development of acp countries, the report ignores this need, does not address such strong problems as the illegal exploitation and expropriation of natural resources by foreign interests in acp countries, ignores the will, opinion and participation of acp countries, giving greater relevance to the affirmation (explicit or implicit) of the EU's geostrategic interests. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this report as I believe it is important to outline the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020, the expiry date of the Cotonou Agreements. The report identifies the promotion of human rights and the rule of law as one of its cornerstones, as well as economic and commercial development between the areas concerned, encouraging the private sector to invest in this cooperation in accordance with UN principles.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Cooperation between the European Union and the ACP countries can bring both sides both economic and economic benefits in the future if the obstacles facing it are overcome. The effectiveness of cooperation needs to be improved and adapted to new challenges, and a new structure must be adopted that retains those parts of European Union law that are universal in nature, such as the commitment to respect for human rights, gender equality, human development, good governance and democracy, the objective of the rule of law and the exchange of best practices within a common framework, with the main work being carried out in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report, which I believe is insufficient and risks proposing yet another very political and ineffective instrument.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020 because I consider this to be a covert form of neo-colonial policy, with direct interventions in the internal affairs of third countries. The Union, promising economic rewards, exercises cultural imperialism by imposing its own values, which it has the vanity to regard as universal.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ It is time to renew the relations with the African, Caribbean and Pacific states. Not only because the current Cotonou Agreement expires in 2020, but also because pressing challenges need solutions that we can only achieve commonly with our partner countries. I am strongly in favour of the support in the EP for a new structure of the cooperation that keeps the unity of EU states with its 79 partner countries under one umbrella, and allows at the same time closer regional cooperation. Climate change is one of the issues that the EU and ACP countries have to tackle, another is to address poverty and fragility of states, as the root causes of migration, in a sustainable way. The forum is best placed to listen to each other’s needs and find common solutions to global problems.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the interparliamentary delegation responsible for the African, Pacific and Caribbean regions, I voted in favour of the report on the EU-ACCS relationship. In this context, particular attention should be paid to the issue of migration. By establishing an appropriate link between these regions and the EU, a well-directed and clean development policy and humanitarian aid can remedy the root causes of migration, such as the threat of war, poverty and mass hunger. It is in the EU's primary interest to help locally, in cooperation with international organisations, to contribute to solving the problem where it develops, rather than bring it into the EU.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the report on the future of ACS-EU relations. The report covers important topics such as the elimination of the donor-beneficiary relationship so far and the development of an equal, autonomy-based relationship. With this new approach, the EU can provide more effective and realistic assistance to the region's pressing problems such as poverty and social inequalities. The report supports the integration of the European Development Fund (EDF) into the budget, which would thus be able to provide more targeted and transparent funding for regional initiatives. I agree with the importance of developing dialogue and coherent policy coordination. Against this background, cooperation with countries in the region (African Union, UN) should be based on a more open networking in the coming period. I consider it important to support the private sector, as well as to promote the aforementioned autonomy. In my opinion, the development of the region must be supported by the above aspects, which is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report convinced of the need to start planning for the future of ACP-EU relations following the conclusion of the Cotonou Agreement between the European Union and the 78 African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) for trade and assistance to be completed by 2020. EU institutions must work to ensure human rights and democracy, as well as the participation of local and regional governments in decision-making in GPA countries. We must keep in mind that 80% of the world's least developed and most forgotten countries are in what we know as the ACP region. That is why the European institutions must consolidate what has been achieved in recent years with the Cotonou Agreement with their sights set on the post-2020 scenario. Similarly, we must take advantage of the coincidence of the expiry of the Cotonou Agreement and the Union's multiannual financial framework in order to integrate the European Development Fund into the general budget and improve in transparency, efficiency and accountability.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Report of the Committee on Development draws up a very comprehensive assessment of the cooperation agreements with the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries which, for over forty years, have been the most important forms in relations between the EU and developing countries.  I think it is very important to remember the political success of this report. More than one hundred countries are currently participating in the Cotonou Agreements, within a framework of very advanced cooperation on various political, economic and commercial aspects and with a substantial budget financed by the European Development Fund. I particularly support what was stated in the report by the Committee on Development on the need for an even more ambitious revision of these agreements, taking into account the changes that have taken place in the global political and economic scenario, and to provide for more binding forms for the objectives set out in the agreement, in particular with regard to poverty reduction and the strengthening of democratic standards.  As elected representatives in Europe, I too would like to stress the importance of interparliamentary cooperation between these macro-regional areas, which operates through the ACP Parliament, the world's largest interparliamentary assembly.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP report on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020 because I believe that the time has come to update relations with these countries, based on the Cotonou Convention and its predecessors.  The strength and acquis of the Cotonou Agreement are based on unique characteristics: it is a legally binding document, the number of countries joining it is unprecedented (79+28 Member States), it is based on three pillars concerning development cooperation, political and economic and trade cooperation and, above all, it has a common institutional framework and a substantial budget (European Development Fund). I hope that the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDOs) will become the focus of a new agreement and that robust monitoring mechanisms will be created to ensure that the implementation of the agreement contributes to the achievement and promotion of the SDOs.  The post-Cotonou Agreement must be a framework political agreement, under which binding minimum requirements are laid down for THEAs (Economic Partnership Agreements), in order to ensure the continuity of the constraints relating to provisions on good governance, respect for human rights, including for the most vulnerable, and respect for social and environmental standards.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The EU must maintain and strengthen its close relations with the ACP countries (Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific) beyond 2020. The ACP countries are an important trading partner of the EU. The cooperation between the EU and the ACP countries initiated by the Cotonou Agreement has led to growth among the partners. In addition to these economic impulses, I also support the political dimension of close cooperation between the EU and the ACP countries. The work done so far in conflict prevention, peace-building and the implementation of democratic structures is exemplary and needs to be further developed beyond the 2020 period.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the non-legislative report. The EU wants to expand its influence over the less economically developed countries of the African, the Caribbean and the Pacific states group (ACP) with the use of the EUR 30 billion of the European Development Fund (EDF), which is outside of the EU budget. The ACP institutions see low-level attendance and produce few results. The EU finances 50% of the costs of the ACP secretariat. UKIP does not support the growing EU influence and the waste of funds on a failing EU project.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because never before has relations between the European Union and the ACP countries needed to be formed from a new perspective that takes into account all the elements of cooperation that comes out of the donor-beneficiary logic, which, after all, has not led to great results in recent years.  The new cooperation no longer speaks the language of welfare: thanks to the new Investment Plan for Africa, we really have the opportunity to create the right economic development and societies. And this path of development can only be linked to the pacification of an area that has already been the scene of too many tragedies. Investment must be accompanied by controls and constraints. It is a path of institutional cooperation that focuses mainly on building fairer societies, with great attention to respect for human rights. The Joint Parliamentary Assembly must strengthen its role. The work must focus on regional focus, analyze specific contexts, solve problems, develop strategies that also serve in context as best practices for other similar situations. Europe must help Africa to become an equal partner and the commitment must be maximum.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. The resolution on ACP-EU relations beyond 2020 is consistent with the Cotonou Agreements, which bring together the European Union, its Member States and the African, Caribbean and Pacific States. These agreements are based on three pillars: development, trade relations and political dialogue. The "trade relations" pillar forced developing countries to lower their tariffs, exposing them to competition against which they could not compete. Similarly, the European Development Fund (EDF), a funding instrument under these agreements, is fictitious: it is only the Member States that abound in this fund. It is also a popular communication technique: to create a 'fund', a 'plan', to simulate political action when the allocated resources already exist. This was the case, for example, with the Juncker Plan for Investment in Europe or the Le Foll Plan for Agricultural Aid. I therefore voted against this report, which purports to correct the current situation by strengthening the power of the European institutions and giving moral lessons to the ACP countries. But without questioning a system that has led to failure...

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution as we believe that it does not reflect the main current challenges of EU-ACP relations. We believe that the post-Cotonou process should provide a fair and balanced framework between equal partners in which to discuss, among other important issues, fair trade issues with all ACP countries, but bearing in mind that trade liberalization is not in itself positive for sustainable development. I reject that there is no call in the resolution to create any binding instrument to identify private sector responsibilities for human rights violations and impunity of transnational corporations. In addition, I stress the importance of respecting, as indicated in SDG 17.15, the sovereignty of the associated countries and that they have a democratic political space to regulate and make decisions for the dignity of their people, a principle not reflected in the resolution.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it highlights the need to keep the binding legal provisions of Cotonou and to strengthen them further whilst boosting the legitimacy of inter-ministerial forums, particularly by including national parliaments to increase legitimacy. The emphasis should be on regional cooperation on the day-to-day level, with the ACP architecture remaining as a forum to promote common standards on issues such as human rights and environment.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I supported this report because I believe it is essential to establish a new framework for cooperation and dialogue between the EU and the ACP countries, which takes into account the political and societal changes that have taken place in recent years, and which enables the achievement of the sustainable development and anti-poverty goals.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats welcome the report's focus on reviewing relations with the ACP countries with a view to the expiry of the Cotonou Agreement in 2020. We are convinced that a future partnership must be based on equal relations based on mutual interests, and it is therefore important that the EUROPEAN Union does not content itself with the continuation of existing agreements that have shown clear shortcomings. We support the report's call for the Commission to put in place a new structure of cooperation based on a broader political partnership than current agreements. At the same time, therefore, we would like to remind you that, at the moment, it is important not to commit ourselves to a ready-made proposal but to enter into negotiations with sensitivity to the needs and assessments of the ACP countries, in order to put in place a future partnership based, among other things, on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and taking into account the differences between the countries and sub-regions.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support the motion for a resolution on the future of ACP-EU relations beyond 2020. Given the unique nature of the European Union’s relationship with the African, Caribbean and Pacific states, I believe that we should strive for increased cooperation and partnership. I accept that the private sector could play a pivotal role in the development process and could contribute to financing development, provided investment occurs that benefits the people, for traditional ownership or use, and for the environment. I agree that EU development aid principles must be applied on an equal basis to all developing countries, and that advanced ACP countries must therefore graduate out of receiving EU development aid on the same terms as non-ACP countries. Furthermore, a higher degree of self-financing by the ACP countries would be in line with the ACP ambitions to be an autonomous player, and the new agreement should include enhanced tools for building ACP countries’ capacity to fund vital economic sectors.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The report looks ahead at the future of the EU’s relations with 79 countries in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific once the Cotonou Partnership Agreement expires in 2020. It is focused on three main areas: political dialogue, development support and economic and trade cooperation; and insists on the fact that a new agreement should be based on the principle of ownership.  I believe strongly in trade and economic cooperation as a contributor to development, and that is why I have voted in favour of this report. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Neuser report on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020. In my opinion, there is no doubt that work on a future partnership between the ACP states and the European Union after the expiry of the Cotonou Agreement in 2020 must continue, as this is in the interest of all stakeholders. However, we need to consider the best choice of the nature of the relationship after the expiry of this agreement.  I believe that the Union's relations with the ACP countries could be included in the form of an umbrella agreement which would define a more general global framework for our relations based on dialogue on issues such as the implementation of the SDGs, climate change and migration, while at the same time giving the possibility of strengthening relations in parallel with individual regions or sub-regions on the basis of more detailed agreements.  We also need to reflect on the future of economic partnership agreements, as it is not clear whether these agreements will be able to exist on their own as a result of their reference to the Cotonou Agreement. However, I think that the Economic Partnership Agreements have been effective in regulating our economic and trade relations, and no one doubts the legitimacy of their continuation. Finally, I would like to stress that the new agreement between the European Union and the ACP states must continue to promote democracy, the rule of law and human rights.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The report covers important topics such as the elimination of the donor-beneficiary relationship so far and the development of an equal, autonomy-based relationship. With this new approach, the EU can provide more effective and realistic assistance to the region's pressing problems such as poverty and social inequalities. The report supports the integration of the European Development Fund (EDF) into the budget, which would thus be able to provide more targeted and transparent funding for regional initiatives. I agree with the importance of developing dialogue and coherent policy coordination. Against this background, cooperation with countries in the region (African Union, UN) should be based on a more open networking in the coming period. I consider it important to support the private sector, as well as to promote the aforementioned autonomy. In my opinion, the development of the region must be supported by the above aspects, which is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the next Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) should be placed at the centre of a new agreement. We need strong monitoring mechanisms to ensure that implementation of the agreement promotes the SDGs.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Future of Relations between the ACP and the EU after 2020, as the PARTNERSHIP between the EU and the ACP is very relevant given that more than 80% of the world's least developed countries are in the ACP regions. These countries have demonstrated their commitment to act together as a group. In order to adapt cooperation to new challenges and improve its effectiveness, a new structure should be adopted in which those parts of the acquis commuli property of ACP and EU countries that are universal in their nature, such as respect for human rights and gender equality, commitment to human development, good governance and democracy, achieving the objective of the rule of law and exchanging best practices within a common framework, while most work must be done in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity , i.e. through regional agreements that would meet the specific needs of the regions and the common interests of the EU and the specific region. In order for successful cooperation to continue and improve, I certainly support this report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Since the EU is trying to revisit the Cotonou agreements, the disastrous effects for the African continent must be remembered. After the victory of unbridled free trade over the paternalistic practice of higher tariffs for northern countries, the African economy was held back in its development. Finally, let us try to recognise the impossibility of an imperialist transposition of our Western values in Africa and to condemn the EU's use of ACP countries to impose its binding framework on states, whose resources it uses to unfairly conduct its own foreign policy. So I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the non-legislative report. The EU wants to expand its influence over the less economically developed countries of the African, the Caribbean and the Pacific states group (ACP) with the use of the EUR 30 billion of the European Development Fund (EDF), which is outside of the EU budget. The ACP institutions see low-level attendance and produce few results. The EU finances 50% of the costs of the ACP secretariat. UKIP does not support the growing EU influence and the waste of funds on a failing EU project.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020, as the sustainable development of the Member States of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of Countries can only be ensured by their gradual integration into the global economy. Partnerships between EU Member States and the ACP Group of Countries must continuously build on previous agreements, including the Cotonou Agreement, which expires in 2020. Only through closer cooperation can development goals, such as eradicating poverty or promoting human rights and democratic principles, be achieved.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Robert Neuser's report on the future of EU-Uk, Caribbean and Pacific relations. This report opens up the debate and prepares the future of relations between the EU and the ACP countries, always within the framework of the Cotonou agreement. With this vote, Parliament reiterates its commitment to support political and economic cooperation with these countries. I welcome this initiative, which is in the direction of a fair trade relationship that will enable the two spaces to benefit from exchanges and to develop. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which contributes to the debate on the future of the partnership between the European Union and the ACP countries by setting out Parliament's priorities. While reaffirming the achievements of the previous agreement (a framework agreement, legally binding and based on the three pillars of political dialogue, cooperation and trade), this report sets out ideas for deepening and further improving our relations after 2020: more regionalisation, a framed budgeting of the European Development Fund, a strengthening of political dialogue and better involvement of civil society and the private sector in particular.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This resolution deals with the reorientation of relations between the Union and the ACP States. However, the Cotonou Agreement, which has been in force to date, has a sobering record, especially in the fight against poverty – the main reason for flight and migration. Setting up another body is unlikely to change much to the current situation, but the reasons, objectives and methods given are perfectly understandable. On the basis of these considerations, I am abstaining on the proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it highlights the need to keep the binding legal provisions of Cotonou and to strengthen them further whilst boosting the legitimacy of inter-ministerial forums particularly by including national parliaments to increase legitimacy. The emphasis should be on regional cooperation on the day to day level with the ACP architecture remaining as a forum to promote common standards on human rights, environment, etc.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I consider the creation of agreements with the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) to be very important, I have decided to abstain from voting on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020. While I fully support the fact that the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the SDGs should become focal points of the new agreement and that a strong monitoring mechanism be established to ensure that the Agreement contributes to and supports the SDGs, I was bothered by the mention that the private sector can play a key role in the development process and can contribute to its financing if the investments are made taking into account both people and traditional ownership or use and the environment, in accordance with the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. This points to the EU's fundamental problem, which is that, although we call it A, we forget B. The belief that corporations will behave in countries that do not have sufficient administrative background and have problems with corruption is nice, but we know that this does not happen very often. While it is an interesting idea to make a shepherd out of a wolf and hope that it does not use its dominance, it is a faith completely blind and incredibly stupid.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against since the framework of future negotiations is in opposition to European values and does not respond to needs of the majority of the population in ACP countries.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Even if this did not seem clear to some in previous years, in the context of the current migrant crisis, it should already be seen that it would be in Europe's fundamental interest to enter into agreements with African countries that would support the survival of the population. For example, the EU could help by improving agriculture, industry and trade to local needs and by transfering the necessary knowledge free of charge. On the other hand, the main objective remains to get African countries into the world economy, which in practice means acquiring their markets by multinationals. It is enough to think about the experience of former KGST countries to be clear about what it means to be involved in wto world trade. The report is unsup supported in its entirety only because it neatly states that developed countries should give €100 billion a year under their previous commitments, which could actually make a significant contribution to this region, as well as to Europe by reducing migratory pressures.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 ACP-EU cooperation is a valuable and important achievement that has strengthened relations between peoples, countries and their parliaments over the past 40 years. Adaptation to new challenges is needed in order to make the partnership between the two countries more efficient.  I call for the 2030 agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to be at the heart of a new agreement, and for strong monitoring mechanisms to be put in place to ensure that the implementation of the agreement contributes and promotes the Sustainable Development Goals. I believe that cooperation should take place in areas of common interest where mutual benefits can be expected – not only in economic terms, but also in terms of peace and security, human rights and the rule of law, good governance and democracy, migration, the environment, climate change and other areas related to the well-being of the ACP and EU populations.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ Traditionally, ACP-EU relations are on a good level. I supported the resolution, it is important to note that at the core of our current relations is the ACP-EU Cotonou Agreement (2000-20), which aims to promote economic links, trade exchanges and political cooperation at different levels (national, regional and multi-regional). Looking from this perspective, it could be argued that ACP-EU cooperation is a valuable and unique achievement that has strengthened not only bonds between ACP and EU peoples and countries but also has raised public awareness of development issues (promotion of sustainable development, eradication of poverty and inequalities).  However, in order to improve the effectiveness of ACP-EU cooperation and to address new global challenges such as climate change, poverty, inequalities, migration, peace and security, a new structure (agreement) should be adopted that maintains partnership and relations with the ACP countries after 2020. The new agreement should primarily be a political project based on the principle of ownership and clearly leave behind the donor-recipient mentality. The 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) would be placed at the centre of the new partnership in order to achieve better results when addressing global challenges.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. This report aims to emphasise the need to create a new structure that maintains a commitment to human rights, good governance and democracy. The main activities should be carried out in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, i.e. in accordance with the principle of determining regional agreements adapted to the specific regional needs and mutual interests existing between the European Union and the region.
