Therefore, ACP-EU cooperation is a valuable achievement which, over the last 40 years, has strengthened the links between the acp and EU peoples and countries and between their respective parliaments. At the same time, a monitoring, reliability and review mechanism is required to cyclically ensure the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals in the Member States, with the relative participation of representatives of acp and EU countries from both central government institutions, parliaments and regional and local authorities.  Therefore, in the light of the above considerations, I support the report.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because the Cotonou agreements are negative for Africa and delay its development. The future of ACP-Europe relations cannot be achieved through these free trade agreements imposed on it.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the future of ACP-EU relations beyond 2020. Apart from the fact that the European Union does not have to have diplomacy in any form, it must be remembered that the Cotonou free trade agreements are a disaster for Africa. They have delayed the creation of African industries, and have contributed to the creation of gigantic African cities linked to a huge rural exodus. On the other hand, how can we accept that the EU uses the European Development Fund to capture achievements due to direct contributions from states (considering X) and to present itself as a friend of Africa while it uses the ACP countries to impose its binding framework on states (paragraph 2), that they intend to create a special procedure to manage the ultramarine territories of States (paragraph 29) and remove them from negotiations with the United Nations or the African Union? Finally, one can only be surprised at the lessons that the EU allows itself to give on corruption (paragraph 11).

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. This report tends to perpetuate what the European Union considers to be the progress of the Cotonou agreements. Signed on 23 June 2000, they are based on three pillars: development, trade relations and political dialogue. For my part, I believe that the Cotonou agreements have not advanced Africa. Prior to these agreements, the countries of the North paid more for tariffs to enable the accelerated development of the area. A system deemed "paternalistic" by the Western world. To this, the Cotonou agreements have replaced a progressive free trade system. As a direct consequence, a huge delay in the development of African industries, an unprecedented rural exodus and the creation of ultra-concentrated megacities, which are gigantic centres of consumption, not production. Finally, the EU's on-the-ground moral lessons, particularly on corruption, are surprising to say the least. For these various reasons, and especially to sanction these agreements which are not the announced success, I voted against.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the future of the agreement between the Union and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) will expire on 29 February 2020. This agreement proposes a framework for the Union's cooperation relations with the ACP countries which is based in three major dimensions: political dialogue; development cooperation and the fight against poverty; and regional trade cooperation and economic integration.  The report proposes to review the partnership framework with the ACP countries to ensure: adaptation to new risks (terrorism, refugees, good governance, peace and security, climate change, SDP), joint action in global for a and the best results in the goal of eradicating poverty. The report underlines the need to ensure control mechanisms with the full participation of civil society and national parliaments; maintain the conditionality of the agreement on the basis of respect for human rights and the rule of law;  strengthen political dialogue to stop being reactive and move on to preventing political crises; strengthen legal procedures and make them operational for the fight against corruption.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This report aims to establish what the relationship between the Union and the african, Caribbean and Pacific countries should look like after 2020. It should be noted that partnership agreements have always had numerous negative impacts on the economies of the ACP countries, so I think a new type of partnership, just and equal, respecting the sovereignty of countries and promoting the development of countries' productive capacities, protecting traditional agriculture and combating land grabbing , and overexploitation, as long as it also has legal mechanisms to combat labour exploitation, modern slavery, the illicit flow of capital and the financing of terrorism and armed conflict. I also think it is important to stress the importance of ending foreign interference in the internal affairs of the ACP countries, as well as the end of neocolonial policies and the dismantling of all foreign military bases. However, this report does not propose any of these changes which I consider fundamental to the future of EU-ACP relations following the end of the Cotonou agreement in 2020, so my vote went against this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution addresses the future of ACP-EU relations after the expiry of the Cotonou Agreement. One of the Commission's priorities is the revision of this agreement, which seeks to promote the economic development of the ACP countries (more than 80% of the least developed countries belong to regions of the GPA), as well as to contribute to the peace, security, political and democratic stability of their countries, with particular emphasis on the promotion of human rights and democratic principles based on the rule of law. In addition, this partnership has played an important role in the Millennium Development Goals, and aspires in the future to address new global challenges (climate change, migration and peace, among others).  I am voting in favour because a special partnership with 79 ACP countries strengthens the Union's role as an important global international player, and will help to continue the change that has already begun to take place in the political and economic landscape of the countries of the GPA region.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which seeks to maintain the legally binding framework agreement based on political dialogue, cooperation and trade.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. We're supposed to be doing business with the countries of Africa and the Caribbean, not stuffing them with subsidies. Nor do I agree with the Involvement of the European Investment Bank in private projects in third countries.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Development, trade and political cooperation between the European Union and ACP Member States is based on the Cotonou Partnership Agreement, signed on 23 June 2000. Since this Agreement became the basis for cooperation between the EU and the ACP Group, there have been major changes in the political and economic context of both regions. In order to increase the effectiveness of the new arrangements, a new structure is needed that will preserve the acquis of the previous Agreement while allowing room for adaptation to emerging political and economic conditions. The main partnership activities must take place within the scope of regional agreements, which are adapted to the specific regional needs and common interests of the EU and a specific region within the ACP Group.  The basis of renewed cooperation between the EU and the ACP group must be an equal partnership. Cooperation in the areas of common interests can expect economic gains and progress in preserving peace, human rights and other progress-related factors. The future agreement must ensure policy coherence to achieve sustainable development and list the fight against inequality and poverty as key features and objectives of the partnership.  In line with previous claims about the importance of renewing and restructuring cooperation with the ACP Group, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The report recalled the unique nature of ACP-EU cooperation and stressed the need to put in place a new structure that maintains those parts of the ACP-EU acquis, e.g., a commitment to human rights and gender equality, human development, good governance and democracy, the objective of the rule of law, exchange of best practice in a common framework. EP members underlined that the common framework and the regional agreements should be legally binding. The report states that the following must be placed at the centre of a new agreement: the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals and respect for internationally agreed aid effectiveness principles, the fight against, and ultimate eradication of, poverty and inequalities, human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Partnership Agreement between the 79 members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States and the European Community and its Member States was signed in Cotonou in 2000. It was subsequently revised in 2005 and 2010. It is based on three pillars of cooperation: development political, economic and trade cooperation. 80% of the least developed countries are from the ACP regions. I support the EP's requests for cooperation after 2020 in order to create the conditions for tackling poverty in these countries, to encourage investment and to set up economic and social development. At the same time, it is necessary to help create institutions in these countries that respect the laws of democracy and the rule of law.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. The Cotonou Agreement, adopted in 2000, will expire in 2020. It is the legally binding framework for relations between the European Union and the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific (ACP). It now provides a framework of reference, based on common values and priorities in 107 countries. It is the most important international partnership agreement, both in terms of the number of signatories and the dimensions it covers: political, development, economic and commercial. The future of EU-ACP relations is a central issue in terms of the long-term political and strategic issues it represents. In order to adapt the partnership to new international challenges, this report calls for the preservation, after 2020, of the previous achievements of the Cotonou agreement.  The report also highlights the urgent need to integrate the results of the major international conferences of 2015: new sustainable development goals, a new development finance framework, the Paris climate agreement/COP21. Convinced that the future of the EU-ACP relationship is a major issue, I vote in favour of this text.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 3/10/2016, and because I believe that this report is neither complete nor documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. The report on the future of ACP-EU relations poses several problems. First, it proposes to deepen the political dialogue between the EU and the ACP countries. Although political cooperation with African countries is welcome, it is not for the European Union to lead it. Fortunately, the Member States still retain their prerogatives in the field of foreign policy. Moreover, the economic relations between the EU and the ACP countries, based on the Cotonou agreements, illustrate all the shortcomings of European trade policy. Indeed, it is an example of a paternalistic system where the countries of the North agreed to pay more tariffs to allow the accelerated development of this area. Finally, despite the fact that the Cotonou agreements were a disaster for Africa, the European Parliament welcomes their success and wants to continue the approach envisaged. We cannot accept that.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ In regard to the report on the future of ACP-EU relations beyond 2020, I expressed a favourable vote given the fact that the partnership has been crucial in making progress towards achieving the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). The report also encourages engagement with other partners around the globe such as the United Nations or the African Union to tackle the challenges of wars, internal conflicts, insecurity, fragility and transition. Finally yet importantly, the report calls for all international actors to come together to fight and eradicate poverty and inequalities while promoting sustainable development.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The Cotonou Agreement, governing relations between the states of Europe, Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific - 107 countries! Is the most extensive international cooperation agreement in existence. Signed in 2000, it will expire in 2020. While the European Commission is in the middle of thinking about the future of this EU-ACP partnership, it was important for the European Parliament to set its terms for the renewal of a possible 'Cotonou II' agreement. I personally believe that it is fundamental that EU-ACP relations remain balanced and that their trade aspect does not take over the pillars of 'political cooperation' and 'development aid'. This aspiration is shared by the Neuser report, which sets strict conditions (and currently not respected by the Commission) for the negotiation of EU-Africa trade agreements. The report also recalls that the "Cotonou" partnership is primarily intended to promote common values (democracy, rule of law) and shared objectives (UN Sustainable Development Goals, COP 21), without obscuring the indispensable political dialogue - symbolized by the joint parliamentary assembly - in particular on human rights. Conversely, the European Union must not skimp on development aid with its ACP partners. I supported the report.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020 because it strengthens the links between the peoples and the ACP countries with the EU countries and the ties between their Parliaments. In order to be able to improve and cooperate effectively, a new structure must be adopted which will preserve the universal elements of the ACP-EU acquis such as commitment to human rights, good democracy and human rights. Finally, I am voting in favour of this resolution and stress that issues such as combating poverty, tackling inequalities and promoting sustainable development should be the primary objective of ACP-EU cooperation.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The resolution deals with the reorientation of the European Union's relations with the ACP Group countries (Cotonou Agreements). Since the record of such agreements so far is rather sobering, I am rather critical of this resolution. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP report on post-2020 relations between The African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) and the EU. The report contains provisions setting out new cooperation objectives and financial, economic instruments to address global challenges in our day more effectively, such as climate change, migration flows, terrorism, extremism, international crime, biodiversity, water supply, energy and food, etc.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. It is a question of the EU continuing and thus justifying the Cotonou agreements. These are based on three pillars (development, trade relations and political dialogue). The aim here is to change structures and deepen procedures, such as the political dialogue in Articles 8 and 96 or the new form of EPAs (economic partnership agreements). It should be noted that the EU has no diplomatic competence in any form. It should also be remembered that the Cotonou agreements were a disaster for Africa. Indeed, by substituting a "progressive" free trade system for the system deemed too paternalistic in which the countries of the North agreed to pay more tariffs to enable the accelerated development of this area, the Cotonou agreements helped to delay the creation of African industries protected and perpetuated by high tariffs, France's objective with "the cooperation project". Today, we are seeing african cities that are growing, a phenomenon favoured by the rural exodus, which have become real centres of consumption without being centres of production. So I objected to that.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. In recent years, development policy has undergone a new impetus at both EU and international level. The EU must continue to focus on deepening relations with acp countries. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support the report on future cooperation between the Union and African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States. The report focuses on measures that can improve upon the existing Cotonou Agreement, it also explicitly calls for the end of the donor-recipient mentality and stresses that the new agreement must be a political project.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Post-Cotonou is a political and strategic issue for the EU. It is the cornerstone of our dialogue and cooperation from the political, developmental, economic and commercial perspectives. It structures our relationship around essential principles and values shared with ACP countries such as respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law, support for peace and security. It provides a framework for our development cooperation, through the EDF. It allows the development of our economic and trade relations, through the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) of which I am a strong advocate. On the eve of 2020, it is not only a question of taking stock of what has been done, but also of taking into account new global issues such as the fight against climate change, international crime, the fight against terrorism and the migration crisis. We must work to improve our development cooperation policy by making it more effective, coherent, more appropriate and more sustainable.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The roots of the Partnership of the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of States and the EU date back to 1963, since then several contractual frameworks have been signed, the last revision of the contractual bases taking place in 2000, known as the Cotonou Agreement. However, this agreement expires in 2020 and it is therefore necessary to launch a debate on the future of the ACP-EU partnership after 2020. The Cotonou Agreement is considered beneficial, so maintaining its provisions will also be part of future relations. The report further examines a number of possible scenarios for the future of the partnership: stronger regionalisation, the EDF budget, the strengthening of political dialogue and greater participation by civil society and the private sector. The 2030 Agenda and the SDGs should form the basis of the new agreement. The fight against poverty remains a central objective of ACP-EU cooperation, but the new agreement must be primarily a political project and must leave behind the donor-recipient mentality. Cooperation should take place in areas of common interest where common benefits can be expected, not only in terms of economic aspects, but also in terms of peace and security, human rights and the rule of law, good governance and democracy, migration, the environment, climate change and other areas related to the prosperity of both ACP and EU citizens.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the future of relations between African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries and the EU beyond 2020, which is the Parliament’s contribution to the follow-up of the international Cotonou Agreement that was launched in 2000 and is due to expire in 2020. The Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) are used as developing instruments to boost intra-African trade, which immensely helps those countries, speeds up their economies and integrates them into the global economy, but they could also be used as an instrument to address new challenges, such as environment, climate change, terrorism, and migration. ACP countries have further room for development and improvement, but to do that we need to strengthen the political dialogue and advance towards a new unique framework with regional agreements that are tailored to specific regional needs and to the mutual interests existing between the EU and the respective region.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACS) was established by the Georgetown Agreement concluded in 1975 and revised in 1992. The Partnership Agreement between the ACCS, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, was established by the Cotonou Agreement signed in Cotonou on 23 June 2000 and revised in 2005 and 2010. Since the signing of the Cotonou Agreement, changes have taken place in the political and economic scene of the ACCS Group and in the European Union, the Committee on Development proposes in its report to Parliament the adoption of a resolution to adopt a new structure to increase the effectiveness of cooperation and adapt it to new challenges. The draft resolution reviews the aspects which should be taken into account in the new agreement. I voted in favour of the draft.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The current relations with the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) and European Union countries have not achieved great results for the parties to the Agreement.  After the Cotonou Agreement, it is vital to prepare a more effective and efficient framework and, more importantly, adapted to new and emerging global challenges. This new framework should be defined in close cooperation with ACP countries, including civil society and in coordination with regional organisations, and should draw on the lessons learned from the Cotonou Partnership Agreement in order to avoid a repeat of efforts and structures. I believe that, in the framework of post-Cotonou action, there should be mechanisms to facilitate trade and that growth and development will have to be its main targets. I endorse the rapporteur's position on the importance of a renewed ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly and its participation in all stages of discussions on the post-Cotonou framework, as well as the existence of strict parliamentary scrutiny of the future framework.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This vote on the future of EU-ACP relations aims to keep the Cotonou agreements going. However, these agreements were a disaster for Africa's development, since instead of setting up a progressive free trade system, a system considered paternalistic in which the countries of the North agreed to pay more tariffs to allow the accelerated development of this zone was instituted. As a result, this has helped to delay the creation of African industries using the "Listian" method of educator protectionism, a development model adopted by emerging Asians. Nor does this text raise the question of the relevance of the CFA franc. Considering that it is up to states to decide their foreign policy and that these agreements are detrimental to Africa's development, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the future of ACP-EU relations beyond 2020. In particular, I support the call for the creation of a specific financial instrument for overseas countries and territories that have so far benefited from the European Development Fund. The EDF should be devoted exclusively to cooperation and development in ACP countries. The report also calls for the continued partnership between the European Union and the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States and for a strengthening of political dialogue between them.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Neuser report on the future of ACP-EU relations beyond 2020. The report aims to contribute to the debate by setting out the European Parliament's priorities for the future EU-ACP relationship. It insists on maintaining the Cotonou acquis, that is, a legally binding framework agreement based on three pillars: political dialogue, cooperation and trade. It then explores possible developments, such as more regionalization, a framed budgeting of the EDF, or the strengthening of political dialogue and better involvement of civil society and the private sector.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the renewed centrality of relations between the European Union and the ACP countries and the expiry, in 2020, of the legal framework laid down in the Cotonou Convention, we strongly support the Neuser report.  Since its inception, the European Union, recognising its historical responsibility and the need to promote a model of sustainable development in areas with a high poverty rate, has pursued policies of assistance and cooperation. Since 1975, the year of the Lomé Convention, cooperation, which is characterized by a holistic approach, has been based on three pillars: development cooperation, political cooperation and economic and trade cooperation. The opening of negotiations to civil society and national parliaments, together with asymmetric trade facilities, has given rise to fruitful dialogue on human rights.  Looking ahead to 2020, however, we believe that the effectiveness of measures to support economic development and the rule of law must be reinvigorated, including through greater rigidity of legal clauses making trade facilitation conditional on respect for fundamental rights.  Finally, we cannot fail to stress the importance of Africa and the need for a comprehensive European policy that sees migration as part of a complex phenomenon and that recognises its distant causes.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union maintains a great relationship with african, Caribbean and Pacific countries. I support the continuation of political and trade cooperation after 2020, following the successful direction so far. I am satisfied with the objectives, and I particularly appreciate the support for regional development, which could be the first step towards eradicating poverty.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: par écrit. ‒ The Cotonou Agreement is a partnership signed by the Member States and the ACP States with the main objective being reducing poverty consistent as much as possible. Moreover, the agreement is contributing to the process of promotion the economy, as well as the cultural and social development of the ACP States. I have voted for this report because of its importance in connecting not only people, but also countries and their parliaments form both ACP and EU over the last 40 years.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – Relations between the EU and the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries are currently governed by the Cotonou Agreement, which expires in 2020. Given that over 80 % of the least developed countries in the world are from the ACP region and that, in particular, there are signs of destabilisation in Africa that pose an immediate risk to Europe's security, I believe that the form of EU-ACP cooperation needs to be renewed. The new form of cooperation, through the Joint Parliamentary Assembly, must exercise effective control over the funds allocated to the ACP States in order to avoid the likelihood that only local elites will benefit from them. Moreover, greater autonomy must be given to local and regional government and help build its capacity so that it participates in all stages of ACP-EU activities, from planning to implementation.  Only so small producers and farmers and civil society will be provided with a favourable development environment and the possibility of quality funding.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the European Union's foreign policy with regard to the relationship with the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific must be continued, especially in the current political and economic context, and must have as its central point the integration and sustainable development of these third countries, through the trade relations they establish with the European countries. Similarly, EU-ACP cooperation is a very important one as it will create more effective working tools in the fight against terrorism and international crime. Last but not least, I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that long-term cooperation between the European Union and the ACP countries can bring more openness to democracy and strengthening of human rights in these countries.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020 and consider it important that the EP deals with this issue so thoroughly. I believe that EU policy in relation to ACP countries should be more consistent. In this sense, the report rightly points out that, although Article 97 of the Cotonou Agreement introduces a consultation procedure and appropriate measures to combat serious cases of corruption, this article has so far only been applied in one case and should therefore be significantly strengthened in the new PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENT between the EU and the ACP countries. I am also of the opinion that legally binding provisions on sustainability, in particular as regards human rights, but also on social and environmental standards, should be included in all economic partnership agreements as a future contractual framework for RELATIONS between the EU and the ACP countries.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report as well. I cannot speak in favour of this report because of the record so far, which is rather sobering, particularly in the fight against poverty. Now we want to set up another body, but I doubt that this will lead to greater effectiveness.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The so-called Cotonou Agreement expires in February 2020 and the EU's relationship with the ACP countries must be a new basis. More than 80 % of the world's least developed countries are located in acp regions, while eu-ACP cooperation covers both political, economic and development cooperation, so the continuation of the agreement between them is of great importance. The renewed agreement sets a general objective to combat poverty and inequality, calls for new sustainable development trends and stronger monitoring mechanisms.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled.  I believe that it is already necessary to pay particular attention to the implementation of the 2030 agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals. It is therefore essential to ensure that the new agreement contributes to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals. In particular, an effective monitoring mechanism and future ACP-EU institutions need to be established, involving the parliamentary dimension. In addition, it is essential to continuously promote open democratic and comprehensive parliamentary dialogue. Another important aspect is future funding. In this context, a specific instrument should be established to finance security expenditure related to development cooperation.  In order to ensure sustainable development and policy coherence, particular attention must also be paid to the implementation of trade policy. It is essential to ensure that sustainability provisions are included on a binding basis without reservation in economic partnership agreements. In addition, mandatory minimum requirements for new Economic Partnership Agreements and control and monitoring mechanisms should be laid down.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The general framework for the EU's relations with Africa is the Cotton Agreement, established in 2000 with the aim of eradicating poverty through the fuller integration of the ACP countries into the world economy. However, many changes have taken place in the political and economic context of the ACP group countries and the European Union since the signing of the Cotton Agreement. Thus, in order to improve the effectiveness of cooperation and to adapt it to new challenges, a new structure must be adopted which will preserve the elements of the ACP-EU acquis, such as commitment to human rights, good governance and democracy, the objective of the rule of law and the exchange of best practices in a common framework. I voted in favour of the report calling for the 2030 agenda and sustainable development objectives to be put at the heart of the new agreement, as well as the establishment of an ACP-EU peer monitoring, accountability and evaluation mechanism, in order to regularly monitor the implementation of the sustainable development objectives in the Member States.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the non-legislative report. The EU wants to expand its influence over the less economically developed countries of the African, the Caribbean and the Pacific states group (ACP) with the use of the EUR 30 billion of the European Development Fund (EDF), which is outside of the EU budget. The ACP institutions see low-level attendance and produce few results. The EU finances 50% of the costs of the ACP secretariat. UKIP does not support the growing EU influence and the waste of funds on a failing EU project.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of this proposal.  I believe that the ACP-EU partnership is of considerable importance, given that more than 80 % of the least developed countries in the world are in ACP regions. The European Union, as a player on the international stage, cannot but enter into agreements aimed at promoting the growth of economies and prosperity in these areas. Finally, it is a question of reducing and eliminating poverty in such a way as to be able to develop the lasting and progressive integration of the ACP countries, while protecting a set of values and principles that include respect for fundamental freedoms and human rights. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the relations between the EU and ACP countries need adapt to the political, structural and demographic changes of recent years. In this regard, a framework needs to be established for implementing the new Agenda 2030 and achieving the objectives of sustainable development. This report calls for the fight against poverty to remain an overarching objective of ACP-EU cooperation.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. Relations and cooperation between the ACP and the EU so far have been and remain aimed at strengthening universal values and objectives such as the promotion of human rights, democracy and sustainable development. My experience on the ground, with the conduct of two European election observation missions in support of democracy in Nigeria and Kenya, speaks to the need to concreteise the starting points through more specific regional strategies and regional agreements that will take greater account of the changed political, economic and security situation. Cooperation should take place in areas of common interest where mutual benefit could be expected, not only from an economic point of view, but also, and above all, with regard to peace and security, human rights and the principles of the rule of law, good governance and democracy, migration, the environment, climate change and other areas related to the well-being of the population. Peace is a value that, in my view, remains the first development priority. We cannot successfully tackle the problem of poverty unless peace is guaranteed. I therefore find it sensible for the ACP and the EU to work together as a whole, on this and other supportive universal values. In this context, I propose that we devote even more energy in the future to intercultural dialogue.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Cooperation between ACP countries and the EU is a valuable and unique achievement that has strengthened ties between ACP countries and the EU and their parliaments over the past 40 years. In order to adapt cooperation to new challenges and improve its effectiveness, a new structure should be adopted that maintains those parts of the acquis of ACP and EU countries that are universal in their nature, such as a commitment to human rights, good governance and democracy, the achievement of the rule of law objective and the exchange of best practices within a common framework. Cooperation should be achieved in areas of common interest where mutual benefit can be expected, not only in economic terms but also in terms of peace and security, human rights, good governance and democracy, environmental protection and the fight against climate change and other areas related to the betterment of the populations of ACP and EU countries. The objectives of the cooperation are to put the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs at the heart of the new agreement and to establish strong monitoring mechanisms to ensure that the implementation of the agreement contributes to and promotes the SDGs. I therefore supported this report, as it will adapt our cooperation to new challenges and contribute to improving it as well as preserving stability.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The EU's aim is to continue what it sees as the progress of the Cotonou Agreements, which are based on three pillars (development, trade relations and political dialogue). Apart from the fact that the Union does not have to have diplomacy, it must be remembered that these agreements were a disaster. By substituting a progressive free trade system for the paternalistic system in which the countries of the North agreed to pay more for tariffs to enable the development of this area, they participated, along with other factors, in delaying the creation of African industries. On the other hand, how can we accept that Europe uses the EDF (European Development Fund) to attribute achievements due to direct contributions from states (point X) and to present itself as a friend of Africa while it uses countries ACP to impose its binding framework on states (point 2), that it intends to create a special procedure to manage the ultramarine territories of states (point 29) and remove them from negotiations with the United Nations or the African Union? Finally, one can only be surprised at the lessons that the EU allows itself in this text to give on corruption (point 11). I therefore vote against this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 ACP-EU cooperation has strengthened links between acp and EU peoples and countries over the past 40 years. The results of the objectives of poverty eradication and integration of acp countries into the world economy, however, are still insufficient to date. Half of the ACP countries are among the least developed countries and, overall, these countries account for less than 5 % of world trade and about 2 % of total GDP. In order to improve the effectiveness of cooperation and make it equal to today's challenges, it is necessary to rethink its structure, preserving the general principles of a universal nature (human rights, gender equality, human development, democracy, the rule of law, etc.) and organising the main activities on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity (favouring regional agreements and the participation of local actors and civil society).  At the same time, a formal right of control over the programming of the European Development Fund (EDF) by the European Parliament should be guaranteed. Budgetization of the EDF would allow democratic control, increase visibility and increase transparency and effectiveness in the use of EU development funds. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The main objective of the Cotonou agreement is to "reduce and ultimately eradicate poverty, in line with the SDGs and the gradual integration of ACP states into the global economy". More than 80% of the world's least developed countries are in ACP regions, their share of global GDP at around 2%. The new agreement must primarily be a political project. I call for an effective cooperation framework for the period following the end of the Cotonou Agreement, which will be adapted to new and upcoming global changes, based on the responsibility of ACP countries, a shift away from the donor-recipient mindset. Tackling poverty and inequality, as well as promoting sustainable development, must continue to be the main objectives of cooperation. The new co-operation agreement should gain a strong parliamentary dimension through the actions of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly. Further cooperation with other partners and stakeholders is also needed whenever possible. Existing (sub)regional organisations and regional strategies and agreements should be taken into account, the involvement of additional countries, such as North African countries, should be allowed. In particular, relations with the African Union may deepen further. The Partnership Agreement is crucial for ACP governments in improving the overall performance of their economies.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 As we have stated, an inflection is necessary in the relationship between the EU and the ACP countries, a relationship now framed by the Cotonou Agreement. This is not the vision behind this report, quite the contrary. When a deeper and more critical approach was required with regard to the relations of dependency and subordination to which acp countries have found themselves subject and the role of EU policies in establishing such relations, the report underlaws, as to the essential, the course taken in recent years. When criticism of the so-called ECONOMIC PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENTS (EPAs) imposed by the EU and the consequences of their implementation was required, the EPAs are not criticised or scrutinised, on the contrary, they are seen as the instrument that should frame relations between the EU and the ACP countries, because they are supposed to be promoting growth and development. When a new framework of cooperation genuinely capable of promoting the sovereign development of acp countries was required, the report ignores this need, does not address such potential problems as the illegal exploitation and expropriation of natural resources by foreign interests in acp countries, ignores the will, opinion and participation of acp countries, giving greater relevance to the affirmation (explicit or implicit) of the EU's geostrategic interests. We voted against it.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has signed a partnership agreement with the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) as early as 2000. Cooperation between the ACP and the EU has strengthened relations between the peoples and the ACP countries and the EU in recent years, including at interparliamentary level. However, mutual agreement needs to be updated to take into account the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and its objectives. The new agreement should also include a specific monitoring mechanism to oversee the achievement of the objectives of the Agenda. I believe that political dialogue needs to be strengthened, especially on the issue of human rights. I also support the idea of creating a specific financial instrument to finance security expenditure in the implementation of development aid.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, through this report, stresses the importance of cooperation between the ACP countries and the EU. The text stresses that, in order to strengthen their effectiveness and avoid overlap, regional agreements with african, caribbean and pacific countries should be designed to take account of existing regional organisations, such as the African Union, and existing regional agreements, such as economic partnership agreements (EPA).  Given the changed political and economic scenario in which the ACP states operate following the signing of the Cotonou Agreement, I believe that the key to improving cooperation with the EU must be sought in the private sector, through the promotion of public-private partnerships. I am convinced that the fight against poverty and, in the long run, its eradication, must remain the main objective of the new ACP-EU agreements.  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The ACP-EU Partnership Agreement is the most comprehensive agreement between developing countries and the European Union. Since 2000, it has been the cornerstone of the EU's relationship with 79 African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries. The Cotonou Agreement expires in 2020, so the main objective of this resolution is to establish new EU relations with ACP countries in order to improve the effectiveness of cooperation and adapt it to new challenges. The resolution sets out the future ACP-EU relationship in three main areas: political dialogue, development support and economic and trade cooperation. calls for the fight against poverty and inequality and the promotion of sustainable development to remain the overarching objective of ACP-EU cooperation; At the same time, it considers that the new agreement must be primarily a political project based on the principles of ownership and unequivocally eliminate the donor-beneficiary mentality. The area to be highlighted is the private sector, as it can play a key role in the development process and contribute to its financing, protecting investment with respect for people, traditional property and use and the environment in line with the UN's main principles on business and human rights. I have hereby abstained.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In 2000, the European Union and the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) signed the Cotonou Agreement, a 20-year framework for political and economic cooperation. It is therefore time to rethink our strategy of partnering with these states, most of which are part of geographical areas that are areas of growth beyond our borders. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of ACP-EU relations and sets out the areas for improving the partnership between the Union and the ACP countries. Fighting poverty is the central objective of supporting European states to troubled states within the ACP group. But, I believe deeply, it is through economic growth that development will be sustainable. Investing in large-scale projects to help ensure that these ACP countries finally have a real capacity to fit into global value chains must be the priority of the future EU-ACP cooperation framework. More generally, this relationship will necessarily have to adapt to structural changes, particularly demographic ones, in order for the EU-ACP partnership to be at the service of long-term development and not short-termist objectives.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Legitimised by the Cotonou agreement, initially signed in 2003, the partnership between the ACP (group of countries in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific), composed of 79 States, and the European Union (EU), which integrates 28 Member States, is a binding document with an unprecedented numerical composition. The Cotonou agreement had as its main pillar the reduction and eradication of poverty, in line with the objectives of sustainable development and progressive integration of acp states into the world economy. This agreement is based on a set of values such as respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, democracy and the rule of law. But it will exhaust its effects even before December 2016. However, given a general assessment, it is noted that, despite a political rapprochement between the parties and advances in the development of poverty eradication, the results have proved to be insufficient and unequal. This report identifies priority areas for the future action of ACP-EU cooperation, of which I highlight, on the one hand, the need for binding allocation to common frameworks and regional agreements, as well as, on the other hand, the importance of emphasising the 2030 Agenda and sustainable development goals at the heart of the new agreement, and, as well as the permanence of the priority objective , eradicating poverty. I therefore vote in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the non-legislative report. The EU wants to expand its influence over the less economically developed countries of the African, the Caribbean and the Pacific states group (ACP) with the use of the EUR 30 billion of the European Development Fund (EDF), which is outside of the EU budget. The ACP institutions see low-level attendance and produce few results. The EU finances 50% of the costs of the ACP secretariat. UKIP does not support the growing EU influence and the waste of funds on a failing EU project.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, taking into account the Partnership Agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific States and the European Community and its Member States, calls for the 2030 Agenda and sustainable development objectives to be placed at the heart of a new agreement, as well as the establishment of sound monitoring mechanisms, to ensure that the implementation of the agreement promotes and contributes to sustainable development goals. For future institutions, the EP calls for acp-EU mixed council meetings to include policy debates on urgent issues with the aim of adopting common conclusions on them. For future funding, the EP is convinced that the simultaneous expiry of the Cotonou Agreement and the multiannual financial framework is an opportunity to finally decide whether the European Development Fund should be included in the budget with a view to increasing the efficiency, transparency, democratic control, accountability, visibility and coherence of EU development funds. In finalising, as regards the trade dimension, the EP reiterates that economic partnership agreements (EPAs) are a basis for regional cooperation and should be instruments for regional development and integration. In view of the above, I voted in favour.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Cooperation between the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) states and the European Union is a valuable and unique achievement that has strengthened ties between acp countries and EU Member States, as well as their national parliaments over the past 40 years. In order to improve the effectiveness of cooperation and adapt to new challenges, it is necessary to continue to invest in human rights and gender equality, human development, good governance and democracy, the rule of law and the exchange of best practices under a common framework, without neglecting specific regional needs.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The current Partnership Agreement with the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States - Cotonou Agreement - was signed in 2000 with effect until 2020 and proposes a framework for cooperation relations focused on three major axes: political dialogue; development cooperation and the fight against poverty; and regional trade cooperation and economic integration. The amount of financial support for the ACP countries for the period 2014-2020 amounts to EUR 30 506 million. The report, which I voted in favour of, propose to review the partnership framework with the ACP countries to ensure their adaptation to new risks (terrorism, refugees, good governance, peace and security, climate change, SDGs); joint action in global for a and better outcomes in the goal of eradicating poverty.  In addition, the report underlines the need to ensure control mechanisms with the full participation of civil society and national parliaments; maintain the conditionality of the agreement on the basis of respect for human rights and the rule of law; strengthen legal procedures and make them operational for the fight against corruption, as well as support for the parliamentary dimension of the new agreement - ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report. This is in the context of the expiration in 2020 of the Cotonou partnership agreement between the EU and the ACP countries. The report contains a set of objectives, principles, cooperation and financing arrangements as well as institutional recommendations for a future partnership. The key intention behind this report is not to achieve a status quo in light of major contextual developments in Europe and within the ACP.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report. It should be noted that cooperation between the EU and the ACP States has not met expectations in the past. Significant funds were called, but the expected results were not achieved. This shows the need for closer and direct cooperation with individual countries, rather than a unified and far-right.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The Cotonou agreement has helped to strengthen political ties between the European Union and the ACP countries (Africa, caribbean, Pacific). However, the results of this partnership are not very noticeable, so ACP-EU relations need to adapt to the political, structural and demographic changes that have occurred in the meantime. I therefore consider it of the utmost importance to establish a new framework implementing the 2030 Agenda and meeting the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The future partnership must also meet mutual ambitions, so it is important that there is great clarity in the priorities identified from the outset. Poverty eradication must remain one of the primary objectives of ACP-EU cooperation. I also believe that political dialogue will have to be more effective and better explored both at government level and at the level of the States themselves as a whole, and should be carried out proactively and not only as a crisis management tool. As Vice-President of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, I have submitted 23 amendments, and i have therefore made in this report some proposals that I have made, in particular in terms of the involvement of local authorities, regional authorities and civil society organisations, as well as maintaining poverty eradication as one of the primary objectives of the future partnership.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which sets out the European Parliament's position on the future relations of the European Union with the ACP countries after 2020, that is, when the Cotonou agreement has expired. It is crucial that the post-2020 partnership with ACP countries is renewed and that it remains legally binding. The report calls for improvements to the current structure while maintaining the ACP-EU acquis, including a commitment to human rights, human development, good governance and democracy. It is essential that the 2030 sustainable development agenda, the fight against poverty and its eventual eradication and human rights be placed at the centre of the future agreement. I supported this text, which also calls for the budgeting of the European Development Fund if it is associated with maintaining the allocations and creating an instrument to finance security spending related to development.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution as we believe that it does not reflect the main current challenges of EU-ACP relations. We believe that the post-Cotonou process should provide a fair and balanced framework between equal partners in which to discuss, among other important issues, fair trade issues with all ACP countries, but bearing in mind that trade liberalization is not in itself positive for sustainable development. I reject that there is no call in the resolution to create any binding instrument to identify private sector responsibilities for human rights violations and impunity of transnational corporations. In addition, I stress the importance of respecting, as indicated in SDG 17.15, the sovereignty of the associated countries and that they have a democratic political space to regulate and make decisions for the dignity of their people, a principle not reflected in the resolution.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the draft report on the future of EU-ACP relations after 2020, as it is an important contribution to the discussion on the future relationship between the EU and the ACP countries. The ACP countries include the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, on which European development policy is focused. The report calls for the retention of the legally binding framework agreement, which is based on the three pillars of political dialogue, cooperation and trade. In addition, relations between the EU and the ACP countries must adapt to the political, structural and demographic changes of recent years. The aim of the report is to create a framework for this.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The relationship between the EU, on the one hand, and the African, Caribbean and Pacific states, on the other, is an important partnership. It is therefore appropriate to build on the Coton Agreement in the future and to support the achievement of objectives such as eradicating poverty and hunger, ensuring access to drinking water or access to education. For example, the new agreement should be based on cooperation in the field of common interests, mutual responsibility and monitoring, stronger involvement of civil society or the fight against corruption. I agree with this, and i would therefore like to support this future cooperation with my vote.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report aims to establish what the relationship between the Union and the african, Caribbean and Pacific countries should look like after 2020. It should be noted that partnership agreements have always had numerous negative impacts on the economies of the ACP countries, so I think a new type of partnership, just and equal, respecting the sovereignty of countries and promoting the development of countries' productive capacities, protecting traditional agriculture and combating land grabbing , and overexploitation, as long as it also has legal mechanisms to combat labour exploitation, modern slavery, the illicit flow of capital and the financing of terrorism and armed conflict. I also think it is important to stress the importance of ending foreign interference in the internal affairs of the ACP countries, as well as the end of neocolonial policies and the dismantling of all foreign military bases. However, this report does not propose any of these changes which I consider fundamental to the future of EU-ACP relations following the end of the Cotonou agreement in 2020, so my vote went against this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. Since 2000, the Cotonou Agreement has provided the framework for development finance cooperation, economic and trade cooperation and political dialogue between the 28 Member States of the European Union (EU) and 78 African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries. As this agreement expires in February 2020, it is necessary to define a new partnership taking into account the results achieved and the shortcomings of the agreement.  ACP-EU relations have developed substantially over the past two decades. However, it is necessary to improve the effectiveness of cooperation and adapt it to the new international challenges that have an impact at all levels in the Member States of the European Union and in the ACP States such as, for example, climate change, water, energy and food security, migration, health, security and financial issues.  I voted in favour of this report, which is an excellent starting point for future discussions on the future post-Cotonou Agreement. In particular, I welcome the emphasis in the report on the key role that the private sector can play in the development process and the importance of creating a favourable environment for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises under the new partnership.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as this is the EU trying to expand their influence.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because it contains very important recommendations and guidelines for the future relationship between the EU and the ACP countries after 2020, the year in which the Cotonou agreement ends. The European Parliament is in favour of a legally binding general framework agreement, complemented by regional agreements adapted to specific needs. The report advocates a partnership agreement focused on sustainable development and the promotion of human rights, with robust monitoring mechanisms, including effective participation of parliaments, local authorities and civil society. As for the economic pillar, regional economic partnership agreements - instruments aimed at fostering the progressive integration of ACP countries into the world economy - should become an important part of the post-Cotonou relationship. As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade, I insisted in particular on strengthening the technical capacity of acp countries and on the appropriate union funding for aid for trade programmes. EU-ACP cooperation is a valuable, unique achievement, and the post-Cotonou framework must continue and strengthen this partnership through a legally binding agreement at the service of development.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted for the report on the future of ACP-EU relations beyond 2020. It calls for breaking down the ACP into regional blocs whilst maintaining the CAP as an umbrella organisation, and for the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to be incorporated as the guiding aim of development cooperation between the EU-ACP amongst the other measures concerning cooperation between the ACP-EU.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, was signed in Cotonou as early as 2000. It was revised in 2005 and 2010. The Objective of the Cotonou Agreement was to reduce and definitively eradicate poverty, in line with the objective of sustainable development and the gradual integration of the ACP countries into the world economy. This Agreement expires in 2020. This resolution maps the current situation in 3 areas: political dialogue, development aid and economic and trade cooperation. At the same time, it emphasises the principle of private ownership and the importance of private investment (SMEs) in the future. For these reasons, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider cooperation between the ACP/African, Caribbean and Pacific/ and EU countries to be a unique achievement that has strengthened ties between ACP nations and countries and EU Member States and their parliaments over the last 40 years. Although a partnership agreement has been concluded with the governments of the ACP countries to improve the overall performance of their economies, it regrets that the existing ACP-EU cooperation has not yet produced the expected results. I believe that, in order to improve the effectiveness of cooperation, we must adapt it to new challenges and areas of common interest where common benefits can be expected, not only in terms of economic aspects, but also in terms of peace and security, human rights and the rule of law, good governance and democracy, migration, the environment, climate change, but also other areas relating to the prosperity of the inhabitants of the ACP-EU countries. I believe that, under the new agreement, there will be a better political dialogue between the partners of the agreement, which has not yet been sufficiently exploited. As half of the ACP Member States are still among the least developed countries in the world and the ACP Member States together account for less than 5% of world trade and roughly 2% of world GDP, I expect that poverty will be significantly eradicated and the ACP countries integrated into the world economy.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The report deals with the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part. It is the broadest partnership agreement between developed and developing countries in the world, which expires in 2020. For this reason, this report advocates the continuation of this agreement under a new structure, which, according to the report's guidelines, is simply too ambitious. The African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries does not function from a decision-making point of view, as decisions must be taken unanimously, which rarely happens. Also, from a political point of view, this group exists almost only because of EU funding, political dialogue between the group countries is often very limited, and the partnership between the EU and the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States is unbalanced, as the EU can act on this group of countries because of its political coherence with pressure. We in the Green Group are therefore working towards a more open approach to partnership. It would also be a good idea to consider replacing the existing agreement with individual agreements between the EU and each of the three regions involved. For all the reasons listed above, I did not support the report.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. \u2012 In 2020, the Cotonou Partnership Agreement between the EU and the African, Caribbean and South Pacific countries (ACP countries) will expire. This is the world's largest partnership between developed and developing countries and relations have existed since the 1960s. The report to the vote sets out the European Parliament's vision for the future of this agreement beyond 2020. The decision was made to continue the Cotonou Agreement with a new structure that preserves universal issues such as human rights and gender equality, development and democracy in a common framework, while the work will have to be done in regional agreements.  Although the Greens value the Cotonou Agreement for the sake of development policy and binding standards on democracy, human rights and the rule of law, they consider there to be serious shortcomings: among other things, the (non-)functioning of the ACP group in decision-making, the systematic lack of respect of many ACP states for general values and irregular funding. Because of these shortcomings, we would have liked to have seen with the Greens a more open approach that includes the option of replacing ACP-EU relations with direct relations between the EU and the three ACP regions separately. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important that the European Union maintains close relations with the African, Pacific and Caribbean states, including the provision of development aid. Given that these include countries that are sources of mass migration (Africa) or the seats of firms involved in tax fraud schemes, we must always make this aid subject to legislative and economic reforms.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament resolution on the future of relations between the ACP countries and the EU after 2020. ACP countries are the group of States in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. The report concerns foreign policy competences that are wrongly assigned to the EU rather than to the Member States.  I think most forms of development aid are wrong. It has been shown to benefit above all the people who are connected to the government in certain ways, thereby cementing adverse anti-market structures. Development aid is only a small part of the support for those for whom it is intended. The report also contains statements on an EU economic and trade partnership with the ACP countries. The EU should not regulate Member States' trade – this is also better located in the national competence framework. Finally, I am also opposed to the report because it calls for gender equality, because cooperation should also take place on climate change and, above all, because the new cooperation agreement provides for a Joint Parliamentary Assembly (JPA), which would create or deepen a completely out-of-place parliamentary dimension within the framework of a partnership agreement.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. The Partnership Agreement between the Members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Countries Group on the one hand and the European Union and its Member States, on the other hand, signed in Cotonou in June 2000, focuses on development, political, economic and trade cooperation with the common institutional framework and a large budget through the European Development Fund. Given that more than 80% of the world's least developed countries are in the ACP regions, the need to eradicate poverty and gradual integration of the ACP into the global economy is further emphasised. Establishing as effective a cooperation framework as possible is important with the aim of promoting strategic interests and common partner values while respecting human rights and fostering sustainable development. It is also important to emphasise the inclusion of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development in the revision of the EU-ACP cooperation framework. I support the Development Committee's report on the future of the ACP-EU relationship after 2020.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020. Cooperation between African, Caribbean and Pacific countries has so far proved to be very welcome and necessary. Partnership is fundamental to basic values and principles such as respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, democracy based on the principles of the rule of law, and transparent and responsible governance. I support the opinion of the Committee on Budgets, which points out that the European Development Fund is finally included in the budget, but only with clear guarantees for the dedicated allocation of funds for ACP-EU cooperation and the maintenance of the level of funding.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The ESA/BPA has set as its principle the equal and fair negotiation between the ACP and the EU for the continuation of its relations. Unfortunately, the two major groups in Parliament have called for the commercial and financial interests of large companies. Among other things, they supported free trade agreements which would subdue the peoples of the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries, as did all free trade agreements. At the same time, the ESA/BPA's proposals for integrated and sustainable development policies by strengthening the labour and democratic rights of all citizens have not been heeded. For the above reasons we voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. This report is a covert form of neo-colonial policy, with direct interventions in the internal affairs of third countries. The Union, promising economic exchanges, exercises cultural imperialism in an attempt to impose its own values, which it has the vanity to regard as universal.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report and the proposals made thereon, appreciing the new foundations for cooperation with the 79 partner countries under the Cotonou Convention, which is already expiring in 2020. I consider that the report contains realistic proposals for a new, more effective framework for cooperation, taking into account both the EU's unified action and the differences between the situations of the partners. I think it is important that, in changing circumstances, particular attention is paid to the effects of climate change and to mass impoverishment, as well as to phenomena closely related to the global migration crisis. I am convinced that in the coming years the Union and its Member States will need to engage in even broader and deeper consultation and cooperation with these important partners.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The Cotonou Partnership Agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries and the European Union needs to be reformed to make it a more effective and challenging platform for cooperation in the 21st century. There is no doubt that, 40 years after the Cotonou Agreement was signed, existing EU-ACP cooperation has not produced the expected results, especially compared to other partnership agreements to which the EU is a party. It is therefore necessary, first of all, to carry out an analysis of the effectiveness of the existing Cotonou Partnership Agreement, the results of which should form the basis for further action. The EP report rightly emphasises that the partnership should be based on a political and economic project and not on a donor-beneficiary relationship. Furthermore, it has been pointed out that economic partnership agreements are a necessary development element for these regions and at the same time benefit European businesses and citizens.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 The Cotonou Agreement signed in 2000 expires in 2020. The aim of the agreement is to promote sustainable development and poverty reduction in african, Caribbean and Pacific countries and to support their integration into the world economy. I voted in favour of this report because cooperation must continue and the terms of the agreement updated.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's relations with the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries have consistently been at a very good level in recent decades. The EU is the main source of development aid for these countries, a position that gives it an extremely important role in supporting the positive development of those countries. However, their position is still quite difficult today, which calls for a new agreement to highlight the 2030 Agenda and The Sustainable Development Goals (ODS). This new agreement should include a mechanism for regular monitoring, accountability and peer review, planning knowledge-based policies, measures to eradicate poverty and inequalities, coherence of development policies (CPD), protection of human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law, appropriate measures in the event of serious corruption situations, political dialogue, strengthening local and regional authorities, support for minorities young people and women, but also the private sector of the economy. To this end, new cooperation institutions are expected to be established, in addition to the ACP-EU Council, such as the Joint Parliamentary Assembly (APP), the APP Office, the APP Commission. I support this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. With this text, we affirm that ACP-EU cooperation is a valuable and unique achievement that has strengthened the links between the people of the ACP states and the Union and between their respective parliaments over the past forty years. We also wanted to emphasize that both the common framework and regional agreements should be legally binding. Finally, we call for the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to be placed at the centre of the new agreement, and for strong monitoring mechanisms to be put in place to ensure that the implementation of the agreement contributes to the achievement of the SDGs and their promotion.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The Cotonou Agreement (2000) aims to reduce and eventually eradicate poverty through the promotion of sustainable development and the gradual integration of the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries into the world economy. The EU-ACP partnership is based on a set of basic values and principles, including respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, democracy based on the rule of law, and transparent and accountable governance. As of recently, the agreement has come to require a revision and reassessment of the long-standing partnership in order to have it better serve its purpose of regional development. I voted in favour of the revision of the ACP-EU agreement because I believe the partnership must now evolve from the donor-recipient mentality, which has not encouraged the full potential of development in the ACP community, to a more mutual political partnership based on sustainable shared cooperation among and between ACP members, providing greater independence from the EU.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I agree that cooperation between ACP countries and the EU is a valuable and unique achievement that has strengthened ties between ACP countries and the EU and their parliaments over the past 40 years. This agreement is also the most comprehensive agreement between developing countries and the European Union, covering 79 countries in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. As the agreement expires in 2020, the main task of this report was to redefine relations between the European Union and those countries, all with a view to improving efficiency and cooperation to facilitate adaptation to new challenges. In this regard, the rapporteur cites three segments as crucial - political dialogue, development support and economic and trade cooperation. While I support the efforts of rapporteurs to eradicate the donor-recipient mentality, I cannot agree with calls to emphasise the importance of legally binding sustainability provisions and calls for non-threat to development aid for beneficiaries of the same and the reliance of migration initiatives solely on fresh resources, as I consider this neither realistic nor proportionate. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020. ACP-EU cooperation is a valuable and unique achievement that over the last 40 years has strengthened ties between the nations, countries and the ACP-EU parliaments.
