The ACP countries have clearly demonstrated their desire to take joint action, stressing that a new structure is urgently needed to work more effectively together and adapt to new challenges, preserving those parts of the ACP-EU acquis that are universal in nature, such as commitment to human rights and gender equality, human development, good governance and democracy, fulfilling the principles of the rule of law and exchanging best practices in a common framework , while the bulk of the work has to be carried out in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, which means that it must be done through regional agreements adapted to specific regional needs and the mutual interests of the EU and individual regions.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution as we believe that it does not reflect the main current challenges of EU-ACP relations. We believe that the post-Cotonou process should provide a fair and balanced framework between equal partners in which to discuss, among other important issues, fair trade issues with all ACP countries, but bearing in mind that trade liberalization is not in itself positive for sustainable development. I reject that there is no call in the resolution to create any binding instrument to identify private sector responsibilities for human rights violations and impunity of transnational corporations. In addition, I stress the importance of respecting, as indicated in SDG 17.15, the sovereignty of the associated countries and that they have a democratic political space to regulate and make decisions for the dignity of their people, a principle not reflected in the resolution.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has and should continue to take the lead and great responsibility with the ACP. This report, calls for the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to be placed at the centre of a new agreement, and for the creation of strong monitoring mechanisms to ensure that implementation of the agreement contributes to and promotes the SDGs. It calls for an ACP-EU peer monitoring, accountability and review mechanism to scrutinise SDG implementation in Member States on a regular basis. Calls for the fight against, and ultimate eradication of, poverty and inequalities and the promotion of sustainable development to be the overarching objectives of ACP-EU cooperation. The EU can only gain from fighting the root causes of many phenomena that affect all of us.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. It is a question of the European Union continuing what it sees as the progress of the Cotonou reports. It should be remembered that the Cotonou agreements are based on three pillars (development, trade relations and political dialogue). The Union does not have to have diplomacy in any form and it must be remembered that the Cotonou agreements were a disaster for Africa. Indeed, by substituting a progressive free trade system for the paternalistic system in which the countries of the North agreed to pay more tariffs to enable the accelerated development of this area, the Cotonou agreements participated with other factors such as the policy of international institutions to delay the creation of African industries protected by high tariffs. , which was France's objective with the cooperation project. Why refuse the natural organic democracy of African countries instead of practising an imperialism of values that is no longer up to date and which is a sinister farce? Finally, we can only be surprised at the lessons that the EU allows itself in this text to give on corruption. I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The Partnership Agreement, signed in 2000 in Cotonou, governs the cooperation of 79 African, Caribbean and Pacific developing countries with the European Union. The agreement expires in 2020, forcing the establishment of a new legal framework for the EU's relations with these countries. The resolution voted sets out future relations in three main areas: political dialogue, development support and economic and trade cooperation. I agree that combating poverty and inequality remains an important objective of ACP-EU cooperation, as well as promoting sustainable development with respect for the environment. 16 years after the cotonou agreement was signed, the development of a new framework for relations with developing countries requires reflection. We should break with the donor-beneficiary relationship. It should be taken into account that the political situation in the ACP countries has changed significantly since 2000. Since the beginning of the century, little has been achieved together in terms of global security m.in. challenges, and the low effectiveness of the ACP-EU joint institutions, which have not achieved concrete results, has been a problem. Financing further cooperation is also an important issue that needs to be rethoughmed. I doubt that the proposal for a future relationship presented in the report responds to these needs. I therefore abstained.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 AKCS-EU cooperation is a valuable and unique achievement that has strengthened relations between the ACCS and the eu's peoples, member states and parliaments over the past 40 years; stresses that, in the light of the ACP countries' commitment to joint action as a group, a new structure should be adopted in order to increase the effectiveness of cooperation and adapt it to new challenges, which puts together universal parts of the ACP-EU acquis in their nature, such as human rights, gender equality, human development, commitment to good governance and democracy, the objective of implementing the rule of law and the exchange of best practices. , while the most important activities should be carried out in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, i.e. through regional agreements adapted to specific regional needs and the common interests of the EU and the region in particular. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution as we believe that it does not reflect the main current challenges of EU-ACP relations. We believe that the post-Cotonou process should provide a fair and balanced framework between equal partners in which to discuss, among other important issues, fair trade issues with all ACP countries, but bearing in mind that trade liberalization is not in itself positive for sustainable development. I reject that there is no call in the resolution to create any binding instrument to identify private sector responsibilities for human rights violations and impunity of transnational corporations. In addition, I stress the importance of respecting, as indicated in SDG 17.15, the sovereignty of the associated countries and that they have a democratic political space to regulate and make decisions for the dignity of their people, a principle not reflected in the resolution.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I opposed this report because I had wished for a more open approach as concerns the different options for post-Cotonou, including the approach of abandoning EU-ACP cooperation for direct cooperation with each of the three ACP subregions: Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I believe that, while strong political alliances based on common interests and values should continue to be at the heart of the ACP Partnership, further cooperation on global issues should be strengthened and appropriate mechanisms developed to address global challenges such as climate change, water, energy and food security, migration flows, terrorism, extremism, international crime, biodiversity, health and financial problems more effectively.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the future of ACP-EU relations beyond 2020. The overarching objective of the Cotonou Agreement is reducing and eventually eradicating poverty, consistent with the objectives of sustainable development and the gradual integration of the ACP countries into the world economy. Over 80% of the world’s least developed countries (LDCs) are from ACP regions, which gives particular relevance to the EU-ACP partnership. However, the numerical strength of the ACP and EU Member States has not sufficiently translated into joint action in global fora.  The report underlines that ACP-EU cooperation is a valuable and unique achievement that has strengthened bonds between ACP and EU peoples and countries and their parliaments throughout the last 40 years. It equally emphasises that the future of ACP-EU relations should be based on a new reflection on the potential and obstacles ahead for EU-ACP cooperation.  I voted in favour because I believe that in order to improve the effectiveness of cooperation and adapt it to new challenges, a new structure must be adopted that maintains those parts of the ACP-EU acquis that are universal in nature, such as a commitment to human rights and gender equality, human development, good governance and democracy.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. This report aims to establish what the relationship between the Union and the african, Caribbean and Pacific countries should look like after 2020. It should be noted that partnership agreements have always had numerous negative impacts on the economies of the ACP countries, so I think a new type of partnership, just and equal, respecting the sovereignty of countries and promoting the development of countries' productive capacities, protecting traditional agriculture and combating land grabbing , and overexploitation, as long as it also has legal mechanisms to combat labour exploitation, modern slavery, the illicit flow of capital and the financing of terrorism and armed conflict. I also think it is important to stress the importance of ending foreign interference in the internal affairs of the ACP countries, as well as the end of neocolonial policies and the dismantling of all foreign military bases. However, this report does not propose any of these changes which I consider fundamental to the future of EU-ACP relations following the end of the Cotonou agreement in 2020, so my vote went against this report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ With my Socialist colleagues, I supported this report because cooperation between EU and ACP should be maintained as it is a valuable tool for encouraging a large number of countries to work together in international development. The new approach of regionalisation gives more flexibility to have tailor-made cooperation between smaller groups of countries. And finally, the human rights perspective will also be given more visibility and better enforcement through a biennial reporting mechanism.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I wholeheartedly agreed with the report. It confirms that ACP-EU cooperation is a valuable and unique achievement that has strengthened the links between the ACP and EU peoples and countries and their parliaments over the last 40 years. Now that the cooperation agreement, after 40 years, had expired, we decided to extend it. Regional cooperation brings progress and prosperity to all parties. ACP: countries from Africa, Caribbean and the Pacific

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020, which provides a good starting point for future negotiations. Positions should not be closed too early, but the best possible form of future cooperation must be sought. It will take its final form during the negotiations.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The Cotonou Agreement "manages" cooperation relations between the EU and its 28 Member States and 79 African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries. The Cotonou agreement was signed on 23 June 2000 for a period of 20 years and can be revised every five years.  The revision of the Cotonou Agreements should promote an inflection in the European Union's policy of cooperation and development assistance. This policy should be geared towards genuine cooperation and solidarity and contribute to promoting the autonomous and sovereign development of acp countries.  There are multiple mechanisms that today keep many of these countries under relations of domination and subjugation. The stifling external debt, which is repeatedly paid and nevertheless ever increasing, plays a central role in establishing this type of relationship.  This report maintains the same line of neocolonialism that we cannot accept.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The resolution deals with the reorientation of the European Union's relations with the ACP Group countries (Cotonou Agreements). The record so far is sobering. Until now, the only consensus between the EU and the ACP was that the political and economic integration of the ACP regions must be promoted. However, there was disagreement about the way in which the poverty reduction objective should be achieved. The future use of the same instruments in relations with the ACP States can therefore have only a limited impact on their development. I have therefore abstained from voting.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is a global leader of the sustainable development agenda, and the relationship between the EU and the ACP countries is a cornerstone of that agenda. That relationship must be based on promoting fair and equitable trade, as advocated in the Alternative Trade Mandate. Relations with ACP countries must put people and planet first, setting out a common agenda on human rights, democracy and the rule of law, as well as empowerment of women and young people.  I would especially like to emphasise the importance of youth participation and empowerment, particularly of women and girls. The existing agreement stipulates cooperation to help children and young people fulfil their potential, and I would like to see those commitments strengthened post-2020.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The report maintains the Cotonou acquis, i.e. a legally binding agreement based on three pillars: political dialogue, cooperation and trade. It examines a number of possible developments, such as more regionalization, the EDF budget, strengthening political dialogue and greater participation of civil society and the private sector. It calls for the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to be placed at the heart of a new agreement to ensure that the fight against poverty remains a primary objective of ACP-EU cooperation.  It reiterates its call for a guaranteed delimitation of the development of funds to maintain the level of funding and a permanent solution for the financing of security expenditure, related to EU development cooperation. It reiterates that economic partnership agreements provide a basis for regional cooperation and should be instruments for development and integration. That is why my vote is in favour of this report, as Spain is in favour of maintaining the geographical areas of the GPA and of preserving and improving the existing legal framework.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the report effectively and effectively addresses the future of the partnership between the EU and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States. The relationship must adapt to the political, structural and demographic changes that have taken place over the last decades. I fully agree that the basis of the new agreement should be an emphasis on sustainable development and political dialogue, which should be actively and systematically used to prevent political crises in the ACP region.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the future of relations between the European Union and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States after 2020. At present, relations with 79 countries, most of which are among the least developed states in the world, are governed by the Cotonou Agreement, which deals with new global challenges, including climate change, migration or the terrorist threat. However, this agreement will expire in 2019. The report highlighted the unique success of mutual cooperation, as well as confirmed that the main objectives will continue to be to combat poverty and promote sustainable development even after the end of the Cotonou Agreement. It also calls for the essential elements of the Cotonou Agreement in the area of respect for human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law to form the value basis of the new agreement. Compared to the Cotonou Agreement, the resolution also proposes new elements that will allow the new agreement to reflect the changed situation, particularly in the area of abandonment of the donor-recipient approach. In addition to these aspects, it also deals with financing, the system of institutions, but also business aspects. I believe that if the new post-2020 agreement can meet the expectations expressed in this report, it will become a beneficial tool for deepening relations between the European Union and the ACP States.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Neuser report which paves the way for strengthening the future of ACP-EU relations. I would remind you that this report is the contribution of the European Parliament which will follow up on the Cotonou International Agreement, which was launched in 2000 and which expires in 2020. In fact, in the last 40 years, the ACP countries and the EU have achieved valuable and unique cooperation through this instrument which has strengthened the links between these peoples. In terms of the process, it is worth noting the willingness of the ACP countries to take joint action as a group, an essential approach to improving the effectiveness of international cooperation, adapting it to new challenges. In terms of content, I would argue that the post-2020 relationship should retain the parts of the ACP-EU acquis that are universal in nature, such as commitment to human rights and gender equality, human development, good governance and democracy. In this context, I also point out that post-2020 relations should be guided by ensuring the strengthening of the representation of civil society in all cooperation processes.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the report on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020. As the report states, ACP-EU cooperation is a valuable and unique achievement that has strengthened ties between the nations, countries and the ACP-EU parliaments over the last 40 years. I therefore believe that future relations between the EU and the ACP countries must adapt to the political, structural and demographic changes of recent years in order to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals on a larger scale and to effectively eliminate poverty.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: – That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: – Madam President, I would like to object, based on Rule 192 of the Rules of Procedure. In respect of minutes for 3 October, I did not agree to be replaced by Catherine Bearder in the Committee on Internal Market and Consumer Protection.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Guoga, we take note of your comments and the relevant service will deal with that in due course. (The Minutes of the previous sitting were approved)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the macroeconomic situation in Greece, structural reforms and their impact, as well as prospects for future negotiations within the Programme (2016/2883(RSP)).

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to be able to debate in plenary session with you on this important subject, which I have had the opportunity to discuss regularly with the working group set up a few months ago in the European Parliament. Let me start with some news that I would describe as rather reassuring, on the economic front in Greece. The country grew by 0.2% in the second quarter, and we expect this trend to continue, so overall growth is expected to remain slightly negative in 2016. But, as I had already announced, the second half of the year is going to be a slightly positive growth semester and this trend is expected to strengthen significantly next year. It is too early to give accurate forecasts; it will be done in a few weeks. This is the autumn forecast for the whole of Europe and the euro area. Disbursements under the programme should, in fact, help to ensure the liquidity necessary for the recovery of economic activity and therefore, our forecast is rather strengthened. On the fiscal front, this year's developments have also been rather encouraging. Based on the data we have on the implementation of the 2016 budget, achieving the target of a primary surplus of 0.5% of GDP should be feasible for Athens in 2016. So we can say that what we have put on track is moving forward positively.  I now turn, more specifically, to the negotiations related to the adjustment programme. There are three points to be noted with regard to the developments of recent months. Firstly, the first revision of the programme partially concluded, as you remember, in the spring, which allowed the Eurogroup of 25 May, which I believe will remain an important date, to mark its political agreement on a further disbursement of EUR 10.3 billion. I am very happy about that. A first sub-slice of 7.5 billion euros, the main one, was paid in June. Part of the second sub-slice, which amounts to EUR 1.1 billion, is conditional on the adoption of a series of milestones which is expected to be completed this week; I'll come back to it, of course. The other part of the second sub-slice, therefore the remaining EUR 1.7 billion, must be used to reduce the arrears of payment of the State for the benefit of suppliers or subcontractors and therefore, in reality, the real economy. So much for the first point. Second, major legislative initiatives were taken in virtually every area of the economy, and that is what was provided for under the MOU, which is our shared benchmark. The government has adopted measures to allow budget savings of 3% of GDP over the period 2016-2018, including income tax reform for 1% of GDP and a major reform of the pension system for 1% of GDP as well. To improve tax collection, a new independent agency for the collection of public revenues has been established. That was something we cared about substantially. It was not the easiest to get, but it is now done. These measures have been accompanied by significant structural reforms. In particular, they concern non-performing loans to restore what is essential to the stability of the banking system in order to boost the financing of companies. Measures have also been taken to improve the business environment, including the implementation of OECD-recommended competition measures. Legislative initiatives have been adopted on land use, liberalisation of the energy market, the establishment of a new privatization and investment fund to combat corruption, another major point of the Memorandum of Understanding adopted in July 2015. We also wanted to strengthen the independence of the Commission and the lines of competition to depoliticize public administration. All of this is an extremely strong set of measures.  It is true, it must be said, that no Member State is conducting so many parallel reforms. It is true that no Member State needs to carry out so many reforms simultaneously. The Eurogroup as a whole expressed its satisfaction that Greece is moving in the right direction. Of course, I want to do this, too, on behalf of the Commission. Finally, third and final point, we are currently assessing progress on the last milestones that I have mentioned, which are the condition for the disbursement of the first remaining substalment of the programme and, therefore, also the second. Measures should have been taken by mid-September pension reform, bank governance, energy market liberalization and privatization and the independent public revenue agency. It is therefore a question of finalising these reforms, which are already adopted in principle. After a relatively slow start, it must be said - slowness which we have attributed to the summer break - the Greek authorities have accelerated the movement since the beginning of September and, sincerely, I hope that we can conclude on this point at the Eurogroup on 10 October. That is to say that there are very few days left to conclude. We are the 5th, there are also, in parallel, the general meetings of the International Monetary Fund, which will be held from tomorrow. I therefore take this opportunity to appeal to the Greek government. It is of paramount importance that we can conclude on this point by Monday, the date of the Eurogroup in Luxembourg. I am now moving on to the next steps. The challenge after that, because I intend it to be done, will be to initiate and conclude the second review of the program within a reasonable time. This reasonable period of time for me - I have said it several times, to Prime Minister Tsipras, to Minister Tsakalotos, to the other ministers in the economic fields - is November. The success of this revision is essential at a time when the Greek economy is showing signs of recovery. We are not making reforms for fun, we are making reforms to get the Greek economy back on track, to make the structure of this economy more efficient, to recreate the confidence that is essential for attractiveness and therefore for the return of investors, because it is an open economy that needs investment. Therefore, there is a win-win situation. This is a positive step that needs to be concluded.  A conclusion within the expected timeframe, I would remind you of this long-awaited economic normality for investors, I would remind us of this long-awaited economic normality. A mission will therefore begin in Greece in mid-October. Our goal remains to conclude the whole by the end of the year. What will be the second revision? It will focus on implementing the reforms adopted. It can therefore be considered that with the end of the first, the biggest will have been done but, as they say in French, the devil sometimes hides in the details.  That is why the second revision will not be easy. Key issues will include the 2017 budget, the framework for business insolvency, labour market reform and the establishment of this famous privatisation and investment fund, which is really a key to unlocking the Greek economy.  It must be acknowledged that over the years - and this is not the government's own, it has been a constant for quite a long time - implementation has been the weak point of previous Greek adjustment programmes. The Commission's approach will be fair, objective and, you feel, positive. I claim that this Commission has always been hostile to the prospect of a Grexit and always in favour of finding solutions. But at the same time, the fact that we are positive does not mean that we are over-volunteering or over-indulgent. We are demanding with the Greek authorities. All departments will have to demonstrate a full commitment to the program to ensure the success of the reforms we have adopted, and the feeling we can have is that this is not necessarily always the case. There are a few head departments moving forward and a few others, which sometimes seem useful to push them to move faster.  It is time for the European side- because we must not be merely demanding with the Greek side - all of us and the partners who are included in the Eurogroup are shouldering their responsibilities by specifying short-term debt measures. I know that this is highly anticipated in Greece, and I find this perfectly legitimate once the work on the reforms has been done and completed. It is also time for the program to move more strongly towards growth and employment. The government, as I know, is developing a growth strategy for the coming years. It will have to be supplemented with social measures and we are also aware of that. The program includes the roll-out of the Guaranteed Minimum Income Mechanism next year. If this is done within the financial balances provided for by the MOU, I think we can all consider that combining social justice with investment and reform is a good policy. The Commission is also doing everything it can to mobilise the Funds European. Our services provide technical assistance to support structural reforms. The commitment of the authorities to ensure the implementation of funded projects, to avoid irregularities and to make better use of technical assistance remains of paramount importance. That, in a matter of minutes, is the state of affairs, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. You see that we are moving forward, you see that we have come out of the period of great difficulty when The Grexit was threatening, but you also see that the work on reforms must continue to move forward so that what was and what is still a problem, a difficulty, not only for Greece but for Europe, turns into - forgive me this anglicism - success story.  This is really what I want, this is what the Commission is committed to and that is what I, for one, continue to dedicate a good part of my political energy, my political capital because I think that we all really have an interest in Greece coming out of this crisis stronger and finding its place in the euro area , as I had the opportunity to say, as simply a normal economy. The Commission is fully committed to ensuring the success of the programme to help Greece find the path to sustainable growth and the path to job creation. I know that this is what the Greek people expect, this is what the Greek youth expect and beyond, once again, the political sensitivities that we can have on this subject, it is for the population and for the youth that we have a duty to act to offer them a better future.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Thank you for coming and also for this statement on the situation in Greece. I think it is extremely important that we have this debate here today. In my view, it should have come earlier. I would like to remind you that Greece is already in the process of the third economic adjustment programme, and I think the expectation is clear: the Greek Government must press ahead with reforms of its own will, with the aim of putting Greece back on the path of growth and jobs in a sustainable way – that is the emphasis on this. Unfortunately, the Tsipras government has all too often shown that it is unable to do so. Reforms that have been adopted on paper are not implemented, and it is certainly not conducive to always blaming the EU institutions or the International Monetary Fund on this. We are at an important stage. Greece already received EUR 7.5 billion in a first payment in June – as you mentioned, Commissioner – although the reforms have been implemented only half-heartedly. The second review is now due, with a second payment of EUR 2.8 billion. The government must finally deliver on this. Eurogroup ministers did not see enough progress in September to give a positive assessment. So the ball is clearly in the Greek field. And this week, too, according to the Eurogroup, there is still no clear progress in implementing the reforms. The Tsipras government is playing with fire. Even if the growth figures for the second quarter appear positive, which is certainly a good sign, more needs to happen. Even if Greece gets the green light for this second payment next week, new challenges are already waiting: the 2017 budget must be presented, and structural reforms must be implemented in one key area, namely the labour market. It is now up to the Eurogroup to assess whether the reform efforts are actually sufficient. I expressed my expectations, Commissioner, and that of my group at the outset: a serious, credible and comprehensive implementation of the agreed reforms. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Peter van DALEN
text: "blue card" question. When I hear Mr Balz, I hear the necessary doubts in his speech. Are the Greeks going to do it? Are they going to make it happen? Are they going to make it happen? Then I ask him my specific question: do you believe in this approach yourself, and why? I immediately put a second question to it: is it not better to make a Grexit and return the Greeks to the drachma, perhaps combining it with a utility in which we partially write off the debts? Isn't that a much better, preferable approach?

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr van Dalen, I would like to thank Mr van Dalen for his excellent work. I believe that what has been agreed must be respected, and the reforms that have been talked about must be implemented. And here – and I have just expressed my doubts about this relatively clearly – the state of affairs is certainly not as it should be. The reforms are hanging in the balance, and I certainly do not agree with the Commissioner on that. Let me be clear: more needs to happen!  The Tsipras government has not delivered so far, and that is why I would have liked to see this discussion much earlier in order to put even more pressure on the Greek Government.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Greek crisis was one of the most difficult, dramatic and important tests for the European Union. The unity and irreversibility of the eurozone has been at risk, while Greek citizens have suffered the harshness of a crisis that has hit them very hard. The consequences of the recession of recent years continue to bite, but today we can finally say that we see light at the end of the tunnel. Greece's membership of the euro area is no longer in question and, after a year marked by better-than-expected results, the estimate of significant growth for 2017 appears realistic, as does the achievement of a primary surplus slightly above the Memorandum of Understanding target.  We must acknowledge the commitment and courage of the Greek Government, which, since the referendum, has been able to make difficult choices and correct its course, saving the country from the abyss and negotiating a demanding programme which has involved painful choices but which contains new elements of social equity that were absent from previous programmes. At the same time, the European Commission must also be acknowledged that it has always opposed Grexit's perspective and has played a valuable role in mediating against certain excessively closed and selfish positions of some creditors. It is now essential not to lose momentum and to take the opportunity for a real breakthrough to the end. First, you must complete the milestones and have the disbursement of the second sub-tranche, so as to start the second review. We know that this review will be demanding and must be carried out in a balanced way, especially in terms of labour market reform. In this context, it would be a good thing if the Monetary Fund were to refrain from throwing petrol on the fire in a delicate budgetary procedure, and to propose further measures which are not necessary. At the same time, creditors need to take seriously not only the implementation of short-term debt relief measures, but also the more concrete definition of medium-term measures. It is clear that, even if the data are better than expected, a prolonged primary surplus of 3.5 does not appear sustainable. We are not asking for an immediate and timely quantification of all these measures and we respect the political needs of some Member States, but this must not be an excuse to avoid giving concrete form to the Conclusions of the Eurogroup and overcoming an ambiguity that would hinder not only the participation of the Monetary Fund in the programme, but also the credibility of the recovery prospects for Greece and the possibility of finally associating Greece with the ECB's QE. This Parliament will continue its role of monitoring and enriching the democratic dimension of economic adjustment programmes for Greece and for the Union as a whole.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, there is no doubt that, for the seven years that have been in the Memorandums, the Greek people have really been being tested and are paying the cost of the wrong policies that have been implemented in particular in recent years. So while these people continue to be under pressure from both the memorandum and the harsh measures, we are simply taking on theoretical concerns without suggesting anything specific to finally get the Greek people out of the tunnel in which they are today. Is this issue only theoretical? Are there no concrete measures and solutions that we can propose? I note that Cyprus, within three years, managed to get out of the memorandum while the Greek people are still being tested.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I did not quite understand. Frankly, more than a question seemed to me a respectable statement but not acceptable. I firmly believe in Greece's growth and development prospects in the euro area and we must, on the one hand, encourage reforms and, on the other, support a policy of investment growth and social equity in Greece and throughout the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, more than six years of implementation of the Memorandum have already been completed in Greece and the country has become a vast social graveyard, since the hundreds of billions of euros given as loans have finally returned to the pockets of lenders, rather than being invested in the Greek economy. So it has been six stone memorial years in which the Greek people experience poverty every day, poverty, unemployment and national humiliation, six stone memorial years of failed troika policy and international loan sharks - a policy that reduced GDP by 25% and in absolute terms by EUR 47 billion or more, which devastated the economy, filled Greece with armies of millions of poor and unemployed and created caravans of young people who are massively migrating , which made a tax resalto in the pockets and fortunes of the poor Greeks, who socialized the losses of the banks, cut the reserves of insurance funds, cut salaries and pensions, led 40% of the Greek population to live below the poverty line.  This is, Mr Moscovici, your policy, the callous policy of the troika, a policy which, instead of reducing the debt, has skyrocketed it. It was at 123% of GDP in 2010 - at 200% it will arrive in 2016. It is a policy that encapsulates, rather than repays, the profits of the ECB and the central banks, a policy that denies the haircut of Greek debt when the European Union does so in the case of Ukraine and Tunisia, a policy that mortgages for a century and sells off, through the occupying fund, public property and hammers the homes of the Greeks , giving them to the crows. This policy has been served for the last six years by all the memorial governments, this policy is imposed by force, as the Tsipras government did yesterday against pensioners. That's enough, Mr Moscovici! The Greek people can no longer stand poverty and unemployment and will soon throw the troika and lenders out of Greece. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, dear colleagues, you know that I appreciate you very much, but do you not think that, before the disbursement of loans that is going to take place in October, the Greek Government,  even though it probably does not have the necessary time, should nevertheless reach certain outcomes, if only in the fields of privatisation, pensions, and banking governance and in the energy sector?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, it seems that you have not understood what is happening in Greece. Greece has so far typically taken out loans of more than 240 billion euros. If this money had been invested in the Greek economy, it would have taken off. We wouldn't have 1.5 million unemployed, we wouldn't have the poor, we wouldn't have a state of disintegration of the country. That's the central question: where did the loans go? They went back to the lenders themselves! Only 4% was invested in the Greek economy. So the problem with the troika's recipes is not solved.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, the relationship between Greece and the eurozone is a chronicle of a huge mess. Beyond the hypocrisies, it is the consequence of the absence of a European government. Having admitted Greece, the Eurogroup should have watched it like milk on fire, but this was the time when Germany and France were breaking with impunity the rules of co-ownership of the euro, the stability and growth pact. In 2009, we took the measure of the disaster and found that, if Greece was over-indebted, its main creditors were domiciled in the euro area. No one has been asked to provide Athens with public works and equipment, weapons systems and other expensive supplies. For its part, Greece has abandoned itself to the facility, taking advantage of European aid and the sudden drop in interest rates on abysmal debt and giving free rein to corruption and clientelism. So let's agree that responsibility is widely shared. These angry cases cannot remain in democratic hiding any longer. We must put them in the public square if we want to move the lines and bring down the smokescreens erected in the name of respect for national sovereignty. It is to the credit of the European Parliament that it has taken up this challenge by deciding to set up a working group on financial assistance, made up of European elected representatives responsible for bringing the debate to life as we do today. We went to Greece in March to try to take stock of the third macroeconomic adjustment programme. We also hear regularly from the Commissioners, the representatives of the Court of Auditors, the European Investment Bank, the European Financial Stability Mechanism and the International Monetary Fund, but more needs to be done. Ladies and gentlemen, the next step is to write a comprehensive and uncompromising report on the state of Greece, which ignores political considerations. The elected official who will be in charge of this Report of the European Parliament must work closely with the Greek parliamentarians so that European and national parliamentarians can knead the budgetary dough together. Control of the bailout can no longer be left to the finance ministers meeting in the Eurogroup, who, since the creation of the euro, have erected opacity and mutual complacency as a golden rule. That is to say whether the Vigilance and diligence of the Commission is vital, but only the pressure of the representatives of the other European peoples who have the euro as their currency will help our Greek friends to carry out the reforms and to put in place the necessary pedagogy with their public opinion. A European currency calls for genuine European democratic governance. The crises in Europe, and in particular the euro crisis, have given rise to continental public opinion. It is, ladies and gentlemen, our responsibility, as European elected officials and national elected officials, to make us the sounding board for this public opinion in the making and to establish trust.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – To you, Mr Moscovici, who have provided us with encouraging information and messages on the prospects for the recovery of the Greek economy and to you, Mr Balz, who has rushed to attack the Commission, I have to say that, unfortunately for you and for the right-wing party, Greece was not bankrupted by SYRIZA and the Tsipras government but by your Friends of the New Democracy, those who left deficits of 15.5% in 2009 and public debt of 125%. The current government is trying, against difficulties, to bring the country back to growth, to reduce unemployment and to reduce red tape, tax evasion, the client state that your friends have created. But for this to happen, Mr Moscovici, it is not enough just for Greece to abide by the agreement in order to proceed quickly, in November, with the completion of the second evaluation. You lenders must also respect the agreement on Greek government debt relief. I am not only referring to the short-term measures you mentioned to us but also to the medium-term measures agreed in the Eurogroup of 24 May: everything must be implemented. The intention of Mr Schäuble and the German Government to postpone everything on debt and sacrifice themselves on the altar of their own petty political purposes is unacceptable and does not help anyone, not even the Greek people, nor the European joint effort itself. The 27 have an obligation to prove, after Brexit, that they are moving forward together towards growth, against dogmatic austerity that has failed. Do not forget, ladies and gentlemen, that the Greek people, a proud nation, have suffered much more than all the peoples and that we must show them, in works and not in words, that what they are experiencing is not the myth of Sisyphus.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: question "blue card" – Madam President, in order to solve the problem of Greece, we must be honest with ourselves. Greece's crisis was created in the lost 1980s by the populism of that era. Unfortunately, that populism moved to SYRIZA in 2014. If we want to solve the problem, then we need European orientation, parliamentary democracy and a free economy. That is what Mr Papadimoulis must say at the SYRIZA conference in the coming days.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: "blue card" answer. – I thank Mr Kefaloyannis for his statement - since it was not a question, because it allows me to add that, in addition to the great responsibilities of his party, the New Democracy for the bankruptcy of the country, the PASOK governments also have great responsibilities.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, can I just say that there were other requests for blue cards which I refused because of time, so we had one per speaker, and I may at some stage have to restrict the cards altogether.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I think that before we talk about individual aspects, one thing is crucial: that we must also pay some respect to the Greek people, but also to the Greek governments, for what you have done here. And Mr Balz, I appreciate you very much, you know that, but I thought that your speech completely missed this point. It is a disrespectful speech not to acknowledge what has been done in Greece before we rightly talk about implementation deficits.  In fact, there are things in the reforms that we do not like. For example, it is wrong for the privatisation fund to make its decisions in a non-transparent manner. This does not fit with European values. Nor does it fit with European values that there is now a partial privatisation of water. It is good that the Greek Parliament has put up a stop sign for full privatisation together with the Greek courts.  We are also very concerned, Mr Moscovici, about investing in new lignite-fired power stations in Greece. These are dead investments. What we need instead in Greece is a departure for sustainable energy, for energy efficiency. These are the jobs of the future! New lignite-fired power stations are destroying the environment and do not create sustainable jobs.  We too want greater reform efforts, especially when it comes to the fact that the tax system in Greece is still too clientelistic and that many of the tax evaders are not persecuted. Efforts must be made in this area.  I would also like to say one more thing: within the framework of the Troika adaptation programmes, there have been many victims of people who really cannot afford such sacrifices. We have noted with interest that the European Court of Justice has now opened the way for individual actions for damages against the European Commission. Our group has decided to help people who have been personally harmed in this way through European law and to use European law to bring them justice.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I find myself in extreme difficulty and embarrassment today because I am listening, for the umpteenth time in all these years, to the same speeches about solutions, recovery, structural reforms and growth. We are at the paradox, because everything you have proposed so far has been a failure. You do not want to acknowledge it and indeed continue, persevere in your mistakes. I have seen Greece over the past few months and I have seen for my own eyes what the real situation is. We can talk about figures and percentages, but everything becomes extremely superfluous and annoying when poverty is on the corner of every street, when hunger is even what the so-called middle class used to suffer. You have destroyed a people and a nation to save two banks and a single currency. But are you satisfied with your result? Commissioner Moscovici, what does Europe represent to you? Is it more important for families to survive in a dignified manner, for children to stop suffering from hunger, or for the stability of the eurozone to be preserved? Because, in the name of this phantom stability of the eurozone, you have turned the cradle of Europe into a tomb.  Europe has died in Greece and now you want to send your emissaries to collect the ashes of what you destroyed, just like that, to complete the work. Greece should close the door on it, take back its sovereignty and pride, because this European Union has behaved criminally towards it, trampling underfoot the rights and dignity of millions of Greek citizens, but also European citizens.  Greece is the clear picture of the failure of the single currency and of the European Union in which the interests of the strongest count and the weak end up squeezed. We want to overturn all this and the peoples of Europe must be aware that their dignity is worth more than any criminal agreement imposed by Brussels.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Members of the parliamentary majority here, when you set up that euro structure, when you set up the empire of your europhoria, you set up a rigid structure that was known to fall over one day. Because you want to bring countries with very different socio-economic cultures into one structure, you have prevented countries in difficulty, those countries that are facing a shock, with a crisis, with a change, that a currency devaluation would give them once again competitiveness. The rigid construction prevents that and what should you do? You have to force those countries to lower their wages, to lower their prices. In many cases, you are pushing these countries into a repulsive unemployment spiral, and in order to prevent your construction from falling over, we must all believe that things will work out later.  You try to make Greeks, Portuguese, Spanish, italians all Germans or Dutch, but that is not sustainable. That's an illusion. There are really only three possibilities: either you move on to more European Union, with even more neocolonialism as is seen in those countries, or we move towards a peaceful partition of that euro area, a peaceful end to this mistake, or we are heading for a catastrophe. I call for a peaceful end, at least a partial end to this euro area.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, Mr Moscovici, the theatre performance played by the troika in Greece is being led to its last act, to the last instalment of the programme, as the memoranda have now been renamed. For the last six years, of course, European citizens have been manipulated and convinced that the Greeks are not working and that they are wasting the Union's borrowed money. At the same time, the incompetent right-wing, left-wing and centrist co-governments of my country, those who are only interested in the rule of power, have led to poverty and poverty for the Greek people. Half a million young Greek scientists have been forced into migration and, at the same time, the tragic choices of the European institutions have led to the entrapment of millions of illegal immigrants. So if the Greeks do not react, then they will witness the total destruction of the country, since borrowing from the Union and the International Monetary Fund no longer exists and since the country's exit to the markets, if it is done, will be done in bandit terms. At the same time, they must demand the write-off of illegal and repugnant debt. But they must not make the same mistake and show confidence in the systemic, so-called democratic schemes that have destroyed my country but in a nationalist government that is only interested in the recovery, progress and development of Greece.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Moscovici said that we are all interested in Greece being strengthened from this crisis. I believe that it is a common objective of this whole House for Greece to return to the path of growth and, more importantly, to the path of job creation. And, without a doubt, a key factor in achieving this goal is competitiveness. And a key factor in achieving competitiveness is undoubtedly structural reforms. It is the most efficient way to achieve the goal we all have in this House.  Let me use my country, Spain, as an example. It has been one of the most ambitious countries in structural reforms and now grows to 3.2% and creates half a million jobs a year.  Some will be tempted to seek magical solutions, such as debt restructuring. Let's not deceive the Greeks. Debt restructuring will not be able to create a single short-term job.  Without a doubt, we need to look at those factors—as competitiveness used to be—that drive growth. And there are other factors, such as tax hikes, which I very much doubt may be the right way to encourage growth and job creation. Let's be very careful when taking steps that don't go in the right direction.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Greece has made extraordinary efforts in terms of reforms and serious budgetary issues in order to fulfil all of its promises to the European Union. The Hellenic government's record, more than a year after the agreement reached in August 2015, is all the more remarkable given that the country is on the front line of the refugee reception crisis. No reason can be put forward to prevent the release of the new tranche of nearly 2.8 billion euros provided for by the programme. But Greece's debt is unsustainable: it is close to 180% of GDP, despite three successive plans for financial support. That is why even the IMF argued on 23 September for debt relief. This relief is an emergency; it would make realistic the target of a primary budget surplus of 3.5% of GDP in 2018 and, above all, ensure the country's sustainable recovery. There cannot be double standards in terms of each other's political calendar, and I do not understand that some people can say: "That is good, Greece must make the reforms and we will see, after our own elections, whether we can discuss the debt." Grexit could be prevented, but at the cost of tensions, which weakened more than strengthened the European spirit. That is why I believe that these endless discussions justify the need for a new economic governance with, in particular, a budget for the euro area. The awareness around this issue is all the more crucial as Europe is going through a moment of disruption as a result of Brexit, which forces us to clarify our objectives and preserve strategic interests in the negotiations that are taking place. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Tim AKER
text: blue-card question. – Winston Churchill called socialism the equal sharing of miseries. At what point are you willing to concede that the misery the eurozone has created across southern Europe is the point at which it should be dissolved and that the best boost for Greece and southern Europe is to revert back to national currencies? Surely that is the way forward if you want to stop countries leaving the European Union. Britain will not be the first. It will not be the last either, come the revolution.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: "blue card" answer. The UNITED Kingdom has never belonged to the eurozone, so I do not know what we are talking about.  As for Greece, I understand that it is one of the countries of the South, which you mentioned. However, Greece, including under the authority of Mr Tsipras, has committed all its credibility, all its strength, all its capacity for reform and mobilization to remain in the euro zone: there must be a reason for this, and I fully support it.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has It is now six and a half years since the bailout susrescue for Greece began, and I cannot immediately recall a single forecast that would have become a reality since then. What has been proclaimed in order to save Greece has always been much, much more optimistic than what has been achieved. That is why I cannot give much confidence and faith to the words that the Commissioner has now addressed to us. I would like to exemplify what the IMF has always predicted for the development of Greece's debt. And now, in his latest debt sustainability analysis, he is almost completely turning it around, saying that Greece's debt service will by no means be 15% in 2016, as previously predicted, no, it will be 60% of gross domestic product. More than half of the total gross domestic product will be used by debt servicing! And the debt itself tripled in 2016 from the International Monetary Fund's previous forecast. Ladies and gentlemen, we simply have to say that the truth is not being spoken here, that the forecasts are wrong and that it is high time to draw conclusions and to release Greece from the euro – against a debt cut!

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: I have heard the Commissioner and I would like to believe it. I would so much like to believe that all reforms are now being implemented, that realistic budgeting will finally be made for 2017. I would so much like to believe that privatisations are now being carried out. But I have great difficulty with it, because the track record is so bad. Only 15% of the laws that have been adopted have actually been implemented. Greece has dropped from 81st to 86th place on the World Economic Forum's Global Competitive Index. We see that only a very small part of the privatisations has been achieved. And when we see that Infrastructure Minister Spirtzis simply says that he hopes that the privatisation deals will fail, that he says in the Greek Parliament, "oh well those companies are so heavily burdened with debt, nobody wants to buy," then I am very concerned. I can only emphasise once again that the Commissioner must be on top of it, that we must not slacken and that we must continue to increase the pressure to achieve better results in greece's interests.  (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: I saw that you were an advocate of privatisation.  But any privatisations that have taken place in Greece have been done at the behest of the troika. Do you consider privatizing the fact that fourteen regional airports in Greece have been passed into the hands of Germany by a state-owned company... (The President interrupts the speaker because he took the floor by mistake)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: There is a blue-card request from Mr Kouloglou. Will you accept it?

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: "blue card" question. – You insist on talking all the time about the implementation of the agreements. Among those agreed in May was Greek debt relief. But most of the people who have spoken here are like they're amnesia. They don't remember anything about these decisions and agreements. Why double standards, ladies and gentlemen? Why do you not say that the agreements must be implemented not only by the Greek government but also by the troika in order to proceed with debt relief?

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, my view is that agreements must always be honoured, but there was also a follow-up time in these agreements. First certain things have to be realized and then the next one comes into view. So as long as agreements have not been fulfilled at the beginning, of course the sequel will not come.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The longer the troika rules greece, the longer the depression – the longest depression of the post-war period – lasts. Let us be honest with each other: it was not the Greek nurse who was saved, but German and French banks. More than 90% of the bailout money went to debt servicing. Wages have fallen, pensions have fallen; VAT has been increased; child poverty has exploded; Hospitals have collapsed, and state assets are being slashed at rampage prices. The German Fraport even secured the sale of the Greek regional airports by the troika. You call it competition, I call it the usual predatory blackmail. Debt continues to grow, despite completely crazy targets for the budget surplus and ultra-low interest rates. Because you can't service debts if you don't earn income! Exports are stagnating despite wage cuts because Greece is deindustrialized and productivity is too low. The IMF says Greece cannot always borrow new loans to pay off old debts. But the German finance minister wants to deceive the German public. Therefore, there must be no debates on debt before the Bundestag election. The troika even forbids Greece from setting up a German-style development bank. Greece needs, above all, public investment. Wolfgang Münchau wrote in the Financial Times yesterday that there are only two options: a European investment programme or an end to the euro. You decide where the journey goes.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, Greece is trying to get ahead despite the steed of this ignominious memorandum signed last year. I would like to celebrate all the efforts that the Greek Government is making to minimise its impact on many of its areas. I really have some things that Greece is currently being demanded to do that do not go e way in the line of growth improvement, nor employment, or to fight poverty, despite rhetoric. Someone has to explain to me, for example, what aid to the development of the country that you, or the troika, ask you to privatize the companies that manage public water to Greece, when there is a movement throughout Europe that what you are asking for is precisely that water be a public good; there was even a referendum in Thessaloniki a few years ago calling for water to be a public good. Or what helps that one of the three remaining actions to be approved before the next payment is the increase in taxes on renewable energy, which is one of the things that the Greek Parliament is being asked to approve; a country that could have huge gains in productivity in a key sector such as renewable energy and you want to put a sca, which is to raise taxes. Frankly, somebody come and understand. Like the privatization of the entire privatization fund in general, it is producing a massive asset sale, without a clear timetable and often bye-making it in what Mr De Masi said is a real pillage. And finally, Greece was promised that we would go to a debt restructuring program. I know that the Commission is on that line and I would like to ask the Council to unlock this at once. It cannot be that this issue is hijacked by elections by any other Member State.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, after a decade of economic cruelty and an austerity-driven recession driven by the European Central Bank, the EU Commission, the IMF and, of course, the hands of the government in Greece, Syriza; after a decade which has seen youth unemployment rates consistently at 50%, a decade where 45% of Greek pensioners live below the poverty line of EUR 655 a month, a decade of the highest levels of suicide known in the Western world, a decade in which we have seen all the assets of Greece handed over, we who had said to Greece that we have seen this tragedy, have recognised that this was a battle to the death between those who wanted to save the euro, and the dignity and the lives of the Greek people. They wanted to save the EU Commissioners’ salaries, rather than the lives of the European people. That is why we said the euro was not more important than ordinary citizens’ lives. Greece should have left the euro. You know it over there, and you failed in your job to protect them.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: –Here we are again: Greece, yes, Greece. Hundreds of billions, no deal. They were bankrupt, they were bankrupt, they remain bankrupt, but of course the Commission is never going to say that. Mr President, the Greeks have a ruined economy and every economist knows that the euro is the cause of this, but of course the Commission is never going to say that either. If politicians were to face reality, this would never have happened, but they would not be politicians either, and the Greeks know it better than anyone else. Demosthenes said 2,400 years ago that "what man aspires to, he wants to believe" is also. And for the Commission, too, self-deception is the easiest, and that is why, Mr President, I am saying what the Commission apparently cannot say: the euro has failed and therefore the euro area must be dismantled and the Netherlands must leave the European Union. (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: "blue card" question. Thank you, Mr. Colleague. I agree with everything you've said, but I want to ask you a question. You said that Greece has always been poor and that it will remain poor. Are you aware that Greece, before these measures were imposed on it in the Memorandum, was not poor? Are you aware that Greeks had an average life expectancy much higher than the average that some other European Union states have, than those with a strong economy? Are you aware that this was done to remove from Greece all its marine and terrestrial wealth... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, I would like to give an answer. Mr President, my honourable colleague said that the Greeks were much richer before the crisis began. However, the statistics also show that in the 10-year period when German real incomes rose 0.7%, that of Greeks rose 70% in a decade. That 70% was not real, which was based on borrowed money which was then hidden in the budget. And that is why it is not a real representation that Greece was so rich at the time. Unfortunately.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, here the Greek people would understand why the European Union cannot improve and only gets worse. The day before yesterday, the chemicals that hit hundreds of pensioners, who were complaining that their pension had been cut by 50% or more, were being held jointly by tsipras' government and the European Union. Because, whether development with New Democracy and PASOK, or now with the newly minted neo-democrats of SYRIZA, this development is built only on poverty, wars and refugees. That's why SYRIZA is the best kid and gets congratulations from both the capital and the European Union...  (The President temporarily interrupts the speaker because there is a problem with interpretation in French. The day before yesterday, the chemicals that hit the 80-year-old pensioners in Athens who were protesting that their pension was cut by more than 50%, were kept by both the Tsipras/SYRIZA government and the European Union. Capitalist development, either with the former, New Democracy and PASOK, or with the newly minted neo-democrats of SYRIZA, rests only on poverty, wars and refugees. That's why Tsipras and syriza get congratulations from the capital and from the European Union: for their dirty work. Whether it was called debt relief or flexibility of Euro-EU rules, none of what was tested brought relief to the people. All we had were new anti-labour measures and subsidies, with the sole condition of the profitability of the capital, and very few underpaid jobs. Social security has been demolished! The public property has been surrendered! The second assessment buries collective agreements, frees up mass redundancies and shrinks the right to strike! Now we need to fight against the new measures, now we need to recall the old ones - the fight against governments, against the European Union, capital and exploitation!

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Madam President, many of my fellow citizens have come out against the Tsipras government because of its hypocrisy and incompetence. Yesterday, thousands of pensioners demonstrated in the centre of Athens denouncing their mocking by the government. Mr. Tsipras promised a thirteenth pension to low-income pensioners to come to power, win their vote, and instead abolished a social benefit that supplemented their income. Police yesterday violently dispersed pensioners using chemical gases.  All polls are damning for the Tsipras government; 80 to 85 percent of citizens believe it is moving in the wrong direction. Half of those who voted SYRIZA in September 2015 have already turned their backs on him. With the Left in power, austerity became tougher and less efficient.  The finance minister, Mr Tsakalotos, signs everything in Brussels appearing like a reformer and denies almost everything in Athens. For example, in the Greek Parliament he pledged that he would not do the privatisations he has agreed to and appears as the leader of the left wing of SYRIZA.  Political disguises raise the social costs of the policy applied. Some of our socialist friends are too easily persuaded by what the representatives of SYRIZA tell them. I wonder why. However, I would also like the line that led to the change of leadership in the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party to prevail in the European Parliament, which would help Greece's exit from the crisis.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has In May, the Eurogroup took the right step by deciding to focus on a pragmatic category, namely gross financial needs and, therefore, maximum debt servicing. The Greek economy must be given the chance to grow, and it must not be suffocated, nor must the people of Greece. However, I believe, Commissioner, that there must be a second step. On the other hand, for sensible reforms, there must also be debt relief. This must no longer be postponed. It is time for this to be included in the Eurogroup. I would have liked to have told the Council, Madam President, if it had been represented. Perhaps we can clarify the fact that the representatives of the Member States are present in such important discussions in the European Parliament. I would consider this to be progress in this discussion. I have to say to my colleagues in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats: I would like to make a request to you again, which I also presented to Mr Weber in our last discussion, this time to mr Balz: please prepare the next discussion on Greece in such a way that you write on a white page on the left what the previous government has achieved in terms of reforms. , and on the right, what the Tsipras government has done so far, and then we discuss this empirically. You have to get down from the Schäuble mantra! Just because you can't suffer it doesn't mean the government isn't at work. We have to talk about that.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, greece's growth has been clearly slower in recent years, i.e. during the programmes, than the troika has predicted. I would now like to ask why this has happened. What's wrong with you?   Many front-runners believe that Greece's debts will eventually have to be cut, that is, forgiven. What is the view of the Commission representative on greece's debt cuts?    There has been talk for years about how Greece will never adapt to the euro and its rules of the game. Why does Greece not break away from the euro and adopt its own currency? Is forcibly holding the eurozone together more important than allowing Greece to make a turn for the better by introducing its own currency?    As Notis Marias has raised numerous occasions in this House, the Greek people have suffered unreasonably. It is time for results to finally be achieved in this House!

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I believe that the people of Greece have a moral right to more understanding and fair treatment. However, a moral right cannot be easily translated into a legal right or an economic right. When talking about morality, there is also another rule: 'To put your own house in order'. On the day Greece treats its national minorities with the demands for justice that they themselves make in relation to the euro area, the day they have the courage to treat their internal minorities with greater fairness, that day I shall also speak with a much stronger voice for the problems of the Greek and Greek people. But as long as you do not have the courage to look reality straight in the eye, and also dare to say that there are no minorities, you do not get so much understanding in this forum.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: Mr. Moscovici, you're lying. You came here to embellish the third memorandum and the state of the Greek economy. For you, today, the Greek government is Europe's best student of austerity and privatisation. You're complicit. You have led 40% of Greek citizens to live below the poverty line. In the name of debt servicing and growth, wages and pensions are constantly falling and taxes are rising. Industrial relations are falling apart and unemployment has risen to record levels. Social reactions are treated with repression and chemicals, as was the case yesterday with pensioners, but you will tell me that this is also the case in Paris.  Mr. Moscovici, you are hypocrites and speculators, because together with the Greek government you sell the public wealth of the country. The Germans took the airports, the Italians took the railroads. For comparison, the transfer of Frenchman Pogba cost twice as much as this takeover. The Chinese took the ports and your friends, the French businessmen, are getting ready to buy the water.  You gave the green light to the predators of the markets to take out the red loans and take out the Greek citizens. So for you, Mr Moscovici, for the European banking system, for the Greek oligarchy and the neo-monumental government, this programme is a success and must be completed. For the Greek people drowning in taxes and poverty, for the Greek youth who emigrate is a failure and must be overthrown.  Shame on you, Mr Moscovici, for you have finally come today to tell us that you have turned Greece into a colony of the troika and the financial markets.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marco VALLI
text: "blue card" question. I agree with many of the things that my colleague has just said, but I would like to understand. Do you think, therefore, that the problem still remains only austerity, as Tsipras thought, or should we call it by a real name that is Economic and Monetary Union and therefore the euro? Do you think that religiously defending this political instrument is for the benefit of the Greeks at the moment or that we must start talking about an exit from this instrument in order to bring growth and development back to a country that otherwise will not find the solution?

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: "blue card" answer. – I thank my colleague for the question, but I would ask him not to dictate to me exactly what I will propose or what I have proposed or what my party is proposing in dealing with this situation. Obviously, within the framework of EMU, neither the crisis can be overcome nor development in the current circumstances.  Nevertheless, we are fighting together with the Greek people to shake off the memoranda and claim a different path in the country in the face of the policies of the troika and the policies of the current Greek government.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Nothing new: we are talking again about Greece and the same issues: economic growth, disbursement conditions, privatisation proceeds. Do you know what I wanted? I wish we had allowed the Greeks to leave the euro. I wish we had forgiven the Greeks for the debt, because they will never pay them and they all know that. And I wish we could turn back the clock and do everything anew. Then we wouldn't have to know about Greek primary surpluses – about priority actions or the Greek pension system.  We would only have to deal with our own affairs, and the Greeks would not have to take to the streets and demonstrate against outside interference. In short, I wish the Greeks had been spared the humiliations of the troika. Greece would not be under Kuratel, but would still be a sovereign democracy, and Europe would now not be divided into discord, but united in peace – that would be my wish.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, you can talk as much as you like about the economic recipe for getting out of the crisis, but as long as Brussels decides what the Member States can and cannot do, nothing will change. In Greece, unemployment is rampant and families are starving, just as in Italy, where there are 4 million poor people. Citizens so poor that they can only afford one meal a day, or lunch or dinner. Greece and Italy are suffering from the same disease, a disease that is destroying our economy and the lives of our citizens. All this disaster has been caused by this wrong Europe, by wrong treaties, by a wrong currency. Either we cure this disaster, this cancer, otherwise let us prepare for the end of the European dream and prepare for the funeral of the European Union.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Madam President, Greece received EUR 216 billion in the first two bailouts. How come he's still in crisis? Well, only 5% of this large amount – 9.7 billion – came into the Greek budget.
