All the rest was taken by creditors, predominantly French and German banks. It was not paid for instead of Greece, only the private loan was converted into a public loan. What does the Troika offer the Greek people? The sale of state assets and further austerity after austerity. The situation is similar to the following: a man drowning in water is thrown a lifeline, but this rope is wrapped around his neck. And when we seem to save it with good intentions, pull it out, we strangle it with the squeeze. That's what the troika does to the Greek people!

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. In principle, it should be noted that in a community one can rely on one another and be prepared to provide solidarity under conditions. This applies to the solidarity of refugees, as well as to the agreed reforms for money. The direction in Greece is right. But the Greek Government must not always rely on the extension when implementing the roadmap. Greece has achieved a lot and, according to the OECD report, has reformed its tax system most strongly of all developed countries over the past year. Nevertheless, only half of the taxes due are collected. Economic growth in Greece in the first half of the year surprised everyone, despite the refugee crisis and despite a unfortunately slow pace of implementation of the third programme. We have currently transferred only EUR 28.9 billion out of EUR 86 billion that has been pledged, because the pace and scope of the reforms have not been sufficiently advanced. That is why we have both: a positive balance sheet and a list of shortcomings. Yes, we can also talk about further debt restructuring, but not instead of reforms, but alongside the reforms.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Madam President, it is really painful to see how, after six years of crisis, the European Union and Greece were not able to deliver a solution for sound recovery. In spite of that, it was possible to identify a clear package deal to do so – a package deal where Greece should make a reform effort and should get more means to invest and create jobs and where Greece would deliver on fiscal consolidation and should have debt re—profiling. So the deal was clear. I think that so far Greece is now delivering on reforms and this is the time to make some effort to re—profile the public debt. The recent IMF report on Greece is again very clear on this. We cannot just ask for the huge effort of providing a fiscal surplus while, at the same time, we do not push forward this debt re—profiling. So my question for the Commission is as follows: the Commission is there, and should be there, to recall, in the Council, the full logic of the package with the elements – and we know very well what these elements are – and now is the right time for the debt re—profiling to be made.  Finally, we need to provide the right environment, and this is about completing the economic and monetary union. So my question is: how is the preparation of the promised White Paper on EMU going?

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Greece has received almost EUR 240 billion in aid for more than six and a half years, but at the same time has experienced nearly 30% of gdp decline, as if war had swept through the country. At the same time, the average unemployment rate in Greece has reached 25% and among young people as much as 50%, which means that the country loses one generation.  The public finance system has also been devastated, as is now reflected in the nearly 180% government debt-to-GDP ratio, and it is worth noting that at the outbreak of the crisis the ratio was only 110%. While most macroeconomic indicators have now improved slightly, the economic and social costs of more than six years of implementation of the recovery programmes in Greece are downright shocking.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Richard HOWITT
text: blue-card question. – Mr Kuźmiuk, you speak on behalf of your conservative group and argue in your group that social protection for workers is a bad thing and should be stripped away, and that that is going to help. But when we look at Greece, and even at what the IMF says, the sort of reductions of social protection that your group advocates leads to more firing and less hiring. Do you accept that today in Greece – which you profess to be concerned about – the maintenance of social protection for the rights of employees is important?

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – We do not accept anything that you accuse us of. Clearly, the therapy applied to Greece is wrong. These are huge billions of aid to this country, but at the same time, in fact, little money goes into the country's budget. Unfortunately, this is aid to banks and big corporations, and certainly not to Greece. This is unfortunately therapy that does not lead to the right goal.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: – Madam President; good afternoon and welcome, Mr. Moscovici, again. What I am going to say is going to complement The Excellent Speech by Minister Arthuis, with which I totally agree, I just want to go a little further. At least three things are enough.  Stop seeking accountable and being a permanent exchange of accusations and going back to the Lyaade and the Odyssey to justify the unjustifiable!  Stop no longer knowing the truth or reserving it for an opaque group of finance ministers! Enough is enough that the Greek shipowners, who are in London, do not pay taxes if they represent more than Greece's GDP! What do I mean by this? That enough lies and inefficiencies, and that Parliament must take the reins as a democratic representative to ensure minimal short-term governance. To do three things: to expose the stark reality and explain to Europeans the real situation, because if the airports are still in Europe, I don't care who owns them.  Secondly, damage the euro as little as possible and preserve it with the contemplation of a restructuring. Let's listen to the IMF if it has anything to propose.  And third, and I conclude, that, democratically, that is done first of all, effectively and with solidarity relief, intense towards Greek citizens during the long transition of change of structures under shared governance.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the title of today's debate is an insult to the Greek people. What you impose as structural reforms and the Greek Government is implementing to the letter on the basis of the third memorandum it signed, you are well aware that it is an unprecedented and unique one in the world, Commissioner, loot in the country's public wealth.  You're ordering everything to sell out. The other day you demanded that even the water be privatised. Commissioner, in seven years of implementing a tough austerity programme - salvation programmes you have called them - you have achieved what a war has achieved. You have reached record levels of unemployment, the largest in Europe. You have succeeded in one in three Greeks living below the poverty line. You've turned 300,000 young scientists into economic migrants. You've become retired beggars.  Today, Commissioner, what macroeconomic situation do you want to discuss? The results of the memorandums strip the Greek economy of any development tool. Really, Commissioner, how exactly do you mean growth and come today and argue that if the programme is fully implemented the Greek economy will recover. In other words, if the disaster continues, it will mean progress, and it is put forward in return for the debt debate, and you know very well that if and when it starts it will be pre-formal and meaningless, because it will be about a dead economy.  Commissioner, why do you continue to support policies that are disastrous for Europe and programmes that all serious economists describe as failures? The answer may be given by recent events at Deutsche Bank.

name: Petr MACH
text: – Commissioner Moscovici, you here are happy to praise the loan programmes to Greece and say that you believe that Greece's economy will grow next year, but that is always a lie to yourself. The Greek economy is declining for the ninth year in a row, and the forecast for next year is falling again. The overall decline over the nine years is about 27%, huge unemployment, the budget still in deep deficit. Those programs just don't work, so it has to be said that the programs so far have simply been a disaster.   I'll tell you what Greece needs. Greece does not need more loans. You've postponed their due dates to 2059, when, with all due respect, you'll all be dead. Greece does not need more bureaucracy, more borrowing, but more freedom to fly so that it can rise again like the Phoenix from the ashes. And part of that important freedom is for it to be able to leave the euro. That's what Greece needs.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Moscovici, I am sorry to share your optimism about Greece's macroeconomic indicators. According to Eurostat, the Greek economy will contract by a further 0.3% this year, and public debt will reach a record 182.8% of GDP. Investment and domestic demand are also declining. I do not want to talk about unemployment, especially youth unemployment. The IMF has long expressed doubts about Greece's debt sustainability, most recently in an analysis in May this year. It now calls on the euro area and The European creditor institutions to make a major debt cut. For a quick agreement with the IMF by the end of the year, a monetary package to provide a loan package will not be respected, and there is a risk that it will happen. It is now up to the Greek government to implement the agreed reform steps so that the Eurogroup can decide to pay out the remaining 2.8 billion. But these reforms are flawed. Although a reform package was adopted by the Greek Parliament last week, only three out of fifteen measures were actually implemented. That is not enough! Announcements of reform alone are not enough. As the Commissioner said, implementation is the weak point of the programme. Perhaps you should take up Mr Lucke's proposal and suggest a debt cut against leaving the eurozone.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, first of all, let me say that I agree with the Commission’s assessment that we could see stagnation in Greece this year, followed by recovery next year, finally. This is also confirmed by independent research. So Greece should be at the turning point, but a turning point that is too low and that has come too late. We should ask why. I think that the first reason was the very bad governance of the Greek state by governments in decades, before the start of the economic crisis, creating a malfunctioning state and promoting unsustainable policies. Second, there has been a lack of trust since the beginning of the programme and a lack of ownership of the programme. I think this was the main reason why the programme in Greece worked much less well than in the cases of Ireland and other countries. Last but not least, we should mention the huge mistake made by Mr Tsipras when he came to power. In my opinion, his experiment delayed the recovery of the Greek economy by about two years, and showed us what would happen if the calls for leaving the euro and giving up the support programme were actually accepted. I believe that Greek debt will be sustainable if the economy grows in nominal terms, interest payments are lower and the budget is in order. So we shall see what sustainability of the Greek economy looks like.  But most importantly, I believe that there is better future for the Greek people. They deserve it. It is a great country and it will be a great country in the future.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Niedermayer, on your comment that things need to go up again: I believe that the crucial thing is that we must, of course, also measure the macroeconomic situation against the microeconomic situation: how are the self-employed and small and medium-sized enterprises in Greece actually doing. Do you think that this could also be tackled in the area of reform, so that the macroeconomic situation can then be strengthened by means of initiatives on its own initiative?

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: blue-card answer. – I guess we need three points. Stable, sustainable and predictable macroeconomic conditions are key. The second requirement is for the reforms that are actually taking place under pressure. And, very importantly, the banking sector must be functioning: the programme was actually aimed at supporting the ability of the banks to lend. We need confidence in the Greek economy. I believe that, after this, confidence will gradually come back, and that the economy will keep growing, including SMEs.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that everyone must admit this: a number of indicators have moved in Greece, as evidenced by its primary surplus, which many other Member States cannot avail themselves of. But how can we rejoice when we see the colossal suffering that the Greek people have endured? I agree with you, Commissioner: the ball is now in the european institutions' court. Eurozone ministers will be responsible for unlocking the new tranche of loans as early as next week, and we expect them to do so. From now on, the agenda must be on debt relief so that we can finally consider getting out of this ongoing crisis. However, all the sacrifices imposed on the Greek people have demonstrated the inadequacy of the tools available to the euro area to respond to asymmetric shocks. We need a budgetary capacity of the euro area, not in twenty years in a utopian future but quickly, with a timetable for implementation, in order to have the tools to deal with the next crises. Similarly, we need an EU budget that is up to the challenge. With the revision of the multi-year financial framework, a new stage begins: it will have to go through both an increase in the ceilings and a reform of the European Fund for Strategic Investments so that it also benefits the States that need it most, such as Greece.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Madam President, Mr Moscovici, I would like to thank mr Moscovici for his work and for his work In 1970, a German Mark cost 9 drachmas. Thirty years later, in 2000, 170 drachmas had to be paid for a German mark. If the euro did not exist, a German mark would cost 250 drachmas today. But no, the creators of the euro have decided that for all eternity a German Mark will cost 174 drachmas.  The result is that the euro is far too strong for Greece – even tomatoes are imported from Holland – and for Germany the euro is far too weak, which is why Germany is the world export champion. In Greece, the situation is a pure disaster. All macroeconomic data are negative, e.B. industrial production is at the level of the 1970s. Today, the Greeks are the victims, not the perpetrators of the whole. The only real possibility is that Greece will leave the eurozone.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her At the time, Greece provided the wrong figures to get into the eurozone. Today, the Commission is presenting false figures to keep Greece in the eurozone. Both are pointless, absurd and, in the long run, unsustainable. I am astonished when the Commissioner says here that Europe should finally assume its responsibilities towards Greece. Have we not made a first aid package, a second aid package – which, incidentally, my party, the German Liberals, has supported? Have we not created an ESM, which we have also supported with the greatest difficulties in Germany? And now we have an ESM package that is objectively illegal. No one here believes that Greece has debt sustainability. In the ESM, however, this is a prerequisite for the spending of funds to a country. That is why the International Monetary Fund is not there – which, incidentally, was the prerequisite for the CDU and the CSU to participate at all – the pension reforms are stalling, the opening up of the energy sector is not progressing, and the evergreen: the cadastre still does not exist. The only chance is that Greece must leave the eurozone in order to regain its competitiveness outside it, but not outside European solidarity. We want to help Greece, but that is not possible in the eurozone.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, as we do every year, we meet to discuss the health of Greece. This European "Dallas" between the troika and the Greeks is endless. The question is whether this country has properly implemented the structural reform policies imposed by Brussels - euro-austerity must be implied. And to oversee all this, which is more competent than a Commissioner who has done the opposite in his country. Mr Moscovici widened public deficits when he was economy minister in France, as did the UMP for that matter. It never cut into bad public spending, which would have allowed the economy to restart. Above all, he refused to question the ultra-liberal dogmas, notably the euro, a single currency and financial abyss, which now commits France to more than 470 billion euros in financial guarantees to the European Union.  The Greek people clearly said no to austerity in a referendum in July 2015, but whatever, the cleptocraticity of private banks and commissioners at the orders of Berlin had nothing to do with popular democracy. Greece is undergoing terrible privatization plans to the delight of German, Chinese or Qatari investors. The Greeks have had incompetent, flamboyant or corrupt governments, but they do not deserve the fate that this European Union has in store for them. The patriots argue for a Europe of nations with national economic governance and not a Greece under the tutelage of Brussels.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici, the completion of the Greek programme is threatened by two black holes: overtaxation and the lack of implementation of structural reforms. First of all, in Greece everything that moves is taxed and you are also responsible for it. You creditors have endorsed a fiscal mix that exacerbates the recession and does not give Greece a way out of development. Instead of insisting on greater tax compliance, you accepted the tax extermination of all small and medium-sized enterprises in Greece. Secondly, you creditors are content with structural reform laws without monitoring their implementation. From cutting red tape to privatizations – not those launched by the New Democracy government but what SYRIZA has to do – we have seen little results. Mr Moscovici, reducing the cost of servicing Greek government debt is an obligation you made in November 2012 and specialized in March 2016. It is necessary to fulfill your commitment to stabilize the landscape in Greece. But at the same time my country needs another policy mix to get on its feet without a memorandum after 2018, it needs a policy with a reduction of the state, with a reduction in taxes and with an emphasis on privatizations and structural changes, so that we can be at the narrow modern core of the European Union.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, you have informed us that the first evaluation is closing positively in a few days' time. I'd like to remind you that this is the thirteenth evaluation. Yes, it sounds paradoxical, but this is the thirteenth positive assessment. Today the real economy is at its worst. There are capital controls, growing and now unserved overtaxation, brain drain. Why did we get here? Because for six years now agreements have been concluded detailing those structural reforms that will pull the country out of the crisis, but when we get to the next one, that is to say in the evaluations, we are only looking at budgetary measures. So the partners lend only as much as they keep Greece alive in intensive care and governments govern without having to clash with the powerful client state. Because that is precisely the problem, this is the key and the uniqueness of the Greek crisis: the management model based on the two-way client father and which cancels out any attempt to develop, transparency and fight corruption. Even if we get to that debt restructuring at some point that will make it debt-serving, our production model is outdated and inefficient. That is why we are calling for the ECON working group to be upgraded, which will monitor with reports the implementation of non-fiscal reforms, because without fundamental change in administration and without cuts in the business environment, taxation and justice, we will never escape the threat of a Grexit. Only Parliament can help. Governments of six years, the Commission and the IMF refuse to do so.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to highlight a very specific aspect of Greece's situation here, namely the use of the structural funds of the so-called EU funds. Due to the tense financial situation, the necessary co-financing could no longer be guaranteed at the end of the funding period. The European Parliament has therefore allowed Greece to renounce this cofinancing. In addition, Greece has been granted an advance of around one billion for the new funding period.  However, this kind of aid to Greece is not a blank cheque. They must benefit concrete projects on the ground, with real added value. Real added value means that the money should not only be called up and spent, but also help Greece to offer long-term products and services that are in demand abroad. Only in this way can Greece grow economically again, reduce its high unemployment and offer its citizens a perspective.  As Parliament's special rapporteur, I have been able to see on the ground on several occasions how these funds have been used: as far as the old funding period is concerned, the completion of the projects seems to have been positive. As far as the new funding period is concerned, however, the new absorption rate of structural funds is very low, and I would therefore call on the commission as a whole to get to the bottom of this low absorption rate immediately and to develop solutions and alternatives so that this money can get into projects more quickly. Otherwise, we run the risk of not achieving added value.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – The situation in Greece is slowly becoming hopeless. Six years after the first bailout, there is still little improvement. Debt is hardly diminishing and the economy is still a quarter smaller than before the crisis. Meanwhile, the population is exposed to an extreme reduction in living standards. We have never seen it so extreme in Europe in peacetime. A quarter of children live in poverty, a quarter of parents are unemployed at home. In my opinion, this cannot continue. The sacrifices have been made. Greece must be able to start with a clean slate and all we have left is a real reform of the economy, combined with debt reduction, with a full restoration of all trade union rights and with substantial aid programmes.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, the agreement on the third Greek programme was signed in July last year. Since then, the Greek economy has returned to a growth path, but the recovery is still fragile and needs urgently to be supported by a range of reforms. We encourage the Greek Government to accelerate their implementation, especially those improving the pension system, tax collection, bank governance and the energy market.  We all express our solidarity with the Greek people in this difficult time, but let me stress that the cost of necessary reforms could have been lower had those reforms been implemented earlier. Unfortunately, because of the populist policy stance adopted initially by the Greek Government, including many unrealistic promises, precious time was wasted and Greece fell back into recession last year. Populism never pays off and this lesson needs to be constantly kept in mind.  The future of the current programme is, however, uncertain because of wide differences in the debt sustainability analyses produced by the Commission and the IMF. In my opinion the IMF conclusions and forecast are controversial. Debt restructuring through nominal reduction is not the solution. It involves moral hazard and is not necessary. Other measures could be considered, including the extension of maturities and grace periods and the reduction of interest rates. Strict conditionality, of course, remains key to the final success.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Greece is the country of marathons, but it is now making a sprint towards a budget surplus of 2%. That budget surplus is achieved by higher costs, in particular the higher costs for which the Greek people foot the bill. As my colleague Agnes Jongerius said, 'the Greek people can hardly bear that anymore'. There is no eurozone country that has a surplus of 2% and Greece has to print on 3.5% because if it does not achieve that, there will be automatic austerity. Meanwhile, the burden of debt is still weighing heavily on the Greek economy and offers little prospect. So I would very much like to see the Commission continue to work, also to reach an agreement with the IMF, including on debt forgiveness in order to give the Greek people and the Greek economy a better perspective.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. We have been dealing with the Greek sovereign debt crisis for six years. Other countries have successfully completed support programmes during this period and have also emerged stronger from the reform process. But the balance sheet in Greece is very sobering: the public debt is almost three times as high as the Maastricht criteria allow, the unemployment rate is 23%, no economic growth for seven years. This raises the question of why things are not progressing in Greece, even though the Greek Parliament has been deciding reform for reform for many years. The central reason , Commissioner, you mentioned this – is that progress is only on paper. What is decided by Parliament does not appear to have any binding effect on the administration. And it raises fundamental questions about the extent to which Greece can be governed or reformed in the first place– I want to make it so clear. That is the real point to be paid to: strengthening the capacity of the administration so that reforms are actually implemented so that they actually arrive. The debate on debt reduction, initiated by the International Monetary Fund, therefore completely misses the problem. The opposite would be true. It is a question of not letting ourselves be divided, but of standing together. And the IMF's model of no reform is not the model we have agreed: loans against reforms. And even the simplest non-economist would have to understand that what the IMF is proposing cannot work. (The speaker refused to answer a question from Sven Giegold under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Commissioner Moscovici for the work and efforts of Commissioner Moscovici during this long period working with Greece. We all lived those first moments, in the first half of 2015, where it seemed that we could give an easier way out of the Greek problem, and we all live how that was resolved, in the first place, in a rather sad way and then, because it seems that in a somewhat more reasonable way. In any case, it is true that Greece, in the last year, year and a half, has begun to make progress on some reforms, has been complying with some of the Commission's requirements, no longer so much focused on adjustments and cuts, and, finally, on setting up a functioning tax system, making an administration that can respond to the country's problems... But it is true that the country remains in many problems and that the volume of debt remains unsumable and that the country cannot continue to record such high primary surpluses if it is to give a way out. And so, in my opinion, I believe that at some point, through the EESM and through the IMF, we will have to give a way out of the debt problem with a redemption program.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has had. For years now, we have been debating in this House the financial and economic crisis and the consequences of it in Greece and other EU Member States. Gradually, I feel that this chapter is about a never-ending story. Please do not misunderstand me, I am still firmly convinced that it was right in 2010 to pledge financial support to the Greek Government because of its economic situation. Genuine European solidarity was needed here. The European Union is more than just an economic community: it is about European values. Solidarity is and will remain one of the cornerstones of the European Union. After all, that is what our European Treaties say.  Nevertheless, we must also be able to demand that the Greek Government make its contribution. Without further reforms, I do not believe that there should be any further financial resources. Solidarity is not a one-way street. In the meantime, funds from the third aid package are flowing to Greece. It is unacceptable to me that, contrary to the commitments, the IMF has still not taken part in it.  Around half of Greeks aged 15 to 24 are still unemployed. This is a scandal! Without necessary reforms, however, there will be no sustainable economic growth and thus no new jobs. This is demonstrated by the experience in other European countries, such as .B in Ireland.  That is why I urge the Greek Government to implement your reform efforts quickly. Continue on the path! In the end, the state will only be able to fulfil its tasks if a tax liability is not only on paper, but the taxes are actually collected.

name: Eva KAILI
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the preliminary draft budget tabled yesterday in the Greek Parliament is a great demonstration of the budgetary impasse that Greece has been in for the last year and a half of governance by a left-right formation. For example, the Ministry of Finance foresees a further reduction of EUR 326 million in pensions, EUR 440 million in the EKAS, new taxes of more than EUR 1.5 billion in the hope of closing the year with a primary surplus of 2%. At the same time, of course, the government ministers themselves are sabotaging any reform effort that would bring investment and are gaining time, since we allow them to do so, to continue the tax raid without carrying out reforms. The burdens are transferred to the citizens and their property is sold off.  The issue, of course, is not the illusions and authoritarianism of a government trying to control the media, justice and banks, but the hypocrisy and apathy of Europe that postpones everything and all decisions until after the German elections. We are playing micro-political games instead of supporting the citizens, we are giving extensions because it may suit us in relation to the refugee issue. Ladies and gentlemen, the budget is unworkable and we cannot ignore it. Debt relief is being carried over for after the German elections as it seems and will prove too little, too late. The country is being strangled by unreasonable demands for budget surpluses. What we need right now is to solve a problem not ideological, but mere arithmetic. Before there is a budgetary collapse, discussions must begin on adjusting the surplus targets. These are conversations that were supposed to start yesterday. We owe solidarity and honesty to the people, that is the point and no longer, to raise a flag of left-wingness that draws or even suits some people in here.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Madam President, the institutions and the current government are forecasting growth of 2.7% for the Greek economy for 2017. We all hope that the objective will be verified, but achieving it requires, among other things, a sharp increase in annual total investment, both public and private. Has the SYRIZA government created the right environment to attract investors? Do you think, Commissioner, that it is realistic to predict growth of 2.7% in 2017 with such taxes and additional taxes of four billion in the 2017 budget, when, for example, total inflows of foreign investment funds in 2015 decreased by 73% compared to 2014 and when Greece retreated in a recent World Economic Forum report by five places in the international competitiveness ranking? Thank you very much.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Madam President, the opening up of the loan market, which is a commitment of the last programme, is the largest transfer of national wealth since the exchange of populations in 1922. Non-performing loans are equivalent to 60% of GDP. If we do not put rules of fairness and transparency in this process, inequalities will become monstrous and lead to a social explosion.  I would like to ask the Commissioner: Why in the case of Greek borrowers is it not possible for them or their guarantors to redeem the loan at a low price, as is the case in Cyprus, 45 days before they are sold to investment funds? If there is an obstacle to the moral hazard of taking this opportunity by strategic bad payers who can but do not pay, then we must set strict conditions, because otherwise there is another, greater moral risk: those who want but cannot – and are the vast majority of the Greek people – lose their property and, as prices have collapsed, remain themselves and their children hostage to debts. , without being able to make a fresh start in their lives.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Dear President, let me first and foremost stand in solidarity with the Greek people, which in these moments carries a great deal of responsibility, regarding the migrant crisis and all that Greece has done and is doing in this case, and this is essential for the whole of Europe. However, let me say that I am a little disappointed in this discussion. The euro is to blame, it's the IMF's fault, it's nea democrats' fault, it's Cipras' fault. It's everyone's fault... a little self-criticism, my dear friends. I come from Croatia and I know very well how some things can be shown on our most beautiful Balkan peninsula.  Let's be a little self-critical. Let's just say we've lived maybe too long too well, not very well founded to the end on realistic indicators of the economy. I think if we put our hand on our hearts, Greece has a great chance and we have to stand with it, but with a realistic basis.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Madam President, the memoranda which constituted the price of transnational borrowing for a number of euro area Member States suffered from the outset, since there was no guarantee that their main architect, namely the International Monetary Fund, would respect primary European law and in particular the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. In practice we have seen excessive restrictions on social rights in particular and this has translated in Greece into dramatic material deprivations for a large part of the population, an increase in deaths due to deteriorating public health, a decrease in the number of births and migration of hundreds of thousands of unemployed young people abroad.  If the European Union wants to show basic respect for the fundamental rights that are supposed to form the basis of its existence, there must be brave relief of Greece's transnational debt so that the economy and society can be put on a sustainable path. Thanks.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, Greece unfortunately has no chance of returning to real and not accounting growth under the present circumstances. Forecasts claiming this would once again fall tragically out, with the same experts predicting a return to growth from 2012. In fact, the famous programs are nothing but nonsense of incompetent technocrats who play with the lives of millions of Greeks. We can no longer tolerate this. The International Monetary Fund has already admitted its serious mistakes and that the programmes are essentially politically directed. The policy of austerity by overtaxation, the reduction of wages and pensions, the dismantling of insurance funds and the mortgage of public property in favour of lenders has led to impoverishment, a humanitarian crisis and thousands of suicides.  The solution for Greece is one: unilateral write-off of illegal debt and prosecution of those responsible, liberalisation from the shackles of the euro – a currency that is disastrous for our country and probably for other countries in the future – and finally a return to domestic production and tariffs on products that are competitive with Greek or can be produced in Greece. Thanks.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, coming from Ireland I have great sympathy for Greece. Like the Greeks, we were in the bailout programme, but unlike Greece we implemented the programme and are now getting the benefits from it. Greece, unfortunately, especially the first Syriza Government, engaged in populist trickery which didn’t pay off. Of course Greeks are not the only ones to engage in that. A few weeks ago Commissioner Moscovici engaged in populism as well when he said that EUR 13 billion of the Apple tax was available to Ireland to build houses and schools etc., knowing full well that it could not become available until after the court case in several years’ time; and also, on the Commission’s own admission, that money may belong to other Member States, not Ireland, so let’s forget about populism and engage in realism. And where Greece is concerned, realism means, firstly, implementing the programme; secondly, introducing reforms; and thirdly, tackling corruption. In that way, Greece will gradually reach the prosperity which the great people of Greece deserve after many years of austerity. It is the only way.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Madam President, a Greek friend of my wife regularly keeps us informed of what is happening in Greece economically and socially. She is particularly worried: for herself - she waited two years before receiving a very small retirement - and for her children - they are not able to enter the workforce in a sustainable way. I would like to commend the work of the Greek Government in order to rectify the situation, as Commissioner Moscovici quite rightly said. This courage in implementing difficult reforms should not be commended, but the impossible should not be asked. Greece has come a long way, and Europe has no right to sacrifice it and its people on the altar of convergence criteria, which will in any case be difficult to meet in a short period of time. The question of debt must of course be asked, not only in Greece for that matter, but also in Europe in general. Europe saved the banks for the first time. Isn't it time to save Europe's social rights?

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: – Madam President, on a point of order, I have not raised a question about a blue card. I have been patient from the very beginning and have asked for catch-the-eye. What have I done wrong? You tell me.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Congressman, I'm sorry. He didn't do anything wrong. He's done nothing wrong. He's looking forward to his turn. The practice is to go around the circle of Members, and quite simply now it is up to the independents after the GUE. Then it's the People's Party. S&D will follow. So please wait. Three minutes, we talked about it more, it was unnecessary.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, those who claim that there is economic growth in Greece either do not know exactly what is going on, or know but do not want to admit that what is happening in Greece, namely the Memorandums, is something that was deliberately imposed. There was no reason to do this and Greece was the scapegoat for the eurozone, the euro, some French and German banks and, above all, for Greece to be stripped of its land, underground and underwater wealth. How can there be growth in Greece when it has been imposed on a massive, illegal and unaffordable debt, which international loan sharks do not want to alleviate? How can there be growth in Greece when the European Union has trapped millions of illegal immigrants there? How can there be growth in Greece when funds are not available for development but these are given with the eyedropper? So let Mr. Moscovici and let us not be told that Europe cares about Greece.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: Madam President, it is a question of making the crisis an opportunity today. But both sides make mistakes. What are the mistakes on greece's part? Excessively high taxation, ideologies, populism and minimal structural reforms have been destroying the productive fabric of the economy for many years now, particularly in the private sector, and small and medium-sized enterprises, devaluing real estate. Example one: in banks we have 120 billion deposits and we have 125 billion red loans. Example two, to meet the objectives as Mr Moscovici said: the public sector's obligations in the private sector are 9 billion, 5% of Greece's Gross National Product. What are Europe's mistakes? Management logic and phobic syndromes. If Europe wants to turn problems like Greece into an opportunity, then Europe must take steps forward and such steps can only be taken if the economic integration of the European Union becomes a reality. Only then will we be able to solve problems, make the Greek crisis an opportunity and, of course, regulate, as it should, the issue of debt for the period after 2022, in order to enable the Greek economy to breathe in the future.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: – Madam President, to make a mistake is human. You made a mistake: you counted me as GUE. I am not GUE, I am S&D. It is OK, but let us turn now to our subject. I will speak using my mother tongue.   (The President cut-off the speaker)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Congressman, I'm sorry. I don't want to argue with you. He's in a perfect place on my list. He sits in the S&D ranks and I call him from the S&D list. Those who were not present were in the ranks of the GUE. It was probably a translation error.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, I, in turn, will congratulate Mr President-in-Office of the Council. Moscovici on the effort he is making for Greece but I will talk about the substance as much as I can.  I will find it hard to believe that there is an economist who would say that Greek public debt is sustainable. So if it is not sustainable, it does not mean that structural changes and everything else are not needed, but without sustainable debt I think Greece will not come to growth as quickly as we really want; because there are also some who are just playing games to help the Greek people either to punish Tsipras or anyone else. Thank you.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to find a compromise in those two positions, that is, whether the light at the end of the tunnel is already visible or whether to give gifts to the Greek people. In my opinion, it is very good what concrete steps may have been taken in the area of structural policy, when greece was forgiven for the compulsory share that the national authorities had to deliver.  For this reason, I would like the light at the end of the tunnel to be seen in the other national macroeconomic indicators. And I express my participation to the Greek people, I believe that the sacrifices he is forced to make are very painful.  On the other hand, this effort must also be seen in the light of the creditors' request to pay at least part of their legitimate claims. In this sense, it is necessary to lead the victims even further, on the other hand, I believe that the light at the end of the tunnel will come.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, it was an important debate with a lot of speeches, a lot of passion as well. I will try to engage in a perhaps a little more reasonable exercise because what I have heard is a whole series of reflections, extremely fair and acute remarks, but also, sometimes, the projection of a political debate that we can have - and this is legitimate - on this subject.  For me, the question is not whether to enter the euro, get out of it or stay there. I am Commissioner for Economic and Financial Affairs and, of course, I consider the euro to be a monetary and political construct that has a very important economic basis. That is what the Commission and I are devoting our efforts to. Personally, the question I am asking myself — I understand that it is different for others — is not whether or not I have sympathy for Mr Tsipras's government. Some have them, some do not, some have had them and no one. No, I want to put myself in terms of the action that we are taking and the fact that the Commission is doing, as well as the Eurogroup, which, as you know, is by definition a very pluralistic body.  Of course, not everything has been done in Greece, many mistakes have been made, especially in the recent period. It is true, time has been wasted, and time wasted is delayed reforms, they are also points of growth that have not been found.  But I think it's not fair either to say that nothing has been done. On the contrary, in recent times, many reforms have been passed and initiated. They have yet to be implemented. I think things are moving forward from our point of view in a positive way. This is what the Commission will continue to strive to promote in such a way as to enable Greece to regain economic success, to offer a future to its people, first of all to its youth, by setting up a virtuous circle.  For me, the virtuous circle is clear: it is a question of ensuring that we are able collectively to live the fulfilment of the commitments made in the Memorandum of Understanding of July 2015. The first revision must be really behind us, the second revision must be completed quickly, the reforms must move forward, it must give a signal of economic confidence and return of investors, and that from that moment on, indeed, and I hope all this by the end of the year, we can reach an agreement on the debt because it is both legitimate and expected.  This requires everyone to make efforts: the creditors, all the partners around the Eurogroup table, including economic thinking efforts, and, above all, the Greek authorities, to carry out the reform programme. This is what the Commission will try, I repeat, to promote, namely the search for sustainable growth that will enable job creation, which also respects the social dimension because it is absolutely essential.  Many of you have called - it is true and it makes sense to say this in this Parliament - to deepen the euro area, so that it has its own instruments and also more democratic governance. This is a view that I share and that is what we will have to find in a White Paper which the Commission must prepare. We will continue the discussions in the Eurogroup on Monday in Luxembourg, where I hope we can see that the famous milestones have all been reached.  Naturally, I will be prepared to resume this debate regularly before you in the European Parliament. I know your vigilance, I know your demands, I also know your attention to the situation in Greece and your wish that Greece come out of this endless crisis. That is what the Commission wants to achieve with you.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – Greece is currently under intense pressure again in relation to delayed structural reforms. Their acceleration is a condition for drawing further aid from the third rescue loan. The problem with Greek debts has been going on for too long, with no appreciable improvement. Forced austerity results in economic decline, unemployment well above 20%, while young unemployed without prospects account for almost half in the country. Such a situation only records the populist and extremist political forces there, promising desperate populations unfulfilled miracles. It is known that Greece will practically never be able to repay its commitments with the current structure of its economy. It is therefore necessary to think about the conditions and setting up of the aid so that the objectives of consolidating the economy there can be achieved. This is one of the remaining destabilising elements, which is part of a broad mosaic of current European problems. In the current situation, in addition to the actions of irresponsible governments, the country has also found itself thanks to the failure of the European control mechanisms for admission to the monetary Union. No one is responsible to this day. Delaying or even limiting aid would particularly affect ordinary people within the already hard-pressed middle class.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. Greece continues to live in dramatic economic and social conditions, with a 25% workforce unemployment and very weak economic growth. At the same time, it must be acknowledged that the Hellenic Republic's public debt is unsustainable, which is also a steed for the Greek economy to bounce. Action must therefore be taken in this regard. Specifically, the financial union involves partly mutualizing the issuance of public debt by eurozone Member States (Eurobonds) and giving a solution to the stock of debt inherited from the past (legacy debt). It is therefore necessary to organise a European debt conference, as proposed by the chairman of my bench, Gianni Pittella, in order to be able to launch a debt repayment fund, under which it would be possible to restructure greek debt. Needless to remember, the International Monetary Fund itself insists that it is essential to address the issue of the restructuring of Greek public debt beyond the fulfilment of the conditions of the financial assistance programme. We cannot forget that solidarity is the basic founding value of a Community Europe with a federal vocation.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. – The ailing Greek economy improved slightly in the second quarter and is still expected to contract by 0.3% this year, according to Eurostat. There remains considerable uncertainty about this data. A booming tourism industry has contributed to a slight decline in unemployment, but public debt has now risen to a record 182.8% of GDP. Youth unemployment was around 47.7% in August 2016. Confirmed by these data, I consider Greece's debt sustainability to be extremely questionable. Apparently, I am going to d'accord here with the IMF, which in May this year called for a debt cut for Greece. However, I am not calling for a debt cut, because without major changes it would be pointless for Greece's inefficient and corrupt economy and administration. I therefore call for the financial sector to be regulated in such a way as to limit the hitherto irresponsible commercial policy of the banks. In doing so, it is necessary to ensure that in future taxpayers will no longer have to pay for the mistakes of the banks. Until now, the euro bailouts have only come to the aid of the banks and not the citizens of Greece.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. I would like to express my solidarity with the Greek people. The Greeks have made many sacrifices in recent years. In order to meet the Troika's austerity requirements, massive welfare cuts and cuts in workers' rights have been endured. More than a third of the Greek population is affected by poverty, one in two young people is unemployed and the suicide rate has risen sharply. Greece has done a great deal, the tasks have been done. Now we too must all do our part. As agreed and repeatedly requested by the IMF and also Commissioner Moscovici, debt relief for Greece is needed in order to achieve sustainable growth again. Because Greece will not simply grow out of its own debt. It is unacceptable that this discussion, on the backs of the Greek people, should be postponed until after the elections in Germany. We need a rethink in Europe. Austerity in Greece must be put to an end. Sustainable investment in the future of the country to create work is necessary. Last but not least, trade union rights must be reinstated.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. When we discuss new reforms, we must first look back and see what previous reforms have brought. Until now, Greece has always been asked to cut spending and lower social standards. Greek pensioners have just suffered their eleventh pension cut since the crisis erupted. Incomes have also fallen by a third since 2008. The poorest 10% of the Greek population have suffered particularly heavy losses of revenue. In terms of labour standards, Greece is now even on a par with Qatar. Instead of alleviating the crisis, the reforms have exacerbated the crisis. The unemployment rate is now 24%. And of the young people with completed education, even one in two are without a job. There is no doubt that Greece urgently needs structural reforms. However, these must not be limited to austerity programmes. With new reforms, we must show people a way out of the crisis. We finally need to boost the Greek economy. Targeted and intelligent investment in key industries must be made. Flexibility in labour law does not bring us an inch further here. On the contrary, we need a strong labour law that guarantees good jobs and combats the flourishing undeclared work!

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – After years and years, Greece has not yet recovered. I have grave doubts that it is only Greece, that it has not carried out the programmes agreed with its creditors. The condition for the success of any restructuring programme at country level is to strike a balance between the actual potential to generate revenue and the debt due during the programme period. This balance was not achieved under the existing programme with Greece. Greece's debt is far too high in relation to this country's real potential to generate revenue. Lenders, including the Member States of the European Union, have an obligation to strike this balance.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. – The fact that in recent years the Greek people have suffered an unprecedented ordeal is well known to all. However, it must finally be recognised that the EU is also responsible for the current situation in Greece. If everyone had acted on time, neither Greece would have experienced the consequences of the crisis to this extent, nor would our partners be constantly called upon to vote on new support packages. Also, if the EU had supported the country's reform forces when it had to, there would not have been a populist setback in recent years that led to even tougher fiscal measures. Greek debt at the moment is not sustainable. Something has to be done. Whether we call it lightening, lengthening or restructuring has little value. This is a reality with which everyone will have to come to terms. Of course, the Greek government itself bears the most important responsibility and will therefore have to proceed immediately with the necessary reforms. However, this programme's obsession with taxes leaves little room for optimism. The country needs real investment and growth. No matter how much you raise taxes, if the country doesn't restart the real economy it's not going to come out of the crisis.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Next item: Joint discussion — Conflicts of interest in the Commission's statement on avoiding conflicts of interest and current Commissioners (2016/2893(RSP)) and the Commission's statement on the Bahamian leak (2016/2914(RSP)). It's a very long list that I've got in my hands. That is why I am asking you not to take advantage of the Blue Card option, because we will not be at the end of the debate. Our recent afternoon debates have been very slipping.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the current Commission, the Juncker Commission, is very firmly committed to meeting its obligations as enshrined in the Treaties and the Commissioners' Code of Conduct. Among these obligations is the obligation of independence and integrity of the members of the Commission. This Commission stresses two major concepts: transparency and exemplarity. Parliament and all citizens must be assured that the Commissioners are acting exclusively in the interests of the European Union and that the necessary transparency is guaranteed. Any situation of conflict of interest must therefore be avoided. The treaties, I would like to remind you, provide for the obligations of independence and integrity to be respected by the members of the Commission for the duration of their duties. Article 245 of the Treaty also provides for members of the Commission to respect the duties of honesty and delicacy in order to accept certain other functions or benefits after the termination of their duties. The Commissioners' Code of Conduct contains provisions that reflect treaty obligations. It aims to prevent any risk of conflict of interest by establishing the prohibition on members of the Commission from performing other functions during their term of office, with the exception of strictly honorary functions or political activities, of course without a warrant. The members of this Commission are men and women who have convictions and political commitments. The code also provides for a procedure for authorizing the activities envisaged at the end of their mandate. These are strict rules, in relation to those that apply to members of other European institutions or those in force in the Member States. I'm starting to have a bit of a political life, at least quite respectable; I have held many positions - Member of Parliament, MEP, local elected official, minister in my country - and I can indeed testify that the rules set for Commissioners are rather stronger than all the rules I have had to live in before. This code has been the subject of several revisions, each time to be more precise and rigorous. These revisions have always been in the direction of strengthening these provisions. I would like to turn my attention for a moment to the post-mandate activities that have generated a great deal of interest. According to the Code of Conduct, when Commissioners are considering professional activity , therefore, ex-Commissioners, within 18 months of the end of their term of office, these members or former members have an obligation to inform the Commission of these activities. This 18-month period is in line with European and international standards and aims to avoid conflict of interest situations at the end of the mandate. In this configuration, the Commission consults with the ad hoc ethics committee when the activity envisaged is related to the portfolio exercised and then decides on the compatibility of the activity envisaged on the proposal of the President. In practice, this means that, in the 18 months since the end of the previous Commission, this Commission - I am referring to the Juncker Commission - consulted the ad hoc ethics committee on 40 of the 114 activities notified by the members of the previous Commissions. The committee adopted 5 negative opinions. In the event of a negative opinion, the members concerned have always, on each case, preferred to withdraw their notification rather than risk receiving a negative opinion from the Commission as well. This, in my view, proves the effectiveness of the ethics committee's operation and the strength of the rules that apply. All the decisions adopted by the Commission are accessible to the public, I would like to say - through its minutes. In order to ensure greater transparency, this Commission has set up a web page where each decision is taken up with a direct link to the corresponding minutes as soon as it has been adopted. Criticisms of laxity or lack of transparency are therefore unfounded. We are faced with debates that are sufficiently serious and to which public opinion attaches sufficient importance not to add to or imagine other types of shortcomings. Moreover, no rule, even the strictest, can replace the individual responsibility of the members of the Commission. If we consider - and you have mentioned two communications, which I have in fact grouped together - the recent cases of the former President of the Commission, Mr Barroso, and the former Vice-President, Mrs Kroes, no extension of the obligations imposed by the code of conduct could have prevented their choice of professional development. There may be assessments here of the individual responsibility for this or that. As for the Commissioners' declarations of interest, everyone is personally responsible for them. This statement must be accurate and complete in order to allow for an effective examination of the risks of conflict of interest, and, again, it is precise, updated and goes to the bottom of it.  I will conclude by saying that the President is closely and personally monitoring the implementation of the Code of Conduct and considers that at this stage no change in the code would have prevented cases that are now the subject of special attention by Parliament and public opinion, which does not, of course, prevent us from debating it and making any such or such assessment that the President has also had the opportunity to make known.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Matters relating to conflicts of interest in the case of commissioners-designate or commissioners are an extremely sensitive issue, but at the same time so sensitive and so moving in the imagination of our society that we cannot silence the situations that are taking place and which are also of concern to us. The European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs is required to give an opinion on whether a commissioner-designate actually meets all the requirements relating to the absence of a conflict of interest. The problem is that, in the Committee on Legal Remedies, we do not have in principle any meaningful material on the basis of which we could give such an opinion in a safe way, while ensuring that we actually issue it in earnest. In this regard, we and the European Commission seem to have a great deal of work to do. The Code of Conduct for Commissioners is, of course, an extremely important instrument, but many of the provisions there are very general. We would like to know what the wording of Family interest means? What kind of family or friendly links do a commissioner or current Commissioner have in this broad sense? This would also facilitate the work of the Committee on Legal Remedies. We do not want to be either a prosecutor's office or a court, but we want to do the work that the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament impose on the shoulders of members of the Committee on Legal Affairs in the selection of new Commissioners and the evaluation of the work of the current Commissioners in a very precise and very honest way.  As for current affairs, Le Monde - a very well-read French newspaper - wrote that the reality described in the Bahamas Leaks is a moral betrayal of the elites. I ask what elites? These are possibly criminals, they are not elites. It would seem that such an excellent newspaper as Le Monde should be more precise.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Today we are dealing with two points: conflicts of interest and the Bahamas leaks. What do these two points have to do with each other? They are primarily evidence of obvious system errors. On the one hand, we have high-ranking former representatives of the European Commission, who could actually be expected to have a particular sensitivity – in practice, misreporting – because of the strict rules clearly highlighted by Commissioner Moscovici. On the other hand, as far as Bahamas leaks are concerned, we have countless anonymous letterbox companies which are not illegal per se, but which open the door to criminal activities such as money laundering and tax evasion. We are dealing here with cover-up crime, which is all too often tolerated by the state. In both cases – and this brings the two things together – the consequences are devastating. The citizens out there get the feeling that certain parts of society that are up there are somehow subject to very different rules, different laws than for ordinary consumers. It doesn't matter if this is true in individual cases or not. The feeling spreads. We, as representatives of the people, must take a profound counter-effect to this, because this goes to the pillars of people's acceptance of our system. In other words, as far as the Commission is concerned, of course we have good rules, but they need to be improved and the sanctions must be even tougher. And as far as letterbox companies are concerned, this naturally means that we need clear rules on which countries will be on a tax haven list for us and what effective sanctions are. This is going to be a long fight. But this House has proved in the past that we have a long breath.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Indeed, what is happening in the context of these leaks – be it the "Mossack-Fonseca leaks", or the "Panama leaks" – is undermining citizens' confidence in politics. At the very least, it gives the impression that politicians are incapable of countering the misuse of tax legislation, the leaking of taxpayers' money into any offshore ports. That in itself is bad at a time when we are already seeing a noticeable increase in the distance between politicians and the population and voters. But here in this situation, of course, the situation is even worse in that it was a former Commissioner who was more or less caught up in fresh action, who clearly violated the code of conduct that she herself signed, where she undertook to disclose her potential conflicts of interest. The point that you have not really raised, Mr Moscovici, and where I would ask you to go back to it later, is this: what are we doing about these violations? I do believe that the rules of conduct are well formulated, that attempts have been made to make them as precise as possible – although the honourable Member from the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has rightly noted some room for improvement. But the phenomenon we have is that it is sometimes violated and apparently knowingly violated. The question is: what are the commission's conclusions? What are the sanctions to be imposed? What penalties can be imposed in such situations? I would really like a response from the Commission.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, the difficult situation in which we find ourselves is rooted in the defects and largesse, in view of the confidence that people place in their leaders, enabled by the Commissioners' code of conduct.   The first important element is that the initiative to draft this code of conduct rests with the Commissioners themselves. So they are judges and parties, and from that point of view, that is really not a good thing. Ironically, it was the Barroso Commission itself, which in 2011 was responsible for the revision of the code of conduct. It cannot be said to have been severe.  Second, the call off period is far too short. Currently, it is eighteen months old. Legislation for which commissioners can be influenced by lobby groups has a much longer, much tougher life: three years, five years and sometimes even, as in the case of the NRP, a good ten years. It is therefore imperative to review this period in order to remove any suspicion. The third element, which I think is very important, is that the Commissioners' Code of Conduct establishes an ad hoc ethics committee, but that committee is only advisory. It is before the Commission itself, when it had to be independent and sovereign and had to be able to self-seize. So here are my recommendations. First, to have an independent ethics committee. Second, allow him, as I have just said, to self-seed. Finally, here is the example of what I call a healthy democracy: Canada, an extremely demanding country. Ministers, secretaries of state and parliamentarians are barred from lobbying for five years. It is a commissioner who oversees this matter who makes the law. He was elected by parliament for seven years. This is a democracy. To the good of the hearing...

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – In 2004, many Members of the European Parliament had serious doubts about Mrs Kroes as a Candidate Commissioner. Kroes had become known during her time as Dutch minister because of her not unfortunate friendships with dubious businessmen. The Dutch Parliament had launched an investigation into conflicts of interest, but that was not completed in time before she was already minister. In that sense, I was not surprised that Kroes was connected to a dark enterprise in the Bahamas, whose main task would have been to buy up a piece of the equally dark Enron. But it is serious, especially since Parliament had demanded in 2004 that, as Commissioner for Competition, she no longer had any interest in any company. She solemnly promised this in this House, but it now appears that she had failed to check whether there was an unfinished project somewhere.  But Kroes continues. She has new jobs at Merrill Lynch and Uber, among others. For the first job, she received conditional approval from the Commission's Ethics Committee. For the second job this was no longer necessary because the cooling-off period of 18 months had ended. Kroes can now lobby for that company and she knows her way as ex-Commissioner Digital Agenda. All in all, it's a mess.  I therefore ask the Commission for three specific points: 1. No longer has a conditional approval by the High-Risk Ethics Committee and the strengthening of that committee with fully independent experts; 2. extension of the cooling-off period to three years; 3. Clear guidelines on what integrity and discretion mean for ex-Commissioners, because it is clear that some of them have or do not want to have any notion of this. Finally, in the case of Barroso and Kroes,the Commission must go to the Court of Justice to take away their pension rights. These people no longer deserve an EU pension. They already get enough money through their dubious boyfriends.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, who is doing the most harm to the European project today? Eurosceptics like Mr Farage or Mrs Le Pen or the Eurocynics like Barroso and Mrs Kroes? What is clear is that the former are gaining ground by squenting the anger aroused by the unworthy behaviour of the latter. The more the rulers are won by cynicism, the more populism seduces the governed. By joining The Goldman Sachs Bank, a symbol of all the excesses of finance and a leading player in the 2008 financial crisis, José Barroso further undermined citizens' confidence in the European project. That is why it must be sanctioned. Mr Juncker's decision to refer the matter to the Ethics Committee is far too late and insufficient. We have to go to the Court of Justice.  The scandal that is splattering today Mrs Kroes reminds us that the Barroso case is far from isolated and the cases of Gerhard Schroeder, Tony Blair or Jérôme Cahuzac illustrate that this is not a disease unique to the European institutions.  There is an urgent need to strengthen the rules on conflicts of interest and I would also like to warn the representatives of the Commission and, beyond that, all of us European politicians, both in Brussels and in the Member States: citizens feel - and all too often rightly - that political decisions are increasingly tailored in the interests of big business. The retraining of former commissioners or ministers in the business community or their involvement in tax avoidance strategies only reinforces their suspicion, not to mention the accumulation of political responsibilities with mandates in the private sector, including in this assembly.  Citizens' confidence in their institutions and their elected representatives is the foundation of democracy and we know that this trust is being shaken. Restoring it requires all of us to put the defence of the public interest back at the heart of our action with particular attention to the most fragile and vulnerable among us. Failing that, it is not only Europhobia that will progress, but the very rejection of our democratic institutions.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the title of this debate is 'Conflicts of interest in the European Union'. I laugh, but we should cry on this issue, not least because we assume that we have a President of the Commission, which all the other groups have supported, who is at the head of a tax haven in fact, which has seen more BANK CEOs in the last eighteen years than European citizens. This is President Juncker right now. Then we have Mr Barroso, the previous President, who now finds himself working for Goldman Sachs, coincidentally another bank, another elite, another potentato.  Let us see whether these banks have their seats in tax havens and what the European Commission is doing and what these people are doing, instead of breathing their mouths, legislatively to plug this problem, because banks and large multinationals do what they want and then they also take them on. Then some people may rightly be in doubt that there is a conflict of interest between these people and the large multinationals, the large elites and the banks, and then that the European Union is founded on this, not on the interests of the citizens but on the interests of the strong powers. And I am addressing the Commissioner, because I see someone who is perhaps trying to take this issue out in words, but then, in practice, nothing happens.  The recommendations have always been made in the TAXE and Panama Papers Committee. I would like to thank the investigative journalists who are keeping this media pressure high. However, the credibility of this European Union is zero, with these people continuing to represent us and with these Members continuing to vote for these committees.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the case of the Bahamas Leaks opens up an even more worrying scenario than the Panama Papers. The position of this former Commissioner, Mrs Kroes, who, while threatening tax evaders, was cultivating undeclared interests in banks while acting as director for the period 2000-2009 of an offshore company that is still active today, is truly scandalous. But just as this Commissioner of yours, who sympathised with the citizens who were burdened with taxes and wanted to trigger investigations into the extra profits accumulated by offenders, sat on the bench where you sit, Mr Moscovici, who seems to me to be Alice in Wonderland in this House. But have you ever heard of the secret meetings of Bilderberg, of the trilateral committee in which Presidents of the Commission and Commissioners cheerfully participated and continue to participate, where governments decide, the euro has been decided, has the whole political and economic and financial history been decided? You're all a conflict of interest. This European Union is a monument to conflict of interest and secrecy and non-transparency. Do not take the citizens of Europe by the butt.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, there is no doubt that corruption is a phenomenon that is seen everywhere. It is an inevitable situation that has appeared since antiquity and, unfortunately, still appears even in this day and age: people above suspicion, in prominent positions, with high pay, people who have solved their economic problem for years, surprise the international community with the corruption they indulge in. Recent well-known examples are the cases of current and former Commissioners of the European Union and the Financial Scandal of Bahama Leaks. A characteristic feature of these people is the complete lack of ethical barriers, ethics and a sense of responsibility. Thus, instead of using the high positions they hold for the benefit of those who believed and trusted them, they use those positions to illegally serve their personal interests. An effort must be made to limit the phenomenon because it is impossible to eradicate it. Because just as Caesar's wife must also appear to be honest, as Julius Caesar said, that is why the European Union must also lay down strict rules and limit the phenomenon ... (The President removes the floor from the speaker.)

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, the so-called ‘Bahamas Leaks’ have revealed further information on the world of offshore tax havens. They shed light on a secretive offshore centre which offers anonymity and no taxes on profits, capital gains income and inheritance to companies that register there. The large scale of both the Panama Papers and the Bahamas Leaks has proven that tax evasion is a massive structural problem, which we can only fight if we act together. This requires an effective cooperation between the EU Member States, as well as exerting pressure on tax haven countries to change their tax policies towards more transparency. Anonymity and secrecy cannot be offered if they are used to avoid or evade paying due taxes.  Taking into account the similar schemes revealed by the Panama Papers and the Bahamas Leaks, I welcome the fact that the Bahamas Leaks revelations fall under the competences of the newly established Committee of Inquiry into Money Laundering, Tax Avoidance, and Tax Evasion (PANA). Therefore, I strongly urge the Commission and the Member States to cooperate closely with Parliament and with the PANA Committee in order to more effectively fight tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering. Speeding up the process of setting up a joint list of tax havens will surely be a step in the right direction. The scandalous practices revealed in the Bahamas Leaks have to be stopped.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done.
