I would like to put it right from behind, namely to mention what we need: we need a public business register so that we can understand who is the beneficial owner of companies – in other words, the disclosure of the beneficial owner. If we had had that, it would have been much quicker to see what was going on with Mrs Kroes. In order to prevent a case such as that of Mr Arias Caete in the future, we need a procedure for declaring the Commission's financial interests, which has been improved and which gives us, as the European Parliament, more say here. Whoever becomes a Commissioner or who is a Commissioner must not be incompatible with the job. What do I mean by that? Commissioner Kroes is not a Female of Mars. It has, of course, a professional past – we all have a professional past, but it is important that it has not affected its political decisions. Ms Kroes has now broken the rules by failing to report the company, which was exposed by the Bahamas leaks. We had her successor, Mrs Vestager, here in the last week of Strasbourg when we talked about her Apple decision – a tough decision. And in order for the Commission to be able to take clear, tough decisions, not to deal with tax evaders – as Mrs Kroes has done, for example – we need a Commission that is unbiased and as free as possible.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – The recent cases of Mario Barroso, Neelie Kroes, Conni Hedegaard, as well as president Juncker's previously revealed role in the development of Luxembourg's economy, undermine already deeply damaged confidence in the European institutions. It is difficult to find better examples of the gap between beautiful words and actions guided by the ancient maxim that money does not stink. I would like to give another current example: two of Parliament's rapporteurs dealing with the audiovisual directive are members of the Westdeutsche Rundfunk council. Mrs Kammerevert is even chair of the programme committee of the WDR Board. At a recent public hearing at CULT, however, in the interests of media independence from the political circles, they relied not on their example, and not, for example, on Mr Ruprecht Mannez, a leading CDU politician and, until recently, the long-time chairman of the ZDF television board, but focused on the example of Polish, a notabene country whose media is dominated by German concerns. It is hardly a better example of hypocrisy.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: – Madam President, I hope that the Commission will do its homework regarding the code of conduct and its application, but the Bahamas Leaks revelations are far wider. This confirmed that the Panama Papers were just the tip of a large iceberg; but there is good news as well. This Parliament established a committee of inquiry and there is a strong impetus and political will to eradicate money laundering, tax evasion and tax avoidance.  I think we must explore two main avenues: the way the legislation is implemented and reinforced, and also whether the legislation is efficient, up to the task. When we see how some European depositors reacted to the introduction of the EU Savings Directive by shifting their wealth to tax havens, we may rightly wonder whether the legislation fully addressed the issue. The same goes for the subsequent legal framework on automatic exchange of information. Moreover, automatic exchange is not sufficient if the real owner of the company can remain anonymous.  The public register is a good thing and a necessary one, but again, if the EU is the only one to impose this, money will just go where it is easy to stay off the radar. It is time the EU used its power to impose restrictive measures on the non-complying jurisdictions, but also to team up more with the OECD and other allies in this crusade against shady money flows.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her US President Roosevelt once said, "It is as bad to be governed by organized money as it is by organized crime!" Some Commissioners are always where the big money is. For more and more people, the European Commission is increasingly sounding like European corruption. If there were an excessive deficit procedure for credibility, the Barrosos & Co would be bankrupt. European Commission President Juncker is the godfather of the corporate tax cartel, while the population is groaning under cuts. Ex-Commission President Barroso prostitutes himself at Goldman Sachs. If ex-competition commissioner Neelie Kroes had her sponsors on her body like Formula One, she would be tattooed from top to bottom. Kroes ran a letterbox company in the Bahamas. She wanted to open up the gas market with the Sheikhs and Enron, while she regulated the gas markets in Brussels. Basta, enough is enough. Brussels must deliver, Mr Moscovici! Withdraw Ms Kroes' pension and create harsh sanctions for breaches of the Code of Conduct. We need a strict cooling-off period against the revolving door into the private economy. The lobby register must become legally binding and the Commission's expert groups must meet in public and be well-balanced. Stop bankers writing laws! Thirdly, close the loopholes in the money laundering directive. No more sham directors! If a company cannot name its true owners, it must not have business relations in the EU. Commissioners have to serve the people, not big money!

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Madam President, Mr Moscovici, I have heard your speech and I wonder if we are living in the same reality, because to get along, very clearly, nothing must be changed and everything is fine. Personally, I do not have quite the same feeling and I have the impression that the vast majority of European citizens do not share it either. So why is Barroso's departure at Goldman Sachs so serious? Because it is part of a decade of loss of legitimacy of the European institutions, and of the Commission in particular, which is no longer seen by European citizens as the area of the European general interest, as you well know, but as for the defence of private interests, especially those of the most privileged and the banks. I will simply mention a few names: Mr Romano Prodi, advisor to Goldman Sachs Italy on international issues, who becomes Chairman of the 1999-2004 Commission; Mario Monti, Competition Commissioner in the same Commission, who was hired in 2008 by Goldman Sachs; Mario Draghi, Vice President Europe of Goldman Sachs between 2002 and 2005, who became President of the European Central Bank. Who imagines Mr Delors or Mrs Veil leaving the European Commission and the Presidency to work for a private bank? Solutions exist, contrary to what you said. We need to change things, we need a high independent authority, so that we can stop the Commission as its own peer judge, we need to extend the lengthening of the ban on public-private gateways, and we must provide for exemplary sanctions when commissioners have lied or concealed from the public interests that are at odds with their duties.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Madam President, the enormous rewards at the top of  corporate businesses pose major conflict of interest challenges. Put bluntly, pay packages have become so big that former EU Commissioners have potential access to untold riches after retiring from public service and there is growing concern that future awards may start to impinge on the consciousness of current Commissioners. The position obtained by Mr Barroso with Goldman Sachs is a case in point. Could such a bonanza affect the thinking of a current Commissioner involved in regulating markets? I fear it could. The European Ombudsman has already criticised the Barroso Commission for laxity in this area, calling for a tougher code of conduct. I must advise this Chamber that the growing gulf between the EU and those it governs was a key weapon for people like me in the UK referendum. So, if the ethical arguments for tougher constraints do not sway you, then you might like to contemplate the imperative for self-preservation instead.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, Edith Cresson and the fictitious jobs, Peter Mandelson and Chinese dumping, John Dalli and the tobacco industry, Jean-Claude Juncker and LuxLeaks, Miguel Arias Caete and the Panama Papers, José Manuel Barroso and Goldman Sachs, and now Nelly Kroes and the Bahamas Leaks. As you will have understood, this is not a litany of saints but rather a litany of the unhealthy. Mr Moscovici, this is just an excerpt from the long series of European Commissioners implicated in conflict of interest and corruption scandals before or during their term of office.  Each Commission brings its share of shameful cases. How, after so many scandals, do you still come to believe in the honesty of this Brussels Europe? How can you not see that the aim of this European Commission is to put itself at the service of private global lobbies? You have to be naïve, crazy or treacherous not to face reality. So, of course, you are going to churn out the need for more transparency, more rules, more surveillance, but that is to ignore the problem because the Europe of Brussels is the problem, and these few scandals are just the tree that hides the forest. Want to solve the conflict of interest problem? So put an end to this ultraliberal and corrupt Europe, Mr Moscovici. Give sovereignty back to the states and let them decide their own economic governance in the interests of all their peoples.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Madam President, the principle of independence and integrity is indeed at the heart of the Treaties as regards the behaviour of the members of the Commission. They must carry out their functions by using the general interest of the Union, which is as much as saying to work with loyalty, confidence and transparency. They must certainly refrain from any act that is incompatible with dignity and also with the obligations of their office, during office and after office. In the relevant committees, we have seen that the Code of Conduct could be improved: among other things, make it mandatory and reform it, extending from eighteen to twenty-two months the waiting period for work later, in the post-office period, and also declaring all those goods beyond EUR 10 000, both from the Commissioners and their descendants, and other improvements.  The Commission must therefore be at the forefront of meeting the highest standards of ethics during and after office. There is no doubt that transparency is the oxygen of democracy and this must be the Commission's own identification sign. Today citizens, to trust the institutions, ask for crystal administrations where everything is seen, where we see everything we do, with whom we do it and how we do it.  I have to finish my speech by saying that Mr Cañete scrupulously complied with the Code of Conduct, went beyond the Code, and under no circumstances is there any conflict of interest as far as its management is concerned.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would have liked to have addressed the President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Junker, because he said that Mr Barroso was his friend. Mr Barroso is not my friend. I and others have never voted for him, but I believe that having been President of the Commission implies obligations. Being a commissioner is a huge burden. I am not saying that after you have been a commissioner, you do not have the right to work. But you can't have carried the European general interest and then go and work for Goldman Sachs. I'm not even saying we wouldn't be allowed to go and work for a bank, but for Goldman Sachs? Goldman Sachs is exactly the opposite of the general European interest. We cannot let that pass without saying anything. However, the 18 months say nothing about this point and yet Article 245 - as a little poetry or literature is sometimes introduced into the legal order - says that after the termination of duties, there is a duty of honesty and delicacy. No one can think that Mr Barroso has shown this delicacy. As for Ms. Nelly Kroes, she simply lied. When it was heard by this Parliament in 2004, we had denounced the risk of a conflict of interest. It had been protected by Mr Barroso in the name of the great liberal alliance. Because I believe that the Commission is an essential institution, that we need it to support the European ideal, we ask you to revise the rules, we ask you that a Commissioner ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, commissioners' conflicts of interest relate not only to commissioners, but also to their close friends and assistants. It is naïve to assume that the Commissioners' personal declarations of interest alone are sufficient to create an overall picture of whose pens are used to write legislation here. Lobbyists for big business too often write them, and for their own benefit, of course.  The way in which commissioners' assistants move back and forth to the tasks of business and various interest organisations should also be made more clear.  Significant participants in the preparation of decisions often have access to inside information belonging to the public sector, which should not be traded to large companies that act as counterparties in a moment. This is a clear grievance that should be rectified.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner! Lux Leaks, Panama, Bahamas – all this shows the need for action. This need for action has been known for some time. A study for this Parliament in 2014 in connection with the Code of Conduct for Commissioners stated that while other codes of ethics "help to increase public confidence in the government, the Commission system seems to be geared to the political and career interests of commissioners". Even then, Parliament called for amendments, and it is very urgent that they are now put into practice quickly. Neelie Kroes shows that there has been an offence that has not been uncovered. Parliament did not recognise it, the Commission did not recognise it – it is a question of a lack of control.  However, Mr Barroso and Mr Arias Caete are notable for the fact that the rules are obviously not enough. Experts have long recommended that the rules be changed, and that must be done now. Because the debate here shows that it is otherwise being abused by the extremes to call the system into question, and that must not happen.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Georgieva prepared her application to the United Nations while receiving salary from the European Commission. Barroso formalized his old connection to Goldman Sachs and went from a de facto union to a marriage. Commissioner Cañete, yes, left the oil lobby to come to the Climate and Energy portfolio. And this list is far from exhaustive. There is a registration problem and there is a problem of conflicts of interest, but none of these examples would be solved by the new proposals of the European Commission. We need an intertemporal record with absolute incompatibilities over the break periods and not only for the periods in which they perform the duties, or we will continue to have commissioners coming from industry and industry will return.  The fundamental problem is that no one can serve two masters: it cannot be at the service of financial interests and at the service of citizens' interests at the same time, and therefore, if there are revolving doors, it is because the rooms in these institutions are contiguous.  As long as the Commission is at the service of financial interests and is not at the service of the interests of the public, we will continue to have these commissioners, but on the day it goes to the service of the citizens, I assure you that these Commissioners will not even want to go to the Commission.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Madam President, unfortunately, there have been a number of European Commissioners who have highlighted a personal conflict of interest. In my opinion, we should not simply ask, even if it is desirable, for the Commissioners to be good people, honest people. This is a subjective ethical request. What is urgent is, for example, that, for a few years, after the period of public service, it is impossible, by law, to use social and economic revolving doors and inside information for its own benefit. Political action and public service must be ethically reinforced from within and the right of any citizen, good or bad, to access positions of power and responsibility must be ensured. The responsible exercise of power must be shielded ethically and legally, accessible to all, the good and those who sometimes do not seem so, open to all, but very controlled by law. Yes, what we're discussing is a matter of legal ethics.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today the 5 Star Movement is seven years old. For seven years we have been fighting conflicts of interest between all those politicians who, by abusing their role, are alienating citizens from public institutions. The 5 Star Movement cannot accept this shame! We do not want to be part of a rotten system! Mr Juncker, who is deserting the debate today, the undisputed protagonist of the LuxLeaks case, represents a gigantic living conflict of interests. Cañete, which he chose, is an oil tanker appointed Commissioner for Climate and Energy. But that is the normal practice of the European Commission. Barroso, his predecessor, is now at Goldman&Sachs. Former Digital Agenda Commissioner Kroes has now been appointed a consultant by Uber. I will stop here but the list could be very long. I wonder if Juncker has already thought about his future, what he will do when his term as President is over. Will he return to be a consultant to some tax haven? Will it serve any lobby? Mr President, the citizens of Europe are calling for concrete action. Do not waste time and present us immediately with European legislation on conflict of interest.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Moscovici said: we do not intend to change the rules. There are proposals on this! If the rules had been so good, they would certainly have had to be better controlled. The list of cases is long – it is not just the ones mentioned here, and there are also differences between these cases.  Mrs Kroes lied to Parliament. In the previous 10 years, it had 37 different mandates and presidencies of companies, companies and supervisory boards. She claimed at her hearing in 2004 that she had put everything down – she lied to Parliament! We will certainly use that in the Panama Commeger Committee of Inquiry to listen to them and put it to them. The other cases mentioned here are Mr Barroso, who has met the deadline. You can say: Yes, that with Goldmann Sachs is difficult, but he has complied!  When I hear what Mr de Masi has said, they prostitute themselves. He mentioned the Presidents of the Commission. I remember very well the Vice-President of Eurojust, Carlos Zeyen from Luxembourg, who still had 15 letterbox companies as managing director in Panama in 2014 and who in previous years housed the SED millions of the German left in these letterbox companies. That can be said! To throw this in a pot is, in my consider, irresponsible. That is why I am in favour of tightening up the rules, of holding Mrs Kroes to account, but not for throwing everything possible together now. We will certainly examine it in the Panama Commegation Committee.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – High salaries and, after the end of his functions, compensate Commissioners, Members, Judges and others, they always represent a prevention against lobby pressures and entangles conflicts of interest. As it turns out for many Commissioners, Neelie Kroes, Karla de Gucht, not to mention Barroso, this clearly does not matter, much more: Barroso sits among the Bilderbergs, Kroes has come up with a whole company in a tax haven. How very competitive. What an example for citizens. Two years ago, a citizen horrified to send me a question about viviane reding's conflict of interest, which is now among us. According to the European Commission's Ethics Commission, there was no such conflict. Just as there will be no punishment for Ireland and Apple in the end, because no one is responsible anymore. And tell me, my colleagues, is it really unusual for the European Union to not enjoy any respect anymore?

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. A serious crisis requires a strong and decisive response. I would like to say that I am disappointed with The Words of Commissioner Moscovici, because there is actually no announcement of major reforms on this issue. I am, like many Members, in favour of the new rules being adopted in order to extend the grace period for former Commissioners to at least five years. Mrs Adinolfi and Mr Durand, as well as many others, have spoken about this. Moreover, on this occasion, it is worth saying that the provisions of mr Giegold's draft report are a good role model for healing the situation. I hope that we will soon be voting on this report, which presents a comprehensive way, comprehensive mechanisms for healing the situation, m.in. a coherent register of lobbyists, the need to record the influence of lobbyists in all legislative reports, that is, the legislative footprint, and finally the extended karen periods. This is a good pattern that we should use.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, there is a fundamental and structural first conflict of interest in the European Union. The conflict between the interests that the European Union defends, the interests of the major powers, the major economic groups, the large financial capital, and the interests of the workers and peoples of Europe. All the rest we discuss here are expressions, revelations, if you will, of this fundamental reality. It is now unsurprisingly known today that Barroso was already working for Goldman Sachs when he was still President of the European Commission, as it is known that Draghi continues to work for Goldman Sachs as President of the European Central Bank, but the problem goes far beyond the so-called revolving door. All the legislation adopted in recent years by the European Union in the financial field, just to give an example, has been determined by the interests and direct intervention of the big banks and insurers.  There is no code of conduct capable of changing the matrix, the class nature of this integration process. It will be the struggle of the workers and the peoples to defeat him and to counter him the necessary alternative, in defense of his own class interests.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Madam President, the Bahamas papers revealed again the central role played in the murky global network of tax havens by the British overseas territories, former colonies and the City of London itself. In the first session of our inquiry committee, we heard that the London property market boom feeds on tax avoidance. As with the Panama Papers, another member of the UK Government has been implicated. Our Home Secretary, Amber Rudd, was named as being a Director of two companies in the Bahamas. Secrecy means we actually cannot tell what companies she controlled, what they were doing, how much money she earned and how much tax was actually avoided. This lack of accountability is precisely what tax havens offer and is why people use them. Our Panama Papers Committee is dedicated to shining a light into these dark corners and I will be insisting that Amber Rudd is called before us. The ease with which the Home Secretary was able to avoid answering questions about her involvement in the Bahamas is evidence of the weakness of democratic accountability in the UK. I am glad that we will have a chance to tackle this during our work in the Panama Papers Committee.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: – The Brussels elite has fallen off its pedestal. That is now clear. And if it hadn't been so sad, I'd be laughing. Because actually it's nothing more than a sequel to the famous TV series Dallas. You remember it.  I'm going to walk you by the main characters. Mr. Juncker actually plays the perfect J.R. Ewing, and he doesn't shy away from the glass either. Mrs Neelie Kroes is the fake Sue Ellen and Timmermans, the Vice-President, is the failhaas Cliff Barnes. If I mention these names, I'm sure you'll recognize them again. But let us not forget that the taxpayer pays for this Brussels soap opera, and that is why I propose to fill the offices in Brussels and Strasbourg with cameras, so that the hard-working Dutch people can enjoy the scheming and the intrigue.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Whoever had the idea for a joint debate had a bad idea. Because touching everything into each other does not mean that things will get better. Commissioner, I would like you to have an influence in changing and tightening up the code of conduct. The Last time the European Parliament called for this was in April this year. The Committee on Budgetary Control has carried out two studies – comparative studies, in 2009 and 2015 – and these comparative studies clearly show that the Code of Conduct is not the best that the world has ever seen, but still has some room for improvement. We must use this air upwards – in the interests of the cause. The Barroso I Commission ended in 2009, and all but one commissioner have been hired as lobbyists. The Barroso II Commission is now facing the same step. And every time a new Commissioner takes office – and it is not the case that the buck is turned into a gardener here, but the gardener becomes a buck – there is a new outcry, a new outrage. This Commission can and must do something, and above all you must also do something in the area in which you have already acted, namely the ad hoc Ethics Committee. There has never been an ad hoc ethics committee, which has been so strongly influenced by the Commission itself, which includes people who are still active for Commissioners. This has never happened before! There has never been such a low level of independence. The Juncker Commission is sending out a very bad signal here. If this continues, we will have to reckon with all sorts of other things. That's why you act as long as you can still act yourself!

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Madam President, combating tax evasion and tax havens is a top priority for the European Union. In the last two years, much has been achieved in this fight. However, the European Union also needs to be seen to act.  At present, a number of high-profile cases involving Mr Barroso and Mrs Kroes are overshadowing this important fight. When former top commissioners are discovered to be linked to overseas tax havens, and the global financial companies that benefit from them, the EU’s credibility takes a justified hit. The EU cannot be seen as having double standards.  The Bahama Leaks teach us two lessons: first of all we need to increase our efforts in combating tax havens. Information provided by whistle-blowers and investigative journalists ought to have been freely available to all European authorities. It is our duty as European politicians to ensure that happens in the future through new legislation to end the world of secrecy, fraud, corruption and tax evasion, and put real pressure on tax havens.  Secondly, when it comes to our own procedures to avoid potential conflict of interest, we must be honest: they are not good enough. In the case of former Commissioner Kroes, the fact that she was a director of a holding company in the Bahamas only came to light after she had retired from the Commission. That proves that the vetting process for Commissioners simply is not working.  Therefore I am calling for a review of the current vetting procedures and for clear sanctions for Commissioners, present and former, that fail to live up to these standards.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, the former Commissioner for Competition, Neelie Kroes, was during her tenure as director of a firm based in a tax haven, without this position ever appearing in her declaration of interests. The former President of the European Commission, Mr Barroso, accepted a position for Goldman Sachs, one of the banks that made a major contribution to the financial crisis. Examples are many. How do we explain this to European citizens? Where's the limit? These people use the relationships they have created during their tenure and the information they have during their tenure, sometimes confidential. The question arises: when were these links created between senior European officials and the industries in which they are then employed? It seems obvious to me that they were created during their mandates. We do not have a binding code of conduct for senior dignitaries. There must be at least a three-year ban on holding positions in the industries for which they have taken decisions during their term of office in the Commission. Today, the deadline is eighteen months and has no sanction.  So we need sanctions - if they don't have ethics, we need sanctions and the sanction can only be the elimination of the pension or the reduction of the pension.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, the Bahamas Leaks show that corrupt officials and politicians are not only resisting action against tax evasion and avoidance, but they are directly engaging in these practices. It is disappointing from my point of view, but not surprising, that some Irish links have been exposed here. For example, billionaire Denis O’Brien is linked to a property development in the Caribbean. His associates are acting as directors of six different companies in this tax haven. Denis O’Brien can use his control over large sections of the Irish media, along with his enthusiasm for launching lawsuits, to intimidate those who would dare make public statements about his business dealings in order to prevent those same dealings being scrutinised.  These leaks again highlight the urgent need for transparency on shell companies which are at the rotten core of the offshore scam. All countries must ensure that full registers of beneficial ownership of offshore companies, foundations and trusts are in place and open to public scrutiny. But that in itself will not be enough. We need to close the loopholes of having nominee directors of companies and dividing up company ownerships, which are used to hide the true owners. Only then can we begin to say that we have learned the lessons from these leaks.

name: Eva JOLY
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Juncker's passivity in the face of the scandal endangers the legitimacy of the institution he chairs. The Barroso and Kroes cases had the effect of a bombshell in public opinion, similar to the Cahuzac case in France.  Some flaws in the system appear in the eyes of all. However, the Commission dare not move, to the point of continuing to work, as if nothing had happened, on an anti-Leaks plan.  You put yourself in an untenable and deleterious situation. Stop defending an opaque operation that no longer preserves the interests of institutions, but promotes conflicts of interest. It is time to put the European Union up to date on transparency, by tackling the slipper without trembling, by normalising wide access to documents, particularly in the context of our committees of inquiry, and by creating, finally, a high independent authority to monitor the financial interests of Commissioners and parliamentarians capable of investigating and bringing the matter to justice. As you well know, she's proven herself in France.  Show us that you have nothing to hide. Stop playing the game of widespread distrust.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, as has been said already, we are dealing with two separate issues. On the first one, I believe that concerning the rules for Commissioners and top rank officials we need clear, strict but also balanced rules, but on top of that we need two other ingredients. The first is common sense and a sense of responsibility in those in question, and also those who are nominating them. And obviously, like in Europe, we always need enforcement of the rules. That is the weak point of our system.  Concerning the information about tens of thousands of offshore accounts in interesting places, held by interesting people with interesting amounts of money, as I said last time, this clearly just underlines the urgency of the tasks that are already underway for some time now. We need to learn more. The question of the balance of illegal, immoral and legitimate activity is still not clear to me but what is obvious is that two key components in the fight against this phenomenon include the programme of beneficial ownership and automated exchange of information on bank accounts. The second one, developed by the OECD, is already underway and will be implemented very soon. We must understand that with this tool it is not only important that we implement it in the EU, but that we force the others to do so. We should not hesitate to use our economic and political tools to achieve it.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, trust underpins democracy. Unfortunately, it builds hard and is lost very easily. People trust us, the chosen ones, to represent them properly, not to fall prey to group interests and to decide in the general interest, based on our own beliefs. This principle also applies to European Commissioners. Commissioners are at the heart of the European administrative apparatus, but they are and must remain accountable to citizens. That is why I think it is important that we, who are voted in the European Parliament, better regulate the system of conflicts of interest to ensure that integrity, reputation, but, above all, trust in the European institutions remain unswed. We are not talking here about a one-off case, we are not just talking about Barroso, Cañette and Kroes. It is about the need for everyone, including the Commissioners, to be clear. Officials do indeed have a professional life before becoming dignitaries, but it is important to realize that occupying a public office requires mostly responsibilities. That is why I am convinced that together we will find the legal framework that can transparently regulate the conflict of interest concerning European Commissioners.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Barroso's case outraged us all. Besides, going to work at Goldman Sachs, a company that is at the center and starred in the big financial scam, is really deplorable. But also very worryingly the lack of response on the part of the European Commission, I have to say. Sending this to the Ethics Committee is a totally inadequate response. They should have already gone to the Court of Justice and initiated the proceedings to suspend their pension; was the least that could be done.  And we need to strengthen legislation on combating conflict of interest. Make a new code, have a new committee with many more competencies and capabilities and extend the period in which ex-notaries cannot work on such activities for at least three years.  But look, there's one urgent thing you have to do: conflict of interest is at home, and it's called "Mr. Arias Cañete." The Commission will not be credible in this area until Mr Arias Cañete resigns as Commissioner because other words the Commission will never be taken seriously in the fight against conflicts of interest.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, in my opinion, the Commissioner should be impartial and disinterested. However, what we are seeing, these cases, to some extent, can undermine the confidence of European citizens in the representatives of the European Union and, of course, in the institutions of the European Union. And I would like to stress here that the European Union is falling and standing on the trust of citizens in its institutions. However, we must distinguish. Mrs Kroes' case, in my view, violates the rules that have been laid down, we must, of course, hear it, but this case does not raise doubts in me.  As far as Mr Barroso is at large, I must say that, formally, I consider that he has not broken the rules that have been laid down, but in my view he has breached the moral obligations arising from the high office thus performed. A company in a tax haven and working with such an important world company right after the end of this withdrawal period, I think that undoubtedly raises questions from the point of view of ethical standards. And that is what we should be responding to. We should further deepen the regulation of conflicts of interest, we should refine our code of ethics.  I would also like to draw attention to national politicians who are 'teed' to various tax havens. I believe that these undermine trust in their citizens as well. This may be a debate that doesn't belong here, but we also have to point it out.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: Madam President, Commissioner, you know, in almost all cases, the lack of transparency and therefore any conflicts of interest go hand in hand with the existence of tax havens. That's the obvious thing. We hide things to make more and more money.  How many revelations about tax evasion of the richest will be needed to finally take strong action at all levels? Indeed, beyond the immorality of these practices, our states are doubly penalized. Every year, as you know, tax evasion deprives the government of EUR 1 trillion in revenue, so much money that will not be invested in health, employment, education or security. This is unbearable, at a time when more and more efforts are being demanded of the weakest, and at a time when mass layoffs are multiplying in Europe.  It has been said, of course, that the behaviour of Mrs Kroes and Mr Barroso must be strongly condemned, which once again casts blame on Europe. But, beyond their cases, all fraudsters, as well as banks and tax advisers of all stripes, who facilitate tax evasion and who therefore fight against transparency and promote conflicts of interest - conflicts of interest that they are, moreover, the first to bear by being, at the same time, advisers to the Commission, advisers to the Member States and advisers to the Member States. One day, however, the question of how to solve this problem will have to be addressed.  In particular, we need to achieve a country by country public reporting to finally get some transparency about the profits of these multinationals. The measures that have been advocated by this Parliament to combat tax erosion must also be applied, rather than postponed until 2024, as the Council has called for. Then, when the Bahamas Leaks affair broke out, they said that nothing could be done and that it was because of Europe.  It is all on the table of Parliament and the Commission. Europe must act quickly. Let's be brave!

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Today we are debating the issue of the Commission's code of conduct and the risk of conflicts of interest. Is it a problem that there is a revolving door between the European Commission and large companies? Is there a risk that political decisions could be affected by EU Commissioners thinking about how it might affect their ability to make money after leaving their political career? Do we have a sufficiently strong regulatory framework?  The answers to these questions give themselves. The more power a politician has, the greater the risk of conflicts of interest, and the sharper the regulatory framework to prevent conflicts of interest we must have. This regulatory framework needs to be improved. We need to make sure that the loopholes in the regulatory framework are closed, because it is quite lax in some places right now. We need to ensure that we improve control with an active and independent ethics committee that has the right to take its own initiative. And we need to extend the withdrawal period to at least three years before a European Commissioner can engage in lobbying.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Without a doubt: the "Bahamas leaks" need consistent preparation. As with the Panama Leaks, we must draw our conclusions from this – in legislation and in international cooperation. The special committee on tax rulings that has already been concluded, then our committee of inquiry into the Panama Papers that has just been set up, and also the Economic and Monetary Committee, which has just been set up, have and are aimed at uncovering tax avoidance and tax evasion practices and closing loopholes.  We have already worked specifically on legislation for this, and we are continuing to work on legislation for this. But, Commissioner, we need the Commission's full commitment and consistent action – and even more so the action of the Member States. This is a renewed call to do so, and we will not tire of reminding you of it. We must work together to strengthen our credibility. What is clear is that the system for identifying the beneficial owners must work better. The Bahamas leaks have shown this once again. Otherwise, Mrs Kroes would not have been able to lie to us.  It is also clear, however, that it is above all the competent authorities in the Member States that must be given effective powers. Indeed, a general call for public transparency does not guarantee us that the system will work. It is the national authorities that must be given the means and the political mandate to identify the beneficial owners and, above all, must implement their decisions actively, including at international level.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Madam President, we would like to be able to say that the Bahamas Leaks, like Mrs Kroes' case, are isolated cases, regrettable but marginal breaches of ethics and fairness. Unfortunately, the facts prove otherwise. In this context, I must say that it is a bit shocking to hear that all of this is a matter of personal morality, because our conception of law, of transparency cannot be variable geometry.  Nevertheless, Mrs Kroes, to speak only of herself, is suspected of serious facts: tax evasion, deliberate lies about the representation of European citizens, false statements, a clear conflict of interest between her private activities and her public responsibilities. I ask you a question: in what democracy would it be acceptable for a person suspected of such acts not to be brought to justice? So if we want to hear Mrs Kroes in the Panama Papers Committee of Inquiry, the Commission must refer the cases of Mr Kroes and Mr Barroso to the Court of Justice.  We need to review the rules, which are far too vague, on the definition of conflicts of interest, which must be more precise, on the powers of control of Parliament, which must be greater, and on the penalties incurred, which must be more severe.  It is at this price that we will regain the confidence of European citizens.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, the hiring of the former President of the Commission by Golden Sachs, the Cañete case and the concealment of offshore interests by former Commissioner Kroes fuel the Europhobic populist discourse because they fuel the just mistrust and anger of citizens. It is unacceptable for Barroso to continue to receive a pension paid by taxpayers while serving Goldman Sachs, which he visited in 2013 when he was President of the European Commission. An ad hoc ethics committee is not enough. The Barroso case must go to the Court of Justice.  It is necessary to strengthen rules on revolving doors between the public and private sectors, to extend periods of disgust and incompatibilities. Sanctions for breaching the most basic rules of transparency and ethics are needed, detailed records of the financial interests of lobbyists and advisers are needed with the Commission, Parliament and the Council.  The measures proposed by the European Commission are manifestly insufficient. Restoring citizens' confidence requires firm and radical reform. In the European Parliament's committee of inquiry into the Panama Papers and Bahama Leaks, we will work on this.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I too was very surprised and negatively surprised at how some members of the Commission commented on events such as Mrs Kroes' and even earlier that of Mr Barroso. What we are discussing here are facts that take away the credibility of the European institutions. That is why we must comment, but critically, and above all we must take action to restore credibility and no longer fall under conditions such as the current ones.  That is why I believe that courageous but rapid choices are also essential. The first is to rewrite the code of conduct. That is not enough, as has been said several times, even in this debate. It must be written by an independent committee, to which it must also reserve the possibility of autonomous intervention, and sanctions in the event of violations must be very heavy in order to have not only a relationship with the violation of the law that has been exercised, but also a deterrence effect that in these cases is worth a lot. Finally, I believe that the period of suspension, between the end of the activity and the beginning of a new professional cycle, must be absolutely extended. I would add, however, that perhaps lengthening the time alone is not enough. For Commissioners who have carried out specific functions, certain areas will have to be closed in on their subsequent work, if not even the time that is running out may not be sufficient.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Neelie Kroes was furious in April 2014, when Belgium banned Uber. "Show your anger!" she exclaimed in a blog. It was recently announced that the same Neelie Kroes will join Uber's advisory board. Commissioners must avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest, and so should former Commissioners. That is bad for the European Commission. That is bad for the standing of the European Union. Last week it was also announced that Neelie Kroes has concealed a position for this Parliament. That's what the Bahamas Leaks showed. Retroactively, Therefore, I would like to respond to that 'Show your anger!' call and, together with 45 other Social Democrats, I have complained to the European Commission about this behaviour and the adjustments that are needed. I would therefore like to hear from the Commissioner what the response is to the complaint we have made.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, like so many of us, I was shocked and appalled when I saw that the former Commission President Barroso was going to work for Goldman Sachs, one of the banks that was implicated in causing the financial and eurozone crisis. There is no doubt that history will judge this as a disgraceful cynical move.  I am very glad that the EU Ombudsman, and now the European Commission, have listened to citizens and Commission staff petitions and concerns about this, and that they are now investigating the case. There is no doubt that the Commission needs to tighten its ethics rules for Commissioners and now is the time. It is also an opportunity for citizens to get involved in EU politics and speak up; to call out conflict of interests and corruption where it is manifested. The EU belongs to its citizens, and has the democratic tools to listen to those concerns and to investigate and penalise Mr Barroso. I will continue to pursue this case and will continue to call for transparent and clean politics in the UK and in the EU.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the Code of Conduct for Commissioners, as defined in 2011, obliges them to declare all the financial or assets that may lead them to a conflict of interest, just as has been the case with the former President of the Commission, Barroso, who has now found itself at Goldman Sachs. Juncker's case in relation to LuxLeaks is also well known. The Panama Papers, the Bahama Papers and LuxLeaks have demonstrated the involvement of political persons with financial interests in order to exempt multinationals from tax and tax evasion.  However, not all of the European Parliament's recommendations on statements of the Commissioners' financial interests are included in the code of conduct, so it is not clear which elements will lead to a conflict of interest. Furthermore, there are no penalties for certain breaches of the Code of Conduct. Therefore, we currently need effective European Union legislation to close this wound.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, the engagement of ex-Commissioners as advisers in multinational financial companies such a short time after they held office does cause rage. The engagement of ex-President Barroso at Goldman Sachs and that of Connie Hedegaard at Volkswagen constitute scandalous moves, which are happening in dramatic times in Europe and can only provide further ammunition for populist and extremist Europhobe propaganda.  European leaders on every level are supposed to give some kind of example of ethical behaviour. I firmly believe that the EU conflict of interest rules need to be tightened. We need strict and clear rules on the quarantine period, as well as ethical rules on quarantine. Commissioner, if there is outrage out there, then the quarantine period is too short. The lack of clear and balanced rules and the lack of explanation as to why this is so will cause strong distrust among our citizens, and that will only grow. We have to plug the leak now, as soon as possible.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Madam President, letting the former President of the Commission hire an American investment bank, which is facing accusations that its activities have contributed to the two biggest crises in the European Union, is a crying arrogance. And I even find the way he has approached legitimate criticism disgusting.  Mr Barroso should, at least until the matter is investigated, be deprived of all the benefits and annuities he receives from the European Union as a retired President of the Commission, barring the possible criminal consequences. As is currently the case, the GUE/NGL faction is asking the Council and the European Commission in the case of the former Dutch Commissioner Kroes. These two cases clearly show only that 'something rotten is in the Kingdom of Denmark' and that therefore the centre of interest for both former and current Commissioners is not resolved at all.  Commissioner, I'm disappointed in you. What your predecessors did is amoral, and I hope it's criminal. What you're doing is you don't care. According to your speech, no doubt.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – We must all be determined in this fight against the conflict of intress, both by the Commission and by Parliament and other competent authorities. And these examples that we are talking about today, which we have talked about in the past, also point to both the Bahamas Leaks and the Panama Papers. But interestingly, these affairs were leaked out with the help of journalists, with the help of so-called whistleblowers. Perhaps we are under-aware of the role of these whistleblowers and are not actually sufficiently protected. I think there is also an appropriate criticism here that we have not done enough to protect whistle-blowers and that, in addition to, of course, this protection, we must also strengthen the so-called code of conduct, including the rules that apply in the event of a conflict of interest. And so we also have bodies that should already be working in these areas, but here the criticism can be quite justified, and I am also thinking of OLAF. And I think we all need to do more in this area.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you for this debate, and I have of course heard the concerns expressed in this House, of which I know - I belong to a political commission, its president is a politician and we are politicians - that it also reflects many questions, questions and sometimes reactions in public opinion. Through all this there is a lot of emotion and I can feel them. There are convictions that exemplarity and transparency are not divided and reduced, that we should not compromise with that, and I totally share these convictions. There may be, here or there, this or that excess, which I can understand and that I would like to see a little more moderate. While it is true that certain situations are questionable and discussed, we must always - we are in systems of law - respect people and their right to assert their rights. I would also like us here in this Chamber to avoid amalgamations, attacks or the risk of weakening an institution in the name of this or that behaviour. I would like to see my very deep feeling that we avoid always shooting the Brussels pianist, because the European Commission, which is your interlocutor, particularly on the subject of the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, is an institution that does more than many others, not only in this area, but also to preserve the ethics and guarantee that of its members and former members. Again, let us be able to distinguish what can be dealt with in a particular individual case, which must be dealt with without damaging, weakening or even smearing this institution which is clean and beautiful. I would like to reaffirm the Commission's desire to apply and enforce the highest standards of political and ethical behaviour in the exercise of its responsibilities, but also to shed light on the behaviour of its former members which would contravene the rules or have contravened the rules in force and take the appropriate measures. That is a commitment made by the president, and I say it very clearly on his behalf. In fact, believe me, President Junker , I spoke with him when I came here to defend this position before you, is the first to regret that the situations you have mentioned are currently the subject of such discussions. In this context, the President, since it is part of his prerogative, has taken the necessary steps at his disposal. He asked for an explanation when he felt that this should be done and consulted the ad hoc ethics committee on the basis of these explanations on two cases involving members of the previous Commission. When the opinions of the ad hoc ethics committee come to us, they have been requested, the Commission will discuss it and decide what appropriate action to take. You have seen , as I said in my opening remarks - that these decisions are still being respected, and the Commission will, of course, go in that direction. President Juncker is committed to keeping this Parliament fully informed on the outcome of these individual issues. Again, I was saying that we must also respect the right of individuals to assert their rights. We have treaties that set obligations, a code of conduct to enforce them, and an ethics committee that we have to trust. The notions of honesty and delicacy, which Mrs Bérès referred to, are included. These concepts, which apply not only for the 18-month period, but also for the entire duration of life, are not in fact meaningless and should not be so for men and women who may, at some point, have the honour of holding office in the Commission, even if, subsequently , we cannot wish for lives to be fossilised or frozen - they can take over or exercise political or professional activities in the private sector.  In conclusion, I believe that we should not turn the problems posed by the members of the previous Commission into an amalgamation of the Commission and Parliament. Let us not use material errors or personal choices that may be regrettable for questioning rules that will, in any case, never govern or determine the solution of this type of situation. The rules of the treaty and the code of conduct are firm. They represent standards, I repeat, that go far beyond what is applied in the majority of Member States or in all the other European institutions. The Commission is committed to applying them with the necessary rigour and transparency towards this Parliament.  We will, of course, be attentive to the debates which will take place on these subjects, in your chamber, and we will give our full support, including the work of the PANA committee. I have already declared myself available to come before her, both to deal with these issues, but also and above all to discuss what is the very substance of the policy that we must - Parliament and the Commission, together - lead, which we must also push towards the Member States and which must be a policy of fiscal transparency First of all. From this point of view, and I repeat, you have an ambitious and bold Commission in front of you. Exemplarity and transparency will always be the two watchwords of the Juncker Commission.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – The Socialists have strongly denounced the behaviour of former Commissioners Durao Barroso for their signing at Goldman Sachs and Neelie Kroes, who combined her role as European Competition Commissioner with that of administrator of an offshore company based in the Bahamas from 2000 to 2009. These are intolerable and immoral behaviour, from the point of view of political ethics, and that is why we have asked the Commission to amend the codes of conduct of the College of Commissioners and urged it to go to the Court of Justice of the European Union in the face of a possible breach of the obligations of independence and integrity required by the Treaties. In addition, we have denounced the serious disclosures contained in the so-called "Bahamas Leaks", which account for 1.3 million publicly available files with the details of opaque corporate records, which lead to tax avoidance, and reveal the names of directors and owners of more than 175,000 Bahamas companies, trusts and foundations registered between 1990 and early 2016. These leaks involve many former senior officials, foreign dignitaries and their families, and show that the lack of parence that characterizes The Bahamas' jurisdiction is a very worrying fact.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. I have spoken several times on the subject of tax transparency and conflict of interest, and each time I am embarrassed to have to defend the European institutions against those who should protect them. The echoes of the LuxLeaks and Panama Papers scandals, which we are witnessing, as if it were a domino effect, in the Bahamas, have not yet been suppressed.  It is no coincidence that the issue of tax transparency is combined with the commissioners' conflict of interests, but a necessary distinction must be made on this: one problem is the violation of the Commission's code of conduct, which prevents any external activity in constant mandate, another thing is to contribute to 'real damage to the image', announcing that work will be done, after the mandate, on influential consultancy firms.  The cases must be combated by different legal and political remedies, by revling the internal code of conduct and inserting a 'vacatio' after the mandate, but first of all we need the awareness that the fight against tax fraud and evasion in Europe is fought from within the European institutions themselves.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The Socialists have strongly denounced the behaviour of former Commissioners Durao Barroso for their signing at Goldman Sachs and Neelie Kroes, who combined her role as European Competition Commissioner with that of administrator of an offshore company based in the Bahamas from 2000 to 2009. These are intolerable and immoral behaviour, from the point of view of political ethics, and that is why we have asked the Commission to amend the codes of conduct of the College of Commissioners and urged it to go to the Court of Justice of the European Union in the face of a possible breach of the obligations of independence and integrity required by the Treaties. In addition, we have denounced the serious disclosures contained in the so-called "Bahamas Leaks", which account for 1.3 million publicly available files with the details of opaque corporate records, which lead to tax avoidance, and reveal the names of directors and owners of more than 175,000 Bahamas companies, trusts and foundations registered between 1990 and early 2016. These leaks involve many former senior officials, foreign dignitaries and their families, and show that the lack of parence that characterizes The Bahamas' jurisdiction is a very worrying fact.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. There was José Manuel Barroso who left for Goldman Sachs. There is Neelie Kroes, former Commissioner for the Digital Economy and Competition, who moved to Uber, who is also an employee of Merrill Lynch, and who has conveniently "forgotten" - oops! - that she continued to run a company based in the Bahamas while she was commissioner. There is also Connie Hedegaard, former climate commissioner, recently hired by Volkswagen. Where will the list end?  Many speakers denounced the weaknesses of a code of conduct for Commissioners, established by themselves. Mr Moscovici, adding his cynicism to that of his former colleagues, explained to us why this code will not be changed. I disagree. It has to be. And that, on a clear and not retroactive basis, actual sanctions should be imposed. They are currently derisory: it is only a matter of depriving people of their pension who in any case earn ten times more in their new positions.  I propose to add a form of banishment in extreme cases: neither they nor the firms that employ them should be on the list of authorized lobbies and have access to the European institutions. This should singularly reduce their attractiveness.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. – The European Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, as a body with a monopoly on the submission of legislative initiatives and with significant executive powers, as an institution performing its function in full independence in the general interest of the Union. Even so, Article 17 of the Treaty on European Union describes the European Commission and its activities. I would like to ask, where has the grandeur that the Treaty forming the basis of the current European Union, and the fathers of European integration, have done? European citizens, the taxpayers that make the Functioning of the Union possible, have recently witnessed the unattemed but undeniably lucrative professional transfer of the former President of the Barossa Commission to Goldman Sachs. It has now emerged that former Dutch Commissioner Neelie Kroes, currently responsible for the digital agenda and competitiveness currently operating at Bank of America, Uber and others, will leave an even bigger stain on the former Commission's report card. Now that we find out that Neelie Kroes is also on the Bahamas papers list, it just seems like the surreal icing on the cake. I am not saying that we must ban former Members of the Commission from operating in the private sphere across the board. However, we must not allow their former functions to be abused. If the Commission does not reform the code of conduct to minimise conflicts of interest, this means a mockery of us MEPs, but also of European citizens.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. – José Manuel Barroso led the European Commission at the time of the financial crisis with dramatic effects on the euro area and its individual countries. The measures proposed or actively supported by the Commission at the time are still viewed very controversially. It is therefore clear that Barroso's subsequent involvement in one of the largest and most influential banks is at least embarrassing. Brussels institutions are often criticised for their low resilience to various lobbying interests. In the case of commissioners and commissioners, any suspicions or associations with interest groups are perceived all the more difficult. I am speaking out for a much clearer adjustment of the rules in relation to benefits after leaving office and probably a longer period of time. However, I am afraid that a perfect arrangement that, in addition to personal integrity, would prevent potential conflicts of interest between former Commissioners and Commissioners will be very difficult to find.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – It is clear that, after the end of their mandate, past Commissioners retain influence and connections from their previous position. The Commission offers them a very generous transitional allowance so that they can preserve their integrity, but unfortunately a considerable number of past Commissioners have given in to the temptation of monetising their influence; this phenomenon being so widespread that it already has a name, the ‘revolving door’. Siim Kallas was allowed by the Commission to take up the position of special advisor to Commissioner Dombrovskis, and a position in the private software company Nortal. Although Kallas had a duty to refrain from lobbying the Commission on Nortal’s behalf, he had, in his position as an advisor, unfettered access to the Commission while being on the payroll of a company on whose behalf he theoretically couldn’t lobby. During his first term as Commissioner he set up the European Transparency Initiative which eventually led to the first lobby register. In an ironic twist of fate the same man who once helped to create the transparency rules and lobby registry was simultaneously advisor to the Commission and on the payroll of a private company, which wasn’t even in the transparency register.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – In the first half of the year, the Society of Investigative Journalists revealed the first set of documents on tax evasion and money outs to tax havens. At the time, Panama was on the attack. We have recently received another disclosure. This time in the Bahamas, with thousands of names of individuals who used the Bahamas to avoid paying taxes. The list includes former competition commissioner Neelie Kroes. And it seems she has failed to do so before she took office as Commissioner. This is a conflict of interest, and the former Commissioner must therefore accept full responsibility. At the same time, I would like to emphasise one more fact. We will not get rid of tax evasion only through forced mechanisms. There is also a leap in the mindset. But a leap like that will take a lot more will than we have today. And that won't happen overnight, especially if we keep getting acquaoise with such high-ranking officials.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Written. Barroso and Kroes have clearly shown that there is a major problem with the moral compass of these ex-Commissioners. They may argue in their defence that they have followed the rules of 2 years of 'defluice', this is really a weakness bid. Their behaviour clearly goes against the spirit of the code of conduct and makes clear a glaring lack of decency and common sense. Moreover, practices such as these undermine citizens' confidence in the European institutions. Commissioners must always put the interests of citizens first and act accordingly, even after their mandate. Transparency, including about their financial interests, is crucial. Conflict of interest is unacceptable. I therefore call for a tightening and clarification of the code of conduct for members and former members of the European Commission. If they themselves do not have a moral compass, strict and unambiguously clear rules must take over this role.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: – The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the situation in Calais (2016/2897(RSP)).

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in April we already had an exchange of views in this Chamber on the impact of the migration crisis in the European Union, particularly on the transport sector. We are all acutely aware of the many challenges posed by migration flows, including in Calais. Together with Commissioner Bulc, we take this issue very seriously, and we want to find sustainable and viable solutions to ensure, first, the normal crossing of borders for people and goods in Calais and, secondly, to improve the management of migration flows in this area and the living conditions of the migrants present.  We must bear in mind that the Franco-British border is an external border of the Schengen area. For this reason, specific bilateral agreements were concluded between France and the United Kingdom, such as the Le Touquet agreement in 2003. We recognise the desperation of migrants, who are trying to board trains or lorries to get to the UK, but their attempts are clearly having a negative effect on the transport sector. Eurotunnel informed us that, compared to the first half of 2015, there was a 43% decrease in the number of freight trains and the amount of freight transported in the first two quarters of 2016.  We continue to work with all stakeholders on two issues. On the one hand, securing the transport of goods and people and, on the other hand, managing the humanitarian and migratory situation. Ladies and gentlemen, while the maintenance of public order and security is France's responsibility on its national territory, our aim is for the passage of people and goods across the border to function normally. For example, over the past summer, the Commission has taken exceptional measures to reduce the impact on the transport sector. We have allowed the UK to temporarily deviate from the rules on the working hours of road drivers. This allowed drivers to wait in a safe parking spot to rest. In the summer of 2015, the Commission wrote to the French and British authorities. We called on them to install safety equipment as quickly as possible at transport facilities near Calais. We also called on the French and British authorities to better coordinate their police and customs forces to improve the efficiency of border controls and reduce congestion. This reduces the risk of migrants getting inside trailers. As a result, the number of illegal intrusions into transport terminals has decreased dramatically. According to Eurotunnel, there were fewer than 17,500 interceptions this year up to September. This figure should be compared to the 80,829 interceptions that took place during 2015. However, I am sure I have recently seen television reports showing that the migrant problem had moved away from transport terminals in Calais. Stowaways are present in truck-only parking lots, sometimes several hundred kilometres from Calais. In this regard, the Commission's services are preparing recommendations for the road freight transport sector in order to better secure vehicles of all types against unauthorized intrusion. We will consult widely with stakeholders. I hope to be able to present these documents at the end of the spring of next year.  The French authorities have had to deal with the security situation and migration issues. They deployed police forces and moved migrants near Calais to centres across the country. In this regard, the Commission welcomes the intention of the French authorities to dismantle the Calais "jungle" by the end of the year. We are convinced that this will help improve living conditions. This is necessary in particular to improve the plight of many unaccompanied minors who are present in Calais. The dismantling of the un organised camp around Calais must be accompanied by the proper application of EU asylum rules for those in need of protection and rules on the return of those who do not have a legal right of residence. At the same time, the situation in Calais demonstrates that the sources of migration need to be better managed within the framework of joint action and a common emigration policy. In this context, as you know, the Commission has proposed a major measures to improve the management of migrant flows and combat migrant trafficking. These measures have already significantly reduced the flow of migrants across Europe.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. It is now the third or fourth time that we have spoken about the problems in Calais today. I am grateful to the Commissioner on the one hand for his overview and his efforts to solve this problem, but I must tell you that I do not think it is sufficient on behalf of the PPE Group. There's a great human drama going on there. There are currently more than 10 000 illegal asylum seekers in the relevant department of France. President Hollande has said that he wants to resolve it before 1 January 2017 and I would at least ask the Commissioner, both Commissioners - because I see that Mrs Bulc has now been pushed - that they, in consultation with the French Government, should also abolish this so-called jungle.  I know it's not just a French problem. There are illegal asylum seekers from all over Europe, which is why, of course, the Commissioner is responsible for this, but it cannot go on like this. Transporters from all over Europe are extremely affected by these aggressive people who are desperate and who are trying to come to Britain. That is why I am pleased with Hollande's commitment, but I do hope that the European Commission will also help France to solve this problem.  Finally, Mr President, we also have Brexit and the reliability of European transport. That's something we have to pay attention to. There is a lot of transport to Great Britain. This is largely done through the Eurotunnel. This must be able to happen on time and it is actually unacceptable for this to happen at our external border.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: – There will be no blue cards during this debate.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Avramopoulos, Commissioner Bulc, Calais is not just France, Calais is Europe. It is Europe not only because it belongs to it geographically, but above all because what is happening in Calais reflects in miniature what is happening in other places in Europe. In Calais we must reconcile security and humanity. Security for all, Europeans and foreigners, who have the right to live and grow up in safe places, not to have to bow to human traffickers, not to live in shacks or bins, to be able to trade freely. The decision by François Hollande'French Government to brutally close what is brutally referred to as the 'Calais Jungle', what a bad name! Concern for security, if it is not accompanied by humanity, becomes disorder. We all know that, if we do not offer alternative housing, assistance and protection to asylum seekers, tomorrow's shacks will rise on today's rubble, which will be even poorer and unlubrious. Those who call for bulldozers do not have a monopoly on security, but rather on the unsolubriity, misery and insecurity that will be created. The decision to put an end to the Jungle therefore makes sense if it responds to an imperative of humanity, because in Calais there are lives, stories, people who cannot be swept away, there is also energy, a hunger for life, the one that has driven so many men and women to face a long journey in which Calais, which also seems like a dead end , it's just a stop. These people must be provided with humanitarian protection and assistance, especially for unaccompanied minors, as Commissioner Avramopoulos mentioned a moment ago. The burden of this support cannot remain as usual on the shoulders of the poorest, and Nord-Pas-de-Calais is one of the poorest departments in France. It is therefore right to distribute asylum seekers in France and, I would add, in Europe. We are talking about 0.01% of the French.  I will end with a call for consistency. Ladies and gentlemen, some of you are in favour of the border at Ventimiglia, but I am against the border in Calais. Make your ideas clear and, above all, understand that borders do not solve problems.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. I have requested this debate, Mr President, because the situation in Calais is completely untenable for everyone, for refugees, for local residents and for drivers. I held a meeting in Rotterdam last year with my esteemed colleague Dennis de Jong and we asked dozens of drivers about their experiences there. There are often trees of men in between, but many of them were terrified to have to drive to Calais, because drivers at Calais are threatened. They get spat on, they get beaten. Many loads of fruit and vegetables disappeared into dumpsters after refugees defecated and on them. And then the driver is fined 1 000 euros for having stowaways in his car.  So we are talking about a European problem and the European Commission needs to address it. Not by sending a few letters to governments, but by organising a summit conference within a few weeks with all those involved to find a solution. Then it is also about the refugees, selection at the gate, resettlement of genuine refugees. This must now be achieved and, at Calais, France and Great Britain must work together to find a solution. Catch those refugees there. France must close the camp and ensure that no new camps are created along the Canal Zone, plus secure parking spaces, no more fines to drivers who are honest and a quick passage at customs.  It is now time for us to stop talking for years because how many French ministers have not been to Calais who have said: 'Yes, it is very bad, we are going to put an end to it'. And now Mr. Hollande again. It doesn't work that way. So, Mr. Avramopoulos, it's with you now to show deeds and stop talking. Not words but deeds, we say in Rotterdam. Announce results, not in spring 2017 but before January, and realize that by holding a summit with everyone involved. Not words but deeds, Mr. Commissioner!

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Madam and Commissioners, dear members of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, in recent years I have had the opportunity to visit many refugee camps on the Syrian border, in Lebanon, Italy, on the Balkan route and in camps organised in Bavaria. Unfortunately, the worst of the camps I saw last July was the one in Calais. These are not things that are happening on the other side of the world, but in Europe, a few hours before this Chamber. For my part, I would like to emphasise what you have mentioned, Commissioner, in particular the situation of unaccompanied minors, the situation of children in Calais, who number more than 6,000 today in this camp, that of 1000 children who are exposed to cold, fatigue, fear, violence, harassment, forced labour, prostitution , despair, disappearance —multiple children have disappeared— or also death, as some of these young people died, suffocated in the back of a truck or struck during the nights they were trying to escape. Last week, my country, France, was condemned for the situation of a Kurdish child in this camp, who lived in the Calais Jungle and has family in the UK. My country has twice refused to register it, to register its asylum application. Here, everyone knows that the asylum application is a mandatory process before family reunification can be studied.
