Beyond the controversy and all these tragic situations, three essential and immediate things to do concerning these children: the first is to register all the children who arrive at the Calais site and on the many slums that surround this sector of my country; the second is to ensure that everyone has access to accurate information, in their own language and adapted to their age, on the right to apply for asylum in France - with the Dublin reform - and on family reunification procedures; and, finally, the third is to implement appropriate reception and shelter so as not to leave them in the hands of smugglers and criminal networks.  These three simple measures must be implemented in the immediate future, pending dismantling and simply in order to comply with our European obligations and treaties.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, Commissioner, I thank you for your expression in this impeccable French. In 1989, everyone was delighted with the fall of the Berlin Wall. Today, new walls are being built and multiplying in Europe and elsewhere. Calais is a symbol of this. Since 2000, barbed wire has been erected there, constantly raised and elongated. Today, we will add more by vegetating and we will dismantle this camp of misery for the third time.  More than 10,000 people live in the area, including more than 1,000 minors, most of them unprotected. We're going to move them again without solving the problem. They want to join the UK because they have ties, family and they think they can easily find work there. If they apply for asylum, they have to wait weeks, and the acceptance rate in France is among the lowest in the European Union. On this basis, the good refugees and the others are sorted out, which are supposed to be deported as soon as possible, including to their country of origin, regardless of the country of origin, as if they had no other rights. Like others, here I have been to Calais. I met these men, these women, these children, I heard their testimonies, their life story, their distress, their mind-blowing journey of violence. Calais is neither a Franco-British affair nor just a transport problem. European law, however imperfect, is flouted, especially for isolated minors. It is humanity, of taking into account their situation that these men, these women, these children need.  Security policies have a cost: one policeman in Calais for every five migrants. How much for hospitality policies? It is time to act for the dignity, respect for the rights of those who are in Calais because they cannot go anywhere else.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I think it is clear that issues of solidarity and delivery of international responsibilities are as important in Calais as anywhere else in the European Union and beyond. But I think it is also clear, when we look at Calais, that deterrence policies over the years clearly have not worked and that the so-called Jungle is a reflection of a long—term problem with no coherent ongoing governmental response. I have been going to Calais since the years of Sangatte, I have been there with the Road Haulage Association and we know the problems well. It is a long-standing history of French failure to deliver effectively on its obligations, aided and abetted by a UK Government that we know drags its heels to deliver safety and security, even to children who are clearly entitled to be in the UK. Every time the camp at Calais is destroyed, children go missing and smuggling gangs responsible for much of the violence there gain more customers because people simply don’t trust the state. My French colleagues and I have again written to the relevant authorities to ask them to just do their jobs properly. It should not be left to NGOs, such as Citizens UK, to identify children who have a right to join their families in the UK. Building walls displaces problems. It does not solve them. That money would be much better spent on the French and British Governments properly managing the asylum system in the region, which will provide safety, information and choices for people in need, be better for the local economy and certainly provide greater security for drivers.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the Calais crisis is a goldmine for people traffickers and criminal gangs and it is aided and abetted by the European Union. British drivers’ lives have been put at risk for months from people the left insist on calling refugees, even though the majority are not. Last year I sat in a lorry in Calais whilst armed migrants broke into vehicles, the drivers unable to stop them.  Closing the jungle will not stop the crisis. It will just move it along the coast to smaller ports like Zeebrugge and Cherbourg, two places where I have personally witnessed criminal gangs in action. And it moves the problem in the UK from the south-east coast to ports like Hull and Immingham. We already have insufficient border staff, thanks to Theresa May.  Millions of pounds of British taxes are being spent fruitlessly building walls, whilst the French blame the UK, and not their politicians who signed up to Schengen. The EU created this mess. It will not be solved until we turn migrant boats in the Mediterranean back, and deport people who are not genuine refugees.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Calais has become the laboratory of a France, of a Europe subject to migratory invasion. This migration submersion is the sad reality to describe what you modestly call "the refugee policy". You are all over the place expressing your indignation at the idea that people are opposed to welcoming migrants, but are you ready, each of you, to experience what the people of Calais are going through every day? Are you prepared to bear only one-tenth of the nightmare of these most humble Frenchmen, who have only one right to remain silent? If you were a farmer in Calais, would you be willing to see your crop trampled daily by migrants? If you owned a small house in Calais, would you be willing to see the value of your property fall by 40% and live behind fences and barbed wire to prevent migrants from breaking into your garden? If you were a trader in Calais, would you be prepared to see your business fall by 50% and file for bankruptcy? If you were a truck driver in Calais, would you be willing to risk every day the road accident because of the projectiles and molotov cocktails thrown by groups of migrants? I know hundreds of Calaisians who would like to share your peaceful life, if only for one day. I therefore propose to you, in perfect coherence with your noble ideals, to relieve the burden of those who can no longer do so: are you ready to live the daily life of the Calaisians?

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which It is strange today: the Council is not there, the Commissioner has left, but we are still discussing what the misguided policy, the EU policy, the migration policy represents. The Commissioner has just said that there are 10 000 illegal immigrants there. This does not only concern France, it concerns the United Kingdom. The 10 000 illegal immigrants would come from all over Europe. I wonder how 10 000 illegal immigrants get there? They are only getting there because Schengen is not working, because our external borders are not controlled. And then Britain should take responsibility?  The politicians who have let Schengen collapse, who have made Frontex a taxi and ferry company for migrants, should take the responsibility. You want to have a solution? Yes, there is a solution. The solution is to reverse policy. Finally, stop wanting to integrate these people who come here under the wrong conditions! Like the Australia model, make a corresponding return rather than integration, and the problem will soon be resolved.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Madam President, the "jungle" of Calais today is the violence, the violence of those who want to cross the Channel at any cost and whose victims are, among others, the truck drivers who need to carry out their trade in the best conditions and, in particular, in safe conditions. Unfortunately, these conditions do not exist for them as they are threatened on a daily basis.  The "jungle" of Calais is also a humanitarian tragedy: for the asylum seekers, whom we have a duty to welcome with dignity, but also for the so-called economic migrants, to whom we cannot offer what they are looking for and whom we must, in this case, send to the other side of the Channel. What shocks me is that the only answer is the construction of a wall paid for by the United Kingdom and accepted by the French government. What a terrible admission of helplessness when we see walls rise again all over Europe! And what a smokescreen, in fact, because the United Kingdom has never assumed its responsibilities in this matter, including with regard to the many miners who are waiting in Calais to be able to reunite with their families. In these circumstances, I say, the Le Touquet agreements must be absolutely renegotiated.  You will allow me to salute the courage of the Calaisians, who have endured this situation for too long, and the courage of the mayor of Calais, Natacha Bouchart, who assumes her responsibilities, even in the face of difficult choices.  The lucidity is to realize that a malaise, a anxiety that creates instability and increases populism, are gradually taking hold in our citizens. I will end by saying that the humanitarian tragedy of the migration crisis threatens to blow up Europe. The exit from the crisis is not in everyone's own, but in a European solution, a common migration policy and better control of our external borders.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, who can think that the French government is satisfied with the situation in Calais? Who can doubt the commitment of the President of the Republic and his Minister of the Interior to resolve the situation in Calais? No, Mrs Grossetête, the only thing that is done is not to build a wall, the thing that is done is to organise at the level of our country this relocation that we have also wanted, here, at the European level.  After Brexit, some thought that the Le Touquet agreements could be denounced. Mrs Grossetête, again, forgets that the man who was The Home Secretary who had concluded these Le Touquet agreements, suddenly wanted to denounce them, as if Schengen were applied by the United Kingdom, as if the United Kingdom could be a failure of the European Union's migration policy, even though that country does not belong to Schengen. After Brexit, denouncing the Le Touquet agreement is simply forgetting geography. It is to allow the United Kingdom to stop taking its share of responsibility, precisely, in the management of this situation. It is to allow asylum seekers to be exposed to terror again. It is to allow smugglers to continue their work of undermining. It's more drama in the English Channel and on the roads. This adds uncertainty to the uncertainty, when it takes two years to denounce the Le Touquet agreement. So, I say, the commitment of the French government, that is what has also enabled the dismantling of the smuggling networks. This is what allows us to examine asylum applications and that is what makes it possible to organise the dismantling of this jungle within the territory, which is why I thank the Commissioner for his support.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent Dear Commissioner, When we were asking for this issue to be seen, we, basically, the Members of the Committee on Transport, really wanted this debate on the transport situation in the Calais and Calais area, and not so much on this as if asylum seekers issue, in which we have once again drifted towards politicising it more. I just want to say that, in my view, this is not just a problem for asylum seekers in this case, because these people are in a safe place. They are located in the Schengen territory, in this case mainly in France, but also in Belgium and neighbouring countries. There's nothing at risk for their lives. They are obliged to register and claim refugee or alternative status, and this does not give them the right to organise – often with criminal entities and criminal organisations – this situation, which creates problems for transport.  In this case, we should have talked more today about whether the Commission, together with the French Government, sees this, especially the situations that could create a safe situation - basically for lorry carriers - that they know where to turn when they see these suspicious situations, if there is an intruder in their cars, so that they themselves do not only become victims of these often criminals, but also afterwards for example, the British authorities, if they have crossed and find themselves in this case in another legal proceedings and are actually considered smugglers. This was something that we should have talked about more today, and I very much hope that the Commissioner will respond to these kinds of aspects.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done What is happening in Calais is indeed an absolute human catastrophe. For me, it is not so decisive in the case of the refugee camp whether these are now illegal or legal refugees who are actually entitled to asylum. They are people who live in unworthy conditions on our continent – the continent that for many stands for security and humanity. That is something that must be very worrying. And then, of course, it is the case – we are talking about transport today – that this terrible situation for people in Europe has also had an impact on the transport sector and on the internal market. It is the case that the psychological burden on lorry drivers, which has already been mentioned, is immense, that they no longer dare to stop in the parking lots because they fear that refugees could enter their lorries illegally. The fact that they no longer do so is not only to protect themselves, but also to protect the refugees. Because no one wants to find a suffocated refugee in the truck later. And, of course, lorry drivers do not want what has happened now: when they come to the UK, they will be punished for having an illegal refugee, in whatever condition, in their lorry. It is, in fact, really a high-security wing that we already have in Calais and at the ferry facilities, and that is something that shows how unresolved the situation is. It is essential that we do something to improve this. It is indeed the case, that is true, it has been mentioned: there are criminal gangs of people smugglers. Truck drivers are also terrified that they will be threatened, forced to take in people and then face penalties afterwards. And I know that Commissioner Avramopoulos said earlier that he welcomed the fact that the refugee camp should be disbanded, and he says that this should actually be accompanied by the proper applications of asylum procedures. I very much hope that this will succeed. Because I fear that if this does not succeed, the dissolution would really only be a transfer to other places. This is not something that any of us can wish for.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Like many others here, I've been to "The Jungle" in Calais, twice. It is a shanty town where 10 000 people, including almost 1 000 children, are stuck. They are stuck because Britain and France have failed to find any policy solutions that are sustainable. They are also subjected to police brutality, tear gas and water cannons. Especially the most vulnerable, namely unaccompanied minors. Now the complete demolition of the camp has been announced and the people of "The Jungle" are living in terror. Where are they going? In addition, France and Britain are building another wall. But there are no more walls that Europe or Britain and France need. Furthermore, there are no excuses for the British Government not to uphold the right to family reunification. Hundreds of children are waiting to come to their families in the UK.  Instead of putting the money on walls, we must invest in a dignified reception. We must have accommodation, we must respect children's rights, we must have gender-separate accommodation for women, who are extremely vulnerable. We will continue to fight for the people of Calais until they are treated as exactly what they are, people.

name: Eva JOLY
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the situation in Calais is unbearable. Each dismantling, sometimes with a bulldozer, adds to the inhumanity of the situation. The latest, announced by François Hollande, must be done with the utmost respect for the population, especially isolated minors, the youngest of whom is only 10 years old, because every time a camp is dismantled, children disappear. Their safety must be a priority. A decent and realistic solution for rehousing must be offered to everyone. Asylum applications must be scrupulously and promptly processed, especially across the Channel. Two children have already lost their lives trying to reach the UK, when a family reunification procedure should have been successful. As for the construction of the Great Wall of Calais, this is the pinnacle of shame. I'm not even talking about his futility. No wall will stop those who have already braved all dangers to escape the war. No one wants this wall, neither the humanitarian associations, nor the truck drivers, nor even the mayor of Calais. Other solutions exist: Damien Lent, the mayor of Grande-Synthe, demonstrated this with the construction of a humanitarian camp that houses hundreds of men, women and children with dignity. It is time to change our approach; repression without an alternative is not a solution, it only dehumanizes us.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to take part in this stage-managed, pretend debate where people on the other side of the House can come out with figures about the people who are in that Calais Jungle without the slightest shred of evidence. I will tell you why I know this: because I have been there and there are a thousand people registered and 10 000 people outside the walls, not registered. So how you can come up with a figure for children is nonsense. You can wave all the pretend leaflets you like. It makes no difference. I did not realise until tonight that France was a totalitarian state, persecuting and prosecuting people, and where people are in fear of their lives. If it is not, then there are no refugees or asylum seekers in Calais or anywhere else, there are only criminals seeking to break UK laws to get into the country or people being trafficked by criminals to get into our country. The French nation has a proud tradition. I believe that the French Government has let the French people down. It is time for them to be honourable, dismantle these camps, break up these criminal gangs, register genuine asylum seekers and stop the other economic migrants seeking to break the law to get into the UK.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: Madam President, I have listened well to the Commissioner, who has since left, and I have mostly heard him complain about the poor migrants. No word on the inhabitants of Calaisis.  Calais, today, is just a disaster town where the daily life of the inhabitants begins to look like the worst nightmare. Calais is dying, suffering the full force of your dismal handling of the migration crisis. This city is becoming the standard of your policies of methodical destruction of our nations. It is the symbol of your incompetence. In Calais, you have an illustration of the erasure of the borders that you have organised. Calais is the symbol of the failure of Schengen.  Steeve Briois gave figures earlier. For you, I have others. Since October 2015, the cost of reinforcements from crS and mobile gendarmes, to whom I want to pay tribute today, and who are completely exhausted by the attacks of migrants, amounts to 150,000 euros per day. An exceptional budget has been devoted to tear gas: two million euros of additional budget.  Today, the French government announces the dismantling of the "jungle" by spreading migrants in French villages. Again, it is the French who will foot the bill. In the Oise, my department, the cost of the forced reception of 300 isolated foreign minors amounts to 50,000 euros per year per minor, at the expense of the community, at the expense of French taxpayers. These figures are totally staggering, especially at a time when there are six million unemployed in France, at the very least, and nine million people living on less than 1,000 euros a month.  You call for solidarity and the values of humanism towards migrants, but you bring injustice, ruin and anger to the French and especially to the Calaisians.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, hundreds of illegal immigrants crowd daily in Calais, France, and at night they try to cross through the Channel Tunnel in order to get out to Britain.  But I think it is wrong to try to look at the situation in Calais separately. It is just another symptom of the great problem called illegal immigration. I insist on the term 'illegal immigration' and not 'refugee'. Most of these people are not refugees, but economic migrants. In fact, if they move without the documents and permits provided for, they are illegal immigrants.  We must in every way ensure a decent living for refugees in the first country who enter after fleeing and ensure that they return to their homes as soon as possible. Their children must continue education in their languages so that they are ready to reintegrate into the societies of their countries.  Economic migrants should return to their countries and come legally only after an expression of interest and know before the start of their journey whether they will be admitted.  If this is implemented in just a few weeks we will solve most of the problem, including Calais.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate has a fundamental flaw, indeed it has more than one. The first is the hypocrisy, the hypocrisy of those who today tell yet another story about reception, a reception without criterion sometimes, a reception where it is difficult to find a distinction between asylum seekers with this right and economic migrants that the right of asylum cannot have. Above all, the hypocrisy of a debate that should be about how to prevent honest hauliers from turning into defendants because of our uncertainty and our inability to find a correct approach to this truly dramatic issue.  I was sorry to see Mr Syleym. Berès to discuss internal policy issues in the European Union with Mrs Grossetête on French. Perhaps Mrs Berès should remember to address her javeliles to President Hollande and listen more to her group leader Pittella, who correctly pointed out that Calais is perhaps not so different from Ventimiglia. Then perhaps Hollande should remember to use the same weight in similar situations. Today the problem is a transport problem. The problem is to find the right way to ensure that road hauliers and the inhabitants of that territory do not become the unjust victims of our political incapacity.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, in July I led a delegation from the LIBE Commission to Calais. We found two very different realities. In Grande-Synthe, by the action of a mayor with humanist sensibility; in Calais, by inaction of a president with a hostile speech to refugees and immigrants. The approach makes all the difference to find decent solutions, to manage the influx that puts a lot of pressure on this border region. Although the French authorities accept asylum applications, the people we spoke to in the jungle do not lose hope of crossing into the UK where they have family, countrymen, and think they have a future, because they know that the networks of traffickers are still active and passing is just a matter of being able to pay, including hundreds of unaccompanied minors that the UK will take to reunite with families. Ethiopians, with whom I spoke in the jungle, said hundreds of their compatriots had arrived there weeks earlier, two to three months after they left their villages on dangerous journeys, risking their lives.  Mr President, building walls and refusing to open legal and safe avenues for immigrant refugees is to continue to give business to the networks of traffickers. In addition to being immoral and violating human rights, it is ineffective and only aggravates Europe's security.  Calais can be on any European beach.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: – Mr President, the British border has been on French soil since the Treaty of Le Touquet in 2003. It is that agreement which gave rise to the Calais jungle, and that migrant camp for over 10 years has been getting steadily bigger, steadily more desperate and steadily more violent. Both the British Government and the French Government have got a duty to ensure safe passage for all legitimate cross-Channel traffic, to forcefully uphold national immigration policies and to provide all necessary humanitarian aid. But there are dangers. First, that in tightening border controls we just displace the problem elsewhere or, we force migrants into ever more desperate measures, such a small boats. And second, in addressing the situation locally, we lose sight of the bigger global problem. We welcome the Commission’s help and support with the problem, but I urge them to remember that migrants all over the world are the consequence of the widening gap between the world’s rich nations and the world’s poor nations, and of climate change and violence. In addressing migration, therefore, we must understand the importance of directing our efforts to the cause, not just to the symptoms.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the suffering experienced by migrants and the inhabitants of Calaisis is obviously at the forefront of our concerns, but I would like to start by talking about the road transport aspect. To give body to this, I will quote very recent figures from the International Road Transport Union which conducted a very thorough survey among truck drivers: 4,500 trucks pass through this region every day, or more than 1.5 million trucks, 87% of companies have already found migrants in their vehicles, 22.5% of companies have at least one driver who has been attacked and 30% of businesses have , including drivers, refuse traffic to the Uk, a total cost, just for the Calais problem, of 2 billion euros for the sector, including damage to the vehicle or goods or fines imposed by the authorities when they discover illegal immigrants despite the searches carried out by the drivers themselves, plus the waiting times at the crossing point , or even the legal assets of trucks. I recall that, in view of the violence of the attacks and the fear of the drivers, many of whom are now armed, a number of drivers have passed roadblocks set up by migrants with deaths: we have spoken - I recall - of "common pits" in Calais.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Calais Jungle that I have seen is a wasteland where 1 000 unaccompanied minors live out of 10 000 refugees. More than half of the children could reach family members in England, European law prescribes. Both Paris and London violate it. Only 20 minors were able to make use of it. I would like to tell you the story of Raheemullah Oryakhel, fourteen years old, afghan, crushed days ago by a lorry in Calais. He wanted to legally join his brother in Manchester. Why so much misanthropy? They will tell you that it is because the candidates for the Elysée are chasing Marine Le Pen, but there is a more substantial rejection. Refugees make up only 0.2 % of europe's population, yet it is as if we are not able to add a single table in a canteen of millions. The children mourn them, but dead, only in photography and possibly far from us.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Calais is today the scene of indignity, even human cowardice, where migrants and inhabitants are truly abandoned to their fate.  Not a single day goes by without lives in danger and the worst being brought close. There's not a week without deaths, without tragedy. Every day, desperate acts are attempted by migrants in order to enter the UK. For example, tree trunks and objects are regularly installed on the roads to force truck drivers to slow down in order to climb into trucks to cross the border. Carriers report on their fear of using these routes every day. For local residents, the situation is no longer tenable and there is a worrying increase in violence. The economy of Calais is collapsing. Human beings are crammed into sanitary conditions unworthy of the land of human rights, as evidenced by the name given to this camp: the "jungle".  Faced with short-term solutions and broken promises, Calaisians no longer see the end of what has become a nightmare. As such, I would like to pay tribute to Natacha Bouchart, Mayor of Calais, and Xavier Bertrand, President of the Hauts-de-France region for their courage and refusal to give in to the populism surroundings. It is imperative that the European Union be at the initiative of a total renegotiation of the Le Touquet agreements between France and the United Kingdom, agreements that were doomed, from the moment they were drafted, to failure. France and the European Union can no longer be the helpless subcontractors of the border with the British. Brexit must be an opportunity to hold the UK accountable. The English border must return to England. Commissioner, there is an urgent need.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: There's a blue card from Mr. Gerice, but I ask for the understanding of both him and all of you. There is a long delay in the agreed timetable, and so, like the previous Vice-Presidents, I will not give blue cards.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, almost 10 000 men, women and children, plus an impressive number of unaccompanied minors, all camped in inhumane conditions in what is the largest bin on our continent. But is this the Europe of welcome? A neighbouring country, the United Kingdom, has already begun work on building yet another wall of shame. Is this the Europe of solidarity? Why do we continue to manage migration by passing the responsibility on to our southern neighbours? Why should we make political choices about militarising borders, closing borders, building walls and setting up camps of shame? If we confine ourselves to dealing with emergency situations, there will always be tentcities in every European country and walls in neighbouring countries.  We must know and remember that it is the lack of solidarity, the non-respected decisions on relocation and the absence of integration and reception policies that make the migration phenomenon ungovernable. I therefore call on the Member States to put into practice what is the greatest principle of solidarity.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa This is not the first time we have talked about Calais here, but every time we talk about it, the situation there is worse. But why? Well, because we do not follow our own rules. Is it legal to attack trucks? No, but they do, they do it every day. And the police? The police do nothing. She was gracious to mention that we need to develop an integration programme for immigrants. That is true – we must, but those immigrants who behave in this way should be integrated into prisons. If we do not follow our own rules, then we face what we have. You say that this is a wall of disgrace that the British are building. And why would a sensible government have someone who behaves like this to let in? Why would he do that? The law that it is should be respected, and that should be our call to the French government today.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: – The situation in Calais has become untenable. Unsustainable for the thousands of refugees, unsustainable for the local population and also unsustainable for the transport sector. I support the French government's plan to dismantle the Jungle, but that does not mean a structural solution. In order to prevent new jungles in Europe, there must be a better European asylum and migration policy, European countries, Member States, European agreements must be implemented loyally and quickly. Solidarity is also needed. In this light, in the light of solidarity, I would like to ask the British Government to take a part in the reception of refugees from Calais, especially the unaccompanied children who have family in the United Kingdom. All Member States, including the United Kingdom, have a responsibility. Take that responsibility.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to reduce my emotions a little and take a slightly pragmatic view of the whole solution. This summer I had the opportunity with the LIBE committee to visit the refugee camps around Calais. And although I have heard many times about this famous jungle, what I saw there shocked and surprised me incredibly. The condition was even more horrible and ugly than any of you can imagine. It's the ugliest refugee camp I've ever seen in my life. And ladies and gentlemen, I've been through camps all over the European Union.  In the jungle, there are various conflicts on a daily basis. Mood at freezing point. And individual nationalities are fighting for dominance here. Not only do the police intervene here every day, but doctors are often asked to treat injuries. The overall conditions for living in this jungle are absolutely appalling.  Ladies and gentlemen, official statistics say that no one knows how many people actually live in the jungle. Nonprofits estimate this at 4, 6, 8, or 9,000. But these people have a dream in common. Get to the UK. You need to pour a clean wine. Most of these people never get there and can't get there because they are economic migrants. These are people who should be denied asylum.  And the last thing I would like to say, Mr President, is that François Hollande is always making excuses for the European Union. But the solution is not up to the European Union, but it is up to François Hollande.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr President, the humanitarian situation in Calais deserves better than the hateful and demagogic comments we sometimes hear here and there. I am pleased that today's debate has been brought under control, at least with a few exceptions, because this situation, in fact, is not tenable for migrants, for the people of Calais, or for the workers. I would like to emphasize three points.  First, sustainable solutions must be found. This situation in Calais is not new, but it has been considerably difficult since the failed closure of Sangatte in 2002. We must therefore find lasting solutions, which is why the French State has decided to dismantle the whole, by the end of the year, in order to send out clear signals that until now had never been so. Secondly, this dismantling must take place with perspectives. We are talking about international protection and shelter, including unaccompanied minors, who are in unsanitary situations. I would like to take this opportunity to tell Nathalie Griesbeck and Marie—Christine Vergiat that there is currently more shortage of people to move into the United Kingdom than overflow, so minors can move on to family reunification in the United Kingdom. This dismantling must be done with responsibility and in an orderly manner, with humanity and dignity, which results in the reception of people in premises on a human scale and with appropriate social and administrative support. This is to bring concrete solutions. Thirdly, we must continue to fight for national and European solutions to co-exist, because that is the only possible key. The situation in Calais will not be resolved just by renegotiating the Le Touquet agreements, with all the uncertainties associated with the two years' notice - Françoise Grossetête is not there to hear it and I regret it. It is therefore a duty of exemplarity and distribution between what we are asking for with the Member States of the European Union and at a time when too often they are turning their backs on European solidarity, as evidenced by the referendum by Viktor Orbon this weekend.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: – Mr President, I am grateful for the Commission's recommendations, but I also express a growing concern. From the beginning, months ago, we said that the relationship between the refugee crisis and the European mobility and transport routes had to be addressed in a holistic way, and not by action-reaction and always too late.  The humanitarian problem of families and minors alone had to be solved, losing their lives and health, through the safe humanitarian corridors we have been demanding, and thus order the arrival and avoid inhumane agglomerations both on the southern beaches and on the eastern and northern borders, as in the case of Calais. It wasn't done. And now we must face a worsening of the situation that threatens to collapse one of the fundamental axes of the European economy: the free movement of goods, services and people.  And it is very sad that since transport we have not been able to anticipate the human and humanitarian problem and we do react when it affects the economy. Well, let's make necessity virtue. And, unlike what has been done since 2000 in the southern countries, it must be recognised as soon as possible that Calais is a European problem, which requires european policies and not leaving the French Government and the inhabitants of Calais abandoned to their fate.  It is urgent, Mrs Bulc, to protect our truckers and to avoid them from limiting the violence and despair against those who are alone, and it is also urgent to implement European policies for welcoming and integrating groups that are among us and those we also need for generational re-relief in transport. We need you, Mrs. Bulc.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – This debate comes at a time when the French President has announced that he will close the camp before the end of the year. He said: 'I am going to do this in a humane way so that the refugees can also apply for asylum properly'. We will, of course, keep him on his toes. But waiting until the end of the year is no longer possible for many drivers. I am surprised that the Commission says: 'Wait, early next year in the spring there will be a letter from the Commission on the situation in transport'. I think we need to make sure that drivers, as long as their safety is at stake, can drive on other routes to Calais without their bosses addressing them. I don't think guaranteeing your safety is a refusal to work. All drivers are entitled to a safe journey, just as asylum seekers are entitled to a safe procedure. I call on the Commission to give more ambition to protect the very workers affected by the unsafe situation at Calais.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the humanitarian situation in the Calais camp is catastrophic, as has been said. The first mistake that led to this situation was the dismantling in 2002 of the Sangatte centre run by the Red Cross. The second mistake was, let's face it, the Agreement of Le Touquet in 2003. Since then, we have had this situation where the camp has grown to reach 7,000 people fleeing war and misery, with the aim of joining their families in the UK.  In the face of this humanitarian situation, the UK's inflexibility has made Calais a dead end for many refugees. And, in the face of these human tragedies, the European Union has failed to take responsibility. In such a context, France has been left to its own devices in the management of this issue.  However, the President of the Republic, when he came to Calais, presented a package of measures to relocate refugees from the Calais camp, which are going in the right direction. It has pledged to provide shelter in reception centres for 80 per cent of the 7,000 refugees eligible for asylum. Therefore, Commissioner, the European Union must show solidarity with Calais and support this relocation of European funding, particularly in the context of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. I think this is an emergency, as we all see, in light of the debate we have just had. Compared to the scale of this refugee crisis in Europe or in Syria's neighbouring countries, the situation in Calais is not insurmountable.  Let us act, Commissioner, Commissioner, to enable, together with France, to give a humanitarian response to this dramatic situation.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! The situation in Calais, as in the lens, shows the problem of the unresolved migration crisis in the European Union, generally in Europe. On the one hand, we have the drama of these migrants who are in and around this camp in tragic circumstances, because we cannot say that they are all criminals there and want to enter the UK illegally.  On the other hand, we have the drama of truck drivers putting their health and lives at risk in order to transport goods safely. For me, it is absolutely unacceptable to impose financial penalties on lorry drivers for putting illegal immigrants on board their cars. It must not be the case that entrepreneurs will be burdened in a situation where the administration is unable to cope with this. Finally, I would like to say, listening to this discussion, that we need more pragmatism and less ideology on this issue, otherwise we will not solve this problem.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Mr President, I would like to go back to the national refugee plan, which was set up by the government, and which means that today there are already 10,000 refugees who are being relocated to solidarity cities. So, yes, there are some in France, and it is not only those politicians who shamefully refuse any solidarity. He had to be called back!  I also wanted to talk about the transport sector and to recall what the French government is doing, no, not doing anything, but acting. Incidents against truck drivers are on the decline thanks to the security measures that have been taken. A compensation fund of four million euros has been set up to help affected companies. In fact, it is rather the waiting times, due to border control, that generate the most costs - delays that carriers would experience at all times if Schengen were to disappear.  Contrary to what some claim with great hypocrisy, closing borders is not the quick fix to all our problems. The wall built at the request of the British government is an example. It is a dangerous panacea that echoes the disastrous effects of the walls erected in Europe, as in Berlin, or more recently in Hungary. Instead of giving the illusion of action, the current government is moving forward in Calais with humanity and dignity, with full respect for European and international law.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Drivers in Calais, including Polish drivers, are victims of violence and aggression. We have a responsibility to ensure that these people return home safely, the safety of their families, and their businesses must also provide the income they simply deserve, which they need to live.  But what are we to do as the European Union? First of all, do not disturb the countries that protect us from illegal immigration. After all, in this House yesterday, we heard several times – and this has been repeated again today – attacks on Hungary for defending not only its borders, but also the borders of the European Union. Here was the statement that Calais is Europe. Yes, this is the image of Europe, but not of today, but of the one that is coming. If we really do not change the migration policy and the European Union authorities responsible for this crisis, we will have 10, 20 and 50 places like Calais, not one.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – The living conditions in the camp near Calais are unacceptable and inhumane. The situation is tantamount to a humanitarian catastrophe. Migrants and refugees do not have access to basic needs, running water and food, and are at risk of various diseases. There are no laws. It is no coincidence that the camp near the city is known as the "jungle".  In this regard, I believe that the decision of the French authorities to remove the camp by the end of the year represents a short-term solution because its inhabitants would move elsewhere within the European Union. In recent years, a number of such temporary camps have been set up in Europe and their existence is a clear sign that we cannot find a sustainable solution to the migration waves.  I also call on the UK authorities to fully cooperate and deliver on their commitments to speed up the transfer of refugee children from migrant camps. The closure of the Calais camp could lead to uncertainty for the survival of hundreds of children living there and the European Union must not allow this to happen.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Mr President, 'the Jungle' is a disgrace and the French and European authorities, not migrants and refugees, are responsible.  The Commission has said it wants to provide viable and sustainable solutions. That it wants to improve the living conditions of migrants, and in reality what it has done is to portray everything they have not done so far and that, among other things, feeds in my opinion the xenophobic discourse that we also suffer here. As my colleague Vergiat has said, this is not a transport problem and, of course, dismantling 'the Jungle' does not solve it. We have already seen many dismantlings in "the Jungle".  Commissioner, you cannot say with this lightness that European measures have significantly reduced the flow of people, because it seems that you are actually washing your hands. These people continue to die on the road to Europe, Commissioner, and those who fail to do so live and die behind our pacts and walls.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul We can ask ourselves where Commissioner Avramopoulos went. He had his speech in ten minutes; then he disappeared as a salary. Of course, with a salary of 300,000 to 400,000 a month, you might not have to sit here and listen to what we have to say. And as I said, it is not a debate we are in favour of; We must not even take blue cards because we are late in time.  We heard here that we are talking about unaccompanied children in Calais, and people are talking about thousands, thousands, of thousands – you seem to be in order of how many there really are. But do we know that? Does anyone know that? Under the Dublin Regulation, should you not be registered in the first, safe country you come to? Is that not what the regulation is for? Why is it that they do not want to remain in France? Could it be that there are better benefits in the UK? It could be, maybe.  I was also thinking about Avramopoulos saying that we should reduce the flow of migrants to Europe. Then I ask myself: how is he going to solve it, given that we will soon have to close our border controls?

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, the Jungle in Calais is the French version of Idomeni. The situation for refugees, although few in number, compared to illegal immigrants is tragic. Even more tragic, however, is the situation of the inhabitants of the area where their lives and property are put at risk every day. Lorry drivers transporting goods from Calais to Great Britain are desperate and many of them are rightly furious.  The situation is out of control and the French government of Hollande, like the Greek government, blames the local government of Calais and the citizens who react. In the end, the most tragic thing of all, on the verge of the absurd, is to describe as racist and xenophobic anyone who tries to save his national status and his life from the hordes of illegal immigrants.  Those in Parliament who speak in a trembling voice calling for solidarity and humanity to show the same zeal by defending the interests of European citizens. That is why they have been elected, after all, do not forget it.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for this debate. It shows again the complex challenges related to the migration crisis we are called to tackle together. The transport sector has been affected by the migration crisis, that is a fact, and whilst the situation in Calais has the highest visibility, it is also important to remember that this problem is not unique. It also affects ferries between Greece and Italy.  We welcome the joint initiatives of the UK and France over the last year that have improved the security at the Eurotunnel and provided practical solutions to the immigration pressure. The underlying problem that is really fuelling the situation is the role that organised criminals are playing in human trafficking, but allow me to clarify how the Commission is addressing the humanitarian crisis in Calais.  Let me stress one more time that preventing migrants from physically boarding goods vehicles is a national police competence. The Commission has no authority in this matter. The Commission has adopted, and helped France, with two emergency assistance grants of nearly EUR nine million under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF). Since 2014: EUR 3.8 million for the setting up and running of the emergency day accommodation centre for irregular migrants in Calais; EUR 5.1 million in relation to the sanitation and humanitarian reception conditions to care for the irregular migrants present in Calais, and with EUR 1.68 million emergency assistance under ISF—Borders for strengthening security efforts and checks at the Channel Tunnel.  In the long-term perspective up to 2020, France has been allocated nearly EUR 430 million in the framework of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and EUR 177 million under the Internal Security Fund for border management and police and security-related actions. Within this financial framework, EUR 85 million were earmarked for actions in the area of return of irregular immigration, improving detention conditions and returns management and an increased information campaign. Let me also stress that EUR 413.4 million were earmarked for the UK for the period covering 2014-2020. On the issue of minors in Calais which was raised, indeed thousands of minors pass through Calais. According to French law they are legally staying, they cannot be returned, and should obtain appropriate support from the French authorities. However, a significant number of unaccompanied minors do not want to be lodged in the available structures and continue living in the camp or leave shortly after having been taken in charge because they want to reach the United Kingdom illegally. In essence, the French authorities cannot oblige unaccompanied minors to remain in the foyers. This issue is indeed very difficult; one of the main priorities there, as minors are prone to exploitation. When dealing with the migration crisis, the Commission pursues a comprehensive approach at all levels, from tackling the root causes of migration to management of the flows at the borders. The Commission is working to implement the European Agenda on Immigration. This will help Member States to better manage all aspects of migration. But let me say I do share your frustration over the day-to-day reality. I was there myself, I met the drivers, I crossed the Channel with them, and since then I am even more convinced that only a comprehensive and systematic approach can offer a sustainable solution; the Commission is doing exactly that.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The "dismantling" of the Calais Jungle is a diversion of public attention. Rather than placing the "migrants" in charters as should be done, President Hollande supports the construction of miniature Calais throughout the French territory, with the exception of Corsica too indocile.  Of course, these pups in gestation are expected to grow considerably. In Australia, there are no camps as boats loaded with "migrants" are approached and brought home. In France, there are camps and there will continue to be camps with the policies carried out by the government and wanted by the European Union, which assumes that it wants so-called "replacement" migration because of the false pretext of the low birth rate of Germany or Italy.  In order to no longer see a Calais situation in France, we must put an end to a mortal logic of unconditional welcome to the other imposed by European policies and the lobbying of associations subsidized from outside to abolish national borders.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – As EU decision-makers, our primary responsibility is to protect our citizens. Therefore, every care must be made to ensure that drivers who have to cross calais are not subjected to physical violence or fearful of being illegally climbed onto their lorry. Unfortunately, a Hungarian lorry driver has also been subjected to serious physical abuse in Calais, and his case must be a warning sign: there can be no outlaw zones in the Member States of the Union, it cannot happen that we cannot protect our own citizens. It can't happen that we can't maintain the legal order. The situation at Calais threatens the union's most fundamental achievement, the free movement of EU citizens and goods. I therefore call on the Commission to prioritise these issues, the situation in Calais, because this is the real rule of law issue, where the citizens of the Union are waiting for concrete action.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. What is happening in Calais is worrying. There is perhaps the largest refugee camp in the EU in Calais, but I come from a region where an entire island is turned into a camp, only that we call it a reception camp. France today discovers its border land, what Sicily has always been. It is now being measured by the need to distribute refugees to other municipalities in the country and by the reticence of mayors and citizens, it is faced with the need to redistribute refugees among EU countries and with opposition from other states, it is experiencing the closure of the borders of its right, the United Kingdom.  They are not easy situations, but bulldozers and forced mackerel are not the solution. It would be very serious to fall into the blackmail of the populists just for fear of an election that is too close. It cannot be the people, especially the children, who are the victims not only of the wars from which they are fleeing, but also of a political battle.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. –  Over 600 unaccompanied children who are trapped in the Calais jungle will be made homeless by Christmas. These children face human traffickers, police violence, sexual abuse and even death trying to reach the UK in a desperate hope for a safe and better future. It is now more urgent than ever for the UK government to get these children to safety. But the situation at the camp is driven by a lack of intervention on both sides of the Channel. Since there is no legal recognition of the camp, there is no formal registration of children. Since there is no official agency operating at the camp, no one knows what actually happens to these children. According to NGOs, nearly half of them have the right to come to the UK. Yet the UK Government fails to act. Only around 50 children were brought to the UK under the EU’s Dublin regulation and NOT ONE child has been relocated under the Dubs amendment. I implore the UK Government to uphold the rule of law and bring these children to safety before the upcoming demolition of the Camp. Britain must step up and show leadership in the face of this humanitarian crisis.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my concern about the situation affecting drivers in Calais. We have long been informed that the safety of carriers is at risk. According to data from the British Road Haulage Association, Polish carriers belong to one of the most numerous groups travelling to England by ferry. Drivers are victims of migrants who have been in the Calais encampment for several months. Migrants storm trucks, putting barricades on the roads, forcing drivers to stop. Any attempt to transport migrants illegally is severely punished by British and French customs officers. The situation is so serious that migrants' behaviour towards drivers is increasingly taking the form of attacks, the consequences of which can prove tragic. I call on all of you to come up with solutions that will ensure the safety of their work while maintaining continuity of supply.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. For several years, the number of migrants present in Calais has continued to increase. The current migration crisis in Europe has only exacerbated this situation. Today about 7,000 migrants live in deplorable conditions on the "camp of the moor" and in Grande-Synthe.  In this context, the French authorities, acting with responsibility and dignity, propose long-term measures to permanently close the Calais camp by the end of 2016. In particular, they carry out a census of the places available on French territory to open centres for the reception of 9,000 migrants. The distribution of these migrants aims to provide them with decent living conditions.  Finally, following the last Franco-British summit, Great Britain increased its financial support by 22 million euros, notably for the admission of unaccompanied minors to its territory, bringing its financial effort to 100 million euros.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. – In Calais there is the indivisible as was the case in Idomeni and as is the case in the islands of the Eastern Aegean. But in the case of Calais, the EU decides to act because the situation threatens the movement of lorries, hence trade. However, it does not do the same for the decongestion of the islands of the Eastern Aegean by refugees and illegal immigrants. Quite the contrary, as in a recent statement by the Commission Brussels expressed its opposition to the movement of some of the 14,000 refugees and illegal immigrants from the eastern Aegean islands to mainland Greece. In Calais, France understands what the eastern Aegean islands as a whole are experiencing. It is obvious, and I have stressed this many times, that the crisis will not be confined to the areas where refugees and illegal immigrants are currently housed. The situation in Calais is already affecting transport between France and the United Kingdom. As in the case of Calais and in the case of Greece, the Member States of the European Union must act in coordination and in solidarity. This means operating the mechanism for relocating refugees from Greece and Italy to other EU member states, re-promoting illegal migrants and, of course, hitting the trafficking rings.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The current migration crisis is challenging Europe. The challenge of solidarity first: solidarity with those people who are fleeing war and who gather en masse in unworthy living conditions on our continent, despite the efforts of associations and local elected officials, as is the case in Calais. But also solidarity with the inhabitants and businesses of these municipalities of Calais who suffer with calm and dignity the disastrous consequences of a situation for which they are in no way responsible.  In order to provide a sustainable response, the European Union must therefore respond at the same time to the challenge of efficiency in the control of its borders. It is indeed aberrant that the only truly watertight border in Europe is between France and Great Britain, and passes through Calais! All the more so since, with the exit of Great Britain, the Hauts-de-France coastline becomes an external border of the European Union, and the European Union cannot accept any longer for a Member State to provide controls on behalf of a third state on its own and on its territory. I therefore hope that the Le Touquet agreements will be quickly renegotiated, and that the European Union will support this approach.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. - Calais is one of the hotbeds of Europe's migrant crisis, which has been a rallying point for those refugees and migrants trying to cross the La Manche Channel and enter the UK for years. The place is at the centre of political debates in both France and the UK, and is a symbol of the poor state of thousands of people. There are currently around 10,000 people fleeing war and poverty waiting here for the chance to get their hands on the UK. An additional difficult circumstance is the safety of passengers passing through these routes, as migrants often try to force their way onto vehicles transported by ferry or rail tunnel, thus significantly affecting the functioning of the transport sector, causing frequent delays or disruptions to traffic and even traffic accidents. Local residents, travellers using local ports and the tunnel are unhappy with the current situation as it hinders regular travel and travel safety itself, as some migrants have started violent methods of fighting for their rights. I am concerned about the current situation and call for this problem to be addressed as quickly as possible to enable all parties to live a normal life: passengers with uninterrupted traffic and migrants assistance in all necessary forms.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda concerns the Commission statement on the InterRail Card for Europe, a gift for the eighteenth birthday (2016/2917(RSP)).

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first of all thank the European Parliament for putting the European Youth Mobility issue on its agenda. The Commission very much supports the thrust of the question raised and welcomes the opportunity to debate it today. This is indeed consistent with two essential priorities of the European Commission:  namely to put a renewed focus on Europe’s Youth, and to facilitate EU citizens’ mobility, and particularly low—emission solutions. These two priorities were specifically highlighted by President Juncker in his recent State of the Union speech and in his Letter of Intent sent to President Schulz and Prime Minister Fico. The Commission welcomes Members’ ideas that go in the same direction. I wish to recall that three weeks ago here, in this Parliament, President Juncker announced several concrete initiatives for our youth. First, in stepping up the fight against youth unemployment, we will in particular pursue the roll-out of the EU Youth Guarantee which has already benefitted 9 million young Europeans. We propose to increase the EU contribution to the Youth Employment Initiative which supports the implementation of the Youth Guarantee by EUR 1 billion under the MFF review. This will allow us to reach a total amount of EUR 8 billion (with EUR 1 billion of matching funding to be provided from the European Social Fund). Earlier today the Commission adopted the report on the implementation of the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative. The report shows the positive impact that these initiatives are having for young people across Europe. Secondly, the Commission will also develop further European solutions, including the European Voluntary Service, the mobility of apprentices, and a European Solidarity Corps. This Corps will give young Europeans the opportunity to express their solidarity by helping communities faced with challenging situations (such as the refugee crisis and the recent earthquake in Italy). Our objective is to have this European Solidarity Corps up and running by the end of the year. By 2020, we intend to see the first 100 000 young Europeans signed up. Thirdly, I also want to highlight the fact that the European Commission is already doing much to support the mobility of young Europeans. Our hugely successful ERASMUS+ Programme is probably the best example of this.  In 2017, we will celebrate the 30th anniversary of Erasmus, which by then will have benefitted more than 5 million Europeans. Participants in these mobility activities are higher education students, trainees and apprentices, young people and young volunteers. In September, the Commission proposed to increase the Erasmus+ budget by EUR 200 million for the period 2017 to 2020 as part of the MFF mid-term review. Let me now refer more specifically to the idea of facilitating access to InterRail tickets for 18 year olds. We admire the boldness and the level of ambition and we are ready to explore it further. Currently, there are 300 000 people using InterRail every year. They buy passes at a cost of between EUR 200 to EUR 480. Extending access to all 18 year—olds for free would therefore present many challenges which require further analysis. The Commission will carefully assess the potential cost and funding sources for this initiative, as well as its administrative feasibility. We will also examine how to ensure that it is truly accessible to all and is as inclusive as possible. The possible scope of such a scheme must be explored, for example, how we can take into account the fact that not all Member States railways are InterRail Members. Also, the scheme could become – at least progressively – intermodal, and not only limited to rail tickets.  InterRail illustrates well the need to address missing links in multimodal and cross-border connections. Of course, we will have to discuss this directly with the rail operators managing the existing InterRail services. They know best what the operational constraints are – for example in terms of capacity and occupancy of trains. We may also consider possible variants to this excellent idea. An attractive option might be to have a lottery open to all or specific categories of Young Europeans, with a significant number winning free tickets. We could think of a pilot phase, to be extended later on. I also wish to challenge Europe’s young people to come up with other ideas for boosting their mobility. Who better to identify their specific mobility needs? Who better to come up with vibrant and innovative solutions? So we could also consider the idea of launching a competition open to all people under the age of 25, with a substantial prize for the best new concrete ideas for youth mobility. To conclude, let me reiterate that the Commission likes this idea. We will carefully look into all possible options to further support the mobility of young people. And we will revert to Parliament as soon as possible.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Firstly, Europe faces enormous challenges, and these are at the heart of our debate. Today we had the conclusion on CO2, on the climate agreement, and we are all aware that this is our main task. Nevertheless, we must realise that we reach many people on the subject of Europe not only with facts, not only with laws, but we must put emotions behind what Europe means. That is why, in my speech two weeks ago, when we were talking about Jean-Claude Juncker's State of the Union, I simply asked what it would be like if we did not see what young people experienced with Interrail this summer, that we could give this gift to every young person in Europe, namely to get to know the beauty of Europe, not to see our neighbour in the other country as a neighbour. , but as a friend, to experience as a friend, simply to feel what it means to be European. That is why I put the idea into the room, whether we can not give every eighteen-year-old a free Interrail ticket. First of all, I want to make it clear that this was not my idea. There have been many initiatives that have initiated this before, which have already made it clear that this can be an access to Europe's youth. I would therefore like to thank the tens of thousands of young people who have taken up the idea on the Internet and on social media. There are polls in Germany showing that 84% of the young generation in Germany support the idea. Jean-Claude Juncker and Commissioner Bulc have made their support clear, and even at the level of the state and government side, Matteo Renzi, for example, to name a Social Democrat, has made it clear that he can imagine this idea. So there is a momentum to tackle this issue now, to take up it, and we should work on it now. Incidentally, it is also remarkable to see who is against it. It is the nationalists who do not want to see the neighbour in the neighbour, who do not want you to recognise the neighbour as a friend. It was rightly cited by the Commissioner as a model for Erasmus. This is our youth project, so that young people get to know each other, a great success of Europe and a positive investment. With Interrail, we could complement this, an investment that really makes it available to all young people in Europe to experience this continent. It is often discussed when it comes to money, investment, that it is much more important to strengthen the Youth Guarantee, to invest money in training. I would like to make it clear that we should not make a contrast out of this, not to play one against the other, but that we should try to tackle both ambitiously now. I want to make it clear that I am someone who is influenced by Interrail. I have twice used this method to get to know Europe. And perhaps to make this clear to the UK, on my first Interrail trip to London, I was fascinated by this great city in the UK. When I was able to experience England via Interrail, i was fascinated by it. And I have really been able to experience the beauty of Europe in the British example. I want many people to be able to do this, and that is why I would like to thank many for the preparatory work that has already been done. I would like to thank the Commission for its openness. And now just get on with the topics! Now it has to become concrete, now the detailed work begins. We must invite the youth associations, we must invite the railway companies, and we must, of course, look at the budget so that all this remains realistic. These points must now be tackled. My group wants the matter to succeed.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this proposal for a free Interrail project for 18-year-olds is beautiful and attractive. We invest in young people, we invest in training for European citizenship by travelling through Europe and in knowing our continent. However, we must also invest, and with equal conviction, in measures to combat youth unemployment, which remains the first dramatic emergency. I am pleased that the Group of the European People's Party has believed in this. I say this because the proposal for a free pass was put forward and supported by the Group of the Party of European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats through a pilot project in the Committee on Transport, which the GROUP of the European People's Party voted against. Having said that, it is a proposal that has important value especially if it is combined with a more explicitly formative and knowledge dimension. What? Firstly, substantial access must be guaranteed to all, with particular attention being paid to 18-year-olds from the less well-off. Secondly, Erasmus+ remains the Union's mobility programme and training programme and cannot be penalised in any way. We therefore need adequate resources for both of us, as has already been announced this evening for the Youth Guarantee. Thirdly, we must make the most of this pass in association with other cultural and citizenship initiatives, such as the so-called e-card for European students, an idea of the Committee on Culture on which the Commission services are already working, or within the framework of the European Year of Cultural Heritage, initiatives that encourage young people to discover our roots and identity. Knowledge of our Europe is the real antidote to populism, Euroscepticism and returning nationalism.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Travel educates – this is what the old Polish proverb says. Today we get to know the world, today in the age of the internet, in the age of television, we get to know the world through social media, but this picture is often false. This is evidenced by a few debates about my country here, which is why I am very pleased with this initiative, I support it. I think it would be Polish very insivising for many young people today to see Polish only from television.  Also, Herr Weber, Sie haben meine volle Unterstützung.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the In my group, we are discussing this very intensively at the moment. As you know, liberals are not necessarily the first to do so when it comes to throwing state benefits among the people, but in this case there is a heated debate because we believe that, in addition to the Europe of regulations, the directives, the summits, we also need a Europe of the soul, the heart and also the grassroots, and what better means there are. , as giving the young generation the opportunity to get to know Europe, to get to know Europe practically locally with new acquaintances, new experiences, to experience this great continent? Manfred Weber quoted the Spiegel article here – in response to Jean-Claude Juncker's State of the Union speech – in which all this was described in detail.  The young generation has a much more positive image of Europe than we professional Europeans sometimes have. It has a much more optimistic view of our continent than many who are always critical. Of course we have crises, and of course – let me make this very clear – the idea is that we are going now and giving young people this chance, not the solution to all our problems. Nobody claims that. But when I look at the figures, they are doable. The Commission has said that it likes this proposal. I think that's a good thing. Now the details are coming, now we are moving on to implementation, now we are going to check, now the whole thing has to be done. I think that's a great thing. The approval is huge, at least in Germany: 84 percent of the young people, 56 percent of the total population say: This is a good idea, because it is so obvious.  And I would like to say to our colleagues – both from the ECR and from the Social Democrats – that the more fathers and mothers this project has, the better. We have a nice German proverb: "Success has many fathers" – the mothers also take it for granted because of equality, even if it is biologically a bit daring. However, the more committed it is, the better, and I am pleased that the Commission will now come up with concrete proposals in the coming weeks and months.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank the two real fathers of the idea, who originally brought this idea to my attention. They are two young men from Germany Vincent-Imanuel Herr and Martin Speer – known on social media as Mr & Speer. I would also like to thank the two of them for the fact that, after the idea was put forward by me months ago, they failed first – including the European Commission – for not letting these two pro-Europeans get lost and said: we are going to move on! It's so good, it's got to get going.  When Mr Weber took this up in the last part-session, particularly in the case of State of the Union, I was surprised. When I listened to Mrs Bulc today, I thought: OK, but we are only three, do the others join in? And it is precisely this assessment that has been confirmed.  I think that's a great idea. With relatively little effort, a great deal of European cooperation and understanding can be achieved. I say this as a former Interrailer. I never went to the UK, I always had to sleep on the beach because I couldn't afford anything else, and I found it quite chic at the time. Let's see how today's generation handles it.  I would never say that this initiative can replace a proper Youth Guarantee, Erasmus, European Schools or even the Ecological Social Year in the European Union. But it could really replace some glossy brochures that cost a lot of money and some of the expensive image campaigns that the European Commission is doing. So I think we are all there today.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Weber, knowing from you that President Renzi is in favour of this initiative has, frankly, made me think that I am against it. But I am deluding it because this is indeed a laudable initiative, which would like to revive the spirit of the European Community that was breathed about twenty years ago, as you have all mentioned. However, there are critical issues. I have heard Commissioner Bulc, who has also expressed concerns that will certainly have to be carefully considered. One of these, for example, is the fact that, as the Commissioner herself has pointed out, there are already instruments such as EURES and Erasmus+ which are concerned with promoting the mobility of young people, both work-related and educationally linked. So the important thing is that we do not take away essential resources from these instruments that already exist, precisely because, considering all the 18-year-olds within the European Union, the budget is beginning to become quite significant as an impact. What are the other critical issues? The absence of meritocratic criteria and socio-economic criteria that contributes to making this initiative a little populist. Now, it seems strange that a populist initiative comes from you. Then there are geographical areas, I think of islands, that have different transport needs. So the talk of intermodality linked to the fact that not all Member States have access to Interrail as an association. Then, of course, money is being made available to a part of the railway industry, which thus guarantees safe revenues at the expense of other market players. So I am in favour of the initiative, but let us work together to find fairer and fairer ways without taking resources away from the instruments we already have.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: It has already been said that Europe is emotion. And you can taste emotion by traveling around. That is the crux of the proposal that we are discussing here this afternoon.
