I am therefore grateful to Mr Weber for combining the idea of many people at the State of the Union.  Why can the nationalists and the populists shout everything and we cannot do anything about it? We are opposed to this today.  It has to be about normal people. All those people who do Erasmus will be there, but the middle management of Europe has to travel around to see what Europe is.  This plan is good for mobility. I very much agree with Mrs Harms: the planes off, the trains in. This is good for the environment and for mobility.  The EPP never puts a plan on the table without money. That, of course, will be the crux of this debate: where do we get the money from? We are going to find the solution in cooperation with the Commission. But the railway companies are getting new customers and this can be customers for life. So they can contribute a bit. Another boundary provision is that the card must be requested. We're not going to send free cards all over Europe.  It would be best if, after the trip, mr Weber were to be sent a report on that trip. Then I'm sure his e-mail box will fill up.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr Weber, you will receive many messages in your e-mail following Mr Van de Camp's proposal, I also see convergences in green sensitivities, here among various political groups, fine, we are doing well.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, I want young people to get to know and love Europe. More importantly, they get to know each other. I therefore believe that every young person should have taken part in a European student exchange at least once. This often fails because of the parents' wallets. It would have been nice if there had been more commitment in this House during the last budget discussions. Yes, I think it is good that Europe is giving something to young people. But the truth is that money can only be spent once. If you invest it in Interrail tickets, you have to take it away somewhere else. I believe that we should give young people good training and jobs, better educational institutions and the opportunity to get to know each other. Then they will love Europe. But only if the whole thing is true. A single gift will not achieve this on its own.

name: Vicky FORD
text: – Mr President, I love trains, I love transport and I want to continue to make it really easy for young people to travel by train across Europe, across the EU and outside the EU, and I want to make sure it is cheap. But do we have to make it free? When I talk to young people, they ask me whether they are studying the right course to get a job; whether they will ever get a job; if when they get a job they will have a home; how they can go and study abroad; what they should do with their university fees. And then they might get onto human rights, they might talk about war, they might talk about the migration crisis and they might talk about climate change and equality, but no young person has ever asked me for a free railway ticket. So let’s keep it cheap, let’s keep it affordable, but let’s encourage young people to do what I did, which is to get a part—time job and buy a cheap ticket and go and enjoy travelling across Europe with the money they have had from their own opportunities, from their own earnings.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: – Mr President, this proposal is insane. This is a recycling of an old idea from the German Greens – and they like recycling, obviously – but with their customary ignorance of the costs of these schemes. The Commission has already rejected the idea once, but in your blind panic at realising that your precious project is now seen as an encumbrance – in fact, an irrelevance to the peoples of our continent – you have reached down into the wastebasket of forgotten grandiose money-wasting schemes and brought out this particular rotten apple. The truth is, you are only doing it because you see your great project slipping through your fingers and, as always when you fail with your policies, you resort to propaganda and bribery. So if you spend EUR 361 for each 18—year—old in the EU on this hare-brained irrelevance, it will cost EUR 1.9 billion a year. Even by the standards of the EU, this is madness.  When the countries of southern Europe are being crushed underfoot by Germany’s insistence that the interests of the euro and the French and German banks should be placed above the lives of ordinary citizens and steel workers in the United Kingdom are losing their livelihoods by the thousands, you people are proposing to waste around EUR 2 billion a year on this Soviet-style Intourist propaganda vehicle. Nero would applaud your insistence on fiddling while Europe burns.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, youth must be the priority of the European Union. Young people are essential for the European Union to remain an area of peace, freedom, tolerance, respect for human rights, sharing and solidarity. The diversity of the European Union is a wealth that must be valued. For this it is necessary, first of all, to know her. This is an opportunity for young people to strengthen contact between different cultures and to better understand the European reality. It facilitates the integration, inclusion and aid for the empowerment of young people. Mobility also helps the economy and allows us to deepen the feeling of belonging to this common space. The review of the multiannual financial framework is on the table, Commissioner, and this is the key moment for us to allocate the appropriate amounts for this initiative to start. I hope that the Commission and the Member States will be in favour of this initiative and I note as extremely positive the Commissioner's statement so that this initiative can start. This proposal is complementary. This is a proposal that does not replace any of the existing programmes and obviously must be inclusive and have the participation of all young people from all member states of the European Union. It is clear that this initiative does not give young people jobs but broadens horizons, helps to strengthen European citizenship and makes the European Union stronger, more united, more supportive and it is with the commitment of young people that we will continue to have the largest economy on the planet, the social state that we all defend, freedom, democracy, inclusion and tolerance.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Who can have anything against mobility? Any serious politician will support this. However, you have listed it, and I would like to renew this: you now have the task, Commissioner, of solving a variety of difficulties or adversities. First of all, they must overcome the financial bottleneck – additional money, that has become clear once again. It cannot be the case that the answer is that this should be taken out of Erasmus. In your administrative proposal, you must also ensure that all sections of the population benefit from it. After all, no one has any idea if those who can afford it anyway can continue to use it, but all sections of the population. Incidentally, you mentioned intermodality. We know that many students like to use long-distance buses. We need to examine to what extent this can also be spread to other modes of transport. Finally, you within the Commission must also clarify at the end that we do not come into conflict with DG Competition because it is problematic under state aid law. So first of all, do your homework, and if everything is positive, then I do not think we are against it.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: – When I first heard about the proposal through Mr Weber after the State of the Union, I thought for a moment that it was a joke. However, we are debating it today, so apparently not. I have already heard here that Europe is more than laws and figures, that it is also about souls. So we'll buy the souls by giving them a free Interrail pass. Buying at a high sum: it could cost almost 1.9 billion euros. I think we can really spend this money on better things.  I am glad to hear comments from the S&D Group today. I do think that this will not reach the average young people, but rather the young people who have been mediated. Because what is the high cost today? Not the transport, but the stay. By the way, I heard you say, you have to sleep on the beach and stuff, and i don't think that's desirable either.  So I think we need to help young people in a sustainable way by helping them get jobs. In this way, they will fare much better than by giving them a free Interrail pass now.

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I welcome the move by our group chairman, Manfred Weber, to have relaunched the debate on the Interrail ticket and to have pushed and submitted the proposal here once again. We must give more young people in Europe the opportunity to get to know their neighbours and to engage in social and cultural exchanges. The promotion of intercultural dialogue is now more important than ever. Mutual understanding and respect between different cultures must be the basis of our coexistence, so that our society can continue to exist in diversity and freedom. A well-thought-out, low-threshold approach to mobility, especially for young people, can certainly help to create opportunities for mutual acquaintance in Europe and to promote European identity formation. Above all, we should target young people, who have so far been little or not at all covered by the existing education programmes. Therefore, the programme must not have too many barriers to access. Well thought out, this idea was a useful addition to the existing European support programmes for young people in Europe, so that potential synergies can arise. To achieve this, we need good concepts that should be developed quickly. Funding must also be carefully examined, because, after all, the consequence should not be to further deprive the well-functioning but hopelessly underfunded education programmes of the funding base. Erasmus+ education programmes are still chronically underfunded, despite the 40% increase. Only a fraction of the good projects, such as a funding programme such as Youth in Action or Comenius or Leonardo, which are submitted, can also be supported in the end. The rate is partly less than 25 percent. Nevertheless, I think this new offer is important, because it reaches exactly another clientele. However, we need to promote mobility, which is on a financially sound basis, and I also call on the Member States and the Commission to participate actively in the project, including financially, and the railway companies could also contribute their share without further ado. Because Europe is built above all by the connection of people and not by paragraphs.

name: István UJHELYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. A year and a half ago, as Vice-Chairman of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I started my campaign here in Parliament and on the Commission to hear the proposals of the two young German activists, Vincent-Immanuel Herr and Martin Speer. I hit a lot of walls, I bounced back from the Commission, my pilot project proposal was voted down here in this House, but now I see that there has been a broad cooperation, and I thank Mr Weber and the other supporters for that. That is why I propose, colleagues, that we give a snapping response to the populists who are showing that the European Union is not needed! Let's give a big slap in the face to the nationalists who want to put the people together here in Europe. And let us use this programme to show everyone, even young people who do not have the money to travel, that we are Europe! I therefore propose, and I have also told Commissioner Bulc, that, as Vice-President for Tourism, head of the Tourism Working Committee, I propose that you be part of the project and that we also find the other sponsors, the tourism industry, the landlords. Let's make this a big European holiday in common.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. Following an impromptu proposal from the PPE-DE, we are sitting in the European Parliament, swimming in thousands of European problems and once again discussing a free interrail ticket for all 18-year-olds. Cost: probably three billion euros – three percent of the EU budget! The EU Commissioner for Transport says: great idea! The majority of the Council in Bratislava is enthusiastic. Today we say: Oh how great and oh how great. Honestly, what's the point? There is no front and back in the budget, but we, but you are throwing EUR 3 billion out of the window to shower the unsolicited Interrail generation with free tickets. Do you notice how cheap this expensive proposal is? Please explain to me how you intend to justify such electoral gifts in the EU Treaties? Bribe voters with free tickets! Stop peddling people with the multibillion-dollar Weber ticket just to put a monument to yourself. If you absolutely want to distribute money, give 500 euros to every newborn in Europe in a blocked account. Then, at 18, anyone can decide for themselves what they are using the money for. I think that most advocates here do not trust Europe for 18 years and are looking for a quick way to win over voters.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Europe is not built with laws, at least not just with laws. People must want it, otherwise it will not work. But for them to want to do so, we need understanding now more than ever, rather than prejudice, interest instead of stubbornness, solidarity instead of arrogance and national secreism. However, these values cannot be explained in theory. We can only achieve all this when people meet to learn, work and celebrate together. That is why I am a strong supporter of European programmes that enable people to meet, especially young Europeans, such as the voluntary European Year, the Erasmus+ programme or town twinning.  A temporary Interrail ticket for the 18-year-olds would be a great addition to the existing offers. But I would go even further in the future and provide every 16- to 23-year-old young person living in a town-twinning community with a free Interrail ticket to visit the town twinning every year. This strengthens such partnerships and will lead to new ones. Applying for free tickets will not exceed the EU budget.  I do see other areas of the financial framework in which we can save. I believe that the funds we are providing for the realisation of the free ticket are very well invested. Let us invest together in young people, thereby giving them a look beyond the national borders. This will restore faith in fair, solidarity-based, open coexistence in the European Union.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: – Mr President, yes, I would like to express, first of all, my surprise, because the Commission gently rejected two pilot projects of the Verts/ALE and S&D groups, and now, on the other hand, you say so, Mr Weber, and it seems that the idea has a different brilliance. The proposal for this gift, however, is presented to us as the totem against growing populism, a populism tied up by the cuts and suspensions that come from his finance minister, Mr Schsuble. First, he sends the youth to unemployment and forced emigration in search of work, and now we give them a trip. That said, it seems simple and advertising travel agency; I am not saying no, Mr Weber, and that you will get the Interrail in the future to be called the 'Weber Pass', but I would like to know: in addition to the trip, are we going to help you with the rest of the expenses or will only those who are rich in your house be able to accept the gift? And secondly, how much does the gift cost? We're told 1.5 billion euros a year. As your Finance Minister, Mr Sch-uble, continues to cut and cut the European budget, where are we going to get them, Mr Weber? Who are we going to take it from? Erasmus or Erasmus +, which does not arrive, or the Youth Employment Initiative, which does not arrive either? Mr Weber, the truth is that I would prefer this gift to be a return ticket for young Spaniards who have had to travel and emigrate to seek employment.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is true that young people need a job. This requires economic development first, but in a labour market where competition is complicated, education is needed and education the Union has programmes: Erasmus and all others and programmes that have been very well received by young people and very effective. However, knowledge is also needed, because knowing Europe, knowing traditions, history, good practices will greatly help young people to find a job, adapt more easily, will be able to apply what they have seen at home or elsewhere, I repeat, in this single labour market. There is, of course, a need for rules, criteria, and I am convinced that consultation with young people will find these rules and criteria so that everyone is satisfied.  Commissioner, you mention in your intervention that a pilot is needed, an initial application on a smaller scale. You have the opportunity in the 2017 budget to try to find a budget line from which you can finance this pilot and thus see, first of all, what is the reaction, what are the best criteria and what are the rules for application, and please do so.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Today we unite because Europe increasingly looks like a project in which enthusiasm is lacking. Everyone has expectations for the European Union, but few have the emotion. And we need the enthusiasm of young people to bring strength to our project. Europe very often looks like an autumn leaf, too exhausted from all crises. Only the enthusiasm of young people can turn autumn for Europe into spring.  Through this freedom, young people need to feel first-hand the meaning of a united Europe, so that they are not so easily susceptible to the rumors of its premature end. They are the ones who will most defend the project and need to know why. Sometimes only one day is enough to feel that something is worth it. If an 18-year-old spends even two days in another country, he will know that the lack of borders or their free passage into the European Union is an important achievement and we must not lose it.  This free card looks like maybe something small. Yes, it does not solve our big problems in the Middle East or our relations with Russia, for example, but it can change the lives of many people who will come out, mingle with the rest of the world, create connections and networks that they will need and will be useful to them in the future. Not all young Europeans have the amount of money to pay for this "pass". For many of them, Europe is still abroad, and if this idea can bring down an iron curtain in front of them, then it would be a great success of this project.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: I would first of all like to express my support for this proposal. It's democratic, because it's meant for every 18-year-old. It is more ecological than low cost flying and it is positively European. A real triple win.  But I also share the concern about the cost. That is why I have defended in the Belgian press today the proposal to offer a standard Interrail ticket. Without a discount, such a ticket costs 200 euros. And if we count that about 70% of European 18-year-olds will use this ticket, the annual cost amounts to 770 million euros.  I am convinced that if we really want to do it, an effort can be made within the current budget and a good solution can be found together with the Member States and the railway companies.  I would like to inform you that I will be in dialogue with the Flemish youth on this. For example, I have already made initial contacts with the Flemish Youth Council. In order to complete the final modalities of this proposal, the input and insights of young people can be very valuable.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today, at the meeting we had with the Commissioners in the presence of all the committees, I finally called for the time to have an integrated and horizontal policy for young people. We can't proceed for commercials. I recognise that this is a proposal which, by the way, was brought forward as early as last year, and then unfortunately rejected by my colleagues in the Committee on Transport, but I just wanted to point out that we have made a proposal for some time, so I would like the Commission to have a common table on these matters.  DG Connect and DG Education have been asked for a number of months – and I say this also to Mr Weber, who may not have known – by the Committee on Culture and Education, together with the Youth Forum, to proceed with the launch of the e-card for European students. What does it mean? A card that has the value of an award of European student status after the age of eighteen. It's not a one-off. It also means having a sustainability of this opportunity, because it means making large-scale agreements with Interrail, but also with other subjects and not only with Interrail, because we are interested not only in children going on holiday or traveling, but also having the opportunity to access cultural and educational services and hospitality. So that was the drawing. I am sorry that the Commission missed an opportunity to give a holistic answer, although I fully understand that this may be one of the instruments that that card set in motion.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the Interrail for Europe card, which will be offered at the end of its 18th year to every citizen of the Union, aims to improve the ability to make cross-border travel. This is a positive idea, but the debate has shown that, in fact, it is a German pre-election initiative which is quite expensive, since it costs EUR 3 billion, when the 'Guarantee for Youth Employment' initiative will cost, as we know, EUR six billion at a time when Europe is full of armies of unemployed and even unemployed people in the European South. I also believe that the initiative should not absorb funds from other European education and training programmes and certainly not unemployment programmes. It should also be stressed that, if the initiative continues, then there should be a level playing field for all citizens of the Union and in particular for the inhabitants of island regions. Finally, I believe that there should be funds to strengthen the European Union's rail networks so that the Interrail card can be used for safe rail infrastructure.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, I very much appreciate that Mr Weber wants to give young people, regardless of their social background or education, the opportunity to discover europe's diversity. I am sure that young people will appreciate the opportunity to travel through Europe, just until they return to their homes, to report to the labour office as unemployed, to build their careers as unpaid trainees, or to fall into the trap of new disadvantageous contracts, which the EPP still supports. Giving people a bent bone is the cornerstone of right-wing politics, but we on the left prefer to address the issue of raising living standards and the differences between the social class that right-wing governments have supported with policies of cuts. Young people certainly have the right to a future in prosperity and social reconciliation, and instead you send them on a trip in the hope that they will live on it all their lives.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to stress one more time that the proposed idea deserves further analysis. There are many challenges to be addressed and the Commission is committed to exploring all possible options, considering also budgetary and administrative constraints. However, at this stage the Commission cannot take further commitments. I do not want to raise expectations which we would not be able to meet later on. So let me also be very clear that if we move in this direction, this can by no means jeopardise existing instruments.  I know that ideas for youth can quickly engage our emotions, and indeed it can bring a lot of positive attention, but to be successful we need to take a very pragmatic approach. So I agree also with those who say that we need to take a closer look at the regions without rail, so my vision would lead towards multimodal solutions for youth where rail projects could be the first step.  I also agree with those who are saying that we need to work closely with service providers. I would invite all involved to see our possible proposal also as a way to develop future uses of public services and public transport. We have some positive examples of a similar nature on an urban mobility level that we can also learn from. So I can confirm that we will work on this idea with you to set up a scheme which will be inclusive, manageable and truly beneficial to all European youth.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, it was to your predecessor I asked to make a point of order. I just want to say that, while I have to respect his decision, he said he had eight on the list for the catch—the—eye procedure and he took only four. That was his decision, but if he had been vigilant in cutting people off when they had passed their time, he would have had plenty of time – not just for four extra speakers, but for about twenty-four. But he has made his decision and he has left. I just wanted to make that point.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Colleague, I wish you were right. I have been told by the services, however, that we are running way behind schedule and even if he had been more stringent perhaps, as you desire, it would probably still have been a limited number of colleagues able to speak under catch-the-eye. Sorry about that. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Writing. I support the idea of The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, Manfred Weber, to allow every EU citizen to have an Interrail ticket for train travel in Europe free of charge for the eighteenth anniversary. We will discuss with other groups in the European Parliament and the European Commission how this idea can be put into practice, and we will now carefully examine the costs and funding options and the administrative burden for this project. It will not be easy. But we believe that it is an investment in young people and therefore an investment in the future of Europe!

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I support this initiative because it directly brings us to the young people of Europe. They would be given the opportunity to experience and get to know other countries, languages and cultures. I would like young people to develop something like a European consciousness and to be more enthusiastic about Europe: because the EU is more than just an economic community – we are also a culture – and a community of values!

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. – In these challenging times for Europe, following the Brexit vote and the divisions among the Member States on the asylum system for migrants, the initiative to launch a Free InterRail initiative should be welcomed and fully embraced with nothing else than enthusiasm. The proposal aims at offering InterRail passes to European teens on their 18th birthday, letting them travel by train across Europe for free for a month. It is often said that travelling opens up the eyes to new horizons and to learn about diversity of cultures. I could not agree more. I particularly encourage the implementation of such a proposal for teenagers to enable them to explore by train the ‘freedom of movement’ across European frontiers. Sometimes, I think we forget how much we actually achieved with Schengen. On the contrary today we are setting up again walls and barriers among our Member States and third countries. My personal hope is that this Free InterRail initiative will make young people even more conscious of that freedom that once we could only dream about and to engage for a stronger and united European Union in the future.

name: Anne SANDER
text: In writing. I support this initiative 100% and thank Manfred Weber for proposing it. Indeed, this interrail pass, which would allow any 18-year-old to visit Europe by train - ecological transport if any - can become the second initiation rite of European youth after the Erasmus exchange. With the advantage of being more accessible, since only 2% of students go on exchanges abroad.  It is a concrete initiative, with a reasonable budget. In any case, "travel is the only thing we buy that makes us richer." It would allow young people to discover the other, his culture, his country, and become aware of a common history and a common European destiny.  Of course, this proposal is only a drop in the bucket compared to the challenges europe faces in helping young people: unemployment, the loss of reference, the ecological, digital and demographic upheavals of the world. But this is a first step. And every journey starts with a first step.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. I support the proposal to make the Interrail Pass free for every Young European who turns 18. The idea was launched by the German greens this summer. We want to encourage young people to have foreign experiences, broaden their horizons and show them that taking the train to go on holiday is fun. It is certainly more ecological than buying massively cheap Ryanair tickets. If there are budgetary concerns, perhaps we can think about more just taxation in aviation? It will be discussed at the aviation conference in Montreal at the same time. Maybe it shouldn't even be free, but is it enough to make a concession or a hefty discount? A thorough analysis of this investment, the availability and capacity of the trains, the integration of the proposal into the current Interrail system and in the total train supply, is needed. The statements by NV-A colleague Van Bossuyt that 'the European Parliament is trying to buy love' is ridicuul. This is about choosing what European money is spent on. Spend billions on surveillance technology or the nuclear industry? Or choose to use the efforts of a few hundred million young people to broaden their horizons and get to know other Member States, people and cultures?

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Freedom of movement is one of the pillars of the European single market, being the principle that allows millions of citizens to move from one Member State to another. This facility contributes not only to the economic growth of the Union and the promotion of tourism, but also to the cementing of a consciousness of European identity. Today's statement by the European Commissioner for Transport Violeta Bulc on the granting of train subscriptions for young people recognises the urgent need to promote mobility, especially among citizens under 30. The EC must respond to requests from the European Parliament to prioritise the needs of this category which has been deeply affected economically in the wake of the crisis. A free subscription to the InterRail system would allow young people to discover in time what Europe has to offer and would also promote a sustainable but underutilised means of travel. However, the Commissioner's statement does not fully meet parliament's expectations. The Commission is still cautious and unambitious that could breathe new life into the discussion about youth mobility. However, the Socialist group will continue to struggle so that all European citizens who turn 18 can benefit from an InterRail subscription.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – Manfred Weber of the CSU is not too bad for anything and is scrapping an old proposal from the Greens: he wants to give all young people an Interrail ticket for their 18th birthday, so that they can travel through Europe for three weeks at the taxpayer's expense. This is how European crisis management goes at the CSU: give away train tickets for two billion euros a year to all eighteen-year-olds. The leitmotif of the CDU/CSU and the European People's Party (EPP) used to be: "More Europe is the solution". This now becomes: "More rail travel is the solution." Manfred Weber stole the idea. The 'Interrail free' project was originally initiated by the Greens Rebecca Harms and Michael Cramer in the European Parliament's Transport Committee – and by the European Commission in the context of the budget discussions with the worst grade C/D (Ref. Ares(2016)4003541 - 29/07/2016). A green idea revived at junk level by the CSU! A three-week Interrail ticket costs 374 euros. In 2015, 5.4 million young people reached the age of eighteen (EU-28). Manfred Weber therefore wants to spend EUR 2 billion on rail travel. And who pays the 19-year-old teenager three weeks of hotels, hostels, food and drink? The CSU is welcome to pay for this from its black party coffers, but not from tax money!

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on "Future developments in telecommunications services, appropriate use and calls within the EU" (2016/2915(RSP)).

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, access to high quality and affordable connectivity for all citizens and businesses seamlessly across the European Union is essential for realising the full benefits of the digital single market. Therefore, before addressing the important issue of roaming, let me stress the importance of the Comprehensive Connectivity Package the Commission adopted in September. We want ambitious connectivity targets and modern rules to support these goals. I am confident that you in the European Parliament share the need for a swift but comprehensive handling of this ambitious package.  Turning now to roaming: in 2015, the European Parliament and the Council adopted a regulation establishing that from 15 June 2017, retail roaming surcharges should be abolished. This regulation only addressed roaming surcharges. It did not aim at price harmonisation or at lowering the price of international calls, which I will address in the second part. Abolishment of retail roaming surcharges is essential for citizens and businesses across the European Union, and the Commission is fully committed to deliver. Now we need to complete the steps necessary to ensure it. When agreeing the end of roaming surcharges in November 2015, the European Parliament and the Council asked the Commission to put in place necessary accompanying measures, the reform of the roaming wholesale market, including the setting of price caps, to set up fair use of our ‘roam like at home’ to prevent abusive or anomalous usage of the system, and an exceptional derogation system in cases where replication of ‘roam like at home’ would otherwise provoke price increases for domestic customers. None of this is an easy task, given the diversity of existing business models in the European Union and fragmentation of the markets, but I am convinced that together we can find solutions and deliver on what we commonly agreed.  Let me also briefly turn to the issue of intra-EU calls which has also been raised in this House. I agree with you that, in a single market, barriers should fall and the price of calls should not depend on the country code. To tackle the fragmentation inside the European Union, the Commission proposed the new electronic communications code. It provides clear rules for the whole of the whole EU for an inclusive single market where competitive investments in networks will ensure high quality connectivity and where consumers enjoy a high level of protection and have access to affordable services. But besides this, the proposal also includes measures that will help to increase competitive pressure and reduce the scope for price discrimination. In particular, we propose the unification of call termination rates also for international calls arriving from other Member States. This will lead to a reduction of the cost for outgoing international calls.  Furthermore, the markets are adjusting to new realities. The growing use of internet-based communications applications has already reinforced the competition for international calls, and it is still early days for such market developments. The codes supported by the market developments will ensure that every European has effective access to wireless broadband, which will facilitate the use of alternative means of communications to make online competition work for consumers, also as regards intra-EU calls.

name: Viviane REDING
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the EU keeps its promises: after years of tireless fighting, roaming fees will soon belong to the past. I still remember in 2004 that, as Commissioner for the Information Society and Media, I made the alarming observation that to make a phone call or send an SMS from abroad was four times more expensive than a domestic call or SMS. So here we are, 13 years later, and roaming surcharges will finally be abolished. To deliver by the deadline of 15 June 2017, the EU needs to agree on implementing the text without creating any loopholes that could reintroduce roaming fees through the back door. The Commission should stick to its fair use proposal, which includes neither time nor volume limits to roam – like at home – and the Council should consent to an ambitiously low wholesale price. But that is not all: the European Parliament is readying itself for the next battle – the one against abusive mobile prices charged for intra—EU calls from your home country to another EU country. Why? Because those fall outside the scope of roaming regulations and hence remain priced at prohibitive levels – often EUR 1 per minute for calls and 15 cents for SMS.  This situation makes absolutely no sense, and that is why more than 150 MEPs from across all political spectrums asked the Commission to address the issue in the telecom package. Well, the Commission did not, so the Parliament has to. Rest assured that Parliament will tackle that problem while working on the telecom package in the next weeks and months.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the principle of roam like at home roaming was a battle that this Parliament has been fighting for some time. I also claim that my political group, the Group of Socialists and Democrats, has done so personally and with great force and consistency, over all these years until the final negotiations on the package that we approved last year. We welcome the fact that, with this proposal, there is consistency with that vote of Parliament, with that common position of Parliament and the Council. Because you see, Commissioner, I am convinced, as you are convinced, that there is credibility for Europe before our citizens if we have consistency in all our steps. This is a battle that certainly cannot be separated, and we agree, from the correct application of the rules and respect for the activities of operators. That is why we agree with the Fair Use Clause, which must also be achieved by lowering wholesale prices, since we are dealing with this game. We are convinced that this must be done with a system that can be as simple and user friendly as possible. We welcome the fact that the proposal imposes neither volume limits nor time limits, because it would have been inconsistent with our parliamentary vote, and that it is based on the approach of a stable link with the country. However, we ask you, while appreciating the proposal that has been made, that we always take into account that consumers must be protected both from the point of view of data protection and in cases of disagreement with telephone companies, because the procedures put in place by operators must be transparent, simple, efficient and non-invasive, no later than necessary. It is therefore necessary that the guiding principle of a single market must also guide us to ensure an increasingly harmonised fair use policy, which is no different from one country to another and which does not include a list of different indicators in each European state, because this would once again set us back on the road to a genuine single market. I think that if we continue along this path, this magic word roam like at home will be of use to the whole of Europe, which must be felt by the citizens as home.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: on the ecr group. – Mr President, the European Union needs a digital single market and cutting-edge electronic communications on 5G networks. In this sense, I generally welcome the Commission's support for connectivity across the European Union. And I also welcome the ambition that is being put into the package, even though our political group has traditionally not been a big supporter of EU-wide objectives. The telecommunications industry needs regulatory certainty for large investments in networks. I therefore hope that this proposal is future-proof and anticipates developments in technology and end-user behaviour so that we do not have to change the regulatory framework again soon. I see as positive the clearer, and in particular the link between the existing directives, as well as clearer rules on consumer protection. More problematic is the management of the spectrum, which is the responsibility of the Member States. Conclusion on roaming: I believe that experts and BEREC will be able to set up a policy of reasonable use so that clear and uniform rules for operators and regulators apply from the outset and that the end of roaming is a happy end for all.

name: Jens ROHDE
text: for the ALDE Group. Mr President! It is actually somewhat ironic that today we are going to discuss fair use and rules of abuse when it comes to citizens' use of telephony and data to telecommunications companies. This shows that the Liberal Group's proposal of the summer of 2013, which at the time caused a great deal of anger and fury, but which nevertheless gained a majority in the resolution just before the summer recess, is a huge success. At the time, it was a question of ensuring fair use for the individual consumer. The tax on roaming for telephony and text messages was barely 300% above the cost price and 698% on average above the cost of network access when staying outside your own country. That is why it is a huge victory for Parliament that we have now reversed the issue and discussed the reverse problem instead of, namely how to prevent citizens from abusing a system in which we have duty-free roaming but still do not yet have a real internal market for common frequencies.  First of all, Commissioner, it requires a very, very clear definition of what abuse really is. In my worldview, there can never, ever be abuse in the case of the traveller or of the person seconded to his business for a shorter or medium period. I would like to make that clear. Abuse can only be if you cheat with your domicile or you try to make a business out of buying sim cards in another country and selling them in a third country. That is why I would also like to acknowledge to the Commission that it withdrew its proposal of 90 days and instead agreed to the premise that abuse on the basis of a place of residence or illegal purchase and sale is what is based on.  I still think that there is a great deal of ambiguity in what the Commission has made, but I believe that we can find a common solution and I expect everyone to live up to their election promises and to take their responsibility for finding solutions, for everyone to live up to the election promises that came in the 2014 election campaign, including the Commission and also the Member States.

name: João FERREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, the asymmetric nature of the European Union is revealed in small things as in great things. Ending roaming in mobile communications is a long-announced goal. Apparently consensual, it has even served purposes of electoral propaganda. But behind the goodness of the proposal is the reverse of the medal: the roaming call has more costs than those associated with national calls. Who will pay these costs?  In addition, net tourism receiving areas will have seasonal pressure increases on their networks, which may require investments in their strengthening. Who pays them? Operators in these countries have already warned: if it is not possible to reflect these and other costs in roaming charges they will be reflected in the national tariffs. In other words, to be clear: it is foreseeable that consumers in southern countries are able to bear the costs of ending roaming. This is the single market for telecommunications. In this as in other sectors, liberalisation and free competition serve objectives of monopolistic concentration on a European scale, serves neither consumers, households, businesses nor the national interest.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Here's a blue card. But we are so far behind in time that I cannot allow them. I ask for your understanding.

name: Michel REIMON
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I would like us not to discuss roam like at home, but phone like at home, that it is not just about roaming, but about telephone in all areas in general. We are laging far behind. We have been waiting a long time for an agenda item, which was about Interrail, and for young people to be able to travel through Europe free of charge by train and then feel a sense of Europe. I believe that nothing could make us feel more that Europe is a home and a living space than that you do not feel abroad if you drive a few kilometres across the border, use your mobile phone and surf something on the Internet. From a European point of view, this should be the way forward, where we want it all to be a communication space. And that's especially important for the boys. We are not on this path. In the first reform of the internal telecoms market, we abandoned net neutrality in order to cushion the profits of the telecoms industry in the roaming sector, it was said. However, roaming was not abolished. Now we have a fair-use clause, which can ultimately still have the left over that there will be roaming. We will see how the market decides here. I'm not confident it's going to get really much better. And that was decided, and then we did not clarify: what is the telephony in other EU Member States? What are wholesale prices? All this is still open, and it is not a reasonable picture. I hope that we will reach a good common conclusion by the end of the period. I am not very confident at the moment.

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, EU legislation to scrap data roaming charges was widely publicised by the Remain campaign as one of the great reasons to stay in the EU. But, as many of us have learned, EU interference on markets simply pushes up prices for businesses and consumers alike, and this case is no exception. One UK network operator has announced that the priced call internationally will rise by 60% a minute, whilst another has announced that domestic call prices will be increased by 25% a minute.  EU interference in this area was at least meant to open up market competition by allowing consumers the choice from across the continent, but compromises to the text now mean that roaming abroad will still have its limits, leaving most citizens tied to purchasing from a domestic network provider. More regulation, less competition and higher prices exemplify all the reasons why Britain will be better off outside the single market.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Commissioner, i would like to begin by thanking the Colleagues! One word is boundaries. Border. Do we remember what borders were very recently in Europe? We experienced them differently. One proportion of Europeans could perhaps travel to other countries, but free travel without a visa – studying freely, working freely – was unthinkable. For those who lived in the Baltic States, behind the "Iron Curtain", still in the Soviet Union, to travel outside this Union at all without special permits was not even unthinkable. If anyone else received these special permits, then there was often some obligation to report to the cheque what had been seen and heard.  Today, we live in the same European Union, where we really have borders open so that we often even forget that it was not very recently. We have a free movement of goods, services, people, capital, which we simply assume to be, but still, when we travel on our mobile phones, suddenly the old borders appear – increased tariffs. God guards, I'm going to want my mom to call me how much it's going to cost me! We have now partially resolved this with our regulation, which will abolish roaming charges from June next year. We have yet to agree on limiting wholesale tariffs, but we will do so. But the other part we still have to talk about. Why is it cheaper or more expensive to call from one Member State, say, from home, than from another. We have these international tariffs. It remains to be seen how to introduce or, more appropriately, eliminate unnecessary prices, open up competition.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, let us act in time to get rid of roaming next summer. In the internal market it should be possible to buy goods and services freely. Buying a SIM card is different. A SIM card always uses the local network for phone calls, text messages and data. That is why we need different tools. Network operators will still charge one another when we travel. This continues even if that price is not charged to the traveller. That is why we are making legislation for operators on wholesale price caps. As rapporteur, I give my word that this Parliament will be ready by the end of November.  There is a strong link between the fair use policy and wholesale caps. Today there are huge differences in SIM card prices between the Member States: for phone calls some seven times and for data 35 times or even a hundred times if I look at my home country, Finland, and compare, as there operators do not limit data volumes at all on the monthly bill. Fair use policy is needed to avoid abusive use, and so as not to put an additional burden on consumers. It is clear that we cannot all order the cheapest SIM cards in Europe and make that operator pay the local operator whose network we will actually use. Mobile usage also varies a lot, with the average use of data ranging from some 0.30 gigabytes to some 10 gigabytes a month. The good news is that investing in capacity will dramatically bring down the unit cost, and data is the most important – if not everywhere, let me tell you that it will be soon. Cheap and fast data is our aim because we are aiming for the gigabyte society. We need low enough wholesale caps so that all operators can provide roaming free services and the telecom sector remains competitive, as stated in the digital single market strategy. Then there is less need and less fear of restriction on the roaming free services and fair use policy will not be used to limit the right of Europeans to have ‘roam like at home’. I think the fair use policy needs to be clarified to a certain extent. Fair rules for consumers and information are needed.

name: Jens ROHDE
text: Mr President! I would just like to express my great amazement at the way in which this debate is being taken in this House. There is no room for questions, there is nothing there is room for because we are under time pressure. Well, it is not us who sit here and work in this area who have that problem. We are talking about some of the highest-profile territory at all from the 2014 election campaign. All parties, including the President's own party, went to the polls on this, and three weeks ago the Commission put forward a proposal for a 90-day restriction. The Commission has now changed this to something where it is said that the principles may be right, but that there are many unresolved issues and we do not have a China man's chance here to discuss what really matters to the individual citizen of Europe, because we have to move on. That, I think, is simply under all the criticism, under all the criticism! That is not acceptable, Mr President! We should have space and time to discuss something that has been ... (the President estook the floor)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Dear colleague Jens Rohde, I would like to thank Mr Rohde for his Personally, I would also prefer us to be able to do it differently. A full debate has been added to the agenda today. At the moment, the forecast is that this evening's last debate will end sometime between 11.30 p.m. and 11.45 p.m. We must therefore have a more compact debate, and that is why, unfortunately, I cannot allow blue cards. The issue is important, it is a political issue. It is also important that it is debated here in this House. But tonight it is only in the narrow terms of the time-corset that has arisen from the additional debate on Greece. I ask for your understanding and I hope that next time it will be better and a little more lively.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: – Mr President, in this debate, I want to stress one important thing. Before, consumers travelled abroad and had a fear of big bills when they used their phone. Now, this fear will be eliminated if the roaming charges are abolished and there is no limitation of days. More consumption definitely means more revenues, so nobody can deny that everybody will benefit from this. This is why the fair use clause needs to be really fair for all parties involved.  However, I want to stress that we have to keep in mind what our end goal is. Our end goal is not to introduce different checks on where people live and IP addresses and requests for documents; our end goal is to have a single market for telecom services. We have to keep this in mind.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Internet and telecommunications are a basic need of all citizens, and roaming charges stand in the way and hinder the free movement of citizens. Fair use yes, but please be nice for everyone involved. And if roaming is to be free in the future only if there is no "abnormal" or "abusive" use, I understand this in terms of "abusive", in the case of large-scale sales and resales of SIM cards e.B., but what is "abnormal"? And why should roaming only be free for "periodic travel"? What are periodic travel?  If a provider now finds an abuse, it can apply to the regulator for roaming charges. To do so, however, he must carry out an investigation, and that is profiling, namely with the metadata of the suspected abuser, through which the border crossings and communication habits become visible. However, that is precisely what we did not mean by the General Data Protection Regulation. Fair use is really different, and what I want is for roaming charges to finally be abolished and for you to deliver on the EU's promise to citizens.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today, the digital and telecommunications markets are the key to creating new jobs, to innovation. This is important for citizens, as is roaming, for which charges should disappear in June next year. Now we need to look at the national rates, because they are too high, and the internet, even fast, is not able to replace faster, reliable links. So we need to invest in the highest capacity networks. Every city, every region, every village in the Union must be connected. And now the most important thing: the use of radio bands. We still have 28 national regulations, prices, schedules. How to compete in 4G and 5G without such unification?  The discussion of the digital revolution concerns all industries. I would therefore like to encourage the industry in the room or listening to us online to have a strong discussion about making radio bands available for our online needs. This may further lead Member States to meet the expectations of the Commission, the European Parliament, the expectations of all citizens.

name: Dan NICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I welcome the presence of the Commission and the willingness to find a solution to the issue of fair use. We all appreciate the replacement of the previous 90-day proposal. Under the Treaties, European citizens are guaranteed free movement in the European Union. We must also guarantee our citizens the right to speak at the same rates as at home when travelling within the European Union, and those who want to use this freedom fraudulently must be prevented. The Commission, together with operators and national regulatory authorities, must work together to ensure a harmonised fair use policy within the European Union. Given that roaming charges will be abolished in 2017 the next necessary step is to address the issue of unjustified prices in intra-EU telecommunications services. Cross-border phone calls, SMS, they are too often expensive for most consumers and are an obstacle to the completion of the single telecom and digital market. The revision of the regulatory framework for electronic communications is a good opportunity to address this issue as well. I also recall that the objectives of the Digital Agenda 2020 are 30 Mbps for all citizens of the European Union and that at least 50% of European households must have internet connections of more than 100 Mbps by 2020. What can we do to keep all our citizens connected, wherever they live, so that we have a real digital society? The European Commission is proposing to create a gigabit company by 2025, which is very good, but it is also necessary for the European Union to also financially support investments in high-capacity networks beyond the new regulatory framework. The European Electronic Communications Code, as well as the 5G Action Plan submitted by the Commission, are very good responses. Investments in infrastructure are needed to have a truly integrated digital market and make progress.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, October 27, 2015 was a very important day for the EU. That was the day that this Parliament voted to end mobile charges and remove one of the biggest obstacles to the completion of the single market. I think it helped to showcase the benefits of EU membership, it ended major bills when people came home and encourages, therefore, people to travel. It boosts tourism and makes it easier for businesses to work in the single market. I sympathise with the people of the UK who, as a result of fear mongering and post-truth-era populist campaigning, may not get to reap the benefit of this. However, I am pleased also with the clarification on fair use. The idea that roaming should be limited to 90 days, or 30 days consecutively, was not acceptable and I am pleased that this now is being changed. We cannot have a watered-down roaming free Europe.  I also want to commend my colleague here alongside me, Viviane Reding, who has kick—started our next big challenge: ending intra-EU phone charges. It makes no sense in the current situation to have free roaming and yet to keep intra-EU phone charges, which is not acceptable. We have to work hard to get rid of this rip-off as well, and only when we have that completed, the end of roaming and the end of intra-phone charges within the EU, can we say that we are moving correctly to complete the digital single market.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the previous proposal of the Commission to restrict roaming to only 90 days a year was absolutely unacceptable. We promised citizens a total ban on roaming, not 90 days of credit. There should be no limit in terms of timing or volume. Therefore, I welcome the Commission’s new approach to fair use of free roaming, which does not impose any maximum restrictions. However, I still have some serious concerns, especially when it comes to consumer protection.  First, rules should not be based on the assumption that the ‘roam like home’ principle will be abused by operators and bona fide consumers. It is normal that once the roaming charges are removed, people will use this service more. Consumers should not be penalised simply because they use a service that was previously too expensive or because no travel occurred in the last 12 months, as the Commission seems to imply. Second, the Commission needs to clarify how, when and what will trigger the fair clause. How will consumers be protected from abusive contractual clauses and subjective assessments added to the non-exhaustive lists of criteria that the telecom companies will use to identify abusive behaviour? Third, the unfair definitions on matters such as periodical travelling, abusive use or anomalous use could lead to different practices among Member States. How will the Commission ensure the application of a more harmonised fair use policy which does not confuse consumers across borders and, more importantly, does not disappoint them? Fourth, the stable link requirements must be simple and sensible without imposing unnecessary administrative burdens on the consumer. Last, but not least, we also need strong data protection and consumer privacy safeguards and proper complaint mechanisms. Consumers must be given enough time and access to easy, efficient and transparent complaint procedures before they are penalised. Consumers expect what was promised to them. Let’s not let them down.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union was built on four freedoms: freedom of movement of workers, freedom of movement of goods, freedom of movement of services and freedom of movement of capital. Today, however, we still do not get rid of the tariffs that telephone companies continue to impose on the internal market.  Last Monday 26 September, the Commission came to the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy to set out its proposal to end roaming from 15 June next year, which will mean a major step forward in the creation of the European single market. To the battle against roaming will follow the battle to end the high and different rates to call another Union country from our country. It is clear that we need to build a true common digital and telecommunications market. Roaming is only an intermediate station and, therefore, the Commission should only relax for a moment to enjoy this progress, to build renewed forces and to continue to fight in the construction of this common market, a market which should already have a real regulatory body at Union level.  We do not understand how it is possible that, since the Commission's proposal of 11 September 2013 on the single market in telecommunications already had a possible solution to limit the over-demands in the main communications to other countries of the Union, there is not yet a legislative proposal on the table on which we can work.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, happy, who like Ulysses has made a fine journey, because, from 2017, he will no longer pay roaming charges, but unfortunate the one who remains, he will continue to pay for his calls abroad. We have promised to end roaming charges by June 2017. We are on track to achieve this with the finalization of the ongoing negotiations on reasonable use and the revision of wholesale rates. However, we have to be very careful in our communication because otherwise, on 15 June 2017, European citizens will think that they can call anywhere in Europe at the cost of a national appeal. However, this will not be the case: the Alsatian border worker who wants to call his German colleagues will always pay extra. After abolishing roaming, we must work to lower the sometimes exorbitant price of calls abroad. However, we have to be careful of two pitfalls: first, some operators already offer non-surcharged calls in Europe - so the market is competitive in a few Member States - and secondly, the telecommunications infrastructure is national - when you call abroad, you call on another network, so who has to pay for that?  I am sure we will be able to deal with these issues in the next telecommunications code.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Commissioner, the new legislation on the abolition of the costs associated with calls between countries of the European Union, which comes into force in June 2017, has to ensure the best service for people, greater transparency, transparency for the market, must prevent the costs that will no longer be paid by European citizens traveling through the European Union from being indirectly imputed to those who do not and must ensure the effective end of roaming within a framework guarantee ing citizens' privacy rights.  The European Commission's proposal is based on the principles of portability and reasonableness. In order to be effective, it is essential that reasonableness verification mechanisms are simple, transparent and do not in any case allow discriminatory and anti-competitive actions by operators; that data protection and user privacy be ensured and that this measure is accompanied by an investment incentive plan, in networks and infrastructure, which harmonises the prevailing conditions in the various territories and meets demand pressures, in particular demand that is seasonal and derived from tourist flows.  It is in these measures that we must continue to work until roaming is achieved as soon as possible, Commissioner.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Viviane Reding reminded us that we have been dealing with this topic for 13 years now. We are actually dealing with the subject of the abolition of borders. Moreover, it has started to fight against additional charges when we cross borders, and let us remember that there are no borders. It's been 13 years, but data charges have fallen more than twentyfold, and roaming charges have fallen several times when we're abroad. Why? Because together with the European Commission we have worked on this and regulated prices. Companies, after all, did not spat, despite these job-like announcements that we have heard many times here. I, too, would prefer that we do not have to regulate so that competition forces prices to fall, but there is no competition and the consumer, when choosing an offer in his own country, is mainly guided by the prices of domestic calls. As a result, foreign talks are horrendously expensive. I agree with everyone who said: Roam like at home is supposed to make Europe our home. We should therefore not be charged for cross-border contacts, since there are no borders. To conclude with one sentence: I very much regret that the proposal to regulate the prices of cross-border telephones within the European Union was not included in the last package and we, the European Parliament, will add it to the European Commission's proposal.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, no matter how much one tries to find a problem or a flaw in this very important proposal and in this important work carried out by the Commission and the European Union, it will not succeed, because this measure is indeed a purely social measure, it is a measure that actually removes borders, it is a measure in favour of consumers, it is a measure that strengthens the social face and social sensitivity of the European Union.  I think it is the first step in the field of telecommunications, because there is a second step which is very important which is the reduction of internet charges and not only. When the founder of Facebook announces that he will personally cover areas that do not have access to the Internet, then I think it is impossible for the European Union not to be able to do so. I do not believe, Commissioner, that the European Union cannot pilot the programme for free and free Internet access in isolated island regions such as Cyprus, Malta, the Canary Islands, thereby giving the message that it is a pioneer, not only for fees, but also for the whole Internet, which is very important.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – Mr President, the debates on the abolition of roaming have lasted for many years. Consumers will not see the final abolition of roaming charges until next year. In doing so, they expect to be able to make phone calls, send messages and use the Internet throughout their stay abroad, whether for work or study reasons, at no additional cost or restriction. The de facto abolition of roaming cannot therefore lead to the setting of blanket additional surcharges or burdensome requirements for consumers simply because the system could hypothetically be misused. I also share the concerns of consumer organisations, inter alia, that the measures taken should not lead to systematic checks on telephone users by service providers. For example, my colleague Marlene Mizzi spoke in detail about other retries. Consumers must not pull the shorter end in relation to operators. I therefore believe that the Commission will take due account of these comments in the proposal.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, we live in the age of information and communications, at a time when human needs are largely served electronically. IT and telecommunications provide new opportunities for the world's economies, as well as businesses, to grow and become more operational. It is a growing, innovative sector, the key of which cannot be questioned.  For these services to function effectively on a continent with as many borders as Europe, net neutrality is required, firstly, to ensure equal free access for consumers and businesses, and secondly, to abolish roaming charges, roaming, which will contribute to the free movement of persons and services and to strengthen the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, so as not to create electronic customs. Roaming must therefore be abolished immediately. I would remind you that the original aim was to abolish it in 2015. The Commission, bowing to pressure from telephone companies, changed it for 2017 in terms and conditions. Finally, gentlemen, respect the citizens.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for this fruitful discussion we are having here right now. If I can just agree with Jens Rohde that time was too limited to broach all those difficult questions within one minute or even four minutes. It is practically impossible. So let’s remember from where we started. A Member of the European Parliament, Viviane Reding, made a proposal and then we started to decrease roaming surcharges. But just one and a half years ago we were faced with the ‘5+5+5’ proposal: five minutes in five days in a year, ‘roam like at home.’ And people had to be happy about this proposal.  We had hot debates and we were able to find a solution. Thanks to this, roaming surcharges have decreased by 75% since this May. This is the first year people have said that they did not feel as if somebody was murdering their wallets when spending their summer holidays in other countries. In comparison with 2009 prices, we can say that the cost of roaming surcharges for calls, and SMS messages have decreased by 92%, and even by 96% for data.  Today, many of you said that that we are bullish with regard to roaming surcharges. It is not a done deal yet and finalising the whole process is very complicated.  As was mentioned by Mr Pereira, Member States are in very different situations. In southern countries operators had to make investments to provide services to tourists visiting those countries only during the three summer months. It means that those operators are not able to get revenues during the other nine months. Of course I am simplifying the situation. It means they have the right to ask for higher prices. And this is the reason why they have blocked this wholesale reform. There is now a blocking minority in the south and also in the north.  What is wrong in the north? Nothing is wrong, but, as Miapetra Kumpula-Natri knows, in Finland for example, for the same price you can get 100 times as many gigabytes than in Hungary. While the average consumption of gigabytes in the European Union is just one gigabyte per month, in Finland it is 10 gigabytes per month. Nevertheless, I think if this pattern of trips made by Europeans during the year does not change then the majority of service providers will survive. It means we have to prevent abuse of the system, because people will not start to travel just to avoid high roaming surcharges.  So fair use policies are, of course, important. As we know, we decided to withdraw this proposal based on daily limits. According to Eurostat, just 0.1% of all trips last longer than 92 days. So practically, financially in real life this is not an issue, and it was not an issue. We have made new proposals based on residency, and I think they are better proposals. But we have to deal with wholesale prices. Today, I still think EUR 50 for one gigabyte is too much. It is too much, and even the proposal we made from the European Commission – EUR 8.50 per gigabyte – still leaves space to decrease wholesale prices.  We have to find a good compromise which allows us to protect those investments made in southern countries to provide services to tourists and also to protect those consumers in Scandinavian countries, for example, who love those generous offers with really affordable prices. So – as I said – I am sorry to say that is not yet a done deal. The European Commission, Member States and the European Parliament have to work together to find the right balance, and we have to be keep our promises. We have to abolish roaming surcharges in the European Union. I am looking forward to a fruitful cooperation with you.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The digitization of our lives is an unquestionable and unstoppable reality. Europe's digital future does not wait: it must be faced now so that Europeans can make the most of their opportunities. And that requires clear and fair rules. He demands that when we travel we do not fear exorbitant invoices. The new proposal on fair use of roaming, while it needs to be improved on privacy issues and the company-user relationship, is going in the right direction. But it also requires guarantees for everyone's internet access, a balanced playing field, where the same services are subject to the same rules and greater coordination in the key element for our mobile communications: spectrum. I believe that the revision of the telecommunications code is a step forward that will help achieve these objectives. But we must not forget the calls between Member States. This time, yes, we must take this opportunity to end abusive prices and a barrier to unbecoming communications and the single market of the time we live in.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. - The European Parliament is very suspicious of the EC's proposal. The items by which the operator has the right to turn off free roaming are quite imprecise. It leaves the possibility for the operator to start charging a higher roaming price without the user having the opportunity to explain their side of the story. The phone bill is one of the most important monthly expenditures of our citizens and we must not leave them at the mercy of operators.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The abolition of roaming charges is undoubtedly one of the great successes of the European Union, which in a tangible way allows Europeans to feel the benefits of membership of the Community. In view of the growing wave of populism and Euroscepticism, such in-kind evidence of the positive impact of the Union is undoubtedly very necessary for us. I therefore believe that we must do everything to ensure that the abolition of roaming is a de facto abolition of roaming, not an artificial passing on of costs from people using phones abroad to other mobile users. Such a potential situation could be interpreted as a sign of the shaming of EU action and the weakness of its institutions, and we cannot afford to do so. I therefore believe that we should take decisive steps to prevent this kind of action on the part of mobile operators.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, high-quality and accessible connectivity for both citizens and European business is essential for realising the full potential of the Digital Single Market. I am convinced that in the long term it is for the benefit of all stakeholders to achieve our ultimate goal – a single market for services in the telecommunications sector. To achieve this, we need comprehensive work by strengthening interinstitutional cooperation to strike the right balance to tackle fragmentation in the European Union and keeping the promise to European citizens to abolish roaming charges in the EU.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. "In the eyes of citizens, the two most tangible advantages of the European Union are the promise of erasmus scholarships for our children and roaming-free telephony and internet access in Europe. In recent weeks, the European Commission has rightly recognised that the eyes of the People of Europe cannot be spotted by not paying roaming for 'only' 90 days a year and imposing a maximum charge on other days. The European Commission is in the interest of European citizens when it ruthlessly shuts down roaming. In a Europe without borders, roaming charges are not recratic. In agreement with the Commission, we are of the view that roaming charges are a significant burden on users and that there is no alternative to the decision to deresist. We accept nothing less than the complete elimination of roaming charges without restrictions! In the coming months, it is up to the European Parliament to ensure that mobile operators do not charge more for foreign telephony than domestic calls. In this spirit, we will continue to do our work!

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The end of roaming tariffs is close. Nevertheless there are still unfortunately some that expect it to fail. We will make sure in the European Parliament that the barriers to intra-European communication will disappear. Millions of Europeans are travelling across Europe every year and hundreds of thousands now live in another European country and they are entitled to fair tariffs and use of their telecommunications tools. Therefore I openly criticise the Commission for leaking in the media the possibility of restricting the free roaming period. Such things should never happen in the future because they affect our work and our credibility as a Union. At the same time with this important change for our citizens we have to continue to invest in the future of European telecommunications – from the introduction of new tools like 5G to the public investments in infrastructure.
