name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – The proposal recently made by the European Commission concerns the use of mobile services for mobile operators' customers when travelling abroad, another country of the European Union. The current proposal is in the right direction, but I strongly believe that it should be an occasion for measures to set a cap on mobile pay that is in line with the purchasing power of citizens.  A recent report was published according to which users of prepaid mobile services in my country Bulgaria pay some of the highest fees for prepaid mobile services in the world. Is that fair? Roaming tariffs in countries outside the European Union also remain extremely high.  The mechanism ek is currently working on also protects the interest of mobile operators, but can citizens be accused of abuse when national mobile operators charge disproportionate amounts for the use of their services? We must put an end to these forms of looting and abuse of our citizens and introduce rules that do not prevent unprincipled and disproportionate charges seized from them.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on - the oral question to the Council on European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust by Claude Moraes on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O—000092/2016 — B8-0715/2016) (2016/2750(RSP)) and — the oral question to the Commission on European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust by Claude Moraes on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O—000093/2016 — B8-0716/2016) (2016/2750(RSP)).

name: Axel VOSS
text: stellvertr. Author. Mr President, Commissioner Jourova, Representative of the Council, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Thank you both for being here today. Eurojust and the European Public Prosecutor's Office have been negotiating in the Council since 2013, and no general approach has yet been reached on either. The Slovak Presidency is very ambitious and has announced that it will also take decisive steps at the European Public Prosecutor's Office, so that the European Public Prosecutor's Office will also be included in the main agenda item of the JHA Council next week. It appears that the dossier of the European Public Prosecutor's Office is on the right track, and Commissioner Jourova has also repeated on several occasions that the European Public Prosecutor's Office is an absolute priority for her.  However, we in Parliament still have a great many unanswered questions and are pleased that we are taking this time for this joint debate this evening. I would like to apologise to Mrs Matera, because unfortunately she cannot be here today. You, in her capacity as rapporteur for the European Public Prosecutor's Office, and I, in my capacity as rapporteur for Eurojust, have now also worked with S&D, ALDE and the Greens on a joint motion for a resolution, and on this point we are in favour of the following points across all political groups and collectively: we are in favour of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and also of the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. We call on the Council to explain the competences of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, both investigative and indictment powers. We regret that, in the case of disputes between the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the national law enforcement authorities, the final decision does not rest with an independent court such as the Court of Justice of the European Union. We are in favour of the independence of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and, in this context, we are also addressing legal assistance and access to information. We call on the Council to end the negotiations on the PIF Directive. In this context, we also want vat fraud to be included in the scope of the PIF Directive.  We also call on the Commission to give an assessment of the impact on Eurojust of the collegial structure of a public prosecutor's office. We underline the role and importance of Eurojust, and we call on the Council to clearly regulate the relationship between the Eurojust Public Prosecutor's Office and OLAF. Finally, we are also in favour of Eurojust and the Public Prosecutor's Office operating from one location. Organised crime knows no borders, and organised groups and terrorists operate globally. However, offences affecting the EU budget are also cross-border. And cross-border fraud, such as VAT carousel fraud, but also any form of fraud against the EU budget is also a fraud against our citizens. We therefore call on the Council to make decisive efforts to speed up the negotiations, particularly on the European Public Prosecutor's Office.  Nevertheless, there are a lot of unresolved questions for us. In my opinion, the collegial structure of the European Public Prosecutor's Office is completely exaggerated and, in my view, not what the legislator wanted in Article 86 of the Treaty. How does the Council enface the system of the European Public Prosecutor and the 28 representatives? Who is to pay for all this? Where does this money come from? Is this really so necessary? And are we not thereby creating a body which, in its structure, resembles Eurojust, but which in reality is devoted only to one competence, namely fraud against the EU budget? This is an important task, which is also called for by the Treaties under Article 86. Nevertheless, we should also leave the church in the village here – it would be as if we in the European Parliament also had 28 deputies of our President of Parliament, which would then be like a Commission, and that will be a very expensive undertaking.  Nor do I want to undermine the importance of the rapid creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. However, we must also realise that we should not achieve something that creates additional bureaucracy or unnecessary bureaucracy. That is why the Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust should also operate in one place and under one roof, and that is probably the will of the legislator in Article 86.  Eurojust has seen an increase in the number of cases – cybercrime, terrorism, the migration crisis – and at the same time, jobs are to be cut or the budget to shrink. This does not really fit with the current requirements.  Which one are the exact effects to be expected for Eurojust? What is the financial impact of the creation of the Public Prosecutor's Office on Eurojust? What does this mean for staff? How many jobs should be cut? What does this mean for infrastructure? What is the operation between Eurojust and the Public Prosecutor's Office? And what I really attach particular importance to is that we will have a very clear procedure – and not duplicate structures or competences in cooperation with the European Public Prosecutor's Office with Eurojust and Europol.  What will happen to OLAF in this context? What should be the cooperation with the national public prosecutors? How should cooperation with national tax authorities be organised? What are the powers of law enforcement when the perpetrator or perpetrator commits several crimes at different times? And what are the powers when the same acts are committed by several offences at the same time? And how do we deal with it?

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the author of the question rightly reminds us that this proposal has been on the table for quite some time, for three years exactly. I remember when it was placed under the leadership of Madam Reding. It is no surprise that this has been on the table for some time, given the sensitivity of this proposal, because in fact the regulation deals with many complex issues which lie at the heart of the criminal law systems of the Member States. Let me update you on the state of play of our work. After very intensive and constructive work, we have now reached a point where the Member States agree on most of the provisions in the draft Regulation, and it looks possible that negotiations in Council can be concluded in the near future. The Presidency is treating the discussions with the highest priority with the objective of closing the file by the end of the year. In this context, we are ready to work – let me underscore this –very closely with Parliament.  Let me briefly mention one issue that has been raised in earlier contacts with Parliament and which is very important for all of us, namely the need to ensure that the Office is both independent and efficient. Let me explain in more detail: the current structure of the Office builds on the idea that the College Member of a given Member State will be in charge of investigations and prosecutions in his or her Member State of origin, and will supervise them. This organisation has been chosen mainly for practical reasons, in particular with a view to ensuring the efficiency of the Office. The legal systems and cultures of the Member States still vary to a considerable degree, and it is clear that only a prosecutor with his or her background in a given legal system will be able to know exactly what actions are most appropriate and efficient in that given state.  I can assure you that the Council wishes to ensure that there is no ambiguity on these issues. The Council remains convinced that the structure proposed in the current text fully ensures the independence of each European Prosecutor and of the Office as such. I also believe that the current Council text is, by and large, in line with the main wishes and expectations of Parliament. A detailed picture of the state of play on the draft European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) regulation, containing all the provisions of the regulation that ministers have preliminarily agreed upon, is freely accessible. This draft should be very close to final outcome. However the documents still do not include a number of provisions: on judicial review, cooperation between the EPPO and Eurojust and relations with third countries. These provisions will be included in a new consolidated version, which will hopefully be completed in the coming weeks. The main task of the Presidency is now to ensure that outstanding reservations are resolved and that the few remaining gaps in the text are filled. In other words, the Council is relatively close to an agreement on the full text.  As noted in your question, it is also clear that the EPPO regulation must be made coherent with the Eurojust regulation and with the directive on the protection of the Union’s financial interests or ‘PIF directive’. The Council adopted its general approach on the Eurojust regulation in March last year and is ready to start negotiations with Parliament at any time. Certain provisions need to be coordinated with the EPPO regulation, but we do not foresee major difficulties. The Council agrees with the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) that it would be useful to ensure that the PIF directive is adopted before or at least around the time of adoption of the regulation. The negotiations on the PIF directive have been on hold since last year, but I am confident that the Council and Parliament will find a compromise solution in the near future. As regards the financial analysis, the Commission is studying this important but complex issue, and it is likely that the Commissioner is better placed to reply to this question. From the point of view of the Council, I would like to underline that it is generally agreed that Eurojust must continue to have sufficient resources to fulfil its tasks in an efficient manner. The EPPO regulation should, for this reason, a priori not have any significant impact on the Eurojust budget.  Finally, the exact nature of the operational, organisational and administrative links between the EPPO and Eurojust is one of the last issues which are still under discussion in the Council. The Council is working on a model according to which the EPPO may rely on the support and resources of the administration of Eurojust, and where Eurojust will provide certain services to the EPPO. Whether there is a need to define these services, or if this could be left to the two bodies, is still under discussion.  It is thus still too early to give a detailed account of the links between the EPPO and Eurojust. We will come back to you with a more precise reply in the coming months. Let me however assure you that our aim is to ensure that the bodies complement each other, and that there is no duplication of work. The creation of the EPPO must not lead to any weakening of Eurojust.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, as we all know, we face some crucial challenges in Europe in the area of security, but also regarding our prosperity.  We have a problem because crime does not know borders, as Mr Voss said before. This goes for big scope crime against EU money, including big cross—border VAT fraud. Crime is harming our economies and decreasing taxpayers’ trust. It is our duty to fight against this crime, which can be done only by joining forces. I am speaking about a pan-European issue that cannot be resolved by national authorities only. As you may know, Eurojust and OLAF are not equipped to lead criminal investigations and prosecutions, and national authorities are facing limits in addressing fraud cases, either for political or resources reasons. That is why I see the European Public Prosecutor as a specialised body dealing with financial crime in the EU, having the necessary competence to investigate and prosecute. We need a European Public Prosecutor to deal with the alleged fraud cases we all read about in some cohesion countries, but we also need it to tackle the big VAT fraud cases, especially in the cross-border context – our very conservative estimation is around EUR 50 billion in revenues lost every year due to VAT fraud, and the real figure is probably much higher. We need an effective answer to these negative impacts on the EU budget, but also on national budgets.  So, where are we on this? I know, replying to questions one and two, we are – as you also heard from the Presidency – in the final stages of our negotiations, and the Commission fully supports the efforts of the Slovak Presidency to achieve a political deal on this by the end of this year. We are hopeful that the Council will be able to finalise the remaining chapters of the proposal for a regulation on the establishment of the EPPO, in particular the provisions on the judicial control of the Office and on relations with third countries and international organisations, with non-participating Member States and relations with Eurojust, in October. Provisions with respect to staff matters relating to the setting—up of the EPPO would also need to be added. At the Justice and Home Affairs Council on 14 October, the Slovak Presidency will present a complete consolidated text to seek the conceptual support of the Council on the revised provisions.  From the perspective of the Commission, the current Council text should still be improved on several points. Two should be highlighted in particular at this stage. The first one relates to competence. The priority competence of the EPPO on cases of fraud affecting the Union’s financial interests demands that the EPPO have access to information on all PIF cases. The EPPO needs to have competence to fight at least serious cross-border VAT fraud. Also, the rules on ancillary competence must not lead to a restriction of the EPPO’s core competence in the PIF area.  The second point is on efficiency, because the efficiency of the EPPO requires a flexible mechanism to redistribute work at central level between the European prosecutors, even if the general principle that European prosecutors supervise cases being handled in their respective Member States is maintained. As already stated on numerous previous occasions, the EPPO can only be launched with confidence if we streamline the rules concerning its competence, and strengthen the guarantees of independence, as well as the provisions on procedural rights. In addition, given that its material competence is defined by reference to the PIF Directive, finalising the directive is essential for setting up the EPPO.  Now let me reply to questions three and four. The EPPO, as a specialised body for financial crime, is to be seen as part of our overall structure in the European Union to combat crime effectively. Since Eurojust will no longer work on financial crimes against the EU budget (so-called ‘PIF cases’), it will be able to focus on the fight against terrorist threats or other crimes such as trafficking, drugs, and in our cooperation with neighbouring countries. In accordance with Article 31 of the Financial Regulation, the Commission’s services undertook an analysis of the financial impact of the changed EPPO structure and competence following the Council compromises. This paper, with initial working estimates, will be shared with you in parallel with Ministers, at the Justice and Home Affairs Council on 14 October. This estimate also takes into account the synergies and the future relationship between the EPPO and Eurojust. The Council model chosen for the EPPO, based on governance by a College, will create the need for new posts in the EPPO’s central office, but as a result of the EPPO’s shared, rather than exclusive, competence it will overall lead to a reduction of posts at central level when compared to the original Commission proposal. This will have an impact on costs. The cost implications of European delegated prosecutors (so-called EDPs) are still under discussion. It depends on how many EDPs will be appointed by the Member States. As regards benefits, the Commission expects that the inclusion of VAT fraud into the EPPO’s competence will bring considerable benefits in comparison to today’s situation where especially large intra-Community VAT fraud cases often remain undetected or are not followed up effectively. As regards the involvement of national parliaments, the Council supports the approach proposed by the Commission whereby the European Chief Prosecutor or one of the deputies may be requested to appear before national parliaments to give account of the general activities of the EPPO. Such appearances should be without prejudice to the EPPO’s obligation of discretion and confidentiality as regards individual cases and personal data.  Axel Voss raised a lot of other questions here, and I can confirm what you also heard from the Minister that we are ready to come back between October and December, when we will go through a decisive period for the final version of EPPO and reply to all your questions, both regarding the text and regarding the relation between the EPPO, Eurojust and OLAF, and all the other practical matters, especially the financial conditions. I only wanted to declare here today that we are working on the cost—benefit conditions for the EPPO, with full regard and full respect to the value of money, which means that we need to do the right thing, to do it in the right way, and to do it for the least possible money. So this is our aim, and that is also why we are working now on a very precise financial analysis.  As for Eurojust, I am not someone who would like to establish a new body for combating serious crime in Europe by devastating the other one. I see the clear picture of combating crime in Europe, standing on three very strong legs: one is OLAF, which has to continue its work; the second is Eurojust, which should focus more on crimes other than financial crime; and the third is the EPPO, with full prosecuting competence. I believe that for the near future, from 2019 we will be able to do this reorganisation so that we will be able at European level to address all of the serious crime which the Member States cannot investigate and prosecute efficiently. It is all about this. We are not replacing here the prosecution at national level; we are setting up a layer above it so that we are jointly more successful.  Finally, let me thank Madam Viviane Reding, who is the mother of the proposal, for giving me the chance to continue what she started. I can only declare here that I will try to be a good stepmother to this proposal and I will do my best to push it to a successful result.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Somehow I feel like I'm in the movie "And every day the marmot salutes". Why? Because every year the Commission states the same thing in its report on the protection of the EU's financial interests, namely that the national authorities only pursue to a limited extent suspected cases against the EU budget sent to them by OLAF. It is unacceptable that these crimes should be insufficiently investigated and that fraudsters should not end up in court. It is therefore right to create a European Public Prosecutor's Office.  However, there can be no free pass for the negotiations in the Council on this European project. The European Public Prosecutor's Office only makes sense if it means real added value for the protection of European taxpayers' money. I would like to mention three points that need to be ensured: firstly, and this also played a role here, there is an inseparable link between the so-called PIF directive and the European Public Prosecutor's Office. The PIF Directive must specify the offences for which the authorities can investigate and prosecute. VAT fraud must, in any case, be included.  Secondly, efficiency must be ensured, and here the division of labour with the national authorities must be clearly regulated. Thirdly, the independence of the European Public Prosecutor's Office must be ensured. Particular attention must be paid to this, particularly in view of the envisaged automatic link between a European Public Prosecutor and cases from his own country of origin.  Only if these and other points are met can we end up saying 'yes' to a European solution that effectively protects European taxpayers' money.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Of course, I am in favour of effective anti-fraud and better use of public funds. Fraud should be investigated with the full cooperation of all Member States.  However, the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, the EPPO, is not the right solution. In addition to OLAF, which is now responsible for combating administrative fraud, we have Eurojust. This agency, which is responsible for judicial cooperation, must also form the basis for the EPPO under Article 86 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  In addition to the unnecessary creation of a third agency, there is also the question of demarcation of competence. The EPPO is responsible for the crimes mentioned in the PIF Directive, but that directive is only a draft law. If the angle and timing of the Commission proposal are completely wrong, we are not doing the right thing. Commissioner Jourová, just do the work again, and this time well.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, 40 years ago the idea of creating a European public prosecutor's office was born. 40 years later, and since 2013, a legislative proposal has been on the table. Today, after three years of negotiations between the States with the Council, what is left on the merits? Three or four points.  First of all, we wanted a European prosecutor's office responsible for serious cross-border crime, transnational crimes, transnational terrorism, because if criminals and crimes have no borders, our investigations and criminal prosecutions should not have them either. This is the popular saying: the gendarmes must have at least the same weapons as the thieves. What's left?  Firstly, a European public prosecutor's office which will only be responsible for the protection of the Union's financial interests. It is true that, in the current context, with the increase in serious organized crime and criminal networks, it was time to limit the powers of such a prosecutor's office. Secondly, a European Prosecutor's Office, moreover, is limited within this competence to combat fraud against the Union's financial interests, since the Council has introduced limiting thresholds. Thus, in the case of co-financing, if the Union does not contribute more than 50% of the amount invested, the prosecutor's office will not be competent. However, everyone knows, especially in the European institutions, that the Union mostly funds projects at less than 50%. Thirdly, an incompetent European prosecutor's office where fraud is linked to another form of crime, such as trafficking or money laundering. Fourthly, a European public prosecutor's office with no jurisdiction over VAT fraud, Commissioner, you have pointed out the principle and you have pointed out the estimated shortfall that this represents, since the Council refuses to include VAT in the directive on the protection of the Union's financial interests. This is a border fraud par excellence.  Secondly, and it is obvious, we want an independent European public prosecutor's office that can conduct its investigations and investigations independently of national interests. What's left here, too? A European prosecutor's office whose structure will be decentralized, a prosecutor's office with a complex organisation tied up by the omnipresence of the national link, a prosecutor's office that will not be competent as a last resort, since in the event of conflicts of division of powers between a national authority and the prosecutor's office, it is the national authority that will decide as a last resort.  Commissioner, the outcome of the negotiations in the Council is simply worrying. The Council has dissected the original proposal and has stripped it of its meaning, that of a European prosecutor's office that is strong, ambitious, effective and, above all, independent. Many of us in this house question the added value of this parquet. The competency chapters should absolutely be reopened.  To conclude, Parliament's approval of the floor is not a given. Yes, we are in for the establishment of a European public prosecutor's office, but not at any price.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. About seven years ago, the Treaty of Lisbon provided for the first legal basis for the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office. Many years have passed since then – and we have just heard it – many years of negotiation.  We have had a special committee here in this House to combat organised crime, money laundering and corruption, in which it has become abundantly clear how important it is for an independent European Public Prosecutor's Office to investigate these crimes across borders, and that is why it is good that the Presidency is now taking this into its own hands and that we seem to be on the last few metres to reach an agreement.  But there are still a few unanswered questions, and I would like to add a few: how many Member States will be there in the end? It will be important that as many Member States as possible actually participate in this European Public Prosecutor's Office. It is not acceptable that all the Member States have been calling for cooperation and coordination in recent times, but that in the end no one wants to be coordinated by such a joint public prosecutor. This must be made clear, and we must also put a little emphasis on the fact that everyone is there.  And how far does the scope of application go? I believe it has become clear here that the European Parliament is clearly in favour of the large-scale VAT fraud being included in the scope. I believe it is important that this should now be regulated again.  Finally, it is important that we continue to create common minimum standards in criminal proceedings. We also need procedural standards in cooperation with national law enforcement authorities.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this resolution calls for the Commission to get on with the job of installing the European Public Prosecutor. The UK supposedly has an opt-out from the jurisdiction of the Public Prosecutor, but this is effectively worthless. The Prosecutor could easily bypass the UK’s opt—out by using the legal instruments and institutions that the UK has already subjected itself to through the auspices of the Member States. Unsurprisingly enough, that brings me onto the subject of Brexit. When the UK leaves the EU, we must repeal all the legal instruments we have enacted, such as the European Arrest Warrant, and withdraw from legal institutions such as Eurojust. We must replace them with genuine cooperative measures such as those that existed before, for example the European Convention on Extradition and Interpol – but all suitably revised, of course, to ensure that the protection of the rights of British citizens under our own law is the priority.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the idea of creating a European public prosecutor's office is just twenty years old, but it has caused so much concern that it has not been successful. However, the Brussels Commission has been trying since 2013 to revive the project. Surprisingly, the Slovak Presidency is now flying to its rescue. I am resolutely opposed to the creation of a European public prosecutor's office. Criminal justice is, and must remain, a prerogative of states. In France, it is returned in the name of the French people. This view is opposed to it being transferred, even in part, to a bureaucratic and undemocratic monster. In criminal justice, it is simple cooperation that European states need, not integration. Like me, the French Senate has denounced this project as too centralizing. He rightly believes that he is in breach of the principle of subsidiarity. But in my opinion, the principle of subsidiarity is a decoy. For the Union, as Philippe Séguin said, it is not a legal principle, but a principle of efficiency that it uses to do what it wants, when it wants. The main thing is said, the rest is secondary. The rest is the parliamentary question that asks when the European public prosecutor's office will be created. I have an answer that corresponds to my wish: never.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his work Come on! I would like to expressly encourage the Slovak Presidency, as rapporteur, together with Mr Aguilar, for the PIF directive, to come to an end. Since July 2015, we have been waiting for the Council to finally agree on something. Just courage, we count on you! We need this. We finally need better justice in this material domain, and I believe that what is on the table is very balanced. We want VAT – and this is the real sticking point – to be included in the scope of the directive. Cases involving at least two countries involving at least EUR 100 000 of damage or even when EU officials or members of the institutions are affected.  We believe that Europe is taking a quantum leap forward, and we are also very attached to Commissioner Jourova that, as a 'stepmother', she takes up and promotes this important dossier. We would like to strongly encourage you: give real added value to this Europe and do not listen to the margins in this Parliament, which do not know what they are doing and do not know what they are talking about. We saw that again very impressively tonight. We need the European Public Prosecutor, and we need a sensible PIF directive, because that is the only way to achieve a real fight against crime. We cannot live with organised crime exploiting and continuing to exploit and exploit the legal loopholes in the common market.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, Mrs Grule said: of course I support the launch of a European Public Prosecutor's Office on the legal basis of Article 86 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I supported her as Minister of Justice of the Government of Spain and as Chairman of the Committee on Freedoms, Justice and Interior. But, before and most urgent, it is still that this Parliament should act as a criminal legislator on the basis of Article 83, which allows Parliament to criminally legislate against cross-border attacks on the Union's financial interests and, in particular, VAT fraud, which imports billionaire amounts, because this is a pre-content step to be taken by the European Public Prosecutor's Office , and it turns out that it is blocked by the Council. I call on the Commission to undertake, as guardian of the Treaties, to fill this role of the European Parliament as a criminal legislator; to unlock the Union's Directive on the protection of financial interests, because that is the first step for the European Public Prosecutor's Office to be able, independently and with an adequate resource system and in cooperation with national jurisdictions, to do what it has to do: first, to protect the Union's financial interests by unlocking the PIF Directive.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Extremeism is the enemy of the good. I do not accept those voices that urge the Presidency to build a centralised prosecutor's office, which is not refecting states. We just need time, sensitivity and common consent on this issue. So I can't agree with what the S&D and ALDE representatives have said here. If a public prosecutor's office is established, it is as a collegial structure and cooperating with the states. I would therefore like to appreciate the presidency's efforts in this area. There is, of course, also the sensitive issue of the shape of the PIF Directive. It is not obvious that VAT fraud is to be in the European domain, especially since in 90% of cases it is the countries that are affected by these frauds. In any case, I call for rationality and consent with a sense of shared trust and to give the Presidency time to complete this work.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Sur President, aħna għandna bżonn uffi大大ju ta' prosekutur li jiffunzjona b'mod tajjeb u li jagħti risposta adegwata għall-ammont enormi ta' frodi li aħna qed naraw fl-Unjoni Ewropea. I大-大ittadini tagħna għandhom bżonn u jridu jaraw li din issir realtà. Kull sena, kważi nofs biljun euro jintilfu. Dawn mhumiex figuri żgħar. U aħna għalhekk qegħdin insejħu flower-Kunsill biex jipprovdilna sett ta' kompetenzi li huma ħari u li mhumiex ambigwi għal dan l-uffiħħjuju. Fl-istess ħin, aħna rridu niżguraw li r-relazzjonijiet bejn il-Eurojust u l-Olaf humaħħħalli nkunu nistgħu naraw id-differenzi ħari bejn ir-rwoli differenti ta' dawn l-organizzazzjonijiet fil-protezz tal-interessi finanzjijar tal-Un Ewjonipearo. Iktar minn hekk, aħna ninsistu li l-uffi大大ju tal-prosekutur għandu jkollu miżuri su大ffijenti investigattivi biex ikun jista' jagħmel ir-rwoli tiegħu proprju għal dawn l-investigazzjonijiet. Fl-aħħar minn l-aħħar, irridu nagħtu lil dan l-uffiħħju l-għodod adegwati biex ikun jista' jagħmel xogħlu. Madankollu, jiena naf li għad hemm affarijiet li rridu niżguraw u nkunu żguri minnhom, pereżempju issues li jmissu s-sovranità u l-kompetenza tal-Istati Membri. Huwa ikear, fl-opinjoni tiegħi, li l-awtoritajiet nazzjonali u l-uffi大ikeju tal-prosekutur għandhom ikollhom numru ta' kompetenzi li huma kumpliment jewari maqsuma fu reqati partikolari.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: – Mr President, from experience, in the Committee on Budgetary Control we have long called for the creation of this European Public Prosecutor's Office which I would have liked to have been stronger, more European and unequivocal. But before we continue to accumulate delays, we prefer to welcome this Regulation which epitomizes a fundamental pillar in order to be able to develop European criminal law and thus tackle increasingly transnational and cross-border criminality in all its forms.  We encourage the Council and the Commission to provide this Public Prosecutor's Office with real and sufficient means so that this Regulation is not reduced, once again, to a layer added to national laws and prosecutors' offices, which will continue to be able to impose limits and obstacles. We also welcome the enhanced cooperation with Eurojust, but we need and demand that the mandate of this Public Prosecutor's Office be broadly and definitively defined in the PIF Directive, which is the framework for guarantees which gives capacity and participation to the democratic body, however important this Parliament is.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, this Parliament has long been advocating the need for the European Union to have the means to sanction cross-border crimes, particularly those which are in the interests of the Union.  In 2014 alone almost €160 billion in VAT revenues was lost. I am sure that the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office is a plan that we all recognise as desirable. However, it already tells the popular wisdom that the devil is in the details. And here there remains disagreement and inertia when we need, on the contrary, rapid action and a clear position. A clear position on the powers of the Public Prosecutor's Office. A clear position on the relationship with Eurojust. A clear position on the structure of the Public Prosecutor's Office that guarantees international best practices, such as its independence. A clear position on procedural rights. A clear position on the judicial review to which it would be subject. This Parliament has already made its position very clear and will do so again through the resolution we will adopt. I believe that the European Public Prosecutor's Office should soon become a reality, respecting the constitutional traditions of the Member States and the highest international standards. And Parliament must continue to act in this direction. If it is certain that the establishment of this Public Prosecutor's Office cannot be done in any way and at any cost, the cost of its non-existence seems increasingly incomprehensible.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by expressing the hope that this evening's debate will really help to give impetus to the negotiations on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which has been dragging on for too long.  I am aware of the difficulties in formulating the text, but we must look at the final objective, effectively combat crimes against the interests of the Union which, as we have said, transcend national borders and against which only a person truly independent of the national authorities and the institutions of the Union will be able to achieve adequate results. A person with primary competence to investigate and prosecute offences under the PIF Directive, including those relating to VAT. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, a body specialising in combating financial crimes against the interests of the Union, without overlapping competences with Eurojust and Olaf, with adequate resources and with cooperation from the Member States that goes beyond the logic of cooperation alone, is an ambitious project that must, however, be implemented in order to adequately protect the Financial Interests of the Union.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, fraud against the financial interests of the EU and our taxpayers, including big VAT fraud, amounts to tens of billions of euros each year. In order to be able to detect and prosecute such crimes, it is clear that we need to build a strong, independent and efficient EPPO that is equipped with sufficient investigative probe powers. In this process, it is vital that the competences of the various related European institutions are clear. We need to ensure that Eurojust, EPPO and OLAF do not duplicate work and do not step on each other’s toes, but form a coherent wall in the fight against fraud. A good division of competences could also free Eurojust from the work it currently does in this field and allow it to concentrate on other crucial criminal areas such as the fight against terrorism and other threats.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I have stressed many times in this Chamber the importance of combating economic crime, tax evasion and tax avoidance within the European Union. It is truly infuriating when tax policies are imposed on Greece, the same people who impose this policy turn a blind eye to the operation of tax havens within the European Union, tax havens that they earn from the tax evasion of Greece and the other countries of the South.  Why is OLAF, when it is set up to combat corruption and fraud within the Member States, doing nothing to help this work? Why is the Commission doing nothing to better protect whistleblowers, people who are currently threatened with prison sentences in Luxembourg? So why should citizens trust the European Public Prosecutor's Office in the European Union, now that it is trying to get its hands on economic crime cases that have so far fall within the scope of national authorities' responsibility? These are important questions, Mr President.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have here some very short concluding remarks but I cannot resist, I would like to react to some of your questions and comments.  Why are we establishing an EPPO which needs to have clear added-value? We see the statistics of OLAF: on average only about 40% of the recommendations of OLAF are sent to the Member States with a clear purpose: investigate and prosecute. We have been saying for years: what can we do? The Member States do not prosecute and we cannot remain helpless. We must act here. I am not criticising any specific Member State, but this is the general situation.  VAT: yes, it must be included in PIF and the EPPO because, besides the many arguments which you have set out here, we have also case law. We have the case which clearly stipulates that VAT is a source for the financial budget.  With regards to VAT, believe me, it is not easy to push the EPPO towards its final adoption because we needed to open the second line of negotiations vis-a-vis the ministers of finance and vis-a-vis the tax authorities, because we will need also all these authorities to be on our side. Then, especially, when the EPPO is working fully, we will need not only national prosecutors, but also the police, tax authorities – and whistle-blowers – to cooperate with the EPPO. We will need the cooperation of a very wide and complex puzzle of institutions at the Member States’ level. So that is why we need to do this right and in a convincing way so that it will bring real added value.  This added value can be, and must be, measured by finance. Of course these are the benefits which we speak about: the money which will one day be brought back to national budgets and the EU budget. We are working on setting up the proper threshold for structural funds and agricultural funds and customs: at the moment this is EUR 10 000, but we will continue to discuss this. For VAT it should be really only a big scope of fraud, so we speak about three or five million euro for cross-border VAT fraud. I want to have the EPPO doing big things. It should not be established, as I said before, to replace national prosecution; it must do only big things creating big benefits. Yes, we need unanimity in the Council. So this will need a very strong push in regard to several Member States. For me it is clear that the cohesion countries, especially, must be there because it would not be logically if we established the EPPO to prosecute fraud on EU funds without having some of the Member States which receive the money, which receive more than they contribute. So here I have had, along with my colleagues, a lot of work in some of the Member States. The final point: speaking about the benefits. I spoke about the financial benefits, but here we must be fully aware that it is the thrust of the people in Europe, taxpayers, at stake.  I am always absolutely frustrated when I hear the critics, and I read the articles of the critics of the EU, who say that structural funds are only a source for fraud and corruption. Where is all that ethos? This is the policy of solidarity. The rich countries are contributing money to the poorer countries and the critics say it is only there to be stolen and cheated on, and all those benefits, all those good projects, all the jobs and all that prosperity, which has been created over years thanks to this money, is forgotten.  I think that we need to act here and to show taxpayers and all those critics that yes, this is the distribution of massive amounts of money, but the money is well managed and controlled. It is our duty to act, and to create the EPPO as a really strong, competent and functioning European body.  We have three decisive months ahead of us and I count on your support so that we will manage first the negotiations in the Council and also the consent in Parliament to be achieved in a reasonably short time.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for all the interventions and statements made which, in my view, clearly show the importance they attach to the establishment of EPPO. At the same time, we have heard you highlight many aspects that we need to address in the remaining period of negotiations during the Slovak Presidency.  I would like to make just two points here in my concluding remarks. First of all, it is clear to the Presidency that we need to ensure that outstanding reservations are lifted in the period remaining and that the gaps in the text must be addressed properly. I dare say that we are close to finalising the text and getting an agreement on it. We will, of course, include some of the outstanding provisions, like judicial review cooperation between EPPO and Eurojust, in the new consolidated version. Second, as many of you have indicated, it is vital that the EPPO Regulation be made coherent with the Eurojust Regulation and with the PIF Directive. It is clear that we need to make progress on this because the PIF Directive should contain the substantive law to be applied by EPPO. So that message is well taken, Mrs Gräßle, and the Presidency will try to address it in the remaining period. I wish to thank Members once again and look forward to further cooperation.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: At the end of the debate, a motion for a resolution supported by four groups in the House was tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 5 October 2016. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. Yesterday, the Committee on Civil Rights, Human Rights, Common Security and Consumer Policy voted on the report on combating organised crime and corruption, which have a major impact on fraud against the financial interests of the European Union. In this report, too, there has been repeated calls for an independent European Public Prosecutor's Office capable of investigating, prosecuting and prosecuting offenders, and the need for a clear definition of its powers and procedures has been stressed. We therefore hope that the PIF directive will be adopted as soon as possible so that we can clearly know the type of crime that the Public Prosecutor's Office will be competent to deal with.  The considerable ability of criminal groups to build international relations, to branch out to different Member States and to give a seemingly legal form to their activities leads us once again to highlight the importance of extending, as provided for in Article 86 TFEI, the powers of the European Public Prosecutor's Office to combat other forms of serious crime, including mafia-type crime, which have a transnational dimension.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – In forming the European Public Prosecutor's Office, the Council has already sufficiently watered down the original Commission proposal by creating a College of Prosecutors, increasing the powers of national prosecutors and weakening the EPPO's powers. However, there are a few things that, in my view, neither the Commission nor Parliament can allow: We cannot allow the European Public Prosecutor's Office to look only at cases which national prosecutors consider to fall within the eppo's remit, but must see all cases in order to examine their actual affiliation with competence. Vat must in any event remain in the Union's Financial Interests Protection (PIF) Directive, thereby falling within the remit of the General Prosecutor's Office. Therefore, it should not be allowed for the Public Prosecutor's Office to have jurisdiction only if the EU is concerned above 50%, since the European impact of VAT is necessarily below that threshold. Vat, recognised by the Court of Justice, is the Union's own financial resource and, as such, must be able to be substantially protected, especially if the system of cross-border VAT fraud is popular in many EU countries and cannot or is not effectively detected by the authorities of the Member States. Without these being fulfilled, the Commission should withdraw its proposal and, where appropriate, consider giving appropriate powers to the European Union Anti-Fraud Office instead of a public prosecutor' office.

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. – An effective fight at European level against misuse of European funds requires effective measures, again at European level, to strengthen cooperation between Member States in this field. More importantly, it is important to ensure that political and economic circles do not influence investigations and cases of such abuses. For this reason, building a strong, independent and active European Public Prosecutor's Office is extremely important.  I believe that it must have broad and clear powers and competences, including in the fight against VAT fraud, and ensure its independence from national prosecutions. At the same time, the procedural rights of suspects and accused persons need to be protected, because this is still at the heart of any democratic and lawful investigation. I believe that the European Public Prosecutor's Office will contribute to strengthening the fight against fraud by European funds in Bulgaria as well. This will help make more money to the people who really need them to develop entrepreneurship, agriculture, innovation.  Therefore, for the sake of European and Bulgarian prosperity, I call on the Member States to reach an agreement and accept the proposal for a European Public Prosecutor's Office within the Council because the EU needs it.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. – When establishing any new office, it is very important to establish its competences and, above all, its relations with existing structures. However, this has not happened in the case of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and to date many questions remain unanswered. It is therefore necessary for the European Commission to clarify not only the links between that office, Eurojust and OLAF, but also to assess the impact that the new office will have on other agencies. Its financial entitlements will certainly be reflected in Eurojust's budget, just as its activities will have a major impact on Eurojust's own activities. It is therefore necessary to establish as soon as possible an effective framework for the activities and links of the new European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I note with appreciation the progress of the legislative work in the Council, which recently adopted the full consolidated text of the draft regulation on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. The establishment of this agency will be the culmination of many years of debate and efforts by the European Parliament and the Commission to equip the European Union with the powers of criminal law to protect its own budgetary interests. However, before the Public Prosecutor's Office starts operating, there are currently a number of problematic issues that need to be resolved. First of all, it is necessary to adopt a new PIF Directive which clarifies the substantive competence of the Public Prosecutor's Office. It seems that the important dilemmas that have arised during the legislative work in the Council (adequate legal basis, vat issue) and have blocked this process have been decided by the Court of Justice in taricco. It is also necessary to complete the reform of eurojust's judicial cooperation body in criminal matters, with which the Public Prosecutor's Office is to be closely linked under the Treaty. Thanks to the recently adopted EP-Council Regulation on Europol, the Public Prosecutor's Office will have important support for the exchange of operational information. These are the boundary conditions for the Council to proceed to the final stage of the creation of the Public Prosecutor's Office, which, as we know today, will operate in a stripped-down format of enhanced cooperation.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on "International Accounting Standards: IFRS 9" by Roberto Gualtieri on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (O-000115/2016 - B8-0721/2016) (2016/2898(RSP)).

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: deputising for the author. – Mr President, the global financial crisis brought the role played by international financial reporting standards in financial stability and growth on to the G20 and EU agendas. In particular, the rules regarding the recognition of losses incurred in the banking system. In July 2014, the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) issued the international financial reporting standard IFRS 9 (Financial Instruments), addressing some aspects of the financial crisis and its impact on the banking sector, as its key response.  In early 2016, the Commission referred the draft implementing measure for international financial reporting standards (financial instruments) to Parliament for scrutiny. On 7 October 2016, the three-month scrutiny period for this important financial reporting standard will end.  The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) had started its scrutiny activities already well before this official referral of the measure by the Commission. These activities have been conducted very thoroughly. The activities included the commissioning of four external studies on IFRS 9 and public scrutiny events during ECON Committee time, for example, a public hearing. In addition, the newly established IFRS permanent team conducted several meetings on this issue. The International Accounting Standards Board, the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group, the Commission and the stakeholders have been invited for an exchange of views on IFRS 9. On 7 June 2016, Parliament adopted a resolution on International Accounting Standards evaluation and the activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation, the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group and the Public Interest Oversight Board, which also addressed some of the issues.  In addition, the ECON Committee had already written in January 2016 a letter to the Chair of the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB) expressing its concern about the lack of reliable quantitative data assessment. The impact of the introduction of IFRS 9 on financial instability in general, and on the amount of loan loss provisioning and banks regulation capital in particular, is of especial concern to the Committee. The Committee requested further analysis from the ESRB of the impact of IFRS 9, especially on financial stability. Another letter was written by the ECON Committee to the Commission in June 2016 addressing additional concerns. These related to possible negative effects of the implementation of IFRS 9 on crucial long-term investment and on the misalignment of the effective dates of IFRS 9 and the upcoming new insurance standard IFRS 17, which will replace the current insurance standard IFRS 4. In this regard the IASB published in September 2016 amendments to IFRS 4, addressing some concerns regarding the insurance issue.  This oral question on IFRS 9 to the Commission and the motion for a resolution which will be voted on on Thursday, reflect the various concerns which Parliament and the ECON Committee have brought forward during its scrutiny activities.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission believes that sound financial reporting is vital for the efficient functioning of its capital markets. Investors and other users of financial information must be able to rely on it. We do not develop the standards ourselves but use those developed by the International Accounting Standards Board. It is for this reason that we have a rigorous endorsement process to test each standard to determine whether it should be adopted into EU law. The scrutiny period by Parliament is an important part of this process. International Reporting Standard 9 is an important standard for financial services companies and governs the accounting for most assets and liabilities on bank balance sheets. It is for this reason that we are here today.  The financial crisis showed that financial accounting has economic consequences. The G20 called on the Standards Board to develop a new approach to accounting for losses on lending so as to avoid reporting too little, too late and the new standard achieves this fundamental change. We assess whether a standard will be conducive to the European public good. For this reason we asked the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group, our adviser on the reporting standard, to consider a number of areas of concern in developing its endorsement advice. Your question reflects some of these areas. First, we wanted to understand its effects on long—term investment. The European Financial Reporting Advisory Group did not expect that Reporting Standard 9 would lead to significant changes in long—term investment strategies, a finding that we recently confirmed. Nevertheless, we will continue to monitor this area carefully and will work with the Advisory Group and the Standards Board to assess whether a change in the standard would be necessary.  Secondly, the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group identified a limitation in the standard for insurance entities. These will face a huge challenge in their accounting for their liabilities relating to their insurance contracts, which will come on board in 2020 or 2021. However, Reporting Standard 9, which covers the accounting for investments backing those liabilities, is effective from 2018. This misalignment of dates could give rise to volatility in reported results, as well as leading to higher costs in implementing the two standards. We therefore support a deferral of Standard 9 for the insurance industry. The International Accounting Standards Board has developed an optional temporary deferral solution which we will propose for endorsement as it will bring relief to most large pure insurance groups in the EU. The solution also includes a form of relief for bank insurers who will not qualify for a full deferral. Most Member States and the European supervisory authorities support this solution. Nevertheless, we are currently considering whether it is satisfactory for Europe as a whole. We are assessing whether the lack of a full deferral could create a significant competitive disadvantage for bank insurers compared to pure insurance groups. If we were to conclude that such risk exists, we would extend the scope of the Standards Board deferral to the bank insurers, taking into consideration that this is a temporary measure. However, we have not yet arrived at this conclusion.  Thirdly, based on the advice of the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group, which drew on input from the European Central Bank and the European supervisory authorities, we believe that Reporting Standard 9 should be an improvement over its predecessor in the area of financial stability. The Commission, together with the European Banking Association and the Basel Committee, is assessing the need for a transitional phasing—in of the prudential capital effects arising from the new impairment model in Reporting Standard 9 so as to prevent a sudden impact on capital ratios when the standard is first applied. I should like to thank you and, in particular, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the International Financial Reporting Standard permanent team under the chairmanship of Mr Stolojan for the detailed and careful consideration of this standard.  In conclusion, we strongly believe that International Financial Reporting Standard 9 should be endorsed, but our work on the standard will not stop with its endorsement. We will be vigilant to avoid any unintended consequences.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, this Standard, financial instruments, has given us a lot of trouble here in the European Parliament. We've had a lot of hearings, we've had a lot of letters from those interested in the banking, insurance industry. What we know very well is that the current standard has allowed banks to report hundreds of billions of dollars or euros in damages with great delay. We have come to the conclusion in this House, in the ECON working group, that the proposed standard, the new standard, is better than the old one, even if it is not perfect. We therefore support the process of adopting the standard in the European Union. We are convinced that it will in particular allow banks to apply a loss recognition policy earlier. At the same time, this resolution to be voted on in the European Parliament on Thursday shows a number of concerns that exist among parliamentarians, but also among those who are to apply this international standard of financial reporting. I thank the European Commission and all my colleagues for their work on this standard.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Commissioner, I thank you for having already, in your opening speech, cleared many of the points of concern to this Parliament. I would also like to thank my colleague Theodor Stolojan, who is very effective and intelligent in leading our working group. The accounting standards developed in the wake of the financial crisis, as you pointed out, were primarily for banks, since the financial crisis revealed the need to strengthen the strength of the global financial system, including through these accounting standards. It was in this spirit, and in line with the conclusions of the G20 in London in April 2009, that accounting regulators worked to replace the IAS 39 standard. It was this reflection that led, in July 2014, to the publication by the IASB of the finalized version of the IFRS 9 accounting standard, which aims to ensure greater transparency on credit risk in financial statements, through an approach to asset impairment that should be more responsive to changes in the credit cycle. THE IFRS 9 standard is initially designed to apply to banking institutions and, as a result, two questions arise: first, in the absence of a real impact study, there are concerns about the potential effects of applying this standard on investment, as it could introduce volatility into accounts unrelated to the economic reality of a long-term lender. In a way, we would like to refer here to the concept of a "public good" as developed by Maystadt in its report. Isn't long-term investment the public good par excellence, especially since we are in this troubled time? Second, we are concerned , as you mentioned , about the impact of this standard on the banking sector—insurance, and we obviously want to continue our work and our intelligence cooperation with EFRAG and its new president.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I welcome the scrutiny of the International Financial Reporting Standard (IFRS) 9, and given the concerns that have been raised, I welcome this short discussion. It is important that measures to represent big changes to the norm, particularly in the financial sector, must be given as much assessment as possible. I very much agree with the principle of what IFRS 9 seeks to achieve, namely to prevent some of the problems that we have encountered in the financial crisis by moving towards a model with banks recognising expected losses and financial assets on the balance sheet. This is a welcome step given that, until now, banks have been unable to book accounting losses until they happened, even if they could see them coming down the line. This could prevent a number of problems.  What concerns me most about the introduction of the IFRS 9, however, is the uncertainty it seems to be generating in the financial sector. It is reported that two-thirds of banks are still unsure how IFRS 9 will affect their balance sheet, and I hope the European Commission can offer some assurances on this issue. Ensuring the same mistakes are not made again is crucial, but there is definitely a need to ensure that unintended negative effects on the economy are avoided, and I welcome the Commissioner’s comments in this regard a few moments ago. Finally, I just want to conclude by saying that the introduction to the IFRS 9 can hopefully find a good solution that allows ample time for the financial sector to adapt to the changes.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, parliament's audit of the Commission's draft implementing measure on the International Financial Reporting Standard 9 will be completed on 7 October 2016. According to the European Union, international financial reporting standards should improve the quality of financial reporting and enable investors to make informed decisions, thereby contributing to the stability of financial markets.  If, however, the audit of the international financial reporting standard 9 shows possible negative effects on long-term investments as well as on financial stability, in particular as regards the downward impact on banks' own funds, the Commission should take immediate measures to re-establish that standard. For this reason, the Commission should work with the competent authorities on international financial reporting standards with a view to achieving financial stability.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their interest in the International Financial Reporting Standard 9 and for the useful elements they have highlighted during its endorsement process. We have found that all the key players in the endorsement process support the standard. Nevertheless, the Commission and others have shared your concerns. Thus, we will continue to work on the areas that you have highlighted with a view to ensuring that the International Financial Reporting Standard 9 delivers the benefits that are expected, as well as ensuring that we avoid any unintended consequences.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure will be published at a later date. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 6 October 2016.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Before concluding the sitting, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the services, the technology and our interpreters. It was a long day for all of us. I wish all of us a good night. (The sitting was closed at 11.20 p.m.)
